column2: The Steamship Office Workers Union broadened its organizational activities yesterday in an apparent effort to frustrate possible competition from a rival union.

NEWARK, Jan. 20 -- A professor at Rutgers University's College of Pharmacy declared here tonight that television advertising of medical products was sometimes dangerous as it might contain distortions or "outright lies."
The National Association of Evangelicals has asked three newspaper organizations to inspect its file of "over 700 documented cases" of persecution of Protestants in Colombia.

A disagreement that continues to trouble the North Atlantic alliance is the still unsettled controversy between Germany and her allies, notably Britain, over a German financial contribution to the support of allied troops stationed in Germany for the common Western defense.
On Jan. 20, 1908, when Joseph G. Osborne went to work at 25 Broad Street for Hayden, Stone Co., Wall Street was just recovering from a short, but severe, depression.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20(AP) -- The Federal Power Commission denied the Pacific Northwest Power Company a license today to build the Mountain Sheep and Pleasant Valley dams on the Snake River.

WILMINGTON, N. C., Jan. 20 -- North Carolina, which wants hunting and fishing tourists, presents an entirely different hunting picture from New York's and New England's. All land, fenced or unfenced, is automatically posted.
THE chemise is no slouch when it comes to wedding plans. As it floated by in coral chiffon at Abraham Straus yesterday, it looked full of honorable intentions.
The Republicans last night let loose a nation-wide broadside of their heaviest artillery against the Democrats.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Ellsworth (Spider) Webb went down for 9-counts in each of the first two rounds tonight, then came back to knock out Rory Calhoun of White Plains, N. Y., in 2:21 of the fourth round.

Leading National League pitchers issued a loud lament over the Dodgers' 250-foot leftfield fence in the Los Angeles Coliseum and blasted what they called a growing tendency in baseball to favor the hitters, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20--Federal laws concerning pension and welfare plans were termed inevitable today at a National Conference on Employe Benefit Plan Legislation.
The gifts off several faithful contributors to the Neediest arrived yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -Howard W. Robison, an Owego (N. Y.) attorney, was sworn in today as the successor to former Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican, from New York State's Thirty-seventh Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -The Senate Banking Committee approved today President Eisenhower's nomination of former Representative Jesse P. Wolcott, a Michigan Republican, for a six-year term as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
A bill to bar sight-seeing buses from parking in the Times Square area will be introduced in the City Council today.
A budget request of $395,674,067 for the fiscal year 1958-59 was announced yesterday by the finance committee of the Board of Education.
A group of bankers, public relations executives, advertising men and business leaders was advised yesterday to cultivate humility before they set out on a goodwill mission to Europe.
James A. Farley, chairman of the board of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation, is in St. Clare's Hospital recovering from a recent fall in which he broke a small bone in his upper left arm.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A union economist asked Congress today for a $100 increase in exemptions from the Federal personal income tax and elimination of "special tax privileges."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -United States inventors were reported today to prefer to deal with industry rather than the defense agencies, which to them mean red tape, indifference and an inadequate return.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The conflict of viewpoints between home builders and land planners, brought about by new highway construction, came into focus today when spokesmen on both sides tried to assign responsibility for creating balanced communities in the nation's suburbs.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell 288,195 shares between mid-December and mid-January, the Exchange reported yesterday.

After a slight upturn last week, steel production is scheduled to decline a bit this week. The American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday that the steel-makers had planned operations at a rate to produce about 1,500,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings this week, compared with actual output of 1,538,000 net tons last week.

The popular grandfather known to the world of pleasure boating as Rosey was honored last night at a National Motor Boat Show adjunct at the WaldorfAstoria. Commodore Morris (Rosey) Rosenfeld of City Island, internationally famed marine photographer, became the recipient of the Ole Evinrude Award for 1958.
The likely position of the Metropolitan Regional Conference on establishing a permanent interstate agency for transit will be shaped at a meeting here Friday.

SOUTH POLE, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Dr. Vivian E. Fuchs said today he was "perfectly happy" that Sir Edmund Hillary had beat him to the South Pole. But he still planned to ignore Sir Edmund's advice and press on with his trans-Antarctic trek.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 20 -- Plans for the fourth annual Debutante Cotillion, to benefit Valley Hospital here, will be advanced at a meeting Thursday in the home of Mrs. Charles E. Eaton, general chairman.

IN the midst of New York's "churlish chiding of the winter's wind," Shakespeare's pastoral comedy "As You Like It" proves warmly reassuring. For, with its background of the Forest of Arden, its orchard, lawn and willowy trees, the classic brings to recollection the greener state of things that cannot be far behind when winter is here.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 4 points (20 cents a bale) lower to 20 points ($1 a bale) higher, with the far months showing the most strength.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 20 (AP) -Carmen Basilio, the middleweight boxing champion, tonight was named the winner of the eighth annual S. Rae Hickok "professional athlete of the year" award.

Syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., are offering for public subscription two issues of public utility securities -- $8,500,000 of mortgage bonds of West Texas Utilities Company and $4,500,000 of long-term notes of Cambridge Electric Light Company.

New Orleans, La., is planning to borrow $6,300,000 on serial bonds on Feb. 5. Proceeds from the sale will be used to finance public improvements. The bonds will be dated March 1, 1958, and will come due on Sept. 1 from 1959 to 1987.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made a valid contention last week before the Senate subcommittee on Preparedness. But pertinence to his contention of the experiences of the other officers he cited is disproved by the circumstances of their testimony to the subcommittee.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 20 -Candidates of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's ruling Kuomintang won a majority of the seats in Taiwan's twenty-one local councils in yesterday's election. The votes were tallied today.
If you can meet these qualifications, there is a $25,000-ayear job waiting for you.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Burl Ives will become Big Daddy again in Metro-GoldwynMayer's screen version of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof." Mr. Ives created the role in the Broadway production of the Tennessee Williams play.
A court ruled yesterday that the Joint Legislative Committee on Government Operations has the power to confer immunity against criminal prosecution on witnesses who appear before it.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20--This is a shaggy dog story, Himalayan variety. It has most everything -- the White House, suspense, adventure, international intrigue, and even a couple of very real, very shaggy dogs.
Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, former leader of the Flying Tigers of World War II, expressed the belief yesterday that this country had surpassed the Soviet Union in over-all scientific development.
LONDON, Jan. 20--A confident and united Labor party welcomes tomorrow's reassembly of Parliament as a chance to hasten the defeat of the Conservative Government.

THE emergence of contemporary Italian painting as a vital part of international modern art is a post-war phenomenon. Still largely unfamiliar in this country, it is the subject of a large and representative exhibition opening today at Columbia University's Casa Italiana, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street, where it will remain on view to the public until Feb. 7.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -President Eisenhower acknowledged in forty-four words today the 10,000-word Jan. 8 letter of Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin. In that letter the Soviet Premier proposed a heads-ofgovernment meeting within two or three months.

Replacement of Mr. Beane by Mr. Smith in the hierarchy of the brokerage house four-fifths of whose title features the names of Messrs. Merrill, Lynch, Pearce and Fenner, underscores for us how business nomenclature has shifted with changing business patterns.

RICHARD NOERA preceded the printed program of his piano debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last night with a sort of encore in reverse. He explained that he would have liked to say something wild or startling to greet his audience but, having found no words for this, he chose to play the Liszt D flat Etude instead.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -The Supreme Court held today that private parties may not bring antitrust suits based on Section 3 of the Robinson-Patman Act of 1936.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Navy has advised Congress that "amazing" progress on the Polaris ballistic missile will probably warrant further speedup in already accelerated production schedules for submarines to launch it.
"THE trouble with you," said Bill Sharman, trying to be nonchalant about it, "is that you don't guard me closely enough."
Milton Berle, who terminated his television comedy show nearly two years ago, will star in a straight dramatic role Feb. 19 on "Kraft Theatre."

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- All grain price futures except soybeans drifted lower in a light Board of Trade business today. The soybean gains were in all contracts and ranged up to more than a half-cent-a-bushel for the deferred months.

United States consumption of silver in the arts and industries last year was 95,000,000 ounces, or 5 per cent below the 1956 rate, according to Handy Harman, refiner and fabricator of precious metals.
The stock averages tell one story and the record of individual stocks may tell another. Harold Clayton, marketing analyst for Hemphill Noyes Co. proved this yesterday with his latest compilations.

The Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York is a voluntary, nonprofit marine trade association composed of over sixty firms operating self-propelled and non-self-propelled lighters, barges and scows in New York Harbor and tributary waters.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The Labor party asserted today that the nationalized British industries were operating more efficiently than they did under private industry.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 -A marine engineer who was ordered off an Eniwetok-bound ship here on Saturday for security reasons said today that he was innocent of any wrongdoing.

IF the Hollywood legend had never existed it would have to be invented. In fact, it was -- and for the decades cresting in the Nineteen Twenties it flourished, with the enormous bathtubs of private swimming pools as symbols of a gaudy new way of life under the sun. Now that the legend has grown seedy, heroic efforts are made from time to time to revive it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -Following are the letter of transmittal and excerpts from President Eisenhower's Economic Report, sent to Congress today:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Alex Hannum, the Western team coach, is doing some "hard thinking" about how to win the National Basketball Association All-Star game tomorrow night from an Eastern squad which he admits is superior.

The Export-Import Bank of Washington announced yesterday a $28,600,000 line of credit to the National Railways of Mexico. The funds will permit purchase in the United States of locomotives, rolling stock and shop, communications and track equipment.
An issue of $15,000,000 of bonds of the Union of South Africa, payable in dollars, is being offered for public subscription today by a banking syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Jan. 20 (UP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison, completely relaxed as pressure killed off his younger foes, won the $17,000 Tijuana open golf tournament today with a 3under-par 69 for a 72-hole total of 280.
A fresh indication was given yesterday of the changes that have been taking place in the garment industry, always a barometer of shifts in New York's "melting pot."
Harold Gomes of Providence socred a knockout over Harold Smith, a lightweight from Washington, in the seventh round of the scheduled tenround feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
The Borden Company has elected Theodore O. Hofman a vice president of the dairy company and president of the Borden Foods Company division.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -President Eisenhower warned business and labor today that "unwarranted" price or wage increases, achieved through "the exercise of economic power," could threaten the recovery he expects this year.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Mayor Wagner's charter revision program ran into a legislative snag today. Some influential Republicans suspect that the legislation involved is full of "sleepers."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 20 -- This tense capital waited today for a general strike scheduled to start tomorrow.
NASHVILLE, Jan. 20 -- The Nashville School Board invoked Tennessee's new Pupil Placement Law today as a defense against complete and immediate integration of the city's public schools.
Record attendance, and far more orders than expected marked the opening yesterday of the local winter furniture market.

Two five-story buildings at 1321-23 Third Avenue, between Seventy-fifth and Seventy-sixth Streets, have been purchased by the Jay Realty Corporation. The company, headed by Sally and Irving Jaeger, will convert the structures into a restaurant. A client of Green Seizer, attorneys, was the seller. Julian E. Gordon Co., Inc., was the broker in the sale.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 20 (UP) -- A Northern general's portrait hanging in the Mississippi Capitol stirred up a storm today.
At one point in his annual Economic Report, transmitted to Congress yesterday, President Eisenhower indulges in this brief but pointed observation:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- For two of TV's lady humorists, there was little to laugh about on this blue Monday. "Sally," starring Joan Caulfield, and "The Eve Arden Show" have felt the sponsors' axe. Both have been canceled, according to reliable sources.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -The State Department announced today that John M. Allison, United States Ambassador to Indonesia, would be transferred to another post.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic national chairman, branded the outpouring of Republican criticism tonight as "stale political charges."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The monthly Treasury statement disclosed today the Government spent about $6,750,000,000 more than it took in during the last six months of 1957.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- An openly skeptical House of Representatives subcommittee began today two weeks of hearings on Administration draft legislation to end by 1963 two laws giving education aid to areas having large Federal installations.
Formation of a major new division of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company was announced yesterday by Alfred E. Driscoll, president.
A woman secretary to the French Ambassador to the United Nations was stabbed in the back yesterday morning by a teen-ager as she walked to work through Central Park.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Advertisers invested more money in newspapers in 1957 than in television, radio, magazines, and billboards combined, according to Gilbert P. Swanson, president of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Governor Harriman declared bluntly today that he would not "abdicate to a Republican Attorney General" his law enforcement powers.
Representatives of 250,000 unionized telephone workers will begin an experiment today to inject greater realism into drafting collective bargaining programs.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 20 -- The National Palace announced tonight that Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes had won a plurality in yesterday's Presidential election. General Ydigoras was the candidate of the rightist National Democratic Reconciliation party.

NEWARK, Jan. 20 -- The Mayor of Union testified today that hundreds of residents had complained to him in the last several years about low-flying airliners from Newark Airport. He said he himself had suffered discomfiture in this respect.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday entered the case of a youthful racial supremacy club uncovered last week in Forest Hills, Queens.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 20 -- Maj. Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, Army Chief of Staff, tonight bluntly warned local and foreign reporters that continued journalistic "insult" and "slander" against the Indonesion Government would not be tolerated.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 20 -New York City spends perhaps $50,000,000 a year on "mainly remedial" programs for its Puerto Rican newcomers, a joint migration conference of city and island officials was told today.

Arrangements are being completed by members of the Canadian Women's Club of New York for their annual Maple Leaf supper dance and ball. The fete, a benefit for the general activities of the organization and the Lighthouse Nursery School, will be held in the Gold Ballroom and the Salon Bleu of the SavoyPlaza on Jan. 31.

Plans for United States representation in the musical part of the 1958 Brussels World Fair have been virtually completed. A substantial list of additions has been made to the roster announced earlier by Howard S. Cullman, United States Commissioner for the Brussels Fair.

The average length of the four-door sedan -- overwhelmingly the most popular body style in America -- has increased nineteen inches in the last twenty years. Scientific automobile design has progressed so far, in fact, that cars are not only longer and therefore more difficult to turn but also lower and therefore more difficult to get in and out of.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -- The Soviet news agency Tass said tonight that the first earth satellite had ceased to exist on Jan. 4.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (UP) -- A capacity crowd of 1,000 persons gathered tonight to pay tribute to the stars who have played baseball in St. Louis. The occasion was the fiftieth anniversary dinner of the St. Louis Chapter of the American Baseball Writers Association.
A dawn - to - dusk search of Long Island Sound by Coast Guard air and surface units yesterday failed to turn up any trace of the tugboat Jim Steers, missing since Sunday. She carried a crew of three.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 21 -In a surprise move the Soviet Government agreed last night to release twenty-one German scientists and technicians who had been kept working in the Soviet Union for thirteen years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The Supreme Court ordered today a new lower court hearing on the request of the Yugoslav regime for the extradition of a former official of the wartime Croatian government. He is accused of having been a war criminal.
DETROIT, Jan. 20 -- The Big Three of the auto industry showed no immediate disposition today to begin manufacturing shorter and narrower cars as Mayor Wagner of New York has proposed.

"Patate" has been submitted by Gilbert Miller to Jose Ferrer. Mr. Miller would like to have Mr. Ferrer direct Marcel Achard's Parisian comedy success, said to be the author's biggest hit to date. In addition, Mr. Ferrer has been invited by Mr. Miller to join him in sponsoring the five-character play, the adaptation of which is to be furnished by Lucienne Hill.
A pictorial exhibit of bolshevism's forty-year record, portraying "the grim Soviet reality in its true colors," was opened yesterday in the lower-level lobby of Grand Central Terminal.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. disclosed yesterday that his department planned to operate next year on a reduced budget.
THANK Off Broadway for another refreshing theatre event. It is Gorky's first play, "The Courageous One," vigorously acted at the Greenwich Mews last evening.
The Federal Power Commission announced yesterday it had granted a $10,180,000-a-year rate increase to the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation.
The Nation's second largest copper producer, the Phelps Dodge Corporation, announced yesterday that its mining operations in Arizona were being curtailed further because of decreased demand.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 (AP) -Governor Harriman reported today he had received 8,765 entries in his contest to pick a New York-sounding name for the Penn-Can highway.

LLOYD VIEL BERKNER, who yesterday told a House subcommittee that Government security regulations were hampering our defense effort, was once described as a man who had "done everything every modern boy would like to do."
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Three of the top contenders for this years Republican nomination for Governor had a secret twohour meeting here this afternoon.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 20 -The New Rochelle Board of Education was accused in a State Supreme Court suit here today of underpaying 221 teachers.

It is strange in these fantastic days to read of any political settlement in any hotly contested area that satisfies both sides. It is particularly strange when the area happens to be the Middle East and involves the relationship of the State of Israel with any Arab state.
ROME, Jan. 20 -- The monarchists are likely to enter next spring's general elections divided into two hostile parties.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The United States will be forced to fight its way through a larger list of rivals this year in the American Zone of the Davis Cup tennis competition.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination charged today that political efforts "to woo the vote of the minorities" was interfering with advances in civil rights legislation.
ANYONE with a passion for collecting glass animals should be directed to Jerolds, 883 First Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, where there's a rather diverse menagerie.
Following the lead of the Cannon Mills Company, other manufacturers of sheets have lowered their prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -The Supreme Court agreed today to review the dismissal of an antitrust suit brought by an independent motion picture producer and distributor against two large movie theatre chains, Loew's and R.K.O.
The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries had a record year in 1957, according to the preliminary annual report released yesterday.

The role of housing in the development of the nation's economy is the theme of the thirteenth annual conference of mortgage banking executives sponsored by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America and the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University.
CAIRO, Jan. 19 -- A new "voice" has been added to Cairo's violent anti-Western babel

The Transit Authority yesterday turned its attention to improving bus operations and decided that service could be made faster if more riders would respond to the long-time appeal: "please move to the rear of the bus."

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 20 -- Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, bitterly attacked the Democratic party tonight as he pleaded for election of a Republican Congress this fall. In a speech at the Minnesota United Republican Dinner at the Leamington Hotel. Mr. Adams suggested the Democrats were responsiblefor the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 and the lag in the United States missile program.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 20 -- A flight engineer for Pan American World Airways was found dead today in his automobile here. He had two bullet wounds in his chest.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- A Republican bill fixing June 3 for the primary election and June 1 and 17 as the dates for the state party conventions was filed tonight. It was introduced by Assemblyman J. Eugene Goddard, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on the Election Law.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon appealed last night to the nation to trust President Eisenhower's judgment on defense needs.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Representative Charles A. Buckley warned today that any attempt to drop Lieut. Gov. George B. De Luca of the Bronx from this year's Democratic state ticket would mean a fight on the convention floor.

HONOLULU, Jan. 20 (UP) -Surface craft today recovered wreckage from one of two military planes missing in the Pacific. A widespread search, aided by planes from the carrier Philippine Sea, was intensified for the other missing aircraft.
GENEVA, Jan. 20 -- Switzerland told the Soviet Union today that she would not take the initiative in convening an East-West heads-of-government meeting now.

West Virginia's Mountaineers, hustling harder than ever after their one close call this season, racked up their thirteenth straight basketball victory last week. As a result, they took a firmer grip on first place in the weekly Associated Press ranking poll yesterday.
Increased sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended Dec. 31 were reported by McKesson Robbins, Inc., in its statement issued yesterday by George Van Gorder, chairman.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 20 (AP) -- A stick of dynamite, uncapped and unfused, was found in an empty locker at integrated Central High School today. Virgil Blossom, Superintendent, called it a weapon of terror "to force us to close the school."
Following are the texts of the introductory address last night by Vice President Richard M. Nixon in New York and President Eisenhower's address in Chicago, as recorded by The New York Times:
Two huge and successful financing operations gave the stock market a good tone yesterday, and it closed with moderate gains.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Following are the highlights of the Economic Report submitted to Congress today by President Eisenhower:
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 20 -Moroccan authorities declared tonight that Yemen, not Morocco, was the destination of the arms and ammunition seized by the French from the Yugoslav ship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -Fasten your seat belts, folks. The big political battle of 1958 is on.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 -The Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals freed eleven alleged Communists today -- the "Hawaii Seven" and four from Seattle.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Eight vice presidents have been elected to the new posts of senior vice presidents of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc. Two of the officers were appointed to the new posts of president of their divisions, which are the company's two largest producing units.

NEWARK, Jan. 20 -- Senator Clifford P. Case declared tonight that the Republican party alone could turn the "tide that has been running against" America, but only if it could persuade the American people that it is capable of "doing the job."
Mrs. Joseph Barbara Sr., wife of the Apalachin gang convention host, has been summoned to appear today before the Tioga County grand jury.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 20 -Repeal of the state's Youth Court Act was asked today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors in a unanimous vote. The law, scheduled to become operative April 1, has been called costly and cumbersome.

Thirty-three souvenirs of persons famous in show business were sold at auction yesterday to add $1.600 to the March of Dimes. The sale took place at Studio 50 of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Broadway at Fifty-third Street.
JOYCE FLISSLER, violinist, who won the Naumburg Award in 1951, played a Town Hall recital last night that reaffirmed the good impression made by the young artist at her debut.
Voluntary death is an inalienable human right, Horace M. Kallen said yesterday at a meeting of the Euthanasia Society of America. The society was twenty years old this month.
Smoke from a Harlem laundry shop fire felled eleven persons shortly before 10 A. M. yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- Lee Kyung Soo Paladino, a 9-year-old Korean war orphan whose bewildering start in life became even more complicated in an adoptive American home, today was making a new beginning.

Israel's frontiers are "more peaceful than at any time in recent times," in large part because an outbreak of war in the Middle East would "involve the atomic powers," Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -The State Department said today that no change of policy was contemplated in defense arrangements for Taiwan (Formosa).
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 20 -- Walter P. Reuther charged today that the three major auto companies were apparently going to apply a double standard in the 1958 contract negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -The time to protest proposed advances in rail freight rates and charges ended today, but not before the railroads had lost a former ally and provoked hundreds of foreign and domestic shippers.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Skiing conditions, as reported to the state commerce department today, follow:
The Rockefeller Institute has just completed four buildings of contemporary design and luxurious modern interiors on its campus at the East River.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 20 -- The Bahamas Federation of Labor began mass picketing of the Bay Street shops owned by members of the Colonial Legislature today as the general strike entered its ninth day with no sign of settlement.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad decided yesterday not to declare a dividend for the current quarter.
Tommy Carroll, the erstwhile bonus boy who "sat around" with the Yankees through two seasons, was one of three players signed by the American League champions yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that the Republicans "are trying to buy the Congressional election in the Twenty-first district of Pennsylvania with a $50,000 slush fund."
Passenger traffic on the Lackawanna Railroad ferry flowed smoothly yesterday and ferryboat loads were below normal.
Directors of the Pittsburgh Steel Company took no dividend action yesterday on the common stock normally due at this time. In previous quarters the company paid 25 cents cash and 1 per cent in stock.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -- South Africans will go to the polls April 16 in the country's first general election in five years. The date of the elections was announced in Parliament here today.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 20 -The Defense Ministers of West Germany, France and Italy will meet here tomorrow to broaden West Europe's attempts at a unified armament policy.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 20--Several Indonesian officials made no secret tonight that they were deeply disappointed about Mr. Allison's departure.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 20, (UP) -- The Virginia Supreme Court ruled today that a legislative committee had acted within its rights when it obtained a court order requiring the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to surrender a list of members and contributors in Virginia.
Film entries for the ninth anual Robert J. Flaherty award, sponsored by the Institute of Film Techniques at City College, will now be accepted. The closing date is Feb. 21.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The stock market was fairly buoyant today under the lead of British Government securities, which gained as much as 5 shillings (70 cents).

Directors of Summers Gyroscope Company, Santa Monica Calif., and of the Mercast Corporation, Los Angeles, have approved a merger plan. The new company would be called Summers Corporation, according to a joint announcement yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The work of restoring Saint Paul's Cathedral, the cathedral church of London, is nearing completion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Supreme Court unanimously reaffirmed today a controversial ruling that the states may not fix minimum wellhead prices for natural gas sold in interstate commerce.
Plastic flowers imported from Italy are now available at both Carole Stupell shops, 507 Madison Avenue and 54 East Fiftyseventh Street.
A 47-year-old labor leader saved himself yesterday from a year in the penitentiary when he promised to withdraw from union activities.

LUMBERTON, N. C., Jan. 20 (AP) -- A Robeson County grand jury today indicted two Ku Klux Klansmen, and others of their group "unknown to the state," on charges of inciting a riot Saturday night. In the disorder, Lumbee Indians broke up a Klan rally designed to intimidate them.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -In a spirit of civic cooperation, officials of the University of Pennsylvania have turned over Franklin Field for the 1958 home games of the Philadelphia Eagles.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20--President Eisenhower opened the Republican 1958 political campaign tonight with a plea that the national security issue be kept out of the year's "political chess game."
Dr. Louis M. Hacker declined yesterday to comment on reports that he might resign as dean of the School of General Studies at Columbia University.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 20 -- Mr. Darby, who is a Republican National Committeeman from Kansas, refused to comment tonight. He said he would supply details tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, accused President Eisenhower today of ignoring "the fact that we are in serious economic trouble."
A warning to be on the alert in the chemical, biological and radiological warfare field was sounded here yesterday by Maj. Gen William M. Creasy, Chief Chemical Officer of the Army.

All cocoa positions soared the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday except the spot January position which has no limit and climbed 203 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume on the New York Cocoa Ex change was only 212 lots but there were 600 unsatisfied bids at the top permissible price.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 -- Lester B. Pearson, newly elected leader of his party, called on John Diefenbaker's minority Government tonight to resign and let the Liberal minority take over without an election for the good of Canada.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 20 -Brazil is making another attempt to enter the race to develop Bolivian oil concessions. Foreign Minister Jose Carlos Macedo Soares is scheduled to leave Thursday to meet his Bolivian counterpart, Manuel Barrau, in an effort to find a way to execute a 1938 treaty that gave Brazil 3,500,000 hectare (about 8,750,000 acres) in oil concessions in southeastern Bolivia.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- The Soviet Government tried again today to demonstrate its concern for the rapidly growing demands of consumers here. It promised progress but no early solutions.
BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- A statement by Dr. Heinrich von Brentano has produced a flurry of criticism. He said that a "werewolf policy" was being advocated for Germany by George F. Kennan.

I am at a loss to understand what purpose can be served beyond obfuscation by editorial and official misrepresentation of Soviet policy toward Germany. Why keep repeating that the rulers of Russia consented at Geneva in 1955 to the reunification of the Reich and later repudiated their pledge?
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Legislative action to aid school districts in marketing their construction bonds at more favorable interest rates is in prospect on two fronts.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 20 -Following are excerpts from the speech of Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, to Minnesota Republicans here tonight:

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 -- Under "certain conditions" the Canadian Government will reconsider its decision not to rent space in Canada House in New York. Sidney E. Smith, Minister for External Affairs, reported this today to a House of Commons committee.
TRENTON, Jan. 20 -- The New Jersey Legislature convened briefly today, then recessed pending the inauguration tomorrow of Gov. Robert B. Meyner for a second four-year term.
The drive to rid Harlem of rats received impetus from two city departments yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -Dean Acheson, Secretary of State under President Truman, denounced the Eisenhower administration today as substituting "words for acts," and leading the country into "serious crisis."
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- France and Yugoslavia exchanged sharp protests tonight over the French seizure of a 150-ton cargo of Czechoslovak arms aboard a Yugoslav ship Saturday in the Mediterranean.

The New York State Bankers Association, at its annual midwinter meeting at the Commodore Hotel yesterday, threw its support behind a bill introduced in Congress to increase taxes on mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 21 (AP)--Mike Green of Miami Beach, Fla., today fought his way into the quarter-final round of the Australian national tennis championships with a 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4 victory over Rod Laver, a 19-year-old Aussie.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Jan. 20 -- Nearly 1,000 Dutch nationals from Indonesia trudged down a gangplank into the chill air of Northern Europe this morning with little but the welcome of Queen Juliana to give them hope for the future.

A 225 - pound six - foot - two - inch seaman smashed three neon-lighted chandeliers and damaged furniture with a cane yesterday outside the clerk's office on the sixth floor of the United States Courthouse in Foley Square.
The drive to rid Harlem of rats received impetus from two city departments yesterday.

A 225 - pound six - foot - two - inch seaman smashed three neon-lighted chandeliers and damaged furniture with a cane yesterday outside the clerk's office on the sixth floor of the United States Courthouse in Foley Square.

FRAME makers are gradually transforming the giltedged securities of many modern art collectors. They are abandoning the gold, silver leaf and black bands which, over the last ten years, have framed abstract and cubist canvases.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has taken the majority of the seats for the Jan. 30 preview performance of "Oh Captain!" at the Alvin Theatre. The association's Legal Defense and Educational Fund will be the beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee called today for lower interest rates on United States loans to other nations as a means of combating the Soviet Union's economic offensive.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 21 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was reported today to have assured Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, that West Germany's restitution laws would remain unchanged.
District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn recommended yesterday that the Legislature enact a law for the indictment and trial for manslaughter of corporations charged with culpable negligence.

The police disclosed yesterday that they had arrested two more members of a Queens racial supremacy club that had planned to rob a bank in Kew Gardens. Eleven youths have been arrested in the case so far.

TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- Gov. Robert Baumle Meyner embarked on a second four-year term today. The 49-year-old Governor, who enhanced his national political reputation with a landslide re-election victory in November, took theoath of office in the most impressive inaugural ceremony here in recent years.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The Conservative Government and the Bank of England have been exonerated of improper disclosure of financial secrets.
The Paragon Mutual Syndicate Company has purchased the six-story apartment building at 90 Laurel Hill Terrace, southwest corner of West 186th Street, on Washington Heights.
TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- New Jersey was without an Attorney General tonight for the first time since the Civil War.
The Radio Corporation of America's two billionth electron tube slid off the assembly line yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Mining spokesmen urged today tax relief to encourage mineral exploration and development. The pleas were made at a hearing of the House Ways and Means Committee.

THAT genial rascal, Jacques Offenbach, respected nothing -- not royalty or military pomp or diplomacy or, for that matter, young love. In his time even some of his victims found his wit and esprit irresistible.
A burglar was shot dead yesterday noon by a policeman who caught him ransacking an apartment in West Fifty-seventh Street.

THERE was a happy reunion last night between Marcel Marceau and New York. The great French mime who first startled and conquered us in 1955 is back on Fifty-fifth Street for a limited engagement and those who neglected to take good advice now have a second chance to discover what all the shouting was about.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- A complete overhauling of the state's truck-mileage tax is about to be proposed by the Harriman administration. It has some bipartisan support.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The East All-Stars got a surprisingly ineffective performance from celebrated Bill Russell, but his "old pro" team-mate Bob Cousy scored 16 second-half points that led them to a record 130118 victory over the West tonight in the annual National Basketball Association All-Star game.

TWO Spanish sisters, the most-talked-about hair stylists in Paris, have set up a beauty shop, done in Japanese decor, at Henri Bendel, an old Manhattan institution. This should be the best place in the world to get a truly international coiffure.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 21 -- Serious repercussions were developing today as a result of the publication of returns from Sunday's Presidential election.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 21 -A leading food broker said today the nation's canning industry must improve old products and develop new ones in order to meet the competition from other convenience foods.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- One of Britain's leading bankers cautioned today that measures adopted here and in the United States to curb inflation might eventually lead to further inflation.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Jan. 21 -- Israel and Jordan will be asked tomorrow to remove any military installations they may be maintaining in Jerusalem's No Man's Land.
PHARSALIA, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- On a farmland hilltop here, two saucer-like microwave radio transmitters are testing the reliability of a technique new to the Bell Telephone Laboratories.
ROME, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Harassed directors of the Rome Opera faced another crisis today when a famous basso walked out of a rehearsal in anger after a dispute with a tenor.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The world's coffee producing nations were warned today they must entice North Americans and Europeans into drinking more coffee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -The White House was amused but not completely clear today about its involvement in a shaggy Tibetan dog story.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the National Academy of Sciences, cautioned today against any massive Federal program designed to improve the nation's educational system.

The possibility was raised yesterday that the vanished tug Jim Steers may have been in a collision with a tank barge when she disappeared early Sunday morning. Three crew members of the tug were lost.
The head of the Air Force ballistic missile program said last night that the United States had the technical capacity to send up a man in an artificial satellite "quite soon."
At the moment Mary Martin does not know what will bring her back to Broadway. However, she is weighing two prospects.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- The Screen Actors Guild and the Writers Guild of America, West, today announced their intention to serve sixty-day notices of "cancellation of contract" on Republic Pictures and its subsidiary, Studio City Television Productions, Inc.
WARSAW, Jan. 21 -- The leader of Poland's twelve-man Roman Catholic parliamentary group called on the ruling Communist party today "to resurrect the energies of the nation" by trusting the people.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- Four prominent Yugoslav citizens face trial on charges of having plotted to overthrow the Communist regime of President Tito, an informed source said tonight.

The Presidential elections in Guatemala appear to have resulted in a resounding plurality for the Right-Wing candidate, Gen. Miguel Ydfgoras Fuentes. The only other two candidates who counted, the moderate Col. Jose Luis Cruz Salazar and the Leftist Mario Mendez Montenegro, ran far enough behind so that it does not matter much which turns out to be the second and which the third contestant.
ROME, Jan. 21 -- It is conceivable that the resources of outer space may help the world to support a population larger than what is now thought possible, Pope Pius XII said today.

The Singer Manufacturing Company, producer and distributor of household and industrial sewing machines, is expanding its interest into the electronics field through the purchase of Haller, Raymond Brown, Inc.
TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- Following is the text of Gov. Robert B. Meyner's second inaugural address to the New Jersey Legislature today:
MONTREAL, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Although operating at a strange position, Dickie Moore of the Montreal Canadiens still leads the National Hockey League scoring race, official statistics showed today.

SHAKESPEARE'S "Henry VIII" is seldom acted, and compared with his more popular plays it is not even widely read. But three of its lines are so familiar and so often quoted that they are all that many people know about their speaker, Thomas Cardinal Wolsey:

TWO post-World War II developments, the home organ and high fidelity, were playing sweet music together yesterday afternoon. At a press showing, the Thomas Organ Company introduced a single keyboard electronic organ with a four-speed record player.
MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- The Soviet Government urged today that the Middle East be kept free of nuclear and missile weapons.
Young Rubicam, Inc., has resigned the Lincoln automobile account with billings of $4,500,000 a year.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Britain's proposals for determining the political future of Cyprus have received a chilly reception from Turkey, British sources indicated today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that further discussion of world disarmament should be carried on within the framework of the United Nations.
Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz' reputation for severity is at least partly responsible for the large backlog of felony cases in Kings County Court, a fellow judge declared yesterday.
The Yankee bandwagon, with New York's broad highways all to itself, continues to roll on, thanks to the evacuation of the Giants and Dodgers.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 21 -- Despite Egyptian coolness to the idea, some Syrian Government sources are predicting that agreement on a union of Syria and Egypt will be announced within two months.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Michael De Capite, Chief of Editorial Services of the United Nations Department of Public Information, died in Mexico City today of injuries received in an automobile accident. He was 42 years old.

The Federal Reserve Board approved yesterday a cut in the discount rate from 3 to 2 3/4 per cent by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. Thus it continued a series of steps begun last fall to reverse the business downturn.

Camp Nyda, near Burlingham, N. Y., where diabetic children are sent for summer vacations, will gain from a theatre benefit at the Feb. 5 performance of "Oh Captain!" at the Alvin Theatre. The new musical is scheduled to open the previous night.

A group of state-chartered savings and loan associations has recommended a fourteen-year term for the State Superintendent of Banks. They also have urged that the Superintendent be given the authority to resolve differences among competing segments of the banking business.
Six courses designed for parents and teachers will be offered during the spring term at the New School for Social Research, 60 West Twelfth Street. They are:

The Sports Car Club of America, grown from a handful of M.G. owners and drivers thirteen years ago to the largest organization of its kind in the world, with more than 10,000 active members, is suffering from growing pains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission heard testimony today that a $64,000,000 tariff windfall had given two Canadian distillers a strong competitive advantage in the United States market.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 21 -- A group of women prominent in this community will appear in a pageant of fashions in St. Peter's Parish Hall here Thursday, wearing gowns that had been worn by well-known women of the past.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- KTLA, an independent Los Angeles television station, intends to transmit subliminal, or "unseen" messages, to viewers "within the next ninety days," according to the station's vice president and general manager, Lew Arnold.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 17 -- The North American Air Defense Command, for many years the orphan of the armed services, is adding some formidable new weapons to the continent's defense this year.

ONE evening last October, John J. Brandt was swapping stories with two strange gentlemen in the club car of a train speeding toward Texas. After several drinks, the two asked Mr. B. what he did for a living.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 21 -- The Economic Committee of the Baghdad Pact nations ended a five-day conference here tonight. The pact's ministerial session begins Monday.

A 34-year-old mother of two sons who does her housework in a wheelchair and goes bowling for a "night out" was named yesterday as National Polio Mother of 1958. She is Mrs. Virginia Huston of Bellingham, Wash.
MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Jan. 21 -- The North American Area Council of the World Presbyterian Alliance was told tonight that Brazil was one of the "great frontiers of the Protestant movement."

The Dry Dock Savings Bank announced yesterday the election of William A. Lyon as president. Mr. Lyon, a former Superintendent of Banks of New York State, had been chairman of the Dry Dock Savings' executive committee since January, 1955.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Harriman filed with the Legislature today a budget deficiency bill providing $11,300,000 in state appropriations for the fiscal year ending March 31. The bill also includes $58,600,000 in what is known as first instance appropriations -- funds for which the state will be reimbursed later.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Government got a high bid of $2,766,000 today for its 63 per cent stockholdings in Karl Lieberknecht, Inc., manufacturing concern at Laureldale, Pa.

New York's two new fireboats have given the city an opportunity to honor two citizens who made notable contributions during their lifetime to the welfare of the city's firemen. Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, wife of the Mayor, has christened one "Harry M. Archer, M. D." and Mrs. Edward F. Cavanagh, wife of the Fire Commissioner, has christened the other "H. Sylvia A. H. G. Wilks."

The number of new books published in the United States last year reached almost its highest point in the twentieth century, with a total of 10,561 titles. The total was surpassed only in 1910 when 11,671 titles were issued.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -Moscow's charge today that the United States was planning to blast missile bases upon MidEastern countries was shrugged off by Washington as an attempt to reveal the United States' hand.

Walter Francis O'Malley, the president of the Dodgers, was back in his Montague Street offices in Brooklyn yesterday -- temporarily -- trying to clear up a few misconceptions about his move to Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, was the main topic of conversation in Washington today.

Housing for the nation's middle-income groups was described by William Zeckendorf yesterday as "the greatest unfilled market and the best bulwark against anything that sounds like communism the country has."
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan 21 -- A proposal for a $250,000 plan to develop young adult leaders in New York, starting with youths of Spanish-speaking ancestry, was announced here tonight.

Johnny Dio, who is serving a sentence of fifteen to thirty years in Sing Sing Prison for labor extortion and conspiracy, will testify today before a special rackets grand jury in Queens. Dio, whose real name is Dioguardi, was brought to Queens yesterday and is being held in the Queens House of Detention in Long Island City.

Two Polish athletes, eager for something to do besides training and sitting in their hotel room, met the press yesterday and expressed their desire to perform well during the current indoor track season.

The decision of the City Planning Commission to fix Thirtieth Street as the route for a trans-Manhattan highway comes as something of a shock to those of us who are most intensely concerned with the alleviation of midtown traffic congestion.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 21 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer urged the Soviet Union today to agree to diplomatic conversations as a first step toward a relaxation of East-West tensions.
After fifty years of work with delinquents and lawbreakers, Abraham N. Fauer thinks it was all worth while. If he could start anew, he would choose the same life work.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 21 -- Lew Burdette arrived here yesterday for the annual polio fund sports dinner which was held last night. He flew in from Pittsburgh -or was it Buffalo or Chicago? The pitching hero of the last world series is losing all sense of geography as he flits thither and yon with such rapidity that even his halo is sometimes worn askew.

ATHENS, Jan. 21 -- A three-judge Athens court sentenced Marion L. Musilli, United States airman, to ten months in prison tonight. A car the 22-year-old West Virginian was driving killed Maj. Gen. Stephanos Serafis, retired, and injured his wife May 30, 1957.

The Standard Financial Corporation, diversified commercial finance company, has acquired for about $2,500,000, control of Factors Corporation of America from the Bankers Securities Corporation and other stockholders.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 21 -Three of Virginia's so-called "anti-N. A. A. C. P. laws" were declared unconstitutional here today. The ruling was made by a special three-judge Federal court. The decision was split, 2 to 1.
THROUGHOUT the city, cooking schools are in session or scheduled to begin soon. There are courses for bewildered beginners, budding Escoffiers and just plain home cooks on the lookout for new ideas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Atomic Energy Commission and the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy have informally agreed on a target date of 1968 for attainment of economic nuclear power in the United States.

President Eisenhower has taken just forty-four words to reply to Premier Bulganin's 10,000-word letter of Jan. 8. This is the message in which the Soviets proposed to call an early "summit" meeting of their own and summon to it both Western and Eastern heads of government.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced revocation of the broker-dealer registration of Cornelis de Vroedt, doing business in New York as Cornelis de Vroedt Company and as Cornelis de Vroedt, Inc., for "willful violation" of the commission's "net capital rule." This limits the indebtedness of a broker-dealer to all persons to 2,000 per cent of the broker-dealer's net capital.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The only Mexican entry, the 36-foot sloop Andasolo, took the lead on a handicap basis today in the 1,500-mile San Diego-to-Acapulco yacht race.

Two new Universal-International releases make up the double bill opening today at various neighborhood theatres. "The Female Animal," a drama with Hedy Lamarr, Jane Powell, Jan Sterling and George Nader, was produced by Albert Zugsmith and directed by Harry Keller.

The State of Connecticut is planning to make an offering of State-guaranteed bonds on Feb. 18. This will be in furtherance of the permanent financing of the 129-mile turnpike extending from Greenwich to Killingly that was opened to traffic on Jan. 2.

Commercial exports and imports of this country for 1958 are expected to drop below last year's levels. This forecast was made yesterday by the balance of payments group of the National Foreign Trade Council.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 21 -- Well, now we know. The "greats" of Italian fashion are generally on the short end of the skirt situation. Of course, today we saw just the boutique collections of lower-priced merchandise, which only indirectly reflect the designers' real fashion feelings.

Dr. James B. Conant, former United States Ambassador to West Germany, and sixteen other Americans yesterday assailed the recent proposals of George F. Kennan for the neutralization of Europe. They called them "a blueprint for the appeasement of the Soviet Union."

Last summer, under Nikita S. Khrushchev's leadership, Soviet authorities began a drive to reimpose Stalinist-type conformity upon the writers of that country. As was to be expected, that campaign has now spread throughout the Communist world.

LUMBERTON, N. C., Jan. 21 (AP) -- A South Carolina Klansman, one of two indicted on charges of inciting an Indian riot by a Ku Klux Klan rally, failed to surrender here today as ordered. Sheriff Malcolm McLeod said the man, James W. Cole, now is considered a fugitive from North Carolina.

The proxy statement of Loew's, Inc., mailed to stockholders yesterday disclosed that all directors, including four nominees for board membership, hold common stock in the motion picture company directly or through beneficial interest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Payments of cash dividends by corporations climbed to a record high of $11,500,000,000 in 1957 despite a downturn in December, the Government reported today.
The Italian Line captured second place in passenger volume among North Atlantic ship lines for the third consecutive year the line announced yesterday.
Connecticut has rejected an informal request from the Department of Agriculture that it join the 1958 Federal-state gypsy moth spraying program.

During a lull in the conversation a voice suddenly was heard from the far end of the table. "Today's best buy in meals," it remarked quietly, "is the church supper." The lull was followed by a moment's stunned silence, while each went to his own thoughts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Navy announced today that it would close four Navy and Marine Corps air stations during the next fourteen months in an effort to save $8,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -Representative Lee Metcalf, Democrat of Montana, challenged today Administration plans to terminate two school aid programs for areas of large Federal installations.

With its worthy objective to help right wrongs and its credo that equal justice for all is the responsibility of all, the Legal Aid Society has been providing free legal help for those who need it in New York City for eighty-two years. The society, at 11 Park Place, New York 7, was founded in 1876 as a non-profit philanthropic organization.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, is advising his fellow Democrats to ignore attacks on the party now being made from within the White House.
JAKARTA, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Military authorities today restricted bank withdrawals by Dutch citizens in Jakarta.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 21-President Carlos Ibanez refused firmly today to consider any change in a decision recently adopted to cut down copper production 10 per cent this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The domestic oil industry, facing reduced demand for its products, today voiced a plea for mandatory curbs on petroleum imports.
Mayor Wagner asked the City Council yesterday to sanction legislative approval of the City Administration's move to revise the City Charter.
MIAMI, Jan. 21 (AP) -- King o' Swords, an invader from the Fair Grounds in New Orleans, romped to a six-length victory in the $6,000 Shalimar Purse today at Hialeah.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 21 -- A general strike of indefinite duration was declared today. Its aim is the ouster of President Perez Jimenez and his dictatorial regime.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A local union president who said he was not allowed to do much thinking pleaded ignorance today to the illegal conversion of dues money.

A reading of Walter Reuther's proposed profit-sharing plan will lead one to conclude that he is either extremely naive (which I do not for one moment believe) in supposing that the Federal Government could be excluded from a share in the profits or deliberately misleading in quoting amounts for "stockholders and executives" that would in fact have to go to the Treasury.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark had a record year in 1957, according to the preliminary annual according report released yesterday.
The 1957 Murray-Green Award of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations will be presented to Dr. Jonas E. Salk, discoverer of the poliomyelitis vaccine.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Congress was told today information about bows and arrows was still locked up as secret Government data.

Graham R. Hodges in a letter in your Jan. 2 issue tells us that "the Dutch policy was to keep all higher education away from the Indonesians." Moh Sharif, an Indonesian official, in a letter printed Jan. 6 stresses the barrenness of more than 300 years of Dutch colonial "sacred mission" in Indonesia.

Yesterday came a report on a $35,000,000,000-a-year business -- commodity futures trading. John Pepion, executive vice president of the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, announced that the number of contracts traded on commodity exchanges in this country was 4,106,412 last year, about 9 per cent below the 1956 total.

KAGOSHIMA, Japan, Jan. 21 -- Land reforms under the United States occupation have made conservatives out of thousands of impoverished farmers, the leading Communist in this former feudal stronghold declared sadly today.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company sold $75,000,000 of long-term first mortgage bonds in the public market yesterday at an interest cost of about 3.71 per cent. The securi ties were bought at competitive bidding by a syndicate headed by The First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart Co.
A cross-section of the arts of the United States is being assembled for exhibition at the Brussels World's Fair in April.
Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division for Manhattan and the Bronx called on the legal profession last night to get whole-heartedly behind the Tweed plan to reorganize the courts.

A membership meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted four resolutions yesterday that favored strengthening New York States laws against wiretapping and "bugging," electronic eaves-dropping.
Rayonier, Inc., chemical cellulose producer, yesterday reported a drop of 55.3 per cent in earnings last year and a decline of 14.8 per cent in sales, compared with 1956.
A Columbia University political scientist defended big-city life yesterday against the attacks of sociologists who, he said, were victims of rural nostalgia.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The California State Supreme Court today was asked to prohibit the City of Los Angeles from placing on the June 3 ballot a referendum measure on the Dodgers' contract with the city for use of Chavez Ravine as a baseball stadium site.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Jan. 21 -- Trade between Singapore and Indonesian barter ports is at a standstill today because of a move taken by the Indonesian Government yesterday.
OTTAWA, Jan. 21 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Government brushed off two challenges tonight as if they were annoyingly persistent horse flies.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Negotiators for the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians accused the National Broadcasting Company and the American Broadcasting Company today with "stalling" in contract talks.

John W. Mulford of Detroit was in the spotlight yesterday at the National Motor Boat Show in New York's Coliseum. Mulford wears two or three hats for his variety of accomplishments. He is head of the huge Gray Engine firm, maker of marine power plants.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Edward E. Burns, president of the Alton Canning Company of Alton, N. Y., yesterdayl was named president of the Nationals Canners Association. Mr. iBurns, who succeeds A. Edward Brown of Benton Harbor, Mich., was to take office today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Reduction of the minimum down payment, interest rate and insurance premium for home purchases financed with loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration was urged today to spur the lagging home-building industry.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Virgil Akins of St. Louis vaulted high into the welterweight picture tonight by scoring a bruising technical knockout over a badly beaten Tony De Marco at 1:53 of the twelfth round at the Boston Garden.

LAST night's concert at Carnegie Hall by Leon Barzin and the National Orchestral Association served to introduce the French 'cellist Maurice Gendron. The 'cellist was soloist in all three works on the evening's program, Haydn's 'Cello Concerto in D, the Dvorak B minor Concerto and Bloch's "Schelomo."

Gold Medal studios announced yesterday a plan to expand its film - making facilities located at 807 East 175th Street in the Bronx. Martin Poll, president, said that Gold Medal would acquire the two remaining buildings in the complex of structures that was once known as the Biograph Studios.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 21 (AP) -- An oral polio vaccine, said to be cheaper to produce than vaccine now in use, will be tested on more than 1,000 persons here starting Monday.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The fact that foreigners don't vote makes many of our legislators regard aid bills with gingerly distaste. Appropriations to build a dam in Africa or Asia have scant ballot-box appeal.

FROGMORE, S. C., Jan. 21 -- Quail are hunted here on St. Helena Island the easy way, but somehow it doesn't always turn out to be a soft touch. There are certain things about the quail that make this so.
HALLETT STATION, Antarctica, Jan. 16 -- The changing of the guard was completed today at another International Geophysical Year station in Antarctica.
The president of New York City's third largest bank gave a brief lesson to stockholders on the subject of reserve requirements at the annual meeting yesterday.
Unemployment insurance rolls in this city went down last week for the first time since the recession began making itself felt last September.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, formally named today three military men and three civilians to help him with studies for reorganization of the Pentagon.

IN his second one-man exhibition at the Salpeter Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, Charles Csuri has opened out, leaving behind the black "leading," which used to bind his paintings, and giving his paintings an assurance they never had before.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The president of the National Broadcasting Company said today that scheduled tests of pay-television systems might lead to the destruction of free television broadcasts.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 21 -- Although Westchester's population has increased from 625,816 to 752,406 in the last seven years, men and women 20 to 24 years old have been moving away from this suburban county.

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Stan Benham of Lake Placid, N. Y., and his brakeman, Pat Martin of Massena, N. Y., will ride the United States No. 1 sled in the two-man world bobsled championships here Saturday and Sunday.

The high school games committee of the Public Schools Athletic League was unable to reach a decision yesterday on whether to use the new "two-point" regulation adopted by the football rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

The first clash between pro-Hoffa forces and a reform group seeking control of the New York Joint Council of the teamsters union took place yesterday at a stormy meeting of candidates for council offices.

MADRID, Jan. 21 -- United States and Spanish aviation authorities have agreed on a plan for controlling the fast-growing commercial and military air traffic in the Madrid area. The plan will go into effect Feb. 1.
Draft indebtedness of LatinAmerican importers to United States exporters rose $3,700,000 last month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Striking employes of The Peoria Journal Star put their own newspaper on the street stands today. The Journal Star announced it was closing its doors while giving nonstriking employes their 1958 vacations.
A poet and an architect have been chosen to receive awards from the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Interest in Government loans slackened on the stock exchange today and the volume of business was abnormally low. Financial commentators said that the findings of the Bank Rate Tribunal with its endorsement of London's financial reputation for probity might well lead to a revival of interest in gilt-edge issues. Uncertainty about the report, which was not published until after the market closed, has tended to check business.

Douglas Moore was the guest composer on the program the Composers Group of New York City presented last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. He was represented by the first New York performance of his Trio for Violin, 'Cello and Piano, a work he wrote in 1953.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- The Journal of the American Dental Association says in an editorial in its January issue that there is no reason to fear dental X-rays.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The National League baseball schedule, ready to be made public Friday, will have to be revised because of sixteen changes in the Los Angeles Dodgers' schedule, it was announced today.

A $7,750,000 addition to the Queensboro Bridge is nearing completion. The construction of two extra lanes on the upper level and intricate approach ramps began in July, 1955. and is expected to end this May.

The New York baseball fan, shorn of the Giants and Dodgers, may have only the Yankee Stadium to look to for his major league fare if he wants to see the games played in the great outdoors in 1958. But he'll still receive a sizeable fill of his favorite sport via his television set.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Corn futures prices hit new lows for the season again today in a weak Board of Trade market, although they resisted the general slide somewhat better than most grains.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- An American who had wintered in both polar regions died a week ago on a drifting ice floe near the center of the Artic Ocean.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -The House Appropriations Committee approved in full today President Eisenhower's request for $1,260,000,000 in emergency funds to speed work on missiles and otherwise strengthen the nation's retaliatory power.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The Army said today it was preparing two of its three-stage Jupiter-C missiles to launch earth satellities.
BOGOTA, Jan. 21 -- "We are studying the possibility of exchanging coffee for wheat with the Russians," Colombia's Minister of Agriculture was reported today to have announced.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Periodically since 1951, official Washington has been summoning Charles Allerton Coolidge from his tenth floor law office here for advice.
The president of the largest airline in the nation suggested yesterday that the Government relax its grip on domestic airline fares.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The Conservative and Labor parties drew the battle lines tonight for the debate in the House of Commons Thursday on the economic situation.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- All town boards in Suffolk County would be empowered to eliminate nuisances caused by sand and gravel pits under the terms of a bill approved in the state Senate today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 3 to 20 points (15 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday.
OTTAWA, Jan. 21 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker has told Premier Bulganin that he would welcome the holding of a high-level conference in Canada, should there be a decision to have one.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Newspaper executives were urged today to stop fighting each other and to work to sell their publications as the basic advertising medium.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -The University of Pennsylvania announced today a new plan to develop researchers and teachers in the basic medical sciences.
Directors of Kudner Agency Inc., accepted yesterday with regret, the resignation of J. H. S. Ellis as president and elected C. M. Rohrabaugh as his successor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration moved today to protect city residents from large blocks of ice that it suspects are dropped from the waste-water pipes of commercial airliners.

ATHENS, Jan. 21 -- The Athens newspaper Apoyevmatini, usually well informed on military matters, asserted yesterday that the Soviet Union had already established five guided missile bases in Bulgaria and two in Albania. From these satellite countries, it was said, targets not only in Greece but in North Africa could easily be reached.

The auto industry and the United Automobile Workers, already at odds over profit-sharing, are likely to have an equally basic clash over a union proposal to invest pension reserves in housing and other community improvements.
Blood will be donated today to the Red ross at the Veterans Administration Hospitals at 130 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, and ropsey and Seventh Avenues, Brooklyn.
FOUNDED IN 1842, the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is not only America's oldest public community museum but also one of the most impressive concentrations of ancient and modern art in this country.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 21 -- Bay Street merchants appealed to Governor Sir Reynor Arthur today to halt mass picketing of their premises in the general strike that has paralyzed this colony since Jan. 12.

" THE BRIDGE OF SAN LUIS REY," Thornton Wilder's philosophical novel on the lesson of love for those who survive the dead, was adapted for television last night in a stunning production that included superlative performances by Eva Le Gallienne and Judith Anderson.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 2l -- The defense ministers of West Germany, France and Italy agreed today to pool the efforts of their countries in the development production and standardization of weapons for Atlantic alliance.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The State Department of Commerce today received the following reports on winter sports conditions:

First Deputy Police Commissioner James R. Kennedy reported yesterday that there was no evidence to support charges of organized shakedowns in the building construction industry by members of the force.
Lewis L. Strauss decried as "almost pathological" last night the "pessimism and doubt" over United States scientific prowess stirred up by the Soviet earth satellites.
BENNO MOISEIWITSCH, currently celebrating his fiftieth anniversary on the concert platform, gave his only New York recital of the season last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Stocks as a whole closed almost unchanged yesterday in a dull session of the New York Stock Exchange.

A headline on the front page of this newspaper yesterday read: "Eisenhower Urges '58 Campaign Ban on Defense Issue." In the adjoining column the headline of another story read: "Adams Rakes Democrats: Pearl Harbor to Missiles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -About twenty persons have been killed, 100 injured and 1,000 arrested in riots sweeping Caracas today, according to reports reaching Washington from the Venezuelan capital.
Commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 21 -- Nassau County detectives equipped with mine detectors failed today to find the weapon used in the slaying of a Pan American World Airways flight engineer.

Two New Yorkers representing the United States in the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas, which opened last night at the Club Militar in Bogota, were successful against their respective opponents, according to a report received through Colombian news sources.
" Look Up and Live," a program dealing with religious aspects of society, will undertake a study of "Broadway and Religion" beginning Sunday at 10:30 A. M.
A new type of financing venture for the merchant marine industry is being planned by the Grace Line.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 21 (AP) -- A blizzard virtually paralyzed Kansas City with fifteen inches of snow today, then swept into the upper Midwest. The storm diminished tonight.
CARACAS, Jan. 21 (UP) -- A former Venezuelan president, Gen. Elezar Lopez Contreras, said in a published manifesto to country:
MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- The Soviet Union conceded today that 1957 had been a difficult year for its agriculture.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Edward G. Conroy resigned tonight as city manager of New Rochelle. Three members of the five-man City Council had made it clear in a two-hour closed conference that if he did not quit the $20,000-a-year-job, he would be summarliy removed.
The appeal of automobile liability insurance companies for a $25,000,000 rate rise was rejected yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The consumer price index for the United States remained unchanged in December compared with November. Various components, however, showed fluctuations. Food, rents, medical care, and many other items went up. These were offset by lower prices for new automobiles, reflecting dealer discounts, and by declines in some clothing prices.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and reports on winter sports conditions:
An early-morning raid on a dice game in Brooklyn yesterday netted sixty-six players and two lookouts seated in automobiles outside.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Eisenhower flew back to Washington from Chicago today but his return was delayed by bad weather. His White House schedule had to be juggled as a result.

White collar workers at the Kollsman Instrument Company voted last night to strike at 6 o'clock this morning. The company, with plants in Elmhurst, Queens, and Syosset, L. I., is an important supplier of electronic instruments for guided missiles and airplanes.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 21 -- The current crisis in French-Tunisian -Algerian affairs is regarded by observers here as a possible opening for international moves toward moderating the three-year guerrilla conflict in Algeria.
IRVINGTON, N. J., Jan. 21 -- A 30-year-old convict, out on parole only two weeks, robbed a bank of $19,865 today, the police said, and was captured two hours later.

A real-estate broker described as a lieutenant colonel in the Air Force Reserve was named the "king of the scofflaws" yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh. Mr. Murtagh crowned the new king with a $6,550 fine, which was paid less than five hours later.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a Soviet Foreign Ministry statement on the Middle East, as reported by Tass, Soviet news agency, and broadcast in English today from Moscow:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Representative Victor L. Anfuso, Democrat of Brooklyn, wants the state to include an Italian explorer in its historical celebration.
