RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 21 -- The Riverhead Town Board took a firm stand here today in opposition to the proposed 7,700-acre buffer zone around the naval jet assembly and testing plant at Calverton.

TURN east into Bond Street from Broadway where Bond starts its short stretch to the Bowery. It is sooty and littered. Jones Alley, a little in from Broadway, is darker and more piled with gritty papers than the street it bisects.

SATURDAY, 11 A. M. and 1:30 P. M.: The first of a series of films by the late Robert Flaherty will be shown at the Museum of the City of New York. Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. It will be the "Louisiana Story" and is suggested for youngsters from 5 to 16 years old. Adults are admitted only if accompanied by a child.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Jan. 22 (UP) -- The directors of Texas A. and M., whose search for a football coach almost had become a lost and laughable cause, reported late today that they had signed Jim Myers of Iowa State, the "forgotten" man in the long hunt.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- An upstate Democrat has protested to Governor Harriman that the State Conservation Commission unjustifiably forced a forest ranger, who is also a Democrat, out of his job.

A research project is under way at Brooklyn College that may lead to automobile steering wheels that do not turn. In fact, it may even do away with conventional steering wheels. A little pressure of varying amounts applied to a control may be all that will be necessary to steer the car of the future.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Snow, rain and ice are the big hazards ahead for more than 300 drivers in the Monte Carlo auto rally. It even snowed today in this Mediterranean resort where the twenty-seventh running of the event ends Friday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The whole list of grain futures turned lower on the Board of Trade today. All corn deliveries and most oats and rye contracts fell to new seasonal lows during the session.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 22 -- The extreme right and left wings of the Greek Cypriote national movement have clashed and tonight the Cypriote people were apprehensive and bewildered.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The United States will put a small amount of yeast in its test satellites to determine the effect of space travel on a simple form of life.
MAXTON, N. C., Jan. 22 -The Klansman arrested in the Saturday night melee here when Indians balked a Ku Klux Klan rally was fined $60 and $14.75 in costs today by an Indian judge.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 22 -- Dr. Fazil Kutchuk, Turkish Cypriote leader, declared today that the situation in Cyprus was deteriorating rapidly. He cited yesterday's incident in which British troops tried unsuccessfully to break up a demonstration of Turkish students at Ataturk Square in Nicosia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An Army research official disclosed tonight that "excellent progress" was being made with a new anti - missile missile designed to protect troops in the field.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- Following is the text of a resolution on a complaint by Jordan unanimously adopted today by the Security Council.

Ski Sketch: Occupying the center of the stage at Bear Mountain's Silvermine Ski Area these days is Sue Z. Sitzmark. Sue is an eight-cylinder sedan that came off the assembly line of a Michigan automobile plant in 1939.

Although many large companies spend millions each year on research, it is possible for these programs to be successful on relatively limited funds, the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., was told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- House Republicans are going to use a film to tell their constituents what this country hopes to accomplish by sending an earth satellite into orbit.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- A jazz festival at Wood Auditorium here Saturday night will provide financial support for the orchestral concerts this season of the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester.

Fog and rain harassed the metropolitan area yesterday, disrupting air and ship traffic. The storm was the result of a low-pressure system that moved northeastward across the state. It was the third major weather disturbance to afflict the state in as many weeks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 -- Charlton Heston was not aware of it, but all the time he was working for William Wyler in "The Big Country" the director apparently was sizing up the actor as a prospective Judah Ben-Hur.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 22 -- "This is the town * * * It is a town of boats and commuters * * * and the school is the heart of the town.

" It is one thing for the courts to permit corruption. It is almost as bad to have courts that do not follow up summonses; that permits a flouting of the judicial process." -- Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh on Nov. 15, 1957, to a state-wide judicial conference at Trenton, N. J., in an address calling it a "national disgrace" that traffic summonses were so frequently evaded:
James E. Dyer, president of the Sinclair Refining Company, was elected yesterday vice chairman of the board of directors of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, the parent organization.

The turbojet engine, largely cast aside in the race into space, may yet have a significant job to perform. A plan for using conventional air-breathing jets as the first stages of ballistic missiles or space vehicles is being promoted by the General Electric Company.

It may seem hard to visualize, but the City Planning Commission has found from new studies of land measurements and Park Department data that in 1956 there were 6,033 miles of mapped streets in the city -- twice the distance from New York to San Francisco.

NEWARK, Jan. 22 -- John R. Cooney, former president of the Loyalty Insurance Group, was sentenced today to a one-to-two-year term in state prison for embezzlement. He was accused of defrauding the Firemen's Insurance Company of Newark, a member of the group, of $222,706.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 22 -- A school where Bulgarian youngsters recite Stalin's deeds in English is the strange fruit of ninety years of dedicated work by American teachers in Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -Carl Carmer, New York State Historian, urged today that the Federal Government participate in New York's "year of history" celebration in 1958. The event will commemorate the discovery of the Hudson River and Lake Champlain.
Two large New York banks, the Guaranty Trust Company and J. P. Morgan Co., reduced their prime lending rate yesterday from 4 1/2 to 4 per cent. Several large banks in other cities also did so.
PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Caterpillar Tractor Company has reported 1957 sales of $649,904,676, the second highest in its history. Sales in 1956 reached a record total of $685,939,782.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for $3,000,000,000 to cover certain requests in his 1959 fiscal year budget.
A 200-ton slab of rock crushed the rear of a Bronx bakery shop yesterday and killed one of its five occupants. Two others were injured.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday declined to 12,400,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 12,500,000,000 in the preceding week the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Jan. 19, 1957, was 12,556,000,000.

An announcement made over Moscow radio yesterday that Russia had invited American athletes to compete in a track and field meet in Moscow July 5 and 6 was a surprise to officials of the United States Amateur Athletic Union.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- A 51-year-old mother became manager of this city of 65,000 tonight. Mrs. Betty A. Meagher was unanimously chosen by the City Council to serve as acting city manager while the Council surveys the country for someone to fill the job permanently.
Cocoa and potatoes continued to be active yesterday in otherwise dull trading on the New York commodity exchanges. The price of both have advanced sharply during the last few weeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- France has been assured by the United States that She can count on aid in solving her economic problems.

A tentative formula for settling the court fight to keep James R. Hoffa out of the presidency of the Teamsters Union has been worked out by attorneys for the warring union factions, authoritative sources reported early today.
Within five years a large part of the Middle East may be permanently lost to United States influence, Dr. John S. Badeau, president of the Near East Foundation, warned yesterday.

VIENNA, Jan. 22 -- Austria has replied to recent Soviet peace proposals by stating her willingness to promote a high-level international conference. However, Austria said that to be effective the conference must be prepared for by advance negotiations.
Alumnae associations of four schools will sponsor a tea dance at the St. Regis Roof on Feb. 18.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 22 -- Veneziani, effervescent Milan couturiere, offered two show stoppers in her presentation of fashions today. They were the sandwich board silhouette and the ten-gallon straw hat. Just as we were all thinking a chemise is a chemise is a chemise, Veneziani put these crisp, straight, sleeveless sandwich board coats over print or striped dresses and it looked like something new.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -Testing of the Soviet inter-continental ballistic missile shows it is capable of coming within six miles of its designated target, a Soviet scientist said today.
Street-cleaning schedules under the city's alternate-side parking program are likely to be changed in about three months, Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane said yesterday.

THE downtown art area is working at its maximum with exhibitions ranging from the conservative selection of water-colors and oils at the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, to avant-garde group shows on Tenth Street.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 -- The Prime Minister of India read some newspaper clippings and became angry. Then he made an angry speech.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Following is the text of the Secretary of State Dulles' statement today on his departure for the Middle East:
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 22 -- Mayor Wagner of New York today attended the dedication of the new Catholic Social Action headquarters in Santurce, a residential section of San Juan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The upshot of the current Senate defense investigation almost certainly will be to refrain from assigning any direct blame to President Eisenhower for this country's lag in missiles.

The Brooks Brother's' building, a ten-story structure at 346 Madison Avenue, northwest corner of Forty-fourth Street, has been sold for $2,640,000 in one of the largest realty transactions so far this year in the Grand Central area.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Striking printers reached tentative agreement with The St. Paul Pioneers Press and Dispatch on a twenty-six-month contract today.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Jan. 22 (AP) -- An explosion of earth-shaking force in a line of chemical tank cars moving through this city's northeast suburbs today injured at least sixty persons. It also caused property damage that could total $1,000,000.

Arthur B. Bisguier of New York gained the lead in the chess championship tournament of the Americas at the Club Militar, Bogotb, last night, according to a report received from Colombian news sources.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following changes for the week ended Wednesday, Jan. 15:
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The legislature is moving again toward enactment of a bill to make parents responsible for wilfull damage caused by their children. The limit of liability would be $250.
Next Thursday's performance of "Two For the Seesaw" at the Booth Theatre will benefit the West Side Day Nursery, 470 West Forty-third Street.

An unusual step was taken yesterday by Gene Wesson, actor, when he filed a damage suit of $100,000 in Supreme Court against Actors Equity Association, of which he is a member. Mr. Wesson took the action because, he charged, he had been "subjected to scorn and ostracism" and that his earning ability had been impaired.

The New York City Opera will admit a limited number of young American composers to rehearsals and performances of the five-week season of American opera that it is presenting in April and May with a $125,000 grant from the Ford Foundation.

The Soviets have fired a verbal broadside against the forthcoming meeting of the Baghdad Pact Council. This broadside is described by our State Department as "totally false" and "incredibly arrogant." Its purpose is obvious. It is intended to confuse and intimidate another alliance for the defense of the free world.

TORONTO, Jan. 22 -- Criticism of the United States is growing in Canada and is making solution of the two countries' mutual problems more difficult, Livingston T. Merchant, United States Ambassador to Canada, said today.
Albert Ackalitis, one of the most feared persons on the waterfront until he was ruled off the docks in a 1954 clean-up, was linked yesterday to a new drive to organize pier hiring bosses.
Sales and earnings of Air Reduction Company, Inc., for 1957 were the highest in its history, John A. Hill, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A secret staff memorandum to the House subcommittee investigating the big Federal administrativeagencies charges members of the Federal Communications Commission with illegally accepting industry favors.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Government issues had their best day in a long time today. The Bank Rate Tribunal's report released pent-up demand, which was supplemented by increased inquiry prompted by the Philadelphia Reserve Bank's cut in the discount rate as well as by the continued firmness of sterling.
VIENNA, Jan. 22 -- The International Atomic Energy Agency announced today the appointment of twelve divisional directors from as many member states, thus completing its executive staff.

If there are more furrowed brows than usual these days along Madison Avenue the reason is probably to be found in two words that have only recently become current: "subliminal advertising." They describe the new technique of presenting messages on movie or TV screens so briefly, or unobtrusively that the viewer isn't aware of seeing them and yet may be subconsciously impelled to respond.
TRENTON, Jan. 22 -- Stanley E. Rutkowski, Mercer County Prosecutor, threatened today to seek a court order to compel a balky witness to testify before a special grand jury here.
CARACAS, Thursday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A "civic-military committee" announced early today that it had overthrown the Government of President Perez Jimenez.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- The presidents of two more radio and television networks urged Congress today to veto proposed tests of pay television. They said the legislators should settle the dispute over the new system.

Donald E. Keyhoe, author of "The Flying Saucers Are Real," was cut off the air for about fifteen seconds during last night's television presentation of "The Armstrong Circle Theatre" on Channel 2. The incident occurred when Mr. Keyhoe said that a Senate subcommittee was investigating unidentified flying objects.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 22 -- A collection of thirty-five oil paintings by Sir Winston Churchill was placed on view here tonight in the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery of Art.

In his letter about colonialism in The New York Times on Jan. 14, Robert Ross calls upon the United States to disown its allies in NATO who are responsible for dependent territories overseas, and "vigorously to champion the principle of self-determination."
The Avalon Foundation has made a grant of $2,500,000 to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Claude Bowers was one of those happy individuals who knew or met countless thousands in a long and fruitful life and never made a personal enemy. One could disagree with him -- about Jefferson, or the Reconstruction era, or the Spanish Civil War, or even about Chile, where he served fourteen years as Ambassador.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Labor Department designated today nearly one third of the nation's major industrial centers as areas of "substantial" unemployment.

BANGKOK, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Mr. Migunov said the Soviet Union wanted to buy rubber, wool, cotton, rawhides and spices in return for farm machinery and iron and steel products. The Soviet delegate said Moscow had signed trade agreements with Japan and Cambodia, a four-year agreement with Ceylon and a two-year agreement with Afghanistan.

The nation's production of crude oil and condensate increased 74,500 barrels to 6,924,535 a day, in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago output averaged 7,431,115 barrels a day.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 22 -- Increased attention to the quality of food at the point of production was recommended by research experts today as providing the best prospect for improving the quality of canned and other processed foods.
JAKARTA, Jan. 22 -- One of Indonesia's highest officials called on "Patriots" today to be prepared to prevent "another Hungary" from happening here.
Three thousand striking workers in the lamp and lampshade industry voted yesterday to end their week-old strike on the basis of an agreement negotiated with the aid of a Federal mediator.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Thursday, Jan. 23 -- The regime of Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez was overthrown early today as the culmination of a bloody revolt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Veterans Administration reported today that it had received fewer applications for mortgage guarantees in December than in any other month since the end of 1945.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a bill to impose tough new penalties on employers who fail to pay the Government the income and social security taxes they withhold from their employes.
The American Gas and Electric Company had records in nearly all of its 1957 operations, according to a preliminary annual report released yesterday.

Dates for next summer's sailing championships for men, women and juniors were made public last night at the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union in the New York Yacht Club. At the same time the delegates re-elected all officers on a slate headed by J. Amory Jeffries of Boston.
Net income of the St. Regis Paper Company last year amounted to about $21,000,000, compared with $25,350,000 in 1956, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday.

Now that the nation's No. 1 and No. 2 railroads -- the Pennsylvania and New York Central, in that order -- have decided to defer dividend action at this time, there is consderable speculation in the board rooms downtown as to "who is going to be the next one to defer or to cut?"
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 22 -- The Soviet Union offered long-term economic aid to Asia today.
SOUTH POLE, Jan. 21 -- Leaving South Ice on Christmas Day, we have traveled 575 miles to reach the South Pole on Jan. 19. We are therefore 932 miles from Shackleton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, entertained at dinner tonight eleven aircraft industry executives, including several who have contended publicly that United States aircraft and missile programs should be speeded up.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Dr. William G. Cooper, Little Rock school board president, said tonight that a 17-year-old girl suspended from integrated Central High School after a "shoving" incident with a Negro girl would return to classes Monday.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 22 (AP) -- John J. Grogan, Mayor of Hoboken and national president of the Shipyard Workers Union, became the first announced candidate for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate today.
A more intensive education, including the fundamentals of a self-sacrificing patriotism, was advocated yesterday as a guide for Americans.
The state accused four real estate syndicate promoters yesterday of fraudulent operations that might have cost 1,200 investors as much as $5,000,000.
A 1956 log book of the tug-boat Jim Steers, which disappeared with her crew of three in Long Island Sound on Sunday, was found washed up on a Kings Point, L. I., beach yesterday.
ROME, Jan. 22 (UP) -- An unrehearsed duel between two singers over who would occupy the center of the stage in the Rome Opera House became a court affair today.

A strike by 5,100 machinists and white-collar workers halted production of electronic instruments for guided missiles and planes yesterday at two Long Island plants of the Kollsman Instrument Company.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Rain washed out the entire program today in the Australian tennis championships for the second time in six days.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 22 -- Informed Moroccan political circles hope that Mr. Dulles will answer two questions when he arrives here tomorrow.
The Yankees yesterday found themselves with a sixth contract signer and a mystery on their hands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Secretary of State Dulles left today for the Middle East to try to reinvigorate the Baghdad Pact by his presence. After having met with the National Security Council and conferred for thirty minutes with President Eisenhower, the Secretary of State issued a statement in which he said:
BALTIMORE, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Two doctors denied today that X-rays showed bone breaks in the right ankle of the Boston Red Sox' Ted Williams and that his baseball career was "in jeopardy,"

Two women airline employes were struck by an automobile during the rain Tuesday night at Thirtieth Street and the Avenue of the Americas. One died several hours later and the other was seriously injured. They had planned to fly to Florida but their plane was grounded.

THE Cosmetic and Millinery Committee of the Fashion Group previewed beauty and bonnets for spring yesterday at the Sheraton-Astor hotel. Although many floral hats were shown, the most notable plant life was the olive branch that hat creators extended to coiffure designers.

The Russian-born ballerina Alexandra Danilova has been chosen as the winner of the seventh annual Capezio Dance Award. Presentation of the citation, which carries with it a cash award of $1,000, will be made on Feb. 18 at a luncheon at the Roof of the St. Regis Hotel.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- A deposed merchant ship captain began picketing the Ministry of Transport today. He blames the ministry for his dismissal from his ship.
WARSAW, Jan. 22 -- Poland is believed to have asked the Soviet Union for a large long-term credit to meet an increasing deficit in hard currencies.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 22 -- In the coming fiscal year Israel expects to spend more money, charge her citizens slightly lower taxes and continue to depend on large loans and contributions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- The Security Council unanimously called today for tighter United Nations control over the No Man's Land between Israel and Jordan in Jerusalem.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Newspapers were urged today to take steps "to make it easier" for national advertisers to use their medium.
DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- Walter P. Reuther prescribed increased purchasing power today as the key remedy for the nation's economic ills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Teamsters Union declared today it was a "malicious misstatement" to say the union wins its labor contracts from Montgomery Ward Co. by favored treatment.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 22 -- Rice production reached an all-time high in Taiwan last year, with a total output from two crops of 1,832,700 tons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by the State Department on Secretary of State Dulles' trip to the Middle East:

Two large utilities announced yesterday plans to finance expansion.

The Pennsylvania Railroad omitted action yesterday on the dividend that it normally declares at this time. Directors announced they had decided to defer dividend action "until a better appraisal of 1958 operations can be made."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren said today that he and the other Supreme Court Justices felt they should not be members of any commission to determine whether a President was disabled.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 22 -- John V. Kenny, who wrested leadership of the Hudson County Democratic organization from the late Mayor Frank Hague in 1949, resigned today as county leader.

MINEOLA, L. I., Thursday, Jan. 23 -- Two Nassau County detectives brought back from Utica, N. Y., a man for questioning in connection with the gunshot death of a 28-year-old Pan American World Airways flight engineer.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- The World Jewish Congress urged today the broadening of a United Nations study on discrimination in religion to include nonmember states.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Jan. 22 -- Army fliers, with the cooperation of the Navy, will soon be wearing a new type of flying helmet.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- Adriano Olivetti, Italy's "Mister Typewriter," entered national politics today. He announced here that his ten-year-old Community movement would present candidates for the parliamentary elections next spring in most or all constituencies.
In the midst of a financial panic a century ago a 21-year-old Massachusetts farm youth named H. W. Johns started out in business for himself in New York as a jobber of paints and roof coatings.
Traffic safety education has fallen on deaf ears because most drivers are convinced that they are good drivers, mass-communication executives were told yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The Legislature was told today that Senator MacNeil Mitchell's transit labor bill, if enacted in its present form, could force a New York City transit fare rise this year.
Additional curtailments in production of major nonferrous metals were announced yesterday as market demand continued slow.

THESE menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The first of a four-volume biography of Theodore Roosevelt by Carleton Putnam will be issued by Scribners Feb. 27. It is called "Theodore Roosevelt, The Formative Years 1858-1886." Mr. Putnam has based his work on T. R.'s private diaries, personal papers in the collection of Alice Roosevelt Longworth and Mrs. Joseph Alsop, as well as the Henry Cabot Lodge correspondence and the Roosevelt archives at Harvard University.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- A bill that would require the use of voting machines in primary elections in New York City after next Jan. 1 was introduced in the Legislature today.
THE HAGUE. the Netherlands, Jan. 22 -- About 75 per cent of the owners of Dutch business enterprises in Indonesia protested to the Indonesian Government tonight against the seizure of their property.

The American Brake Shoe Company has acquired, in a cash transaction, the assets of Gaines Foundry, Inc., near Los Angeles. The foundry, which has about seventy-five employes, making aluminum and magnesium castings for the aircraft industry, will be operated as the Gaines Works of the Light Metals department of American Brake Shoe.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 9 to 17 points (45 to 85 cents a bale) yesterday.
California raised $100,000,000 yesterday, by the sale of bonds, to help war veterans finance farms and homes.
Walter J. Mahoney, Majority leader of the State Senate, designated crime and the business recession last night as the big issues in this year's Governorship campaign.
THE appeal of professional football lies in the mechanical perfection and flawless execution of every maneuver. Oh, yeah ?
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Hundreds have been killed in the second day of rioting in Caracas, Venezuela, sources here said today.
LIMA, Peru, Jan. 22 -- In a surprise move Peru's Central Reserve Bank notified commercial banks yesterday that it was ending the sales of foreign exchange certificates.

The League of Women Voters has heretofore taken such a constructive part in behalf of court reorganization that it is disappointing to find one of the league's leaders, in her letter published Jan. 17, rejecting your call for enthusiastic support of the court reorganization plan proposed by the Temporary Commission on the Courts.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Holly Mims floored Bobby Boyd once tonight and held him to an upset ten-round draw in their return television fight at the Miami Beach Auditorium.
Thieves stole and then lost 42,000 pounds of coffee in Brooklyn yesterday because a trailer truck carrying the load reacted like a jack-in-the-box.
SUNNYVALE, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) -- A wind tunnel that generates speeds up to 15,000 miles an hour for testing missiles is being built at near-by Palo Alto.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers held George Yardley to 14 points and beat the Detroit Pistons, 115 -- 92, to gain third place by 2 points in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division tonight. A crowd of 3,097 watched the contest.

HONG KONG, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The chief justice of a Manchurian supreme court has accused the Chinese Communists of wrongfully punishing innocent people. Organized pressure forced him to back down on the charge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -The director of the Government's aircraft nuclear-propulsion project said today that research could profitably be increased on an atomic-powered rocket that could soar out into space.
ST. PAUL, Minn. Jan. 22 (AP) -- MacAlester College has announced the appointment of Dr. Mitchell Rice, 51 years old, of Buffalo, as its next president.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Clarence G. Morse, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, raised the possibility today that ocean-going ships some day might travel at twice the speed of sound.
" The average house in this neighborhood costs perhaps eight hundred dollars." Thus Thoreau, a little more than a century ago, scoffed at the extravagance of a conventional home.
BOSTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Tony De Marco, who took a career-wrecking lesson in boxing last night, may soon be teaching youngsters the finer points of the manly art.
The Monsanto Chemical Company yesterday reported consolidated net earnings for last year of $48,878,000, an increase of 6.8 per cent above the $45,781,000 cleared in 1956.
A syndicate headed by The First Boston Corporation is offering for public subscription today $10,000,000 of new 3 3/8 percent first mortgage bonds of the Iowa Power and Light Company due in 1988.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -Heavy snow and hazardous highways made for smaller livestock receipts at Chicago today and prices for hogs and cattle advanced to their highest levels in some time.
Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, renowned musical collaborators, have stepped forward with an offer to assist the financially beset New York Shakespeare Festival.
" EDDIE," last night's offering on Channel 4's "Kraft Television Theatre," was not a great drama, but it was a warm, occasionally saccharine little play competently conceived and executed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -United States Government and international economic development experts took an interested and sympathetic view today of the plans for a privately organized development bank in Iran.

Horace Stoneham, the president of the San Francisco Giants, was back in New York yesterday and was extraordinarily busy. But he still found time to announce that he had a new first baseman for this season.

The initial program in a new series, "First Films, 1897.1901," will be shown today through Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art. Screenings are scheduled for 3:00 and 5:30 P. M. daily. The program will include illustrations of the work of Skladanowsky, Lumiere and Edison.
Judge Nathan R. Sobel said yesterday that his colleague, Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz, "is the hardest working judge" of the five sitting in Kings County Court.
The New York Board of Rabbis appealed to Mayor Wagner yesterday to use his influence for the enactment of legislation enabling Jewish merchants to conduct business on Sunday.

Eight Fordham graduates received achievement awards at the 104th annual dinner of the Fordham College Alumni Association last night in the Biltmore Hotel. The presentations were made by the Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of the university.

GREENSBURG, Pa., Jan. 22 (AP) -- State Senator John Dent, a Democrat elected to Congress yesterday in a special election, said today that his victory in the heavily Democratic Twenty-first Pennsylvania District was a repudiation of the Eisenhower Administration.

The National Motor Boat Show in the New York Coliseum rounded a buoy yesterday. It probably was the best day of the ten-day run that started last Friday night. It attracted a crowd of serious-minded lookers and buyers, most of whom had been at the Coliseum at least once earlier this week.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- Otto Grotewohl, Premier of East Germany, advocated tonight that both parts of Germany vote on the inclusion of the country in a proposed Central European zone from which atomic weapons would be barred.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 22 (UP) -- The city today offered a revised version of its $2,000,000 parking proposal aimed at keeping the Redlegs in Cincinnati another five years.

Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York issued in 1957 a record volume of $826,800,000 in life insurance, Louis W. Dawson, president, reported yesterday. This was a gain of 26 per cent over the 1956 volume of $655,700,000, he said.
MIAMI, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A 3-year-old chestnut filly named Stay Smoochie came flying down the stretch today to capture the $26,150 Jasmine Stakes before 18,147 spectators at Hialeah.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The announcement of an agreement in principle between the United States and the Soviet Union on a broad exchange of cultural contacts is expected within a few days.

Sir Laurence Olivier arrived yesterday from London to act in John Osborne's play, "The Entertainer." His plane was prevented from landing here because of fog and was diverted to Baltimore. Sir Laurence completed his trip by train.
A child's music education, one expert contends, does not begin by buying him an instrument and forcing him to take lessons. This, he says, is "the worst thing in the world."

Horace C. Flanigan, chairman of Manufacturers Trust Company, hinted at the annual stockholders meeting yesterday that the bank might soon follow the lead of the Chase Manhattan Bank and cut its prime rate.

The Yankees have drawn two holiday double-headers at home, the American League's 1958 schedule, just released, reveals. The Bombers will play host to the Washington Senators on Memorial Day, May 30, and the Boston Red Sox will be the twin-bill opponents on Labor Day, Sept. 1.

Bankers Trust Company stockholders, at their annual meeting yesterday, approved a change in the bylaws ending the "stagger system" of electing directors. Bankers Trust thus becomes the first large bank in the city to put election of the entire board on a once-a-year basis.

The Kings County grand jury investigating lawlessness in Brooklyn public schools demanded again yesterday that a uniformed policeman be assigned to the schools because of what it described as "a crime wave."
Lazard Freres Co., investment banking firm, and the Chase International Corporation have organized a mission for establishing a financial institution in Iran to promote her industrial development.
PARIS, Jan 22 -- The French National Assembly gave routine approval tonight to the Government's course in North African, European and international security affairs.

BRILLAT-SAVARIN, considered in food circles as the greatest gastronomist of all time, once remarked that the discovery of the olive did more for humanity than the finding of "some as yet unsuspected star." Robert Louis Stevenson, despite his lean and hungry look, also admired the olive.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Reginald Maudling, Britain's Paymaster General, said today that he believed it would be a dark day for the Western world if Europe did not establish a free trade area.
George Leggett, 20-year-old leader of the "United Nordic Confederation," convinced a Queens magistrate yesterday that he was not in need of psychiatric observation.
MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- The Communist party said today that it was angry. Moonshining is one thing and sousing in the villages perhaps another, it declared.
MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Jan. 22 -- Segregation was denounced tonight as an evil that has confronted churches with what may prove to be their major challenge of the era.

For two months the police in the East New York section in Brooklyn have been on the alert for a group of youthful muggers and purse snatchers. Yesterday they arrested five juveniles who admitted twenty-five such crimes.
The Board of Health yesterday ordered rigid controls on the operation and sale of X-ray machines and fluoroscopes that are employed in the diagnosis and treatment of human ailments.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Members of the National Association of Home Builders heard Government officials and spokesmen for lending institutions predict today that:
The election of Jason W. Stockbridge as president of the New York Financial Advertisers was announced yesterday. He succeeds Donald R. Hassell, an assistant vice president of the Hanover Bank.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Theodore V. Houser today submitted his resignation as board chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., to be effective May 12, date of the stockholders meeting. He will however, remain as director.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 22 -- It appeared today that Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes had emerged in first place in Sunday's election.
WASHINGTON, Jam 22 -- Farm income dropped about $200,000,000 in 1957, Government estimates showed today.

RUGGIERO RICCI, in his violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall, measured himself against a difficult and serious program. Many times in the past he has stressed the virtuoso side of his nature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Senate rackets committee heard today about a padded ballot count, falsified meeting records, a check-cashing expedition through five states, and the purchase of a boat, a plane, and a cabin -- all by officers of Local 3, International Union of Operating Engineers.

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 2 (AP) -- James Sheffield, the team manager, today said Stan Benham would have to race it out with two other pilots for the right to represent the United States in the world bobsled championships.

Stock market prices responded yesterday to the lowering of the discount rate of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia with an early upward movement that had all the qualities of a shrug. The opening prices were the day's highest.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 22 -A Congressional committee was told today that the State Department was permitting Chinese athletes to compete in the United States but was excluding Chinese astronomers from a scientific meeting.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 22 -- Residents of Grant's Town, the main Negro district of Nassau, have tightened their belts in expectation that the general strike, now in its eleventh day, may continue another week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission underscored today the possibility of substantial revision in its rule pertaining to the registration of securities resulting from mergers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- The American Association for the United Nations called today for immediate disarmament negotiations between the eWst and the Soviet Union, "no matter how difficult or distasteful" they might be. .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -More than 200,000 Americans and Canadians, operating about 2,000 aircraft and hundreds of anti-aircraft weapons, ships and radar-warning stations, serve in the North American Air Defense Command.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -TheSena te Judiciary Committee gave unanimous approval today to President Eisenhower's nomination of William R. Rogers to be Attorney General. Final Senate action is expected tomorrow.
UNUSUAL sights and sounds from the island of Madagascar provided the most absorbing moments on "High Adventure" over Channel 2 last night.

Exiled leaders in New York of Venezuela's three major political parties unanimously endorsed yesterday a manifesto issued in Caracas by Eleazar Lopez Contreras, former Venezuelan President, calling for the formation of a civic front to safe the country from "anarchy and terrorism."
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 22 -The traditional Ice Carnival of the Princeton Skating Club, not held for three years, will he revived March 14 and 15 at Princeton University's Baker Rink.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Senate can no longer permit the threat of filibuster to hang over it, Senator Jacob K. Javits declared today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -President Eisenhower had the last word on publication of the Gaither Committee's defense report today, and the general feeling here was that it was the right one.

An appeal for $$6,000,000 to build twelve modern community centers in New York City and Westchester and Nassau Counties in the next three years was announced yesterday by the Associated Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Associations of Greater New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The American Council of Education proposed today the establishment of a permanent council of educational advisers to the President.

AMIABLE, mild - mannered Louis Jacob Lefkowitz acquired a passionate interest in the right of a purchaser to full value for his money very young in life. He has made the protection of investors and consumers against fraud his principal concern since the Legislature appoint ed him to succeed Senator Jacob K. Javits as Attorney General a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Robert B. Anderson said today that a nation-wide campaign to stimulate sale of United States savings bonds would get under way soon.

From time to time, it's mentioned that college basketball made its debut in Madison Square Garden in 1934. Such a statement stands up only when amended to read that college basketball was first presented at the Garden on an organized basis in 1934 when Ned Irish instituted the doubleheader program that still is in operation.
BLOOMINGDALE'S Bridal Shop has barred its door to the chemise. Unwilling to send brides to the altar trussed up in a sack, the store's bridal buyer remains faithful to fitted waists and full skirts.
Donald C. Keyhoe completed yesterday what he had started to say on television Wednesday night when he was cut off the air.

The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday partly supported Mayor Wagner's request for $40,000,000 more in state aid in 1958-59. In a letter to Governor Harriman, the commission declared that it favored granting the Mayor's request to the extent of $17,900,000.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 23 -Directors of the First Bank Stock Corporation today declared a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share to be paid to capital stockholders of record Feb. 14.
TRENTON, Jan. 23 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner is expected to submit to the State Legislature on Feb. 17 a record state budget of at least $400,000,000 for the 1958-59 fiscal year.
A feud among New York State Republicans broke into the open last night.

ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 23 -- The sixth annual Community Ball of the Junior League of the Oranges, to be held at Graulich's here Saturday evening, will be one of the league's major social events of the year. Many prefatory cocktail and dinner parties have been planned by members and their husbands to mark the event, which will raise funds for various organizations.
TRENTON, Jan. 23 -- The first rise in automobile insurance rates in New Jersey since 1952 was authorized today by the State Department of Banking and Insurance.

Thomas E. Murray, former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, called last night for a new accent on science within the framework of "the larger and older tradition of liberal and Christian knowledge."
Record net earnings of $64,160,000 were reported yesterday for last year by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, one of the "big three" tobacco manufacturers. In 1956 the company cleared $61,912,680.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 23 -For the second day in succession Left-wing demonstrations were held in Nicosia and other towns today to protest the brutal killing of two prominent trade unionists.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 23 -Government and Opposition leaders agreed today on the need for diplomatic conversations wih the Soviet Union but clashed on the fundamental ideas that should guide these conversations.
The Board of Education reasserted yesterday its opposition to the assignment of policemen in the city's schools as two more outbreaks of violence were reported in a Brooklyn school.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A committee representing several thousand small banks urged Congress today to impose far greater taxes on savings banks and savings and loan associations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The conference of the world's coffee-growing nations is well on its way toward creating an international coffee organization that may affect millions of consumers and producers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Investigating Senators put forward a seventeen-point plan today for winning what they called "a race for survival" with the Soviet Union.
The Carl S. Brown Company, buffeted in November by the resignation of 50 per cent of its billings, has bounced part way back by winning the account of B. T. Babbitt, Inc.

Eric Johnston, foreign aid adviser to President Eisenhower, urged public support last night for the President's proposal to double last year's $300,000,000 Development Loan Fund in this year's mutual security program.

The National Labor Relations Board has issued an order which is a good example of one way to fight against "sweetheart" contracts -- those which benefit racketeering union officials and employers, but do not represent the will of the workers involved.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Seven additional grounds for revoking or suspending driving licenses were proposed today by Governor Harriman.

Noel Coward is on the sick list with laryngitis and fatigue. He was able to appear at yesterday's matinee of his comedy, "Nude With Violin." But performances from last night through Jan. 30 have been canceled at the Belasco.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain and France filed protests with the Soviet Charge d'Affaires in East Berlin today concerning the march of armed factory workers Sunday in East Berlin at a political demonstration.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23 -- The harried men who have the toughest jobs in India -trying to pull this country out of a deep economic hole -- worked late tonight, preparing for a mission to the United States and winding up an agreement with France.
Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the State University of New York, has resigned and the resignation has been accepted by the board of trustees, effective Sept. 1.
MACY'S is not waiting for the groundhog's decision. Spring arrives at the department store today, when the most floral-festooned rooms to be seen in many years will be opened to the public.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23--The United States proposed today that the veto power in the Security Council be dropped in some specific issues.
Like a stitch in time, a day saved can be important.
The Avco Manufacturing Corporation operated in the black last year, after suffering a sharp loss in 1956, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
TRENTON, Jan. 23 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner hailed John V. Kenny today as a "truly good" Democrat who had made a major contribution to the building of a strong Democratic party in New Jersey.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 23 -- If the Soviet Union is interested in bilateral contacts with the United States on disarmament such procedure "shall not be rejetced," Dr. Halvard M. Lange said today.

The city's Investigation Commissioner hinted yesterday that he had uncovered evidence of irregularities by the Nassau Management Company, Inc., in the handling of fifteen city contracts for relocating apartment house tenants.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 23 -- The Rightist candidate, Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, said today at a press conference that he was confident Congress would pick him as President.

The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation raised its sales and revenues last year by 2 per cent to a record total of $683,078,735 from $668,937,533 in 1956. Earnings from operations, however, declined 7.7 per cent, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Merger of the Wayne Pump Company, makers of gasoline dispensing pumps and the SymingtonGould Corporation, railroad equipment producers, with combined assets of about $35,000,000 was announced yesterday.

CARACAS, Jan. 23 (AP) -Sixty bodies were reported found in the police headquarters building after the fight.

The Girdler Construction division of the National Cylinder Gas Company announced yesterday it had received a contract to engineer and equip the first large-scale hydrogen sulphide plant to be used in ore processing.

LIVERPOOL, England, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The world featherweight champion, Hogan (Kid) Bassey of Nigeria, outpointed Pierre Cossemyns of Belgium tonight in a ten-round nontitle bout. The exact weights were not announced but each weighed close to the 128 pounds stipulated for the match.

State Senator MacNeil Mitchell hinted yesterday that the business community might have to assume part of the transit burden to prevent a major subway fare increase.
MARRAKESH, Morocco, Jan. Jan. 23 -- Secretary of State Dulles spent the day in this sunny resort, philosophizing and reminiscing with Foreign Minister Ahmed Balafrej.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The United States Court of Appeals dismissed today a constitutional challenge to the law that gives preference to veterans in the United States Civil Service.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday plans for the sale of $40,000,000 of revenue bonds Wednesday. The issue will be dated Feb. 1, 1958, and will come due serially on Aug. 1 from 1959 to 1978.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, proposed today that the Atomic Energy Commission be given the task of "peaceful conquest of outer space."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 23 -- Rejoicing and violence, cheers and death marked the fall of the Venezuelan dictator in Caracas today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A Government announcement that No. 3 and 4 grades of corn have been removed from its export sales list and will be stored indefinitely helped raise the price of the grain a cent a bushel on all the futures contracts today.
FASHION creators have found more than an inspiration in art for their designs. They have sold and collected it as well.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Governor Harriman will recommend a $15,000,000 pay adjustment for state employes in his new budget, it was disclosed today. The budget will be submitted to the Legislature on Monday.

Lyndon Johnson, majority leader of the Senate, is taking both a politically astute and morally invulnerable position in asking that partisanship and recrimination be kept out of the current examination of our national defense status.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 23 -- A bill to create the Metropolitan Transit District of New York and New Jersey will be introduced in the New Jersey Senate on Monday by Senator Walter H. DETROIT, Jan. 23 -- The United Automobile Workers adopted today a broad collective bargaining program that appeared certain to precipitate a bitter battle in this year's automobile negotiations.

A religious organization in France and a program to combat juvenile delinquency here will share in the proceeds of a luncheon and fashion show in the ballroom of the Biltmore on Feb. 15. The event is being sponsored by the Fellowship of the Fifth Avenue, Presbyterian Church.

Cocoa futures opened lower on the New York Cocoa Exchange but then rose sharply. All positions were up the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit except the neglected March, 1959, contract, which rose 78 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

"Telephone Time," which has Dr. Frank Baxter as its host, will be terminated April 1. The film series is televised by the American Broadcasting Company on Tuesdays from 9:30 to 10 P. M.

JEFFERSON VALLEY, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- Conversion of this sleepy agricultural hamlet into a tax-balanced metropolis, preplanned down to the final classroom desk and commuter's parking space, was called for by planning contracts signed today.

General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen refused yesterday to reduce the prison sentence of James J. Moran, once confidant of former Mayor William O'Dwyer. Moran was convicted of extortion and conspiracy in 1952.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Sir John Cockroft will relinquish his post as director of the Harwell atomic research establishment next month to devote more time to his policy-making responsibilities as the British Atomic Energy Authority's member for scientific research.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Jan. 23 -- Israeli officials expressed sorrow and anger at yesterday's United Nations Security Council resolution calling for tighter United Nations control of the No Man's Land south of Jerusalem.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 -- A Communist Chinese chemical industry mission has found definite coolness among Japanese industrialists.

CARACAS, Jan. 23 -- Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal, named President of the junta that now rules Venezuela, is a good-looking, tall well-mannered man of 46 whose family has been identified for generations with the Venezuelan Navy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, introduced a bill today to carry out the Administration's proposed five-year extension of the reciprocal trade agreements. He said hearings would start Feb. 17.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The merged labor federation said today that it would form a new international council for laundry and dye house workers at a meeting tomorrow in Milwaukee.
Despite the revolution in Venezuela, oil operations there were going ahead yesterday at only a slightly reduced rate, according to reports received here by companies concerned.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A racquet-smashing outburst by temperamental Mervyn Rose and the defeat of the young Americans, Barry MacKay and Mike Green, marked the doubles semi-finals of the Australian tennis championships at White City today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Washington Senators traded Pete Runnels today in the first of a series of "housecleaning" deals that might even send Roy Sievers, the home-run king, to the Yankees.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (UP) -The middleweight champion, Carmen Basilio, and a former titleholder, Ray (Sugar) Robinson, signed formal contracts today for a fifteen-round title bout March 25. Each figures to pick up more than a quarter of a million dollars for his appearance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -The United States has proposed continuation of talks with Communist China at the ambassadorial level.
MOUNT POCONO, Jan. 23--The North American Area Council of the World Presbyterian Alliance called upon its member churches today to combat segregation wherever it existed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A new formula for farm-price supports was proposed today by the American Farm Bureau Federation.
Maria Callas arrived here by plane from Chicago last night. She was accompanied by her husband, Giovanni Meneghini, and carried her toy French poodle.

The uniformed quotas of the Police and Fire Departments were raised to new highs yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The quotas represent the authorized strength of the uniformed forces, as compared with actual strength.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 23 -- Simonetta's launching of her new balloon silhouette last night was sensational.

It will be thirteen years next Aug. 6 since the first atomic bomb ever used in war was dropped on Hiroshima. On Wednesday of this week one of the victims of that attack, Tsunejiro Nagayama, a man of 52 years, died of a liver disease which his doctor said had been caused by exposure to radiation.
Until someone else comes along to disprove the claim, let's call Charles F. Eaton the champion long distance user of the inland waterway to Florida.

HENRY BEETLE HOUGH, editor and publisher of The Vineyard Gazette for the last thirty-eight years, is one of the best known country editors in this nation -- because of the excellence of his weekly newspaper and because of two delightful books, "Country Editor" and its sequel, "Once More The Thunderer."

Cooperative effort between Federal authorities and various states to develop new workable boating legislation was prophesied at yesterday's meeting of the American Boat and Yacht Council at the National Motor Boat Show.

In the casual semantics of breakfast table conversation the word "new" has ceased to be heard in regular juxtaposition to the word "year"; the calendar in the kitchen, so fresh and novel a few weeks ago, has became a familiar part of the domestic decor; adjustment is virtually complete in the business of consistently writing an "8" where for more than fifty weeks one had been using a "7."
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses.
WINNETKA, Ill., Jan. 23 -- A plan to enable Winnetka's public school teachers to earn up to $12,000 a year, plus fringe benefits comparable to those in business, was offered here today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- The continuing importance of the major film production-distribution company was illustrated again today by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
LONDON, Jan. 23--After a hard-hitting debate, the House of Commons expressed tonight its confidence in the Conservative Government's economic policies.
GREENVILLE, S. C., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Four Ku Klux Klansmen convicted in the beating of a Negro man were sentenced today to prison terms.
NEWARK, Jan. 23 -- How much sound is a nuisance?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A subcommittee of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee said unanimously today that it was still not clear that tax cuts would be the right medicine for the current recession.
Four thousand transistor radios, each small enough to fit into a man's shirt pocket, were stolen early yesterday from a Queens building. Their total value was estimated at $160,000.

A new glass and aluminum building at 830 Third Avenue was dedicated yesterday as the national headquarters of the Girl Scouts of the U. S.A. Governor Harriman and officials representing 3,000,000 members, led by the Scouts' president, Mrs. Charles U. Culmer of Libertyville, Ill., spoke at the ceremony.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 23 -- A junta composed of five officers and two civilians took control fo Venezuela today. The country's overthrown dictator, Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez, fled to the Dominican Republic.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A national shortage of 140,000 public school classrooms was reported today by the Office of Education.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits introduced a bill today that would empower the Attorney General to seek Federal Court injunctions against civil rights violations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -Senator J. William Fulbright declared today that five years of the Eisenhower Administration had left the country "fat and immobile" from a diet of "sugar-coated half-truths."

Your editorial of Jan. 13 "Social Security Needs," while correct in pointing out the necessity for increased workmen's compensation and unemployment insurance benefits in New York State, ends with a misleading inference. You state:

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- Hanif Mohammad, 23-year-old Pakistani batsman, today set a world record for a marathon innings in first-class cricket and scored the second highest run total for any test match in history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Spokesmen for business protested to Congress today that the internal revenue laws gave tax advantages to competing cooperative corporations.
MIAMI, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Hasty House Farms' Alarullah, Bill Hartack's third winner of the afternoon, romped to a sixlength victory in the $5,000 Tequesta purse today at Hialeah.
Gyroscopes as small as rolls of film that keep big off assembly lines of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -Legislation calling on Congress to appropriate sufficient funds to broaden United States participation in the Brussels World's Fair was introduced in the House of Representatives today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The view in diplomatic circles here today was that the revolt that swept the Venezuelan dictator, Marcos Perez Jimenez, from power was far from settled.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Jan. 23 -- Prime Minister Bakshi Ghulam Mohammed won another round against Sheikh Abdullah today when a majority of the members of the seventy-fiveman Legislative Assembly expressed confidence in his leadership.
A New Rochelle landlord is making another attempt to overthrow provisions of the state law against discrimination banning racial discrimination in publicly assisted housing.

P. C. Spencer, president of the Sinclair Oil Corporation estimated yesterday that consolidated net income of the company last year was $79,000,000 to $80,000,000. He said such earnings would equal about $5.20 each on the average of 15,300,000 shares outstanding during 1957.

Two theatre benefits will aid the Child Study Association of America. Mrs. Frank E. Karelsen, chairman, and her committee have selected the Feb. 27 performance of "The Day the Money Stopped" at the Belasco and the March 11 performance of "The Entertainer" at the Royale as the benefit events.
Unlike the proverbial coals to Newcastle, British cars are pouring into the auto-rich United States at record rates.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -The United States intends to remain in Antarctica after the end of the International Geophysical Year, on Dec. 31.
Two state investigations into reported corruption in the city administration of Utica, N. Y., were disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -Agreements for expanded cultural, technical, scientific exchanges have been worked out in negotiations since Oct. 28 between United States Ambassador William S. B. Lacy and Soviet Ambassador Georgi N. Zaroubin.
PANAMA, Jan. 23 (AP) --Arnold Palmer of Latrobe, Pa., shot a 6-under-par 66 today to take the lead in the $10,000 Panama open golf tournament.
Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, denounced the Supreme Court yesterday as "the greatest single threat to our Constitution."

DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation today reported net profit of $4,948,736 for its first fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31. The earnings, equal to 88.6 cents a common share, compare with a loss of $2,994,613 in the like quarter a year earlier.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 23 -- The Aluminum Company of America has ended 2,200 jobs at its plants in Alcoa, Tenn., since November, with 400 more due to be dropped next Thursday, officials of Local 309, United Steelworkers of America, said today. Company officials declined to comment.

The largest graduating class in the eight-year history of the American Language Center at Columbia University received certificates yesterday. The 100 students representing thirty-six countries had completed an eight-week intensive course in English.
President Eisenhower added his telegraphed congratulations last night to other expressions of good wishes at a dinner honoring Bernard Katzen, special consultant to the State Department.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The University of Chicago plans to exchange students with the Universities of Moscow and Leningrad beginning next fall, John P. Netherton, dean of Students, said today.
PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Finance Minister Pierre Pflimlin said today the Government was seeking to wipe out France's foreign payments deficit by the end of this year.
Seamstresses, elevator operators, doormen, chefs and maids at the Pierre Hotel were still talking yesterday about a woman who died last June.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks announced today that S. D. Bechtel, president of the Bechtel Corporation of San Francisco, has been elected chairman of the Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council for 1958.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Fowler B. McConnell, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., is to become chairman of the board.
Midtown New York witnessed yesterday all the fanfare and trappings of a shipyard launching as American Export Lines formally opened new offices at 666 Fifth Avenue.

BELA BARTOK'S Violin Concerto is a major work by a major contemporary composer. Like the Violin Concerto by Ernest Bloch, which was performed earlier this season at a New York Philharmonic concert, it deserves to be a recurrent visitor at orchestral events.

The first reaction to the thrilling and heroic revolution in Venezuela must be a tribute to the people of the country who fought -- and in many cases died -- for freedom. The second must be the hope that Venezuela is through, once and for all, with military dictators and will create a true democracy with the unified support of her political parties.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 23 -- A new name looms large on the Italian fashion horizon. It is Antonio De Luca.

Two new films open today. "A Farewell to Arms," David O. Selznick's production of the Ernest Hemingway novel, starring Rock Hudson. Jennifer Jones and Vittoria De Sica, is at the Roxy Theatre. Charles Vidor directed and Ben Hecht wrote the script of the Twentieth Century-Fox presentation, made in CinemaScope and color.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Assembly prepared today to act next week on three bills to tighten the state law on the use of eavesdropping devices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- An ousted San Francisco union official, who said he was the victim of a "calculated conspiracy," denied under oath today sworn testimony that he had received a $9,884.76 "kickback" on the sale of union property.
Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, predicted yesterday that the 1960 Olympic Games in Rome would be the largest and best in the history of Olympic competition.

The Laclede Gas Company may speed a planned permanent financing "in view of more favorable money market conditions," H. R. Derrick, president, told an annual meeting of shareholders at St. Louis yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Svend's most sensational hats are not for the subway circuit. They are for the lucky few who can sail through the streets in a chauffeur-driven limousine.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 23 -- Israel said today she agreed whole-heartedly with the Soviet Union's professed desire for peaceful coexistence in the Middle East. But she said this idea would be greatly aided if Moscow would urge the Arab nations to conclude a peace treaty with Israel.
Members banks across the nation operated under lessened reserve pressure in the week ended Wednsday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

ALMA, Ga., Jan. 23 -- The Georgia State Fox Hunters Association and its guests met in grave convention just before daylight this morning on a dirt road along the edge of pine woods about ten miles north of here. It was something to see.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- British Government securities continued their advance today in an otherwise dull stock market. With a few exceptions most other groups drifted slightly lower.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The $158,490 Santa Anita Maturity shaped up today as a duel between Round Table and Promised Land as seven 4-yearolds were entered in Saturday's race at a mile and a quarter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -President Eisenhower nominated today new ambassadors to revolt-torn Venezuela and to Jordan, Thailand, Greece, Libya, Guatemala and Rumania.
PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- A judge today ordered the State Parole Board to justify extension of the prison term of Joseph (Socks) Lanza until 1960.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 23 -Gov. Luis Munoz Marin has asked the Puerto Rican Legislature to start a program to reduce gambling, which has been estimated to involve $100,000,000 here yearly.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- Yemen charged today i that British troops made a new !attack Dec. 30 on her territories north of Aden. MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- One of the worst earthquakes ever recorded rumpled the earth's surface in the Gobi area of Outer Mongolia last month.
FOR twelve years or so the tower's directory in the R. C. A. Building, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, has gravely listed among other tenants "N. E. B. Armstrong, Room 5005."
MORE than a dozen artists are effectively represented, chiefly by work in varying expressionist veins, in the lively group show at the Charles Alan Gallery, 766 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -The House subcommittee investigating Federal regulatory agencies refused today to lend any official endorsement to a staff memorandum containing allegations of illegal conduct by members of the Federal Communications Commission.
Many prominent persons were hosts last night at the eighth annual Animal Kingdom Ball, which took place in the Ballroom Suite of the Pierre.

A shoeless inmate of the House of Detention for Women, 10 Greenwich Avenue, climbed and dropped four floors to freedom early yesterday morning in what was described as the first successful break from the twenty-five-year-old institution.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -Lieut. Gov. Roy E. Furman of Pennsylvania, broke publicly today with his Democratic colleague, Gov. George M. Leader.

The American edition of Jacob Presser's first novel, which received the 1957 Van Der Hoogt Prize of the Dutch Society for Literature, will be issued Feb. 10 by World. Called "Breaking Point," it is set in the infamous Nazi concentration camp of Westerbork.

A move to get the International Brotherhood of Teamsters back into the merged labor federation is expected to follow the establishment of a board of monitors to ride herd on James R. Hoffa as the union's president.

I am certain all thoughtful citizens concerned for the future of public education will agree with the sentiments expressed in The New York Times editorial of Jan. 22 under the apt caption "Between Three Stools."
President Eisenhower praised Dr. Buell G. Gallagher last night as "a leader in the field of education and human affairs" who "has won the respect and affection of a splendid community."
A mandatory safety code to protect waterfront workers from on-the-job injuries is being prepared by the New York State Board of Standards and Appeals.

BEGINNING today at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West Fifty-third Street, the large and handsomely installed exhibition of the art of Louis Comfort Tiffany (1848-1933) reopens a chapter of American taste.
Many boxholders and patrons have been announced for the benefit recital to be given by Artur Rubinstein, pianist, in Carnegie Hall on the evening of Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Soviet Ambassador Georgi N. Zaroubin, who is leaving this country shortly to return to Moscow, will be able to give the Kremlin a first-hand report on Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering today $5,700,000 of Great Northern Railway equipment trust certificates priced to yield from 3 per cent on Aug. 1, 1958, out to 3.5 per cent on Feb. 1, 1973.

MARIO SERRANO, Mexican bass baritone, who has sung extensively in Latin America and has toured in Canada and the Midwestern United States, sang his first New York program last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Business loans outstanding at the seventeen leading New York City banks fell $235,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $58,000,000 in the comparable 1957 week.
This harbor played host at two maiden ship arrivals yesterday, but only one of the vessels was accorded the traditional greeting.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 23 -The Kenya Government announced today that no native political meetings would be permitted in Nairobi until further notice.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 -Terminals of Metropolitan Lines and Asbury Rapid Transit System prepared today to resume early tomorrow the transportation service that was cut off fifty-four days ago by a strike of 1,200 drivers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Porter M. Jarvis, president of Swift Co., told the annual stockholders meeting today that rising costs would be met by consolidations and improved efficiency in operations and distribution.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 23 -Suffolk County's recently reorganized ten-man Board of Supervisors completed here today the first leg of a county-wide inspection tour.
The promise of lower temperatures by the weatherman made it appear almost a certainty yesterday that recreational skiers were going to enjoy another big week-end of the snow running sport.

The Coast Guard halted its hunt yesterday for the thirtyseven-foot tug Jim Steers. But a Navy minesweeper searching the area in Long Island Sound where the craft disappeared with her crew of three last Sunday reported six possible sonar contacts.

THE American public's taste for a juicy steak or a rare roast beef is becoming more expensive daily. The spiraling cost of meat, especially beef, definitely places this commodity in the luxury bracket. At present, the cost of round, sirloin and porterhouse steaks ranges well over $1 a pound.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The White House echoed with the melody "The Eyes of Texas" tonight as Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn took his place of honor at a state dinner given him by the President and Mrs. Eisenhower.
Horace Stoneham and his transplanted Giants may start collecting from pay television in San Francisco this year.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Mrs. Barbara Romack Porter of Sacramento, Calif., kept the favorite's role in the twenty-sixth annual Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament by defeating Phyllis Preuss of Pompano Beach, Fla., 4 and 3, today.
WANTAGH, L. I., Jan. 23 -- A letter that had lain in a Brooklyn post office more than forty years has finally reached its destination here.

OTTAWA, Jan. 23 -- Two leading economists reported to an official commission today that United States agricultural and tariff policies and some aspects of private financial operations were harmful to Canada's economy.
Patrolman James Clark was minding his own business yesterday in front of a building at 80 Warren Street when a seaman walked over to him.

The Soviet drive to neutralize Europe and the Middle East by making much of the area a denuclearized zone is running up against increasing Western opposition. The most determined opposition to this proposal comes from the Government of Chancellor Adenauer.
Relatively good news gave the stock market fair gains in sluggish trading yesterday.
Negotiations on a settlement of disputes arising from Egypt's nationalization of the Universal Suez Canal Company will take place in Rome during the third week of February.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- This city shook politically today with reverberations from the change in city managers at last night's meeting of the City Council.
