CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The National Association of Home Builders asked today that the loan guaranty rights of the G. I. Bill of Rights for World War II veterans be extended.
Stocks pushed ahead most of yesterday, with a surge in mid-afternoon apparently based on a report that steel scrap prices were rising.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- Comrade Omarov is in trouble.

The chairman of the state Legislature's watchdog committee said yesterday he was considering calling a public hearing into reports that public officials of Utica were protecting gambling and vice rackets.
Older persons who tend to become nonfunctioning respond more readily to group psychotherapy than to individual treatment, a therapist said here yesterday.
COMO, Italy, Jan. 24 -- Official contract bridge teams of the United States, Europe and South America will start a ten-day, 288-hand contest for the 1958 world championship tomorrow.

In The Times of Jan. 16 it is reported that the Administration, in drafting the new budget, has markedly reduced the funds proposed by the National Science Foundation for basic research and research facilities. The comment on this by Dr. Alan T. Waterman, director of the foundation, should be carefully considered.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The United States is trying to hasten the Soviet Union's response to President Eisenhower's proposal for diplomatic talks preparatory to a conference of heads of government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Ernie (Sonny Boy) Williams threatened the lightweight champion, Joe Brown, in the early rounds of their nontitle fight tonight before losing on a technical knockout in the fifth round.

HAVANA, Jan. 24 -- A thousand Government troops were moved yesterday into Manzanillo, a port on the south coast of Oriente Province, in anticipation of a rebel attack, according to reports from that city.
PEIPING, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- Premier Chou En-lai refused today to consider the appeals of three visiting American mothers for the release of their imprisoned sons.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- The Budd Company today reported earnings of $8,865,807, equal to $1.91 a common share, on sales of $317,762,211, during 1957. This compared with earnings of $9,163,274, or $1.97 a share on sales of $307,829,326 in 1956.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A bill to upset the Supreme Court's recent ruling against treble damage actions under the Robinson-Patman Act was introduced in the House today by Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, co-author of the Act.

WARSAW, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- Several hundred workers at an electrical machine factory at Wroclaw are threatening proest action unless their demands, including a 20 per cent wage increase, are met by tomorrow, according to information reaching here tonight. Wroclaw is the former German Breslau in Silesia.
OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 24 -- Great Lakes shipping interests of the United States and Canada have again failed to achieve accord on the question of tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- A secret list of witnesses who testified about Soviet repression of the Hungarian revolt of 1956 was quietly burned this afternon on the roof of the United Nations Building.
A landlords' motion seeking the decontrol of about 5,000 so-called luxury dwellings was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 24 -- The long-suppressed animosity that focused on Chancellor Konrad Adenauer erupted during the debate on foreign policy in the Bundestag that ended early today.

How an automobile will respond to the steering wheel can be measured before the car actually is built, by means of an electronic analog computer, a miniature automobile and a full size steering wheel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Techniques for equipping the United States' big nuclear bombers with devices to ward off attacking missiles are understood to be well advanced.
Three facets of labor racketeering were involved in indictments yesterday by the Federal rackets grand jury against management and union officials.
The 250 shareholders in the Concourse Plaza Hotel took steps yesterday to prevent the 400-room Bronx building from closing and jeopardizing more than a million dollars they have invested in it.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 24 (AP) -- A majority of the state Democratic executive committee reportedly agreed tonight to reject a segregation oath that would bar Negro candidates unless they abandoned their integration fight.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 24 -- Puerto Rico's birth rate was reported today to be declining as a result of a continuing heavy rate of sterilization and the migration of young people to the mainland.

The election of four directors of Johnson Johnson International has been announced by Robert J. Dixson, president. They are Robert J. Mortimer. L. E. S. Santamaria. John A. van Raalte, all vice presidents, and Paul J. Quinn, vice president and treasurer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Dr. Arthur Edward Ruark, who fuses a professional intensity with a whimsical humor, is sometimes so staggered at what he is trying to do that he has to sit back and laugh.

Plans for the construction of a $3,500,000 building at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and 100th Street to house the psychiatric services of Mount Sinai Hospital have been filed with the Department of Buildings.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Although factions in this city of 72,195 continue in conflict over schools, integration, taxes, politics and City Managers, most of them were agreed today on a problem that has been debated for forty years.
WILLIAM STANLEY HASELTINE (1835 - 1900) was an American painter who early succumbed to the enchantment of Italy and belonged to the group of cultivated expatriates who settled in Rome.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Welfare officials relented today and decided to put Annabelle Whit-ford Buchan, recently widowed, back on the old-age relief roles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Unemployment among workers covered by the unemployment compensation system reached a record for the second week in a row, the Labor Department reported tonight.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 24 -- The Nassau County police today reported one new development in the search for the slayer of Clyde W. Rose, flight engineer for Pan American Airways. A .32 caliber automatic pistol owned by Arthur T. Jones of Clinton, N. Y., was turned over in Syracuse to Nassau detectives.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets, here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The wholesale price index of average primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent to 118.8 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

A team of British industrial scientists reported yesterday it had achieved in a small $28,000 glass-walled tube demonstrations of controlled fusion nearly as impressive as results claimed by British and United States agencies.
MADRID, Jan. 19 -- The Spanish Government has taken a significant step toward dropping its traditional policy of "proud isolation" and merging Spain economically with Europe.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Court of Claims today awarded the Uintah and White River bands of Ute Indians of Eastern Utah a $3,250,000 judgment against the United States.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- New crop wheat futures prices, spurred by proposed legislation in their behalf, ran up good gains on the Board of Trade here today.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Jan. 24 -- The opportunity to develop a sports hobby is one of the magnets that draws persons from the city to the suburbs. Long Island's stepped-up program of adult education offers everything from archery to zither-playing. An offshoot of the program is the Long Island Swordsmen, a fencing club.
Directors of the International Railways of Central America took no action yesterday on a dividend on the 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 24 -- A new wave of political conflicts and street riots swept this capital today. The atmosphere was one of general insecurity and chaos in the wake of the revolution that yesterday ousted the dictator, Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 24 -- The Mayor of Fair Lawn and four other persons were indicted today over irregularities in municipal garbage contracts.
HONG KONG, Jan. 24 -- The city wall and four massive city gates of the 2,000-year-old capital of the Han dynasty have been uncovered in excavations near Sian in northwest China.

OTTAWA, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports rose to a record value of $4,397,200,000 in the first eleven months of 1957, owing mainly to sharply increased shipments of uranium, cattle, crude oil and seeds.
Progress has been made and is continuing in the abatement of water pollution in the metropolitan New York area, according to the annual report of the Interstate Sanitation Commission.

The Feb. 7 performance of "The Music Man" will be a benefit for the scholarship fund of the Scarborough (N. Y.) Country Day School. Mrs. Charles R. Reder is chairman of the event. She is assisted by Mrs. Henry Homes Jr. and Mrs. Roland Stearns.
One of America's major unions is thinking of asking the public to help shape its bargaining demands before they are presented to management.
A wildcat strike of conductors against the New York Central Railroad disrupted main line passenger service between Albany and Buffalo yesterday morning for seven hours.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 24 (_ _) -- Nine drivers of a starting field of 303 in the Monte Carlo auto rally completed the first part of the grueling test for touring cars without a penalty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Spokesmen for three dairy cooperatives operating in the New York milkshed outlined today a proposed $1,000,000-a-year milk sales promotion and research program.
After years of intermittent violence, costing more than a thousand casualties, the situation in the strategic British Crown Colony of Cyprus is beginning to drift toward chaos.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Sir John Cockcroft, chief of Britain's research establishment at Harwell, said today he was "90 per cent certain" that thermonuclear fusion of heavy hydrogen nuclei had been achieved.
Gale force winds bearing a mixture of snow, sleet and rain were expected to hit the metropolitan area today as a blustery winter storm moved up the East Coast.

Two divers began an underwater search yesterday for the missing tugboat Jim Steers. but failed to find a trace. The craft disappeared Sunday in Long Island Sound with a three-man crew.
The Junior League of Brooklyn held its annual ball last night in the ballroom of the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- Dr. Vivian Fuchs set out today on a 1,200mile trek from the South Pole.
SO MUCH has been said about the "expressionist" character of German art that the current exhibition, "Six Centuries of German Prints," at the New York Public Library is a provocative event.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that one of the results it wanted from an East-West heads-of-government meeting was the lifting of the United States ban on shipments of strategic materials to the Soviet bloc.
Evelyn King, soprano, making her debut as a soloist at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, presented a program of songs in Italian, German, French, Russian, Spanish and English.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- William DeKoning Jr., president of a Long Island labor union, promised Senate investigators today to "do everything in my power" to reinstate three expelled members who had challenged his rule.

PARENTS who flare up occasionally at their youngster's misdeeds -- and who does not ? -- may take heart. A burst of honest parental wrath does not inflict a deep emotional wound on an otherwise healthy child. OWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Mrs. Joseph Barbara Sr., wife of the host to the Apalachin gangland convention, refused today to answer questions before the grand jury on the ground that her answers might incriminate her.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 24 (UP) -- Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit of Toronto beat two seasoned golfers today to lead the way into the semifinals of the women's Helen Lee Doherty amateur tournament.

Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, has sold the fifteen-story Excelsior Hotel at 45 West Eighty-first Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. The hotel, formerly known as the Standish Hall, was bought by Excelsior Syndicate, Inc., represented by Charles H. Kelman, attorney.
A three - story apartment house in Queens, in a "dangerous condition" with one of its walls buckling, was inspected yesterday by the Department of Buildings.
The Police Department will pinpoint city areas where poor street lighting was conducive to crime last year.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Harriman disclosed today that his budget for next year would recommend state expenditures of $656,000,000 for education.
A host of new products and machines designed to turn out newer ones are emerging from the laboratories.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, has told a House committee "there isn't any doubt" that the Soviet Union plans a series of limited wars.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The West German Bundesrat (upper house of Parliament) voted today to file suit against President Theodor Heuss in the Supreme Court on the ground that he had violated the Constitution.
ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 24 (UP) -- Tony Vincent of New York defeated the Colombian Davis Cup star, William Alverez, today to gain a semi-final berth in the Florida State tennis championships.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Village officials have reached an agreement with the New York Central Railroad that will enable them to convert the virtually unused Central station here into quarters for the community's library.
Wagner Lutheran College marked its seventy-fifth anniversary yesterday.

Four men allegedly involved in the theft of an "in-bond" shipment from a Hudson River pier eight months ago were rounded up yesterday for questioning, the Waterfront Commission reported. A spokesman for the bi-state agency said the arrests involved action by Customs agents, New York City and Nassau County police and members of the commission's investigation staff.
A man went beserk in a Yorkville tenement yesterday, stabbing his daughter to death, killing a fellow tenant with a pistol and striking his wife with a hatchet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The Authors League of America, Inc., said today that the present Federal income tax set-up was discouraging "creative writing." It appealed to Congress to give authors a "depletion allowance" like the oil industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The United States and Britain reported today encouraging progress in their cooperative research to harness for peaceful purposes the vast thermonuclear power of the hydrogen bomb.
Andrew Jackson High School scored a victory in the final event to capture the Public Schools Athletic League swimming championship last night at the New York University pool. University Heights.

A letter written by the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham won a suspended prison term yesterday for a man who stole $500 from a Graham rally here. After sentencing Louis Silver, 46 years old, to two and a half to five years in prison, Bronx County Judge Eugene G. Schulz said, "I am going to suspend this sentence."
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 -- Romulo Gallegos, former President of Venezuela, said today he would not return to Caracas "until the political situation there has evolved."
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- If you are emotionally upset, you should not drive an automobile, a committee of the American Medical Association said today.

BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP) -- A civilian scientist for the Air Force said today that a delay of up to eighteen months in United States pioneering in the fusion techniques disclosed today by the British was due to classification problems and "disinterest."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The Air Force has chosen the Radio Corporation of America as contractor for a system to detect enemy ballistic missiles.

Twelve budding executives in the brewing industry reached an important milestone in their careers last week -- they made their own beer -- and what's more, drank it. Comprising the latest class at the United States Brewers' Academy in Mount Vernon, N. Y., they have been studying the techniques of beer making since last September.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 -- Directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco decided today to keep the discount rate at 3 per cent. Thus, they refused to follow the example of seven other Federal Reserve Banks led by Philadelphia, which earlier this week cut the rate from 3 to 2 3/4% per cent.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 24 -- At 3:10 A. M. yesterday a slight, blond, 29-year-old man stepped to the microphone of the Caracas radio and said:
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- A storm moved in today and prospects of more than an inch of rain threatened heavy going for the $100,000-added Santa Anita Maturity tomorrow.

Events today: Verdi's "La Forza del Destino," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Gounod's "Faust," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15; Mozart's "The Magic Flute," Lyric Players, Jan Hus Auditorium, 2:15; Mozart's "Don Giovanni," Opera Workshop, Public School 75; Puccini's "La Boheme," Carl Yohst Master - Singers, Little Theatre, 5 West Sixty-third Street, 8.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
DECATUR, Ill., Jan. 23 (AP) -- A. E. Staley Jr. announced tonight he would turn over the presidency of the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company to E. K. Scheiter in May.
PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Maurice Faure, French Deputy Foreign Minister, was named today as permanent head of France's delegation to European organizations.

WARSAW, Jan. 24 -- All Warsaw newspapers today published a Polish Press Agency article lauding the effect on Poland's economy of the $95,000,000 worth of credits extended by the United States last year.
MADRID, Jan. 23 -- Spanish Government leaders are seriously concerned over indications of mounting unrest among university students and youth groups in Spain.

A series of technical reports released simultaneously yesterday by the United States Atomic Energy Commission in Washington and the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority in London have revealed to the world that significant progress has been made in both countries in the quest for ways to harness the vast power of the hydrogen bomb into a generator of practically limitless electricity for all mankind.
Two television networks moved yesterday to inject life into their Friday night schedules.

The proposals of Secretary of Labor Mitchell for Federal legislation in the labor-management field -- made those of the entire Administration by President Eisenhower in his message to Congress -- add up to a statesmanlike program that must command respect, if not agreement, from labor, management and the public.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Donald A. Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense, called on military men today to "separate themselves from the political arena" and accept the policy direction of their civilian superiors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Lilly Dache of New York, who is best known as a designer of hats, has turned inventor. She received a patent this week for a mixer that blends powder for the individual taste and complexion.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that, for the first time since 1953, its net earnings covered its dividend of $8 a share last year. The annual report showed net income equal to $8.06 a share, against $7.97 in 1956, $7.73 in 1955 and $7.55 in 1954.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Soviet Ambassador paid an unusual farewell call today upon Vice President Richard M. Nixon. They agreed that a wider exchange of nongovernment visitors between their two nations would help to promote peace.

The state's cities are preparing to cope with the human problems of the current business recession, particularly those of families impoverished by long lay-offs of the breadwinner. One proposal was for a revival of the work project idea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 -- The Screen Directors Guild will add its weight to the protests by the Screen Actors Guild and the Writers Guild of America, West, against the release by Republic Pictures of post-1948 theatrical movies for free television exhibition.

A master of the keyboard, Artur Rubinstein, sat before his piano last night in Carnegie Hall like a monarch on his throne. He was surrounded on all sides by a throng that filled every available seat in the auditorium and spilled over onto the stage, where extra chairs were placed.

THE majesty of British law takes another fine spoofing in Henry Cecil's new novel, "The Long Arm."* A theory is sometimes batted around that Mr. Cecil is the pen, or the typewriter, name of a celebrated English jurist. I wouldn't know about that But it seems fairly certain that he is soundly familiar with the traditions of the Old Bailey, the works of Gilbert and Sullivan and the late Charles Dickens' "Pickwick Papers."
Representatives of the city and Moore-McCormack Lines met yesterday to work out details for construction of a $7,500.000 marine terminal at the foot of Twenty-third Street in Brooklyn.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- British hopes for a practical thermonuclear power system rest on a six-stage plan calculated to take at least twenty years to fulfill.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- L. Judson Morhouse, Republican State Chairman, announced today the selection of Rochester for this year's Republican State Convention.
Coffee futures prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange dropped more than a cent a pound in most positions yesterday in the most active trading of the year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- A business woman is challenging the sanctity of an all-male passenger plane.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield told Congress today that a failure to increase postal rates might necessitate another rise in the national debt limit within five years.

ALMA, Ga., Jan. 24 -- Something ought to be done about such persons as Fred Missildine of Sea Island, Ga. Maybe there should be a conservation law in every state barring them from hunting except with one another.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24 -- Secretary of State Dulles, on his first visit to Iran, arrived today for an exchange of views with the leaders of one of the principal Middle Eastern allies of the United States.
Railroading and trucking might well consider getting together, in the opinion of a leader of the American Trucking Association.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 24 -- Premier Adnan Menderes left Ankara today on an unexpected trip to Baghdad that aroused speculation here.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia demanded today that France make full restitution for a cargo of armse seized from a Yugoslav freighter and pay damages arising from the incident.
American and Canadian military officials were called upon yesterday to integrate and bolster Arctic defense programs to curb possible Soviet supremacy there.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 24 (UP) -- A family counselor told a group of church educators today that frankness in sex matters and greater equality between husband and wife were leading American families to a "richness and creativity" previously almost unknown.

Pleasure boat people don't subscribe to apprehensions about a business recession. Several hundred makers of craft, engines, fittings and marine hardware spent hours yesterday at the Essex House congratulating themselves on the huge success of the National Motor Boat Show two blocks westward at the New York Coliseum.
" PERSON TO PERSON," a program dedicated to noncontroversy. did it again last night on Channel 2.

On the north side of Forty-third Street in Times Square the city's Police Department has a small, one-story building which it man's around the clock. Just a few feet away, across Forty-third Street, the Department of Commerce and Public Events has its own small, new, one-story building, open to the public since Nov. 25.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Research on thermonuclear power may also provide the technological secret permiting travel in space.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (UP) -- A boy who saved two girls from drowning was among four residents of New York City cited today for outstanding heroism by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.

RICHARD STRAUSS' "Salome" remains a theatrical and moral shocker even today though we have been spared little in the exploration of the depths of sick passion. A great composer, like a possessed poet or novelist, can draw beauty from what he perceives in the dark places of the soul.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Chamber of Commerce today endorsed proposals for changes in the banking laws.
There is a good chance that "Look Homeward, Angel," the Ketti Frings drama based on the novel by Thomas Wolfe, may represent the United States at the Brussels World's Fair of 1958.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Missouri-Kansas-Texas (Katy) Railroad reported today a deficit of $855,538 for 1957, contrasted with net income of $1,940,207 in 1956.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 24 -- Antonelli and Carosa of Rome were the last designers to offer their collections in this week's review of Italian fashions for spring at the Pitti Palace. The fact that these two showed at the utimate hour in no way cut down on the effectiveness of their presentations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The United States anti Spain will sign a $69,000,000 economic aid agreement in Madrid next Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Scorching sprint finishes by Ron Delany and Charles (Deacon) Jones produced meet-record clockings for the mile and two-mile runs in the fourteenth annual Philadelphia Inquirer Games tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A spokesman for the General Accounting Office said today that his agency would check the expense vouchers of members of the Federal Communications Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- The State Supreme Court upheld today the substitution of private for public trustees as a means by which Girard College could continue as an institution for fatherless white boys.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Prince Souphanouvong disavowed today his allegiance to communism and declared he no longer was an enemy of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Project Sherwood -- the Atomic Energy Commission's research program into thermonuclear power -- has been expanded thirty-fold in the last five years.

Let us ponder a moment the comparative euphoria which must, these days, fill the spirit of that brave man Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, as he contemplates the recent agonies of his opposite number, the director of the Rome Opera, Carlo Latini.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was made the first honorary member today of Junior Achievement Inc. The organization encourages high school youths to learn about economics by operating spare-time business enterprises.

Two new imports from the Soviet Union are on today's program at the Cameo Theatre. "Flames on the Volga," a drama of Czarist Russia, was produced in color by Mosfilm Studios, under the direction of G. Roshal. M. Merkulov, R. Nifontova and V. Platov are among the featured players.

William Byrd (1674-1744), one of the original Byrds of Virginia, was a planter, author, surveyor, explorer, colonial agent in England and diarist. Three parts of his diaries, written in shorthand, were discovered between 1939 and 1942 in three libraries.
Three boys with a snow remover are making profits by the snow pile. Their profitable business venture began a year ago.

Morey Ritt, a young lady who has won several prizes and has appeared as piano soloist with orchestras in this city, made her solo debut last night in Town Hall. Her program was not easy; it consisted of Haydn's E flat Sonata, Ravel's Sonatine, Prokofieff's Third Sonata and Schumann's "Kreisleriana."
A Brooklyn justice ruled yesterday that Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh had overstepped his legal powers in his drive against flagrant traffic violators.
An exiled Venezuelan political leader said here last night that he was going home at once to work for "the final establishment of political freedoms and democratic institutions."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Following are excerpts from a statement by Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, on the release today of technical reports on thermonuclear research and the texts of a British statement and an A. E. C. summary of the reports:
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- A ruling today by the State Attorney General further complicated the legalizing of bingo.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Martie Dutra, using a revamped swing and putting stance, fired his second straight sub-par round and remained in front today in the nineteenth annual Professional Golfers Association senior tournament.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Young Ken Venturi shot a spectacular 8-under-par 33, 30 -- 63 and Jimmy Demaret a 32, 33 -- 65 to tie for the lead with 133's at the midway mark of the $15,000 Thunderbird invitation golf tournament today.
Cotton futures declined 5 to 20 points (25 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday. The close was a few points up from the lows of the day. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet.

PANAMA CITY, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Bob Watson of Ardsley, N. Y., shot a 6-under-par 66 today to take the lead at the end of the second round of the Panama open golf tournament today with a 36-hole total of 134.

A new headboard rule for mainsales on yachts racing under Cruising Club of America ratings has been adopted, Robert L. Hall, secretary, said yesterday. Wide headboards will be discouraged to prevent "rule beaters" from benefiting from sail area measurements.

Four drawn games last night in the third round of the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas in Bogota broke up the clean scores of two leaders, according to a report received through Colombian news sources.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Scrap steel prices, up $2 to $3 a ton in recent Chicago trading, were termed unrealistic today by some dealers.
Many prominent persons interested in the work of the Yorkville Community Association entertained last night in connection with the organization's annual benefit dinner dance.
Underwriting of new issues is continuing at a high level, with bullish factors predominating in the bond market.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 24 -- No pay rises are in sight for city employes "in view of present economic conditions," Mayor Irving C. Freese informed heads of city departments today. In a memorandum he wrote:...
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The executive board of the Illinois State Federation of Labor refused today to expel locals of three unions ousted by the national merged federation.
DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- The United Automobile Workers made plans today to raise a strike fund of $50,000,000 to implement the union's 1958 bargaining drive.
Coach Vince Boryla of the New York Knickerbockers, an individual who likes to speak his mind, was fined $325 yesterday because he talked too much during a basketball game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized tonight an increase of about 6.6 per cent in domestic airline fares.
Charges of "strong-arm tactics'' made by the National Maritime Union have been termed "ridiculous" by the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24 -- Miners at one of Yugoslavia's most important coal mines have staged a "stay-down" strike in protest against not being fully paid.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The Census Bureau will try out a new "do-it-yourself" method of gathering information in a special census beginning tomorrow in Memphis, Tenn.

MANY different descriptions may apply to the older woman. She may be slender, or not so slender, and in her fifties or late eighties. But whatever her age or her measurements, she wants to look chic, young and comfortable.

Gimel Associates sold the six-story apartment house at 1684 West Tenth Street in Brooklyn to an investing client of Saul Siller and Judah Rosner, brokers in the deal. The building occupies a plot 180 by 184 feet and contains eighty-four apartments and seven stores.

State Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine yesterday denied temporary injunctions sought by the scandal-tainted Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union against officers of two former New York affiliates.

Mrs. Peter I. B. Lavan, chairman of the Turtle Bay Music School benefit committee, has announced that the organization has taken over the Feb. 27 performance of "The Entertainer" by John Osborne. Sir Laurence Olivier is scheduled to open in the play at the Royale Theatre on Feb. 12.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- An eighty-ton Trade-wind flying boat, with a hole below the waterline and one set of propellers gone, piled up on a rocky breakwater at Alameda Naval Air Station today.
Senator Jacob K. Javits and the assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee ignored President Eisenhower's appeal and attacked the Democrats yesterday on national security.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The Communist Government is preparing to hold a treason "show trial" this summer for the non-Communist leaders of the 1956 anti-Communist rebellion, informed sources said today.

Milwaukee County, Wis., sold yesterday $5,650,000 of sewer bonds secured by general taxation to the First National Bank of Chicago and associates at an interest cost of 2.1526 per cent. The bonds, which will come due serially from 1959 to 1968, were reoffered at yields from 1.5 to 2.15 per cent.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Jan. 20 -- An alarm-clock bell gives a couple of short rings. Three seconds elapse -- followed by a crack like a muffled bark of a pistol. It's all over in an instant. Everything looks just as it did before.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- South African gold-mining stocks registered the best gains on the stock exchange today. The chief reason for their strength seemed to be renewed reports that a recession in United States might lead to an increase in the price of gold.

Occasionally in the course of historical re search one stumbles across an extremely odd bit of information -- such as, for example, the name of the man who introduced the umbrella to England as a protection against rain.
Baseball's two major leagues today are expected to set up new rules that should preclude future squabbling about "territorial rights" involving franchise shifts.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 24 -- The Glen Alden Corporation this afternoon conveyed 2,945 acres of coal reserves to the Bliss Coal Corporation, Truesdale Coal Corporation and Loomis Coal Corporation, newly organized and named after Glen Alden collieries.
Two teen-agers were shot and two others were stabbed last night in a fight after four youths had invaded a dance sponsored by an East Harlem church.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Jose Cuadros Quiroga, Minister of Interior, said today that a plot to assassinate President Hernan Siles Suazo had been thwarted.
Business was urged yesterday to spend more for education and take a more active interest in school affairs.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- In contemplating the rivalry between our own and Soviet aid programs to uncommitted nations we must remember one salient point. This is that despite Moscow propaganda to the contrary, Russia is ruled not by a Communist but by a state capitalist system.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 24 -- Provisional President Guillermo Flores Avendano warned Congress today that unless it acted with "fairness and serenity" in choosing a new President disorders might be provoked.
Harry Gross, former head of a multi-million-dollar bookmaking syndicate, lost a bid yesterday for early freedom.
Cardinal Spellman will preside tomorrow at a pontifical mass of thanksgiving commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Paulist Fathers.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- The Board of Regents approved today a $3,792,000 bond issue for school construction in the Locust Grove - Syosset - Woodbury Central School District in Nassau County.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court suffered a slightly wrenched back and a bloody nose in an automobile collision today.
A Basenji dog that snarls, growls and yodels -- but never barks -- has arrived from the Belgian Congo as part of a plan that fanciers hope will put new blood into his degenerating American cousins.
MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Monk Shoe, saving ground along the rail throughout, defeated Olympia's Ace by a neck today in the $5,000 Inagua Purse at Hialeah.

Wrestling was suspended at the St. Nicholas Arena yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission. The ruling will remain in effect until the commission decides that adequate protection against disorders can be provided.
ESPECIALLY seasonal for dessert now are puddings. Usually a substantial concoction, they make a satisfying conclusion to lunch or dinner on a cold winter day.

The stage is being set for the Treasury's first big re. funding of the year, a total of $15,000,000,000 of certificates, notes and bonds due from Feb. 14 to April 14. Terms probably will be announced by the Treasury late next week.

In your editorial of Jan. 23 on the death of Claude G. Bowers you conveyed his personality, his physical presence and his public record in three paragraphs -- a rare achievement -- and with the tender touch this gentle wielder of a vigorous pen merited for his memorial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Administration put on a show of determination with respect to Defense Department reorganization this week after President Eisenhower appeared to falter last week. This determination was emphasized today by the President's visit to the Pentagon to participate in reorganization talks.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Howard Boston, 48year-old sailmaker from Mount Clements, Mich., won the eleventh annual Thistle class sailing championships today under light airs.
The 26,000-gross-ton Empres of Scotland, a former Canadian Pacific liner recently purchased by the Hamburg-Atlantic Line, is now at the Howaldtswerke shipyard at Hamburg, Germany, for refitting.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 25 -- Costa Ricans not only earned more last year, but spent more and saved more simultaneously, according to an analysis made by the Central Bank here. They also smoked more locally made cigarettes, drank more local beer and governmentmade liquor, paid more income tax and -- based on an increase of 2,000,000 colones (about $300,000) in receipts from automobile taxes -- drove more cars.

HONG KONG, Jan. 25 -- Meetings preparatory to the opening of a regular session of the National People's Congress began in Peiping today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Eisenhower prodded the Soviet Union today to encourage scientific research on the problem of harnessing the hydrogen bomb's power for peaceful purposes.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- A Westchester Republican legislator has proposed giving the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles the power to determine the volume, pitch and tone of automobile horns.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 25 --The Soviet Union's Ambassador to Iran, Nicolai Pegov, left for the Soviet border and presumably Moscow at 1 A. M. today. His departure was not announced to the Iranian Foreign Ministry until later in the day.
The 1957 Billy Graham Evangelistic Crusade gave the Protestant churches of New York a "spiritual lift," but otherwise it had little lasting impact on the city.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 25 -A neighborhood controversy over the installation of new street lights on Silvermine Avenue here is heading toward a showdown.

SURGING talent all by itself does not necessarily make a good novel; but when unmistakably brilliant writing is combined with a degree of natural insight, the result, as in "Corruption," is likely to be most impressive.

A Russian sailor with the unpronounceable name of Zheleznyakov has a niche in the history of our times because he was in command of the military guard at the Tauride Palace in Petrograd on Jan. 18, 1918, when the All-Russian Constituent Assembly met for its first and only session.
TO the growing list of cheerful theatre evenings add one more: William Gibson's "Two for the Seesaw," in which Henry Fonda and Anne Bancroft play all the parts.

THE world of amateur astronomy has been invaded of late by manmade moons; these furnish new focal objects for the telescopes and talents of hobbyists who are veteran watchers of the old original moon. Artificial satellites are viewed with some ambivalence by the more dedicated amateurs, since information obtained from them concerns the shape of the earth, the composition of the upper atmosphere, and kindred matters more terrestrial than astronomical.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 25 -- Public order was restored in most of Caracas today and the outlook for political peace in Venezuela became more encouraging.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -The venerable Academy of Music inaugurated tonight its second century with a star-studded concert preceded by many festive dinners and followed by a gala champagne supper and ball.
LAKE WORTH, Fla., Jan. (UP) -- Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge dropped her approach its close to the flag today to in a three-stroke lead in the 000 annual Lake Worth woman's invitation golf tournament.
European shirt manufacturers are said to be copying American styling.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Three members of the Federal Communications Commission denied today that they had been guilty of improprieties in their expense accounts.
CAIRO, Jan. 25 -- Egyptian and Syrian officials rushed plans today to proclaim a federation of the two Arab nationalist states with President Gamal Abdel Nasser as its chief.
Barringer High of Newark swept through ten hours of competition to win the interscholastic fencing tournament yesterday at New York University's Washington Square College.

Today is the eighth anniversary of the proclamation of the Republic of India. On Jan. 26, 1950, the Indian Constitution was formally adopted and a new and different government took form. India had been independent since 1947, but there was the desire to create something apart from what had seemed, at first, the easiest course.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan 25 -Argentina's half dozen neoPeronist parties and groups were sharply divided this week over the political strategy they should employ in next month's national elections.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Jan. (AP) -- Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore, a 1952 finalist, and Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit of nthill. Ont., gained the final the Helen Lee Doherty woman's amateur golf tournament today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the New York Central Railroad, killed himself today with a shotgun.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman of Australia caused the biggest upset to date in the $22,400 Australian roundrobin professional tournament today when he beat Pancho Gonzales, 7 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

LEBANON, N. H., Jan. 25 -Conditioning and knowledge of wax told the story today at the Lebanon Outing Club's invitation cross-country ski race. Eight of the top ten finishers were either members of the United States Federation Internationale de Ski, cross-country and Nordic combined squad or had been at the recent training camp at McCall, Idaho.

AS readers of "The Islanders" will know, those three English schoolboys, Pat, Toby and Nick, are spending their summer vacation on the Devonshire estate of Old B., a widower with thoughts of adopting the orphan Pat and naming him heir.

The question in the minds of many business men these days is this: "Can taxes be reduced this year without upsetting economic stability?" Before the President's Budget Message, there was considerable doubt that the tax burden could be eased.

As a part of the new "austerity" program in the Philippines, President Garcia has made an announcement that sheds much light on the whole problem of "industrialization" in many areas. At this time, he says, the Philippines will halt any further establishment of packaging and processing plants as "industries" but will make every effort to give additional incentives to such operations as can make use of locally produced raw materials.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 25 -- The State Democratic Executive Committee readopted today its loyalty oath banning party members straying from the fold in Presidential elections from seeking office as a Democrat.

ACCORDING to one point of view, modern science has become so complex that it can be presented in any thorough manner only to persons with considerable scientific background. Knowledge is accumulating at such an imposing rate that even active investigators barely manage to keep up with developments in their own specialized fields.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 25 -- Mike Green of Miami Beach took advantage of Ashley Cooper's desire for "practice" and nearly pulled the biggest upset of the Australian tennis championships today before bowing, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 2.

NASSAU -- Tourists who cannot stand other tourists would enjoy Nassau this season. With all sixteen major hotels closed by a general strike and with tourist traffic virtually halted, the town, at what should have been its winter peak, belonged last week exclusively to the permanent residents and a handful of visitors oblivious to the crisis.
CERAMIC tiles are so durable, most homeowners scarcely give them a second thought once they have been installed.

WHAT were the people outside the circus really like? Flora, the little girl who had spent all her life under the big top, had a frightening dream about them. Her fellow-performers told her that people outside "spin on their heads" or "spin webs and live in them, all tangled up."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 -- The sleepiest dog of those that began competition in the Maryland Kennel Club show today was a shaggy gray Irish wolfhound named Castledawn Tartan. He spread his 150-pound frame on the red and yellow bench that was his temporary home in complete disregard of the crowd that milled around him.

ATHENS, Jan. 15 -- The excavations that Dr. John Papadimitriou recently carried out in the Royal Grave Circle inside the huge cyclopean walls of the Acropolis at Mycenae have led to new conclusions about the peoples of Greek prehistory, who created the Mycenaean civilization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Mr. Dulles has gone out to the Middle East armed with the sword of military aid and the buckler of economic aid, with the Eisenhower Doctrine on his lips and the Charter of the United Nations in his heart.
French period furniture and companionable decorations will be sold at auction on Friday and Saturday at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

THE crisis over Fort Sumter lasted from November, 1860, after Lincoln's election, until April 14, 1865, and, as W. A. Swanberg points out, reflected in "miniature" the conflict between the sections. As Mr. Swanberg does not point out, the specific contest over Sumter also reflected the way in which maneuver for advantage gradually came to dominate efforts at resolution of the fundamental differences involved.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Millions of Americans may be able to see the second Soviet satellite in the next few days, the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory said tonight. The satellite is traveling from north northwest to south southwest.
SEVERAL new evening courses in photography for beginners and advanced students will start sessions this week and next month, according to school notices.

LONDON. A HISTORY of the Russian theatre today might well begin with some such opening as this: After Stalin came the thaw. After the thaw came the sputnik. A study of the changes that have recently taken place is most revealing.

TWO more important milestones in the East's history of ski and winter vacation development were marked yesterday. Dedication ceremonies were held at the $2,000,000 ski development on Whiteface Mountain in the northern Adirondacks, while to the east in New Hampshire a cabin-gondola lift, the first of its kind in America, began operating at the $1,500,000 Wildcat Mountain area near Pinkham Notch.
SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 25 -Observations of auroras, rare in tropic skies, have been made by three German scientists working here as part of the program of the International Geophysical Year.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Construction on the first phase of a new $50,000,000 school for the mentally retarded and children's psychiatric hospital at West Seneca, N. Y., will get under way this summer.
TOKYO, Jan. 21 -- Tokyo's pawnshops are enjoying a boom. The reason: the wild December buying spree has resulted in many financial hangovers.
The social side of baseball's fading off-season will sweep to its climax tonight when more than 1,400 guests gather in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

BEETHOVEN: Symphony No. 6, Pastoral; Philharmonia Orchestra, Herbert von Karajan conducting (Angel). An excellent performance which, however, does not catch all the subtlety of this simple-seeming score.

"IT was midnight of October 11-12 and the whole course of world history was going to change forever, in just two hours more." This opening sentence (referring to the discovery of America) is typical of the sense of immediacy and drama which the Bakelesses bring to their account of the exploration of North America.
A ruse by Dutch industrialists to thwart Hitler was the genesis of one of this country's largest makers of electronic specialties.
PANAMA, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. of Pocono Manor, Pa., carded a 32, 33 -- 65 today to take a five-stroke lead after fifty-four holes of the Panama open golf championship.
Twenty-eight publishers, editors and chief news executives of daily newspapers will begin a two-week seminar tomorrow at the American Press Institute, Columbia University.

THE second increase in two years in trans-Atlantic steamship fares will go into effect next fall. The rate boosts, ranging from around 2 per cent for tourist class to about 4 per cent for first class, will affect the off-season fare schedule, going into effect for eastbound sailings on Sept. 1, on westbound sailings Nov. 1.
Dr. Morton Gottschall, whose career at City College spans a half century, will be honored next Saturday by a group of college alumni.
The Feb. 18 performance of "Summer of the 17th Doll" will benefit the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students. The play opened Wednesday at the Coronet Theatre.

TO eliminate the danger of having appliance or extension cords stretch across the floor, homeowners can now purchase a specially shaped rubber duct which carries the wires on the inside. Shaped with sloping sides, much like a door saddle, these "over-the-floor" ducts will stay where they are put and are easy to sweep over, to walk over, and to roll casters over.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The British Government indicated week that it had been impressed by the increasingly strong political and popular clamor in this country for talks between heads of government of the Soviet bloc and the free world. Almost imperceptibly the language and tone of the remarks by Government leaders, like Richard A. Butler, Acting Prime Minister, have reflected a more malleable attitude toward a summit conference.

No column we have written in recent months has drawn a response to equal that accorded "The Double Role of the Single Parent," which appeared Oct. 13. Within two weeks of its publication nearly 1,000 requests for information had poured into headquarters of Parents Without Partners, the newly organized group we had mentioned, set up here to help widowed and divorced mothers and fathers help themselves toward a better life with their young.

THE men in the Kremlin have found it convenient and profitable -- in terms of propaganda--to conduct their relations with other nations, especially with the United States, through direct approaches to the American leaders. Diplomacy by well publicized messages, backed by the full weight of the propaganda machine, has been their preferred instrument.
Jets of wind howled along the East Coast yesterday. The storm brought torrential rains along the coast and heavy snow inland.

AMERICAN education, in the grip of a crisis for over a decade, has been forced into self-examination by the launching of the Russian sputniks. Stunned, perhaps, but also awakened to the harsh realities of the modern world, the American people sense the crucial roles played by systems of education in Russia's scientific success and in our own failure.

There would seem to be some question as to whether the United States and Britain are ahead of the Soviet Union in research aimed at harnessing the thermo-nuclear power that makes possible the hydrogen bomb.

A strange little ceremony attended by four witnesses took place on the roof of the United Nations Friday afternoon. The persons present were U. N. Under Secretary Dragoslav Protitch, a citizen of Yugoslavia; Frank Begley, head of the U. N. special police; Povl Bang-Jensen, a Danish political officer of the U. N., and Adolph A. Berle Jr., Mr. Bang-Jensen's attorney.

Less than a generation ago ornithologists said that New York's Central Park was the northeastern limit of that feathered dandy the cardinal, or, as he is known in the South, Mr. Redbird. The cardinal wasn't a familiar resident of Central Park even then, but he was out of the accidental wanderer class.
Public school enrollment in the city next fall will be the highest since 1941.

CANTON, China, Sunday, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -- Three disappointed American mothers headed for home early today, leaving their three sons behind in Chinese Communist prisons. They saw their sons seven times during their visit to the Communist country, but their appeal to Premier Chou En-lai for the men's release failed.
Although bank lending rates have begun to erode, it may be some time before it becomes cheaper for most business men to borrow.
With the deadline only five days away, automobile license date renewals in the city are running 22,000 behind last year's date, the Motor Vehicle Bureau reported yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 25 -- Current signs in this motor capital indicate that the spring labor negotiations in the auto industry will be rough and tough.
ATHENS, Jan. 25 -- If so requested, Greece will provide nuNorth Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Government and the principal parliamentary opposition are in substantial agreement on this policy.
AT Canada's Agricultural experiment stations, the breeding and selection of hardy fruits are of prime importance. The frequently severe climatic conditions demand hardy, vigorous varieties.

AN obscure landscape painter of the mid-nineteenth century and a dabbler in photography, whose technical assistant helped to raise him to a leading place in the annals of photography, has a one-man show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party leader, has proposed another major revision of the Soviet Union's economic system -- elimination of the machine and tractor stations that have been an integral part of Soviet agriculture for many years.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The United States Golf Association, at its annual meeting, acted today to prevent pre-arranged "prize-splitting" by professionals in its two national open tournaments.
ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 25 (UP) -- Iyo Pimental of Venezuela and Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., posted upsets today to gain the final of the Florida State tennis championship.
The Brooklyn Post Office tomorrow begins a 30-day experiment with a new schedule of afternoon and early evening collections. Success will mean overnight delivery for areas within about 400 miles.

THOUGH the troubles that beset the movie industry these days make it seem faintly old and weary, the search for fresh, new faces goes on. New actors are sought who may magically capture the public's imagination and draw millions back into movie houses, new actors who may replace the maturing, fading kings and queens of the last two and three decades.
Charles Gilman, administrator of business affairs of the Board of Education who was once referred to as "the best investment ever made by the city," is about to complete fifty years with the board.

IN this admirable collection of Maine folklore Horace P. Beck, a native of Rhode Island who teaches American literature at Middlebury College, has instituted a new pattern that will be followed, as the original methods of Thomas Wentworth Higginson and John Lomax were followed before him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- To understand the fight over Ezra Taft Benson and his farm policy there must be some understanding of the man himself. Perhaps oversimplified, Mr. Benson's basic philosophy as he wanders through the tangle of farm politics is best seen in what he told a recent world agriculture meeting in Rome.
THE tomato has top priority in the vegetable breeding programs under way in Canada. The Canadian experimental stations have introduced several varieties of fine quality for home gardens.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Charles Sheppard came close but when the second round ended today no one had been able to wrest the lead from Mortie Dutra in the Professional Golfers Association seniors' tournament.

The local art season, in a new burst of energy, brings into the galleries this week group and one-man exhibitions in wide variety. The new attractions include paintings, sculpture and graphic art by many well-known European and American artists working in a wide range of styles.

PONTA DELGADA, St. Michael, Azores -- That widespread impulse of tourists to get away from it all, so as to go home with dreamy stories of places which practically nobody else has visited, can be wonderfully satisfied in these islands.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Eisenhower went to the Pentagon today to demonstrate dramatically his personal interest in the reorganization of the Defense Department.

NORFOLK, Jan. 25 -- Hampton Roads ports during 1957 preciable gains in export volume during 1957 in both grain and general cargo categories, while North Atlantic ports generally recorded declines in the previous year.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 25 -- It is relatively certain that the candidate of the extreme Right party, Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, has won the highest plurality in last Sunday's Presidential elections. Barring a political upheaval (which is highly possible) General Ydigoras probably will be elected President by the Congress, which chooses a President when no candidate has an absolute majority.
THIS is a fictionalized story of the struggle over slavery in "Bleeding Kansas" before it became a state. Some romantic hearts bleed, too, along with a lot of ordinary citizens.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 25 -- Since Jan. 12 the prized political security of the Bahamas has been shaken by a strange and disturbing strike of Negro workers. On that day a mass walkout of hotel employes, laborers, cab drivers and garbage collectors forced all the major hotels to close on the eve of the peak tourist season.
Voluntary curbs on crude oil imports imposed last July by the Government are being assailed from several directions.

Dance interest this week continues to center on the Israeli company known as Inbal, which has been packing the Martin Beck Theatre for the last three weeks. It begins its final week today, and a special matinee has been added on Wednesday.
An optimistic view of United States export prospects in the six-nation European Common Market was expressed last week by Aldo Morante, commercial counselor of the Italian Embassy in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -Senator H. Alexander Smith assailed Dean Acheson and the Democratic National Committee tonight for what he described as attempts to "interject partisan politics" into foreign policy.

THOUGH the family Rosaceae is most noted for the rose, there are many landscape trees that give the clan further distinction. Among the most handsome members are hawthorn, mountain ash, the flowering crabs, cherries, plums, almonds and quinces.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Governor Harriman contended today that administrative improvements he had put into effect were saving the state's taxpayers at least $17,300,000 a year.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 25 (AP) -- John D. Hoblitzell Jr., chairman of the West Virginia State Republican Committee, was named by Gov. Cecil H. Underwood today to the United States Senate. He will succeed Matthew M. Neely, Democrat, who died last Saturday.
Laurence Watson, tenor, who made his debut here two years ago, was heard in a program at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.
MAXTON, N. C., Jan. 25 -The 2,000 or more persons who live in this little city near the Lumber River still haven't quite figured out what happened here a week ago tonight.

THE old English folk names of many garden flowers had a warm, frequently whimsical touch. In fact, most of the common plant names used today are far less imaginative than are the folk names to be found in old garden books. Though these names were the despair of the botanist, they delighted poets.

THIS week, in a resort hotel on the Italian side of Lake Como, a United States team is playing for the world bridge championship -- and is trying to recapture some of our lost glory in international competition.

"SEA HUNT" may best be described as an adventure series in depth, sometimes up to ninety feet, but mostly forty or under. As a regular filmed series about frogmen it offers a cool contrast to the dusty mesas and booted provincials that dominate TV's adventure story schedules.

IN presenting its one hundred and fifty-third annual exhibition of American oil painting and sculpture, the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts has this time come up with a lively show and some highly cheering announcements.

ROME, Jan. 25 -- Jewish victims of Nazi outrages in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are to receive this year for the first time aid out of funds made available as reparations by West Germany.

ALTHOUGH it isn't even spring, cast today's first glance beyond, toward autumn. Due then is a new novel -- "major" the term -- by John P. Marquand. The title: "Script by Thomas Harrow." The theme: Career of a playwright.
Robert Ralph Young, the "daring young man of Wall Street," who died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla., was a financial juggler with an extraordinary talent for public relations.

Eight members of a Bronx youth gang were accused yesterday of attacking three members of another gang outside a Bronx church. They were charged with felonious assault, illegal possession of a dangerous weapon and unlawful assembly.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 25 -The conflict between the Right Wing and Left-Wing section in Ceylon's coalition Government, which has been brewing in private for some months, has come into the open.
BURLINGTON, N. C., Jan. 25 -- A couple of thousand persons turned out here tonight for a Ku Klux Klan rally that was never held.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 (AP) -- R. L. Baird sent Joe W. Brown's Tenacious through a tiny hole in the final strides today to nip the late-finishing Speed Rouser and win the $13,525 Pelleteri Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

AN intercontinental ballistic missile -- capable of launching an earth satellite or an H-bomb -- rears from its concrete launching pad like an artillery shell as tall as a ten-story building. WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- The Senate rackets committee will turn its spotlight Monday on a local of the Operating Engineers Union once linked to Joseph S. (Joey) Fay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -The Republican elephant gave itself a mighty shake this week in an effort to stir up its hormones and fighting spirit for the political battles that lie ahead, but the temptation to settle back into its former condition of disconsolate brooding seems to have been just too much to overcome for long.

MYSTERY writing is, fortunately, one field in which one hears nothing of the problems of gerontology and superannuation. An established mystery writer usually keeps on writing (and publishing) as long as he lives -- and often exactly the same kind of book with which he was successful thirty years ago.
Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh moved yesterday to cut possible legal red tape in his drive on persistent traffic violators.

IN "Fiction and the Unconscious," Simon Lesser has written the most intelligent fulllength study I have seen of the psychological hold of all forms of storytelling on the mind of man. Too often such attempts to apply a theory of psychology to the "esthetic" process end up in some shrill, one-sided, allinclusive doctrine, a tour de force of ingenuity and irrelevance.

THE recent season of the New York City Ballet, besides being in its own right the organization's most distinguished single season; has a historical importance of another sort. It established with unshadowable clarity the company's uniqueness (in the literal meaning of the word) and the more important fact that this state is solely and completely a manifestation of the uniqueness of its artistic director, George Balanchine.

HAVANA, Jan. 25 -- Guarantees of constitutional rights were restored to the people of Cuba, with the exception of Oriente Province, early today by President Fulgencio Batista. The announcement was made at the Presidential Palace after a Cabinet meeting.

A FORMER English engineer, Max Catto switched over to writing more than twenty years ago. His new novel is a colorful entertainment indeed, sure-fire material for a motion picture along the lines of that wonderful spoof "The African Queen."

THIS new novel by Robert S. Close, his third, is a realistic historical story, replete with sex, booze, violence and malevolence. His fascination with these is justifiable here because he tells the story of a young Irish girl, mixed up in crime in London, who is transported to Van Diemen's Land in the early Eighteen Twenties.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 25 -- In the opinion of informed persons who are friends of the United States, Washington's policy toward Indonesia is driving a wedge in the relations between the two countries. The situation is serious, possibly even critical, and the Communist world is doing its best to exploit it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- As everybody knows, politeness, like baseball, was invented in the Soviet Union, but even so, this does not wholly explain the Soviet Ambassador's farewell call on Vice President Richard M. Nixon yesterday morning.
The State Court of Appeals has upheld the power of an impartial arbitrator to order the halt of a strike or slowdown and of the courts to give force to the order.

NAPLES, Fla. -- A new highway running forty miles northeastward from Naples to Immokalee affords a quick route for tourists who want to see what primitive Florida looks like. The highway pierces an area of more than 700,000 acres hitherto unfrequented except by roving Seminole Indians and occasional hunters.

THE year just passed marked the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Thorstein Veblen, the best-known American economist, and possibly the best-known American social scientist. The occasion was celebrated by memorial articles, conferences and a special session of Veblen's own guild, the American Economic Association.

ANTONINO ROCCA is a man of such majestic mien and imperious dignity that no skeptic would dare ask him to his face whether wrestling really was on the level. Not only is the mightly Antonino cloaked in an aura of righteousness, but he dominates any gathering by the electric magnetism of an overpowering personality.

The public relations committee of the American Merchant Marine Institute has designated nine subcommittee chairmen. The executive committee will be headed by Warren M. Drew, who is also chairman of the public relations committee.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 25 -President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines put into operation yesterday the Tingambato hydroelectric plant in the state of Michoacan. This 135,000-kilowatt unit represents the nation's greatest step in the desperate ten-year race to stay ahead of the electric power demand.
In compiling its new book list for teen-agers, the New York Public Library has named titles, 80 per cent of which are adult fare.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 25 -- Documents signed by Juan D. Peron and Guillermo Patrick Kelly advising the ousted Venezuelan dictatorial regime in detail how to maintain itself in power have been found in the offices of that regime's Seguridad Nacional, the secret police.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 25 -Secretary of State Dulles completed tonight his series of talks with Iranian Government leaders. He will leave tomorrow morning for Ankara and the Baghdad Pact meeting.

FREDERIC COHEN'S impressive report on the state of opera in America and Howard Taubman's comments, I believe, deserve the widest attention. DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. -After many delays caused primarily by financing difficulties, a new automobile speedway to cost $2,500,000 is being built here. It is to be completed in time for the winter racing of 1959.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., Jan. 25 (Canadian Press) -- St. Lawrence Seaway officials plan to borrow some ideas from airport traffic control to keep ships moving speedily through the giant seaway after it opens in 1959.

The designation jointly by the Federal, state and city governments of this year for a twelve months' observance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Civil Service merit systems is a well-earned tribute to thousands of faithful workers who spend their active lives in faithful service to government.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 25 -- Premier Adnan Menderes of Turkey returned today from a surprise trip to Baghdad that was believed to have been an unsuccessful effort to get better cooperation from Iraq in Baghdad Pact affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -President Eisenhower's Education Message, will go to Congress Monday. It will detail his $1,000,000,000 program of Federal aid for the extension of scientific knowledge.
Henri Salaun of Boston, the national titleholder, moved into the semi-final round of the annual Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets tournament at the Harvard Club yesterday.

BY going off Broadway with his brand new "Garden District," Tennessee Williams may have started a trend that could be only for good in the American theatre. In choosing the renovated York on First Avenue for the presentation of what actually are two short plays, "Something Unspoken" and "Suddenly Last Summer," Mr. Williams said that among the compelling reasons was a desire to escape the high-voltage excitement and tension that beset the Broadway theatre.
FRANKLIN LAKES, N. J., Jan. 25 -- A pioneering statewide effort was made here today to reconcile two often disparate groups -- hunters and nature lovers -- in the interest of conservation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- A United Nations survey has indicated the staggering dimensions of aid extended to under-developed nations around the world, from both governmental and private sources.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 -- After enjoying their second best season in history in 1957, operators of the giant ore-carrying industry on the Great Lakes are not too hopeful of repeating the performance next season.

THE "Country Editor" of Martha's Vineyard turns to fiction again with a tale likely to give some precious literati a plague of itchy, scratchy hives. In a somewhat pedestrian novel, he brings out the difference between the mythology of a literary masterpiece and things-asthey-actually-were.

Beating Frank Sanchez of the Dominican Republic in the fourth round, Arthur B. Bisguier of New York gained sole possession of the lead in the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas at the Club Militar in Bogota yesterday, according to a report received through Colombian news sources.

SIXTY-SIX years after it was launched as one of the world's finest and fastest trains, the Empire State Express is to become, for all practical purposes just a local train shuttling between here and Buffalo.

LOS ANGELES -- That cherished facet of the American myth, "Hollywood night life," can now be said to be extinct. If any proof was needed, it came the other day in the bankruptcy of Ciro's, the last f the Sunset Boulevard bistros with a reputation for glamour.

In simple terms this means that men are subject either to benign circles that make things better or to vicious ones that make them worse.

GIBRALTAR -- The British authorities in this celebrated Rock colony on Spain's sunny southern coast are now making a determined effort to attract Americans and other tourists. New hotels, a new swimming pool beside the luxurious Rook Hotel, a new airport terminal, a bathing Lido on the sheltered eastern side of the peninsula -these and other amenities highlight the new drive.

HARTFORD, Jan. 25 -- Connecticut Republican leaders opened fire this week on Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, signaling the start of the 1958 state election campaign.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 25 -- Billy Beck, a two-time American Olympian who grins after saying to friends, "I'm getting old," outsped a lot of younger rivals today to win in the first running of the Stowe Cup downhill.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 25 -What is said to be one of the largest municipal construction projects in the world for sanitary sewers is now half completed here.

Four Brooklyn preparatory schools are forming committees under the leadership of Miss Martha Jane MacGregor to plan an inter-preparatory-school benefit dance. The event will be held in the Officers Club of the New York Naval Shipyard on March 28.

Despite Brazil's current financial difficulties -- manifested chiefly in an extremely unfavorable trade balance for 1957 -the country is making rapid strides industrially, according to Ruben M. Berta, president of Varig Airlines of Brazil.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- France stands on the threshold either of great economic progress or prolonged decline with her conduct in the next four or five years as the decisive factor, Premier Felix Gaillard said today.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 25 -President Syngman Rhee signed into law today a controversial election bill.

At the A. F. L.-C. I. O. convention last December, the presidents of the federation's 135 affiliated unions issued a Statement which said labor would "resist to the uttermost any and every proposal which, under the guise of seeking to protect workers from corruption or improper activities, seeks instead to destroy honest, decent American trade unions."

Business this year is off to a "plodding start," according to members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Newspaper advertising executives took a searching look last week at their business. They found that 1957 was a good year, but that heightened competition called for a greater selling effort this year.

COMO, Italy, Jan. 25 -- An allItalian world championship contract bridge team this afternoon took an early lead of fourteen international match points against the United States in the opening sixteen-hand session of the 1958 world championship.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 23 -- The University of Notre Dame will soon launch its largest fund drive. Most of the money will be used for a ten-year plan to raise the university's academic level.

" THE BOY FRIEND," which was revived over the week-end at the Downtown Theatre, has completed a full circle. WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., United States Ambassador to Moscow, returned to Washington today with a report of "no progress" in his efforts to break the deadlock on preparations for an East-West top-level meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 -- The Ukrainian Nationals of this city, leading in the American Soccer League, won today in the second round of the annual National Cup competition of the United States Soccer Football Association. They defeated the May A. C., 5 -- 1, at Edison Field.
