A bloody tale of mutiny and murder aboard an American whaling ship a century ago has come to light as the result of Department of Justice research in preparation for a case of barratry.
A diplomat, a scientist and an educator received honorary degrees yesterday in the closing program of the three-day Seventy-fifth Anniversary Convocation of Wagner College on Staten Island.
BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- The East German regime was conducting a convention of tractor station officials today when news arrived that the Soviet Union planned to dissolve these institutions.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 26 -- A constitution for the new United Church of Christ is scheduled to be completed by the summer of 1959.
" Operation nail-biting" is under way among agencies thought to have a chance of landing the $24,000,000 Buick advertising account. A decision is expected shortly.

ANDRES SEGOVIA gave his first concert in New York on Jan. 8, 1928, so the guitarist's appearance last night at Town Hall might be construed as a celebration, only slightly belated, of the thirtieth anniversary of his local debut.
One of the greatest problems for music lovers has been to find a practical solution for lighting music at the grand piano. Their main concern is to light the music without shadows or interference.

The American Agricultural Chemical Company has leased the major portion of the twelfth floor in the office building rising at 100 Church Street from Erwin S. Wolfson, the owner. The company has been at 50 Church Street since 1934 and plans to move next summer.
SAALFELDEN, Austria, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Toni Sailer, Austria's triple Olympic champion, won the men's giant slalom race today in Saalfelden's international ski meet with a time of 1 minute 45.3 seconds.

Three enchanting performances of rarely heard works by Rameau, Mozart and Bach were presented by the New York Chamber Soloists under the direction of Margaret Hillis late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of Britain's Labor party, asked Western governments tonight to agree to the Soviet Union's appeals for a summit conference between the leaders of East and West.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 26 -Juan D. Peron said tonight he would leave Venezuela "as soon as possible."

Dave Coe, the athletic director and wrestling coach at the St. Mark's School of Southborough, Mass., was talking about the new scoring system being used this season by the New England Interscholastic Wrestling Association.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 -- This month could be the bottom of the current downtrend in steel and may result in the smallest steel tonnage produced since the recession of 1954.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Maj. John S. Eisenhower cannot recall having received any "specific advice" from his father while a high school student.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that it was just as important for the United States to liberalize the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act as it was "to catch up" with the Soviet Union in missiles and rockets.

ORANGEBURG, S. C., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Benedict College of Columbia, S. C., was leading the hometown South Carolina State College quintet, 87-82, in overtime last night when Benedict noticed the clock wasn't running.

AT 4:30 in the morning of April 15, 1861, Confederate batteries opened fire on Fort Sumter, an unfinished and pathetically undermanned United States redoubt that commanded the narrows leading to the harbor of Charleston, S. C. The Civil War had begun. But that was not the first time rebellious Southerners had fired on the United States flag.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 26 -Erich Ollenhauer, the Social Democratic Opposition leader, charged today that the Adenauer Government had decided in principle to equip the West German armed forces with atomic weapons.

The Northern Pacific Railway reported yesterday for 1957 net income of $21,126,050, or $4.25 a share. This compared with $20,983,445, or $4.23 a share, in 1956. Gross revenues were $184,402,990, down $3,766,822.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that the training period at the Police Academy would be extended by two months. This will permit the 675 students to be assigned to patrol duties for four days on alternate weeks.

WHEN Roosevelt Hospital opened 'almost ninety years ago, a massive thing of red brick with a soaring steeple in West Fifty-ninth Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, it was generally described as the most advanced hospital structure in the world.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The collections opened tonight with Mme. Gres. The salon was bursting with people. Unfortunately her spring and summer collection did not live up to the expectations of the excited crowd that had been so enthusiastic about her fall collection.
Five new films will open in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

THE Metropolitan Opera Association, which in its previous television encounter discovered that life with Ed Sullivan can be trying, had a far happier experience yesterday afternoon on "Omnibus" over Channel 4.
Books of statistics are not likely to be interesting, until suddenly one has need of them. These books abound with useful figures, waiting to be needed.
A new electronic counter the computes, simultaneously, output of forty different production, processing or packaging operations was announced over the week-end by the Radio Corporation of America.

THE new Soviet-made double bill that opened Saturday at the Cameo is composed of a couple of odd numbers. Odd and none too rewarding. One is "Magdana's Donkey," the other "Flames on the Volga." (Both are Artkino presentations.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Winger Leo LaBine fired home Don McKenney's rebound in the last second of play tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 3-3 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at the Garden.
Dr. Miriam Freund, national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, warned yesterday against cut in President Eisenhower's request for foreign aid.
Although New York has lost two major league ball clubs, the Giants and Dodgers, its baseball writing fraternity apparently hasn't yet lost its sense of humor.

Within recent days the Administration in Washington has taken two positive steps to try to bolster the troubled Post Office Department's health -- both physical and fiscal. Both steps are directed at us in our roles of ordinary citizens.

MILAN, Italy, Jan. 26 -- More than 500 visitors, three times the first-day attendance of last August, were at the opening today of the second Milan Textile Mart, called Mitam. The week-long exhibition of fall and winter fabrics is in the Textile and Clothing Pavilion of the famous Milan Fairground.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Jorge Magnasco, an Argentine race driver, died tonight of injuries sustained when his Maserati sports car skidded and overturned during the 1,000-kilometer (625-mile) Grand Prix of Buenos Aires.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -The Treasury Secreary said tonight that the Administration was prepared to act to prevent the economic slump from getting worse.
Walter (Red) Barber, the sports announcer, applied his first-hand knowledge of baseball to a sermon here yesterday.
The Commodity Exchange, Inc., has elected Harold A. Rousselot as president, it was announced over the week-end.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles arrived here tonight to head a delegation of United States observers at Baghdad Pact meetings opening tomorrow.

Because of the peculiarities of the State Constitution and the absence of true home rule for cities, if New York City wants new borrowing power to assure continuation of school construction at the needed pace beyond 1960, legislative action has to be started during the present session in Albany.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Sir Oliver Franks, chairman of Lloyds Bank, has cautioned Britain that even if the inflationary spiral did not continue, the low level of her gold and dollar reserves might cause her economic trouble.
ROME, Jan. 26 -- More than $10,000,000 paid as reparations by West Germany will be distributed this year for the aid of Jewish victims of Nazism in thirty countries.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 26 -- An early-morning fire destroyed three stores and damaged a theater here today before it was quelled by 400 firemen from four communities. Damage was estimated at more than $500,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers defated the Minneapolis Lakers, 109 -- 106, today despite Dick Garmaker's scoring spree that tied three National Basketball Association records.
" A Houseful of Love." Marjorie Housepian's diverting account of her Armenian relatives, is to be adapted to the stage by Leslie Stevens.

KEY LARGO, Fla., Jan. 26 (UP) -- Les Moss, a Chicago White Sox catcher, his wife and 10-year-old daughter drifted in a 14-foot boat for more than twenty hours before being rescued today from the storm-tossed waters off the Florida keys.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Union announced tonight its economic report for 1957.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Australia's Mal Anderson, the holder of the United States title, beat Mervyn Rose, 6 -- 2, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 19 -- 17, in the semi-final of the Australian tennis championship today.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 26 -- Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan relinquished the command of the Israeli armed forces today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -Congressional economizers are again aiming torpedoes at aircraft carriers.
Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, yesterday assured a minor league committee that he would continue to seek a solution to the problem of competition from telecasts of major league games.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 27 -- At least 222 persons aboard seven ships were missing and feared lost today after a violent storm raked Japan's south and east coasts.

Free performances of "As You Like It" at the Heckscher Theatre are assured for an extra week until Feb. 8. The extension of the New York Shakespeare Festival's production was made possible by a grant of $3,000 from the New York Foundation.

AT a reader's request, the following menu has been devised as a luncheon to be served to eight women gathered for an afternoon of bridge. The main course, preceded by piping hot consomme, is hors d'oeuvres varies, including two hot ones -- kidneys and potato salad.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Union said today that it had developed a portable electronic calculator that works on transistors.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The debate on economic policy in the House of Commons last week offered further proof that the Government was determined to continue its anti-inflationary credit squeeze.

Whatever else may be said or thought about the union of Egypt and Syria, presumably effected this morning, there can be no doubt on one point. The timing was deliberate. It cannot have been accident or coincidence that this marriage of convenience was hurried to the altar just in time to let its chimes ring a dissonant overtone to the meeting of the Baghdad Pact nations at the ministerial level, which has also begun today.
MONACO, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -- An opposition party seeking constitutional reforms in the tiny Mediterranean principality of Monaco won a majority today in the final stage of local elections.

HONG KONG, Jan. 26 -- Three American mothers, back from visiting their sons in prison in Communist China, said here today they were still hopeful their sons would be released before serving their full terms.
PARIS, Jan. 26 -- A spokesman for the French steel industry denounced last week the proposed European free trade area as incompatible with the European Coal and Steel Community.
GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- A proposed constitutional amendment to make cartels illegal in Switzerland was rejected today in a national referendum.

Net income of the Republic Steel Corporation was $85,014,422 in 1957, equal to $5.45 a share on 15,595,101 common shares outstanding. It was the third highest in the company's history, having been exceeded only in 1956 and 1955.
Emmanuel Swedenborg was lauded for his "new concept of what a church should be" in a service yesterday observing the 270th anniversary of the birth of the Swedish scientist and philosopher.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 25 -- It is a sign of the new, milder climate in Bulgaria today that Communist writers guilty of deviation from the party line are getting off with reprimands and promises of good behavior.

Charges of employer bias because of color have accounted for 70.8 per cent of the 4,582 cases handled by the State Commission Against Discrimination in its twelve-year history, Chairman Charles Abrams said yesterday.
Capital Airlines has arranged to purchase a fleet of Convair 880 jet planes in an unusual financing deal with the manufacturer.
The high point of Gina Bachauer's piano recital Saturday night at Hunter College was her powerful performance of the gigantic Brahms F minor Sonata.

Committees are making final arrangements for a theatre party at the Feb. 25 performance of "Oh Captain!" Greenwich House, a settlement at 27 Barrow Street, will receive the proceeds of the benefit. The musical will open at the Alvin Theatre on Feb. 4.
The Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital, 29 Greene Avenue, which is in the midst of its 1958 drive for funds, announced yesterday a new corneal clinic for the restoration of sight.

SALISBURY, Conn., Jan. 26 -- Art Devlin soared through a cold drizzle to jumps of 168 and 170 feet to take the Class A championship at the Salisbury Winter Sports Association invitation ski jump today. Devlin, 35, a Lake Placid, N. Y., motel owner, totaled 215.9 points.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Harriman's budget for the state fiscal year, starting April 1, is to be submitted to the Legislature tomorrow. It is expected to touch off the sharpest partisan clash of the legislative session to date.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith said today that he would introduce a bill Tuesday to carry out President Eisenhower's program for education.

THE main attraction of a casserole is the infinite variety of foods that can be cooked in one. This includes fish, shell fish, meat, poultry, cheese, eggs and vegetables. These dishes have special appeal when their principal contents are combined with rice, potatoes or cream sauces to stretch the servings.

CAIRO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser told visiting United States newspaper and radio editors today the proposed federation of Egypt and Syria would be announced soon, members of the group reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- One of our whooping cranes is missing -- apparently for good.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, deputy chairman of the Senate rackets committee, called today for a campaign to prod Congress into cracking down on labor-management racketeers.

The trustees who shape the policies of our colleges, universities and social agencies are chosen on the basis of proved leadership and citizen responsibility. No man better exemplifies these qualities than Bayard F. Pope. That he has recently retired as chairman of the board of trustees of the Community Service Society is a matter of general regret.

The 200th anniversary of the Columbia University libraries will be celebrated tomorrow night. A few shelves of books that were among the earliest acquisitions of the library and the recently acquired papers of John Jay will go on display in the Nicholas Murray Butler Library.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -New York Democrats in the House of Representatives made public today a letter to Marion B. Folsom, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, opposing sale of Ellis Island for commercial purposes.
Three high school students and two college students saw little hope yesterday for an early break in the East-West deadlock. They expressed their views in a New York Times Youth Forum.
John H. Mitchell was named yesterday to the newly created post of superintendent of the New York City Housing Authority police.

Events tonight: Bizet's "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Jeanne Mitchell, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Nicanor Zableta, harpist, Town Hall, 8:30, and New York Symphonic Choir, Willie T. Jones conducting, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 -- New Delhi is always an early rising sort of town. Long before light, vegetable carts are creaking through the streets, Sikh taxi drivers are combing out their long hair by the roadside, milkmen's carts bang on their bicycles and from night watchman to night watchman the last chain of calls is shouted across the gardens.

The United Corporation reported over the week-end net investment income of $3,436,111, equal to 24.4 cents a share, for 1957, compared with $3,332,350, or 23.7 cents a share, in 1956. In addition to this income, the investment company also reported profits of $3,196,326, or 22.7 cents a share, from the sale of securities.
Detroit, Mich., is planning to offer bond issues totaling $13,715,000 on Feb. 4.

Most of us at some time have been patients in hospitals and know how much visits from friends mean. But when one is disabled by a long-term illness and the hospital is one's only home, with the volunteer one's only friend, holy much more do these visits signify.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A special House investigatory subcommittee, emerging from a stormy preparation period, begins public hearings tomorrow on how the big Federal administrative agencies operate.

In your Jan. 16 letter column "State Trooper" has hit on the only way I can see to stop much of the highway slaughter. He suggests taxing cars by horsepower instead of weight when cars are registered.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 26 -The Cyprus situation took a new turn today as it was announced that the island's Governor General. Sir Hugh Foot, was en route here.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 26 -- Arthur B. Eisenhower, oldest brother of President Eisenhower, died at his home late today. He had suffered with a heart ailment for some time since his retirement from a post with a Kansas City bank. He was 71 years old.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 26 -- Billy Beck, Dartmouth's nimble assistant ski coach who has represented the United States on two Olympic teams, clinched the Alpine combined event as the two-day Stowe Cup competition was concluded on Spruce Peak today.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's "Climax!" program plans to present a television dramatization next month of the life and death of Albert Anastasia, the notorious racketeer.
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev has taken a major political gamble in his drive to increase the Soviet Union's production of food.

ABOARD THE COAST GUARD CUTTER PERSEUS, JAN. 26 (UP) -- A record in the 1,500-mile San Diego-Acapulco, Mexico, yacht race appeared just over the horizon late today as the eighty-two-foot sloop Windward continued at a pace that could crack the old mark by more than a day.
THE curtain will rise tomorrow on what has been described as "the most super-colossal fashion show in America." It is the fourteenth annual parade of styles for the March of Dimes.
HONG KONG, Jan 26 -- Mao Tse-tung Chief of State of Communist China, made a special goodwill gesture toward India last Thursday by receiving the outgoing Indian Ambassador in Canton.
Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan, the only Republican member of the City Council said yesterday that he saw no need for a special commission to draft a new City Charter.

Maria Meneghini Callas will sing the role of Violetta in Verdi's "La Traviata" for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday, Feb. 6. Mario Zanasi will make his American debut as the elder Germont in the same performance, which will be a benefit for the Free Milk Fund for Babies.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 (AP) -- One of major league baseball's biggest giveaway programs ended today as the Baltimore Orioles signed Dave Nicholson for a price estimated at $110,000 or above.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Democrats increased pressure on the Administration today to come up with a speedy and comprehensive reorganization of the Defense Department.
A Jesuit editor urged yesterday that non-Catholics join with Roman Catholics to combat "a progressive debasement of public morals in the entertainment and the advertising world."
Allan P. Kirby was projected last night as the man most likely to succeed Robert R. Young as board chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, which controls a far-flung railroad empire.
The steamship charter market still exists but that is all. It has come through another week of depressed volume and lower rates and its future is still dark.

St. John's University, the metropolitan area's only basketball team rated among the top twenty in the nation, got back into action last week and remained unbeaten. But the Redmen suffered a serious setback through an injury.

In boating circles there's a strong opinion that ten days are not enough for a national show in New York every January. The forty-eighth annual exhibit closed last night at the Coliseum with a traditional final din of bells, horns and sirens.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Film production costs will move upward again as a result of automatic pay increases for actors and extra players. They take effect this week in accordance with terms of basic bargaining agreements negotiated in 1956 by the Screen Actors Guild and the Screen Extras Guild with the Association of Motion Picture Producers.
HAVANA, Jan. 26 (UP) -- A large band of rebels stormed the Oriente Province Jail at Boniato tonight and rescued two top lieutenants of the rebel leader Fidel Castro.
The Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick of Harvard University warned yesterday against the numerous "voices of authority" in the world.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 26 -- The new Chief of Staff of Israel's armed forces is a difficult man to keep up with, possibly because he starts a typical day with four miles of roadwork.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 26 -- The United States Government came under bitter attack today from one of Venezuela's most important political leaders for what he said was its support of Latin American dictators.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 26 -- A second attempt to launch a Vanguard rocket bearing a test satellite has been suspended because of mechanical troubles. It was learned that the first count-down on this new launching attempt began Wednesday night.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Moscow's latest fulminations against the Baghdad Pact are neither novel nor particularly frightening. It has become routine for the Kremlin to bark whenever the free world meets to improve its defenses. In this respect Soviet missile diplomacy represents no change from Soviet nuclear diplomacy, or the good old-fashioned cannon diplomacy of Stalin.
Cardinal Spellman presided yesterday at a pontifical mass of thanksgiving commemorating the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Paulist Fathers.

The men's clothing industry operated at 65 per cent of capacity last month, compared with 80 per cent in December, 1956, Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States, announced over the week-end.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 26 -- Stock market trading was focused last week on Royal Dutch rights. The issue was strong, indicating that liquidation by Dutch holders was not as heavy as was feared or that a syndicate was supporting the market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A Harvard economist attacked today the validity of the theory that higher wages benefit the whole economy and spread prosperity.
Grace O'Connor, contralto who was heard at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, sang a difficult program and acquitted herself well.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 26 -Foreign Minister Fatin Rustu Zorlu of Turkey confirmed today that the Baghdad Pact countries were working toward a unified military command.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Gene Sandvig of Minneapolis, 26-year-old former Olympic skater, captured the national outdoor speed-skating title today from his fellow townsman, Ken Bartholomew. Bartholomew have held or shared the crown for the last eight years.

THERE were undertones of sadness to the boisterous hilarity of the baseball writers' show at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The Giants and the Dodgers, as indigenous to New York as the skyline or Broadway, were irrevocably gone and the press-box tenants tried to give this situation the Pagliacci treatment of Laugh, Clown, Laugh. It was a brave effort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Percival F. Brundage, Budget Director, said today he would "like to find some way of tapping" the money spent on gambling, perhaps through a bond issue tied with a lottery.
The Grace Line expects to increase its competitive position greatly by dividing its run to the Pacific Coast of South America into two separte services.

Speaking on Jan. 9 for the American people "to all other peoples, especially those of the Soviet Union," President Eisenhower said that "the problem is to find a way of translating this universal desire" (for peace) "into action." He added: "This will require more than words of peace.

Some of the pioneers in surgery of the heart and circulatory system will speak tomorrow at an all-day conference at the Waldorf-Astoria. The meeting, sponsored by the New York Heart Association, is the association's fourth annual Conference on Cardiovascular Surgery.
COMO, Italy, Jan. 26 -- The United States contract bridge team fell behind both Italy and Argentina today in the ten-day contest for the 1958 world championship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- An agreement permitting Yugoslavia to buy about $60,000,000 worth of United States farm surpluses for Yugoslav currency will be announced soon.

Despite demands of Mayor Wagner that budget requests for 1958-59 be "cut to the bone," ninety city agencies so far have asked for a total of $15,538,269 more than was allocated to them in the present budget.
Stocks ended unevenly off yesterday after a session visibly affected by spot news developments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Following is the text of the joint communique of the United States and the Soviet Union on cultural exchanges and the "letter of understanding" exchanged between the negotiators:
TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- New Jersey may be without an Attorney General for an indefinite period, it became apparent tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics reported today that rising costs and governmental economy had cut its research efforts as compared with those of the Russians.
Mrs. Richard Monroe Cukor, benefit chairman, has announced that the Parents Guild chapter of the Women's Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest is planning a benefit dance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today denied a rehearing to Gilbert Green and Henry Winston. They were among the eleven top Communist leaders convicted in 1949 of conspiring to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the government.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday upheld the validity of the tweleve-month-old ambulance-chasing inquiry being conducted by Supreme Court Justice George A. Arkwright.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Treasury announced today that it had sold its regular issue of ninety-one-day bills at the lowest interest rate in nearly two years.

Grown-up New Yorkers who spent their childhood in this city carry into their adulthood a mixed image of New York policemen. Only vaguely are they likely to recall the cop who stood guard on the school corner. More clearly they remember the patrol car that was forever turning into the street where they played stickball and the policeman emerging to confiscate the sawed-off broomstick as if it were a sawed-off shotgun.
A scaffold of iron and wood rose yesterday like a grotesque catcher's mask around the Corinthian columns of the Soldiers and Sailors Monument, on Riverside Drive at Eighty-ninth Street.
The National Labor Relations Board, in a major policy shift, has put additional strength into its machinery for barring jurisdictional strikes.

In your column for Jan. 8 there appeared a letter from Reuben A. Lazarus, favoring the Legislature rather than a constitutional convention as a vehicle for amending the Constitution of the State of New York. What Mr. Lazarus forgets is that such a convention does not have only the weaknesses of democracy, but also its strengths -very great strengths, I must add.

James Crane Kellogg 3d, chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange for the last two terms, announced yesterday that he would not be a candidate to succeed himself. He is the senior partner in the specialist firm of Spear, Leeds Kellogg.

The City Housing Authority, facing reorganization by the State Legislature, has hired James William Gaynor to do a quick job of advising it on putting its management procedures in better order. Mr. Gaynor is the authority's former executive director.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 27 -- Egypt and Israel exchanged captive fishermen today at a border meeting arranged by Lieut. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, commander of the United Nations Emergency Force.
The Texas Company plans to gain control of the Seaboard Oil Company of Dallas, Tex., in which it has held a third interest since 1933.
AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today denied accusations that it had misrepresented facts in its tire advertisement.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Ashley Cooper cracked a longtime jinx and retained the Australian national tennis championship today by beating Mal Anderson, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Following is the text of the opening statement of Secretary of State Dulles at the fourth Ministerial Council session of the Baghdad Pact in Ankara, Turkey, today:

In 1851, when the schooner America went to England and brought back a silver mug that later became known as the America's Cup, she carried in her crew a lad named Henry Sears, cabin boy. In 1876, another schooner, Madeleine, beat Canada's Countess of Dufferin off Sandy Hook for that cup. Madeleine's owner was John Stiles Dickerson.

An eighty-foot circus mural was presented to Bronx Hospital yesterday by nine art students of the Morris High School in the Bronx. It took three months to complete and was painted on ten panels. It has been placed in the Pediatrics ward.
The J. I. Case Company turned in a net profit of $1,303,628 in its fiscal year ended Oct. 31, after operating in the red the year before.
A Queens lawyer was arrested last night and charged with having stolen most of a client's life savings by forging two bank checks totaling $12,000.
The Hungarian shake-up seems likely to vest more authority in the hands of the hard-line Stalinist faction of the Hungarian Communist party.

The small, wiry man hadn't been in the room for a moment when he was besieged by old friends -- most of whom he hadn't seen for years. They took his hand, shook it hard and said, "Welcome back Clair."
E. R. Squibb Sons and two of its unions have taken only two hours to negotiate their 1958 contracts.
LAST night's installment in the "O. S. S." series on Channel 7 was an exciting story of counter-sabotage measures during World War II.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Charley Boswell, blind golfing champion of international repute, who lost his sight in World War II, tonight was named the most courageous athlete of 1957 by the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association.
The major oil and gas holdings of the Atlas Corporation have been sold to American Petrofina, Inc., both companies announced yesterday.
Leading sales finance companies announced a cut of 1/4 percentage point yesterday in the yields on the commercial paper they sell directly to investors.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Investors were cautious and most industrial stocks drifted down slightly today. Hesitancy was attributed to fears of industrial strife, coupled with the irregular opening on Wall Street.
WEST CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The disinherited daughter of the founder of Publicker Industries, distillers, will receive $500,000 from his $11,900,000 estate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The Air Transport Association said today the Civil Aeronautics Board had "evaded its responsibilities" by announcing it was willing to approve an interim airline fare increase amounting to 6.6 per cent.

Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, zinc, copper, lead, tin, hides and wool rose; cocoa, world sugar months, potatoes and rubber declined, and price movements for cottonseed oil and the domestic sugar contract were mixed.
FROST reports to the contrary, there will be a rousing crop of oranges down south. Some of them, ripened in the north, will be there through the courtesy of Brett Winston.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- An agreement for a joint movie-making venture between an American company and this country was signed here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A late rally raised most grain futures on the Board of Trade today.

Jimmy Archer, tireless warrior from the Bronx, gained the decision over Danny Russo of Brooklyn, in the star bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The fight was a grueling one, packed through with action, and it pleased the crowd of 1,597 fans completely.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Harriman expects the state to have $98,500,000 more in tax revenues available for expenditure during the fiscal year opening April 1 than it will in the year now closing.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 2 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia complained today of the "big noise" made abroad over the recent strike of coal miners in Slovenia.
THE Abraham Straus model rooms opening today are as American as the eagle that hangs over the entrance to the exhibit and as modern as the style in which the bird is carved.
Bloodmobiles of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will visit the Cities Service Oil Company, 70 Pine Street, and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, 708 First Avenue, today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The House investigation of big Federal regulatory agencies opened today with questioning bearing hard on the role of the White House in
GENEVA, Jan. 27 -The Hungarian refugee problem in Yugoslavia has been completely solved, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.
In a move to help brokers cut down overhead and at the same time share their specialist experience, a northern New Jersey real estate broker has organized a company called Mutual Realty.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 27 -- Robert D. Levitt, newspaper and television executive, was found dead today in his country home here. He was a brother of State Controller Arthur Levitt and the former husband of Ethel Merman, musical comedy star.
Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, was told yesterday that $250,000 in research grants was received last year by the institutions it sponsors in Israel.
ROSLYN, L. I., Jan. 27 -- A recommendation for the construction of a $2,600,000 North Hempstead Town incinerator here has brought a storm of protest from village officials and civic associations.
A young man was shot dead on a Brooklyn street last night while walking with a friend in what the police termed "the aftermath of a gang fight."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Truman today sold 220 acres of the old Truman family farm at near-by Grandview to local investors. It will be used for a multi-million-dollar shopping and residential development.
The establishment of the first Consultation and Information Center on Judaism here was announced.

The bid of the Manhattan Refrigerating Company for a five-year lease of the 3,000,000 cubic feet of cold-storage facilities of the Bronx Terminal Market was accepted yesterday by the Department of Markets.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The National Football League and the Players Association today discussed the feasibility of a player pension plan.
The Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear a plea by a ship line for injunctions to bar seamen and marine officers from peaceful picketing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Supreme Court held today that the Federal Trade Commission did not have to attack discriminatory prices on an industry-wide basis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -The national income climbed to record annual rate in the third quarter of 1957 and then fell back as the current business decline set in, the Government reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Dag Hammarskjold urged an international committee of scientists today to ignore the pressures of politics and speak out "with a single, objective voice" on the hazards of atomic radiation.
The Military Sea Transportation Service announced yesterday that it had purchased forty new radar sets from the Raytheon Manufacturing Company of Waltham, Mass., for $385,000.
The affairs of the Nassau Management Company were taken out of the hands of its principal officers yesterday and turned over to two court-appointed receivers.

RIO DE, JANEIRO, Jan. 27 (UP) -- The world's coffee producing countries signed today an agreement that eliminated for the time being the possibility of world export controls and price supports on coffee.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- Mrs. Marion Borgstrand, retiring Bayonne school teacher, received an unusual farewell today from her two-score pupils. The sixth-grade youngsters at Public School 3 escorted her to the New Jersey Legislature here. Then, while she sat with the remaining students in the Assembly and Senate galleries, 10-year-old Richard Cohen, president of the class, took the floor of each house to wish her farewell.
BIGELOW'S new "International Style Group" carpets seem to have something for everyone's taste and budget. They will be introduced today in B. Altman's rug department.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 (AP) -- For the third straight day, the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Minneapolis Lakers, 113-102, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
PARIS, Jan. 26 -- An exciting peek into some fabrics undoubtedly slated for popularity in the spring and summer collections was presented today by Ascher, an English fabric firm.
" Carmen" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera last night, with Blanche Thebom singing the title role for the first time this season.
The Motormen's Benevolent Association is challenging the right of the Transit Authority to continue its suit for a permanent anti-strike injunction.
IN America, hamlets get fashion from the big cities. In Israel, this system is reversed. The villages set the styles worn in the metropolis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Labor's anticorruption machinery was geared up today for action involving two more organizations, the International Union of Operating Engineers and the International Jewelry Workers Union.

While the Secretary of State visits part of the Middle East Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge, head of the United States Delegation to the United Nations, is leaving this evening for a tour of his own. Ambassador Lodge is visiting two of the Baghdad Pact countries, Iran and Pakistan, and is also going to Afghanistan and India.
A proposal to merge the Thiokol Chemical Corporation and Reaction Motors, Inc., was announced yesterday by directors of the two missile motor manufacturing concerns.

OTTAWA, Jan. 27 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker and his Conservative supporters in the House of Commons are acting more and more like a government preparing for a new general election. That was the interpretation placed on new Government moves to benefit the provinces and to use federal funds for the relief of unemployment.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles promised the Baghdad Pact nations today that "mobile power of great force" would be supplied in case of Commu nist attack. He spoke as the Baghdad Pact nations opened the fourth ministerial meeting with appeals for more economic aid.
DURHAM, N. C., Jan. 27 (UP) -- Duke's fast break proved too much for West Virginia tonight as the Blue Devils upset the previously undefeated Mountaineers, ranked No. 1 in the nation, 72 -- 68.
LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Soviet Ambassador Jacob A. Malik asked the British tonight to get together with the Russians on a bilateral nonaggression pact.
Burglars, working with what the police said was a neat and professional style, broke into an Edison Hotel suite late Sunday and made away with $250,000 in jewelry and cash.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- In the early returns from Paris, two strong votes have been cast for the chemise. They were registered by Pierre Cardin, one of the bright young comers of the Paris couture, and by Mademoiselle Mad, a longtime fixture in Paris designing who is formerly of Mad Carpentier and is now doing her first collection for Jean Patou. Both raised skirt hems, many of Cardin's showing the knee cap.
The cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 13 to 31 points (65 cents to $1.55 a bale) yesterday.

A little less than two years ago Lieut. Gen. Sir John Bagot Glubb was dismissed from his post as Commander of the Arab Legion after thirty-six years of service with the Arabs. He gives the story behind his dismissal by King Hussein in a book titled "A Soldier With the Arabs."
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev renewed tonight his call for a summit meeting of East and West.
A renewal of one of Manhattan's most bitter election rivalries was in the making yesterday in the Seventeenth Congressional District.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Pay rises for at least ten key members of his personal staff, the eight Court of Claims judges and many others in the Administration were recommended by Governor Harriman in his budget today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -The United States and the Soviet Union announced today a compromise agreement to increase fivefold the cultural, technical, education and sports exchanges between the two countries.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 27 -- Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal, President of Venezuela's Government junta, said tonight that elections for a constituent assembly would be held this year. A President of Venezuela, the admiral said, will be elected about six months later, some time next year.
An American scientist speculated here yesterday that the Russians might one day be capable of freezing Florida or turning the Midwest into a permanent drought belt.
The State of Minnesota is planning to borrow $12,000,000 to finance public improvements on Feb. 11. Dated March 1, 1958, the bonds will come due serially on March 1 from 1961 to 1977.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Jan. 27 -- The 142-foot ketch Atlantis has left on an eight-month cruise to investigate the deep currents in the South Atlantic Ocean, the ocean bottom and the influence of a large river system on ocean-bottom deposits.
The Government of Surinam and the Aluminum Company of America have signed an agreement for a $150 million hydroelectric power and aluminum smelter project.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Harriman proposed today record outlays of $480,217,000 on highways in the state in the fiscal year that opens April 1.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Jan. 27 -- The anti-Administration Independent party scored a sweeping victory yesterday in Iceland's municipal elections.

VIENNA, Jan. 27 -- Janos Kadar, whom the Russians appointed Premier of Hungary after they had suppressed the 1956 revolt, announced his resignation today to make way for his first deputy, Dr. Ferenc Munnich.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 27 -- Two members of the local police force had to take a boat trip today to recover evidence in a numbers game arrest.
REYKJAVIK, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- The coalition Government appeared to be in grave danger today.

A further decline in steel production is expected this week. The American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday that the industry had scheduled output of 1,479,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -Neil H. McElroy has told Senate investigators that the Administration hopes to have its Defense Department reorganization plan ready for Congress by the end of March.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A strong move developed in the Senate Finance Committee today to grant the Administration only $3,000,000,000 of its requested $5,000,000,000 increase in the national debt ceiling.

CAIRO, Jan. 26 -- Syria's strong man, Lieut. Col. Abdul Hamid Serraj, has been in Cairo for the last week, secretly working out military and political details of the proposed union of Egypt and Syria, it was learned today.

The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation and its subsidiaries had net income last year of $23,024,249 on sales of $538,525,429, John E. Bierwirth, president, reported yesterday. This compares with net earnings of $22,632,689 for 1956, originally reported as $20,103,816. Sales for that year were $543,099,524.
Charles (Chub) Feeney, the San Francisco Giants' vice president, said yesterday that the club was still "talking trade" with several other National League teams.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The National Education Association announced today that Marion B. Folsom, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, and his 82-year-old former teacher, Miss Lila Windsor of McRae, Georgia, will be given the 1958 Golden Key Awards.
The National Legion of Decency, Roman Catholic film reviewing group, placed eleven films in the "C" or "condemned" category during the twelve months ended last October.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 27 -- Juan D. Peron left Venezuela this afternoon for the Dominican Republic.

Governor Harriman's fourth annual budget message is a sobering document. It is long on spending, short on revenue-raising. It speeds the fuller departure from pay-aswe-go policy that was long the state's pride. It reaps the retribution of fiscal irresponsibility of the past three years in which the Republicans of the Legislature outdid the Governor in competition for political favor by cutting taxes and retreating from needed tax increases.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Supreme Court reversed today a lower court order that had blocked a disputed stock issue planned by the late Robert R. Young's Alleghany Corporation. Mr. Young committed suicide in Palm Beach, Fla., last Saturday.
Columbia University scientists, drifting on an ice floe in the Arctic night, have lowered a camera a mile or more through icy waters to photograph the ocean floor.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -The Philadelphia Electric Company earned $33,235,352 last year, equal to $2.60 a share, on 12,806,125 shares outstanding Dec. 31. These figures compare with earnings of $31,545,980, or $2.59 a share, on a smaller number of shares in 1956.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 27 -- A West German Air Force team left for Britain today to survey the market for fighter aircraft.
Floyd Patterson, the heavyweight champion, will defend his title in England this June, but first will have a "tune-up" championship fight in the United States.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- The nation's coat and suit industry has the capacity to create its own prosperity, Max E. Weinstock, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, said here today.

Sam Snead, winner of more than a hundred tournaments, will head a list of golfing celebrities who will be honored tonight. The occasion will be the metropolitan golf writers' Gold Tee Award dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill to prohibit payment of more than $1,000,000,000 in "windfall" tax refunds to liquor distillers and tobacco manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -The Defense Department has again put off a decision on whether to press an accelerated schedule for producing the first atomic-powered airplane.
Brooklyn put its own flag on public display yesterday for the first time, making up for a deficiency dating to 1683.
Despite a $5,371,000 drop in fourth - quarter earnings, the Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation last year achieved the second highest profits in its history.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- The Soviet Union made public today its final economic report for 1957. It said that last year's reorganization of industrial management was already bearing fruit.

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 27 (AP) -Trial runs were halted abruptly and orders went out to repair one of the curves today after a series of accidents marred practice for next week-end's world four-man bobsled championships.
HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- A "second front" was reported to have been opened today by rebel forces against the Government of President Fulgencio Batista in the mountains of Las Villas Province.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The New York Central Railroad proposed today to raise its fares and charges on its Weehawken ferries by 393.7 per cent.

NEWARK, Jan. 27 -- Miss Antoinette Quinby Scudder, co-founder and president of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, died today at her home here, 49 Manchester Place, apparently of a heart attack. She was 72 years old.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 26 -- No matter what other benefits may be derived from Baghdad Pact meetings here, their sessions afford an opportunity for Turkey's leaders to show their diplomatic friends and neighbors this country's massive new Parliament buildings.

Iceland never did go Communist, even at the height of the silly season. The farthest it went in that direction, in the election of June, 1956, was to produce an Althing, or Parliament (said to be the oldest in the world), which had eight Communists out of fifty-two members.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Howard Hughes, industrialist and former owner of R. K. O. Pictures, is being sued in Los Angeles Superior Court by a former employe for back wages.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors said today that failure to repeal the Youth Court Act would be "a dangerous failure in the state's responsibility toward solving the serious problems of juvenile delinquency and youth crime."

IT is often believed abroad that America's favorite meat is beef. We are regarded by many as a nation that subsists mainly -- and rather luxuriously -- on porterhouse steak and prime ribs of beef. Actually, on a country-wide basis, we eat more pork than beef.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 27 -- Turkish Cypriotes rioted during most of the day in the capital city of this Mediterranean island colony of Britain.

A new and exciting period has now opened in Cuba. President Batista has restored freedom of the press in Havana and also has lifted the suspension of constitutional guarantees except in the Province of Oriente. For having done this much, General Batista is to be commended.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 27 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors today balked at plans of the new County Park way Authority for a toll station on the Cross County Parkway near some of Mount Vernon's finest homes.
MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Myron N. Goodwin's Jimmer passed his first test for the Bahamas and Flamingo Stakes today -when he won the $7,500 Corsair Purse at Hialeah. But he had to survive a foul claim.
While the meteoric career of Robert R. Young was recounted in full detail yesterday, the stock of the New York Central Railroad, of which he was chairman, sped almost nowhere.

Plans for the presentation of twelve plays by Nobel Prize winners, over a two-year period, were disclosed yesterday by Norris Houghton and T. Edward Hambleton, founders and managers of Second Avenue's Phoenix Theatre.
If Dick Waite had his way -- and he admits he doesn't -- there would be wrestling competition on the interscholastic level in New York.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- The Chrysler Corporation sent home 5,000 employes at its Dodge main plant in Hamtramck at noon today because of "scheduling difficulties."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- It is a pity that Ambassador William Sterling Byrd Lacy, who has just finished negotiations with Soviet Ambassador Georgi N. Zaroubin, is such a devotee of unpublicized diplomacy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Los Angeles TV-viewers will be able to acquire without charge a science-fact education in extra-terrestrial travel beginning Feb. 15 when KTTV, local independent TV station, begins "Space School."

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 27 -- The nomination of candidates ended today and the stage is now set for the first Sudanese general elections since the country attained independence two years ago. Votes will be cast from Feb. 27 onward and counted March 10.
The Board of Education's proposed 1958-59 budget came under heavy criticism at a public hearing yesterday.

After three months of quiet negotiations the United States and Soviet Russia have signed an agreement in Washington that marks at least a beginning toward carrying out one part of the Geneva directive of 1955. The agreement falls far short of the Western proposals which sought to remove one of the root causes of East-West tension by lifting the Iron Curtain.
JEANNE MITCHELL, violinist, who made her debut here eleven years ago, returned to the stage of Carnegie Hall last night for a solo recital.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 27 -- The Mayor and two other officials of Fair Lawn were among five persons who pleaded not guilty today to indictments returned in an investigation of municipal garbage collection contracts.
James R. Hoffa was reported yesterday to have killed a controversial project to raise a defense fund for Teamster Union officials in trouble with the law.

SINCE the Middle Ages, and probably before, human beings have thought of the harp as the favorite instrument in heaven. In recent years it is likely that many have accounted for this predilection as the result of the harp's feathery, pretty tone, and perhaps its capacity to suggest the flight of angels.
The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics plunged yesterday into the spreading struggle over leadership of the nation's prospective assaults on space.
ROME, Jan. 27 -- The use of the Polish language to define four dioceses in an official Roman Catholic Church publication has created discord between West Germany and the Vatican.

FEZ, Morocco, Jan. 27 -- Putting aside current political differences, the countries of the Arab world found new unity today with the opening of the first conference of Arab members of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Attorneys for the state, the city and two Negro boys seeking admission to Girard College decided today to ask the Pennsylvania Supreme Court to reargue its decision of last Friday.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 27 -The United States will give aid to Ceylon this year totaling 7,364,000 rupees (about $1,500,000). An official agreement is to be signed in a few days.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia asserted today that the Western Big Three's replies to the Soviet summit meeting bid contain proposals that "can only lead any international problem into an impasse."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, sharply disputing Vice President Richard M. Nixon, said today Congress would receive legislation aimed at equalizing the anti-trust status of professional sports.
COMO, Italy, Tuesday, Jan. 28 -- The United States contract bridge team last night narrowed Italy's lead and overtook Argentina in a three-nation contest for the 1958 world championship.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Parts of New England faced today their greatest flood threat since Hurricane Diane of 1955.
" Dick and the Duchess," a comedy-adventure series filmed in London, will end its run March 15. It is televised on Saturdays from 8:30 to 9 P. M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today new valuation provisions of the Customs Simplification Act would go into effect Feb. 27, slightly reducing duties on a number of commodities.

ROME, Tuesday, Jan. 28 -- Prince Filippo Napoleone Orsini di Solofra was hospitalized last night after what was reputed to be an apparent attempt to take his own life. As one of the two "Prince Assistants to the Pontifical Throne," the 37-year-old nobleman is one of the highest lay dignitaries of the Papal Court.

The second annual Dance Magazine Awards for achievements in the dance field were made yesterday at a cocktail reception in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel. The recipients were Alicia Markova, ballerina; Jerome Robbins, choreographer; Lucia Chase, co-director of the American Ballet Theatre, and Jose Limon, dancer and choreographer.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The Republican State Chairman held tonight the first of three party conferences for legislators and county chairmen. Attending were representatives of eighteen counties in the Third and Fourth Judicial Districts.
JUDGING by the increasing number of oriental shops in New York that sell everything from jade to rice crackers, it may be only a question of time before a few Jinrikshas turn up on Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -President Eisenhower sent his Education Message to Congress today. Democrats, however, are ready to push for twice as much Federal aid as he asked.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 27 (AP) -- All but four of Nassau's sixteen strike-bound hotels will reopen at once for partial operation, the Bahamas Hotel Association announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -The Administration asked Congress today to liberalize the atomic-energy law to permit closer cooperation on atomic weapons with friendly nations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Eisenhower's nomination of William P. Rogers as Attorney General.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) --Representative John Dowdy urged Congress today to "put the fear of the law" into "peddlers of smut and filth."
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Harriman answered Mayor Wagner's request for $40,000,000 in new state aid today with proposals to allot the city $13,450,000 in new assistance.

A victory over Antonio Medina of Venezuela in the fifth round yesterday enabled Arthur B. Bisguier of New York to retain his lead in the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas at the Club Militar in Bogota, according to a report received through Colombian news sources.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- "The motion-picture business is going through a revolution, and some people are bound to get hurt, but the business will emerge in healthier condition than it has ever known."
FORT CHURCHILL, Man., Jan. 27 (CP) -- Scientists fired two rockets eighty-five and ninety miles into the air today in the fourth and fifth launchings of 1958 in International Geophysical Year tests.
The Supreme Court yesterday broke down a barrier against which the late Robert R. Young had been battering the last two and one-half years.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 (UP) -- The Argentine Government tonight outlawed all strikes in the country for the next forty days. The announcement came shortly after light and power workers had canceled a strike that threatened to disrupt essential services.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- The Army, not the Navy, will make the next attempt to put the first United States earth satellite into orbit.

THE problems of conformity in frontier days are dramatized in Frank X. Tolbert's "The Staked Plain."* This is an enjoyable, free-swinging historical novel about impulsive men and women. Some were Texans, some were Comanches, some were blue-uniformed soldiers of the Great White Father in faraway Washington. Each group tended, to a belligerent degree, to deplore the ideals of any other -- and thereby hangs Mr. Tolbert's lively tale.
A nation that is rapidly becoming heavily urbanized got good news yesterday. Cities are becoming healthier places to live.

The Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases has raised its rates for private and semi-private patients by 8 1/2 per cent in an effort to reduce the $400,000 deficit it incurred last year.

BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., Jan. 27 -- The Rev. Dr. Truman B. Douglass of New York, executive vice president of the Board of Home Missions of the Congregational Christian Churches, took sharp issue today with churchmen who attribute the so-called crisis in education to the "secularization" of this country's colleges and universities.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 27 -The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham said today that saving even one soul would have made his 1957 evangelistic crusade in New York worthwhile. "There were many hundreds," he said.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 26 -- A dispatch in The New York Times of Jan. 2 that there were widespread corruption and a lack of political freedom in Iran was criticized today by a court official as being untrue and unfair.
The Santa Fe Railway had a net income in 1957 of $61,941,791, compared with $70,213,171 in 1956, E. S. Marsh, president, reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Harriman today submitted a record state budget of $1,800,800,000 to the Legislature.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- A high State Department official called today for continued reduction of trade barriers among the free nations in order to counteract the Soviet Union's economic offensive.
STUART, Fla., Jan. 27 -- The way it is down here now, in a cocoanut shell, the wise old heads have taken command and there are more wise old heads here than anywhere in the civilized world.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 27 -Puerto Rico offered today to increase its program for aiding underdeveloped countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to end the Federal tax exemption now given to certain church-related activities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower gave a White House luncheon today for a group of business and civic leaders he hopes to rally behind the Administration's four-billion-dollar foreign aid program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today it would be a wonderful thing to bring a lot of Russian students to this country and to let them stay a full year even if Russia admitted no United States students.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -Gene Sarazen, the top golfer in the nation a generation ago, battled back from 5 strokes off the pace and won his second Professional Golfers Association seniors' championship today with 288.

Net earnings of the National Biscuit Company for 1957 increased 8.9 per cent to $22,052,473 from $20,286,954 the year before, George H. Coppers, president, reported yesterday in a preliminary statement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration today scheduled a public hearing March 10 to determine whether certain synthetically produced colors for use in foods should be tested and certified as harmless before they are marketed.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The Government demanded its money back today from a ballet featuring the much-discussed work of Francoise Sagan, novelist, and Bernard Buffet, painter, two of the brightest young stars of French arts and letters.
Net assets of the Massachusetts Investors Trust tumbled $122,486,335 in 1957, according to the annual report released yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 -- Neither wind nor rain nor the dark of night could keep Cardinal Spellman of New York from a baptism here yesterday. The baby was his grand nephew.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 27 -Americans in Tunisia and Morocco are subject these days to a growing barrage of appeals, criticisms and warnings about United States policy toward Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- On the point raised before the Johnson Preparedness subcommittee by Gen. Nathan F. Twining -- that Congress should not seek to require a military officer to characterize as "adequate" or "inadequate" for national security a budget figure for his service branch that has been fixed by the Commander in Chief in the White House -- Gen. Thomas D. White made some very sound comments to the same Senate group.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 27 -- The Grand National Assembly (Parliament) unanimously adopted today a resolution attributing the two bombings of United States property this morning to "the instigation of Communist agents seeking to destroy Turkish-American friendship."

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 27 -The head of the Rabbinical Council of America declared here tonight that political Zionism no longer was the 'binding link bewteen American Jews and Israel as in the past." The council embraces 750 Orthodox Jewish spiritual leaders with a total congregation of more than 1,000,000.

The investment companies fared no better than the average investor during the market declines of last fall, according to the year-end report released yesterday by the National Association of Investment Companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- President Eisenhower presented today the first gold medals awarded for distinguished federal service to J. Edgar Hoover, Federal Bureau of Investigation Director, and four other top officials.
John A. Roosevelt, youngest son of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, said yesterday that his company had been retained as public relations counsel to the Republic of Haiti.
HARTFORD, Jan. 28 -- Fred R. Zeller, state controller for 13 years in the period since 1939, announced today he was a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor this year.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 28 -- The Puerto Rican Government disclosed today it had offered to help Florida in aiding distressed migratory farm workers in the state.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Government spending seems likely to provide the only significant "upward thrust" for the economy this year, six experts testified today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn and Representatiye Joseph W. Martin Jr., minority leader, said today that the President's education program was already in trouble in Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts, already loaded with talented quarterbacks, picked first in the National Football League college player draft today and selected Quarterback Ray Brown, the hero of Mississippi's Sugar Bowl victory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -The Interstate Commerce Commission asked today for more time to give "full consideration" to the railroads' proposal for freight rate increases.
The Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday an 11 per cent gain in net income last year, although net assets fell more than $21,000,000.

NOW is the time when most women begin to plan their spring shopping. The frustrated among them who spend hours flipping through racks of clothes without finding anything to suit them may now be guided to their goal by a fashion expert.
A SPRIGHTLY and highly engaging exhibition of graphic work by three very individual modern painters goes on view today in the main floor galleries of the Museum of Modern Art.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Jan. 28 -- Political observers were cautious today in assaying the possible effect on the national coalition Government of the anti-Government Independence party's election victory Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Joseph S. Fay, paroled union extortionist, acknowledged today that during his eight years in Sing Sing his wife had received a salary from the Newark local of the International Union of Operating Engineers.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 -Oleta O'Connor Yates, San Francisco Communist party leader, was re-sentenced today to a year in jail by United States Judge William C. Mathes on charges of criminal contempt.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 28 -- Aides of Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes reported today that a pact had been signed last night to settle the Guatemalan Presidential election.
Prices of cotton futures advanced 16 to 20 points (80 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday. The market was somewhat quieter than on Monday.
" MICKEY SPILLANE'S MIKE HAMMER" roughhoused onto WCBS-TV last night, spilling over with lust, violence and chicanery. Darren McGavin played Mike Hammer, the private eye, with sinister gusto.

Two teen-age girls were stabbed in the back yesterday as they were changing trains at Franklin Avenue and Fulton Street, Brooklyn. The girls were on their way home after examinations at Bishop McDonnell Memorial High School.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Syrian Cabinet today gave final approval to union of Syria and Egypt.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 28 -- The harsh effects that the Dutch-Indonesian dispute has had on people is beginning to stir critical second thoughts here about the wisdom of the Dutch policy on Netherlands New Guinea.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company yesterday reported a record $688,245,862 in sales and other revenues despite a decline in the shipment of steel products in 1957. This compares with the previous high of $684,041,021 set in 1956.

NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 28 -The newly elected Mayor of Naha and his leftist political allies are moving fast to maintain their position on the crest of the wave of feeling against the United States administration of the Ryukyu Islands.
Quotas that have reduced the volume of foreign petroleum imported into the United States were described yesterday as a major factor in the cancellation of tanker orders at American shipyards.

The Penn-Texas industrial empire continues to shrink. Yesterday the board of directors approved the sale of another subsidiary, the Crescent Company of Pawtucket, R. I. The price was $1,100,000 in cash and the buyer was Milton C. Sapinsley, who founded Crescent in 1920 and sold it to the Penn-Texas Corporation in 1953 for the equivalent of $1,800,000 in stock.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The Soviet Union said today that the Western replies to its call for a meeting of government leaders contained nothing that could relax tension.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -The heads of three Federal regulatory agencies assured Congress today that, except for minor limitations, they operated without interference from the Executive Branch of the Government.

NEWARK, Jan. 28 -- Albert J. Schwenker, former assistant treasurer and assistant secretary of the Oradell branch of the Peoples Trust Company of Bergen County, pleaded guilty today in the Federal District Court to a five-count criminal information.

A NAVY blimp out of Lakehurst, N. J., will hover over the Atlantic off Fire Island the week-end of Feb. 8-9, if the weather's right, to resume instrument search for the wreck of the hybrid sail-steam packet Savannah. The first search flights started last month.
With the increasing use of heart-lung machines, surgery in New York City may be entering a new era in the repair of human hearts.

Victor Herbert's operetta "The Red Mill" will be televised in color on April 19 from 7:30 to 9 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network. It will be a feature of the "Du Pont Show of the Month" series.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Three more designers outlined today -- the third day of the Paris spring fashion collections -- their ideas of a woman's new look for spring. Chemises and shorter skirts appeared at all three houses.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Over Democratic opposition, the Senate approved today a bill empowering the Attorney General to conduct a state-wide crime investigation.

The future of Dan Cushman's novel "Stay Away, Joe" has finally been clarified to the satisfaction of all concerned. Instead of the popular book's emerging as a movie, the song-and-dance variation will reach Broadway first. This was decided yesterday by the sponsors, Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin.

Camp Green Acres, a family camp sponsored by the New York City Mission Society, will benefit from the March 24 showing of "South Pacific" at the Criterion Theatre. The Technicolor, Todd-AO film stars Rossano Brazzi, Mitzi Gaynor and John Kerr. Mrs. Whitehouse Walker is chairman of the event.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Jan. 28 -- When word about the new Air Force Academy gets back East, the young men of West Point and Annapolis may be encouraged to strike for better living conditions.
Mrs. John M. Young of 10 Gracie Square, chairman of the New York City Committee of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, will be hostess this afternoon at the organization's annual meeting.
John J. McCloy, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, told its annual meeting yesterday that he did not expect any drastic decline in earnings this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- "The Walter Winchell File" will be dropped by its sponsor, Revlon, on March 28.While the cosmetic company indicates that it probably will give up its claim on the 10-to-10:30 P. M. spot on the American Broadcasting Company network, it is understood the company will stay in network television if another show can be found.
WHITE potatoes are now one of the best investments at vegetable counters. At 6 cents a pound, the spuds are an economy. They are also delectable, if properly prepared.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today in an attack on current farm price supports the United States could not afford to waste land, manpower, machinery, gasoline, tires, and electricity in producing foods and fiber for storage far in excess of sensible reserves.
Foote, Cone Belding has obtained the account of the Zenith Radio Corporation for its radio, television and high-fidelity equipment. The agency's Chicago office will handle the account.
CAIRO, Jan. 27 -- The Communists were reported today to have been greatly disturbed over the proposed union of Egypt and Syria.
Forty-seven years of service on the city transit system will come to an end Friday for Edward T. McNally, general superintendent of the Transit Authority.
The New York Rangers will return to home ice after being away for seventeen days when they meet the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- Luxembourg does not oppose East-West top-level talks provided they are prepared sufficiently. Premier Jo seph Bech said in a letter today to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Virtually every section of the stock market closed dull today. However, losses were rarely more than a few pence.

William H. Harder, vice president of the Buffalo Savings Bank, Buffalo, N. Y., has been elected president of Institutional investors Mutual Fund. Inc. He succeeds Walter J. Hess, president of the Ridgewood Savings Bank, Ridgewood, Queens.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
A 16-year-old schoolboy and an 18-year-old trucker's helper were arrested yesterday on a charge of killing a man in Brooklyn in the aftermath of a gang fight.

ALTHOUGH twelve years and more have passed since the end of World War II, no German war novel has yet succeeded in capturing the imagination of the American reading public. And so far none has been worthy of comparison with Erich Maria Remarque's "All Quiet on the Western Front" or Arnold Zweig's "The Case of Sergeant Grischa." Wolfgang Ott's "Sharks and Little Fish"* is no exception.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 28 -- The Dutch Government has declared two military offiicals and an interpreter of the Soviet Embassy personally unacceptable and is about to ask for their recall.
An Air Force team described yesterday plans for a nationwide electronic party line to improve weather forecasting and reporting for the guided missile age.
The shipbuilding industry expanded last year to keep pace with the world trend toward bigger vessels, Walter L. Green, chairman of the board of the American Bureau of Shipping, said yesterday.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 28 (AP) -- On the basis of trial runs today, Dick Severino of Saratoga Springs, N. Y., and Stan Benham of Lake Placid, N. Y., probably will drive United States sleds in the world four-man championships here Saturday and Sunday.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Legislation establishing a June 3 primary date for this year's election was approved in the Assembly today over unanimous Democratic opposition.

A traditional gift to the Neediest came yesterday from printers at The New York Times. Members of the Times Chapel of the New York Typographical Union, Local 6, gave a total of $455 in memory of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph S. Ochs.
ROME, Jan. 28 -- Representatives of Jewish organizations dealing with general Jewish problems all over the world protested in Rome today against the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union.
The United Taxpayers party disclosed yesterday that it would take part in the election campaign this fall on a state-wide basis.
TOKYO, Jan. 28 -- Japanese Government leaders placed this country today among those backing a heads-of-government conference on problems between Communist and Democratic camps.

A new biography by Nancy Mitford, "Voltaire In Love," will be issued Feb. 21 by Harper. The book tells of the most important romance of Voltaire's life, his affair with the Marquise du Chatelet, "the divine Emilie." A scholar, physicist and philosopher in her own right, the Marquise was the mistress of Voltaire for about eleven years. The only flaw in "their idyll," Miss Mitford says, was Emilie's periodic jealousy.

REBECCA PETRIKIN of Stern's is a decorator after every woman's heart. When she arranges model rooms for the store she watches the budget assiduously. And then, like a woman, she goes out and buys for each setting one luxurious item that literally makes the decor.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 28 -- Israel lost two dead and six wounded in a three-hour battle with Syrians on the northeast frontier today.
ROME, Jan. 28 -- Italy outlawed licensed prostitution today under a bill, ratified by the Chamber with a large majority. All brothels must be closed within six months.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (UP) -- The State Supreme Court today refused to set up a possible roadblock in the path of the Los Angeles Dodgers to Chavez Ravine and their proposed 50,000-seat stadium
JOHN HAMILTON, a harpsichord, player who has been active on the West Coast, made his New York debut last night with a recital in Carnegie Recital Hall.
Time and again, George Goldfarb, principal of John Marshall Junior High School in Brooklyn, who committed suicide yesterday, would admonish his pupils to steer clear of trouble.

PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 29 (UP) -- British Gen. Sir Richard N. Gale, a World War II paratroop commander, was named Deputy Supreme Allied Commander in Europe today to succeed retiring Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery.

Mayor Wagner has made a plausible, persuasive case for more state aid to New York City in a letter sent to Governor Harriman and the legislative leaders. He argued calmly, almost resignedly, for correction of some old inequities. Mr. Harriman, in a passage in his budget message, recommended favorable treatment of some, but by no means all, of the Mayor's requests.

MIAMI, Jan. 28 -- The mutuals on the feature race at Hialeah today were not of high nutritive content. It was a six-furlong sprint for 3-year-olds and Calumet Farm was represented by the highly regarded team of Kentucky Pride and Tim Tam. The team was bet down to 1 to 4.

An exclusive license for a new plastic injection molding technique has been granted by Columbus Plastic Products, Inc., to the Polymer Chemicals Division of W. R. Grace Co. Grace will arrange licenses, involving royalty payments to Columbus, for plastic molders who wish to use the technique.
A Bronx County jury returned a verdict of guilty of first-degree murder last night against a Bronx man in the slaying of a taxicab driver. The verdict makes the death penalty mandatory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Eisenhower and his Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, made new pleas today for Congressional action on increases in postal rates.
Arthur W. Cain has been elected president of Volco Brass and Copper Company, Kenilworth, N. J. Nicholas Darchi was elevated to secretary.
The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania borrowed $50,000,000 yesterday on 31-year debentures at a net interest cost of 3.69 per cent.

Why is it that we taxpayers happily go on paying for the huge farm subsidy program when additional billions are needed for defense?
