In the current year over $5 billion will drain out of the taxpayers' pockets to support a minority group, the result of which makes for higher prices for the foodstuffs we buy.

The Long Island Rail Road had a net loss of $20,022 in December, in contrast with an $80,367 profit in December, 1956. A spokesman for the road said yesterday that the loss would have been even greater except for a sharp spurt in passenger traffic caused by last month's subway strike and cold weather.
HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- A bill to grant amnesty to all political enemies of Government whether in prison, in open rebellion or living abroad in exile was presented to the Senate late yesterday.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina last night acknowledged that he was "thinking about retiring" in a few months. He will be 70 years old Feb. 16.
Commodity prices closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy asked yesterday for $207,666,339 to run his department in the fiscal year beginning July 1.
The Amateur Athletic Union still hopes to carry through its plan to bring Hungary's Istvan Rozsavolgyi to this country for an indoor track tour.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Wednesday, Jan. 29 -- Roy Campanella, 36-year-old catcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was critically injured here early yesterday when his automobile overturned on a slippery road.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 28 -- Late every afternoon, in fair weather or foul, a station wagon swings into Dunemere Lane at the fashionable Maidstone Golf Course here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Eisenhower will travel by special plant to Kansas City, Mo., early tomorrow morning to attend a funeral service there for his eldest brother, Arthur B. Eisenhower, who died Sunday night of a heart ailment.

Performing in poor fashion, the New York Knickerbockers bowed to the Syracuse Nationals, 110 to 102, in the feature of a stormy National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

ANKARA, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Baghdad Pact's Council of Ministers approved today a report of its military committee recommending a long-term defense building project. The cost would run into billons with the United States helping foot the bill.
OWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 28 (AP) -- A rural grand jury had its first face-to-face meeting today with some of the participants in last November's Apalachin gang-land convention.

Samuel Duff McCoy and Geza Grosschmid have both mistaken (in your issues of Jan. 4 and 14 respectively) the official NATO emblem for a caltrop, which is alleged to be "an obsolete military instrument."

An artificial electrical pacemaker for the heart, which operates through a thin wire attached directly to the heart muscle, was described here yesterday. A report on the development was made at the fourth annual conference on cardiovascular surgery sponsored by the New York Heart Association.

Directors of International Business Machines Corporation declared a quarterly dividend of 65 cents a common share yesterday. It is payable March 10 to holders of record of Feb. 10. The rate had been 60 cents a quarter.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 28 -- Navy's basketball team, sparked by the second-half shooting of Jim Bower, a sophomore, pulled away in the final seven minutes to defeat Penn State, 58 -- 53, today.

At this moment, when the Venezuelan uprising has finally shocked America into a realization of the terror of Latin-American dictatorships, it is fitting to re-examine our own responsibility in this tragedy. Perhaps we may thus prevent similar losses of life and human betrayal in the remaining dictatorships of the Dominican Republic, Paraguay, Nicaragua and Cuba.

DENVER, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Lawrence T. (Buck) Shaw resigned today as head football coach at the Air Force Academy, saying business commitments on the West Coast made it impossible for him to devote adequate time to the academy.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 28 -- A Jewish Orthodox leader declared today that there was a "compelling need" for intensified dissemination of Orthodox Judaism. He said there was increasing dissatisfaction among American Jews with "the superficialities of religious thinking."
Arthur Tracy testified in court yesterday that although he was a vice president of the Nassau Management Company he had "no real knowledge" of the company's operations.

Plans for a sixteen-story store and apartment building at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street have been announced by Maurice Epstein, realty investor and builder, who has taken a 100-year lease on the corner.
Two satellites, one comparatively simple and rugged, the other more complex, have been prepared for launching by the Army's Jupiter-C rockets. Both will probably be sent aloft.

DETROIT, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers tonight announced the completion of a deal with the San Francisco Giants of the National League. The Tigers get a first baseman, Gale Harris, and an infielder, Ossie Virgil, in exchange for an infielder, Jim Finigan, and cash.
Business and city officials have teamed up to protest the Army's recent action in moving its chief distribution point for perishable foods from New York to Cheatham Annex, Williamsburg, Va.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- Proposed tax cuts totaling 2,000,000,000 rubles ($500,000,000 at the official rate) were submitted today to the Supreme Soviet of the Russian Federation, largest republic in the Soviet Union.

Oscar Panno of Argentina, an international grandmaster, assumed the lead in the chess tournament for the championship of the Americas at the Club Militar in Bogota when he defeated Francisco Denis of Panama in the sixth round, according to a report received yesterday through Colombian news sources.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Britain is developing an intermediate range ballistic missile whose range will exceed that of either the Thor or the Jupiter missiles, now in production in the United States, authoritative sources said today.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 28 -- It is painful to report that eight of Stuart's leading snook anglers fished from four boats for several hours yesterday in the South Fork of the St. Lucie River, and did not raise a fish.
The City Council, in an unusual show of independence, demanded yesterday that Mayor Wagner explain his intentions in calling for revision of the City Charter.

Not long ago the head of the house had an unnerving experience. Telephoning from a coin box, he was asked by the operator to please give the number of the machine he was using. It was there, directly before him, but was a blur.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A special advisory committee urged today that the Government shift its emphasis in stockpiling away from raw materials and toward items needed for human survival and relief in case of war.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 28 -Another Thor -- the Air Force's intermediate range ballistic missile -- was test-fired successfully here just after 3 o'clock this afternoon.
The Police Department's information booth on Times Square, a landmark for countless out-of-towners and New Yorkers with questions, is soon to disappear.
Mickey Mantle, reportedly seeking a $75,000 salary for 1958, left for Florida yesterday morning with his contract still unsigned.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Floored by a punch after the eighth round had ended, the British lightweight champion, Dave Charnley, rallied in the last two rounds to win a close decision over Don Jordan of Los Angeles in a ten-round bout tonight.

In support of Point Five of President Eisenhower's State of the Union message, the Administration has asked Congress to make a far-reaching revision of the Atomic Energy Law in order to strengthen the North Atlantic alliance and meet the Soviet military and scientific challenge.
SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Jan. 29 -- Oxygen was flown to the polar plateau last night to give urgently needed help to one of Dr. Fuchs' party who had been struck down by carbon monoxide poisoning.

Your editorial of Jan. 13 calling for a study of the New York social insurance laws with particular reference to the benefit structure of the New York Workmen's Compensation and Unemployment Insurance Laws was timely and sound, Thomas Jefferson Miley to the contrary notwithstanding.
WARSAW, Jan. 28 -- Poland's leaders recently got Soviet approval for the idea of inspection and control of the "denuclearized" zone in Central Europe proposed by the Poles.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- The National Assembly unanimously approved by a show of hands today the resignation of Janos Kadar as Premier and elected Dr. Ferenc Muennich his successor.
TRENTON. Jan. 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today he would welcome a public airing of charges that have delayed Senate confirmation of Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a voluminous bill designed to deal with loopholes, errors and unintended hardships in the Federal revenue laws.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 28 -- A three-year grass roots project to create among white homeowners a "climate of opinion" favorable to non-segregated residential housing will be started this fall by five Protestant denominations.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., pharmaceutical and chemical producer, last year attained the highest sales and earnings in its 109-year history.
Sir Pierson Dixon, British Ambassador to the United Nations, said last night that the West should find a way of "getting down to talks with the Russians."
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Proposals to reform Algeria's political stucture and its electoral system were approved by the National Assembly today on a second reading.
MONTREAL, Jan. 28 -The theft of negotiable bonds worth $1,800,000 from a trust company in the heart of Montreal's financial district was disclosed today.
Americans would do well to temper their idealism with a realistic approach to international affairs, Sir Percy Spender of Australia said here yesterday in his valedictory to this country.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 28 -- The Cyprus situation has put a sudden strain on relations between Turkey and Britain.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 28 (AP) -- A reduction in the work week to thirty-six and one quarter hours, effective Aug. 11, and wage increases are contained in a tentative agreement reached between The St. Paul Dispatch and Pioneer Press and mailing employes, the Minnesota labor conciliator said today.
Insure your life while you do your daily shopping -that's the latest inducement being offered by trading stamps.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 28 -- Two of the foremost microbiologists in the United States and the Soviet Union will trade their top assistants for six months under the new cultural and technical exchange agreement between the two countries.

The ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria became a veritable fairway last night as 600 golfing enthusiasts honored some of the nation's top players. The occasion was the sixth annual Gold Tee Award dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Members of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board today asked for closer compliance with its trade practices code to combat rising demands for favored treatment by retailers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Louis S. Rothschild, Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, recommended today that trust fund appropriations for regular Federal-aid highways be held to $900,000,000 annually beginning in fiscal year 1961.
Water and pumps are being used more widely for pumping solid foods through pipes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Two of the biggest unions joined today in opening a drive for "substantial" wage increases for 550,000 workers in aircraft and missile plants.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 28 -The Baghdad Pact moved one step closer today to unifying its military command. Its Combined Military Planning Organization, which was formed in June at Karachi, was changed to a Combined Military Planning Staff.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- An Argentine trade delegation completed negotiations today for the purchase of $3,000,000 to $4,000,000 worth of Soviet industrial products.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 28 -- Cyprus was the scene of more bloodshed and unrest today as Turkish Cypriotes continued their demonstrations in support of partitioning the island.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 28 -- The idea that all parties name a widely respected civilian with no political ties as their joint candidate for President is gaining acceptance in Venezuela.

IRVINGTON, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Mrs. Harold B. Scott of Irvington, a member of the New York Vassar Alumnae Club, is serving as Westchester chairman of the club's thirty-sixth annual opera benefit committee. Tickets for the March 8 evening performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera are available.

The riots of the Turkish Cypriotes against the British and the tragic roll of deaths and wounded are a bitter setback for all concerned -- Turks, Greeks, British and the West in general. One gets a sense of bafflement and despair about Cyprus in reading the events of the last three days.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- A Congressman said today that a proposed new form of television advertising might make beer-drinkers out of unsuspecting teen-agers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Another well-publicized Hollywood talent search ended today:
FERENC MUENNICH might be called communism's indestructible man. He seems to have emerged unscathed, untouched and tranquil after nearly half a century as a Commnuist in Eastern Europe.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Britain's big "magnetic inner tube," which contains hydrogen gas at solar heat for fusion experiments, is undergoing modifications to raise its temperature from 5,000,000 to 25,000,000 degrees Centigrade .

AN audience of almost 2,400 assembled at Carnegie Hall last night for the first of the two Chopin recitals that Alexander Brailowsky is giving there this season. In undertaking the two Chopin concerts the pianist is repeating his recital plan of the 1953-54 season. But these cycles are not so large as those he gave in 1937-38 and 1942-43. In both those seasons he gave six Chopin programs.
A 27-year-old Bronx man was shot yesterday in an apparent case of mistaken identity. His attacker took his own life moments before the police arrived at his home to arrest him.
Four new feature films open today.
HONG KONG, Jan. 27 -- Having demonstrated his physical prowess last year by swimming the mile-wide Yangtze River, Mao Tse-tung, one-time farm boy, recently showed he could also plow a neat furrow.

Anything can happen on the transit system. Yesterday an employe refused money. His name is John Burns. He is 50 years old, lives at 195-07 Forty-second Avenue, Flushing, Queens, and is a railroad clerk in a BMT change booth at the Forty-ninth Street station.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -The State Department accused Nikita S. Khrushchev today of spreading a "distorted view of United States policies and motivations."
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., set new highs in virtually every phase of its 1957 operations, according to the preliminary annual report released yesterday.

Harry Canelstein, realty investor and builder, has contracted to buy the taxpayer building at 360-68 East 167th Street, the Bronx, from the 360-68 East 167 Street Corporation. The property covers a blockfront and is 125 by 100 feet. It contains eight stores.

New York City borrowed $55,000,000 yesterday on an issue of tax anticipation notes due in May at an interest rate of 2 1/4 per cent. The issue consists of $25,000,000 due on May 1 and subject to prepayment on April 22 and $30,000,000 due on May 5 and redeemable on April 25. The notes were sold by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to twenty banks and trust companies by allotment as follows:
The merger of Solar Aircraft Company and Norden-Ketay Corporation through an exchange of stock has been approved by the boards of directors of both companies, it was announced late yesterday.

The net income of the Kennecott Copper Corporation last year dropped to $79,222,594 from the record high of $143,154,210 in 1956, according to the preliminary annual report issued yesterday by C. R. Cox, president.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The Board of Regents was reported today to favor a $78,000,000 increase in the state aid to education.
The United States Steel Corporation achieved record sales and profits in 1957, despite a substantial decline in demand during the second half.

Duncan S. Briggs of Oneonta, N. Y., was elected president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association yesterday at the annual convention in the Statler Hotel. Mr. Briggs, secretary-treasurer of the Briggs Lumber Company of Oneonta, succeeds Joseph E. Hollingworth, president of the Pratt and Forest Company, Lowell, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers Union, proposed today the establishment of a Federal fact-finding agency to pass judgment on price increases proposed by major producers.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- There is a curious parallelism in present instincts for administrative change within the Soviet Union and the United States. Each superpower strives to improve its efficiency to meet competitive challenges from the other. Thus there is simultaneous trend toward reform.
The Police Department said yesterday that it had proved that alcohol was more of a factor in automobile accidents than had been realized.
The principal of a Brooklyn public school that has been beset by juvenile crime committed suicide yesterday.
The foreman of the special grand jury investigating lawlessness in Brooklyn public schools suggested yesterday that parents have their children boycott schools where crime is prevalent.
MONTREAL, Jan. 28 -Queen Mother Elizabeth arrived here today in a blinding snowstorm on the first leg of a flight that will take her around the world.

Bank reserves -- a barometer of money policy -- are becoming so plentiful that demand is evaporating. Trading in Federal funds, the market term for excess reserves lent by one bank to another, slowed to a near halt yesterday.
A Marshall Plan for the Middle East to combat communism there was urged yesterday at the midwinter conference of Hadassah, the women's Zionist Organization of America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Army announced today that next June it would have four combat-ready networks of Nike-Hercules guided missiles, including one to protect the New York City area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Government has asked the Supreme Court to give special, early consideration to a case that the natural gas industry regards as its most important legal test in years -- the so-called Memphis case.

A recent study of drivers' psychology has turned up the disconcerting conclusion that most people consider themselves above average in driving skill -- a delusion on the face of it. Disconcerting, but not surprising. How many people, particularly men, have you heard say, "I'm not a good driver"?
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 28 -- The Get-Well Cupboard will give a benefit luncheon on Thursday at Bethel Presbyterian Church here.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -Governor Harriman's budget proposes state aid payments of $372,597,000 to New York City, according to a breakdown of the recommendations released by the Division of the Budget today.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 28 -- This city is drafting an application for $150,000 in urban renewal planning funds from the Federal Government as a preliminary to a $5,500,000 downtown redevelopment program.
The figure of Franklin Delano Roosevelt once again drew the plaudits of enthusiastic Democrats last night on the stage of the Cort Theatre.
Three men, a mother and her two daughters were arrested yesterday in the burglary of more than $100,000 worth of expensive sweaters and other clothing.

THE news that Roy Campanella had suffered a broken neck in an auto accident early yesterday morning was a genuine shocker. Round Roy always has been such a delightfully warm and wonderful guy that the report of his crack-up had to be weighed not so much from an impersonal baseball standpoint but from the totally personal standpoint of Campy himself
The Port of New York Authority will start construction in June of the fifth of ten new piers in its $85,000,000 redevelopment program in Brooklyn.

What factors constitute safe driving in city traffic! How far must a car travel in the "wrong" lane in order to pass a car traveling ahead of it at a constant rate of speed? At what point should a driver start to slow down when he sees a traffic jam ahead? What happens when your car is going sixty miles an hour and you suddenly push the brake pedal to the floor?
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 28 -- Tennessee's pupil placement law was described in Federal District Court today as part of a "package deal" aimed at preserving racial segregation in public schools.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will open a broad inquiry next week into the state of world affairs.
ACCORDING to David Evins, a leading shoe designer, 1957 was the most profitable period in eight years for the shoe industry. This year is expected to yield as much of a bonanza.
W. J. SLOANE has furnished and decorated a gem of a two-and-one-half-room "apartment." Unfortunately, it is not for rent.

Reacting to a distressing recent experience, Bernie Sarachek, Yeshiva University's basketball coach, urges a change in the college basketball rule requiring a team to play with fewer than five men when the rest of its players have fouled out.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- After running up good gains for most of the day, grain futures prices declined in the final minutes on the Board of Trade today. About half the contracts finished lower.

In a fumbling, hesitant market, nonferrous metals and business machines rose solidly yesterday, while rubbers, aircrafts and electrical manufacturers mostly declined. Steels and oils showed more gains than losses.

New Federal funds must come to the aid of the United States educational system if Russian space-age accomplishments are to be matched, a group of jet propulsion and airframe researchers said yesterday.
COMO, Italy, Jan. 28 -- A champion Italian contract bridge team increased its lead over the United States today to 33 points in a three-nation contest for the 1958 world championship.
THANKS largely to the bitterness of the direction and the acting, Samuel Beckett's second play turns out to be quite impressive. Impressive in the macabre intensity of the mood, that is.

We note with approval that Police Commissioner Kennedy has ordered the removal of his department's information booth in Times Square on the north side of Fortythird Street. Manned around the clock, and its principal function of assisting visitors and others duplicated since November by the new information center across the street built for the city's Department of Commerce and Public Events, it had become a waste of public funds. It was unsightly besides.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A majority of economists testifying before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee expressed doubt today that the pick-up in defense orders would cure the current recession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Administration's proposal to share atomic weapons information with friendly nations was attacked today as a legal "subterfuge" that could accelerate the international atomic arms race.

Losing Roy Campanella was almost worse than losing the Dodgers. He was a team in himself, a game guy who gave every play the old college try, cheerful, uncomplaining, an inspiration to everybody, on the field or watching. He caught as if his life depended on it.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29 -- The Department of Defense reversed itself today with regard to the "successful" test firing of a Thor.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Lew Hoad remained the only unbeaten player in the $50,000 Australian round-robin professional tennis tournament today by defeating Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles, 7 -- 5, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4.

Your editorial of Jan. 22 entitled "Health Insurance Gap" was a clear statement of the need to protect citizens of this state against the insurance company practice of terminating health insurance policies at the time people need protection most -when they are ill or leave work or retire.

NOT being a literary type, Joseph Stanley (Joey) Fay, the labor racketeer's racketeer, may never have heard of the line of poetry that goes: "Stone walls do not a prison make." But he would understand thoroughly the meaning of that bit of verse because it is a concise description of the eight years he spent in jail, beginning in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Federal regulatory agencies which the Congressional Directory classifies as "independent," the first of which was the Interstate Commerce Commission, now require fifty-two pages for their listing; consequently the current inquiry by a House subcommittee into their actual "independence" of the Executive affects a major Government operation.
A year from now science should have the basic information necessary to start work on a space vehicle that will safely return a human being to earth, a scientist declared yesterday.

The New York Yankees yesterday signed two players, raising their total to eight. Art Ditmar, the big right-handed pitcher from Springfield, Mass., is the important man of the duo. He probably received a contract for around $12,000.
DETROIT, Jan. 29 (UP) -- The labor dispute at the Chrysler Dodge division continued today. Five thousand employes were sent home on company charges that some had not kept up with the production line.

The Newspaper Guild of New York warned Michael J. Quill last night that unless he apologized for accusations against the press, the Guild would never support him for office "in any central body of organized labor."
YEHUDA GUTTMAN, an Israeli pianist who has been studying here since 1949, gave a recital in Carnegie Hall last night. He proved to have the instincts of a virtuoso, but not always the fingers of one.
LONDON, Jan 29 -- British Government securities went further ahead in the stock market today, but gains among industrial shares generally were limited to pennies.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, unchanged to 31 points ($1.55 a bale) higher. The far months showed the most strength.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A woman and six men were convicted in Federal court today on charges they conspired to lie about Communist party membership.
Equipment to detect whether time, in the strange new world of sub-atomic physics, can run backward as well as forward was described here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- The House of Representatives and the Senate voted more than $2,000,000 for various investigating committees today, despite some Congressional misgivings.

The eight-day wave of youthful violence that has rolled across Brooklyn could just as well have struck Washington Heights, Harlem, the area west of Central Park, the Bronx or other sections, according to law enforcement officials, educators and social workers.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 29 -- Manufacturers of women's and children's coats and suits will press for a nation-wide promotion campaign to spur lagging sales. At the closing session of a three-day meeting, the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board again approved today the plan for a campaign originally presented last year by its public relations committee.

Four meet records were established and one was tied as La Salle Academy took the lead for the senior team title in the Manhattan-Bronx-Westchester Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field meet at Mount St. Michael High, the Bronx, yesterday.
Pronounced strength for the rails, developing between 2:30 and 3:15 P. M., sent the stock price averages through their December and November highs yesterday.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 29 Thailand reported today she had reached agreement with the new Government of Laos to eliminate the twenty-five-mile demilitarized zone between the two countries.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The United States Army has accused a lieutenant of conduct unbecoming an officer because he refused to shake hand of his new commanding officer, a Negro captain.
Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that he would oppose any move to abolish the City Council as part of a general revision of the City Charter.

HONOLULU, T. H., Jan. 29 -- Four Japanese warships paid tribute to the 1,102 men who died in the battleship Arizona when they arrived here on a ceremonial visit today. The Arizona was sunk in the Japanese attack here on Dec. 7, 1941.

PARIS, Jan. 29 --Three more collections of spring fashions were shown today and, for the most part, reiterated what already has been displayed, to wit: short skirts, chemises, broad shoulders, long torsos and fussy hems.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The West's embargo on oil shipments to Communist China was reported today to have seriously affected that country's industrial expansion and collectivization program on the farms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, delivered a six-hour lecture today, with many Senatorial interruptions, on the imbalance of the nation's economy and how to set it straight.

A claim by the United States Government to a collection of original field notes of the Lewis and Clark expedition of 1804-06 was dismissed on Jan. 23 by the United States Court of Appeals in St. Louis.

Three four-story houses at 19, 21 and 23 West Ninth Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), have been purchased by Nat Simons, owner of the Penguin Restaurant on the property.

COMO, Italy, Jan. 29 -- Today was a rest day in the 1958 contract bridge world championship play. A crack six-man Italian team was well ahead of the squads representing the United States and Argentina.
George Goldfarb was buried yesterday in Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L. I., after a funeral service of simplicity and dignity.

Samuel Schulman, president of the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., urged last night that the industry cooperate more closely in promotion, the exchange of credit information and combatting injurious trade practices.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The State Senate approved unanimously today a bill to let Mayor Wagner bypass the City Council in setting up a City Charter Revision Commission:

A rise in the city's debt service of $41,335,272 -- or about 12 per cent -- for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 was forecast yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa. Of this amount $40,122,022 would be charged against real estate, he estimated.
DOUGLAS, Wyo., Jan. 29 -- Charles Starkweather, 19 years old, Nebraska gunman sought in ten slayings, was captured today near here.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Thursday, Jan. 30 -- Four policemen and a bystander were shot last night by an elderly hermit. The police, held at bay for an hour, fired tear-gas bombs into the shack in which David Taylor, 67 years old, lived alone at 1417 Sewell Avenue here. He emerged from the shack firing a shotgun.

Henry (Hank) Thompson, former third baseman and outfielder for the New York Giants, was arrested with two friends last night on charges of grand larceny. The charges involved a car that Mr. Thompson told the police he had only borrowed when he found his own car blocked off in a garage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke has predicted that the United States and the Soviet Union soon will have the ability to destroy each other.

"WELL, here I am," writes Benjamin Kopman in the catalogue for his present exhibition at the World House Galleries, 987 Madison Avenue; "in everybody's judgment (except perhaps my own)) I am an old man."
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin tonight applauded the United States-Soviet agreement on cultural exchange signed in Washington two days ago.

The top operating post in the United States Lines will change hands on Saturday. Newbold T. Lawrence, vice president, will retire. Capt. Jones F. Devlin Jr., general manager for operations, has been named by John M. Franklin, president, to succeed him.
MONTREAL, Jan. 29 -- The Canadian Pulp and Paper Association announced today that the output of member mills in 1957 was slightly less than the record output in 1956.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- The Soviet Union granted Egypt a large twelve-year loan today. It also agreed to provide technical assistance for the development of several major Egyptian industrial projects.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- The Inland Steel Company set new records in profits, production and mill shipments in 1957, Joseph L. Block, president, said today. He noted that there was "a marked easing" in demand "during the latter part of the year."
Dramatic evidence of the impact upon the Soviet system of exchange contacts with the United States has been provided by Nikita S. Khrushchev.

New York University's basketball team produced its best performance of the season to rout a favored Fordham five, 90 -- 73, before a near-capacity crowd of 3,500 in Fordham's campus gymnasium last night.
Evidence supporting the unorthodox idea that electricity in clouds is a cause, rather than a result, of rain was offered here yesterday by a physicist.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 29 (UP) -United States bobsleds driven by Stan Benham of Lake Placid, N. Y., and Dick Severino of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., posted the fastest times today in practice runs for the world four-man championships.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The State Department reasserted today that President Eisenhower would go to a heads-of-government meeting only if he had prior assurance that agreements could be reached.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Stan (The Man) Musial, the National League batting champion for the seventh time at the age of 37, today became the National League's highest paid player in history. He signed a 1958 St. Louis Cardinal contract calling for $100,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -A picture of a sick railroad industry that will become sicker unless freight rates are raised immediately was painted today before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -- Casey Robinson, writer-producer, and Claude Heilman, former assistant manager at Grauman's Chinese Theatre, have incorporated as Vintage Productions to film "This Earth Is Mine." Mr. Robinson's screenplay about a California wine dynasty in the prohibition era is based on the novel "The Cup and the Sword," by Alice Tisdale Hobart.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn said today that both the money and the authority were available to extend the east front of the Capitol.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Members of the Federal Communications Commission will be called before a special House subcommittee next Monday to answer charges of "alleged personal and official misconduct."

WASHINGTON, D. C., Jan. 29 -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House tonight after having attended a funeral service for his elder brother, Arthur, at Kansas City. His plane arrived at 6:49 P. M., Eastern standard time.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 29 -- Civil defense is no longer "academic bird-watching" but a vital part of the nation's military, Nelson A. Rockefeller told 150 members of the Affiliated Republican Women of Westchester County tonight.

WHETHER it is a princely establishment on Rome's Via Veneto or a family-style trattoria in New York's Little Italy, the best indication of an Italian restaurant's quality is, more often than not, its pasta. These are the dishes -- the macaroni products, such as spaghetti, linguine and mostaccioli -- whose esteem depends not only on the succulent sauces that accompany them but also on a proper cooking time.

The City Council, accustomed though it is to accepting with loyal alacrity the bidding that comes from the other end of City Hall, has finally rebelled and asked a question of Mayor Wagner. The question, put rather in sorrow than in anger, is in effect: "Boss, if we forward this endorsement of Charter revision to Albany, are we signing our own death warrant?"

Directors of the ABC Vending Corporation have increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 25 cents from 20 cents a share. The dividend is payable Feb. 24 to stockholders of record Feb. 10. The action places the stock on an annual rate of $1 a share.

11 A. M. and l:30 P. M.: Three free films, "Gerald McBoing Boing," "Romance of Transportation" and "Squeak the Squirrel," will be shown at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. The program is suggested for children 4 to 8 years old.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Harriman today urged the Legislature to provide more extensive insurance protection for older people. He submitted an eleven-point program concerning health and life insurance.

Lorne (Gump) Worsley returned to Madison Square Garden as the goal-minder for the New York Rangers last night and gave a fine exhibition of his art. The only trouble with Gump's comeback was that Harry Lumley, the guardian of the Boston Bruins' cage, also gave a splendid exhibition of how to play goal.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Willi Messerschmitt and Ernst Heinkel, Germany's two leading aircraft designers, have decided to pool their engineering skill in an attempt to put the German aircraft industry back on its feet, the magazine Deutsche International said today.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 29 -- Americans are eating more potatoes, reversing a downward trend in per capita consumption that started twenty-five years ago.

The Irving Trust Company's decision to pay a 2 per cent stock dividend instead of its customary year-end 10-cent cash extra represented an alternative to a stock subscription offering, Richard H. West, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday.
Abraham J. Isserman, a defense lawyer in the 1949 conspiracy trial of eleven Communist leaders, was disbarred yesterday from practicing in Federal Court in the Southern District of New York.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday record sales in 1957 and the fourth quarter last year. Volume for the year was $2,009,043,000. Earnings were second only to those of 1954.

Nikita S. Khrushchev has opened new perspectives for the development of Soviet agriculture by his latest suggestion for a major change in the collective farm system. For almost thirty years that system has operated on a dual basis: the collective farms have provided the manual laborers needed to till the fields, while the Government-owned and operated Machine Tractor Stations have provided the machines.

Chemical Fund, Inc., entered 1958 with the highest year-end net assets in its twenty-year history, according to the annual report mailed yesterday. Net assets as of Dec. 31, 1957, totaled $136,101,875, equal to $15.02 a share.

A modern $275,000 shelter for animals in transit was opened yesterday in the cargo area of New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. It was built by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals to tend the 100,000 animals that pass through Idlewild yearly.
Cocoa futures were strong yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The gains followed three days of sharp declines. Final quotations rose 70 to 88 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 365 lots.

A six-story apartment building on a plot 157 by 123 feet at 1731 Harrison Avenue, corner of West Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Phillip Zipes, realty operator. It contains nine stores and forty-four apartments.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Leslie Fenton's 6-year-old mare, Nooran, won the $29,050 Santa Maria Handicap today, but Willie Shoemaker will have to wait at least another day to gain the 3,000th victory of his career. He rode two winners today.
The Knickerbocker Club, one of the citys oldest private social clubs, may dissolve and accept a bid to join the Union Club's roster.

As Gertrude Stein might have put it, a crisis is a crisis is a crisis. It cannot be shrugged off, shelved or forgotten, especially in a democracy, where national reaction must continue to depend on a wellinformed citizenry basing its opinions on authenticated facts.
A search for "the most outstanding" teachers of chemistry in the secondary schools of the metropolitan area has been started by the American Chemical Society.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- The Senate today confirmed by voice vote the following nominations:

Taxicab drivers have been losing a little more time lately, and not because of traffic congestion. The delay stems from requests for receipts from business men whose expenses are to be carefully scrutinized by the Internal Revenue Service this year.
UNDER the guidance of Paul Boepple, a devoted musician and dedicated student of the past, the Dessoff Choirs and its Town Hall audience last night spent an hour and a half in the sixteenth century.

MIAMI, Jan. 29 -- The two chief items of news at the Hialeah horse park today were provided by (1) an undistinguished horse named Moraine that won at 51 to 1 and completed a $1,426.60 daily double, and (2) a game stakes horse named Encore that ran off with first money in the $23,200 Palm Beach Handicap.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the New York State Commerce Department:

THE ready response of parents to problems that affect children often provides the very stimulus needed to get citizens working toward improving communities and neighborhoods. When action and leadership come from within -- whether in a public housing project or a new suburban development -successful solutions are found more often than when residents wait for outside direction or Government action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -Leaders of the opposition to the natural gas bill predicted today that they had the votes to defeat it in the House of Representatives. The measure, twice vetoed, would ease Federal controls of natural gas prices.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox today sold Mickey Vernon, a graceful but aging first baseman, to the Cleveland Indians. Red Sox spokesmen said Vernon was sold for the waiver price of $20,000.

Owen Wister, in his novel "The Virginian," made a legendary hero of the American cowboy and put "When you call me that, smile!" into the American language. A selection of his heretofore unknown journals and letters has been edited by his daughter,

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 29 -- Julius Birge, secretary and director of the Bobbs-Merrill Company, Inc., book publishers, was found dead of shotgun wounds tonight in the basement of his home. A sixteen-gauge, double-barreled shotgun was found beside his body.
Court action to override the state's refusal to grant a rise in automobile liability insurance rates was started yesterday by 187 underwriters.
WARSAW, Jan. 29 -- A trickle of Jews from the flood that emigrated to Israel last year has returned to Poland. Israeli officials today set the number at seven families and a few individuals.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Soybean prices suffered one of their worst setbacks in many weeks on the Board of Trade here today, carrying the March. May and July contracts to new lows for the season.

It took courage on the part of Colonel Cruz Salazar, one of the losing candidates in the Guatemalan Presidential elections, to release his party followers in Congress. The elections of Jan. 19 failed to provide a majority, but it did result in a commanding plurality for the Right-Wing candidate, General Ydigoras.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan 29 -- Premier Viliam Siroky of Czechoslovakia charged today that the United States was supporting "separatist" efforts in Indonesia's anti-Communist outer regions.
Preferreds weren't preferred last year. Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., investment banking firm, reports that in 1957 there was a drastic decline in the number of offerings of preferred stock.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The National Football League owners tonight eliminated the bonus choice from their annual player draft. They also reaffirmed their television policy for another year, added another college player protection clause to their rules, and -- in a joint action with the Players Association -- turned the pension plan problem over to a former pro football ace, Bill Dudley.

HONG KONG, Jan. 29 -- Details of lawlessness and resistance to the Communist system last year in the Chinese Central Asian Province of Sinkiang are contained in copies of the Sinkiang Daily News of Urumchi that have reached here.
A proxy fight -- the fourth in five years -- may erupt for control of the embattled New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A $1,000,000 Federal grant for operating expenses for the country's eleven university schools of public health was urged by several witnesses today before the House Subcommittee on Health.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Two alternate bills to revise the state's truck mileage tax were submitted to the Legislature today under bipartisan sponsorship.
Telephoned bomb scares caused considerable delays yesterday in two flights leaving New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

Ski Sketch: In the summer of 1937 a young reporter for The New York Times, Arthur Draper, was assigned by his city editor to cover the 100th anniversary celebration of the first ascent of Mount Marcy, the highest peak in New York State.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and three New York banks made loans totaling $8,000,000 yesterday to the Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Japan. Kawasaki is expanding blast furnace facilities at its Chiba plant near Tokyo to increase its capacity to produce pig iron from 324,000 to 684,000 tons a year.
Two youths accused of stabbing two teen-age girls at a subway transfer point Tuesday were held in high bail in Brooklyn Adolescent Court yesterday.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- Israel is spending three times as much as she earns in foreign trade, Finance Minister Levi Eshkol told the Knesset (Parliament) today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Did Jack Benny violate the copyright laws when he parodied the movie "Gaslight" on television?
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The establishment of an interstate agency to control air pollution in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area was recommended yesterday.
The Board of Education received both praise and criticism yesterday from parents and teachers aroused by the current outbreaks of juvenile delinquency on school property.
MADRID, Jan. 29 -- A sweeping reorganization of Editorial Catolica, the voice of Catholic Action, powerful secular movement in Spain, has attracted widespread political interest here.
STUART, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Light-tackle anglers are doing a brisk business in a nice sort of a way now with both bluefish and mackerel.

The Port of New York Authority borrowed $40,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance capital outlays at the La Guardia Airport and New York International Air port at Idlewild, Queens. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds due from 1959 to 1978 at an interest cost of 3.060068 per cent.

THE accident, which probably brought the career of Roy Campanella to a jolting end, cannot help but have a profound reaction on the National League pennant race. It may seem cruel to be so prosaic and down to earth. But time never stands still and there is just no way of avoiding a discussion of the broader aspects of the automobile crack-up that involved the No. 1 catcher of the Dodgers.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- France applied today to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for financial aid in maintaining her armed forces in West Germany. The request for consideration of French difficulties was made to the alliance's council at its regular weekly meeting.
The Cessna Aircraft Company yesterday announced the declaration of a 40-cent quarterly dividend payable to common stockholders on Feb. 21. The company had paid 35 cents in previous quarters.

THESE menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 29 -- Col. Jose Luis Cruz Salazar announced to the nation by radio today that he had released his supporters in Congress from their commitment to vote for him for President.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Legislative approval for some, if not all, of the Board of Regents proposals for a $78,000,000 increase in state school aid appeared probable today.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- A graceful tribute to "the British achievement in harnessing thermonuclear energy" was broadcast by the Moscow radio today.

The letter of Charles H. Silver President of the Board of Education which appeared in the Jan. 24 issue of The Times, is a timely communication. I join in commending the sentiments expressed in The Time editorial of Jan. 22.
Twenty-nine rookies from the Police Academy were assigned yesterday to patrol duty in the Twenty-third Precince on Manhattan's upper East Side.

Six attendants will open the ninth annual St. Nicholas Society Ball in the grand ballroom of the Plaza tomorrow night. One will play on his bugle the old Dutch tune of "Mynheer Van Donck" and another will hold aloft the weathervane that once perched atop the Dutch Government House in New Amsterdam.
The Government's X-15 rocket ship research program is scheduled to begin probing the frontier between the earth's atmosphere and outer space in the spring of 1959.

Today's new film is "Seven Hills of Rome," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical offering in color starring Mario Lanza, at the Radio City Music Hall. Lester Welch produced and Roy Rowland directed from a screenplay by Art Cohn and Giorgio Prosperi.

The Circle in the Square, Greenwich Village group that played a major role in stimulating the current off-Broadway renaissance has selected Edwin Justus Mayer's "Children of Darkness" as its next offering.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford said tonight that the United States had lost one of its greatest assets -- its post-D-Day industrial potential that "allowed it to come from behind to win two wars."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today the condition stateleading cities. The report showed that in the week ended Jan. 22 there were decreases of $538,000,000 in loans adjusted, $216,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $964,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.

EPHRATA, Pa., Jan. 29 (AP) -- A Greyhound bus traveling from St. Louis to New York smashed into the rear of a trailer-truck on the Pennsylvania Turnpike today, killing the bus driver and injuring twenty-one passengers. The truck driver also was hurt.
Board of Education officials charged yesterday that George Goldfarb, principal of John Marshall Junior High School, had committed suicide because a grand juror had told him he might be indicted.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 29 -The Rabinnical Council of America has called on the Mayor of New York to "fulfill his promise" to introduce legislation to permit Jewish merchants who observe the Sabbath to operate businesses on Sunday.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The Republican-controlled Legislature approved Governor Harriman's $69,900,000 deficiency appropriation bill today. But it first deleted $105,000 in reimbursement to New York City toward the cost of probation services.

Mike Herman, New York University's jack - of - all - trades junior, easily won the broad jump and then tied for first place in the pole vault yesterday for a successful start in his attempt to win five events in the sixteenth annual Metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field meet
Nikita S. Khrushchev has declared that Western acceptance of the status quo in Communist Eastern Europe is a prerequisite for a successful summit meeting and an end to the "cold war."

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday declined slightly to 12,399,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 12,400,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Jan. 26, 1957, was 12,410,000,000. percentage changes in the last two weeks compared with the corresponding periods of 1957 follow:
Recommendations to regulate chemical additives in foods and to provide for precautionary labeling of household chemicals will be submitted to the city's Board of Health on Feb. 19.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 29 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer denied tonight he had received and refused Soviet offers to reunify Germany through free elections.

The American Government has been prodding the Soviets by diplomatic demarche and public statements to reply to President Eisenhower's proposal for a carefully prepared "summit" meeting that would promise real progress toward peace. This proposal, containing a detailed three-point program and echoed in other Western notes, was delivered to Moscow seventeen days ago.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 29 -- A state legislative commission called on local school boards today to reduce construction costs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- India sent a warm "thank you" to the United States today for the recent offer of American loans to help her meet her economic problems.

A special committee appointed by the State Education Commissioner has recommended that "radical steps" be taken at the local, state and national levels to upgrade the amount and quality of American education.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Two British papers said today that Britain, France and the United States had decided to accept Moscow's call for a heads - of - government meeting, and that the conference would be held in Geneva in May or June.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Newspaper reviewers were enthusiastic about Eugene O'Neill's, "The Icemen Cometh," which opened tonight at the Arts Theatre.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 25 -In a drive to achieve 100 per cent collectivization the Bulgarian regime has now resorted to siege methods against the peasantry.
A simple story from a village in South Korea can teach us some things about how aid to nations in need can be effectively given.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 29 -- A struggle by the Westchester Mental Health Board to keep its jurisdiction and expand throughout the county was disclosed today. A threat of divorcement by Mount Vernon became its immediate problem.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Eisenhower's last illness has definitely reopened the question of how to govern the country when a President is disabled.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner opened the annual Mothers March on Polio yesterday by contributing to the March of Dimes.

The Government of Israel is planning to order two large oil tankers in Japan. Arieh Rosen, director of the bulk carrier division of the Zim Israel Navigation Company, Ltd., of Haifa, disclosed the plan here yesterday.

DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- Australia's cricket squad today rallied to force a draw on the last day of their third test match with South Africa. The series now stands at one victory for Australia and two draws, with two matches to play.

Although Drury Gallagher of the Maroon squad won three events, Fordham's swimming team bowed to New York University, 49 to 37, in Fordham's pool yesterday. Gallagher took the 200-yard butterfly, the 440yard free-style and 200-yard breast-stroke events.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee today neared informal agreement on a bill to permit a Vice President to act for an incapacitated President.

When has the securing of lasting peace ever been so vitally needed yet held in such apparently lowesteem because of its identification with propaganda? There are event those who seem to fear the prospect of extended peace as though it much inevitably contain only elements stagnation, compromise, submission to adulterated interests.
The green of the shamrock will join the colors of other international airlines in April when Aerlinte Eireann will begin Ireland's first regular trans-Atlantic air passenger service.
Snow that may have fallen on Antarctica in the days of Charlemagne is being extracted from the depths of the Marie Byrd Land ice sheet in the form of highly compressed ice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Senate committee investigators estimated today that Joseph S. Fay and his wife received the equivalent of $238,800 from a union local since he went to prison in 1948 for extortion.
One of the oldest and most tightly held real estate portfolios in the city is passing to new control after 170 years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The United States will establish a missile range on the Pacific Coast, the Defense Department announced today.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 29 -- The Norwalk Planning Commission made known today its new plans for a civic center in Veterans Memorial Park. Previous plans have in cluded an access road from West Avenue, one of the city's main arteries, but under the latest proposal the main approach would be from Butler Street to the north.
"NEVER KNOW THE END," last night's drama on the United States Steel Hour on Channel 2, was a study in contrast.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 29 -The United States promised today a grant of $10,000,000 to help improve communications among four Baghdad Pact countries.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 29 -- Roy Campanella was able to move his fingers and arms slightly tonight, and he was reported to be considerably improved. His condition was still listed as critical, however.

An increase of 2,620,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they totaled 203,256,000 barrels, compared with 200,636,000 a week earlier and 193,248,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Treasury offered a three-way choice of securities today to holders of five maturing issues totaling $16,785,000,000.

IN "Maybe Tuesday," which was acted at The Playhouse last evening, Mel Tolkin and Lucille Kallen proceed on the following assumption: that the spectacle of seven bachelor girls living together in a common apartment is hilarious and fraught with piquancy.

The office of Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy listed fifteen Brooklyn schools yesterday where a patrolman would be posted outside until further notice. In addition, a patrolman will be stationed inside Public School 210 and Junior High School 258. The borough-wide list follows:
The second large jewelry robbery in three days in midtown Manhattan occurred yesterday morning when two men escaped with $100,000 worth of gems.
Sixteen public officials returned from a tour of Ellis Island yesterday, apparently convinced that its facilities could be turned into a hospital for the treatment of narcotic addicts.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 29 -- The South African treason hearing drew to a close today with debate on whether Communists or traitors could be judged by their jargon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Morris Block of Brooklyn came to Washington today to get back his passport. He got it by grabbing it, but the State Department says it's no good.

Pacific Lighting Corporation's 1957 net income was adversely affected by a combination of "inadequate rates" and "unseasonably warm weather in Southern California, during the winter months," according to the preliminary annual report mailed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Dr. Morris Meister, principal of Bronx High School of Science, told a Senate committee today that the United States must "break through the dead center of inaction" in science education."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 29 -- Venezuela's ruling Government junta was greeted today with a standing ovation at the Caracas Cathedral at a solemn high mass for the victims of last week's revolution.
Could 1929 happen again? That grim question is in the fore these days as the business recession deepens.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 29 -- Another tense and difficult situation appeared to be developing tonight in the troubled frontier region between Algeria and Tunisia.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 29 -- "I still believe with Sir Winston Churchill that jaw-jaw is better than war-war," Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain said tonight at dinner in his honor in Canberra.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 29 (UP) -- An attack of the flu sidelined Nonie Foley of Houghton, Mich., today and left five girls from the United States to take part in the world ski championships starting Sunday.
Philip Morris, Inc., realized an increase of 9.4 per cent in earnings last year on a sales gain of 5.9 per cent over 1956, according to the annual report of Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president.
Three television programs in the area of news and public affairs will be discontinued next month by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Another news program will change its format to "reduce costs.
American advertising agencies never had it so good, according to the president of Israel's largest agency, whose messages are beamed to consumers in eleven languages.
A move to identify the American Red Cross as closely as possible with the national civil defense organization in natural disasters or enemy action was disclosed here yesterday.
Georgi N. Zaroubin sailed from New York yesterday on the first leg of his journey home after five years as Soviet Ambassador to the United States.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 29 -- In a break with labor's high command, David Dubinsky endorsed today President Eisenhower's call for a special Federal agency with broad power to investigate union abuses.
Almost four years of legal wrangling have ended with the Waterfront Commission retaining the right to discipline longshoremen found guilty of misconduct during strikes or work stoppages.
A note by a quick-thinking stenographer and some loud shouting by two other employes and a passer-by resulted in the capture yesterday of two gunmen who had held up a loan office.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The Republican - controlled Legislature took steps today to keep Nelson A. Rockefeller, a potential candidate for the Governorship, in the limelight.
PARIS, Jan. 30 -- French Government officials tempered their evident relief over the success of France's foreign loan negotiations with warnings tonight of a hard road ahead.
George Gregory Jr., the Civil Service Commissioner of New York, banked the ball in cleanly when he recently pointed out that college basketball made its debut in Madison Square Garden in 1931.
HONG KONG, Jan. 28 -- Communist China's birth control program has met with only moderate success and over-population remains one of the country's biggest problems.

A group of boys threw a forty-foot length of chain on the express tracks of the BMT Brighton Line at Dorchester Road, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn yesterday. Service on the line was disrupted for nearly an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The difference in outlook between two men is entering into calculations on the Government's response to the recession. Close observers of economic affairs have come almost unanimously to the conclusion that Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, is significantly different from his predecessor, George M. Humphrey.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 29 -- The Hudson County Tax Research Council called on the Board of Freeholders today to "hold the line" on county administration costs. A preliminary estimate, however, indicated that the 1958 county budget would set a record of $29,691,153.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- It is now evident that the only agreement reached thus far among the party leaders of Congress on a method to operate Clause 5, Section 1, Article II of the Constitution (the Presidential "inability" provision) is that in view of President Eisenhower's three illnesses "something" -- at least advisory -- should be done at this session.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The House of Lords gave final and unanimous approval today to a bill that would admit women to the upper chamber of the British Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A special House subcommittee will question five members of the Federal Communications Commission under oath next week on charges of "personal misconduct."
A new waterway to parallel Canada's Welland Canal will not be needed for the St. Lawrence Seaway in the "reasonably foreseeable future."
NEWARK, Jan. 30 -- Representative Robert W. Kean of Livingston announced his candidacy today for the Republican nomination for United States Senator.

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 30 -- Gov. Luther H. Hodges warned Ku Klux Klan leaders today of possible prosecution for law violations connected with mass rallies. He also accused the Klan of giving "aid and comfort to Communist Russia."

IT cannot be said that Aaron Copland is a neglected American composer. His position as one of our best is firm, and his music has had wide acceptance. But here is the Third Symphony, one of his big works.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30 -- Officials of the United States escorted two very important guests to the New Delhi airport today and saw them aboard a plane for London, comfortably secured in crates.
Contract negotiations between an engineering and technicians union and two major networks are still going on.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- The grimy run-down waterfront on the Hudson River's Tappan Zee here is being transformed. Slums, junk yards and swamps are giving way to commuters' parking lots, public housing, parks and boat basins. Mayor John J. Nagle said today that assessed valuations in Tarrytown had risen from $18,000,000 to $40,000,000 in the last six years.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- The Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Union informed Senate rackets investigators today that the union would welcome an inquiry into its affairs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- A 6-foot, 1-inch policeman and an expert bowler have been added to the membership of the San Francisco Symphony orchestra for a "pop" concert Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Soviet Union is preparing to launch a huge rocket, probably in an attempt to lift its third artificial earth satellite, according to reports believed to be reliable.

WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Jan. 30 (UP) -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of Treasury, said tonight that there was "every reason to be confident that our economic activity will resume its upward growth during the year."

Those who expected some new and bold course of action to come out of the Baghdad Pact meeting that has just concluded in Ankara will be disappointed by the final communique. This document expresses sentiments that have already been expressed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Victor Purse, a State Department employe who figured in a controversy last fall after he had accepted an automobile from King Saud of Saudi Arabia, was found unconscious today in his gas-filled apartment.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 30 (AP) -- An unidentified white boy reportedly kicked a Negro girl at Central High School yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- When the history of this year is written, the economic policies of the Administration at home and abroad, rather than defense policy, are likely to emerge as the central political issues. Unemployment, foreign trade and foreign aid, are already vying with the missile controversy for the headlines and these are dividing Congress more than anything in the defense picture.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt attended last night's opening of "Sunrise at Campobello," a play about her husband, at the Cort Theatre.
STAN MUSIAL visited New York with his wife a couple of weeks ago, saw all the shows, and had a most pleasant holiday.
The High School Teachers Association yesterday called for state legislation to rid the city's schools of "all goons and juvenile delinquents."

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Garrison H. Davidson, Military Academy superintendent, placed a wreath from President Eisenhower on the grave of President Franklin D. Roosevelt today. The ceremony marked the seventy-sixth anniversary of the President's birth.
Hertz American Express International, Ltd., has acquired Daimler Hire, Ltd., the largest chauffeur-driven and rent-a-car company in Great Britain, for approximately $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The nation's railroads announced today they were sticking to all aspects of a proposed freight rate increase they estimated would bring in an additional $176,000,000 this year.
An increase in deaths from pneumonia anal other respiratory diseases caused the city's death rate to rise above normal last week for the first time since last fall's Asian influenza epidemic.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- John W. McCormack, House Democratic leader, said today that Congress must authorize some greater exchange of information on atomic weapons with allies.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30 -- Ten years ago today the man India called her great soul and her giver of light was murdered as he walked to prayer.
The seventh annual Carioca Ball will be held in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 14. The Gold Star Wives of America, Inc., service and welfare fund will benefit.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Harriman today named Magistrate John R. Starkey of Brooklyn to fill a vacancy on the City Court in Brooklyn. The appointment requires confirmation by the State Senate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Army has advised Congress that the Soviet Union may have an operational intercontinental ballistic missile as early as next July.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Administration asked Congress today to extend the reciprocal trade program for five years beyond next June 30.

A Brooklyn manufacturer and his wife were found dead in their bedroom last night. Each had been stabbed more than a dozen times. In the basement of their two-story brick home at 4 Gotham Avenue, Gerritson Beach, the police found the body of a pet Spitz dog that had also been stabbed.

" Untamed Woman," the final feature of Japanese Film Week, will be shown tonight in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art. "The Nature of Hokkaido," a color documentary, is the accompanying short subject on the program.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 30 -- Eight college ski teams are here to participate in the annual Dartmouth winter carnival tomorrow and Saturday. The Hanoverians are favored.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Australia's Lew Hoad completed a clean sweep of the 322,400 round-robin professional tennis tournament tonight when he beat Frank Sedgman of Australia, 6 -- 3, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3.
Two members of a $20,000,000-a-year international narcotics ring pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy to violate the narcotics laws.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Nineteen-year-old Herb Elliott ran a mile under 4 minutes for the second time within a week today. Merv Lincoln, the runner-up, also cracked the 4-minute barrier.
The stock market tried to continue its rally yesterday but lost momentum. The session ended with a modest loss.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A $500,000 gift to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington to build a school for retarded children was made today by the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A tax adjustment program designed to help small business to expand in the general economic field was introduced in the Senate today. The measure was based on conclusions drawn from a year's study of the impact of present tax laws upon small business.
BRIDES-TO-BE will find a refreshingly good selection of wedding gowns at Rosette Pennington's Brides Shop.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Emilio Arenales Catalan of Guatemala today was elected president of the United Nations Trusteeship Council. Alfred Claeys Bouuart of Belgium was elected vice president.

Henry Korn of Archbishop Stepinac yesterday posted his fifth record-breaking performance of the season as he won the 12-pound shot-put event at the twelfth annual Bronx-Manhattan-Westchester Catholic High Schools track and field championships.
The sum of $2,165,000 was raised by the women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, it was announced yesterday at a final campaign rally of the division.
Sales of the Union Carbide Corporation last year rose 5 per cent to a new high, but earnings fell 8.5 per cent from those of 1956, Morse G. Dial, president, disclosed in a preliminary statement.
Marcella Ayer. soprano, who made her debut here five years ago at Town Hall, presented a program of German lieder and Dvorak's "Gypsy Songs" last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A Democratic bill calling for a six-year, $3,000,000,000 program for Federal aid to scientific education was introduced in both houses of Congress today.

An Air Force meteorologist expressed confidence here yesterday that electronic computers might one day help jet pilots leave for bases hours away knowing what the weather would be when they got there.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A right-wing Republican Senator paid tribute in the Senate today to a judge who for some four decades has symbolized political liberalism to many.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 30 -- A mystery painting was included in the more than $120,000 worth of art gifts given to Rutgers University last year.
FOOD shoppers seeking bargains this week-end will find them just as scarce as they have been in recent weeks. This is especially true at the meat counter.

Eighteen years ago David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, began a historic effort to get organized labor to rid its ranks of corruptionists -- by a resolution he proposed at the American Federation of Labor convention in New Orleans to bar those convicted of wrongdoing from holding union office.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Pitt ran away with St. John's of Brooklyn, ranked thirteenth nationally in The Associated Press poll, by upsetting the Redmen tonight, 86 -- 73. St. John's was the only unbeaten major college basketball team.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 30 -- A central Sumatran group reflecting the viewpoint of several of Indonesia's leading "rebel" colonels has demanded the immediate resignation of Premier Djuanda's Cabinet, handpicked by President Sukarno last April.
The president of the American Physical Society said here yesterday that it was unfortunate that fusion reaction studies were being treated as a three-team "Olympic game."
The Boeing Airplane Company announced yesterday that it was accelerating its work in technical research and new product develpoment in the air and space equipment field.
The Heart Fund campaign was started here yesterday by the New York Heart Association at a gathering in the children's room of the Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Harriman, in a special message to the Legislature, outlined today a six-point program for improving conditions at farm migrant labor camps.

A school operating budget totaling $395,674,067 for 1958-59, was adopted without a change yesterday by the Board of Education. Earlier in the week it had come under a barrage of criticism, including a charge of "pressure" from City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The White House announced late today that President Eisenhower would leave tomorrow morning for a three-day holiday at his Augusta, Ga., vacation retreat. The program called for his return Sunday night.

Two suspects were arrested last night in the $100,000 robbery on Wednesday of the Kobrin Brothers Jewelry Store, 575 Madison Avenue. On a car seat beside one of the men were two paper bags containing at least $75,000 in gems.

MIAMI, Jan. 30 -- It wasn't till the last of his seventeen starts, on Dec. 26, that the Pastorale Stable's Ever Best won a race last year. It's a different story in 1958. The 6-year-old horse made his first start of the year at Hialeah today and took first money in the $5,000 race that was run in the No. 7 spot.
Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, appealed last night for "an aggressive attack on the entire goal of market expansion" to help solve the farm problem.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The 40-foot sloop Carousel was unofficially declared over all winner of the San Diego-to-Acapulco yacht race today in a close duel with the Mistral, another Class C entry.
FEZ, Morocco, Jan. 30 -- The first regional United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization conference of the Arab world closed here tonight.
ANIMAL, bird and fish forms lend themselves admirably to metal sculpture as executed by Tom Hardy in his current exhibition at the Kraushaar Gallery, 1055 Madison Avenue.

PARIS, Jan 30 -- For Jean Monnet, whose main business is the unification of a continent, the negotiation of hundreds of millions in financial aid for France probably seemed to be a relatively minor interruption.

Title to the sixty-acre tract involved in the $205,000,000 Lincoln Square project will be taken by the city on Feb. 28. At 2 P. M. the same day the city will sell to private sponsors at public auction the separate areas involved in the cultural, performing arts and housing phases of the huge project.

A guard at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men was arrested yesterday for assertedly walking into jail cells and beating up two teen-age prisoners who were reported to have confessed killing the guard's friend in a gang fight. The prisoners were treated at the prison infirmary for head bruises.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Critics reacted with praise and a good many reservations to "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," which opened here tonight. It was directed by Peter Hall.

It is a recognized practice, especially in countries where Anglo-Saxon legal forms are observed, not to pass public judgment on the guilt or innocence of parties whose case is sub judice. An American may not, therefore, have the moral right to say that the South African Government is condemning ninety-five innocent men and women.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore and Marge Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., the 1957 winners, led an advance of the favored teams today in the women's international four-ball golf tournament.
Member banks operated under slightly easier reserve positions in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
COMO, Italy, Jan. 30 -- The United States team whittled the Italian team's lead to 29 points tonight in the three-nation contest for the 1958 world contract bridge championship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee approved today a bill to bring some organized sports under antitrust laws. It would apply to professional baseball, football, hockey and basketball.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Governor Harriman appointed today his one-time running mate, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., to head a Governor's "committee to end poliomyelitis by vaccination."

IT has been June in January at every bridal salon in town. Thousands of future brides are buying their wedding regalia now for May and June weddings, proving that fiancees are foresighted as well as starry-eyed.
John A. Stephens, long chief bargaining representative for the steel industry in his capacity as vice president, industrial relations, of United States Steel Corporation, is leaving that position.

The writer of the following letter, formerly economic adviser to the Office of Defense Mobilization, is author of "The Budgetary Process in the United States." He is Professor of Economics at Harvard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A Southern member of Congress asked today why President Eisenhower had not ordered National Guardsmen into New York City to deal with "racial crime and violence" in the schools.
