Troubled and divided Vietnam is the subject of a political history by Joseph Buttinger that Praeger will issue Feb. 14. Called "The Smaller Dragon," the book is based in part on French Government files kept secret until late 1955.

MONTREAL, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens erupted for five third-period goals against Detroit's goalie, Terry Sawchuk, tonight to rout the Red Wings, 7 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 14,267.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the communique issued by the Baghdad Pact Council here today:
ATLANTA, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Negro leaders urged the Federal Civil Rights Commission today to participate in the Crusade for Citizenship, a drive to double voter registration of Southern Negroes by 1960.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Reciprocal Trade Message to Congress today:

Sales of the Hercules Powder Company last year were the highest in its forty-five-year history, according to the annual report issued to stockholders today by Albert E. Forster, president and board chairman. Net earnings were the company's second highest.

Directors of the Granite City Steel Company yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend on the common stock, with the declaration of 40 cents a share for payment on March 15. In previous quarters, shareholders had received 75 cents a share.
The biggest shipline in the world has decided to call at United States ports.

The State Bar Association was urged yesterday to support Federal legislation to enable the Department of Justice to subpoena business records in anti trust cases before starting criminal or civil actions.
Baseball fans of the country will have no voice in choosing the players on the National and American Leagues' All-Star teams this year.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Although Federal inheritance taxes took almost half of a $9,946,135 Eastman Kodak fortune, the Government demanded an additional 67 cents as interest, it was disclosed here.
ADMIRATION of F. D. R.'s native courage is implicit in Dore Schary's "Sunrise at Campobello," which opened at the Cort last evening.
In these days of relatively high though declining interest rates, many issues of securities have carried sweeteners, such as convertibility, to entice investors. Now comes a sour-mash sweetener.
In this centennial year of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt we may pause to reflect upon an event of the greatest national significance that occurred just fifty years ago this week.

New York City banks operated under sharply reduced reserve pressures in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. With the looser credit conditions already in evidence elsewhere in the nation, this contributed to the markedly easier tone of the money market.
MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- Pravda threw cold water today on the idea of preparing an East-West summit meeting by means of informal and unpublicized talks.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30 -- A Hudson County grand jury today completed its inquiry into an alleged bribe offer of $1,000 by a West New York police captain without calling three of the principals in the case.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- Twenty-five years ago today Adolf Hitler acceded to power in Berlin and started a reign of terror that provoked World War II, the bloodiest war in history.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A "robot" pilot unexpectedly took control of a British Britannia airliner recently and sent it into a dive while the plane's crew fought to regain control, informed sources said today.

In an effort to get its car seen on the road, Edsel is going after police department business. The unit of the Ford Motor Company has just sold fifteen cars to Greenwich, Conn., at a price well below dealers' cost.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) estimated yesterday that consolidated net earnings for 1957 totaled $800,000,000, or about $4.05 each on the average number of shares outstanding during the year. This compared with $808,500,000, or $4.11 a share, in 1956.

ELICK MOLL demonstrated once again on "Playhouse 90" last night that he has a talent for writing dialogue that is vivid and authentic. His play, "The Gentleman from Seventh Avenue," shown over Channel 2, caught the flavor of Manhattan's garment center engagingly.
The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday a net income from all sources for 1957 of $78,247,776. This was $321,069 less than the figure for 1956 and $979,480 less than that for 1955.
The shoe industry will undertake its first general promotion campaign in March.

Salomon Bros. Hutzler and associates are offering $7,590,000 of new equipment trust certificates of the Seaboard Air Line and the Chicago and North Western Railroad. The banking group bought the issues yesterday at public sale.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 30 -- The new Venezuelan Government continued to consolidate its position today.

Camille Gutt, Belgian Minister of State, who was the first managing director of the International Monetary Fund, urged yesterday a speeding up in the timetable for organization of Europe's new Common Market.

The Wiltwyck School for Boys, an interracial, interfaith rehabilitation center for seriously disturbed boys in Esopus, N. Y., will benefit from the Feb. 19 preview performance of the play "The Day The Money Stopped," at the Belasco Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Secretary of Labor said today he expected unemployment next month to be 4,000,000 to 4,500,000. The rise from December to February would be largely seasonal.

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Stan Benham of Lake Placid, N. Y., and Dick Severino of Saratoga Springs, N. Y., today were selected to carry the United States hopes in the world four-man bobsled championships to be run Saturday and Sunday.

In another move to meet the Soviet challenge President Eisenhower yesterday asked Congress to extend the reciprocal trade program for another five years and to give him added power to negotiate reciprocal tariff reductions. This is the program, in effect for some twenty-four years, which permits the Administration to lower our own tariffs on imports from abroad in return for like cuts in foreign tariffs on American exports.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 30 -- Russians have come to Pakistan bearing gifts to a commodity - hungry people. Pakistanis are having second thoughts about their alliances with the West.
All of its regular employes working on an hourly basis in this country will be placed on salary tomorrow, the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors Corporation, defended the competitiveness of his company's automobile prices today. He testified that they had not risen as much as the costs of production.
DOUGLAS, Wyo., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Nebraska officers won custody today of Charles Starkweather, 19-year-old garbage truck driver who police say is responsible for the slaying of eleven persons.
PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- A judge today cut off arguments and summarily dismissed a move for the release of Joseph (Socks) Lanza, labor racketeer, from Clinton State Prison at Dannemora.

Consumption of slab zinc in this country was about 936,000 tons in 1957, a decline of 7 per cent below the total for the preceding year, the American Zinc Institute estimated yesterday in its annual review. Shipments fell 8 per cent to 959,568 tons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- Twenty-six movie stars have responded thus far to invitations by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to play active parts in the television presentation of the thirtieth annual awards ceremony on March 26.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan bitterly assailed the judges of the Court of General Sessions yesterday for giving lenient sentences in cases involving frauds and swindles. Mr. Hogan called a press conference after learning that a defendant who was a leader in a fake insurance-claims ring had received a suspended sentence from Judge John M. Cannella.
Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon charged last night that the Eisenhower Administration had not been a "strong defense administration but a weak one."
The city's Motor Vehicle offices were bracing today for the annual last-minute rush of car owners seeking new license plates before the deadline.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The general strike in this island resort ended today, but the four leading hotels remained closed to tourists.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- A Soviet physiologist called today for cessation of nuclear weapons tests as "the only sure method" of eliminating the hazards of atomic radiation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 30 -- The construction of proposed state roads that would compete with the New Jersey Turnpike will be scheduled so that the interests of turnpike bondholders will not be endangered, it was indicated today.
The City Housing Authority suspended its budget coordinator yesterday. He is Sidney Schackman who is said to have doubled as accountant for the Nassau Management Company, Inc.
Four youths charged with assault and robbery in the Bronx early yesterday were later held in $7,500 bail in Bronx Adolescents Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended last Saturday totaled 550,667 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The screen rights to "Fair Game," the comedy hit at the Longacre, have been jointly acquired by Charles K. Feldman and Columbia Pictures.

PAKIS, Jan. 30 -- The great suspense is over. Yves St. Laurent, the youthful successor to the late Christian Dior, proved today that he could carry on the great tradition of the master, and he did so to applause and bravos from the delighted audience. The collection was absolutely beautiful, the over-all impression being one of breathtaking youth and femininity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Washington puzzled today over the meaning of the proposed merger between Egypt and Syria.
A City Commissioner charged yesterday that his department was being deprived of more than 10 per cent of the amount allocated to it in the current expense budget.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The Public Works, Department opened bids today for three major construction projects and one lesser one in the New York metropolitan area. The low bids on the four amounted to $17,394,856.
TRENTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The State Racing Commission today ruled out the "dark Mondays" sought by Garden State Park race track.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Following is the text of an announcement by the United States on financial discussions with France along with excerpts from a statement by the French Government and statements by Jean Monnet, head of the French financial mission; Per Jacobsson, chairman and managing director of the International Monetary Fund, and C. Douglas Dillon, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The House, overriding the objections of Representative Roy W. Wier, Democrat of Minnesota, voted $305,000 today to finance the work of its Committee on Un-American Activities this year.

KITCHENER, Ont., Jan. 30 (Canadian Press) -- The United States national hockey team can be thankful they don't have to meet the Kitchener-Waterloo Dutchmen in the world hockey tournament at Oslo, Norway, next month. The Dutchmen trounced the Americans, 9 -- 0, tonight under international rules before a crowd of 4,000.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30 -- Argentina's week-long nationwide bank strike was settled today in an unorthodox fashion.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 30 -- Fifteen organizations from suburban Essex County areas will participate in a fashion show benefit to be staged on Tuesday evening at the Montclair store of Hahne Co. Proceeds from the event will be divided among the organizations for their civic, charitable and educational projects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Meade Alcorn, the national Republican chairman, said today that the party's morale had received a big lift in the last few weeks. He gave a large share of the credit to President Eisenhower.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 -- Education for social work must be improved to meet man's new problems in the space age, an educator in the field said here today.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The Public Service Commission today ordered the New York Central Railroad to continue operating its Empire State Express and the De Witt Clinton on their present schedules pending an investigation of service changes that the railroad had proposed to put into effect Feb. 15.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30 -- A leading Yugoslav Communist told the disgruntled coal-miners of Trbovlje today that demands for better pay and working conditions could not always be granted, even if the miners in theory were their own bosses.
The controversy over the school situation in Brooklyn grew more bitter yesterday.

The State of Kentucky announced yesterday plans for the sale of $35,000,000 of highway, bridge and tunnel bonds secured by general taxation. The sale will take place on Feb. 25. The bonds will come due serially from 1973 to 1986.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Strong opposition was voiced by insurance industry spokesmen today to proposals before the Legislature to require the writing of health insurance at level premiums for life.
Profits, billings and production of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in 1957 were the largest in the company's history.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Cristobal Balenciaga is, experts agree, the greatest dressmaker in the world today. Although this self-effacing Spaniard shuns publicity and genuinely detests exploitation, he has reached the very pinnacle of success in the fashion world.
BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Bud Werner of Steamboat Springs, Colo., tonight drew the coveted pole position for the men's slalom, which opens the world ski championships Sunday.
The Federal Power Commission yesterday granted New York State a final license for a Niagara power project.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Spruille Braden, former Ambassador to several Latin-American countries, said today the United States was "disobeying God's will" by its foreign aid program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Benjamin F. Fairless, steel executive, said tonight that unemployment would increase if industry adopted a union proposal to share business profits with workers.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 30 -- Roy Campanella continued to show improvement today from the critical injuries he suffered in an automobile accident early Tuesday.
The new Laust Maersk, the final unit of a special five-ship program for the Moller Steamship Company's Maersk Line, will make her maiden arrival here this morning.

THE petition filed by the New York Central Railroad the other day for increased fares on its West Shore ferries to Cortlandt Street and to Forty-second Street is an unwieldy and coldly legalistic document as such papers are likely to be.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- British government securities led a general, though modest, advance in the stock market today.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Only 129 accidents involving uninsured automobiles registered in New York State were reported during the last eleven months of 1957.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Senator Clifford P. Case declared here tonight that limited warfare was a far greater danger to the United States at present than an all-out nuclear struggle.

A snow crocus, defying the weather, is blooming in the front yard. The lady of the house -- who in season is also the head gardener -- stopped to admire it the other day. And then came to pass that which the assistant gardener, chewing on his pipestem, had greatly feared.
TOKYO, Jan. 30 -- Japan has "no intention" of joining a North Pacific defense alliance similar to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Premier Nobusuke Kishi stated today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- One of the highest salaried union officials in the country sometimes charged three times for the same expenses, a Senate committee heard today.
Protestants are moving in ten so-called critical city areas to meet what some church officials regard as "the greatest missionary challenge" their denominations face.

Following is the text of a presentment handed up yesterday to Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz by a grand jury investigating violence in Brooklyn schools; remarks by Judge Leibowitz to the jury, as recorded by newspaper reporters in court, and the text of a statement last night by the Board of Education:

The season's sixth and last performance of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" took place last night at the Metropolitan Opera. In a largely familiar cast, Carlo Bergonzi sang his first Chenier at the house and Rosalind Elias was heard for the first time as Madelon.

About $120,000 will be spent in altering the three five-story apartment houses at 518-20 and 522 East Eighty-fourth Street into fifty-eight small suites. George Zauderer Sons sold the property, part of which is vacant, to the Larede Construction and Improvement Corporation, representing Morris Rogos and Marks Rosen, builders.
Futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light in most markets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--France, the United States and two international organizations announced today financial assistance for France totaling $655,250,000. Of this, $525,000,000 will be available this year.
The late Robert R. Young's silent partner, Allan P. Kirby, has succeeded him as chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
Dr. Paul A. Siple, who has perhaps spent more time on the Antarctic continent than any other man, was presented last night with the American Geographical Society's David Livingstone Gold Medal.

On April 16, 1861, four days after Confederate guns had blasted Fort Sumter and the Civil War had begun, former President Franklin Pierce wrote to former President Martin Van Buren for help in trying to stop the strife.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union announced yesterday that it was expanding its investments in Government-backed mortgages to provide housing for members of the Armed Forces.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Britain claimed world leadership today in the race with the United States and the Soviet Union to tame the energy in hydrogen fusion for peaceful use.

MARIO LANZA, who in previous films has had lots of trouble with women but no problems with a stentorian tenor that probably could shatter glass at a hundred paces, is in a fairly similar fix in "Seven Hills of Rome," which came to the Music Hall yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 30 -- Ninety-five South Africans who have fought the Government's policies on white supremacy and segregation of races were committed today for trial on charges of high treason.
STUART, Fla., Jan. 30 -- This is the land of luxury quail hunting, made possible by various bush buggies that follow the tastes of their owners. Some of them are astounding production numbers.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Rarely does a hoped-for miracle come off just on time and in full splendor, but it can happen. No planned tribute to the late Christian Dior could possibly have been a bigger success than today's two showings -- first for the press in the morning and second for the buyers in the afternoon. Dior was the couturier who, for the last ten years, headed the largest dress-making business in Paris.
Nearly every pleasure boatman under the age of 60 (some even older) sooner or later wants to be a water skier. Like fishing, it becomes a part of boating.
The election of Maj. Gen. Albert Boyd as vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and general manager of its defense products divisions was announced yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Dow Finsterwald and Stan Mosel shaved five strokes off par today and shared the first-round lead in the 72-hole, $15,000 Phoenix open golf tournament. They carded 66's.

Your editorial of Jan. 20 on "A Taxicab Fare Rise" is timely, particularly your suggestion that "the City Council should make a thorough study of the whole taxicab business: earnings, the take-home income of drivers * * *."
Another valuable contribution of the animal kingdom to man's preparations for space travel was disclosed yesterday.
The presidents of two divisions of the Protestant Council of the City of New York were elected last night. Both will serve two-year terms.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Israel charged today that a "new wave of aggression" had been launched against her borders by Syria.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 30 -- High winds in the upper air appeared likely tonight to keep the firing schedule of the Army's satellite-bearing Jupiter-C rocket in doubt for several days.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The fastest and most peaceful National Football League meeting in history ended today with the owners leaving things as they were.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Manchester Guardian reported today that three United States-educated Chinese students tried to assassinate Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier, last July 28.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- The Indian Rights Association was told tonight that the Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs was trying to dispose of the Indian problem by sweeping it under the rug.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- Construction contractors appealed to the leaders of 3,000,000 union building mechanics today for a joint effort to eliminate wasteful practices and cut costs.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company announced yesterday that it was engaged in the commercial production of a stretchable paper with several times the tear-resistance of conventional papers.

The Police Department said yesterday that policemen would be posted at forty-one schools in the city to maintain order. Seven of the schools will have a policeman assigned from 8 A. M. to 4 P. M., and the patrolmen will make periodic checks inside the buildings.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- Howard Fast was treated here today to a scathing denunciation that covered more than a page of Moscow's chief literary newspaper and appeared to be designed as the final Soviet word on the American novelist.
Nelson A. Rockefeller left the door open yesterday to a race for Governor this year.
Mayor Wagner and other city, county and borough officials were guests last night at a dinner sponsored by the National Democratic Club at its clubhouse, Madison Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 30 -- Secretary of State Dulles told the Baghdad Pact powers today that the United States was fully committed to back up their defenses.

The market for United States Government securities registered a conflicting reaction yesterday to the terms of the $16,785,000,000 refunding that the Treasury plans next week. Short-term securities moved up in price and long-term bonds down.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 30 -- The Isotopes Extension of the Atomic Energy Commission's Division of Licensing and Regulation will move from Oak Ridge to Washington Feb. 15.

The problems of more than twenty million persons, divided among ten territories that are at the moment neither free nor unfree, are involved in sessions of the United Nations Trusteeship Council that started yesterday and will continue about eight weeks.
Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country last year amounted to $32,173,412,000, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reports. To total in 1956 was $31,612,196,000.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The transfer of funds to the London money market by American banks attracted by the high interest rates here helped lead to a sharp drop in the British Treasury bill rate today.

LONDON, Jan. 81 -- While British Government securities continued to move ahead today, industrial groups were unsettled by a cut in the interim dividend and a forecast of a "marked decline" in profits by the General Electric Company, Ltd.

ALTHOUGH the popularity of St. Valentine's Day has dimmed a little in the last ten years, it is still a day for gift-giving on any scale you choose. Here are a few possible ways to express your sentiments:
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- About 30 per cent of all the armed services' flag rank officers are stationed in Washington, a survey disclosed today.
Acting General Sessions Judge John M. Cannella said yesterday that the attack made upon him by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan on Thursday was "unfair, unjustified and unwarranted."

We know that we voice the thoughts of all Americans in expressing hearty congratulations to the devoted group of scientists, engineers and technicians who have made possible the first successful test of the Jupiter-C satellite-carrying rocket.

The tentative assessed valuation of property here reached a record of $22,648,947,353 yesterday. This is a net increase of $705,901,736, or 3.2 per cent, over the present fiscal year, which ends June 30.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- British steel companies are embarking on a nation-wide campaign to arouse public opinion against renationalization of the industry.

Maurice H. Bunting, a shipping official for twenty-five years, has been appointed general manager in the United States and Canada of the new joint service to be established in March by the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company and the Orient Line.

A nine-foot telescopic camera with a focal length of ninety-five inches has produced valuable information on aerial haze penetration in experiments by H. R. Condit of the Eastman Kodak Company at Rochester, N. Y.

The recent transit labor disputes demonstrate again how widely the slogan "one cannot strike against the government" is regarded as an article of faith to be accepted without examination. If one asks why, the answer in effect is, "Because." Or, in the editorial words of The Times, "The employe of the government, being part of the government, cannot be permitted to strike against government."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -President Eisenhower exhorted the Republicans today to work hard, with "faith in a good cause," for a party victory in the Congressional elections in November.
The Nephrosis Foundation of New York has taken over the Alvin Theatre for the March 5 evening performance of "Oh Captain!" as part of its annual fund-raising campaign.
The nation rejoiced early this morning as the news spread that the United States now had its own satellite, "The Explorer," circling the earth.

HAMBURGER -- that ever popular and comparatively economical beef cut -- is prepared in an unusual and delicious way by Mrs. Sandra Behrend of Belleville, N. J. She has sent directions for the dish -- meat balls marsala -- which, she writes, is especially good with noodles or boiled rice. The dish also makes an excellent hors d'oeuvre.
They are making driver licenses of aluminum in South Carolina.
Columbia University hit another legal roadblock yesterday in its long-standing attempt to evict some tenants from an apartment house it owns across the street from the campus.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 31 -- The United States' first earth satellite was borne spaceward tonight on a tremendous golden jet that roared its way across the sky from the base of the Army's Jupiter-C rocket.

A VINTAGE chart that should hold uncommon interest for both amateurs and connoisseurs interested in the subject was made available this week by the Sherry Wine and Spirits Company, 679 Madison Avenue.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 31 -- A tracheotomy was performed today on Roy Campanella to relieve a lung congestion that had developed during the last twenty-four hours. The ballplayer continued to make progress here today, however, after his injury in an auto crash.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner asserted today that much of the leadership of the nation had been transferred from "amateurs" in the White House and the Administration to practical and effective politicians in Congress.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The British Government's approach to a top-level meeting with the Soviet Union stiffened appreciably today.

An X-ray miscroscope with a very long name has just been introduced by Philips Electronics, Inc., Mount Vernon, N. Y. The company says it will permit scientists to examine the arrangement of constituents in opaque speciments and quickly identify their chemical composition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A coal industry spokesman today called railroad Pullman and diner services "as obsolete as the dodo," in joining livestock and meat packing interests in attacking proposed freight rate increases.

Everybody in horse racing knows who "Willie the Shoe" is. He's one of the best of the current crop of jockeys. The nickname belongs to one William Lee Shoemaker, born in Fabens, Tex., on Aug. 19, 1931.

The Board of Estimate has unanimously endorsed "in principle" a proposal to build a sports stadium on city-owned land. It could provide by 1960 a modern playing field for a National League baseball team.
A broad inquiry by Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney into the Board of Estimate's bureau of real estate has resulted in the suspension of the bureau's executive officer.

The Summer Soldiers This is the time of year when those who live in the suburbs engage in morbid speculation. As they shovel snow from the sidewalk and bail water from the cellar, their thoughts are dark.

A railroad president, the head of a bank, a district attorney and a band leader will be among the prominent Nassau County men who will act as escorts in the grand finale of a benefit fashion show in the Georgian Room of the Garden City Hotel on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A long list of witnesses from Government and industry has been called to testify on charges that five members of the Federal Communications Commission engaged in "personal, official misconduct."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm prices increased 2 per cent during the month ended Jan. 15.
Two physicists reported yesterday that the first satisfactory calculation of the creation of the solar system may have been found in studies of the atmosphere of the moon.

Over Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive along the East River an eyeful of incongruity sprouts from the cement and steel on each side of the highway and stretches high over the motorist's head. The skeletal steel girder work is the embryo of a baby skyscraper, Cannon Point South, a new luxury apartment house.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- The Private Truck Council of America was urged today to maintain constant vigilance against roadblocks that would threaten completion of the Federal-state highway program.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The pressure tightened on grain futures in Board of Trade today. Almost the entire market recorded new losses.
A basic trainer for space flights that would carry a man 120 miles high on a short trip was outlined yesterday by a missile scientist.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Nathan Cayton, a 59-year-old retired judge, was designated today as chairman of a three-member board of monitors that will look over the shoulder of James R. Hoffa while he runs the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- Calls for further decentralization of the legal system and for additional guarantees against miscarriages of justice like those of the Stalin era are heard persistently here from legal specialists.
"Noah's Ark" will return to the National Broadcasting Company television network next May. The filmed series about the adventures of a veterinarian is produced by Jack Webb, star of "Dragnet."

On Nov. 6 Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet Communist Party chief, told the Supreme Soviet that the Russian satellites were "waiting for the American and other satellites to join them and to form a commonwealth of sputniks."

WARSAW, Jan. 31 -- Poland's participation in the information media guarantee program sponsored by the United States was foreshadowed today in an announcement of an agreement to purchase twenty-five American movies.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The British Government agreed today to a sweeping review of parliamentary procedure in response to vigorous criticism inside and outside the House of Commons.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 31 -- The detailed day-to-day story of the Army's Jupiter-C and the Navy's most recent Vanguard was withheld from publication because of an unusual agreement between the Department of Defense, as represented by Maj. Gen. Donald N. Yates, commanding the Air Force Missile Test Center here, and all news media.
New York's building and construction industry was threatened yesterday with a strike on Monday by truck drivers who deliver sand, gravel, concrete and other building materials.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Jan 31 -- When a Bible school runs short of chapel space, the faculty usually views it as a spiritual omen. But to the Northeastern Bible Institute here, cramped chapel quarters were a mixed and costly blessing that meant holding most of the religious and social activities in off-campus, rented auditoriums.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31 -- The great "Chetnik conspiracy" to overthrow the Tito regime in Yugoslavia went to trial today.
Three Puerto Rican youths arrived here yesterday with their own version of the "fly now-pay later" plan.
BOSTON, Saturday, Feb 1 -- Negotiators worked beyond a midnight strike deadline to reach agreement on a contract for two major radio and television networks.

The Esso Standard Oil Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), announced yesterday a reduction averaging four-tenths of a cent a gallon in the prices of heating oil, kerosene and Diesel fuel throughout its eighteen- state marketing area.
Robert Schick of this city, who has studied piano at the Juilliard School and composition at Columbia University, made his New York debut as a pianist last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

ALTHOUGH Dore Schary concededly is a man of many parts, his pronouncement here one day last April that he would write and produce with the Theatre Guild a play about Franklin Delano Roosevelt was met by Shubert Alley skeptics with arched eyebrows.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 31 -- There is a great difference between the satellitelaunchers of the Army and the Navy.
The New York State Athletic Commission approved a plan yesterday which will allow boxing fans to watch live preliminaries and a televised title fight on the same night without changing their seats.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31 -- A top union leader accused employers today of having deliberately created the present economic recession in the belief that mass unemployment would help them in an open war against labor this year.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 31 -- The Indonesian Cabinet has dismissed Sjafruddin Prawiranegara, outspoken critic of the Government, from his post as Governor of the Bank of Indonesia, officials said today. Lukman Hakin, Vice Governor, is acting Governor.

Yvon Durelle, the rugged fisherman from Moncton, N. B., registered a victory by technical knockout over Clarence Hinnant of Washington at Madison Square Garden last night. The Canadian was declared the winner at 1:46 of the seventh round by Referee Harry Kessler.
The radio signal from the United States satellite "Explorer," now in orbit, was picked up over California early this morning.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 31 -- President Eisenhower returned today to his favorite golfing retreat -- the Augusta National -- and within half an hour of his arrival was trying to play the shots he has practiced in the White House backyard for many weeks.
Leroy Keith was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair. He had been convicted of the first-degree murder of a taxicab driver.
Futures trading on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday was narrow and dull. Evening of positions before the weekend accounted for most of the volume.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Congressional investigators called on the Secretary of Defense today to proceed immediately at full speed with construction of a $6,000,000,000 ballistic missile defense system.
PEIPING, Jan 31 (Reuters) -- Three non-Communist cabinet Ministers were dismissed today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The unemployment insurance system produced the first mildly optimistic statistics in weeks today.
The plan for launching an artificial satellite with a multistage system of the Jupiter-C variety dates to the summer of 1954.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano announced today details of a reorganization of the Foreign Ministry following the appointment of Hilger Albert Scherpenberg as State Secretary in succession to Prof. Walter Hallstein.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Defense Department fact sheet giving details of the Army's satellite - carrying Jupiter-C rocket:
The satellite orbit should not carry it over any substantial part of the United States for twenty-one hours after firing.
DETROIT, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports today estimated January car sales at 400,000 units compared with 490,000 in the same month last year.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation yesterday declared a 2 per cent stock dividend and the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents cash on the common stock, both payable March 26. A similar stock dividend was paid in previous quarters.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Saturday, Feb. 1 -- President Eisenhower announced early today the successful launching of an earth satellite into orbit by the United States.

It will be good news to all of Western Europe that France is to get $655,250,000 in financial aid from the United States, the International Monetary Fund and the European Payments Union. Without such aid France could not have hoped to play her allotted role in the European Common Market Euratom (the atomic energy community) and all the financial and trade arrangements that link France to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 31--The Westchester Board of Elections began rechecking permanent personal voter registration today under the county's new system. But it hoped that before another year the State Legislature would provide some relief.

A one-story taxpayer building on a plot 90 by 191 feet at 42-7 to 42-25 Queens Boulevard in Sunnyside, Queens, has been sold by the Colonial Investing Corporation, Al J. Schecter, president. It was bought by an investing client of George Levine, lawyer, in a deal negotiated by Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., broker.

TRUMBULL, Conn., Jan. 31 -- The Connecticut Public Utilities Commission warned this town today that it had violated commission regulations by permitting the construction of a building near a high pressure natural gas pipeline.
Three American mothers who visited their sons imprisoned in Communist China arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, last night at the end of their flight from Hong Kong.
New securities offered publicly here in January dropped below the level of those of a year ago, but were larger than those in December.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Khrushchev these days is showing signs of what psychologists call a split personality. On the one hand he has made consistent efforts to change those forms of Stalinism which had gripped Russia in a rigid ice pack. But, on the other hand, he accepts the orthodoxy of certain Stalinist opinions in foreign policy.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Empire Stateway was the name selected by judges today for the state's newest superhighway. The name must be approved by the Legislature.

Dr. Samuel H. Stein, in his letter published Jan. 24, says that the recent American Medical Association report endorsing water fluoridation as safe and effective "dismisses the very recent work of Dr. George Waldbott."

Camilla Williams, returning to Town Hall after the absence of several years, gave a fine song recital there last night. She sang familiar songs by Schubert, Wolf and Strauss, some less familiar material by Vivaldi and Mozart, and ended with a group of spirituals.
DALLAS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Bob Kamensky of North Hollywood, Calif., has a T-33 Shooting Star for sale despite Government regulations prohibiting private civilians from owning military jet aircraft.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- Representatives of fourteen science information services joined forces today in an effort to eliminate duplication and thus increase their output for the benefit of scientists and technologists of the English-speaking world.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 -- Lewis Milestone, director, will do Pork Chop Hill" as the first of three pictures for Gregory Peck's independent company, Melville Productions.
BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- George Yardley scored 36 points to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 119105 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight at the Boston Garden.

MOOSE JAW, Sask., Jan. 31 (Canadian Press) -- Three Moose Jaw hunters pulled off a sports oddity near here last Oct. 23. They shot five mallard ducks and two of the birds carried United States Fish and Wildlife Department rings with consecutive numbers. They were shot within half an hour of each other.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 31 -- The will of the late Florence Belding Nuchols, wife of Henry W. Nuchols of Stanwich Road, Greenwich, disposes of an estate in excess of $3,000,000. At least $1,000,000 is set aside for charitable purposes.
The Armco Steel Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries reached a record in sales last year, but net income was down $10,549,182 from 1956, the preliminary annual statement disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that sand was being added to some test atomic bombs in an attempt to reduce the deadly radioactive fall-out.

Two of the largest glass furnaces ever built are part of a new container plant opened in Atlanta, Ga., yesterday by the Owens-Illinois Glass Company. The furnaces are fed automatically with raw materials -- principally sand, limestone and soda ash -- from a thirteen - story "batch house."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 31 -- Venezuelan newspapers have been having a field day since censorship was abolished with the overthrow last week of the Government of Marcos Perez Jimenez.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Dr. John P. Hagen, director of the Vanguard satellite project, called on the United States tonight to create an intellectual "elite" to lead the nation to supremacy in the space-age.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 31 -- A mission of a delegate of the International Red Cross into the Algerian frontier region to make contact with four French prisoners appeared tonight to be drawing to a safe end.
TOKYO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Japan's Antarctic expedition headquarters decided today to call for help to get the trapped expedition icebreaker Soya into open water.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) The Moscow radio has told the Russian people that Elizabeth Eckford, a Negro student at Central High School, Little Rock, Ark., was murdered last week in a racial outburst.

Whether by accident or design -- and it will be unwise to rule out design -- the Soviet Union has stepped up overtures to Pakistan that have coincided with the just-concluded meeting of the Baghdad Pact powers. A Soviet Agriculture Minister is touring the country offering various sorts of aid, including the promise to assist in the building of a steel mill.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Following are excerpts from President Eisenhower's remarks today to the Republican National Committee:

The New York State Senate has on its calendar for summary action on Feb. 3 -- without even a public hearing -- a bill by Senator Cooke to require a year's residence in the state before anyone can receive public assistance with state reimbursement.
Lawyers were urged yesterday to assume greater public responsibilities lest these tasks be assumed by others not as well qualified.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--The Chicago Sun - Times, a morning newspaper, marked its tenth anniversary today with the dedication of its new $15,000,000 building on the north bank of the Chicago River near the heart of the city.
NAHA, Okinawa, Saturday, Feb. 1 -- About 25,000 former Mawashi citizens are expected to go to the polls tomorrow to elect fifteen new members of the Naha city council.

Following is the text of the address by Adlai E. Stevenson last night at the tenth annual National Roosevelt Day Dinner given here by Americans for Democratic Action in memory of the late Franklin D. Roosevelt:
MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- Several Soviet republics have decided to hold lotteries this year to raise funds for housing and other purposes.
"Support of those who seek freedom and justice in the face of discrimination" is urged in the annual race-relations message of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 -- India and Pakistan are studying important new proposals for ending the dispute over control of the waters that bring life to the farmlands of the Indus River basin.

Mayor Wagner and the City Bar Association moved yesterday to inquire into the acrimonious dispute over Brooklyn school delinquency. The Mayor announced that he would meet with members of the Board of Education and other school officials Monday at 4:30 P. M. in Gracie Mansion.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange in January registered the best gain since August, when the combined average rose 21.01 points. Last month The New York Times average gained 14.46 points, or 5.4 per cent.
Adlai E. Stevenson proposed last night a new kind of United Nations effort to end the EastWest deadlock over disarmament.
The State Bar Association adopted resolutions yesterday urging new state legislation to protect civil rights.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Marge Burns of Greensboro, N. C., and Dale Fleming of Tulsa provided the first upset of the women's international amateur four-ball golf tournament today when they ousted Mrs. Barbara Romack Porter of Sacramento, Calif., and Anne Richardson of Columbus, Ohio, 2 and 1, in the quarter-finals.
Thousands of travelers arriving in the United States by sea and air are finding their purchases in France assessed at about 20 per cent more than the official rate by customs inspectors.
Protesting Federal interference in "a local New York State matter," the State Power Authority "reluctantly" accepted yesterday a final Federal Power Commission license for a Niagara power project.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--The latest Soviet version of the World War II Battle of Stalingrad attempts to dispel once and for all the idea that Stalin was the architect of that decisive Soviet victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The origin of certain fanciful figures that flit about on television screens was explained this week in a patent. It is done with flexible mirrors. John P. Hoppe, the inventor, has made clowns for Ernie Kovacs, pink elephants for Kathryn Murray, Halloween ghosts for Ed Sullivan and Christmas elves for Eddie Fisher.

The Bureau of Child Guidance is swamped with emotionally disturbed children, its director said yesterday. The burden on the Board of Education's agency is especially heavy in Brooklyn and Manhattan, Dr. Jean Thompson, the director, added.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Charles Johnson, State Labor Conciliator, said agreements were reached early today that, if ratified by the unions, would end the strike against The St. Paul Dispatch and Pioneer Press, which began Dec. 17.

THERE is something gravely wrong here. Berl Senofsky is an American violinist who beat all comers to win first prize in the Brussels 1955 competition, and he gets to play in New York as guest of the Metropolitan Museum's Young Artists Series.
THE National Broadcasting Company's new "Comment" program could not have gotten off to a more auspicious start last night on television.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -The Court of Military Appeals today cautioned military commanders against ordering service men to bare their personal lives.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Cabinet has approved a higher federal budget for 1958-59 but it will be balanced by a surplus from the current year, the West German Finance Ministry announced today.
Five out-of-state gangsters are to appear before the Legislative watchdog committee when it moves its Apalachin investigation here next Friday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Consumers' installment debt increased by $531,000,000 in December and was at a record total of $34,127,000,000 at the end of the year.
Mike Herman Completed the greatest personal triumph in the sixteen-year history of the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships last night.

GARIMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 31 (AP) -The International Bobsled and Toboggan Federation today threatened to call for an allsports boycott of the 1960 Winter Olympic Games at Squaw Valley, Calif., unless a bobsled run is built there and bobsleding restored to the program.
Max Wiederman has been appointed vice president, engineemng, ArnotJamestown, marine division of Aetna Steel Products Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The State Department is not particularly disturbed by the current tour through Soviet-bloc countries of an Argentine trade delegation.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that he was willing to agree to some delay in convening a summit meeting, but that the conference should not be postponed into the indefinite future.
A three-year test of a propeller cast in one piece of Nialite showed virtually no wear caused by erosion or cavitation, according to its builder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The United States Court of Appeals here upheld today the conviction of Harry Sacher, New York attorney, for contempt of Congress. Sachet pleaded the First Amendment to the Constitution in refusing to answer questions about Communist membership.

For the first time aircraft have landed on solid ground on the Antarctic continent. Two small United States Navy planes set down yesterday on an air strip bulldozed smooth on the boulder-strewn shoulder of Marble Point.

An investing client of Harry Handschu, broker, bought the six-story apartment house for seventy-one families at 1119 Foster Avenue, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The property is on a plot 172 by 99 feet and is assessed at $290,000. It was sold by the Freseld Realty Corporation.

DENVER, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Ben Martin, the University of Virginia coach, today was named head football coach at the United States Air Force Academy. The appointment was announced by Col. George B. Simler, the academy athletic director.

NEWPORT, R. I., Jan. 31 -- Robert R. Young, railroad financier, left his entire estate including personal property of more than $6,000,000 to his widow, Anita O'Keefe Young. His will was filed in probate court today by Cornelius C. Moore, his attorney.
A new definition of a pump -- some chemical concerns use 3,000 centrifugal types -- will be devised late this month.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Governor Harriman appointed today eight persons to fill vacancies in the Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Diplomatic Corps was speculating today on what significance there was in the farewell calls of Georgi N. Zaroubin, the Soviet Ambassador.

Two railroads -- the Pennsylvania and the Lehigh Valley -- yesterday announced planned reductions in service. The Pennsylvania Railroad will drop its Senator between New York and Washington Feb. 14. The Senator now leaves New York at 3:45 P. M. daily.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 -- Erich Ollenhauer, West German Social Democratic leader, reaffirmed tonight that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer had received and refused in 1952 a Soviet offer to reunify Germany through free elections. He was alluding to Soviet letters of March 10 and April 9, 1952.

IT is a truth universally acknowledged that a light novel always has a devil of a time staying light. Dank clouds of sententious solemnity are forever menacing its bright artificial skies. The spirit of comic invention fails somewhere along the line and laughter grows forced, if not downright grim.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The New York State Thruway reported to Governor Harriman and the Legislature today that it had operated last year at a profit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Government sources said today that they would not be surprised if the Soviet Union tried within the next few days to launch a third earth satellite.
John Blanchard, a protege of Bill Dickey, and Dick Sanders, an outfielder, brought to ten yesterday the number of Yankees under contract.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Senate's chief racket investigator implied today that gang violence had helped put William E. Maloney at the top of the International Union of Operating Engineers.
William G. McEwan, a 23year-old unemployed service station attendant, was arrested yesterday in the slaying of a Brooklyn shipyard owner and his wife. The police said the motive was robbery.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Jan. 31 -- Pressure is growing within Iceland's Social Democratic party to sever its links with the Communists by quitting the coalition government.

The bond market continued to make adjustment yesterday to the terms of the $16,785,000,000 Treasury refunding, which is likely to result next week in more than $2,000,000,000 of short-dated debt being converted into long-term obligations.
THE Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, almost synonymous with French paintings of quality, is now showing a group of pictures by nineteenthcentury French masters.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP) -- A sophomore at the University of Tampa was charged with aggravated assault today in the shooting of a fellow student. The police said the shooting occurred last night during an argument over noise in a dormitory.

The New York Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks will meet in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden today. The contest, which will be on national television, will start at 2 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Three Democratic Senators opened a sharp floor attack today on President Eisenhower's economic and housing policies.

The launching of the American artificial earth satellite is the first in a series of scientific experiments that will explore space in much the way that the Western world explored the earth during past centuries.
A jig borer controlled automatically by holes punched in tape is performing a multiple hole-drilling and boring operation on 150-pound planetary gear cages for the Navy Department's Bureau of Ships.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- The East German regime, which represents itself as a government based on "the power of the workers and peasants," apparently has a long way to go to win general support from these groups.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Dr. Ali Amini, Ambassador of Iran, advocated today pooling the oil incomes of Middle Eastern nations.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Gen. Sir Francis Wogan Festing as been appointed to succeed retiring Gen. Sir Gerald Templer in September as Chief of the Imperial General Staff, Britain's top military post.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Communists protested today the United Nations Command's introduction of atomic weapons into South Korea. The United Nations promptly rejected the protest.
The student newspaper of violence-plagued John Marshall Junior High School, Brooklyn, appeared this week with one student's conception of a delinquent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- A group of Congressional witnesses today backed President Eisenhower's plea for a change in tax laws to make it easier for states and cities to borrow money for schools, roads and other facilities.
"Sunrise at Campobello," Dore Schary's play about the fateful years of illness in the life of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, is Broadway's newest hit.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Jan. 31 -- Sheikh Abdullah said today that Pakistan was a friend of Kashmir and India the enemy of the Kashmiris.
In line with the company's jet age expansion, United Air Lines has announced the appointment of seven senior vice presidents and seventeen new vice presidents.
THE Easter parade already has formed in New York's custom millinery salons where customers are busy selecting spring chapeaux.
Regulation T of the Federal Reserve Board, controlling margins on stock purchases, does not apply to every securities transaction.

Like mother tigers protecting their young, Republican Representative John Taber of New York and Democratic Representative Clarence Cannon of Missouri, those two doughty tigers of the Appropriations Committee, are fighting tooth and claw to maintain the old ways and to prevent passage of a bill to alter (for the better) the budgetary procedure of the Federal Government.
Twenty employes of the City Housing Authority held part-time jobs with the Nassau Management Company or had money invested in it, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -Average wholesale prices at the primary market level remained unchanged at 118.8 per cent of their 1947-49 prices during the week ended Tuesday, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 31 -- It is a well publicized fact that fishermen are men of independent mind, ever seeking the solitary triumph or discovery, always questing, never imitative. It must be so, since they all say it is.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Representative Lee Metcalf, Democrat of Montana, charged today that a Negro leader had "cynically and maliciously" helped to defeat last year's school construction bill in alliance with President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The ranking Republican on the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee put a reservation today on his endorsement of President Eisenhower's request for a 5-cent stamp on non-local letter mail.
A leading British aircraft manufacturer said yesterday he was convinced that the Soviet Union was going to "attack" commercial aircraft markets outside its orbit.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, Feb. 1 -- The earth satellite launched by the Army last night is circling the earth at a peak altitude of 2,000 miles.
OTTAWA, Jan. 31 (Canadian Press) -- Official Government publications have disclosed a goldmine of hitherto secret information on Canada's air defense system.

NAPA, Calif., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Forty-five children, ranging from six months to college age, were marooned in an orphanage today by a flood on Pope Creek in a remote valley about thirty miles northwest of here.

Events today: Samuel Barber's "Vanessa," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera, 7:30; Puccini's "La Boheme." Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15; Mozart's "Don Giovanni," Opera Workshop, Public School 75, 7:45.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 31 -Dartmouth's skiers took a substantial lead as their annual winter carnival opened today under sunny skies.
The lawyer for the National Hockey League Players Association yesterday called for the "amicable withdrawal" of the group's pending $3,000,000 damage suit against the clubowners.

MIAMI, Jan. 31 -- A Miami automobile sales agency gives a plaque to any jockey who rides three or more winners on one Hialeah program. John Ruane qualified for one today. He had four winners in six tries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today the Pullman Company planned to increase charges for some sleeping car space on six Eastern railroads and the Southern Pacific, which operates through the Southwest and West.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Jay Hebert took the lead at the half-way mark in the $15,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today with a thirty-six hole score of 136. He was a stroke ahead of Billy Maxwell and two strokes in front of five others.
Members of New York's only Negro longshore local will vote for officers today in an election that has attracted widespread waterfront interest.
The state's insurance superintendent yesterday turned down a request by New York Blue Cross for an average increase of 40 per cent in its hospitalization insurance rates.

Counsel for the Transit Authority, and the Motormen's Benevolent Association conferred yesterday with former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind on procedures for hearing charges against the transit workers in last December's subway strike.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation has purchased for $8,400,000 the copper mining properties of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation in White Pine County, Nevada, near Ely.
Stock prices yesterday ended the day and the week with hardly any change.

Many cocktail parties were given last night in private homes and at the St. Regis in advance of the forty-eighth annual Blue Ridge Ball. The fete was held in the hotel's Roof and Penthouse, which were decorated with pink roses, quince blossoms and white stock.

CAIRO, Jan. 31--President Shukri al-Kuwatly of Syria arrived here today to join in a proclamation uniting his country with Egypt. The announcement of the merging of the two Arab states will be made simultaneously before the National Assemblies in Cairo and Damascus tomorrow or Sunday, it was predicted in both capitals.

The new capital market is occupied at present chiefly with Government financing. Major interest is centering on the outcome of the Treasury's refunding next week of $16,785,000,000 of maturing securities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, has re-emphasized to Congress that United States nuclear warheads "must still remain in the custody of United States personnel" under President Eisenhower's proposed atomic exchange program.
The development fund of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale the Bronx, will be augmented as a result of a fashion show and bridge party in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria on March 1.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Although Paris haute couture designs will always hold first place on the Paris fashion scene, there is growing interest and activity in French ready-to-wear clothes. Until recently, they could boast only the tiniest toehold on popularity with discerning francwise French women. But the picture is gradually changing, and Paris department stores offer a fairly wide range of high fashion adaptations.
COMO, Italy, Jan. 31 -- A championship Italian contract bridge team still led the United States players tonight in the 1958 team-of-four world championship.
Engineers at the General Electric Company are using electrified paint to coat castings for shipment from the foundries at Elmira, N. Y.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Willie Shoemaker, who rode his first winner less than nine years ago, today scored the 3,000th victory of his racing career at Santa Anita today when he captured the eighth race with Eternal Pere.
Howard Fast struck back yesterday against the "maniacal castigation" of him published in Moscow this week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The president of General Motors Corporation testified today that creation of a Federal fact-finding board to pass judgment on price increases by big business would be "ruinous" to free enterprise.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points up to 5 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- The Algeria Reform Bill finally because law today amid official concern for the state of military affairs in the embattled North African territory.

A biography of Pope Pius XII by Katherine Burton is planned for publication in late March by Longmans, Green. It will be called "Witness of the Light: The Life of Pope Pius XII, Spiritual Leader, Scholar, Diplomat."

"Winterset" (1936), with Burgess Meredith and Margo, will be shown today in the "Fifty Years of New York Movies" series at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. The screening time is 3 P. M.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Barry Eagle, 15 years old, son of a New York shirt manufacturer. was killed today in a three-vehicle crash on the Lehigh Valley Thruway about four miles north of here.
Net income of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation last year declined 24 per cent from 1956 while sales dipped only one-half of 1 per cent, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

A friend of the United States, who has accomplished a delicate task successfully, is leaving this country to assume a new post in an even wider field. He is Dr. Heinz L. Krekeler, the first German Ambassador to Washington after the war, who has been appointed a member of the directing commission of the European Atomic Energy Community, one of the milestones on the road toward a United States of Europe.
DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- Labor difficulties in Chrysler Corporation plants made nearly 14,000 workers idle today.
ALGERIA, Jan. 31 -- The French military authorities reported today heavy fighting in eastern Algeria as rebel bands sought to step up the flow of weapons from Tunisia.
The Southern pine lumber industry, one of the oldest industries in the nation, is celebrating its 350th anniversary this year.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 31 -- Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes in effect told a group of wavering members of Congress last night that they risked the people's wrath if they did not vote for him for President.

The first four players in the standing for the chess championship of the Americas in Bogota, including William Lombardy and Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, were winners in the eighth round, according to a report received yesterday through Colombian news sources.
The TelePrompter Corporation has developed a central panel to take the snafu out of meetings.
CONSULTATION chess is more than 100 years old. It has been effectively demonstrated that the quality of play is vastly improved when two or more players consult on the best move before it is made.

Venezuela's turn toward democracy augurs well for the huge amount of foreign capital invested there, in the opinion of Romulo Betancourt, former President of Venezuela and head of Accion Democratica, the largest political party in the country.
Foreign aid can work both ways. Ask Rheem Manufacturing.

The American and Soviet satellites represent the Model T of man-made space devices. But the time is not too far off when the earth may be ringed with bigger, maybe faster and elaborately instrumental models.

Prospects for increased production and sales now appear a little brighter than a month ago. Some observers of the economic scene believe that the worst of the business recession is over. They point to the gains made in the stock market, lower inventories in the face of sustained retail selling and a renewal of confidence brought about by the Government's announced plan to increase spending for defense.
NORWALK, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Acrid fumes enveloped the area. Ghostly light from the burning flame flared over the darkened neighborhood.

THE business barometer is down and still falling. Industrial production has been slipping, at first almost unnoticeably, for over a year. A variety of important indexes joined the downward movement during the summer. Personal income, which held out longest, finally began to give way in September.
In a broad municipal real estate venture, New York City is selling and otherwise disposing of 6,675 of its 73,000 acres of water-supply lands upstate and on Long Island.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Administration has rejected pleas for expanded meteorological research, which the Weather Bureau says could lead to improved forecasting and eventually weather control.
The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, will benefit from the Toyland Ball, to be held April 9 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

" IT is this way with verse and animals," writes William Meredith, "* * * what is rare is off before you have it anywhere." Mr. Meredith has been luckier than most. There are many rare things in his book. "The Open Sea," his third volume, should consolidate his reputation as one of the most important of the new poets.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Danny Litwhiler led the National League to a 4-2 victory over the American League today in the third annual oldtimers baseball game.
Three rabbis declared yesterday that religious resources should be mobilized to combat juvenile delinquency by giving young people a worthwhile outlet for "frustrated" energies.

MANILA, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Danny Kid of the Philippines rallied in the final round tonight to hold Cuba's Manuel Armenteros, to a ten-round draw before 8,000 spectators. Kid weighed 117 1/2 pounds to Armenteros' 118.

Youngsters in private schools suffer more from emotional disturbances than do public school children, according to a soonto-be-released survey sponsored by Columbia University's Department of Psychiatry.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Make no mistake about it, Art Tokle is the top ski jumper in the East. The 35year-old Odin Ski Club member leaped 148 and 145 feet today to capture easily the Bear Mountain Sports Association Class A championship.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- A practical-minded Bostonian has made known his intention of wielding a legislative knife on the legal bands tied around a codicil of Benjamin Franklin's will.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 30 -- (Reuters) -- Australian scientists, after years of rain-making research, believe they are on the threshold of perfecting a successful method.

STRANGE how the pre-revolution Russian theatre still haunts us. It is constantly in the news. We are still drawing dividends from the artistic investments that Russians made a half century and more ago.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 1 -- The trial of three elderly Serbs, charged with conspiracy to overthrow Communist rule in Yugoslavia, went into secret session this evening.

Showing the best gain for any month since last August, the stock market last week edged higher as January came to a close. The advance, however, was quite selective; trading was moderately active. A great deal of the volume centered on issues influenced by news developments and corporate reports.

ANY child who has had to stay behind when the family embarked on a new venture will share Kimi's feelings. When her family moved from their little Japanese village, Kimi naturally wanted to go too, but the grown-ups agreed she should stay behind to keep old Aunt Nishi company.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 1 -- The Maryland General Assembly received a preview this week of a record-breaking $386,052,416 budget that Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin will propose when it convenes Feb. 5. The proposed budget includes 50 per cent increases in state sales and income taxes.

SEVERANCE Hall in Cleveland was opened in 1931. It cost John Long Severance, Cleveland philanthropist, some three million good depression dollars (about $8,000,000 today). When the hall was finished, Mr. Severance gave it to the Cleveland Orchestra, with a healthy endowment to keep it functioning for the foreseeable future.
The final chapter in the short, but heroic, career of a 22-year-old Air Force sergeant lost in the North Burma jungle in 1945 will be written this week.

VETERAN observers of philatelic trends agree that American postal history is being researched today as never before. The hobby's serious students are no longer content with mere accumulations of stamps.

A fire started by a kerosene stove killed five members of a family of eight in Brooklyn early yesterday. Seven hours later Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. visited the neighborhood to deliver a street warning on fire hazards.
CAIRO, Feb. 1 -- Egypt and Syria, two young republics, joined hands today as a unified state. They call their new nation the United Arab Republic.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M. -- The erstwhile gate guardhouse of this "atomic town," which used to be harder to get past than the portals of Fort Knox, is now a hot-dog and hamburger emporium, with curb service.

In the face of Germany's persistent refusal to contribute any further to the support of Allied troops stationed on her soil for Western -- but also for her own -protection, Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic alliance and one of Europe's best diplomats, has gone to Bonn in an effort to settle a controversy that is disturbing Western defenses.

New claims for state unemployment compensation decreased for the second consecutive week, but total claims advanced to a new high of 37,000. With an additional 2 1/2-point drop in the rate of steel production, the Cleveland - Lorain district output was estimated at 43.5 per cent of capacity.

LOS ANGELES -- On the last day of 1957 Disneyland tallied its 10,000,000th visitor. The total represents an average of some 10,000 visitors a day, 365 days a year, since the suburban amusement park's opening on July 18, 1955. The patronage betokens an impressive array of records in the field of entertainment and recreation.

THOSE who argue that George Balanchine's ballets are all alike certainly found support for their belief in at least one direction in the four new works he created for the New York City Ballet's recent season -- all four works were monotonously successful.
VIENNA, Feb. 1 -- The puppet regime installed by Moscow in Hungary a year ago after Soviet armed forces had suppressed the Hungarian revolution changed its trade name this week.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Like the Army's artificial satellite, West Point's athletic teams were flying high today.

SUMMER on Malibu Beach might mean the sweet cycle of sea and sun and sleep. It might, Mike and Steve Hortons' summer include that serene cycle. It also includes ingredients cyclonic -- an escaped convict, a whiskery gnome of a hobo, a pest named Henry Parks and a small tidal wave.

In the recent Kennan-Achesor pronouncements for and against disengagement in mid-Europe it is surprising that these eminent gentlemen did not emphasize a factor which will be of increasing and major importance in the coming ten years -- the industrial, military and political resurgence of Germany.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 23 -- A descendant of a French admiral who fought on the side of Washington and Lafayette in the American Revolution is playing a key role in the struggle to keep the French flag flying over Algeria.

ANNUALS are used in many different ways because gardeners know they are reliable for colorful displays or accents. Many interesting varieties make their debut this year.

The Inter-American Law Institute, which brings Latin American lawyers to the United States each year for post-graduate study, will proclaim its program a success in a tenth anniversary report now being prepared.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Feb. 1 -- Roy Campanella's general condition continues to improve, his physicians reported today.
MONTREAL, Feb. 1 (UP) -The Montreal Canadiens spotted the Boston Bruins the first goal tonight and then rallied behind the fine netminding of Jacques Plante to win, 3 -- 1.
A campaign to "Keep Your Home Safe from Fire" will open tomorrow when firemen begin distribution of 1,000,000 educational comic books throughout the city schools.

An attempt is to be made by the Federal Government to improve the study of foreign languages in the nation's schools and colleges. In his education message last week, President Eisenhower drew attention to the importance of foreign languages, and asked Congress for funds to help strengthen this program.

ALFRED HAYES has given us a powerful and disturbing novel of morality. It should also be said -- and quickly too -- that "My Face for the World to See" is an exciting, engrossing work, written with beautiful economy and the sure skill of an artist who knows what he is doing.

NEW LONDON, Conn. THE prognosis of war was never so chancy as it is today. New weapons pose new possibilities which call for new strategies. But, in the face of all the uncertainties, the United States has just recently put a strong emphasis on submarines.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Army and technical officials agreed today that the successful launching last night of the United States' first satellite had opened the way to hitting the moon or putting a man-made object into orbit around it.
An insurgent reform group was defeated at the polls yesterday in an attempt to wrest control of a Brooklyn waterfront local from the independent International Longshoremen's Association.
Four new chrysanthemums mark the debut of the All-America Mum Selections while All-America Gladiolus Selections designates one winner for 1958.

A significant reminder of this fact is the appearance of the first two volumes of the new Cambridge Modern History, a masterwork which will employ scores of historians over several years.
The Westchester Committee of Sarah Lawrence College is planning a scholarship program benefit, which will be held on Feb. 22, in the Reisinger Auditorium of the college in Bronxville, N. Y.
NEWARK, Feb. 1 -- Teachers College of New Britain, Conn., successfully defended its Collegiate Track Conference indoor championship this afternoon at Newark Armory.
AMES, Iowa, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Iowa State College today appointed Clay Stapleton, an assistant at Oregon State as head football coach.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The role of television in British election campaigns has been undergoing a cautious reappraisal in the last week.

COMMERCIAL radio and television are fast developing a canopy of culture. An assortment of educational programs has mushroomed recently into what marks a surprising effort by the broadcasting industry to extend the intellectual and scientific horizons of its masses.
