NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 1 -- Turkish Cypriotes were urged today to begin a campaign of passive resistance against British troops and officials.

IT'S not surprising the most highly rated -- currently 15.4 on the Nielsen chart -- local live television program in Los Angeles is "Traffic Court" on KABC-TV. After all, traffic and citations are afflictions with which the Angeleno learns to live, like earthquakes, forest fires and plaster-cracking sonic booms.

This year General Motors Corporation and E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. are putting into effect amended bonus plans, adopted last year. They are designed to give the recipients incentives to work hard, despite high taxes and possible declines in the stock market.

WARSAW. TAKE one thin, round bottle, scrape off the lead seal and fish out the cork, pour and swallow. This is the simple recipe for a drink of vodka in Poland. It is about the only part of Polish life that is perfectly easy and, to the horror of Government and church leaders alike, the easy habit has spread to the point of being a serious national headache.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- Kurt Herbert Adler, general director of the San Francisco Opera, is accepting applications for the 1958 opera debut auditions.
VILLALBA, P. R., Jan. 25 -There is a new cafetin -- a typical Puerto Rican bar and grocery -here, and the Rev. Salvatore Ruffolo, a Roman Catholic parish priest, started it.

Democratic Governor Harriman last week dropped a two-volume, six-pound 1958-59 budget into the hopper of the Republican-controlled Legislature. It is the biggest in New York's history and its political reverberations are sure to be felt in the elections in November.

EVERY suburban parent is familiar with the phrase "for the good of the children." It explains very neatly why he's living where and as he's living in 1958. Experts began pointing out a score of years ago the importance of green grass as an adjunct to child development; parents heard, heeded and began what has become a near stampede to the suburbs.

Ireland has announced that it will invade our shores by air in April. We are glad to learn that the Dublin Government has been able to give Aerlinte Eireann the green light for trans-Atlantic operations. Since 1948, the airline was ready on two separate occasions to fly between New York and Dublin.

The holding company, often a player of bizarre roles in the drama of finance, was on stage again last week. In the form of the Alleghany Corporation, it was closely intertwined in the plot that came to a climax with the suicide of Robert R. Young.
OTTAWA, Feb. 1 -- The Conservative Government's stated intention of buying more from Britain and less from the United States is already being fulfilled, without in fact any effort on its part.
The investment banking house of Spencer Trask Co. will observe tomorrow its ninetieth anniversary.

CAIRO, Feb. 1 -- A modern Egyptian Pharoah is preparing to extend his reign across the far Euphrates and to the Tigris River as did his forebears in ancient times. The phenomenal thing about this is that no blade of conquest is being bared and, in fact, leaders of the area, which is now modern Syria, are allowing the ruler of the Nile Valley to take over the reins of their Government.

Nikita S. Khrushchev's program to give the Soviet people as much meat as Americans get appears to have run into difficulties.

IN last Sunday's Times, Ossia Trilling concludes a report on the Russian theatre: "The professional artist and writer watch their [the "party pundits"] puny efforts with mild amusement, for once the floodgates are fully open, the dictatorship of the amateur is doomed."

RAOUL LEVY, youthful French producer of "And God Created Woman, a film that may make Brigitte Bardot more popular than crepes Suzette, is hopeful of teaming none other than Frank Sinatra and the torrid "B. B."

IN Frank X. Tolbert's THE STAKED PLAIN (Harper, $3.95), there are a few historical characters -- Colonel Mackenzie of the Fourth Cavalry and the Kiowa chieftain White Bear, better known to infamy as Satanta -- but just about all the other characters, along with the various battle scenes, are completely fictional.

A CONSCIENTIOUS observer who is more than a little concerned about creeping deterioration in the content and quality of American films, might do well t o make a study of David O. Selznick's "A Farewell to Arms" in search of some clue to what is causing the peculiar and unnecessary decline.

The undefeated Columbia fencing team, seeking its third consecutive Ivy title, opened its league season yesterday by defeating Harvard, 20 -- 7, at the University Hall gymnasium. The victory was the Lions' sixth this season.
HAVANA, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Jackie Pung of Hawaii, playing out of San Francisco, retained her lead today after the second round of the Havana women's invitation fifty-four-hole golf tournament.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- The land of the first earth satellite received the news of the successful launching of a United States satellite with a display of good sportsmanship today.

VIENNA, Jan. 31 -- For those whose education is lacking in the social graces the Vienna telephone exchange this week had a discreet remedy. A subscriber had only to dial 1514 to hear a recorded male voice giving confidential advice on how to behave in polite society.

SCHIERSTEIN, Germany, Feb. 1 -- The United States Navy struck the colors on its little fleet on the Rhine River today. The ceremony marked the end of nine years of naval operations 250 miles from the open sea.

THE sound of hoofbeats on television echoes on many new children's records. The Western records follow the Westerns on television that follow those from the movies with the exception, of course, that the so-called nervous Western (sheriff discovers after a Rohrschach that he has a psychological bloc about firing his Colt) has not yet been transferred to long-play.

A wave of speculative buying is sweeping over the market for United States Government securities on the eve of another effort of the Treasury to get more of the public debt funded into long-term bonds.

ROME, Feb. 1 -- Italy is still prodding the United States to pool its resources with those of other Western countries for a bold new approach to the problem of under-developed areas in the Middle East.

COMO, Italy, Feb. 1 -- In a stormy session marked by official protests and sharp exchanges, the Italian team increased its lead over the United States players this morning to thirty-one match points in the 1958 contract bridge world championships.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Joe W. Brown's Tenacious whipped through the stretch to win the $13,525 Louisiana Handicap with a two-length margin over a stablemate, Fanciful Miss, at the Fair Grounds today.
The Explorer satellite is a cylinder eighty inches long with a tapered nose and a rocket nozzle at its rear.

MOSCOW. IF President Eisenhower were to rise angrily tomorrow and proclaim that to prove the superiority of the capitalist system the United States planned to overtake and surpass the Soviet Union in vodka consumption, the leaders of the Kremlin would not grieve.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Five members of the Federal Communications Commission prepared today the answers that they will give on Monday to charges that they have engaged in "personal, official misconduct."

A comprehensive exhibition of Korean art, said to be the first held outside the Orient, is one of the highlights of another crowded week in New York museums and galleries. It has been sent under the auspices of the Republic of Korea and will open to the public at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday.
OTTAWA, Feb. 1 -- The Canadian Parliament was dissolved tonight and a general election called for March 31.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 1 -- It has been a year since this capital city experienced racial terrorism in connection with desegregation of public bus facilities.

Auction sales of interest to collectors of early American and English period furniture and those who admire the poetic water colors of the late Charles Demuth are scheduled for this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 28 -- The United State is not in the Baghdad Pact but United States citizens certainly are in the pact countries.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 1 -- For the seventh consecutive year, Dartmouth's skiers emerged victorious today in their annual winter carnival.

MADISON AVENUE. EVERYBODY knows that the population of the United States rose from 154,652,000 in 1952 to 168,662,000 in 1956. Not everybody knows that the United States per capita consumption of vegetable juices (of which 85 per cent is tomato juice) dropped from 5.1 pounds to 4.6 pounds during the same period.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- Many Russians, especially those more than 40 years old, are trying to give up smoking on physicians' orders.

Standing off a steady battering toward the close, the New York Rangers defeated the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Paced by a pair of goals by Andy Hebenton, the Broadway Blues set down the Hawks, 3 to 2.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles expressed gratification today at the launching of the first United States satellite.

HOW much has been printed and said in recent years, we wonder, about helping children to understand "the facts of life"? Books, pamphlets, articles, speeches by uncounted hundreds on this topic have been addressed to parents.
Boxholders and patrons have been announced for the Free Milk Fund for Babies benefit on Thursday.

The American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers has announced the winners of five awards that will be conferred during its national convention here on Feb. 16 to 20. These are in addition to several other awards announced earlier.

IN November, 1956, C. B. S. television launched a twenty-six-week series, Air Power, with music by Norman Dello Joio. From the television series the composer extracted music for a symphonic suite, which has been recorded by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra (Columbia).

AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- King Hussein has proposed to King Faisal of Iraq and King Saudi of Saudi Arabia a conference to discuss "the best ways and means of achieving Arab unity," a reliable source said today.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Manchester United scored a 5-4 victory over Arsenal today in an English Soccer League thriller that saw United strike back after the home team had tallied three times in as many minutes.
Doug Tynan of St. Francis Prep in Brooklyn ran the fastest schoolboy indoor 600-yard race on record last night when he won the event in 1 minute 13.7 seconds at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Wholesale trade in the Chicago area reached a new high mark by a narrow margin in 1957, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. The new record was 21.5 billion compared with 21.3 billion in 1956.
PLASTIC greenhouses for home use are coming to the fore. While gardeners contemplate buying or building one, it may be helpful to answer some questions.
The union of Egypt and Syria brings together two nations alike in religion and language but very different in personality.

Not every skill or implement fashioned for war remains unused in the shaky peace that exists in the world. At least one battlefield mission -- aero-medical evacuation-- finds and application amid the human suffering that goes on, war or no war.

THIS collection of letters from Dylan Thomas to his best, earliest friend and fellow-poet, Vernon Watkins, is fresh and reassuring as a spring of water -- a very lively spring to be sure, bubbling and leaping and running sometimes through muddy flats and stones and rubbish, but a true source, just the same; a good long look at the poet in the morning of his energies and gifts.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sunday, Feb. 2 -- A four-engine DC-4 airliner crashed and burned here last night.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 1 -- Having recognized with reasonable promptness Venezuela's revolutionary Government this week, the United States left behind it a long controversy as to whether or not it had actually and actively supported the ousted dictatorial regime of Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez.

-rs. Gordon C. Forbes, general chairman, has announced a junior committee for the cocktail dance bDing sponsored by the Committee for the Rehabilitation of Crlpled Children that will be held in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador on Feb. 13.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Bud Werner of Steamboat Springs, Colo, the United States' chief nope in the world ski championships, narrowly escaped, serious injury today in a final tune-up for tomorrow's opening slalom event.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight submits his final California state budget to the Legislature on Monday.
Both Edwin L. Dale Jr. and "Bill" Martin, the subject of Mr. Dale's article ("Martin of 'The Fed'", Jan. 19), are among my favorite people.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 1 (AP) -- A strike that has halted publication of The St. Paul Dispatch and Pioneer Press since Dec. 17 was settled today with ratification of agreements by the memberships of three unions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Two out of three adult Americans class themselves as Protestants and one in four as Roman Catholic, the Census Bureau reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Edward T. Dickinson, New York State Commissioner of Commerce, met informally today with the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board to discuss business conditions.

MUSIC and food, it is said, are likely to kindle in the mind a remembrance of things past. Granted that this is true, there is probably nothing more apt to stir recollections of one's youth than the odor of sausage frying. There is something indefinable about the pungent and savory aroma of a well-spiced pork link which seems particularly associated with the gusty blasts of winter, and the home as a haven and refuge.
The Boeing Airplane Company has destroyed a new jet transport in the cause of safety.

HONG KONG, Feb. 1 -- Communist China has completed its first five-year plan and this month has begun another.

THE new roses for 1958 are more exciting than ever. Color -- as might be expected from modern trends -- is important, but not the only good quality sought by breeders. Disease resistance and vigor rank high as breeding objectives.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom's private secretary was sentenced today to four months imprisonment and four strokes with a cane for having had sexual relations with a 19-year-old African girl.

SOLEMNLY clapping their own hands in response to the standing ovation from the crowded People's Congress, the little group of men in party uniform make their way past the crimson pillars in the Hall of Magnanimity and ascend the platform to take their seats with other members of the Politburo amid the potted palms, gilded screens and painted scrolls.

A HALF-CENTURY or so after the poet's death, a German critic observed that Heine's works did not belong to the history of literature: they were still literature. With the passage of a century, the observation continues to hold true.

THE inquisitive gardener will add much interest and value to his plantings of vegetables if he explores the merits and demerits of some of the newer varieties. Vegetable breeders are launching them, seemingly in increasing numbers, year after year.

HOLLYVOOD, Fla., Feb. 1 (UP) -- Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore and Marie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., moved a step nearer their second straight women's four-ball golf title today with a 4-and-2 victory over Marge Burns of Greensboro, N. C., and Dale Fleming of Tulsa in a semi-finals match.
The likelihood of a strike tomorrow by 2,000 truck drivers who haul sand, gravel, concrete and other building materials increased yesterday.
TORONTO, Feb. 1 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs bombarded Terry Sawchuk for the the second straight game tonight, firing nine goals past him in a 9-2 rout of the floundering Detroit Red Wings.
An anticipated rise in the marriage rate this year is expected to spur sales of the sterling silver industry.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- The memory of Ferdinand Rudolph Hassler, first superintendent of the United States Coast Survey, will be honored here Feb. 25 when Union College will hold its traditional Founders Day exercises. The occasion will mark the 163d anniversay of the college's chartering by the State Board of Regents.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Secretary of State Dulles declared today that the United States and the Baghdad Pact countries "stand unitedly to bar Soviet armed aggression from the north."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Administration took a major step this week toward breaking down the nationalistic secrecy barriers that have surrounded the atomic weapons arsenal for the last thirteen years.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 1 -- President Eisenhower asked today that his personal congratulations be extended to all those having a part in the successful launching of the first United States earth satellite, the Explorer.
TELEVISION'S pin-up girl, as far as many members of the toddler set are concerned these days, is a petite (5 feet even, 95 pounds), red-haired young woman named Shari Lewis.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 1 -- An optimistic forecast for Long Island's economy this year has been made by Hofstra College economists.

THE spring of 1958 is to be especially favored by the appearance or wider distribution of many new varieties of perennials. Some of these are imports from England. Many were produced by skilled hybridizers while a few are mutations from existing species. All have been thoroughly tested and judged superior.

ONLY a month ago I begged indulgence for a column put together from odds and ends. I do so again today, not for lack of a topic to write about (there are several waiting on which, unfortunately, a little homework remains to be done) but because of some interesting sidelights which have come into view in connection with topics previously discussed.

If The New York Times printed more letters from parents of school age children instead of opinions from the educators and VIP's, perhaps George Z. F. Bereday, in his letter published Jan. 26, would not be so quick to declaim "J'accuse!"
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A House Interior subcommittee today put off for another four months a showdown vote on Hells Canyon dam legislation.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Chuck Spieser, rusty from a ten-month layoff, tonight gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Bobby Lane in a wild-swinging bout at Light Guard Armory. Spieser weighed 176 pounds, his opponent 168.

The turbulent Middle East is an arena of intense political rivalries. The Soviet Government, like the regime of the Czars, has pressed to gain a foothold in the Middle East. The West has been equally intent upon keeping the Russians out.

MIAMI BEACH -- A week ago today the sun came out over Miami Beach, and for the rest of the week warm sunny weather prevailed most of the time, to the delight of the Chamber of Commerce and the hoteliers.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- One of the most astute politicians of the Conservative party will be satisfied if the party loses the next by-election by only 5,000 votes. But he and his colleagues are sure the Conservatives have a good chance of winning the next general election.
City College students, returning to classes tomorrow after a mid-year recess, will get their first look at a stone version of the college's answer to the Columbia Lion and the Yale Bulldog.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- The union of Syria and Egypt has posed a problem new to the United Nations. The question is whether Syria and Egypt will lose the separate membership they now hold in the international organization if the two countries become one, and how the matter will be decided. Thus far, no definite answers have been formulated.
PHILADELPIA, Feb. 1 -- The Donner Foundation of Philadelphia today announced grants to six organizations totaling $242,500.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 1 -- Harvard's 6-foot 4-inch center, Bryant Danner, set a team scoring record with 31 points tonight as the Crimson trounced Yale, 82 to 70.
Jimmy Brown, the former all-America fullback from Syracuse University, was a great success for the Cleveland Browns during his rookie season in the National Football League.

THIS first novel, winner of first prize in the major-fiction division of the Avery Hopwood contests at the University of Michigan in 1956, is the newest example of what can now be identified confidently as a genuine, if minor, literary phenomenon: the genre novel of jazz.
ONE of the most pressing general problems in the field of conservation is the disappearance of the green spaces and natural areas in and around our expanding cities and towns.

The question is whether Syria and Egypt will lose the separate membership they now hold in the international organization if the two countries become one, and how the matter will be decided. A 5-year-old Yugoslav boy who has lived most of his life in the United States is on his way to Belgrade, in full agreement with his parents that America is hard to understand.

ERIC LARRABEE'S article, "The Face We Turn to the World," on those 350 books chosen for the Carnegie Corporation to give libraries in the British Commonwealth puzzles me because it is not clear if Mr. Larrabee in his resume has covered all categories of the gift.
LIMA, Peru, Jan. 20 -- The Government has ordered the expropriation of 988 acres of farm land north of the port of Callao for a new airport to serve the Lima-Callao area.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 2 -- The streets of New Delhi were choked today by a strange, silent procession of bearded men in blue turbans.
MIRNY, Antarctica, Jan. 30 -- The first American visit to the main Russian base in Antarctica was a social success.

ROCKY POINT, L. I., Feb 2 -- The Army's only Nike guided-missile installation in Suffolk County was dedicated here today. Four hundred persons, including dignitaries and Army officials, were taken on a guided tour of the forty-acre site.
A theatre benefit and supper dance on May 15 will benefit Irvington House, a treatment center in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., for children with rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease.
LAST year the girdle industry was agog over a special design by Emilio Pucci. It reshaped the seat of the foundation, lifting it up and out. Enter the chemise; exit Mr. Pucci's girdle.
A Norwegian fishing village will be recreated this summer on the lagoon and huge outdoor stage of the Jones Beach Marine Theatre, where "Song of Norway" will be revived on June 19.

The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority declared yesterday that its arterial highway program would take care of future traffic demands if a "realistic" approach were made to a particular problem, that is the routing traffic across Manhattan over two proposed elevated expressways.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 -- A perpetual air traffic jam ranking as the worst in the nation appeared today to have been the underlying cause of last night's collision of two military planes over suburban Norwalk.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The University of Chicago, which dropped intercollegiate football at the end of the 1939 season, placed three more former luminaries in the college football Hall of Fame last night. They were Amos Alonzo Stagg, Jay Berwanger and the late Walter Eckersall.

ALTHOUGH a city child may never in his life milk a cow, drain maple syrup from a tree or hold a newly hatched chick in the palm of his hand, the wonders of nature abound, nonetheless, just beyond his doorstep.
HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- "A month from today all Cuba will be in flames."

Net income of the National Steel Corporation, the nation's sixth largest steel producer, declined to $45,518,884 last year from $52,502,422 in 1956, the company reported over the week-end. Profits last year equaled $6.13 a common share, compared with $7.09 a share for the preceding year.

The current discussion about the economic state of the nation, beginning with the President's Economic Report of Jan. 20 and continuing through the hearings of the Joint Congressional Economic Committee on the President's Economic Report, which opened last Wednesday, has produced some divergent comments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The desire of a White House aide to become a judge of the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals has stirred some bristling opposition from patent lawyers and put the Department of Justice in an embarrassing position.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- All grain futures had rallying moments at one time or another on the Board of Trade last week, but those for corn and soybeans failed to generate much steam.

S. W. Brown of New York has been appointed consultant to the French Line for the air-conditioning of its new 55,000-ton luxury liner France. This was announced over the weekend by Guy de Berc, general manager for the line in this country and Canada.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- All major Soviet newspapers reported today the launching of an earth satellite in the United States. In almost all cases the announcement was brief and occupied space on inside pages.
Stockholders of the Turner Construction Company elected three officers to the board at their annual meeting Saturday.

PEIPING, Feb. 2 (Reuters) -- Three ministers ousted from the Chinese Government were reported to be confined to their offices here today while awaiting removal to the countryside for "education and reform through labor."

A thousand orthopedic surgeons went back to school yesterday morning in two Manhattan hotels. They attended twenty-two simultaneous courses given by leading specialists as part of the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons.
Leaders of the United Transit Employes Council yesterday asked for public support of its aims. The council is composed of six craft unions of workers employed by the Transit Authority.

Repeal of the Lyons Residence Law was urged yesterday by Joseph Schechter, City Personnel Director. Removing this local law from the city's books, he declared would help greatly in recruiting manpower in areas of critical shortage, such as engineers and policemen.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Washington took a mildly hopeful view today of the union of Syria and Egypt.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Grauman's Chinese Theatre, a Hollywood landmark and tourist attraction since 1927, was closed tonight to undergo interior modernization. The theatre's famous forecourt, where handprints and footprints of movie stars are embedded in the cement walk squares, will not be changed, however.

Robert Morris, former chief counsel for the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, declared yesterday that the United States "has failed to comprehend the regime of the Soviet Union over the last twelve years."

The announcement from Ottawa that the Canadian Parliament has been dissolved and that a general election will be held on March 31 reminds one that our northern neighbors, so like us in many respects, take their politics quite differently.
They called in the old pros of jazz for a concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening. "Dody in Dixieland" it was called.
YESTERDAY afternoon's performance at Carnegie Recital Hall by Karl and Phyllis Kraeuter, violin and 'cello duo, was prefaced by an announcement from Mr. Kraeuter.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors spurted in the final five minutes today to defeat the New York Knickerbockers, 131 -- 120, before 5,246 at Convention Hall. The triumph strengthened the Warriors' hold on third place in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division.
Housing construction in the state hit an eleven-year low in 1957, the State Housing Commissioner, Joseph P. McMurray, said yesterday.
ZURICH, Feb. 2 -- An optimistic tone pervaded business on all sectors of the Stock Exchange here last week. It marked progress in the process of consolidation after a long period of tumult.

Archbishop Amleto G. Cicogani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, celebrated a pontifical mass at 11 A. M. yesterday in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Sixtieth Street and Columbus Avenue. The mass was offered for all non-Catholics.

It seems reasonable that weak and troubled peoples who have some basic homogeneity in language, culture or religion should unite to achieve a political and economic viability that might be impossible for each separately. On this ground there can be no complaint, in theory at least, over the attempt to bring together Egypt and Syria -- and the even more remote Kingdom of Yemen -- into some sort of federal structure.
WARSAW, Feb. 2 -- Poland held local elections today in which, for the second time since the 1956 political upheaval, the voters were given a limited choice of candidates on a single list.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower was urged today to call together representatives of management, labor and Federal agencies to draft a full employment program for the electronics and electrical manufacturing industry.

The Sheltering Arms Children's Service will open its 135th anniversary year with a Parcel Party-Tea Dance on April 20 in the Pierre. Guests will be asked to bring useful articles that may be resold later at the Nearly-New Shop, with proceeds going to Sheltering Arms.

In its first change of ownership in fourteen years, the nine-story apartment building at 334 West Eighty-seventh Street, near Riverside Drive, has been sold by Joseph Teichman. It was bought by a syndicate represented by Morton Greenberg in a deal negotiated by Alfred Kohn Co., broker.
ROME, Feb, 2 -- Amintore Fanfani, secretary of the ruling Christian Democratic party, put forth today in effect his bid to become Italy's next Premier at the head of a strong anti-Communist regime.
BOSTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Three middle period goals carried the Boston Bruins to a 4 -- 3 victory over the New York Rangers tonight in a wild National Hockey League game.
United States Attorney Paul W. Williams said yesterday that he agreed in principle with District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's criticism of lenient sentences involving frauds and swindles.
The United States -- despite Soviet missile successes -- still holds a dominant military position in the world.
Winners of the first David Sarnoff Outstanding Achievement Awards in Science and Engineering have been announced by the Radio Corporation of America.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 -- With the United States' first satellite secure in its orbit, the general expectation in this rocket-conscious area is that the Navy's Vanguard is due for another chance.

ANN FOGARTY, the fashion designer who parachuted to fame on a wide, white petticoat, has joined the staff of Saks Fifth Avenue. This move was announced over the week-end by Adam L. Gimbel, store president.

CHANTILLY, France, Feb. 2 -- The usual row about care and feeding of ambassadors has started between Congress and the State Department. State wants $1,000,000, or, .00135 per cent, of the total annual budget to pay representation expenses of its envoys.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Andy Korenak recorded two victories today and easily captured the senior men's title in the North American speed skating championships at near-by West Allis, his home town.

PADUCAH, Ky., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Trooper William Little of the Missouri State Police was found safe tonight after one of the two gunmen who had kidnapped him tried to kill himself. The other fugitive fled on foot.
Events tonight: "The Marriage of Figaro," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Daniel Kunin, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Sylvia Marlowe, harpsichordist, and Bernard Greenhouse, 'cellist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

Steps have been initiated by the Ford Foundation to select fifteen young actors and actresses to appear in professional theatrical productions over a three-year period. Nominations are to be made by leaders in the professional, community and university theatre.

Following early weakness, cotton prices in the domestic market turned sharply upward last week until Friday, when they leveled off, according to the New York Cotton Exchange. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts showed a net improvement for the week of 38 to 94 points ($1.90 to $4.70 a bale).
Ellis Island was proposed yesterday as an ideal site for a national lottery center.
Precious parking space at street curbs and in garages is being wasted because automobiles are too long and too wide, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley declared yesterday.
HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- An army lieutenant was killed and three soldiers wounded by a group of youths believed to be members of the Castro movement in the town of Bayamo last night.

Now that arrangements have been made, and the financing provided, for the creation of a new Monetary Commission under the sponsorship of the Committee for Economic Development, it is, presumably, only a matter of time now before a beginning is made in this long overdue investigation.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 -- Steel sales showed no improvement last week nor did many salesmen look for a significant increase before March. Some observers continued to have "hopes" for a rise, but statistics failed to back them up.

Play in the ninth round of the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas brought no change in the standing of the first three at Bogota yesterday, according to a report received through Colombian news sources.
The X-15 rocket plane, due to fly next year, is reported to be a fifty-foot cylinder with stubby wings and unusual protrusions to cope with speeds over 4,000 miles an hour.
The West Virginia and St. John's college basketball teams reached the end of the all-winning trail last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A new staff memorandum and documents presented to a House subcommittee accuse the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission of official misconduct involving a payment from a broadcasting industry organization.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- The Ardsley No. 1 rink, skipped by Victor F. Hockmeyer, captured the Ardsley Medal as the third annual Cuthbertson bonspiel ended at the St. Andrews Golf Club curling rink today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens disappointed the largest Black Hawk home crowd in five years tonight by rallying for a 3-1 victory over Chicago.
Gloria Davy, Brooklyn-born soprano, will make her Metropolitan Opera debut Wednesday evening, Feb. 12, singing the title role in Verdi's "Aida."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Democratic Advisory Council today attacked the economic policies of the Eisenhower Administration and warned that depression might lie ahead unless they were changed.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 2 -- The Indian Government is firmly convinced that nuclear tests present an enormous menace to humanity. The Indian people are similarly convinced that the tests already have affected their lives.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina, the world champion, drove his Maserati to victory today in the 175.2-mile City of Buenos Aires Grand Prix.
" Let's Take a Trip" was forced to cancel its intended journey yesterday because of a jurisdictional issue that involved three labor unions.
The political and medical questions raised by the growing reservoir of radioactive dust in the upper air are almost as universal as the fall-out that it produces.

NORTH CONWAY, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Edi Mall, a Mount Cranmore ski instructor, today won the Harvey Gibson Trophy for the third time with two fast runs through the forty-seven gate slalom course on Cranmore's steep Arlberg Trail.
GARMISCH - Partenkirchen, Germany, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Germans won the first two places in the world four-seat bobsledding championships today on the bob chute used in the 1936 Olympic Games.

LEONID KOGAN, Russian violinist, who played Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole" with the New York Philharmonic Thursday and Friday, played Mozart's Concerto No. 3 in G major (K. 216) when he appeared with the orchestra in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.
What is said to be the first low-cost electronic data processing system that can answer all the record-keeping needs of the garment industry was introduced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Treasury has been swamped with protests that a United States flag depicted on the back of the $10 bill has the field of stars placed at the bottom.

CAIRO, Feb. 2 -- Crown Prince Saif al-Islam Mohammed al-Badr of Yemen was reported en route to Cairo today to announce his country's willingness to join in a federation with the new United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria.
Sidney Shackman, suspended budget coordinator of the City Housing Authority, complained yesterday that he was being "railroaded without a fair trial either in the authority or before the public."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 2 (UP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami today turned back Jack Frost of Monterey, Calif., 1 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, in the Austin Smith tennis final.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- "I wouldn't say we're not concerned about the fall-out. But to tell the truth, we're a lot more worried by the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease on the other side of the fells."

City College will begin construction this spring of an $8,000,000 center for its School of Technology. The center will enable the school to increase by 38 per cent the number of engineers it will train in coming years.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2 -- The merged labor federation decided today to meet James R. Hoffa on a new battlefront.
The steamship charter market continued its plunging pattern last week, dropping for the fifth consecutive time this year. The market opened 1958 on a downward trend and held to it through January.
BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Austria's Josl Rieder won the first title at stake in the world ski championships today by covering two slalom courses in the aggregate time of 115.1 seconds.
Two new one-act operas will be presented by the Department of Music and the Theatre Associates of Columbia University at Brander Matthews Hall on March 19 to 22. Emerson Buckley will conduct.

One of the legislative perennials at Albany is the proposal that New York State refuse public welfare relief of the sick and needy unless they have established residence in the state for a year or two. Bills to that end have bobbed up again, and are moving toward a vote, thus far without public hearing.

An industrial plot on Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Queens, has been purchased by Samuel Zaretsky, president of Tasty Food Products of Brooklyn. The buyer acquired the site from the H. R. D. Realty Company. He will improve it with a food-processing plant containing 50,000 square feet of space.
It was feast and famine for the privately owned American tanker fleet in 1957.
Two thousand union truck drivers who deliver cement, sand and gravel to construction projects in the metropolitan area have called a strike for 7 o'clock this morning.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The American Tariff League, Inc., proposed today the setting up of sliding scale tariffs based on the wages and living standards of workers in exporting countries.

OTTAWA, Feb. 2 -- An election campaign that has been going on unofficially since last June, when the Conservatives ousted the Liberals from the Government, was official today following the dissolution of Parliament last night.
PADUCAH, Ky., Feb. 2 (UP) -- Earlier, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the police had sealed the Paducah area today in a search for the two gunmen.

The tempo of modern scientific advance is so swift that even a decade hence the earth satellite feats of recent months, both Soviet and American, may be regarded as but faltering steps toward the conquest of space. Yet modest as the present achievements may seem by the standards of the future, the present period may well be crucial.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Legislature heads into the fourth week of the 1958 session tomorrow, with efforts to reform the lawmaking process playing an increasing role in its proceedings.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- Art Tokle, with three formful leaps that included one of 164 feet, had an all-winning day today at the New York State ski jumping championships.
Two patrolmen, making a quick switch in their duties to midwifery yesterday morning, saved the life of a prematurely born, three-and-one-half-pound boy.
COMO, Italy, Feb. 2 -- Chances of an American victory in the world contract bridge championships all but vanished today as the ten-day tournament neared its close.
The flight engineers union announced here yesterday it would request leaders of the merged labor movement to suspend the Air Line Pilots Association for anti-union activities.

WAGNERIANS have been ring on a starvation diet at the Metropolitan Opera this season. At the end of the fourteenth week, last Saturday night, there arrived finally a work by the master, "Tristan und Isolde." As if to compensate the faithful for their long vigil, there were two Tristans for the price of one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Congress, cheered by the United States satellite and in a considerably happier mood than it has known in several months, will get its first bill to reorganize the Pentagon tomorrow.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Mike Todd said today that Soviet Communist Party Leader Nikita S. Khrushchev would make a perfect movie magnate.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Fay Crocker of Uruguay, the 1955 United States open champion, today won Havana's 54-hole women's invitation golf tournament by defeating Mrs. Jackie Pung of San Francisco on the first extra hole after they had tied at 222.
EXECUTIVE kitchens and dining room accommodations are one of the most conspicuous innovations in new office buildings today.

The Rockland Light and Power Company and subsidiaries reported over the week-end new highs in operating revenues and net income for 1957. The Public Service Commission announced at the same time that it had approved the merger of Rockland Light and Power and the Orange and Rockland Electric Company into a new utility to be known as Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc.
The assignment of policemen to schools was endorsed and opposed by teen-agers appearing on the New York Times Youth Forum yesterday.
Columbia College announced yesterday an accelerated course of study under which qualified chemistry majors can get the degrees of Bachelor of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy in six years.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 2 -- The proclamation of the political union of Egypt and Syria has caused considerable consternation in the Middle East.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Forms for filing state income tax returns for 1957 will be distributed this week by the State Tax Commission. Returns are due April 15.
Cleveland, Ohio, is planning to borrow $15,300,000 in the public bond market on Feb. 25 on issues of securities dated March 1, 1958 and due serially on Sept. 1 from 1959 to 1983.
Two teen-age boys and a 28-year-old man identified by the police as a City Youth Board worker were arrested last night in a Bronx movie house on charges of using narcotics.

ALTHOUGH there have been many filmed accounts on television of the preparations for the Allied invasion of Normandy in 1944, yesterday's Channel 2 presentation, called "D-Day Buildup," gave the story a new dimension.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 2 -- The challenge of tomorrow will be one of social understanding to prevent the accomplishments of science from becoming hazards, Dr. John J. Theobald said today.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Moscow radio told today what two former high Soviet officials were doing nowadays.

In his State of the Union message the President stated: "The only answer to a regime that wages total cold war is to wage total peace." His program for waging peace he divided into two parts -- military and nonmilitary.

FOR a couple of weeks now, the Metropolitan Opera Company's cast for a new production of "Butterfly" has suffered common affliction. Principals, men and women of the chorus and men and women of the ballet have sore knees, blisters between the large toe and the one next to it, tired backs and peculiar gaits.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- Damage by strong winds and heavy rains last month to the tobacco crop now being harvested in Cuba has been estimated at an average of 50 per cent in all areas of the island. This estimate was made by Roland Torricella, president of the Tobacco Stabilization Fund, which controls the production and sale of tobacco in Cuba.
A panel of nine judges for the ninth annual Robert J Flaherty documentary film award was announced yesterday by the City College Institute of Film Techniques, which sponsors the competition.

Percival F. Brundage, Budget Director, appearing before a TV panel of newsmen recently, was asked whether the adoption of a national lottery would help keep the Federal budget in balance. The proposal, in that form, replied the Budget Director, "would not be practical.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 2 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, conferred for four hours today with West German leaders on the inter-Allied dispute over support costs.
Churchgoers were urged yesterday by the Rev. Edward O. Miller to view Lent as "a call to Christian nonconformity."

When Hartland S. West was hired by J. P. Morgan Co. forty-eight years ago to carry messages and papers for the partners, the bookkeepers kept their accounts in longhand. Joining the bank as a 17-year-old boy fresh from high school, he was promoted into a virtuosic fraternity.
A testimonial dinner, liberally spiced with confident retorts to critics, was tendered last night to a Board of Education official completing fifty years of service.

New state and municipal financing scheduled for this week amounts to $328,207,042. This is the largest weekly total since the week ended June 19, 1954, when $393,112,721 of issues were up for sale, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.
Suk Soon Kim, soprano, made a highly favorable impression in a song program at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night.

WHEN William Schwenck Gilbert was 2 years old he was kidnapped by Neapolitan bandits and ransomed by his father for 25. It is unlikely, that the annals of kidnapping include a greater bargain in ransoms; for the baby, who was restored to his parents for so small a sum in 1838, grew up to leave an estate valued at 112,000 when he died in 1911.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 2 -- Costa Ricans turned out in above-average numbers today to elect their public officers, from President down to municipal officials.
Four new films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
WHEN Albert (Dolly) Stark, a reformed umpire, saw Whitey Ford of the Yankees, he went into an exaggerated pantomine of a pitcher taking his stretch while trying to hold a base-runner on first.

A coordinated attack against neuromuscular disorders is to be undertaken by the New York University - Bellevue Medical Center in cooperation with national headquarters of the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation.

The Women's City Club of New York endorses the new proposals of the Tweed Commission for Court Reorganization announced Jan. 6, of the grounds that they provide for unified Family Court for New York City, a large measure of court consolidation in the state and substantial improvement in state-wide court administration.

Dr. Henry Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, called yesterday for a Federal aid program of $1,000,000,000 a year to meet the crisis in education. He proposed that this cover education from the "nursery school to the Ph. D. level."
An 18-year-old youth was shot dead last night in a "hobby club" in the basement of the multi-family home in which he lived in downtown Brooklyn.

This is National Weight Watching Week, and no doubt weight watching is a very good thing. From a medical standpoint, at least, it will be well if the pointer on the scales rises no higher at the end of the week than at the beginning.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Soviet Ambassador Jacob A. Malik had his first British television interview tonight.

Earnings of Smith-Corona, Inc., in the six months ended Dec. 31 were the highest for any similar period in the company's history, according to the report of Edward H. Litchfield, chairman, and Elwyn L. Smith, president.

OAKDALE, L. I., Feb. 2 -- Phil Marriner's Mischief, of the Centerport Fleet, took honors today in the annual invitation regatta of the Connetquot Dinghy Club on Great River. Mischief had only one first place in the six races, but two seconds and two fourths helped put her ahead of the thirty-one other craft.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 2 -- The Cabinet discussed the implications of the merger of Egypt and Syria at its regular weekly meeting today in Jerusalem.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- A commission such as requested by Mayor Wagner to revise the New York City Charter would have sweeping powers to alter a wide variety of state laws.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, Feb. 3 -- Premier Djuanda predicted today the failure of "efforts" by anti-Communist off-Java leaders to establish either a new Indonesian government or separate state on Sumatra.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 2 -- A 16-year-old Great Neck High School boy has won a New York State contest to name a new highway.
The Very Rev. Edward B. Cochran, dean-elect of All Saints Anglican Cathedral, Halifax, N. S., spoke yesterday of the durability of the Christian tradition.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 2 -- This spring promises to see bloodier fighting in Algeria than any of the three previous springs since the guerrilla war began.
For any student of the English banking system this book is a fine basic course, written by a well known Professor of Economics at the University of London.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- Scientific techniques put at the service of industry in Ceylon more than two years ago have justified their cost many times over. The staff of a research laboratory at Colombo has demonstrated that it can not only originate practical uses for waste products, but also provide the bases for additional local industries.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that the United States should be able to send a rocket to the moon within "a few months."
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The stock markets were quiet and somewhat erratic last week.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 2 (UP) -- Ken Venturi won his second straight golf tournament, the $15,000 Phoenix open, today.
Picard-Marvin, Inc., has joined Richard La Fond Advertising, Inc., to form an agency with billings estimated at $4,000,000 a year.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 2 -- In an atmosphere of rising tension and suspense throughout the island, a Greek Cypriote was murdered last night near Kornos, about twenty miles from Nicosia.

SOMERSET, Wis., Feb, 2 (AP) -- Elmer J. Ryan of St. Paul, former Democratic member of Congress from Minnesota's Second District, was killed in a collision of automobiles near here last night. The two persons in the other car were injured.

Edith Hamilton, educator and classical scholar, has been named winner of the 1958 Constance Lindsay Skinner Award. The bronze plaque is voted annually by the Women's National Book Association to an American woman who has made "an outstanding contribution to our culture through books."

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. (AP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, the forgotten man of professional tennis, upset the Australian ace, Lew Hoad, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today in the semi-finals of a big-money tournament at White City Stadium.
Anyone knows that a surprise party without the guest of honor is like a coronation without a king. Still, that's what almost happened at the Lawrenceville (N. J.) School last Friday afternoon.
The teen-aged generation was defended here yesterday as "a scapegoat for the adult sense of guilt" for the present-day world.
The United States' first artificial satellite continued yesterday to orbit and signal by radio from outer space.
A Boston Athletic Association carnival that produced the campaign's fastest times over-all set the stage for New York's five annual track meets beginning with the Millrose Games on Saturday.

YESTERDAY afternoon's hour - long conversation with former President Harry S. Truman, filmed a year ago by Edward R. Murrow for "See It Now," was one of the most remarkable human documents ever shown on television. The program was presented on Channel 2.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower received another letter from Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin today discussing a possible heads-of-government meeting between East and West.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- The Soviet Union and Poland have announced their readiness to take part in "an effective system of control" to guarantee that Central Europe be kept free of nuclear weapons.
VARIETY was the keynote in the second concert of Max Pollikoff's "Music in Our Time" series late yesterday afternoon at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

Former President Harry S. Truman said in an interview televised yesterday that he had never offered to back President Eisenhower for the Presidency, but had, in fact, warned him against seeking the office.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Mary Ann Downey and Marge Lindsay, knocking in putts of all lengths when they needed them most, rallied and won their second straight women's international four-ball golf tournament today on the thirty-eighth hole.

AT first glance, Kalustyan's grocery shop, 407 Third Avenue, looks like an old-fashioned New England country store. But a closer inspection of the wares, some in wooden kegs, others in glass canisters, reveals foodstuffs that were seldom, if ever, heard of in North Hero, Vt., or Center Sandwich, N. H.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 2 -- There is evidence of lower consumption by the Netherlands and rising exports. Thus the balance of payments probably will be better than was expected.

WARSAW, Feb. 2 -- It has taken Adam Rapacki a long time to grow out of the shadow of a famous father who was one of Poland's prewar leaders of the cooperative movement. In the public mind the son has assumed a firm identity of his own only as Foreign Minister, a job he took in May, 1956.
Tentative plans to raise political funds through a mass appeal to voters were disclosed yesterday in a clash between the Democratic and Republican national chairmen.
Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., New York realty brokers and auctioneers, has announced plans for two auction sales of estates in Florida.
HOBART, Okla., Jan. 29 -- The war drums are throbbing again in the old Comanche territory.
Two agencies that carry major responsibility for foster care of New York's Jewish children will combine a number of their key operations next month.
CRAIL CONNER, soprano, and Martin Josman, baritone, appeared in a joint performance at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.
Roy Eugene Nickell, who will be 3 years old in April, arrived here yesterday from Excello, Ohio, for a medical examination that will determine if surgery can restore the sight in his right eye.
HAMILTON, Feb. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Steel Company of Canada, Ltd., had consolidated net profit of $21,158,112, or $4.90 a share, in 1957, compared with $22,693,712, or $5.25 a share, in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House tonight after three days at his vacation retreat on the grounds of the Augusta National Golf Club at Augusta, Ga.

The Brooklyn Museum will have on exhibition today a new acquisition, a forged steel sculpture seventy-four inches high by David Smith. It is titled "The Hero." Mr. Smith's work, completed in 1952, was shown last fall in his retrospective exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas asserted today that Congressional refusal to extend the reciprocal trade tariff-lowering program would invite the collapse of Western defenses.
An estimated total of 200,000 sales and management people will go back to school next month through the medium of closed-circuit television.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 3 -A hunt for guerrillas by helicopter today afforded a birdseye view of the tremendous difficulties the French Army faces in smashing rebel bands that raid from the heavily wooded mountains.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Hints are among the numerous pressures that have no effect on Harold E. Stassen. And that goes double for anonymous hints, even when he is perceptive enough to realize that their source is deep within the Presidential circle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today reported that the December sales of merchant wholesalers totaled $9,300,000,000, down 3 per cent below the November level and 7 per cent below the December total a year ago.

I read your editorial of Jan. 29 "Tragedy in Cyprus" with great interest. I am glad that it gives me an opportunity to express my appreciation for your many attempts to obtain objectivity in this problem that has cast troubling shadows on relations between Turkey, Greece and Great Britain.
A strike by fifty-one cleaning and maintenance workers at the Bronx campus of New York University kept some food supplies from the college cafeterias yesterday. Students attended classes as usual.
William J. Kaufman, a lawyer and real estate operator, was indicted yesterday by a New York County grand jury on charges of rent gouging.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 -- Library scientists at Western Reserve University proposed today the establishment of a national center to coordinate scientific and technical information.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Naval Research Laboratory issued today this timetable of expected appearances tomorrow of the satellite Explorer. All times are Eastern standard.

Now at last construction can begin on the great Niagara power project. The New York State Power Authority has accepted the license issued by the Federal Power Commission. Preparations in anticipation of license have to some extent mitigated the delay.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Defense Department has decided to release money for advance planning on satellite projects more ambitious than those now under way.
TRENTON, Feb. 3 -- The Republican-controlled State Senate has decided not to confirm Grover C. Richman Jr. as State Attorney General, leaders of the Senate declared here tonight.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy presented certificate of achievement yesterday to thirty-nine ranking police officers who have just completed the first executive development course of the Police Department.

Although nearly two years have passed since Howard Hobson gave up his coach's kit for an attache case, the former Yale basketball mentor is still advocating changes in the game's rules.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Conservative party agreed today to participate in a series of programs on the Rochdale by-election.

An actual psysical start within a week on the $625,000,000 Niagara power project was a probability last night as the State Power Authority announced it had obtained $100,000,000 in temporary financing.
EVEN midway through the twentieth century the Oedipus legend is impressive.

New Yorkers naturally feel let down by the news that the remarkable decrease in the number of fires which took place in the first three years of Fire Commissioner Cavanagh's administration was reversed last year. There were about 8,500 more in 1957 than in the year before, when there were almost 10,000 less than in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The report of a speech by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, before the annual conference of the Middle East Institute, erroneously stated in Sunday's issue of the New York Times that the Senator had praised Gamal Abdel Nasser. President of Egypt, as a bulwark against communism.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A preliminary report from the Soviet Union on its two satellites finally reached headquarters of the International Geophysical Year today, but it carried no secrets from space.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision reversing the conviction of five Connecticut Communists for conspiring to advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence. It took no stand on the issues.
DUBLIN, Feb. 3 -- A strike of 3,000 municipal workers has left this city without any street repair services or staffs to take care of public lighting, sewage, garbage disposal or waterworks.

Some Americans in positions of great responsibility believe that the United States is facing the most dangerous era in its history. The next five years, as Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, the Army's retiring chief of research and development, puts it, may be a period of "extreme criticality."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The White House called on the Soviet Government today for "further clarification" of its attitude if it wanted to bring about a meeting of heads of government.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- House of Representatives leaders today eulogized former Representative Bertrand H. Snell, New York Republican, as a person and as a legislator.
OTTAWA, Feb. 3 -- Canada's party leaders started planning their strategy today for the general election of March 31.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 3 -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg signed today the long-awaited treaty establishing the Benelux Economic Union.

THIS is the time of year when imagination gets its first whiff of the fragrance from the orange groves. The major league ball clubs start sending out their brochures, listing the candidates who soon will report for spring training. This awakens a sense of anticipation and stirs up images of palm trees, pelicans, palmetto shrubs, sunshine, warmth and ballplayers.
LONDON, Feb. 3 (Reuters) -- A confusion of Cossacks plagued impresario Victor Hochhauser today.
The development of the European Common Market provides a major opportunity for increased commerce in this country, a conference on its implications was told yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Traffic deaths in the nation were 1,128, or 3 per cent, fewer in 1957 than in 1956, reflecting "an unmistakable improvement in traffic behavior and enforcement," the National Safety Council reported today.
The trustees of Columbia University accepted "with regret" yesterday the resignation of Dr. Louis M. Hacker as dean of the School of General Studies.
A slim, mustachioed man dressed in blue blazer, short-sleeve sport shirt and Oxford gray slacks paid a visit to this department the other day to talk about the tennis program in the city's schools.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 3 -- The Indonesian Army announced today withdrawal of the concessions granted to B. P. M., the Royal Dutch Shell subsidiary, to exploit oil fields in the Sumatran provinces of Achin and North Sumatra.

The retrial of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Teamsters Union, and two others on wiretap conspiracy charges was put over yesterday by Federal Judge John M. Cashin until Feb. 24. The first trial ended in a hung jury.

The six-story loft building at 79 Barrow Street, near Hudson Street, will be converted into an apartment house. The property, on a plot 25 by 100 feet, has been purchased by a builder client of L. J. Phillips-Wood Dolson Company, brokers in the sale.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Cyril Henry Hoskins, plumber's son from Plympton, is hiding near Dublin.
A Valentine Ball will be given in the Savoy-Plaza on Feb. 14 by the Junior Committee of the New York Philharmonic to aid the student ticket fund.

WARSAW, Feb. 3 -- The Soviet Union has played a top trump in reinforcing Poland's proposal for a "denuclearized" zone in Central Europe by offering to discuss reduction of foreign troops and conventional armaments in the zone.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The House may consider this week a bill to let into this country more duty-free coarse wool for carpet making.

The Madison Investing Corporation, a mortgage investment concern with offices at 342 Madison Avenue, has been organized by Arthur E. Buehwald. Mr. Buehwald had been vice president of the Sterling Investing Corporation.
PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 3 -Initial indications from the United States' Explorer satellite are that neither cosmic rays nor meteoritic particles pose a problem to travel in the nearer reaches of space.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The stock market reacted to a bouyant mood today and most sections moved strongly ahead under the lead of British Government securities.
Mrs. Fela Topf flew out of the United States Courthouse at Foley Square on wings of elation yesterday. The next stop was the Beekman-Downtown Hospital.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Kansas State lost a 13-point lead in the second half of regulation playing time, then defeated Kansas tonight, 79 -- 75, in double overtime. A crowd of 17,000 saw the Big Eight Conference test.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Marion B. Folsom told Congress today that the United States needed stronger science education more than it did new classrooms.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Temporary Commission, headed by Harrison Tweed, on the Courts laid its final plan for judicial reform before the Legislature tonight.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 3 (UP) -- Charles Starkweather pleaded not guilty today to charges of murdering one of eleven persons he earlier confessed to killing.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 3 -- Allen W. Dulles, Director of The Central Intelligence Agency, called tonight for the removal of "certain legislative bars" to the exchange of nuclear information with this country's allies.
Earnings of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway dropped to $2,927,000 last month from $4,025,000 in January of 1957. On a share basis, net income was 36 cents, compared with 50 cents a year ago.
MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 3 -- A Long Beach housewife was held in $20,000 bail here today as a material witness in the recent slaying of her husband, an airline flight engineer.
The Nation's small business men have themselves to blame for much of their rough sledding in the present recession, according to Wendell B. Barnes, administrator of the Small Business Administration.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- A training school for sea lawyers will hold its first classes here next Friday in anticipation of Chicago's future role as a major port.
Sales and profits of Safeway Stores, Inc., Oakland, Calif., reached new highs last year, acording to an unaudited preliminary report released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, of Delaware, said today owners of one of the country's richest racing stables had received $28,914 for drought relief.
Southern newspaper reaction to violence in the schools of Brooklyn has run from the sharply caustic to the thoughtfully moderate, according to an Associated Press round-up yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The chairman of the President's Science Advisory Committee cautioned today that the successful launching of the Explorer satellite must not lessen the new "sense of urgency" in maintaining scientific supremacy over the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Congress may or may not vote the necessary funds for school construction and scholarships this year, but at least it will not be able to say that it has not had an education on the state of the nation's education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court refused today to hear a New York cap manufacturer's complaint about being barred from Navy contracts after he had pleaded the Fifth Amendment in a Senate investigation.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- A Republican bill to pave the way for modernizing New York City's twenty-two-year-old charter was submitted to the Legislature tonight.

The extensive Warner-Pathe newsreel film library will be placed on public auction today at the film studios, 33 West Sixtieth Street. The footage includes approximately 22,000,000 feet of film depicting important news events dating back to 1910.
PEIPING, Feb. 3 (Reuters) -- A top economic planner held out little hope today that the Chinese people would get a bigger slice of Communist China's economic pie in the next few years.

Sales of the eight major department stores in the metropolitan area last month rose, on the average, 5 per cent above those of January, 1957, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.
DANIEL KUNIN, a Minneapolis-born pianist trained at the Juilliard School, played a debut recital at Town Hall last night in which he gave a very promising account of himself.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 3 -- The Government suspended constitutional guarantees for thirty days last night in an attempt to control a strike of 600 policemen in the southern cities of Arequipa and Cuzco.
