" STUDIO ONE IN HOLLYWOOD" continues its run of pedestrian dramas with built-in happy endings. Last night on Channel 2 it dipped into a bathetic tidbit entitled "The Laughing Willow," by Sumner Locke Elliott. It was soap opera in the large expensive size.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3 -- A new dispute between Walter P. Reuther and powerful units of the old American Federation of Labor created a headache today for labor's high command.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- A committee of district attorneys asked today the creation of a special rackets bureau in the State Police.
A potentially disastrous fire was averted yesterday when a burning lighter -- a barge used in loading and unloading cargo -- was towed away from a ship at Pier 4, Bush Terminal, Brooklyn.

CARNEGIE Recital Hall was crowded last night for the second concert of harpsichord music presented by Sylvia Marlowe with Bernard Greenhouse, 'cellist. It was an unusually knowing audience, including many professional as well as amateur musicians, and their growing enthusiasm as the evening progressed evoked the happiest response from the skilled performers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Soviet Union has invited the United States to send observers to its national elections March 16, when members of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) will be chosen on a single slate.
Remains of one of the earliest Christian churches were recently dug from the sands of western Galilee in Israel, between the Biblical cities of Acre and Tyre.
New York was red in the face yesterday, but it wasn't mad at anyone. It was cold.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn established today that there was still one branch of Congress hospitable to nobly proportioned ladies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court held unanimously today that a union that had not complied with the Taft-Hartley Act might nevertheless, in some circumstances, take part in representation election called by the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The Federal Home Loan Board reported today that its 4,501 member institutions made loans totaling about $10,000,000,000 in 1957. This was about 37 per cent of all home mortgages financed.

A "highly placed official" of the City Housing Authority was questioned for almost two hours at the State Attorney General's office yesterday as tthe agency pressed its inquiry into alleged links between authority employes and the Nassau Management Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the so-called Memphis case, which has disturbed the natural gas industry more than any other judicial ruling in recent years.

National confidence, rising with the successful launching of the Explorer satellite, spilled over into the stock market yesterday. There was no other news to explain the advance of virtually every major group. The leading averages topped their November highs.

DALLAS, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, assailed today what he called President Eisenhower's "mad infatuation with Wall Street money leaders." He said that General Eisenhower's "mishandling of rural power cooperatives is another example of inept leadership."

The fourth and final volume of Sir Winston Churchill's "A History of the English-Speaking Peoples" will be published by Dodd, Mead on March 17, Subtitled "The Great Democracies," the volume begins in 1815 and describes the building of the British Empire in the Reign of Victoria, the events in the Crimean War, the rise of the "Teutonic menace" and the migrations to Canada, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.
FOR the woman about to fly off to Montego Bay, Nice or Athens, there are as many words of advice on what to wear as what to see.
Auto production declined sharply last month from the 1957 pace.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Inger Bjoernbakken of Norway outsped Austria's favored Putzi Frandl today to win the women's world slalom skiing championship. The American entrants finished far out of the running.
City efforts to bring new industry here and to provide bigger sites for crowded old industries will not involve tax abatement or land resale at reduced prices, James Felt declared yesterday.
The city's construction industry was hit yesterday by a strike of drivers who haul materials to building sites and remove debris.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The following skiing conditions were reported to the State Commerce Department today:
Taxicab representatives at a City Hall conference sought yesterday to obtain consideration for cab drivers in the enforcement of the tightened state traffic laws that go into effect April 1.
MIAMI, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Charlie's Song, scoring his first victory in two years, led throughout to win the $5,000 South Atlantic Purse today at Hialeah.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Balenciaga, after first announcing that he would show his spring fashion collection to buyers on Jan. 31, then canceling that date at the last minute, finally opened his doors this afternoon. Buyers, confident that he would eventually show, stayed on here an extra day or two.

PACKING the family off for a trip to Jones Beach in the middle of winter offers one distinct advantage: the traffic is light. Scores of families making the trip on alternate Sunday evenings are attracted by still another inducement: a stunning view of the heavens, and perhaps even a satellite, as interpreted by an amateur astronomer with a sense of the poetic.
" Lucky Dollar," a word-game show based on the old parlor game, "Ghost," is under consideration by the Columbia Broadcasting System as a replacement for Garry Moore's television program.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on the common. The dividend, unchanged from the rate paid last year and in 1956, is payable March 10 to holders of record Feb. 13.

ONE of the familiar figures in the fields of art is the relative of a celebrity. He is often willing to tell us, without brutal coerccion, how much he contributed to a noted kinsman's fame. An almost flawless example of this ruthlessly modest type was Stanislaus Joyce, younger brother of James Joyce, whose posthumous memoir is called "My Brother's Keeper."*

The sorely tried New York Knickerbockers will attempt to snap a four-game losing streak tonight when they meet the St. Louis Hawks in the feature of the National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden.

The names of Isaac Logart of Camaguey, Cuba, and Virgil Akins of St. Louis were drawn from a hat yesterday, and now they are designated to fight each other. Where they will fight, or who will promote a match between them, is a matter yet to be settled.
NORTHPORT, L. I., Feb. 3 -The Coast Guard responded by air, sea and land here today to a fire alarm sounded by its own lifeboat and lighthouse station at Eatons Neck on Long Island Sound.

The "United Arab Republic" proclaimed in Cairo over the week-end must still prove its viability, but there is one aspect of it which must be faced at once. The projected merger of Egypt and Syria marks one more step in President Nasser's drive toward a pan-Arab empire stretching from the Atlantic to the Persian Gulf and controlling Western Europe's lifeblood and life lines -- namely, oil and the arteries through which it flows.

No American city has greater need for a strong and effective Red Cross program than New York. It has 150,000 sons and daughters in the country's armed forces. The city's blood needs and its health and safety training requirements are greater than those of other American communities.

Dr. Anthony M. Palermo, former physician for the New York Giants baseball club, was sentenced yesterday in Federal court to two years in prison for income tax evasion. He also was assessed court costs of $2,000.

American industry will have to produce 40 per cent more in 1962 than it did last year, according to Tomlinson Fort, a vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. He told a group of utility executives and equipment makers in Cincinnati yesterday that both the national plant and the labor force would be inadequate for the task.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Internal Revenue Service has issued a ruling that could be of substantial tax help to some people with large incomes from dividends.
The Duquesne Light Company and subsidiaries achieved gains in operating revenues and net income in 1957 despite the general business decline in the Pittsburgh area, the company reported yesterday.

As a high school teacher of some ten years' standing who is reasonably familiar with conditions both past and present in the public-school system of our city I should like to comment on the educational controversy now raging.
City and school officials met last night and this morning at City Hall and drafted a joint program to combat juvenile crime in the schools.
Cotton futures fell 23 to 45 points ($1.15 to $2.25 a bale) yesterday. The new crop months showed the most weakness.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday he had had no intention of reflecting on the integrity of acting General Sessions Judge John M. Cannella when he criticized a suspended sentence imposed by that judge.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- All the wheat futures declined on the Board of Trade today, while May soybeans and all the corn contracts again reached new low prices for the season.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- Eli Wallach and Don Ameche will co-star in "Albert Anastasia: His Life and Death," to be presented Feb. 27 on the Columbia Broadcasting System "Climax!" show.
KAREL APPEL is a prolific young vanguard painter whose latest canvases are on view at the Gallery Seventy-five, 30 East Seventy-fifth Street. Born in the Netherlands, he became a resident of France.
Automation is proving to be an excellent leavening agent in the baking industry. It is helping to combat rising costs of materials and production and to stabilize prices.
Two Queens Republicans in the Legislature appealed yesterday to Mayor Wagner to prevent the closing of several Queens public schools in June.

AFTER a recent meeting of entomologists here, at which the carpet beetle was described as this city's No. 1 residential destructive pest, carpet manufacturers, newspapers and exterminators, were besieged with phone calls.

COMO, Italy, Feb. 3 -- A six-man Italian team today won the World Contract Bridge Championship for the second successive year. It decisively defeated the United States and Argentina in a ten-day contest.
The private railroad car that August Belmont once rode to race meetings and hunting lodges drew into Weehawken, N. J., yesterday, on its way to becoming a museum piece.
MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 3 -- Detectives began sifting information tonight to identify youthful vandals who set fire to the Maplewood Junior High School early yesterday.

Track and field's closely united clan of sprinters, runners, walkers, hurdlers, jumpers, vaulters and throwers holds its first of five weekly assemblies at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Clock-conscious railbirds will turn out in swarms, as usual.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The State Health Department issued a xvarnmg today against adopting raccoons as pets. The department said that raccoons suffered from a disease whose symptoms were indistinuishable from those of rabies. The department said it had had reports that persons had been seen in parts of Rockland County with raccoons on leashes.

Employes of downtown banking institutions will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross blood program today at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street. It will be the second day of a five-day donation.
William Lombardy of New York scored in the tenth round of the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas at Bogota, according to a report received yesterday through Colombian news sources.

The House Appropriations subcommittee has at last yielded to public clamor and the White House's request and is holding a hearing in Washington this morning on the Brussels Fair. It is now a notorious and unhappy fact that the Soviet Union is going to put on a display of culture and science in Brussels which will make the United States look, like a second-rate power.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Following is the text of a prepared statement made by John Charles Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, before the special subcommittee on legislative oversight:

A syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Stone Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co., is offering for public subscription today 1,000,000 new shares of common stock of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company at $30.75 a share.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The world's fastest flier and two balloonists received today 1957 international Harmon trophies.

The stars of "Long Day's Journey Into Night," Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, will have an additional reason to remember the Eugene O'Neill drama. Last summer they went to Paris to act in the prize-winning play, which represented the United States at the International Drama Festival.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants held today that the Internal Revenue Service had no authority to make taxpayers account for expense money.

Mount Vernon Life Insurance Company of New York, Mount Vernon, N. Y., and Northeastern Life Insurance Company of this city announced yesterday their merger into a new company, operating under the latter's name.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn cleared the former chief investigator of the Suffolk County District Attorney's office yesterday of charges of perjury and bribery in two indictments. A later perjury indictment is still pending.
A Congress seriously concerned with the defense of the United States would no more let the reciprocal trade act be gutted this year than it would ignore the military budget.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3 -- Westchester's two county parks closest to New York and most heavily used by recreationists from the city will no longer be open to nonresidents of Westchester. The parks are Glen Island at New Rochelle and Tibbetts Brook at Yonkers.

Most commodity futures were dull and featureless on the New York exchanges yesterday. Prices closed generally higher, but movements were narrow. Coffee, sugar, potatoes, wool, hides and copper rose; tin and zinc declined, and price movements for cocoa, cottonseed oil and rubber were mixed.
R. H. Macy Co., Inc., became the 310th member of the Hundred Year Association of New York yesterday.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 3 -- There is nothing like a stiff, persistent wind to make a life-long fisherman turn to bowling or even to canasta. If this keeps up a few more days the Yankees around here are going to be dealing in strikes and spares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether certain trademark holders who restrict importation of foreign products with the same trademark are exempt from the anti-trust laws.

Frankie Ryff of the Bronx gained the decision over Tony De Cola, a Brooklyn welterweight, in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Although the fight was savagely contested, especially toward the close, the decision was unanimous.

UNION GROVE, Wis., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Gilbert H. Jackson, National Boxing Association president, said his organization would be satisfied with the eliminations although the draw today seemed to "put it in inverse order."

Long-range missiles are intended to be rough on a possible aggressor, but every now and then they threaten to be rough on the indigenous population. This is apparently the case at Fort Sill, Okla., founded in the late Eighteen Sixties to keep the Indians friendly, but now used for nearly half a century as an artillery range.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 3 -- The career of India's Finance Minister has been placed in serious jeopardy by an investigation into charges that the nationalized Life Insurance Corporation had misused funds.
The scheduled sale of $25,000,000 of exposition building revenue bonds of the Metropolitan Fair and Exposition Authority, Ill., has been postponed indefinitely because of litigation.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 -- High winds today made a new attempt to launch the Navy Vanguard rocket virtually impossible for at least twenty-four hours.
Grafts of blood vessels in the legs of aged patients have saved 75 per cent from amputation in a series of fifty recent cases.
A City Youth Board street club worker was suspended from his job yesterday after he had been arraigned in Bronx Magistrates Court on a charge of possessing heroin.

We the officers and parents of the Parent-Teachers Association of John Marshall Junior High School deplore the continued harassment of the supervisors, the teachers and the children by the representatives of the press, radio and television.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 3 -- Marie Echandi, candidate of the Opposition's National Union party, was virtually certain of gaining the necessary 40 per cent plurality of Sunday's votes to be elected President of Costa Rica.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Governor Harriman suggested today that increased spending for education be financed by higher local taxes.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 3 -- A lawyer accused of taking $22,000 pay from the Board of Education here for teaching duties he did not perform was freed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court extended today the right of seamen to recover damages from their employers for shipboard injuries.

Leaky walls, chipped plaster, rusted elevator mechanisms and other physical shortcomings of Fort Greene Houses in Brooklyn are being remedied in the biggest home fix-it job undertaken by the City Housing Authority.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. delegated young school children yesterday to "carry home" his message on fire prevention. The Commissioner began a fireprevention program in the city's public, parochial and private schools by asking the help of 100 children from two lower East Side schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- John Charles Doerfer thrives on making up his mind.
Scientists worked to refine their calculations of the orbit of the United States' satellite yesterday as it spun into its fourth day of travel around the globe.
The decline in steel production continued last week, and a further drop was scheduled for this week.
Hearings will start in Washington today that could lead to the addition of two large new units to this country's fleet of passenger liners.

CAIRO, Feb. 3 -- Union of the Kingdom of Yemen with new United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria in some sort of federation remained unrealized today. Yemen's Crown Prince, Saif al-Islam Mohammed al-Badr, failed to arrive in Cairo.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Budget Director insisted today that the Administration was "pretty safe" in its estimate of a pick-up in revenues in the fiscal year 1959, beginning July 1.
MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- The Soviet Union has agreed that there will have to be preparation before an East-West heads-of-government meeting can be held.
School days are hardly golden rule days at Manhattan's High School of Commerce.
WARWICK, England, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The American Ambassador, John Hay Whitney, had one winner out of two tries at the Warwick horse race meet today.
The death of Dr. George Goldfarb, principal of Junior High School 210, Brooklyn, points up tragically the needs of our schools and community in dealing with disturbed or delinquent youngsters.
A new nation-wide, nonpartisan plan for obtaining political campaign funds survived yesterday a threat of being scuttled by feuding Republican and Democratic national chairmen.

IT started somewhere in Texas when one housewife lent another her special recipe for chocolate cake. Within a short time, the same recipe had been passed from home to home throughout the Southwest. A cafeteria in St. Louis added the cake to its menu with great success.
The Continental Oil Company last year had net earnings of $46,700,000, or $2.38 a share, L. F. McCollum, president, reported yesterday. This compares with $51,800,000, or $2.65 a share, in 1956.

Charles Dudley Warner's remark, in 1890, that everybody talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it lost part of its validity when the rainmakers started operating some years ago. It will lose even more if the Advisory Committee on Weather Control is right in its forecast that man may learn to control and modify weather to a degree now beyond the imagination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Treasury bill rate dropped sharply this week to the lowest point since mid-1955, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,700,000,000 of the 91-day discount bills was 1.583 per cent, compared with 2.202 per cent last week.

NAHA, Okinawa, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Mayor Saiichi Kaneshi's Red-tinged Leftists won seven new seats in Naha's enlarged City Assembly today, threatening new trouble for United States rule on Okinawa. The Mayor and his supporters want the island, the main Far Eastern base of the United States, returned to Japan.
Paul Robeson has asked the State Department for a "limited" passport to appear in the summer with one of England's most celebrated companies -- the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre at Stratford-on-Avon.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Conservative party turned angrily on its Laborite tormentors in Parliament today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission angrily denied today that he was guilty of any wrongdoing in discharging his duties as head of one of the Government's big administrative agencies.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Australia's Frank Sedgman upset Pancho Gonzales, 7 -- 5, 3 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, today and qualified to meet Tony Trabert in the final of the $16,800 White City professional tennis tournament.
SPRING is not just around the corner. It is here, despite the groundhog's pessimistic forecast two days ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Senate approved unanimously today a $1,410,000,000 emergency defense appropriations bill.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- One of the biggest police scandals in the history of British law enforcement moved today into the No. 1 courtroom at the Old Bailey, London's Central Criminal Court.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 3 -- Four West New York police officials were indicted today by the Hudson County Grand Jury for an alleged bribe offered on behalf of Carmen...

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 3 -- The Junior League of Montclair will sponsor a benefit film preview on Feb. 18 at the Wellmont Theatre here. Proceeds will go to the Camp Madeleine Mulford Building Fund, a project set up by the Essex Mountain Girl Scout Council to raise money for a new Girl Scout camp near Blairstown.
HAVANA, Feb. 3 -- President Fulgencio Batista signed a decree today lifting censorship of press and radio in Oriente Province, center of revolutionary activities against the Government.

George Alpert said yesterday that he was looking forward to that day when he could relinquish the office of president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. But it would not be to a dissident stockholders group that is challenging his management, and which, he said, seeks to "drain $10,000,000 from the company treasury."
The recession has caused Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy to ask for a $43,619,560 increase in his departmental budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 4--Mario Echandi Jimenez, the candidate of the National Union party, appeared certain today to be the winner of Sunday's Presidential election.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 4 -Eight Lutheran denominations representing more than 5,000,000 Churchgoers were called upon today to scrap piecemeal efforts toward unity in favor of a single, all-inclusive church.
The Rev. Dr. John M. Coleman, the first Negro appointed to the Board of Education, has submitted his resignation to Mayor Wagner. He said he had been ill.

Two events in the Wall Street money market this week point up the degree to which the recent reversal of the Federal Reserve's restrictive monetary policy, less than three months ago, has left its impress on the nation's interest rate structure.

COLFAX, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP) -- A Greyhound bus and an empty tank truck-trailer sideswiped last night in the High Sierra near Donner Summit. Two persons were killed and at least twenty-two were injured.

Events today: Peter M. Fyfe, organist, St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, 12:30 P. M.; "Die Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera, 7:45; Cleveland Orchestra, George Szell conducting, Paul Badura-Skoda, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
The Unexcelled Chemical Corporation has acquired the Jasco Aluminum Products Corporation of New Hyde Park, L. I., for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock.
MOSCOW, Feb. 4 -- A political miracle -- that is just about the only way to describe what has happened to Comrade A. Mkrtchyan down in Armenia.

A Briton was in New York yesterday to warn a group of stockholders of "leaner times than anything we have experienced for some years." He was Sir Ronald L. Prain, chairman of Rhodesian Selection Trust, Ltd, Roan Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., and some affiliates generally called the Rhodesian Selection Trust Group -- major suppliers of copper to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission testified today that he recently had repaid an Oklahoma City television station the $165.12 it had given him three years ago for an airplane trip he never made.
DAN, Israel, Feb. 4 -- The Israeli police returned to a border tinderbox today.

NEITHER Richard Strauss nor Claude Debussy lost the mastery of his craft in the late stages of his career. The mysterious essence of their genius might evade their grasp, but they could make a brave display. Even if the music was not their best, they could evoke moods and colors that can still provide a cool and distant enchantment.

The recent announcement of the United States Navy that yeast would be placed in its test satellites to determine the effects of space travel on life has more immediacy now that the Army's Jupiter-C has launched an earth satellite into orbit.
MIAMI, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The indictment of thirty persons on charges of conspiring to undertake a military expedition against President Fulgencio Batista was announced today.
TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- The proceedings in Japan's Diet (Parliament) were at a standstill today as the Socialists boycotted committee sessions the lower house.
How the consumer views the business downturn may determine its depth and length, two New York City banks conclude in their monthly business letters.
CAIRO, Feb. 4 -- A rule as absolute as that of any Arab monarch is to be established for the new United Arab Republic during its transition from two sovereign states to one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower affirmed today a decision of the Civil Aeronautics Board to deny Pan America World Airways the right to serve Seattle and Portland on its Great Circle route to Tokyo.

We wish to protest most emphatically the attitude of the Committee on Finance and Budget of the Board of Education toward the representatives of civic organizations and parent groups who testified on Jan. 27 on the tentative budget estimate for 1958-59.

Following is the text of the Board of Education's statement yesterday on juvenile delinquency in the schools. It is an outgrowth of two meetings held Monday at the request of Mayor Wagner between city and school officials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -The Soviet Union's new Ambassador to Washington, Mikhail A. Menshikov, will arrive Thursday aboard a Soviet TU104 jet airliner.

ROME, Feb. 4 (UP) -- A charge that the Italian Olympic Committee is "a thriving Red colony" set sports officials to squabbling with politicians in Italy today about preparations for the 1960 Olympic Games in Rome.
Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney is seeking any evidence of conflict of interest among employes of the Bureau of Real Estate of the Board of Estimate.

Oscar Panno of Argentina, leading from the start of the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas at the Club Militar in Bogota, strengthened his hold on first place by winning his adjourned game from the tenth round, according to a report received yesterday through Colombian news sources.

MALE reactions to the chemise silhouette are often negative or sarcastic. One man who might be expected to agitate against the "sack" shape is showing considerable restraint. He is Eric Kreisel, whose wholesale concern, Colony Accessories, sells belts to department stores all over the country.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Wednesday, Feb. 5 -- The second attempt to launch an earth satellite in the Navy's Vanguard project ended in spectacular failure here shortly after 2:30 A. M. today.

In a richly deserved gesture of tribute Dartmouth College is paying honor tonight to its former president, Dr. Ernest Martin Hopkins, who became 80 years old last Nov. 6. At Dartmouth Dr. Hopkins won admiration for his open-mindedness, his definition of educational aims, his administrative skill and his warm personal leadership.

IF cerebral writers with an appeal limited (for the most part) to literary intellectuals, such as James and Melville, can enjoy critical and popular revivals, why shouldn't the most popular storyteller who ever lived? Certainly the way is being made straight for a new interest in the historical romances of Alexandre Dumas pere.

Nine concerts of the Boston "Pops" Orchestra and six concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., will be broadcast live to New Yorkers over radio station WQXR from May 3 through Aug. 9.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations appealed tonight for more attention to the rural economies of the underdeveloped nations.

Dealers cut the yields on commercial paper yesterday by three-eighths of 1 per cent, the largest reduction in interest rates paid investors since the Nineteen Thirties. Commercial paper is the short-term obligations of businesses sold in the open market.
The clouds that recently obscured the advertising accounts of several airlines cleared yesterday following an unexpected development.
The program of Union Settlement at 237 East 104th Street will be furthered as a result of the March 25 performance of the motion picture "South Pacific" at the Criterion Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Economists for two business-oriented organizations criticized today the President's economic report. They said it had not come to grips with the problems of inflation or recession.
A Eugene O'Neill Scholarship Fund will be established at the Yale University School of Drama with proceeds from the local world premiere of the film version of "Desire Under the Elms."
MIAMI, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A hard freeze threatening the entire citrus industry anew and every plant in the farmlands was predicted for Florida tomorrow.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The Legislature received today a bipartisan bill designed to reduce the cost of the institutional care of mentally retarded persons.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 4 -- Groups of students and newsmen accused certain Ambassadors today of having supported the Dec. 15 plebiscite that was to return Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez to the Presidency for five years.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 4 -Mrs. Priscilla Rose remained in the Nassau County jail today when she was unable to post a bond for her release. She was held in $20,000 bail yesterday as a material witness in her husband's death.

The Soviets have now made one slight and qualified concession in the East-West debate about a new "summit" meeting. They agree to some advance preparation through diplomatic channels, as urged by the West. But they do so only on two conditions.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 4 (AP) -Toivo Salonen of Finland captured the 500 and 3,000-meter all-around events today for top honors in the international speed skating competition.
Even for trained observers the United States' first artificial satellite is proving extremely difficult to see.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 (AP) -The formation of a nine-man board of trustees to carry out a chemistry research program in racing was announced today by D. Eldred Rinehart, president of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners.
FORT CHURCHILL, Man., Feb. 4 (UP) -- Rocket scientists fired an Aerobee-Hi rocket to a height of 147 miles today, the eighth launching from the subarctic base this year.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The Republican leadership in the Legislature decided today to send back to Governor Harriman the unemployment insurance bill he twice vetoed last year.
CHINO, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP) -"If I return that money there are lots of other people who are going to have to return the drought relief money they got."
ALBANY, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The State Senate gave unanimous approval today to a resolution urging that St. Lawrence Seaway tolls be set at a level that would pay for the waterway in fifty years.
A Brooklyn judge warned yesterday that if drastic action was not taken immediately the law of the jungle would prevail in some of the city's public schools.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Steve Allen is preparing for Hollywood-originated shows on the next two Sundays over the National Broadcasting Company television network.
Sixty-three men, women and children were killed in traffic accidents in the city during January compared with forty-nine in the same month of 1957.

Brendan McCann, a young man from St. Bonaventure College who has had little opportunity to perform because of inexperience in the professional ranks, picked last night to stamp himself a pro as he sparker the New York Knickerbockers to a thrilling 120-to-ll6 victory over the St. Louis Hawks at Madison Square Garden.
WANT your portrait done, mister? In crayon'"

Cutting down trees or poles alongside highways will reduce the number of severely disabling thigh bone fractures in automobile accidents, it was suggested yesterday at the meeting of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons.

No "crash" program for dealing with juvenile delinquency, no single preliminary report drafted overnight by city and educational officials will find a panacea for the deep troubles that afflict our schools in New York. But it is an encouraging development when the city administration's interest is actively enlisted for a partnership with the Board of Education in a search for solutions.

A. H. Raskin's recent report that "Mayor Wagner is considering the issuance, in the next few weeks, of an executive order giving civil service unions many of the rights enjoyed by unions in private industry" is very good news indeed for New York City employes.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Stock market prices advanced modestly today, influenced by strength in British Government securities.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- deLasseps S. Morrison won a fourth straight four-year term as Mayor of New Orleans today.

A clearly defined objective for thoroughgoing court reform is now before the New York Legislature. The time has come for all those who believe in the cause to unite and to press on with vigor to attain it.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 4 -- Judge Learned Hand said tonight that the power of the courts as final interpreters of the Constitution had been essential to the American system of government.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 4 (UP) -- A new director was elected today to each of the principal boards of the Gannett newspapers.
BOSTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Baseball writers today failed to vote any new members into the Hall of Fame for the first time since 1950.
The study and treatment of mental and emotional disorders will be undertaken under a $10,000,000 bequest made by Anne Parrish, the novelist, who died five months ago.

Robert Muczynski, an American composer born in Chicago in 1929, gave a piano recital of his own music last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. On his program were a Sonatina, five Sketches, the Variations on a Theme of Tcherepnin, six Preludes and the Sonata No. 1.
An end of "demagoguery" in the fight against juvenile delinquency was urged yesterday by Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The head of the United States Lines asked the House Merchant Marine Committee today to approve legislation authorizing the financing of a sister ship to the liner United States.

A merger agreement between Julius Kayser Co. and the Chester H. Roth Company, Inc., was announced yesterday by Abraham Feinberg, president of Kayser, following approval by directors. The transaction embraces the assets of the two companies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -The Army has acknowledged to Congress that it plans a 44,000-man cut in the strength of the National Guard.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 5 -Indonesian rebel leaders have notified President Sukarno, who is in Japan, of an insurgent plan for reforms in the government of the island republic, a top Indonesian Army officer said today.

Bloodmobiles of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today will visit the McGrawHill building, 330 West Forty-second Street, and the Belock Instrument Corporation, 111-01 Fourteenth Avenue, College Point, Queens.
The atomic age has reverted to high school physics and the pinhole camera, according to an announcement yesterday by General Electric Company.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Two Manhattan legislators reported today that 31,000 New York City families would pay $2 to $3 more a month for utility service if the Consolidated Edison Company was permitted to end wholesale billing.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Supporters of legislation to permit shopkeepers who observe another Holy Day to open on Sunday received some encouragement today from the Republican legislative leadership.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -Senator Herman E. Talmadge and Senator Jacob K. Javits clashed verbally in the Senate today over outbreaks of violence in Brooklyn schools.
An inquiry into the possession and use of weapons by criminals and juvenile delinquents was opened yesterday by the City Council.
Two clinics set up by an American physician in the jungles of Laos have sparked a project for private United States medical aid to underdeveloped areas.
" Parkinson's Law" comes to mind these days as the Federal independent regulatory agencies come under Congressional fire. Its origin may have been British, but its application is obviously universal.
GHARDAIA, Algeria, Jan. 29 -- The Mzabites are still running from the newer advances of civilization, as they have since the seventh century.
Western Union Telegraph Company's earnings were third highest in history last year. But they were more than $1,000,000 below the record level of 1956.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 4 -Ceylonese celebrated the tenth anniversary of their independence today with religious services at Buddhist temples and Christian churches.
OMAHA, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A radio track meet between Omaha University and a Russian university has been proposed by two Nebraska Congressmen.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Governor Harriman announced today seventy-two appointments to his committee to end polio by vaccination.
Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless and prices moved in narrow ranges.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Governor Harriman recommended today that membership in the Communist party be made prima facie evidence of disqualification for state employment.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 4 -- The President's Committee on Scientists and Engineers urged today that a greater share of the national income be devoted to education and science.

Directors of the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation yesterday declared the first dividend on the common stock in four and a half years. The company reported 1957 earnings of $6,607,253, compared with $8,648,358 in 1956.

MIAMI, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The forty-three-foot yawl Rob Roy, with a fifteen-mile-an-hour cold northwest wind filling her sails, thrust ahead of a fleet of nineteen yachts at the start of the twentieth annual Miami-to-Nassau race today.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Feb. 5 -- The Project Vanguard team was thrown early this morning from momentary elation to long-faced gloom by its second failure to launch a small test satellite.

Goodson-Todman Productions, Inc., producer of television programs, has leased a floor in the Seagram Building that is nearing completion at 375 Park Avenue at Fifty-second Street. The lessee now is at 41 East Fiftyseventh Street and will move to Park Avenue in April.

A 36-year-old certified public accountant was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a forgery charge in connection with the theft of more than $30,000. The accountant, Leon Rubin of 40 Elliott Place, the Bronx, was held in $5,000 bail by Magistrate Reuben Levy.
Carter L. Burgess has been elected president of the American Machine and Foundry Company. He will serve under Morehead Patterson, chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower was suffering from a "slight cold," but that it was not serious enough to disrupt his activities.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Feb. 4 -- The two divergent groups that have split the county Democratic party here for more than a year showed signs of healing their rift tonight.

SYDNEY Australia, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Frank Sedgman of Australia completed a popular triumph in the Ampol professional tennis tournament today when he staged a brilliant comeback to beat Tony Trabert of Cincinnati in the final round, 3 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 4 -- A historic gristmill that has withstood the elements for 265 years at the edge of Manhasset Bay at Plandome Manor is at the half-way mark in its metamorphosis from mill to a modern-day home.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A team of Johns Hopkins scientists is detecting lung cancer with a cough-producing sulphur dioxide spray dispensed from a capsule much like the household hold bug bomb.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A group of young Foreign Service career officers -- chosen by lot from a group of seventy-seven nominated for their first assignments -- underwent critical questioning today at an open meeting of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The Tweed Commission's latest plan for state-wide court reorganization got a mixed reception today.

A syndicate of investors headed by A. S. Soloff has purchased the five-story apartment house for sixty-two families at 223-27 Cypress Avenue, the Bronx. The property, which contains seven stores, was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $180,000.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- A smashing Conservative victory tonight ended the bitterest, most personal debate of post-war parliamentary history.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 4 -The former Prime Minister of the Maldive Islands was forced out of office in December by a hostile crowd that surrounded his palace, according to reports circulating in Ceylon. Ibrahim Ali Didi was officially reported to have resigned because of ill health.
The strike of truck drivers against the construction industry passed the second day yesterday with no indication of a quick settlement.

A tariff authority asserted yesterday that without effective Administration authority to negotiate new trade agreements, this country would be unable to protect its export interest in the European Common Market.
The Board of Education, with Mayor Wagner's approval, announced yesterday its program to deal with juvenile delinquency in the public schools.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Two Republican legislators proposed today that the state ban the construction of gasoline stations along limited-access highways.
DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther said today he has appealed to President Eisenhower to call a national conference on "the problems of unemployment and recession."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -A Ford Motor Company executive today called the similarity in Big Three auto manufacturers' prices the "essence of competition."

Heat pumps are now believed to be capable of warming commercial and industrial buildings in regions where temperatures reach as low as 20 degrees below zero. This was reported yesterday at the winter meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at the Statler Hotel.

HARRISBURG, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad was ordered today by the Public Utility Commission to abandon plans for wholesale passenger train service curtailment scheduled to go into effect Feb. 16.
FRED SCHMERTZ was excited as he talked into the phone. There's nothing especially strange about that because the effervescent director of the Millrose Games always is excited when he talks.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The three haute couture collections presented here today presage a spring of grays, neutrals and pale colors. The gray look, established by Michael this morning, switched to beige and brown at Mattli but was solidly reinstalled later at Ronald Paterson.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The mystic word in Europe these days is "'disengagement." Broadly speaking, disengagement means relaxing of EastWest tensions by military neutralization of a zone in the Continent's center. This, it is held, might lessen chances of nuclear war between Russia and the United States.
The officer responsible for the security of the Port of New York for close to four years retired yesterday. He is Capt. Frank K. Johnson of the Coast Guard.
IN case any of our business men are tired, they can count on Jose Ferrer. His production of "Oh Captain!", which opened at the Alvin last evening, will not strain their minds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Naval Research Laboratory issued a new timetable today giving times and places at which signals from the satellite Explorer may be picked up tomorrow. All times are Eastern standard.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON Feb. 4 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey asked President Eisenhower today to open a more limited and more positive approach to the Soviet Union on disarmament.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -The Vertol Aircraft Corporation announced today plans to acquire Allied Research Associates, Inc., of Boston, and confirmed reports that it has been negotiating for a possible merger with the Bell Aicraft Corporation of Buffalo.
PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The Government, and the Socialist party in particular, came under rightwing attack in the National Assembly today for alleged political favoritism in promoting army officers.

Edward R. Murrow's interview with former President Harry S. Truman will be repeated tomorrow evening over the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network. It will be broadcast by station WCBS here from 10 to 11 o'clock and at an earlier hour in other cities.
HOUSTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A boxing enthusiast has suggested that Joe Brown of New Orleans defend his world lightweight title on a barge in the Gulf of Mexico.

IN a few weeks or so the wreckers will come. They will tear down the two venerable brick and brownstone mansions that have stood hard by the First Presbyterian Church in West Twelfth Street for more than 100 years.

The Wellington Fund ended 1957 with net assets of $604,578,038, against $578,756,593 on Dec. 31, 1956, the previous yearend high. On a per-share basis, however, net assets slipped to $11.56 a share, on 52,309,759 shares outstanding, from $12.99 on 44,558,207 shares outstanding a year earlier.

The eighth annual international Grand Prix of Sebring, Fla., is scheduled for Saturday, March 22. This is America's contribution to the world championship for sports cars. It is, therefore, the outstanding race on a list of hundreds to be run in the United States in 1958.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Plans for the San Francisco Giants' new stadium were approved by the club's president, Horace Stoneham, today and forwarded to city officials. City approval is expected within a week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Following is the official guest list for tonight's science-military state dinner at the White House:
The pricing machinery of the market absorbing new issues of local government bonds was taxed yesterday to an extent exceeding any comparable period within the memory of bond men here.

MIAMI, Feb. 4 -- Christopher T. Chenery decided to run his 3-year-old colt Yemen in a $5,000 race at Hialeah today instead of in tomorrow's $20,000 added Bahamas Stakes over the same seven-furlong course. The owners of the eleven Bahamas entrants must be delighted about the Chenery decision.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 4 -- The head of the scandal-scarred International Union of Operating Engineers was reported today to be planning to quit within thirty days.
For the last few months, groups of New York policemen have been testing their marksmanship on a complex new pistol target that requires judgment as well as good aim.

As a practicing school man I wish to thank you for the editorial "Crime in the Schools." To my mind, yours is the first voice of reason that has been heard in our newspapers for some time in the matter of delinquency in the schools. It has become fashionable these days for publicity seekers and scapegoat seekers to have a field day in throwing brickbats at schools.

HAMBURG, Germany, Jan. 31 -- For reasons of geography and economics, the charges that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was preventing German reunification, made by his political enemies, have struck a responsive note here.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 4 -- The apparent Presidentelect, Mario Echandi Jimenez, and the incumbent President, Jose Figueres, have this in common: They are both of pure Spanish descent.
Gil McDougald, the Yankees' most versatile player, had his first salary discussion yesterday with Lee MacPhail, the assistant general manager, and left the Bombers' office without signing.

Sales and rentals of the American Can Company in 1957 passed the billion-dollar mark for the first time in history, William C. Stolk, president, reported in the preliminary annual statement yesterday. Earnings, however, declined below the 1956 level.
Two physicians have declared that there is no medical evidence that a suspended Youth Board street club worker used heroin, as charged by the police.

Issues of new securities amounting to more than $33,000,000 are being offered to investors today. Utility stock, bonds and railroad debt securities, all won at competitive bidding by investment banking groups yesterday, consist of the following:

IRVINGTON, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- Mrs. Burnham Bowden, president of the Westchester Vassar Alumnae Club has announced that the group will not have a benefit scholarship fund-raising party this year. The $3,000 scholarship goal will be met from proceeds from the sale of maple syrup, maple cream and maple candy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -The Navy announced today a one-third slash in its pilot training rate because of cutbacks in aircraft, personnel and bases.

Any program for survival in the nuclear age involves sacrifice, hard work, huge costs, difficult judgments and imaginative research. No defense was offered yesterday at a Waterfront Commission hearing into the loan shark activities of a hiring agent and a longshoreman while they were employed on Pier 90, Hudson River and West Fiftieth Street.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 4 -- Three elderly Serbs, accused of a conspiracy to overthrow the Tito regime, were sent to prison today for terms of four to eight and a half years.
The Very Rev. James A. Pike was elected yesterday to be the next Bishop of the protestant Episcopal Diocese of California.
Abraham Straus is at the moment looking dreamily into space. The Brooklyn department store opened an exposition of rocketry and satellites yesterday.

United States Attorney Paul W. Williams told a Federal Court jury yesterday that the Government would prove that Harry Stromberg, a bigtime gambler and racketeer, had financed a $20,000,000-a-year international narcotics ring from 1954 through 1956.

A look at the great changes in Asia during the last fifty years is given by Ian Thomson in his "The Rise of Modern Asia." Mr. Thomson was born in China and has travelled widely in Asia. He surveys the continent's history from the beginning of the century to the end of World War II, giving portraits of such prominent Asians as Sun Yat-Sen, Kemal Ataturk and Chiang Kai-shek.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- Sterle is a name for women who admire imaginative and exquisitely fashioned real jewelry. Expected to be on sale in New York in the near future, these rings, clips, bracelets and necklaces are in a class by themselves.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Government settled today its four-year-old antitrust suit against the United Fruit Company. Under the terms the company agreed to create a competitor in the banana industry.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The gold and dollar reserves held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area rose last month by $131,000,000.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Scattered light demand on a variety of influences pulled most grain futures prices out of another slide today on the Board of Trade.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved up 6 to 15 points (30 to 75 cents a bale) in quiet trading yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A change of some importance has come over the diplomatic corps in Washington. Many of the intelligent and experienced ambassadors here are beginning to laugh at Premier, Nikolai A. Bulganin's interminable letterwriting offensive.

TRENTON, Feb. 4 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner indicated today that Grover C. Richman Jr. might be named acting State Attorney General pending a solution of the impasse with the State Senate on the reappointment of Mr. Richman to a full term.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Feb. 4 (Canadian Press) -- A return to work began this afternoon for 6,000 British Columbia pulp and paper workers. They had been on strike since Nov. 14.

Once again the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve System are working at cross-purposes. The Federal Reserve Board recently lowered the rediscount rate to 2 3/4 per cent from its 3 1/2 per cent high of a few months ago. Presumably further action will be taken to loosen up the money market.
HAVANA, Feb. 4 -- Rebels in Oriente Province led by Senor Castro increased their activities in the last few days in and near their Sierra Maestra stronghold.
The Erie and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroads disclosed yesterday that they had rejected a proposal to establish a commuter pool with Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.

The proprietor of a restaurant and bar in Greenwich Village that features poetry contests, lectures, charades and open forums was found guilty yesterday of violating the Administrative Code by failing to have a cabaret license.

A LIGHT note in the week's art exhibitions now and then provides a bit of welcome relief. This time it is furnished by the drawings of Eugene Ludins, who has hitherto been known chiefly through his landscape paintings around Woodstock or of the vineyard on the Mississippi levee country.
PALM BEACH, Feb. 4 (AP) -National Hockey League playerowner talks were held tonight in strict secrecy.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 4 (AP) -- St. Paul residents today were reading the first issue of The Pioneer Press since Dec. 17 after the week-end settlement of a strike by members of three unions.
Lower money rates, Washington forecasts of a business upturn and alleged "buy signals" in the action of the market itself kept stocks rising yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the issuance of a foreign fraud order against seven companies and persons involved in the promotion of Cuban oil stock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--President Eisenhower has ordered a special study to resolve the growing issue of civilian versus military control of prospective assaults on outer space.
The Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company placed in force during 1957 a record $643,037,747 in new insurance, Malcolm Adam, president, has reported.
TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 4--Fordham University, rowing its first varsity crew race since 1916, defeated Tampa University by one length today over a one-mile course on the Hillsboro River.
Dr. Louis M. Hacker made clear yesterday that he was resigning as dean of Columbia University's School of General Studies because he could not accept proposals to change the character of the school.

PATE MAISON, invariably one of the appetizers at French restaurants here, differs immensely in taste, texture, and, most seriously, in quality. An excellent version of this seasoned liver paste is that served at the Baccara Restaurant, 23 East Forty-fifth Street.
Three new films will open today at first-run theatres.

The elections for President and the Legislative Assembly in Costa Rica were a model of what democratic elections can and should be. This was a splendid example for Latin America as a whole and one that we could expect from such a democracy as Costa Rica and such a confirmed champion of liberty as President Jose Figueres.

The formation of a Broadway producing outfit is being discussed by John Osborne and Tony Richardson, well-known author and director, respectively. International in scope, their operation calls for an exchange of productions between London and New York.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire of Lake Park, Fla., and Grace DeMoss of St. Augustine, Fla., tied for the medal with 6 over par 76's today on the Palm Beach Country Club's frigid fairways in the qualifying round of the fortieth annual Palm Beach women's amateur golf tournament.
ALBANY, Feb. 4--The Cities Committee of the Assembly endorsed a bill today to enable Mayor Wagner to bypass the New York City Council in setting up a charter revision commission.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -President Eisenhower and former President Harry S. Truman are scheduled to speak at a two-day nonpartisan conference on foreign aid and trade here late this month.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Perpetuation of the present East-West division of Europe and military neutralization of Central Europe are emerging as the two chief objectives of the Soviet Government at the proposed summit meeting.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Feb. 4 (AP) -Seven star witnesses in a grand jury's inquiry into the Apalachin gangland convention last Nov. 14 appeared before the jury today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Two books set against the background of Nazi-occupied Europe figured today in the plans of Hollywood moviemakers.
Another top official of the Nassau Management Company yesterday refused to answer questions regarding the real estate concern. He is Kelsey Volner, executive vice president.
STUART, Fla., Feb. 4 -- E. H. Madison hooked and lost a pelican today, misplaced a reindeer and got the City of Stuart into something of a swivet.
A penguin, leaving its native habitat far behind, has penetrated deep into the Antarctic hinterland, headed almost straight for the South Pole.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Dr. William R. Sears of Cornell University said today that electromagnetic fields offered a possible means of returning satellites to earth and accelerating rockets to tremendous speeds.

The sale of the vast WarnerPathe newsreel film library, which was put up for public auction yesterday, was deferred when the top bid turned out to be only $27,000. The name of the top bidder was not disclosed.

CAIRO, Feb. 5 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser described to an applauding Egyptian National Assembly today the framework of the new United Arab Republic.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Foreign oil companies may be caught in the middle if the rebellious forces on Sumatra set up a counter-government to the central regime on Java.

A convenience food known as Pan o' Gold buttered fried chicken was introduced at a luncheon yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Packaged by Armour Co. in a rigid foil pan, the item consists of a twoand-one-half-pound chicken cut up for "oven frying."

BALTIMORE, Feb. 5 (AP) -Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower advanced today an education program to combat what he called a tendency toward decreased quality, "if not mediocrity," in the nation's secondary school system.

THE essential difference between Conrad Marca-Relli's recent collage paintings at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue, and his former work lies in the artist's altered attitude toward picture space.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Undefeated Old Pueblo once again proved himself the best of California's Kentucky Derby hopefuls today but he was lucky to escape the furious stretch run of the sensational chestnut, Silky Sullivan, in the $67,250 California Breeder's Champion Stakes.

Senator Mike Mansfield's move into the Algerian policy field yesterday will not cause the sensation which his colleague Senator Kennedy aroused last summer. The latter made a flaming speech in the Senate on July 2 calling on the United States to use its good offices to solve the Algerian conflict.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Selective demand brought minor gains to many leading industrials on the stock market today. The firmest section continued to be British Government securities.
Haila Stoddard and Paul Crabtree, in association with Marilyn Shapiro, will present on Broadway in March "Plaintiff in a Pretty Hat," an English comedy by Hugh and Margaret Williams.

Regardless of the weather, this spring promises to be a bright one. More women will answer the call to the colors -- in spring coats, suits and dresses. Navy, blue and gray are receiving a run for their money by colors in bright fresh tones.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's foreign trade deficit dropped to $693,700,000 last year from the peak of $842,300,000 in 1956 as exports rose slightly and imports eased from the record high.

A concert of sacred music by Igor Stravinsky will comprise the Service for Evensong at St. Thomas' Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street, on March 2, the second Sunday in Lent.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The new Bonn proposal to break the deadlock on the financing of British forces in West Germany met a coldly unfavorable reaction in British Governmental circles tonight.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Favored Toni Sailer of Austria won the giant slalom today in the world ski championships, virtually ending the chances of Bud Werner, America's top hope, for the title of world's best skier.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Several major changes in the state's banking laws were proposed today in eight bills submitted to the Legislature. Most of the bills are direct outgrowths of the First National City Bank's plan to set up a holding company to acquire the County Trust Company of Westchester.
The Metropolitan Regional Council voted support in principle yesterday for a permanent interstate agency to meet area transportation needs.

THERE is no welcome mat outside the door to the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown. This is as it should be. Once the baseball pantheon loses its exclusiveness, its loses its value, and becomes merely a hangout for the old-timers. So there are no regrets over the fact that the Baseball Writers Association failed to elect any candidates in the balloting that was revealed Tuesday.
Columbia University announced yesterday the resignation of Dr. Lawrence H. Chamberlain as dean of Columbia College, effective at the end of the academic year.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Kim II Sung, North Korean Premier, called tonight for the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Korea and elections to unify the divided nation.

" THEY CAME TO CORDURA,"* a novel by Glendon Swarthout, is an allegory of human valor told in the terse, tense Western style. It has a variety of faults -- Mr. Swarthout seems to feel that nothing succeeds like excess -- but readability is decidedly not one of these. What he set out to do he does: he maintains an air of bloodcurdling excitement from start to finish.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 5 -- Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal, president of the governing junta, said tonight that present arrangements with foreign oil companies would be preserved.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Since 1954, coal production in the Republic of Korea has more than doubled, the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency reported yesterday from Seoul. According to the report, production in the Governmentowned Dai Han Coal Corporation mines rose from 667,631 tons in 1954 to more than 1,520,000 tons last year.
Directors of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation yesterday declared a first-quarter dividend of 40 cents a share. The payment will be made March 31 to holders of record March 17.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Twentieth Century-Fox confirmed today acquisition of film rights to "Beloved Infidel: The Education of a Woman," to be published in the spring by Henry Holt Co.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 6 -President Sukarno will be asked to continue as titular head of the Indonesian Government under the regime planned by dissident East Indonesians and Sumatrans, it was stated here today.

George F. Kennan, former American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, has written two more books that will be published soon. One will be the second of three volumes of his "Soviet - American Relations, 1917-1920."

The police last night arrested seven men, two women and three juvenile offenders in a series of burglaries in Jamaica, Queens. Seven schools and a church were among the score or more places looted of about $10,000 in goods since November.

Burlington Industries, Inc., one of the nation's largest textile producers, reported yesterday an increase in earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 28, despite a drop in sales from the corresponding period of 1956.
