WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The United States has pigeonholed three Bulgarian proposals in the last two years to resume diplomatic relations, State Department officials said today.

THE curriculum provided by local television for the home student was further broadened yesterday morning. After English Literature with Prof. Floyd Zulli Jr. of New York University, at 7 o'clock over Channel 2, the set owner now can study Foreign Policy with Prof. John G. Stoessinger of Hunter College at 11:30 A. M. Wednesdays over Channel 11.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Upsets marked first-round match play today in the fortieth annual women's Palm Beach golf tournament.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 5 -- Ho Chi Minh, the bearded President of Communist North Vietnam, arrived in New Delhi today. He received precisely the same welcome accorded to his countryman and mortal enemy, President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, last November.
Five chairmen of the twentieth annual campaign of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York will start soliciting funds today in the organization's national drive for $208,424,000.

The Times of Jan. 24 contained two references to problems of education that confront us today: teacher pay and teacher recruitment. The statements are noteworthy in that they reflect a sharp dichotomy in efforts to resolve them by two of our leaders of commerce and industry, James C. Worthy and Charles H. Silver.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Accidents in the United States killed 94,800 persons and injured 9,500,000 in 1957. The total cost was $11,800,000,000.
Missile developers have ready answers for those who wonder how the long count-downs in Florida tests square with the notion of pushbutton warfare.

Irving I. Goldenberg, an investing client of Samuel Hollander, attorney, bought the building containing twenty-five apartments and four stores at 747 Melrose Avenue, northeast corner of East 156th Street, the Bronx. The property is assessed at $68,000. It was sold in a deal negotiated by Adrian H. Muller Son, broker.

" The Gisele MacKenzie Show," a musical series that has been afflicted by backstage discord, may be terminated in April. It is televised on Saturdays from 9:30 to 10 P. M. by the National Broadcasting Company.
MIAMI, Feb. 5 -- Fred W. Hooper's team of Olymar and Alhambra beat the Calumet Farm's team of Kentucky Pride and Tim Tam in the $25,425 Bahamas Stakes at the Hialeah track today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Jackie Cooper will take time out from his regular series, "The People's Choice," to star in a "Studio One in Hollywood" drama.

A 19-year-old Harlem peddler who ignored forty-six summonses while selling fruit and vegetables without a license from a horse-drawn wagon was sentenced yesterday to seventyfour days in jail and a $395 fine. If he does not pay the fine, he must serve eighty-nine additional days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -Senator Mike Mansfield, saying that "time is running out for the Western powers in North Africa," recommended today that thee United States intervene to help end the Algerian conflict.
The Court of Special Sessions ruled yesterday that gravity knives were in the same category as switchblade knives, and their sale or possession was a violation of the Sullivan law.

BEAUMONT, Tex., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Dr. V. A. Kalichevsky, an internationally known chemical engineer, author and lecturer, was found dead of a gunshot would at his home last night. Justice of the Peace Horace Blades ruled that the wound had been self-inflicted.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly yesterday, 4 points lower to 29 higher, with the far months showing the most strength. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Business and industry called today for a complete revision of the state's "little Wagner" Act to "bring it into conformity with current labor-management problems.

The New York State coffers were swelled by $32,767,271.49 from harness racing tracks in 1957. The Harness Racing Commission's annual report, which disclosed the record figure, cooed over this good fortune and over other aspects of the year's trotting and pacing activity.

Arthur B. Bisguier of New York drew in twenty-two moves against Oscar Panno of Buenos Aires in the eleventh round of the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas in Bogota, according to a report received yesterday through Colombian news sources.

Artur Rodzinski, former conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, will make his first appearance in this country in a decade conducting two productions of the Chicago Lyric Opera's seven-week fall season.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Rob Roy loomed as probable start-to-finish leader in the twentieth annual Miami to Nassau yacht race tonight as the fleet of nineteen ocean racers inched through calm seas.

The celebrated case of the thirteen insurgent teamsters against James R. Hoffa has been "settled" out of court, but the settlement hasn't really settled anything. As the days have passed since Federal Judge Letts dissolved the injunction that had blocked Mr. Hoffa's accession to the teamster throne one thing has become increasingly clear.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -The nation's twenty-five scheduled domestic airlines said today that they had filed a request with the Government for a 4 per cent increase in fares plus a fee of $1 a ticket.

Should Mayor Wagner accept the resignation of the Rev. Dr. John M. Coleman from the Board of Education, his successor may be the Rev. Dr. Gardner Calvin Taylor, it was learned last night. Dr. Taylor is the pastor of the Concord Baptist Church of Brooklyn.
A bird that whistles Beethoven -- and even variations on Beethoven -- is a backstage pet at the American Museum of Natural History.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -President Eisenhower nominated today Walter K. Scott, foreign service officer, to be Assistant Secretary of State for Administration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -President Eisenhower responded today to an attack on his selection of Tariff Commission members.

Cape Canaveral, Fla., where America's "birds" are launched on their flight into space, provided a good example last week of the healthy aspects of inter-service rivalry. There a hybrid Army missile defeated a Navy-sponsored entry for the honor of launching America's first satellite.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5 -- His colleagues at Harvard University knew that sooner or later Dr. Norman Foster Ramsey would be called on again for some important assignment away from Cambridge.
The American President Lines needs Government aid to build a trans-Pacific luxury liner, Noah M. Brinson told the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee yesterday.
ATHENS, Ohio, Feb. 5 -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, called today for more diplomacy and less public debate within the United Nations.
PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The Government announced today that it planned to call an early conference of French and African political leaders to discuss reforms of the political structure of the French Union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told a House subcommittee today of three expense-paid trips to the South.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) House Democratic leaders said today that they would press ahead with a Presidential disability bill despite a veto threat from Attorney General William P. Rogers.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 5 -- President Shukri al-Kuwatly formally announced Syria's union with Egypt tonight. He nominated President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt to head the United Arab Republic.

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that employer contributions to a union local's welfare fund could be transferred for the benefit of individual members who are reassigned from one local to another of the same international union.

In these days of jubilation, when the Arab people are looking with hope toward the building of a unified, stable society and the fulfillment of their long-cherished dream of reuniting their fragmented countries after having been divided under the influence of foreign domination, one wonders whether your editorials of Feb. 3 and 4 are aimed at helping the Arabs make the many adjustments needed for the creation of their new unified state.

Members of the Community and Social Agency Employes Union early today voted to postpone a threatened strike against seven agencies affiliated with the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. They acceded to a request received yesterday from Governor Harriman to continue working.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 -Building unions and contractors agreed tonight on a national program to eliminate featherbedding and other abuses that have added millions of dollars each year to construction costs.

Plans for this year's Russian Mi-Carme Ball have been announced by Grand Duchess Olga and Princess Vera of Russia and the Association of Officers of the Former Imperial Russian Cavalry and Horse Artillery. A benefit for war invalids and needy members of the association, the fate will be held in the ballroom of the Ambassador on Feb. 21.
The National Retail Merchants Association has urged Wendell B. Barnes, head of the Small Business Administration, to enlarge that agency's definition of "small" retail stores.
Another private group announced yesterday that it was ready to undertake a task Congress failed last year to do -- study and recommend changes in the nation's monetary and banking system.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 -- George Romney asserted today that the American Motors Corporation was on the way to its first profitable year. In an optimistic report to stockholders at the annual meeting, Mr. Romney, president of American Motors, cited a profit of $4,948,736 for the first quarter of the company's fiscal year and indicated that January operations also were in the black.
Cocoa opened with a decline yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange but recovered and rose almost the 1-cent a pound daily limit.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb 5 (UP) -- National Hockey League players settled for more cash benefits in a meeting with club owners that ended early today. In exchange, the players dropped their pleas for recognition of their association and plans for lawsuits.
Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will serve again as honorary chairman of the seventh April in Paris Ball. The ball will be held on April 10 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
TRENTON, Feb. 5 -- New Jersey moved today to speed final Federal approval of the proposed $120,000,000 Bergen-Passaic Expressway.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Encouraging reports of export business today sparked the best buyer demand that grain futures have had in weeks on the Chicago Board of Trade.
New calculations of the orbit being followed by the United States' first artificial satellite put its closest approach to earth at about 219 miles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -President Eisenhower reaffirmed today that the Administration might favor a tax cut to brake the recession unless the economy turned upward by mid-year.

WAGNER at the Metropolitan Opera is almost getting to be a novelty. Here it is the fifteenth week of the season and "Die Walkuere" has finally come around for the first time. How different it was only twenty years ago, when "Ring" cycles were standard bills of fare and the rafters echoed with "Ho-jo-to-hos!"
The United Taxpayers Party issued yesterday the text of its state legislative program for 1958.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
A heart-lung machine with sensitive electronic controls has been devised by a team of physicians and surgeons at Maimonides Hospital of Brooklyn.
A 39-year-old Minnesotan of Italian extraction, head of one of the nation's leading producers of Chinese foods, is embarking on a new venture with the aid of Chippewa Indians.

Eleven men, seized Jan. 24 in a four-state round-up that netted thirty-seven pounds of heroin valued at $6,000,000 on the illicit market, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury here. They were charged with conspiring to violate the narcotics laws.

PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 6 -- A heavy explosion rocket the Palais Bourbon, home of France's National Assembly, about 10:40 last night. The Assembly was not in session at the time and there were no casualties. Damage to washrooms on the ground floor was reported to be extensive.

THE Cleveland Orchestra is celebrating its fortieth season with a flourish. It has commissioned a series of new works by American and European composers. Among other touring chores it has undertaken three Carnegie Hall concerts as if to challenge the primacy of the three famous orchestras that appear there year after year.
Package freight service on the Great Lakes -- a casualty of World War II -- may get a new chance at life.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 5 -The International Supervisory Commission for Vietnam announced today that its headquarters would be moved from Hanoi, capital of North Vietnam, to Saigon, South Vietnam's capital, late next month.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5 -- Judge Learned Hand criticized the Supreme Court tonight for occasionally exercising what he regarded as too broad a supervision over legislative decisions.

THESE menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The Aetna Life Affiliated Companies wrote a record total of insurance and reached new highs in payments during 1957, according to Henry S. Beers, president. Mr. Beers reported a record number of 14,375,000 policies, certificates and bonds in force on Dec. 31, 1957, while premium income increased by $94,000,000 to $940,672,518.

Seven teenage boys went on trial in General Sessions Court yesterday on charges of firstdegree murder. The youths are accused of killing Michael Farmer, 15 years old, of 575 West 175th Street, near Highbridge Park at 173rd Street and Amsterdam Avenue last July.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 5 -A Lutheran Church leader challenged today a widely held belief that college and university campuses were in the midst of a religious awakening.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (UP) -The Los Angeles Dodgers announced a revised home schedule today resulting from the National League club's games conflicting with other events in Memorial Coliseum.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -The Naval Research Laboratory released tonight this timetable of expected appearances of the satellite Explorer. All times in Eastern standard:
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 5 -- Algerian nationalist rebels accused French authorities tonight of condemning military prisoners to death and thus breaking a Geneva convention on guerrilla warfare.
TRENTON, Feb. 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner challenged State Senator Alfred McCay today to make public his reasons for blocking the reappointment of Grover C. Richman Jr. as State Attorney General.
Dr. William Jansen, who will retire Sept. 1 as Superintendent of Schools, will immediately step into a new job.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5--The second failure of a satellite-bearing Vanguard test vehicle was said officially this afternoon to have been caused by defects in the first-stage engine control system.
The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, in cooperation with state groups and individual savings banks, is starting a coordinated program of basic research for the $35 billion industry.
Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons urged yesterday that the City Council introduce a law to prohibit Westchester residents from parking their cars in the North Bronx.
City departments have asked for a record total of $2,123,875,384 in their expense budgets for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The major railroads of the state joined today in a request for tax relief amounting to at least $15,000,000 and possibly $25,000,000 a year.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 5 (AP) -Ralph Dupas, a lightweight contender from New Orleans, tonight won a majority decision over Gaspar Ortega of Mexico, a welterweight contender. Dupas weighed 141 pounds and Ortega 145.
PARIS, Feb. 5 -- A 42-year-old Harvard physicist was named today to advise the Atlantic alliance on scientific adjustment to the nuclear-missile-space age.

Dr. James E. Allen Jr., New York State Commissioner of Education, sent to Governor Harriman and members of the Legislature a week ago a program of recommendations by the Board of Regents for increased aid to education. The Regents "firmly believe," said the Commissioner, "that the program is essential as a minimum and that the people, weighing both need and cost, are ready and willing to supply the needed financial support."
Twelve public officials from the Utica area are to appear before the Legislature's watchdog committee here today as public hearings begin on reports of gambling and prostitution there.

Once-beaten West Virginia faces twice-beaten St. John's and New York University meets Holy Cross as the collegiaite basketball double-header program resumes at Madison Square Garden tonight after a four-week break.

Bryan Houston, Inc., has been named to "supervise" overseas advertising for Remington Rand electric shavers, effective April 1. The account is said to be one of the largest in the international field, with billings estimated at $1,250,000 a year.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Senator MacNeil Mitchell modified his transit labor bill today by proposing special criteria to guide the State Labor Relations Board in establishing bargaining units.

The United Fruit Company, in entering into a consent decree creating a new competitor in the banana industry, did not admit any violation of the antitrust laws, Kenneth H. Redmond, its president, said yesterday. On Tuesday the Government announced that the decree had terminated the antitrust suit it had filed against the company in 1954.

In your Jan. 22 issue there was an article about an expected clash between the automobile companies and the United Auto Workers over the union's proposal to invest pension reserves in housing and other community improvements.

The nineteenth annual American Music Festival sponsored by radio station WNYC will take place Feb. 12 to 22. It will present more than 100 special programs, including first performances of seventy works by American composers.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 5 -- The Cabinet decided today to offer Britain 100,000,000 ($280,000,000) in armament orders during the next three years. This would be an alter native to a contribution of 50,000,000 to the support of the British Army of the Rhine in West Germany next year, which London has been demanding.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 -The head of labor's political education committee predicted today that Governor Harriman would have the backing of New York unions in his re-election bid next fall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -Leading Senators, in a bipartisan action, moved today to settle whether military or civilian authorities should direct the nation's effort to conquer outer space.

Scores of New York University alumni will have learned with sorrow of the passing of Prof. Clyde Eagleton, reported in The Times on Jan. 30. They will be grateful to The Times for the mention made of this great man's life and of his public accomplishments.
As part of its answer to the problem of delinquency in the schools, the Board of Education is going ahead with plans to double the facilities of its special schools for difficult pupils.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -With a twelve-word statement today Senator John J. Williams heartened the Republicans and discomfited the Democrats for the approaching Congressional elections.

LAKE GROVE, L. I., Feb. 5 -- One boy was killed and two others injured early today in a fire that destroyed a two-story frame dormitory in the private Lake Grove School. The fire, discovered just before 1 A. M., routed thirtyseven boy students and five teachers from their beds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- When Senator Hennings of Missouri moved this week to defer action by the Judiciary Committee on the bill to eliminate five legal areas from those in which the Supreme Court has the last word, he could not have known that almost simultaneously one of the most respected of judicial voices would be raised in his support.

After studying the latest Bulganin letter, President Eisenhower said yesterday that the prospects for a fruitful "summit" meeting have not been brightened. He continues to insist, and rightly so, that such a meeting can be useful only if it offers a chance for mutual accommodation of policies, and he finds nothing in the letter to suggest that the Soviets are ready for this.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Governor Harriman called on the Legislature today to provide more protection for consumers who are required to take life insurance when making installment purchases.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Dr. John P. Hagen, director of the Vanguard Project, and other Navy officials said today that their efforts to launch a satellite into space would continue.
Today's new film is "Witness for the Prosecution," starring Tyrone Power, Marlene Dietrich and Charles Laughton, at the Astor and Plaza Theatres.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 5 -- It is time now to add pompano fishermen to the list of cult anglers whose dark rites are practiced along the Eastern Shore of the United States. It is time now because in some ways, they are the only happy people around here.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- Izvestia, Soviet Government newspaper, has labeled as "lies" reports that the Soviet Union still might take part in meetings of the United Nations Disarmament Commission.
DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 5 -- An effort to obtain tax revenue from privately owned boats, a somewhat neglected source till now, has raised Darien's assessment list more than $300,000.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5 (AP) -The United States Steel Corporation and Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation announced today price reductions of about 1 per cent in two stainless steel items.

A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a former Brooklyn manufacturer must pay approximately $500,000 in back Federal income taxes, penalties and interest. The Government previously had collected more than $1,100,000 in the same tax inquiry involving also his brother and their company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Art experts discovered with X-rays today that Georges Seurat, the French post-impressionist artist, had concealed his only self-portrait under layers of paint in "Young Woman Powdering," a study of his mistress, Madeleine Knobloch.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Before John Cavanagh gallantly leaped in this afternoon and pulled the old girl out, Dame Fashion had taken a count of three and was nearly done for. All those who had mourned through the preceding shows -- at Hardy Amies, Charles Creed and Lachasse -were made cheerful again by Cavanagh's brilliant rescue.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from a speech by President Gamal Abdel Nasser today before the Council of the Nation in Cairo, as transmitted here:
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows.

An increase of 1,303,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 204,559,000 barrels, compared with 203,256,000 a week earlier and 196,351,000 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles conferred for nearly two hours today on possible ways to induce the Soviet Union to undertake diplomatic negotiations leading to a summit conference.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- A Soviet newspaper alleged today that four military officers attached to the United States, British and Canadian Embassies here had behaved like "hooligans" on a recent trip to Tiflis and Baku.
EATING peas in February is not just a highly palatable idea; some quarters suggest that it may be a downright publicspirited thing to do.
Whether Europe's Common Market becomes a boon or a bane for the free world will depend largely on the course of the United States' economy, according to the French economist, Robert Marjolin.
IRISH linen will be all over the house this summer, if the Irish Linen Guild has anything to say.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 5 -- The Indonesian Government shrugged off tonight foreign press reports that a rival government was about to be proclaimed in Central Sumatra.
The Very Rev. James A. Pike said yesterday that he would be honored to become a Bishop in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese in California.

A two-story building containing stores and the Harlem Grand Theatre at 115-25 East 125th Street has been sold by the United States Trust Company and Le Roy and Rodney Soher, who erected it several years ago. The buyer was the Latin - American Pentecostal Church, which will alter and occupy the theatre portion of the property.
Mediation efforts failed again yesterday to end the three-day-old strike of truck drivers in the construction industry.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- It would be an exaggeration to say that the team of Scottish women curlers that played at the St. Andrews Golf Club today continued to sweep the country, but sweep they did. The broom is important to curling, an old and esoteric ice game scored a little like shuffleboard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 29:

The premieres of two films, "The Quiet American" at the Victoria Theatre and "Beautiful But Dangerous" at the Mayfair, were benefits last night. Proceeds from the former went to the International Rescue Committee. A portion of the proceeds from the latter was donated to the American Committee on Italian Migration.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 5--Robert Lacoste, Minister for Algeria, outlined today initial plans for political reforms designed to help end the rebellion.
An engineering consultant said here today that a method must be found to increase the accuracy with which human beings can communicate with electronic machines.

Thirteen local governmental housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration sold yesterday bond issues totaling $67,135,000 to finance the development of lowrent projects. The borrowing incurred an average interest cost of 2.8865 per cent.
Members of the ball, gift and men's committees for the third annual Heart of America Ball! have been announced.
The American people were advised yesterday not to become complacent because a United States satellite was now circling the earth.
PARIS, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -The owners of the old Suez Canal Company appointed an American, a Briton and a Frenchman today to confer with the Egyptian Government on compensation for the canal.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 5 -- President Jose Figueres promised today that his party would cooperate with the incoming Administration "to the extent that it is good for Costa Rica."

Of the major groups on the New York Stock Exchange only utilities made fairly general gains yesterday. Aircrafts, retailers, foods and rails were mixed. The others declined, partly in reaction to two days of rising prices, partly perhaps reflecting disappointment over the failure of the Vanguard missile.

When Woodrow Wilson a generation ago called for "open covenants openly arrived at" he could not have foreseen the time when the head of an international organization somewhat resembling the League of Nations would come out for "privacy in peacemaking."
HARTSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 5 -Robert F. Peters, chief announcer for radio station WFAS, committed suicide today just as he was to have gone on the air with a newscast.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Scientists envisioned today satellites on weather patrol and possible large-scale control of the weather.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 6 -- The National Lutheran Council ruled out of order today an "eleventh-hour" proposal to scrap two church merger plans and to seek instead all-out Lutheran unity.
MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 6 -- A British airliner carrying Britain's champion soccer team, Manchester United, crashed and burned on its third try to take off here in a snowstorm today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP) -- A Chinese-born scientist at the Harvard School of Public Health was reported today to have succeeded in devolping human cells that could subsist on distant chemical relatives of glucose, the blood sugar considered essential to higher life forms.
Coffee futures declined yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Reports that Colombia had increased February export quotas and that supplies were piling up in Brazil weakened the market.
IF the dress fits, wear it. If it does not, fit it.
A bomb scare delayed fourteen Eastern Airlines planes up to an hour and a half last night at three metropolitan airports and grounded three others already in the air. No bomb was found.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 21.8 per cent above the 1957 level, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 2.7 per cent over the same week last year, and orders were up 5.9 per cent.

As we have said before, there should be no objection to the union of weak Arab states to form a more viable government and a better economy. But the proclamation of Egypt's President Nasser, in which the structure of the new Arab state was outlined, must create apprehension.

HONG KONG, Feb. 6 -- More than 100,000 counter-revolutionaries and Rightists have been uncovered in Communist China over a twenty-seven-month period, according to Lo Jui-ching, Minister of Public Security.
A FRAGILE story was dramatized with care last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2. The result was a telecast illuminated by fine acting and splendid scenic effects.

SCRANTON, Pa., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Federal District Judge John W. Murphy ruled today that Representative William J. Green and six others must stand trial "shortly" on charges of fraud. The charges stem from construction of the $33,000,000 Signal Corps Depot at Tobyhanna, Pa.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 -- A leading Soviet scientist has agreed with colleagues in the West that "several more years of strenuous research" will be required before thermonuclear power can be harnessed successfully for industrial use.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -- "Traffic Court," Los Angeles' highest rated local live TV show, pondered today an adverse legal opinion from a battery of fifteen California judges that cost the show the services of its principal "actor," Judge Evelle Younger.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senate leaders of both parties strongly backed today President Eisenhower's refusal to enter an East-West summit conference without preparatory negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senator Wayne Morse called the Eisenhower education aid bill today "so inadequate I am shocked the Administration is so ill-informed."
The recent outbreak of violence in the public schools has caused harried city officials, worried parents and others to ask: What can be done about the problem of crime in the schools?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The parade of state court decisions against state "fair trade" laws in recent years has resulted in a proposal that Congress pass a Federal law applying the principle to goods traded in interstate commerce.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 4 -- Israel's capacity to increase her population by a million in the next ten years will depend greatly on intensified American economic assistance, Jewish leaders said today.

COATESVILLE, Pa., Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Lukens Steel Company reported record 1957 sales and earnings today and Charles L. Huston Jr., its president, said the company "looks forward to another good year in 1958."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- A group that plans to send four men aboard a vessel into the nuclear bomb test area in the Marshall Islands has asked President Eisenhower to call off such tests. The group, Non-Violent Action Against Nuclear Weapons, has headquarters here.

Rudolf Serkin took over the second half of last night's New York Philharmonic concert. With Dimitri Mitropolous on the podium, he played Schumann's Introduction and Allegro Appassionata (also known as the Concertstueck in G) and the Strauss "Burlesque" for piano and orchestra.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 6 -- The United States today accepted Haiti's apology for the death of an American in prison here last Sept. 29. Haiti punished two Army lieutenants involved and paid $100,000 indemnity for his widow and baby.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 -- The Naval Research Laboratory has traced the failure of the satellite-bearing Vanguard rocket fired early yesterday morning to a simple wiring defect.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 6 -- The head of the much-investigated International Union of Operating Engineers resigned his $50,000-a-year post today.
Sales of the Diamond Gardner Corporation rose last year to $170,645,000 from $168,797,000 in 1956, but earnings were down $2,677,000, according to Robert G. Fairburn, president.
No new snowstorms were reported in the north country yesterday but, as far as the week-end skier was concerned, it didn't matter. Virtually all of the areas have ample supplies of white cover.
I read your editorial of Feb. 3 "This Isn't 1929" with much interest, and wish to make the following comment:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- T. A. M. Craven, Federal Communications Commissioner, once returned an expense check to a Maryland broadcasting group because he considered it improper to accept the funds, it was disclosed today.

Several offers for the sunken Italian liner Andrea Doria have been made to the Italian marine underwriters who hold title to the vessel. None of these offers, however, has resulted in the sale of the vessel.

It is getting so that the more we can keep human nature out of modern electronic computing machines the better work those machines are going to do. This much we deduce from some remarks made this week by S. L. Seaton of Hampton, Va., at a meeting in this city of a committee of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Appeals to Congress to end secrecy in information were sounded by spokesmen for the nation's newspapers.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The British are a dancing nation.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 6 (UP)--Frank Stranahan, Manuel de la Torre and Bill Johnston fired 6-under-par 64's today to take the lead in the first round of the $15,000 Tucson open golf tournament at the Del Rio Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, today set in operation the nation-wide "share in America" savings bond drive.

PARIS, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Dr. Norman F. Ramsey, United States nuclear physicist named to the new post of scientific adviser to the Atlantic Alliance said today that the Western Nations still led the Soviet Union "in most basic science."
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 6 -- The political wing of E. O. K. A., the Greek Cypriote fighting organization, said today the "truce" with the British authorities had ended.

IN "American Working Drawings Prior to 1925, the Davis Galleries, 231 East Sixtieth Street, offers us an informal opportunity to see work by such artists as Glackens, Bellows, Shinn, Prendergast and Sloan when they were in a casual mood.
Two cancer researchers reported here yesterday that they had transplanted the skin of unborn babies onto two adults and that the skin was still living after almost a year.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- Transport Minister Hans Seebohm will ask the Federal Cabinet to reconsider its decision to deny cheap Government loans for the build-up of a West German trans-Atlantic passenger service.
The Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad, which, on the basis of preliminary figures believes that it had little or no earnings last month, yesterday halved its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 6 -- Moroccan police prevented a crowd of several hundred vociferous students from marching on the French Embassy today to protest against the French Government's recent decision to dissolve the General Union of Algerian Moslem Students.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Congress was warned today that the United States had only six "fully modern" passenger ships available for troop transport in war.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 6 (AP) -- The principal of Central High School here said tonight he had drawn up suspension notices for one of the nine Negro students enrolled at the school and for a white student.
A 44-year-old manufacturer of plastic products was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions Court, charged with the theft of $134,168 from commercial discount houses.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Governor Harriman urged the Legislature today to enact bills liberalizing the state's assistance for educational and recreational projects set up for elderly persons.
A quick rundown of the program for tomorrow night's Millrose Athletic Association Games attests the robust state of track and field in the colleges.

The problems of defense in the nuclear-missile age transcend the boundaries of the Pentagon, the authority of the Secretary of Defense and, indeed, the competence of the Government. The launching of the Soviet satellites last fall spurred a critical evaluation of our security organization that is continuing.

Help for the family before divorce or delinquency occur was stressed yesterday at an all-day conference sponsored by the Community Council of Greater New York. It was agreed that even the healthy family had problems, but that community agencies had the ability to help solve them.

John L. Loeb, chairman of the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company, issued a statement yesterday replying to two former directors who resigned in protest against the proposed sale of the company's Hershey sugar properties in Cuba.
TRENTON, Feb. 6 -- Unemployment insurance payments reached a record of $126,234,007 in New Jersey last year, while wages paid to employes covered by such benefits rose by $450,000,000.
CAIRO, Feb. 6 -- Discussions that are expected to bring Yemen into a federation with the Egyptian-Syrian union began today.

LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Florida Southern defeated Fordham's crew today on choppy Lake Hollingsworth. Southern covered the nine - tenths - mile course in 4:34.5. The Rams were clocked in 4:41. The margin was a length and three-quarters.
A four-day strike by construction industry truck drivers appeared certain yesterday to continue into next week.

William J. Alford, president since 1940 of Continental Paper Company, parent company in the Alford packaging group, has been elected chairman of the board and treasurer. C. L. Von Egloffstein has been elected president.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 5 -- No changes were made in the latest Afrikaans edition of the Bible to conform with South African racial laws, Dutch Reformed Church leaders stated here today.
WARSAW, Feb. 6 -- Polish Communists have seized on a Soviet decision to abolish machine-tractor stations as vindication of the whole Polish program of liberalization.
BUYING a sofa on impulse is almost unheard of in our society, according to a study made recently.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Four Senators said today they had received a sympathetic hearing at the White House on their plea for additional farm credit for the heavily damaged cotton area.
The Roxy Theatre will install a Cinemiracle wide screen for the premiere of Louis de Rochemont's "Windjammer," scheduled for a mid-April opening.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Mayor Wagner and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa renewed their differences of opinion today on New York City's need for a $500,000,000 debt exemp tion to finance new schools.
The substantial economic development attained by Puerto Rico mainly through private investments was cited yesterday as a timely example for less developed nations.
The venerable tanker Bidwell -- twice as old as economists say a ship should be -- was being readied yesterday for whatever the future holds.

West Virginia demonstrated last night why many authorities regard it as the nations No. 1 college basketball team. After being subjected to heavy pressure for twenty-five minutes, the Mountaineer quintet blasted out an 87-78 victory over St. John's.
Stocks yesterday continued to react from their 1958 highs but the losses were small.

News that a committee has been granted $295,000 to study what happens when the head of the house sits down each month with his checkbook and the inevitable pile of bills and attempts to make income cover expenditures must have puzzled a good many family breadwinners.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Britain's reply to Premier Bulganin will emphasize the necessity of "adequate preparation" for top-level talks without making a foreign ministers' conference an essential pre-condition to a meeting.

When I attended public school on West Twenty-eighth Street in the Eighteen Nineties -- until I was 14 -- classes for boys and girls were separate, except in the first grade. When boys reached age 11 they were transferred to a boys' school on West Thirtieth Street.

A patrolman testified yesterday how on last July 30 he had found Michael Farmer, 15 years old, dying in Highbridge Park, 173d Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The patrolman, John T. Collich, appeared in general sessions court at the trial of seven teen-age boys for first-degree murder.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The president of a New York direct mail advertising concern took issue today with the Post Office Department's contention that the public was "willing and even anxious" to pay higher postal rates.
A 14-year-old East Harlem youth was twice attacked by teen-agers yesterday.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Lucille Wheeler, averaging more than forty miles per hour on a bumpy course, gave Canada her first victory in the history of the world ski championships by winning the women's downhill race in record time today.
The financial community did some second guessing yesterday about the outcome of the Treasury's $16,875,000,000 refinancing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The new Soviet Ambassador, Mikhail A. Menshikov, arrived in the United States today aboard a Soviet jet airliner. He declared that he "came as an Ambassador of peace,...
The police announced yesterday that 4,200 of 10,000 motorists who received summonses for moving violations in an eighty-two-day period were repeaters.
Prostitution, gambling and killings in Utica, N. Y., do not necessarily indicate organized crime in that city, its chief of police testified yesterday.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 -- Control of farm machinery by collective farms instead of tractor stations was apparently tested successfully before Nikita S. Khrushchev proposed such a step.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 4 East Eighty-ninth Street has been sold by the Retor Building Corporation to an investing client of Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., broker in the transacation.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 -- A Soviet official has said that commercialism in the United States television and excessive sexuality in that nation's movies, art and literature may somewhat limit exchanges in these fields with the Soviet Union.
The Columbia Broadcasting System filed a charge of an unfair labor practice yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board.

RICHIE GUERIN beat Bill Sharman to the punch and he never made a worse mistake in his life. It was only an exhibition game last October, but whenever the New York Knickerbockers clash with the Boston Celtics on a basketball court, both teams perform with such frenzied violence that each game resembles open warfare.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The White House has called an interagency meeting tomorrow afternoon to consider a plan for returning German and Japanese assets seized in this country during World War II.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday were 550,426 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
KOREAN art, little known until the excavation of tombs and caves in the present century, and still unfamiliar to the Western world, makes up an impressive exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum.
Nuclear explosions caused a 33 per cent increase in the concentration of radioactive strontium-90 in the human body in the year ended June 30, scientists reported yesterday.
The Administration's educational and financial programs were attacked yesterday by Prof. Seymour E. Harris of Harvard University.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The Republican leaders of the Legislature announced today that they were recommending a $300,000 increase in the budget to provide for the acquisition of 17,000 acres in the Adirondack forest preserve.

Congratulations and regrets are in order over the election of Dean James A. Pike of St. John the Divine as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of California. The congratulations are for Dr. Pike at what he rightly terms "a great honor." The regrets are for all of us New Yorkers who will, in a sense, be losing one of our most respected and interesting churchmen.
An unusual and dramatic program for encouraging eye safety among workers on hazardous jobs has been developed by a man who was blinded in an accident.
The State Attorney General reminded municipal officials yesterday that the new bingo law required them to wait until Feb. 19 before holding referendums on local ordinances.

New York State borrowed at long-term yesterday $50,000,000 in furtherance of the permanent financing of the $1,000,000,000 Thruway. The money was raised by the sale of bonds bearing the full faith and credit of the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The State Department has written off as "extremely dangerous" the Polish plan for establishing a Central European zone from which nuclear arms would be barred.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- There was not much inducement today to do business in grain futures on the Board of Trade and prices reacted narrowly to minor influences.
ONE of the best food buys for the week-end is chicken. It is a thrifty purchase, and especially in view of the prevailing high prices of beef and other popular meat cuts.

The Westchester County Council of Social Agencies has selected the preview performance of "Love Me Little" on April 7 for its fifth annual theatre party. The play, which opens on April 9, features Joan Bennett, Meg Mundy and Donald Cook.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6 -- Westchester County officials expressed doubts today that Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons would be able to carry out his proposal to prohibit Westchester residents from parking their cars in the north Bronx.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The 1957 winner, Finisterre, thirty-nine-foot yawl owned by Carleton Mitchell of Annapolis, Md., won both Class C and over-all honors in the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau yacht race today.
A Roman Catholic author and home missioner exhorted Catholic educators here yesterday to increase their efforts to instill a missionary spirit in their students.

One of the authors of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund report on defense said yesterday that President Eisenhower could begin major savings by asking Congress to dispose of more than 250 surplus military installations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Half the Senate was worrying about outer space today but the other half was even more worried about the inner tensions of the national economy.

Former Senator William Benton of Connecticut suggested last night that President Eisenhower call a meeting of the forty-eight state commissioners of education to inspect school curriculums and clean out "a lot of the tripe and triviality."

Fanny Burney (1752-1840), letter writer, diarist, novelist and playwright, is the subject of a biography by Joyce Hemlow, which Oxford University Press will issue Feb. 27. "The History of Fanny Burney" is based on the voluminous Burney papers that include 8,000 unpublished letters and journals, her unpublished plays, holograph worksheets of novels and plays and many documents of biographical, social and historical interest.
The Pharmaceutical Society of the State of New York announced yesterday that it had recommended tighter state control over the sale of proprietary medicines.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 6 -- The military commander of the defiant province of Central Sumatra sharply criticized the Central Government in Jakarta tonight. But he made no reference to the possibility of an imminent proclamation of a rival government, according to reports here.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Governor Harriman declared tonight that the state could score a major advance in the battle against crime if Republican legislative leaders would "forget politics."
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6 -- The use of Federal money two years ago to reconstruct short stretches of the Cross County Parkway threatened today to block toll collections by Westchester on the parkway.
TRENTON, Feb. 6 -- The multi-billion-dollar Federal Highway Program will be "outmoded" before it is completed, a Federal budget official declared here today.
Harold H. Gumm was restrained yesterday by Surrogate S. Samuel Di Falco from withdrawing money from the estate of his late brother, Harry Von Tilzer, a song writer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Ninety-three years after Jules Verne published "De la Terre a la Lune" the Senate of the United States today established a special committee to decide a national policy for the space age in which round-trips to the moon by living earthlings will be only one of their routes through the universe.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 5 -- Luis Alberto Monge will announce next week his resignation as secretary general of the Inter-American Regional Labor Organization.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 6 -- The General Assembly of Maryland overrode today Governor Theodore R. McKeldin's veto of a $400 teacher pay increase. It also rejected his veto of a bill imposing a state-wide cigarette tax of 3 cents a pack to finance the salary increase.
A FORMER magician is teaching women to master memories that play tricks on them.
EVEN in a wheelchair, Celeste Holm looks charming and indomitable. Most women in rugged health would be happy to have half of her splendor.

DENVER, Feb. 6 -- Paul F. Genachte, vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said here today that the Federal Government must give the uranium industry more help. Mr. Genachte, head of the bank's atomic energy division, spoke at the opening day of the sixty-first national Western mining conference. More than 2,000 miners and mill men from the United States, Canada, Mexico and South America are attending the three-day meeting in the Shirley-Savoy Hotel.
The Board of Education announced last night that pupils "charged with a violation of law involving violence or insubordination" would be suspended at once.

BOSTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- A rookie center, Bob Hull, the youngest player in the National Hockey League, and Glen Hall paced the last-place Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-1 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.
Holdings of acceptances in the larger New York City banks increased $51,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

A committee of public officials and private citizens began a campaign yesterday for 250,000 signatures to petitions for outlawing the gravity knife and the sale of ammunition to anyone except a licensed hunter.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Federation Internationale de Ski tonight recommended that national federations reduce the number of international races and the time which top skiers are allowed to spend away from their jobs in training.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A New York and Chicago investment firm indicated today that it might submit a slate of directors for election at the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's annual meeting in April.

The first performance of a tuneful new chamber opera, "The Dragon," by Deems Taylor was presented last night at the Hall of Fame Playhouse of New York University. The production was staged by the University Heights Opera Workshop and the Green Room Honor Society with the help of three professional singers in leading roles.
Weiss Geller, Inc., has won the advertising account of the Bon Ami Company, with billings of more than $1,000,000 a year.
The State Power Authority told the Legislature yesterday that terms under which it had borrowed $100,000,000 to speed construction of the Niagara power project had precluded the payment of any taxes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee asked the Federal Communications Commission today to call off its plans for pay-TV field tests, at least for the time being.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Senate created a special committee today to frame legislation concerning the exploration and development of outer space.

BEFORE noon on Feb. 12 in 1908 fifty thousand persons filled Times Square. The New York Times next day described this assemblage as "one of the greatest throngs that ever crowded into a small space." The attraction was the start of an automobile race from New York to Paris.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 6 -- One immediate effect of the union between Egypt and Syria has been to shake the position of the most active Communist party in the Middle East -- Syria's.

DETROIT, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings tonight fought off a third-period Montreal Canadien rally to pull out a 1-1 tie in a wide-open National Hockey League game. The Wings took full possession of third place, breaking a tie with the Boston Bruins.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 -- Judge Learned Hand weighed and found wanting tonight the asserted advantages of relying on judges for protection against legislative "frailties."

A Lebanese representative in the United Nations was said to have been "doing some narcotics business" in 1952 with a $20,000,000-a-year international narcotics ring, a witness testified yesterday in Federal Court.
The Home Fashions League compared a century of clothing styles with a century of home fashion designs at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Going to the heart of the issue dividing the world, President Eisenhower has rejected the false equation, launched by Soviet propaganda but also propounded in some quarters in the West, which puts Soviet ideology on a par with the Western creed. In a letter written on his behalf by Secretary Dulles and published in London, he points to one basic difference of fundamental importance in world affairs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland said today the Administration considered it inadvisable for Congress to take up Alaska statehood legislation without considering Hawaii statehood also.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP) -- More than 6,000 auto workers were sent home today in work disputes at the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Norman Hartnell, unlike most fashion designers who tend to take themselves too seriously, has a sly sense of humor. His showing today included a black draped jersey dinner dress with sinister bat wings, which he chose to call "Dracula."

Those who engineered the success of "Two for the Seesaw" are likely to string along with another entry. The participants will be William Gibson (author), Arthur Penn (director) and Fred Coe (producer). Their efforts will be directed toward bringing "The Miracle Worker" to Broadway in the fall of 1959.

The Minneapolis - Honeywell Regulator Company increased its sales last year to a record of $324,800,000 from $287,944,462 in 1956, but earnings declined slightly, the preliminary unaudited annual report disclosed yesterday.
STRATHFORD, Conn., Feb. 6 -- Fiftene hundred voters here were asked today to tell their councilman -- by prepaid postcard -- what they thought of a proposed $4,000,000 municipal budget.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Embassy here said Mme. Vera Lukic, 24-year-old wife of the Yugoslav air attache in London, and her 22-month-old son also were survivors. They were injured and in the hospital.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire, Anne Richardson of Columbus, Ohio; Betty Kerby of Akron and Mary Janssen of Charlottesville, Va., gained the semi-finals of the Palm Beach women's amateur golf championship today.
SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Feb. 6 -- Dr. Vivian E. Fuchs said today that he was in trouble after two of his vehicles had fallen into crevasses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, Jerome D. Fenton, moved on three fronts against the International Typographical Union today as a result of demands and strikes at The Worcester Telegram and Haverhill Gazette.
NEWPORT, R. I., Feb. 6--Mrs. Anita O'Keefe Young was appointed today executrix of the estate of her husband, Robert R. Young, financier and chairman of the board of the New York Central Railroad.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that he had been invited to visit Moscow, presumably to discuss United Nations affairs involving the Soviet Union. Among these is disarmament.
A 27-year-old convicted car thief drove downtown in a stolen car yesterday to report to his parole officer in the Criminal Courts Building.
Just ahead is the pleasure boat skipper's worst season of the year. He needs pity and sympathy until the weather breaks and he can start doing some fitting-out chores in, say, April.

Is it necessary or at least helpful, when a new member is to be appointed by the Mayor to the New York City Board of Education, to get the endorsement of the county Democratic organization? This question -- which makes one pause to think -- comes up in connection with the offered resignation of the Rev. Dr. John M. Coleman, rector of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church of Brooklyn.

TRENTON, Feb. 6 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner threatened today to make the failure of the state Senate to confirm Grover C. Richman Jr. as state Attorney General a major issue in next year's Legislative campaign.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The House of Commons defeated tonight a Labor party motion criticizing the Government's industrial and social policies. The vote was 318 to 251, a Government majority of sixty-seven.
Sir John Barbirolli, who succeeded Arturo Toscanini as conductor of the New York Philharmonic from 1937 to 1943, will return to the orchestra for four weeks starting Dec. 29.

YESTERDAY'S action of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee in delaying toll television over the air is an intriguing illustration of the complications involved in the regulation of the broadcasting industry.

As a strong advocate of the purposes in the main of the Temporary Commission on the Courts (the Tweed commission) for court reform in this state, I am very much disturbed by those proposals of the commission which seek to affect the Surrogate's Courts in the City of New York and to relegate them to the status of a subdivision of the Supreme Court of the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Secretary of State Dulles spoke today for President Eisenhower in a three-cornered exchange of ideas on war and peace with Bertrand Russell and Nikita S. Khrushchev.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 6 -- Cambodia and Laos have done little to quiet apprehension here over Communist activities in Southeast Asia, observers said today.
The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to suspend trading in the common and $1 cumulative preferred stocks of the Peninsular Telephone Company, effective Feb. 17.

A new six-story apartment building at 645 West 239th Street, in the Riverdale area of the Bronx, has ben sold by Max Steinberg and Louis Zucker to an investor. It occupies a plot 125 by 115 feet at the corner of Independence Avenue and contains forty-eight apartments. E. Osborne Smith, Inc., was the broker.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 6 -- A former Indonesian finance minister today denounced the Government of President Sukarno and said it would probably topple "within ten days."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Atomic Energy Commission told Congress today that the tiny atomic nucleus had the power to propel large satellites and manned space vehicles far out into space.
A reception committee has been named for the Ball of the Year. a benefit for Boys Towns of Italy, which will take place at the Waldorf-Astoria on March 27.
FORT LEE, N. J., Feb. 6 -- If George Washington were to revisit this place, from which he led his retreating forces in 1776, he would feel quite at home with some of the weapons he would find here.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 6 -- Habib Bourguiba, the Western-minded President of Tunisia, warned the United States and France today of the danger that North Africa might "slide down hill toward communism."
Casey Stengel was assured yesterday that his No. 1 candidate for the Yankees' left-field post would be ready for the start of the season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The frequently forecast resignation of Harold E. Stassen as White House disarmament adviser was believed today to be impending. The White House announced that President Eisenhower would meet tomorrow with the former Minnesota Governor and president of the University of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Air Force announced today that its advanced long-range tactical missile, the Mace, was successfully fired a distance of 650 miles today. It followed a course from the missile center at Alamogordo, N. M., to Wendover Air Force Base, Utah.

IN the southeast corner of Iraq a few miles north of the city of Basra the Tigris River flowing down from the north is joined by the Euphrates River flowing in at a right angle from the west. North of the Euphrates and on both sides of the Tigris lies one of the strangest and least known regions in the world, the permanent marshlands inhabited by the Ma'dan tribes.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 13 to 30 points (65 cents to $1.50 a bale) yesterday. Strength was greatest in the last months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today last year's boom in cotton markets was fading under a 17 per cent decline in demand, both at home and abroad.
Displays of what are believed to be aurora, or northern lights, have been detected on the dark face of Venus.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Rudolf Serkin, pianist, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Puccini's "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera House 8:15; Claudio Arrau, pianist, Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Spokesmen for New York State and the Federal Government conferred today with Senator Jacob K. Javits on the possibility of establishing a narcotics treatment center on Ellis Island.
FORT LEE, N. J., Feb. 6 -- The Fort Lee Council unanimously adopted a zoning amendment last night that would permit the construction of an apartment house that would tower over the Palisades.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation is studying the possibility of entering the small car field.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Britain was stunned tonight by the tragedy that befell the Manchester United soccer team in Munich.
This year's performance here of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., will benefit the Travelers Aid Society.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 6 -- Three South African scientists have discovered the remains of an early man in the Sterkfontein caves near Johannesburg. They said the discovery promised to revolutionize theories aboupt the origin of the human race.

MIAMI, Feb. 6 -- William Hartack, the $250,000-a-year jockey whose picture is on the cover of this week's issue of a news magazine, was beginning to fret when he rode out for today's sixth race at Hialeah. He had been on four successive out-of-the-money horses.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday that the United States should ask the Soviet Union to join in "pooling the joint good offices and resources" of all countries to bring peace and prosperity to the Middle East.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 6 -- The weather has turned right here at last, but the black bass have not yet learned about it -- except for the bass in Canal 23. Nobody seems to know why the Canal 23 bass have begun to strike briskly, although, of course, the wise old heads all have explanations of one sort or another.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Rising unemployment brought sharp criticism of the Eisenhower Administration in the Senate today.

One of the signs of spring outside the city this year may be the appearance of cattle egrets, which have arrived mysteriously in this country from their native Africa. An alert for the rare white bird, similar to domestic egrets, was sounded yesterday by John K. Terres, editor of The Audubon Magazine, 1130 Fifth Avenue.
The New York City League of Women Voters, already committed to opposition, held an open forum as a public service last night on 1958 proposals for state court reform. More than 500 persons attended.
A group of real estate syndicators volunteered yesterday to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission any offerings of an interstate character.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 6 -- Aly Khan, who was passed over for the leadership of 20,000,000 Ismaili Moslems, was named Pakistan's Ambassador to the United Nations today.

BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Ted Williams signed a contract today for a reported 1958 salary of $135,000. It will be his eighteenth season with the Boston Red Sox. The contract probably is the best ever given to a baseball player.

Treasury deposits with the Federal Reserve banks declined $304,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was the major factor, apart from Reserve open market activity, affecting member bank reserves.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that farmers were not responding to "the old prosperity pills" provided by present aid programs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -- Jeff Chandler will team with Susan Hayward in "Between the Thunder and the Sun," to be produced by Seven Arts Productions as a United Artists release.

A 12-year-old girl was used as a hostage yesterday in a Bronx bank robbery in which a gunman escaped with $12,440.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 7 (AP) -- George Bernardi of Miami slipped to a 73 today but held on to a share of the lead after thirty-six holes in the $2,000 Puerto Rican open golf tournament.

With Ron Delany as, grand marshal, an all-star cast of runners, hurdlers, jumpers and vaulters will parade tonight in the fifty-first Millrose Athletic Association games, the first of Madison Square Garden's five annual track and field galas.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 7 -- The Central Committee of the East German Socialist Unity (Communist) party disclosed today that it had suppressed an attempt inside the party to change its political policies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, in a jovial mood but still fighting a cold, had as visitors today twelve Explorer Boy Scouts representing all sections of the nation.

THE slavish following of a strict housekeeping routine is dangerous. So believes Mrs. Anne McKellar, Home Management instructor in the Department of Home Economics at Hunter College.
Cotton futures prices were unchanged to 15 points (75 cents a bale) off yesterday. Business was moderate.

One of the interesting and significant aspects of the recent Sikh demonstration in New Delhi was the emphasis upon its peaceful character. More than 100,000 Sikhs gathered to march in the streets of the capital in protest against certain policies of the Government and certain acts of individuals, but they were instructed to refrain from shouting slogans, to avoid any action that could be thought "inflammatory,'' to make a "peaceful" protest.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- A new effort by Britain to enlist the aid of Greece in solving the Cyprus problem was announced today.

Court action was started yesterday in a move to punish the Rev. William Howard Melish for contempt because of his asserted failure to surrender the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn to the Rev. Dr. Herman S. Sidener.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Federal Government decided today to go to the rescue of the Long Island Sound oyster, which is being squeezed to death by starfish.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Defense Department established today the first United States agency to devise outer space weapons and rockets and other space vehicles.
BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Syracuse, sparked by Larry Costello, defeated New York, 105 -- 102, tonight by building up a third-period cushion and holding off a late Knicks' surge.

A 58-year-old woman was killed on a Bronx sidewalk yesterday by a runaway bus. Her daughter and two grandchildren were injured.

CAIRO, Feb. 7 -- The Soviet bloc has extended to Egypt, Syria and Yemen $770,000,000 in military and economic aid over the last two years. Egypt and Syria have merged in the United Arab Republic; Yemen is a prospective member.

MIAMI, Feb. 7 -- It seems likely that Mrs. Mabel D. Lewis, who owns a race mare named Happy Princess, set a value of precisely $3,250 on the four-hour rain that doused Miami this morning. That's the amount the mare won in the day's main divertissement at Hialeah Race Course.

Events today: Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" and Strauss' "Salome," Metropolitan Opera House, 2; Puccini's "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15; Puccini's "La Boheme," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15; Deems Taylor's "The Dragon," Hall of Fame Playhouse, University Heights Campus of New York University, 8:30; "The King Says Farewell to His Favourite," Chinese Opera Group, Hunter College Assembly Hall, 8:30.
Erik Thygesen, a 16-year-old Dane who won an essay contest and a trip to the United States, took only one day to decide that America and Americans are "fantastic."

Two high-bidding California-shipyards have seen selected to receive the first contracts granted under a 1956 shipbuilding allocation law.
Directors of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company yesterday voted to omit the dividend on the common stock for the present quarter.
Thirteen reputed leaders of last December's subway strike were notified yesterday by the Transit Authority to answer disciplinary charges on Feb. 17 before former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind.

The annual bridge luncheon for the benefit of the Catholic Big Sisters will be held Feb. 18 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Roman Catholic and Protestant agencies are starting their annual drives to cope with what relief officials call the "continuous emergencies" posed by the needy overseas.

Studies suggesting that classical techniques of immunology may govern the transplant of tissues or organs from one person to another were presented here yesterday. The reports were made at a special conference on tissue homo transplantation, sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences.

S. S. R. as well as in every satellite country.

ARTHUR MILLER, three of whose plays have been filmed but who has never written a scenario that has reached the screen, is about to set a precedent.
