PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania, off-setting a 27-point performance by Brown University's Joe Tebo, scored a 77-60 Ivy League basketball victory over the Bruins in the first game of a Palestra doubleheader tonight.
Irving Dilliard, editorial writer on The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, has won the second Florina Lasker Civil Liberties Award, the New York Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 8 -- The merged labor federation called on its affiliated unions today to press for higher wages and increased mass purchasing power as a cure for recession-born unemployment.
The largest expansion program in the 169-year history of Jesuit colleges in America is under way.
New York University's basketball team climbed back to the .500 mark last night as it defeated Boston University, 72 -- 66, at Alumni gymnasium.

The National Academy of Sciences, the nation's top-ranking scientific body, issued last week an interim report of its committee on meteorology with several far-reaching recommendations. The committee of nine leading authorities was appointed two years ago by Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the academy and also of the Rockefeller Institute.

A FEW years ago, I turned my gardening hobby and some new-found leisure to very good use. My time was spent beautifying the grounds around my family's summer home on the shore of a small lake in St. Lawrence County, N. Y.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 8 -- Missouri legislators this week were considering a record $534,000,000 budget presented by Gov. James T. Blair.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro tonight announced proposals to eliminate Baltimore's five-week-old advertising tax and the thirteen-month-old tax on manufacturers' inventories and machinery.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 8 -- The Israel Bond Organization officially opened its 1958 campaign here tonight with the sale of a total of $14,601,200 in Israeli bonds. The receipts go toward the consolidation of Israel's economic framework.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- The American Friends Service Committee announced today that its Quaker work camp program would be resumed in Poland this summer after a lapse of nine years.

Waterways have thousands of outboarders who have sheared off tens of thousands of pins when their propellers hit submerged objects. Those were the days! One of the ticklish feats of a boat pilot was to emplace a new shear pin, with cotter and all, on the lower unit of a motor hanging on a stern transom while the boat was gyrating in rough water and bobbing like a cork.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Kellogg Company, one of the world's largest breakfast food firms, ordered resumption of production tonight pending settlement of a work stoppage which made 3,500 employes idle earlier today...
Wednesday is the deadline for the filing of briefs with the Tariff Commission on competitive conditions in this country between domestic and foreign whisky.

The Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, has announced competition for 165 scholarships in thirteen foreign countries. The awards, for one year beginning in the fall of 1958, are in Austria, Brazil, Cuba, Denmark, France, Germany, Iran, Israel, Italy, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom.

For too long now Mr. Smith has been gingerly trodding on critical eggshells in his many reviews of jazz books, but Mr. Feather's "The Book of Jazz" seems to have provoked him into making a few forthright statements.
TOKYO, Feb. 8 -- Japanese scientists have achieved this country's first nuclear fusion reaction, Osaka University announced today.

I read your recent William Holden story ("Extraordinary 'Ordinary Guy,'" by Charlotte and Denis Plimmer, Jan. 19) with great interest but was surprised to note that you credited a Paramount Picture scout with the discovery of William Holden for "Golden Boy."

NEW DELHI, Feb. 8 -- For the past couple of weeks Indians have been edified and hugely entertained by a spectacle long dear to the American heart: the big shot sizzling in the pan of a public investigation.

THE American Indian, a traditional foil for making cowboys look superior, will be glorified and glamorized next fall in a musical play about Hiawatha. According to tentative plans, it is scheduled for presentation over the National Broadcasting Company television and radio networks on Oct. 12 from 6:30 to 7:30 P. M.

Recent advances in the art of rocketry place a trip to the moon at least within the bounds of possibility. A recent study by the Space Flight Committee of the American Rocket Society suggested this rough schedule: Payloads in the hundreds of pounds might be placed on or around the moon within five or ten years, and manned flight around the moon, including landings there, might be accomplished within twenty years.
SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 3 -- Salvadoran youths serving their hitch in the army are learning modern methods of agriculture at a Government-owned farm in the province of La Libertad.

UP to this moment, only those American readers who have chanced upon the writings of Henry Lawson in English or Australian editions have had the very great pleasure of savoring the work of this master of the short fictional narrative.

An airborne fire extinguishing system for use in airplane crashes occurring in remote areas is being developed by the American LaFrance Corporation of Elmira, N. Y. The work is in collaboration with the Sikorsky Aircraft division of the United Aircraft Corporation, Bridgeport, Conn.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 -- On stages 3,000 miles apart a politically charged drama of electric power is getting under way coincident with the 1958 campaign.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Feb. 8 -- Charley Sullivan and North Shore's Vic Elmaleh led the way into the semi-final round of the Rockaway Hunt Club member-guest squash racquets tournament by taking two matches today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 8 -- The people of Israel, whose little state has become sandwiched between the provinces of Gamal Abdel Nasser's empire-bent United Arab Republic, are not worried about being swallowed themselves, but are, paradoxically, solicitous for their unloved neighbor, King Hussein of Jordan.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 8 (UP) -- The Government today suspended its state of siege for forty-eight hours to permit Paraguayans to vote for a President and Congress tomorrow in an election that President Alfredo Stroessner and his one-party slate connot lose.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 -- The local undertaking industry, which has gained international note by its aggressive and sometimes rococo methods of getting business, came of second best this week in a battle with a renowned medical sleuth from New York.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 8 -- Don January, a Texan who always plays some of his best golf in February, played through the rain and wind to take over first place in the third round of the Tucson open tournament today with a 54-hole score of 198.
MIAMI, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Alvin Dark, the defending champion, is favored to repeat in the baseball players' golf tournament, which gets under way Thursday.
MAY I point out two factual errors in Charles Edward Smith's review of my book, "The Book of Jazz."

EDWARD R. MURROW's informal conversation with former President Harry S. Truman was by all odds the most fruitful television of the last week. It is not often that there is an opportunity to watch and hear a man who helped make history discuss in unhurried style some of the decisions, recollections and anecdotes of his career.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 7 -- President Francois Duvalier appears to have kept the Haitian Army satisfied while obtaining an essential improvement in relations with the United States.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 8 -- Eight mannerly boys from the Frederick Douglass Junior High School in Harlem today wrote a chapter that will never be incorporated in reports of juvenile delinquency in the New York City schools.

KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The major league player representatives today unanimously endorsed a recently proposed bill by the House Antitrust sub-committee to bring business aspects of all professional sports under Federal regulation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 -- Two major steps were taken this week to insure the transplanted Giants a new 45,400-seat stadium in which to entertain National League baseball rivals in 1959.
Motion pictures are appearing with increasing frequency in the advertising and promotion programs of corporations.
Experimental child-guidance clinics in three Bronx public schools won a reprieve last week from the Board of Education.
The role of a university in a metropolitan community came into question last week with the resignation of Dean Louis M. Hacker of Columbia University's School of General Studies.
BUFFALO, Feb. 8 -- Manhattan broke away from Canisius in the closing moments tonight for a 76-57 victory in the second game of a basketball twin bill at Memorial Auditorium.
Time was when the main stock in trade of the retail lumber dealer was lumber. Today he's selling all kinds of building and home materials -- including the kitchen sink.
Construction of a new Broadway Bridge across the Harlem River at 225th Street will start within ten days, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen announced yesterday.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 8 -- Indonesian leaders gathered here in opposition to the Government in Jakarta have given no definite indication yet on what action they are planning to take.

VIENNA, Feb. 5 -- The Bulgarian police have been deporting thousands of "hooligans" from Sofia and other Bulgarian cities during the last ten days. They have been sent to state farms and other institutions, where they will be put to work.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- Western political observers in Moscow have been puzzling in recent days over the significance, if any, of nominations now being made throughout the Soviet Union of candidates for election as Deputies to the Supreme Soviet, this country's parliament.

TWO important American plays for which London has had to wait some time have just been staged here on consecutive evenings. By a coincidence each of them is being produced not by a commercial management trying to sell it to the general public but by a theatre club for the benefit of its members.

WASHINGTON -- Automation came to the National Gallery of Art last week, to the apparent delight of sight-seers as well as staff members. The gallery introduced an experimental new electronic guide service called LecTour.

A NEW and exotic chapter in the post-war expansion of our acquaintance with oriental art brings us a selection of the treasures of Korea over twenty centuries. The exhibition which has just opened at the Metropolitan Museum includes 200 examples of paintings, bronze sculpture, intricate gold work, beautiful ceramics and stoneware and tiles from Korean Museums and private collections.

ALTHOUGH Calouste Gulbenkian listed gardening as his recreation in "Who's Who," the only soil he ever cultivated -- and he did it by remote control from a suite in the Paris Ritz -- was that of the desert country of the Middle East.
ATHENS, Feb. 4 -- The bulwark in Greece against communism, so firm a decade ago when attacking forces were mainly military, has yielded perceptibly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Once again Congressional sleuths have turned their attention to the behavior of Government officials.
On an average there are about fifty-five dwelling units, or 175 persons, within every acre in the city, according to a survey by the Department of City Planning.

VALENTINE'S DAY, with its sentimental associations, is the perfect time to accent the hearts and flowers theme. Unusual containers, ribbons and paper lace doilies can be used imaginatively to add a nostalgic touch to the home-made flower arrangements.

IT was April 19, 1919, the play, Jacinto Benavente's "The Bonds of Interest," and it marked the beginning of the first season of the Theatre Guild. The next October the tyro group began its second season with John Masefield's "The Faithful" and that was the last time there were two distinct seasons starting the same year.

As a teacher, I deeply resent Mr. Raeff's statement that "It is the average younger teacher who is to blame. Our teachers are trained how to teach, but are they provided with the knowledge and understanding of what to teach?"
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Legislation to authorize the arrest and conviction of speeders on the basis of radar evidence will be introduced in the Legislature on Monday.

Once more our culture is going into one of those confused rampages involving a prevalent pattern of business behavior which at odd moments is dramatized by mink coats, deep freezers, colored television sets and trips to conventions.
A Greek who speaks for the United States in Athens is going home with new enthusiasm based on a first-hand acquaintance with his subject.
CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 8 -- Plans to turn part of an estate near here into a country club for disabled veterans have run into strenuous objections from neighboring property owners.
Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, president of New York University, said yesterday that debate on education missed the point wherever it concluded that more money was needed.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6 -- Jose Sanchez, the average Argentine, is more aggressive than he was thirty months ago when Juan D. Peron was in power. The "liberating" revolution of September, 1955, has given him freedom to display his anger about the frustrations and difficulties of daily life.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 8 -- Spring racing started at the Bowie race track today. That's what it said on the program of the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association of Prince George's County, Md., which operates the local course.

OUR foremost literary critic has achieved eminence not alone because he is a sensitive and thoughtful reader of texts. What gives his work its particular distinction is that he is the endlessly curious and probing critic of so many other things in our civilization besides our literature -- and not just of related matters, like theatre, films, music and painting, but of our politics, economic organization, crime, social injustice and our broad folkways.

ALTHOUGH the National Association of Gardeners is primarily a fraternal society of professional gardeners, its slogan, "A Power for Good in Gardening," has real meaning. The association's emblem -- a small ivy leaf -- may be seen at flower shows where many of the members act as judges or enter exhibits.

The union of Egypt and Syria generally is considered a step aimed at consolidating the Arab world in a single political unit, which would control the vast oil resources stretching from the Persian Gulf through North Africa to the Atlantic.

ONE of Hollywood's most successful and least publicized directors, Fred Zinnemann is about to receive an unusual tribute. Starting March 13 the Museum of Modern Art will hold daily showings of outstanding movies Zinnemann made between 1937 and 1957. Besides those shown here, they include "The Men," "Teresa" and "A Hatful of Rain." The S0-yearo old, Vienna-born director will not attend museum showings; he is abroad for "The Nun's Story" with Audrey Hepburn.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Four racing yachts suffered damage estimated at a total of $50,000 today in a dockside jam touched off when another yacht went out of control while under tow.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 8 -- Leading Britons believe that their country's rich political experience, not the possibility of a rebirth of its military power, will be the major British contribution in negotiating coexistence between East and West, according to a Princeton University report released today.

SOME time in the remote past, perhaps three or four billion years ago, the earth was ready for a subtle and explosive sea-change -- the coming of life. An enormously complex mixture of chemical substances existed in the oceans. Tides stirred the ingredients; radiation from the sun warmed them and provided energy for the synthesis of new compounds.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The British Government has decided to assign a considerable proportion of its defense expenditure in men, money and material to anti-submarine forces in the North Atlantic.

THE Soviet earth satellites and the rapidly moving events that have followed confront the United States with possibly the gravest propaganda crisis since America became a world power. The launching of our own "moon" has by no means halted the march of Soviet propaganda.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Feb. 8 -- The Police Association of Suffolk County will honor Ray R. Leighton, former Huntington Town Police Chief, at a dinner next Wednesday. The dinner will be held at Geide's Inn in Centerport.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Would a tax cut to fight the business recession lead to a future problem of inflation?

BETWEEN 6:30 and 8 o'clock tonight a fragment of Holland will be simulated in a television studio in Brooklyn. The occasion will be the production of "Hans Brinker or the Silver Skates" in the "Hallmark Hall of Fame Series" on the National Broadcasting Company network.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 8 -- The Dutch Government has rebuffed, calmly but completely, recent Soviet efforts to undermine its support of the Atlantic alliance and participation in Western security.

DAVIS W. Va. -- A few years ago skiers displaced below the Mason-Dixon line either had to give up the sport or make the long trip north. But today the skiing boom has reached into the South, where there are mountains high and cold enough to retain skiable snow.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- The tropical atmosphere of Puerto Rico was supercharged last week with several kinds of excitement and it was difficult to tell which caused a greater stir among the natives and the visiting Continentals (an island phrase for Americans down from the mainland).
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Feb. 8 -- Yale University's freshmen swimming team scored its forty-second consecutive triumph since 1955 by defeating the Hill School, 50 -- 36, in Cunningham Pool today.

While the United States' Explorer satellite has been in orbit for only a little more than a week, it has already transmitted to earth by its highly "sophisticated" instruments valuable preliminary information on conditions in the upper atmosphere at a distance of about 220 to 1,600 miles above the earth.

THAT lively trade paper, Variety -- "the bible of show biz," as they say -- has a cute little way of sticking needles under the skin of the movie industry. It likes to work up "dope stories" that make slyly vexatious points when directed at particular sensitive areas, of which the industry has plenty these days.

NEW YORK State's motor vehicle inspection program has just entered its second year with owners of 1939 or older vehicles required to pass the annual safety check this month. The testing covers four items: brakes, lights, steering and wheel alignment, the same as last year.

CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 5 -- One of the last acts of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Conservative Government of Canada, prior to calling a general election for March 31, was to appoint a native Indian to the Canadian Senate.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 8. (UP) -- Investigation into the unsuccessful flight of the Air Force's Atlas intercontinental missile raised speculation today that a fluke radio signal might have knocked down the missile by fouling its guidance system.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 8 -- The Rev. Sidney Lovett, Yale University chaplain known as "Uncle Sid" to students for more than a quarter of a century, will retire at the end of the academic year on June 30.
ROME, Feb. 5 -- A well-publicized pilgrimage by seven Roman Catholic Lithuanians to see Pope Pius XII is interpreted here as another move in the current Soviet campaign of blandishing the Vatican.

TO those who missed it in the daily papers, the news of the week is that Italy has won the world contract bridge championship again -- the second victory in a row for the Italians, the fourth in a row for Europe over America. To those who saw the results, the question is, Why?
MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev recently presided over an important gathering of Soviet economic planners and party leaders in Moscow, it was announced tonight.

An increasing number of columns and letters have appeared in the country's press pointing to the urgent and delicate problem of legislating with regard to the disability of the President to perform his duties of office and the transfer of these duties to the Vice President.
The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, former president of Fordham University, last night criticized Roman Catholic educators who had charged there were not enough Catholic "intellectuals."

One of the most important changes resulting from the long post-war effort to reform United States tariff procedures will go into effect on the 27th of this month. On that date the country will largely abandon its historic (and notorious) "dual system" of determining the value of imports subject to ad valorem duties.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Britain plans to double the number of her trained scientists in the next decade. Education Minister Geoffrey Lloyd told industrialists here this week that 11,700 scientists were graduated in 1956.
The market in second-hand ships continued its downward trend in the first month of 1958, threatening to carry last year's sharp drop in values well into a second year.

THE release by Caedmon of Wallace Stevens must be more an act of piety than of commerce, for it would be hard to think of a poet whose work is less effective on records than that of Stevens. Poetry was for him less a mode of feeling than an intellectual act, and he was deflected from his own austere probing of reality neither by early indifference nor later renown.

There is no Iron Curtain blocking American electrical engineers from observing the Russian power industry, according to a paper on "Electrical Engineering Education and Research in the U. S. S. R." read Friday to the American Institute of Electrical Engineering.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Feb. 8 -- Tengku (Prince) Abdul Rahman, Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, returned here today from visits to South Vietnam, Thailand and Ceylon eager to have a meeting of the heads of Southeast Asian countries to discuss their common problems.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 8 -- Critics of county government spending took aim this week at plans by Hudson's nine Freeholders to seat themselves in custom swivel chairs at white Carrara marble-topped desks costing $1,136 a set.

JUST ten months ago yesterday Sophia Loren arrived in Hollywood on a massive wave of publicity to contribute her sultry talent to "Desire Under the Elms." However, the conjunction of the Italian pin-up girl and the Eugene O'Neill drama of boiling passions that movie producers had found too censorable to handle for more than thirty years, wasn't, by any means, the only cause of the excitement.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. Feb. 8 -- The women moved in here this year and just about took over the twenty-first annual Silver Sailfish Derby. Nothing like it has been seen before and it may be a dark omen that men are about to become obsolete.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Parry O'Brien, the world and Olympic record-holder for the shot-put, bettered his world indoor mark tonight with a heave of 18.81 meters (61 feet 8 1/2 inches) during an international meet at the Festhalle Stadium.

TODAY'S column follows from the fact that there is no business about which the general reading public knows less than it does about the book-publishing business. It couldn't seem to care less, either. Ask the friend who has just urged you to read "My Mother Was No Lady" and the chances are he will be unable to tell you who published it.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 8 -- Ceylon signed an aid agreement with the United States yesterday and a trade agreement with the Soviet Union today.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 8 -- A gift to Brown University for a center for research and experimentation on electronic computing and data processing equipment was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities said today that the Communist operation in the United States was presenting a menace more serious than ever.
NEWARK, Feb. 8 -- New Jersey's Commissioner of Labor and Industry proposed today that the national Administration resort to pump priming to block a full-scale depression.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 8 -- Born Rich, a gray daughter of Stymie, found the kind of an off track she likes today and raced to a surprise victory in the $57,300 Santa Margarita Handicap for fillies and mares at Santa Anita.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 5 -- An energetic man who is considered the leading farm authority in Suffolk County completed thirty years of service to farmers on eastern Long Island this week.
Governor Harriman said last night that improved unemployment benefits were needed to meet the increase in lay-offs.
MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 8 -- Nassau County continued its rapid population growth last year to remain one of the fastest growing communities in the nation.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Gay Vista, an Australian speedster, was pushed to the limit by T. A. Grissom's Stag Line in the early running, but won the $10,000 Black Gold Handicap at the New Orleans Fair Grounds today and tied a fifteen-year-old track record.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 8 -- Rumors of a rift in the Cabinet of Premier Adnan Menderes received apparent substantiation tonight. The Government's Anatolian News Agency announced the shift of Samet Agaoglu from Minister of Industry to State Minister.

FIFTY years ago this week, at the Macbeth Galleries in New York, a single exhibition of paintings overthrew the reactionary dominance of academic art in America. Like 1789, 1908 marks a date when, suddenly, a whole moribund, but still powerful, establishment collapsed.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- The people of West Germany are aware that they must be prepared for sacrifices to maintain freedom, Willy Brandt, Mayor of West Berlin, said here today.

A twilight dinner dance, called Gotham in the Spring, is being planned by a men's committee of former members of the various military services. A benefit for the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club, it will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Easter Sunday, April 6.

Ron Delany stepped a bit out of character last nght and tried for the world indoor mile record. He missed it by one second, but his time of 4 minutes 4.6 seconds was the second fastest in the fifty-one year history of the Millrose Athletic Association Games, in which Denmark's Gunnar Nielsen three years ago set the target mark of 4:03.6.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Defense Department, in an unusual review of progress and planning, forecast today a new arsenal of space weapons to replace missiles now in development.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 8 -- Undergraduates who have difficulty in getting to early morning classes may find an example in S. Harbert Hamilton.

WHENEVER Jack Kramer has waved large chunks of folding money in front of a top-ranking amateur tennis player and lured him into his troupe of touring professionals, the Boy Promoter has baited his trap in the winter. But he switched tactics last year when he tucked a $125,000 guarantee into the wallet of Lew Hoad of Australia. This was in July, almost six months before the tour was scheduled to begin.

Steps are being taken by the Greek shipping fraternity toward placing firm floors under present tramp shipping rates. At the moment, the drive is concerned only with Greek-controlled dry-cargo ships.

Dame Myra Hess gave a piano recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, playing before a sold-out house that overflowed on the stage. The veteran British pianist selected a program that demanded unflagging concentration from her and from the audience.

HUMANITY'S view of events in the Holy Land often seems affected by the extraordinary high-angled sunshine and clear air that places every scene flat and naked on the landscape, without explanatory shadows. The Textile Workers Union of America yesterday decided not to press for major contract changes for 65,000 workers.
BONN, Feb. 8 -- Soviet and Polish proposals to disengage NATO and Warsaw Pact forces in Europe are the subject of a continuing debate between the Government and the Opposition in west Germany.

ONE of the extra-legal writing judges who are so busy this publishing season, Michael A. Musmanno here tells of his first ten years as lawyer and Pennsylvania State legislator. Although filled with what his profession calls obiter dicta, Judge Musmanno's recollections are interesting to read because they give insight into the practice of law on the human rather than the corporate level.

RUMFORD, Me., Feb. 8 -- A Southern-born New Jerseyite, who lived in Finland for five of his pre-teen years, captured the national 15 - kilometer cross-country skiing championship today.

Uncertainty created as to the extent and duration of the business recession took some of the zest out of the stock market last week. And the possibility that a tax cut may be necessary to stem the trend was of little help.

Prohibition of nuclear weapons testing and increased authority for the United Nations were recommended by the Federation of American Scientists yesterday as steps "along the road to world peace."

FRENCH film producers are breathing a little easier now. In spite of the recent rise in film theatre admission prices, moviegoing has remained about the same, which has led to some optimism in local screen circles.

"Rumors of Violence Curtailing School Attendance." "Instructor Stabbed." "Two Students Seized. Threatened to Shoot Teacher's Husband." And finally, following the rape of a 13-year-old girl, "Head of School Beset by Crime Leaps to Death."

IN establishing with revelatory clarity the status of George Balanchine as the creative force of which the entity of the New York City Ballet is simply the emanation, the company's recent season became possibly the most important, certainly the most definitive, of its history.

Formula for rapid growth in a highly-competitive business: Merge judiciously. Press new-product development hard. And don't hesitate to change the complexion of your operations if higher profit margins beckon elsewhere.

The biggest such festival is the St. Paul, Minn., Winter Carnival, which was first held in a burst of civic pride in 1886 after a visiting Eastern journalist had dared describe Minnesota's capital as "another Siberia, unfit for human habitation."

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Fordham University rowed to a one-length victory over Rollins College on Lake Maitland's one-mile course today. It was the Rams' second triumph over Florida crews in five days.
PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Twenty-five French bombers and fighters raided a Tunisian village near the Algerian frontier today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Thirteen Senators were named today to a special committee that will frame legislation for the coordinated exploration and development of outer space.
VIENNA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia's Communist Government says the country increased its industrial production by 10.2 per cent in 1957 over 1956.

IN Morris L. West's BACKLASH (Morrow, $3.50), Maj. Mark Hanlon, Commander of the British Occupation Forces in the village of Bad Quellenberg, first appears as an able and humane officer whose desire to establish a decent Occupation is complicated by the necessity of solving the unprovoked murder of one of his men.
" The Commercial Impact of Synthetic Rubber" will be the theme of the annual New York meeting of the Commercial Chemical Development Association to be held March 27 at the Statler-Hilton Hotel here.

THE ancient truism that it is better to listen to music than to read about it applies to children of all ages as it does to adults. But listening can be stimulated by reading, just as listening can induce reading.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Roy Sievers, who last season led the American League in home runs and runs batted in while hitting .301 for the Washington Senators, said today he wanted a 100 per cent increase in salary for the 1958 season.

The skywatchers are looking for something other than the Army's man-made satellite. They have an eye peeled for future activity in the field of business. The long range planners, looking well ahead, are fairly certain that all the statistics are in their favor.
Seals of approval, the agencies that grant them and the concerns that print them are multiplying as self-service retailing expands.
WELLINGTON, N. Z., Feb. 8 (Reuters) -- Mechanical difficulties held up today the trans-Antarctic march of Dr. Vivian E. Fuchs and his British team.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- An atmosphere resembling armistice negotiations between contending powers is developing here as Governor Harriman, a Democrat, and the Republican majorities in the Legislature grope toward compromises on conflicting programs.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 8 -- Senor Orlich conceded defeat tonight. Although the voting tally gives Mario Echandi slightly more than 104,000 votes against approximately 98,000 for Senor Orlich, the loser's party had refused to concede on the ground that faulty voting procedure had invalidated thousands of votes, it should have received.

Columbia University announced yesterday that Dr. Richard N. Gardner, Associate Professor of Law, had been named Visiting Professor of Law to the University of Istanbul, Turkey, for the spring semester.

Richard Kay, 'cellist, who made his New York solo debut in 1950 and is now first 'cellist with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, played a program of twentieth-century works for unaccompanied 'cello late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.
GENEVA, Feb. 5 -- A pilot who can navigate the complexities of the English language can make his way with ease along the air lanes of the world.

The Celestini, an orphanage in Prato, Italy, will be the beneficiary of A Renaissance Night in Italy Ball to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on April 22.
HAVANA, Feb. 8 -- A revolutionary expedition landed at Colorada Beach south of Niquero in Oriente Province two days ago, according to a report reaching Havana.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Mongi Slim, the Tunisian Ambassador, called on Joseph Palmer 2d, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for North African Affairs, this morning to convey the serious view that his Government took of the attack by French planes.

The chemise Silhouette has become the dominant factor in dresses and lingerie, and even in sports and sleep wear the influence is apparent sources in the buying offices report. Summer lines are now being reviewed.
Princeton's fencing team gained a 15-12 victory over Columbia at University Hall yesterday. It was the Lions' first Ivy League setback in three seasons.

AS a librarian I wish to protest the review of "The Movies," by Richard Griffith and Arthur Mayer. * * * The vast panorama unfolded with unusual artistry in, by all odds, the best volume ever published on the subject is completely ignored by your reviewer Seymour Peck, who seems to think that the authors should have presented him with a personal listing of his favorite films and actors.

IN connection with the New York premiere of my opera "The Transposed Heads" the question is bound to arise, just how, and to what extent have Oriental musical ingredients been used in this work? Such a query is pertinent, since it touches upon the vital difference between "arrangement" and synthesis -- the one superficial, the other an organic process.

EASIER accessibility because of the New York State Thruway and excellent connecting roads has made such western and central Adirondack Mountain skiing retreats as Snow Ridge at Turin, Maple Ridge at Old Forge and the Oak Mountain Ski Area at Speculator more popular than ever with the winter-sports crowd.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported today in New England and the Weather Bureau forecast:
Legislative leaders in Albany are determined to hammer out a solution to New York State's branch banking and holding company problems this session, industry sources are convinced.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
Work on the great St. Lawrence Seaway project, which will open the middle of the continent to deep-sea shipping, is moving into the home stretch.

Your excellent article, "Astronomical Number of Sky Watchers" by Donald G. Cooley (Jan. 26) did a good job in telling the public some of the activities of amateur astronomers, whose numbers have increased since the satellites were sent aloft.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 8 -- The Defense Ministry is preparing an amendment to the 1956 conscription law that would enable 19-year-old West German youths to reduce their military service by enlisting in territorial defense forces.
Racial integration is increasing in activities of the Young Women's Christian Association across the country, a review of its membership noted yesterday.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- This coral - studded British island resort is back in business again as a major winter-vacation center. The hotels and nightclubs are open, the tourists are back sunning themselves and the colony is out to make up for the losses in its $38,924,000 annual holiday trade which were incurred during last month's general strike.

THE deep emotional power of "Sunrise at Campobello" is not simple to explain. Although Dore Schary's script is well written, although Ralph Bellamy's performance as F. D. R. is remarkable, neither the one nor the other is great enough to account for the profound impression the production makes on the audience.

SO many interesting and exciting books have been published here in the past year that the publishers, spurred by the purest frustration, have hauled out and re-examined the skeleton in the Italian cultural closet. For the dreadful truth is that, generally speaking, Italians do not read books.

IN variety, prolific output, inventiveness and the scope of his influence Paul Klee has probably been Picasso's closest rival. This is the more remarkable in that their work was so different and their philosophic attitudes in many ways were diametrically opposed.

FIFTEEN years ago a large number of Americans passed through Algeria on their way to the victorious conclusion of World War II. They formed varying impressions of the ubiquitous "Ayrabs" who pressed hungry noses against the windows of their mess-halls, slowed down their trucks at busy market-places, wanted to shine their shoes and wore what looked like sheets.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 8 -- The carnival of sports on the Plain was a successful one today for Army's varsity forces as the cadets scored six victories in as many contests, including two major upsets.

EVERY year sees the emergence of small, hopeful record companies. Some stay in business; others depart fast. These days, now that the LP classical catalogue has become more or less stabilized, a small company cannot succeed in bucking the giants.

WITH the help of Gerald Brenan in Malaga, Honor Tracy planned an interesting itinerary across Spain from Gibraltar and Algeciras to Vigo. The time: summer of 1955. She went first to Cadiz, Arcos de la Frontera, Jerez, Sevilla, Huelva and La Rabida.
I hope every public school board and P.-T. A. member will read and deliberate over Marc Raeff's article.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 8 -- Moroccan Government circles were deeply disturbed tonight over the French bombing of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef. They called it one of the gravest events of the three-year-old Algerian war.
For his New York Philharmonic appearance at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, Rudolf Serkin resurrected a novelty -- the Piano Concerto in F minor by Max Reger.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 9 -- A mass rally held today in Padang, capital of the anti-Communist Province of Central Sumatra, demanded that President Sukarno dissolve his hand-picked cabinet. The meeting also asked that former Vice President Mohammed Hatta and the Sultan of Jogjakarta be appointed to draft a new Indonesian Government.

Three patrolmen received awards of honorable mention yesterday for bravery on duty. The awards, among the highest given by the Police Department, were among 223 citations presented by Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

WEST ORANGE N J., Feb. 19 -- A warning against over-standardization of education was voiced today by Norman R. Speiden, supervising curator of the Edison Laboratory National Monument here today. He spoke on a public tour of the laboratory to mark the 111th anniversary of Thomas A. Edison's birth on Tuesday.
A 23-year-old laborer was arrested yesterday on a charge of setting a four-alarm fire that swept three tenements at Amsterdam Avenue and Sixty-first Street Saturday.

CHRISTINEHAMN, Sweden, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Inga Artamanova retained her over-all title with a powerful performance in the 3,000-meter finale today as Russia swept the first four places in the women's world speed-skating championships.
Three men active in chartering and ship operating were named in staff changes announced over the week-end.

Oscar Panno of Argentina held his lead in the chess championship of the Americas by triumphing yesterday in an adjourned twelfth-round game, according to a report received here through Colombian news sources.
Mississippi is planning to sell $20,000,000 of school bonds on March 6. The securities will be dated April 1, 1958, and will come due serially on April 1 from 1959 to 1973.
The stage appeared to be set yesterday for the City Council to approve Mayor Wagner's request that it ask the Legislature to pass his bill setting up a commission to revise this city's Charter.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9 -- The slightly better tone in the steel market will not be reflected in the steel production rate. This is because order volume in recent weeks has been below the operating rate of many companies so the catching-up period is not yet complete for the industry.
Unless immediate action is taken to reform the courts in New York State, many years may pass before current legislative proposals are revived, Louis N. Loeb said yesterday.
A panel of five high school students agreed yesterday on the need for Federal aid to education. They differed, however, on some of the other issues facing Congress this year.
"THE KING SAYS FAREWELL TO HIS FAVORITE," a 2,000-year-old Chinese opera, was presented at Hunter College on Saturday evening by the Yenching Alumni Association.
THE underfed, indoor, super-sophisticated fashion model s fading out of the picture.
The worst cold wave of the year held the metropolitan area in a frozen grasp today. The Weather Bureau said it would remain "very cold" through tomorrow.

It's hard to get through a day without hearing a cliche. Probably impossible, as long as you hear any words at all. You thought you and your partner had the golf game in the bag, but the other two fellows didn't play according to Hoyle and so they upset the applecart.
THE entire cast of "Tosca" Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera seemed stimulated by the presence of Eleanor Steber in the title role.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Nick Mickoski scored in the final 12 seconds tonight to enable the Detroit Red Wings to post a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The Hawks dropped into sole possession of the National Hockey League cellar as a result of the setback.
Joseph Hayes, whose suspense melodrama "The Desparate Hours" scored a successful run on Broadway in 1955, has completed a new play, called "The Midnight Sun."
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 9 -- Dave Beck was reported on his way from Seattle today to appeal for his retention as chairman of the committee that administers the teamster pension system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission accused the Shell Oil Company of New York today of "unfair business practices." It charged that Shell gave its customers inducements to "discontinue handling competitors' petroleum products."
There is nothing seriously wrong with our economy now that vigorous and enlightened leadership cannot quickly overcome.
"I am not disposed to claim that the Anglican Church is the 'True Church,'" the Very Rev. James A. Pike, dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine; said yesterday.

The American Bankers Association announced yesterday the establishment of a special five-man committee to work with the Federal Reserve Board, other interested agencies and Congress toward reduction and reform of member bank reserve requirements.

One hundred and sixty-five years ago George Washington laid the foundation stone for our National Capitol. General Washington said "It has grandeur, simplicity and beauty." It was completed in 1829, the result of the genius of three of our early architects, Thornton, Latrobe and Bulfinch. This central building stands today as approved by the founders of the Republic.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 9 -- Romulo Betancourt, former President of Venezuela and leader of the Democratic Action party, said here today that he had returned "to help Venezuela." He announced an "irrevocable decision" to serve the country "without any ambition for power."
CHARLES PETREMONT, the Boston violinist last heard here in 1948, returned to Carnegie Hall last night to play a recital that left hearers perplexed as to what to make of him.
ZURICH, Feb. 9 -- After Stock Exchange business closed on Friday, unexpected developments made Interhandel affairs front-page week-end news.

Jimmy Butler, a Yorkshireman, celebrated his fortieth birthday yesterday in grand style. His job is handling dogs professionally. He put in a highly successful business day at the Associated Terrier Clubs event at the 212th AAA Group Armory.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 9 -- A belief that provincial life under ancient Greek colonialism was far different from that under Roman imperialism has been supported by new evidence. It was collected by Princeton University archaeologists who discovered a lost city in Sicily last fall.
Track and field's spectacular local bow in the Millrose Games sets the stage for further high excitement at Madison Square Garden on the next four Saturdays.

THE last time Mickey Cochrane served on a big league squad was in 1950. The Philadelphia Athletics brought him back as a coach and the high-spirited Black Mike was delighted at the chance. One sizzling day in West Palm Beach the incongruity of it all suddenly hit him.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Lionel Hebert of Lafayette, La., today won the $15,000 Tucson open golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 265, fifteen under par.

There are two equally good but quite different reasons for visiting the new exhibition of Korean art at the Metropolitan Museum. Both are apart from the element of novelty, even if this is the first exhibit of its kind to be seen here.

RUMFORD, Me., Feb. 9 -- Ken House of Iron Mountain, Mich., the smallest competitor in a twenty-man Class A field, turned in two big leaps today to capture the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association jumping championship.

What happened last Saturday morning at the Tunisian market town of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef, just across the border from war-torn Algeria, is now the center of a widening circle of irreparable tragedy. It was a pitiful calamity to perhaps fourscore dead and an equal number wounded, to residents who fled from their wrecked or threatened homes, to hundreds of peasants and villagers who had come in for a holiday.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Carl H. Pforzheimer Jr. of Purchase, Westchester, was reported tonight as a probable Republican choice for one of two vacancies on the Board of Regents. He is former president of the United Jewish Appeal.

THE Dutch probably are the greatest fanciers of herring. Each spring, they have a festival to celebrate the return of the fishing fleets with the first herring catch of the season. On the streets of Amsterdam, push cart venders sell herring in the same way hot dogs are offered here.

Television set production last year dropped by 1,000,000 units, compared with 1956, the Electronic Industries Association reported over the week-end. The group, to which most important receiver makers belong, put 1957 output at 6,400,000 sets.
Governor Harriman charged last night that discrimination was "blatantly defended -- discrimination in our schools, in job opportunity, in housing."
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- An expert in population trends urged medical educators today to plan now for a substantial increase in the demand for medical services.
Trans World Airlines has agreed to become the first American airline flying international routes to hire a Negro as a flight stewardess.
Four new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

The Battle of Gettysburg is the subject of at least three books scheduled for April publication. The first to appear will be "The Battle of Gettysburg," written a few weeks after the battle by Frank A. Haskell, a Union officer who took part in it.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- Tunisia protested to the United Nations today against the bombing by French warplanes of the village of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef, near the Algerian border.
The scope of Title I of the National Housing Act should be extended to permit the rebuilding of rundown commercial and industrial areas, according to the Metropolitan Regional Council.

Ch. Marjack's Golden Windjammer, owned by Mr. and Mrs. John P. Wagner of Chicago, gained best of breed last night at the fifteenth annual specialty show of the American Boxer Club. The show was held at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory. It drew 268 dogs.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 9 -- A young airman "stepped into space" today at the School of Aviation Medicine at Randolph Air Force Base. The airman is Donald G. Farrell, 23 years old, of 513 Commonwealth Avenue, the Bronx....
Leffert Holz last night declined to confirm reports in political circles that he intended to resign as State Superintendent of Insurance.

The State Attorney General said yesterday it was time to consider what he called the plight of teachers in the city's schools. He urged "more parental responsibility in connection with juvenile delinquency."

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 9 -- Although the stock market started last week with a strong demand for international and selected domestic issues, interest later declined and gains were reduced. The index, however, advanced to 180 from 177 for the week before.
The long downward plunge of the steamship charter market was halted last week. The dry cargo freight rate index rose one-tenth of a percentage point.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- At Northwood School a house party week-end is one of the year's major events. Tonight the annual winter house party week-end came to a close. And since Northwood is located in one of the East's big winter resorts, there was a diversified sports program.
SIEGFRIED LANDAU led the Brooklyn Philharmonia and the choirs of the Manhasset (L. I.) Congregational Church on Saturday night in an admirable performance of Giuseppe Verdi's Requiem Mass.
PARIS, Feb. 9 -- The people who died under French bombs in the Tunisian village of Sakiet - Sidi - Youssef yesterday were the victims of a tragic conflict in logic, French and Tunisian.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Eisenhower-Truman feud, now in its fifth year, is apparently still going great guns.

Two more contracts dropped into the Yankees' hopper yesterday. Lee MacPhail, the assistant general manager, announced the signing of two first basemen, the 35-year-old Joe Collins and the 26-year-old John Jaciuk.

VIARMES, France, Feb. 9 -- One can detect in Western Europe today a groping toward a new political alignment. This is a Franco-German axis which, with Italian support and within NATO's over-all framework, might eventually replace the famous Anglo-French entente cordiale.
EVER since Christmas, New York stores have been the scene of a weird paradox. Women bundled up in winter coats are buying summer cottons.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 9 -- The Arab Kings seemed to have struck a snag today in their efforts to find a practical answer to the merger of Egypt and Syria.

A syndicate of investors headed by Herman Kerbel and Jack Zipes bought the ten-story apartment building at 2860 -- 66 Broadway, at the northeast corner of West 111th Street. The property is on a plot 75 by 225 feet and contains 137 apartments and five stores.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 9 -- The East German Communist organ urged today an unrelenting struggle against ideas identifiable with the three leaders expelled last week from the party's Central Committee and Politburo.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Australian swimmers set one world record tonight but failed in two other record attempts at the 55-yard North Sydney Olympic Pool.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Pancho Gonzales defeated Lew Hoad, 24 -- 22, in the second set and went on to beat his Australian rival, two sets to one, before a capacity crowd of 7,000 today.

TROY, N. Y., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Laurence Owen, representing the Skating Club of Boston, today captured the senior women's title at the Eastern figure skating, championships. Gregory Kelley, also of the Boston club, won the men's championship last night.

THE Quartetto di Roma, a new chamber music group that began its first United States tour with a concert at the Library of Congress last month, made its New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. It was a resounding success.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -- "Studio One in Hollywood" will present Elizabeth Montgomery and Gig Young on March 10 in "A Man After His Own Heart," the working title for a play by Madeline and Henry Misrock.

A GROWING development in Italian fashion circles is he ready-to-wear business being done by the grand couturiers. Even the French have ome to Italy for these clothes, which some call boutique and ome confection.

Working through sixty institutions and services, the Salvation Army extends its helping hand to the people of New York City, fulfilling material needs and services. Last year Family Service Bureaus helped 5,203 families with serious troubles.
AN engrossing visit to Pitcairn Island, including an underwater search for remnants of H. M. S. Bounty, was shown on "Omnibus" over Channel 4 yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The Government's determination to maintain the credit squeeze for some time is now generally accepted here.
The Right Rev. John B. Bentley told church members yesterday not to build "a wall around the church," but rather to give their full support to missionary work.
CAIRO, Feb. 9 -- Egypt has been conferring in the last few days with Saudi Arabia about the possible adherence of that Arab monarchy to an Arab federation led by President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

A new production of "Madama Butterfly" on Wednesday evening, Feb. 19, will be a feature of the seventeenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season.

We don't believe President Eisenhower was being disingenuous when he came out at his press conference last week for bringing the Alaska and Hawaii statehood bills up "simultaneously." PARIS, Feb. 9 -- The Government's National Credit Council has set this year's volume of short-and medium-term credits from banks to private enterprise at three trillion francs ($7 billion).

Lourdes was described yesterday as the "most Catholic shrine in the world" by the Rev. Harry J. Wolff at the 10 A. M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Father Wolff, a member of the cathedral staff, said that after Rome, Lourdes was the "Catholic city par excellence."
Two more state officials turned their attention to New York City's troubled school situation yesterday.

ONE day in 1881 Eugene Moran Sr., for years head of the Moran towing fleet, came to Manhattan from Brooklyn with his father. They stopped at 2 Broadway, east of Bowling Green. The boy was fascinated by workmen swarming over a new foundation for the Produce Exchange.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Raoul Salan, French commander in Algeria, declared tonight that aerial photographs of the bombed Tunisian village of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef showed nine-tenths of it to be intact.

The quietest of the six places at which dogs were concentrated in New York yesterday was the basement of Madison Square Garden. It will be different today and tomorrow. That's when the Westminster Kennel Club show will occupy the premises.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The Southern Coal Producers Association called on Congress today to end the civilian atomic power development program of the Atomic Energy Commission.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 2 -- The "black fruit" will be ripening soon on a tree that grows in the Northern Transvaal.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- One hefty buying splurge last week gave grain futures prices a sufficient gain on the Board of Trade to offset all or most of their losses on the other days.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- Had a prize been awarded for the oldest competitor in today's third annual Old-Timers ski jumping tournament it would have gone, hands down, to the 65-year-old Oscar Haug of Providence.
WHILE mother is debating about the chemise, children are gobbling it up. According to Altman's, the long, loose torso is incredibly successful with its young clientele.

Earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company in 1957 were down only 4 per cent from the year before despite an 8.5 per cent decline in sales. The figures were released by John D. Biggers, chairman and G. P. MacNichol Jr., president, in their annual statement issued to stockholders today.

TORONTO, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister John G. Diefenbaker declared here last night that an international agency should be established to control outer space. He addressed the Ontario Section of the Canadian Bar Association.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Kansas City Philharmonic, short $50,000, has scheduled a special benefit concert that they hope will wipe out the deficit.
"HANS BRINKER" was brought to television last night in a musical version consisting of about equal parts of the children's story and a skating exhibition starring Dick Button, Olympic champion.
MONGI SLIM of Tunisia wears three hats and does a good deal of commuting. He is his country's chief representative to the United Nations and its Ambassador to both the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Secretary of State Dulles called the French Ambassador to his home today to express United States concern over yesterday's French air attack on a Tunisian border town.

Whether the government, in its present form, will survive is an open question.

It was clearly demonstrated at Madison Square Garden last night that no team can spot the Canadiens of Montreal three goals and get anywhere. The New York Rangers were in that unhappy position and they lost, 3 to 1.

The appointment of a new Davis Cup team captain to succeed William Talbert was among the sweeping changes in the administration and direction of the affairs of the United States Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday by the newly elected president, Victor Denny of Seattle.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -- Prizes for directorial achievements in 1957, presented last night by the Screen Directors Guild, went begging in a sense. None of the five principal winners was present at the organization's annual awards banquet held in the Biltmore Bowl.
The Regional Plan Association and the New York Chamber of Commerce yesterday called for legislative action to improve mass transportation in the metropolitan area.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews announced yesterday it was conferring thirteen National Brotherhood Awards for outstanding work in mass communications last year "in the cause of brotherhood." The recipients follow:

KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 9 (UP) -- Billy Martin of the Detroit Tigers smashed a pair of doubles today to pace the American League All-Stars to a 4-3 victory over the National League in 2 charity game staged by the Major League Baseball Players Association.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Ed Chadwick, the Toronto Maple Leafs' goalie, scored his fourth shutout of the National Hockey League season as the Leafs beat the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 0, before 13,503 at the Garden tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has told Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin that he is willing to participate in a heads-of-government conference. But he said in reply to the Soviet leader's letter of Jan. 9 that there must be "a reasonable prospect of achieving concrete results on specific issues."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The troubles of the House subcommittee investigating the Federal Government's big regulatory agencies appeared headed for a climax tomorrow. The dismissal of the subcommittee's chief counsel is expected, followed by a fight on the House floor.
FREEPORT, L. I., Feb. 9 -- Plans for a new Town of Hempstead recreation area here are being studied by town officials.
Dartmouth continued unbeaten in the Ivy League and stayed on top of the loop with two basketball victories last week. Yet the Big Green faced its hardest chore from a surprising quarter -- Columbia.
