A forty-foot widening of Fulton Street to provide traffic relief near downtown Brooklyn's $125,000,000 Civic Center was proposed yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore.
James P. Warburg, author and foreign affairs analyst, outlined yesterday a program to "make coexistence more tolerable."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate Republican leader hit back today at Democratic charges the Eisenhower Administration was letting the country slide into a major depression. He said the Administration would start a public works program if necessary to halt the downward trend of the economy.
A sense of futility pervades most official activity on the narcotic problem, according to the state's joint Legislative Committee on Narcotic Study.
A back-seat device said to measure for the first time piston ring wear under actual driving conditions has been developed by the Esso Research and Engineering Company.
WARSAW, Feb. 9 -- The Polish Government is about to start the most serious of a number of campaigns undertaken in recent years against alcoholism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, referred today to President Eisenhower's assistant, Sherman Adams, as "Acting President."

How TO RU-W A SUCCESSFUL INVESTMENT CLUB. By Raymond Trigger. 115 pp. Harper Brothers, lew York. $2.75. This book is a delight to read, perhaps because it deals with a lively, pertinent and everbroadening subject--inrestment clubs.

HAVANA, Feb. 9 -- Sabotage by rebel elements is increasing in the three eastern provinces of Cuba, according to reports from that area. The chief targets are transportation services and commercial establishments.

AN excellent string ensemble from the Netherlands made its debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. It was the Netherlands String Quartet, and behind its appearance was a story of co-operation and devotion as gravely touching as the ensemble's playing.

DOWN small gullets into outraged, stomachs flows a steady stream of common household poisons. High on the list are lye, kerosene, ammonia, oil of wintergreen, insect and rat poisons, ink and turpentine.

Governor Harriman and State Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo traded recriminations yesterday over legislation to increase state unemployment compensation. They appeared on separate television programs.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont., Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The Algoma Steel Corporation, Ltd., had net profit in 1957 of $14,178,000, or $2.49 a share, compared with $15,714,000, or $2.76 a share, in 1956, David S. Hol-

The second floor of the former Wanamaker department store building at Broadway and Ninth Street has been leased by the American Express Company to house its money order accounting department. The lease involved 55,000 square feet of space and was negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company, represented by Robert V. Cronan, vice president.

The latest purge in the ruling hierarchy of East Germany's Communists has far more than local importance. The world has long known that there was massive discontent in East Germany -- a discontent evidenced dramatically and tragically in June, 1953, and less dramatically by the continued large flow of escapees to West Germany.
The State Power Authority predicted yesterday that "honest, non-political, business-like" direction of the Niagara power project would dispel any misgivings about it plans and objectives.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- The economy of Bolivia has taken a dramatic change for the better. Perhaps "epochal" is the word.

Last week this space carried an introductory piece about a new and live study titled "Foreign Central Banking: The Instruments of Monetary Policy" prepared and authored by Peter G. Fousek with the cooperation of his colleagues in the Foreign Research Division of the New York Reserve Bank.

Boy Scouts massed in churches of their denominations here yesterday for ceremonies in observance of Boy Scout Sunday. They were told that by living in accord with the principles of their faiths and the Scout movement they never would become juvenile delinquents.

The American Cyanamid Company, maker of a diversified line of chemical, pharmaceutical and allied products, last year achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual results released today.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 9 -- Today was the third anniversary of the merger compact that ended twenty years of war between the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Business men, teachers and 400 families in a Brooklyn community that has had its share of juvenile delinquency have joined to emphasize juvenile decency.
Schools, roads and zoning are the more spectacular aspects of suburban growth. But there are others, less apparent although equally vital. One is the expansion of public health services.
Cotton futures prices turned firm on the New York Cotton Exchange last week after a shaky start and closed the period with mixed net changes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Justice Department has asked a Federal District court to reverse a ruling forbiding the Pacific Far East Steamship Line to operate unsubsidized vessels between the Pacific Coast and Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The oldest known site of human habitation in the southeastern United States has been given to the Federal Government as a national archeological monument. The gift of Russell Cave, where Stone Age Americans lived 9,000 years ago, was announced today by the National Geographic Society through its president, Melville Bell Grosvenor.

According to the news report of a speech of Sherman Adams to the Dartmouth alumni, President Eisenhower is considering the idea of a world-wide cultural conference to seek "new and better ways for human beings to exist peaceably together."
The French air attack on a Tunisian village Saturday was stressed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Edward O. Miller in a sermon marking Race Relations Sunday.
Norwegian shipping men last week renewed a campaign against a trend that has most major maritime nations worried.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A rare legal paper in Abraham Lincoln's handwriting, which has been in private hands for 100 years, has just come to light here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Members of a House Appropriations subcommittee have urged the Interior Department to speed its research on converting salt water to fresh.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 9 -- Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, a right-wing candidate, won first place in the Presidential election Jan. 19 by more than 52,000 votes, official figures disclosed today.

Ch. Averill's Maximilian, a 4-year-old bulldog owned by Mrs. S. P. Averill of Westwood, N. J., went best of breed at the annual specialty event of the Bulldog Club of America at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

SITTING comfortably in his easy chair, any romantically minded landlubber needs little provocation to lament the passing of the age of sail. Has the mind of man yet conceived anything more beautiful than a square-rigged ship with all sails set as painted by dozens of marine artists? Was there ever heroism more stirring to the imagination than that of iron men in wooden ships?

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 9 -- Middlebury tallied 578.13 points to capture the two-day Williams winter carnival, which ended today. Dartmouth, the defending champion, finished second with 566.16 points and St. Lawrence was third with 530.45. The host team had 510.30 points to finish fifth.
The Hamilton - Madison House Settlement will receive the proceeds of the Valentine cocktail dansant to be held in the Crystal Suite of the Savoy-Plaza on Feb. 16.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Austria's Toni Sailer captured the last two titles at stake in the world ski championships today by setting a record of 2 minutes 28.5 seconds in the downhill run.

Edward T. McCormick, president of the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of new governors for three-year terms. Those named were Vanderpoel Adriance Jr. of Adriance Finn, and James A. Herman and Edwin P. Wheeler, floor brokers.

LYNCHBURG, Tenn., Feb. 10 -Lant Russell Wood has a rather special job. He's the taster at the Jack Daniel distillery here and determines, five years before it is put in the bottle, whether a jigger of "Old Jack" is to be good for drinking.

Since the recent passage of the Sharkey-Brown-Isaacs law I have heard much about the need for educating the public toward a broader and more liberal understanding of unrestricted housing. Generally this plea for education is accompanied by a statement that civil rights legislation is futile unless the general public is ready to accept the changes contemplated.

Lewis Hoad attributes the fact that he is leading Pancho Gonzales by nine to six in their series of one hundred tennis matches to the improvement in his game rather than to any decline in the powers of his 29-year-old California rival.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A delegation from the Jewish Labor Committee urged the State Department today to press Moscow for an explanation of the disappearance of more than 400 Jewish writers, artists, actors and musicians within the Soviet Union during the last decade.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 10 -- For the first time in nine years a group of Princeton University sophomores have not become members of the eating clubs for upperclassmen.
Local track fans soon will be seeing a 16-year-old high jumper and hurdler who is the hottest scholastic performer in New England this season.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The feed grains moved up slightly but nearly all other contracts lost ground in light dealings on the Board of Trade today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- Following, in unofficial, translation from the French, is the text of a protest handad yesterday to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold by Mongi Slim, representative of the Tunisian Government.

PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 10 -- The Navy announced today the development of a radically new torpedo. It is shot into the air by a rocket, dropped into the water by parachute, then "hunts" underwater for enemy submarines.

With Prime Minister Macmillan's reply on the projected summit meeting, the responses of virtually all the Western heads of government to the recent spate of Bulganin letters are now at hand. Except perhaps at one point still to be clarified, these answers show a gratifyingly complete agreement on all salient issues.

The world premiere of "The Good Soldier Schweik," by the late Robert Kurka, and productions of nine other contemporary American operas will be presented by the New York City Opera in a five-week season beginning April 3.
In the issue of The New York Times of Jan. 30 Arthur Krock took the opportunity to discuss the subject of the power of the President to remove members of Federal independent regulatory agencies.
After a weak morning, the stock market steadied yesterday afternoon, but closed with a considerable loss.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Communist China has proposed to the United States that Chinese and Western forces be withdrawn from Korea.
Arthur Godfrey and the Columbia Broadcasting System are working out a plan whereby he will star in separate radio and television programs on week-day mornings.

Wladyslaw Gomulka's drive to secure political conformity in the Polish press has claimed another victim. Wiktor Woroszylski has apparently been forced to resign as chief editor of Nowa Kultura, the organ of the Polish Writers Union. Among his "crimes" was his decision to publish cartoons poking fun at the Soviet Union.

ALTHOUGH Americans are the best fed people in the world, there are appalling deficiencies in the national diet. Nutritional lacks -- equally evident in the daily fare of rich and poor alike -- constitute a major health problem.
Supplementary gifts from funds left by benefactors of the Neediest appear among the donations recorded today.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 10 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is willing to mediate the disputes between South Korea and Japan, it was disclosed here today.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 10 (AP) -- West Virginia gave a convincing demonstration of its basketball prowess tonight by overpowering William and Mary for a second time this season, 82 -- 68.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 10 -- The Hashemite Arab kingdoms or Iraq and Jordan seemed headed tonight for federation in a move that could take the Iraqi regime out of the Western-oriented Baghdad Pact.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The president of the American Medical Association said tonight that new legislation would be required in some states to permit licensing of physicians educated under the experimental speed-up program of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.

Columbia University announced yesterday that John T. Cahill, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, had been named head of the seventh annual Columbia College fund drive.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The Democratic Assembly leader accused his Republican counterpart tonight of "sheer hypocrisy" for criticizing Governor Harriman's appointment policies.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 7 -- Haiti seems geared economically just about as low as a country can be. She might rise rapidly if she could avert more political trouble, adhere to avowed policies of honesty and entice outside investment.

The captain of the Staten Island ferryboat Dongan Hills, which was in a collision with a British tanker Saturday night off St. George, S. I., said yesterday that the tanker was making too tight a left turn as she was heading out of Kill van Kull.
To be efficient an advertising appeal must be important, believable and unique to a brand, Dr. Robert J. Williams of Alfred Politz Research, Inc., said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Feb. 10 -- J. Lewis Chapman, 81 years old, a volunteer fireman here for the last sixty-one years, was struck and killed by an automobile last night. The accident occurred a few minutes after Mr. Chapman had left his home at 25 Hackett Place to buy ice cream for his wife Sadie.

In 1956, the latest year for which complete figures are available, heart and circulatory diseases were responsible for 53.9 per cent of all deaths at all ages in this country. These diseases, it is estimated, affect more than 10,000,000 living Americans, including 500,000 children of school age.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 10 -- The Tunisian Constituent Assembly recessed today so that its members could return to their constituencies "to be at our posts in this time of emergency to face the war that is being waged against us."

WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Feb. 10 -- Departmental hearings for two West New York policemen were put off without a new date today by Public Safety Director Ernest J. Modarelli. The policemen have been under suspension since Jan. 7 when they refused to testify publicly before the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council.
The state's Penal Law should be revised to raise from 16 to 18 years the age of persons permitted to purchase firearms and ammunition. Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -The Treasury bill rate rose slightly this week, it was reported tonight.
OMAHA, Feb. 10 -- The concept of infinite space is compatible with Christian doctrine and theology, in the opinion of two prominent Protestant leaders.

WITH their suits neatly pressed, their hair slicked down and their faces freshly scrubbed, the students will check in today for Prof. Casey Stengel's Advanced School of Baseball Knowledge. This is the cram course that the Yankees open in St. Pete each February a couple of weeks before the older scholars report for spring training.
HINDUS are a moody, impetuous lot, if you credit Peggy Glanville-Hicks' opera, "The Transposed Heads," which had its New York premiere at the Phoenix Theatre last night.
Democratic and Republican proposals in Albany to put three paid commissioners at the head of a reorganized City Housing Authority were criticized yesterday by a Federal official.
A New York hotel man's plan for $50 Atlantic ship fares was introduced in Congress yesterday.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad sustained a $2,363,702 net loss last year. In 1956 the system cleared $261,704. In December the road operated at a net loss of $880,517 in contrast to the net profit of $475,793 recorded in the like 1956 month.

ON television tonight, Walter Slezak will portray the life of Henri Charpentier, the chef who reputedly originated crepes Suzette. If the enjoyment of food is any criterion, Mr. Slezak is ideally suited to the role. He estimates that he has gained -and lost -- about 900 pounds in the last twenty years.
A third of this state's 932 towns reportedly are being engulfed by metropolitan problems that can be solved only by close inter-community cooperation.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Lord Chamberlain has banned an English-language version of a play by an Irishman that he approved when it was performed here last year in French.

THREE RIVERS, Que. -- This busy port city, birthplace of Quebec Premier Maurice Duplessis, doughty fighter for development of the resources of his province, is the outlet for the products of Quebec's "wood pulp valley."
HARTFORD, Feb. 10 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff proposed today a special legislative session to deal with rising unemployment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana called on the Administration today to try to start a cooperative international exploration of space.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 -James R. Hoffa presided today at two sessions of the Teamsters Union executive board despite reports that he had suffered a mild heart attack this week-end.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- Many people in the West have a distorted picture of Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet Union's leader.

MONTREAL, Feb. 10 (AP) -Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, star right winger of the Montreal Canadiens, was discharged from the hospital today but said he was "through for this season" as far as hockey was concerned.
ROCHDALE, England, Feb. 10 -- The two strongest candidates in the Parliamentary by-election being fought here urge Britain's unilateral nuclear disarmament.

The Department of City Planning has come up with another survey which, while it contains no surprises, helps to round out for us the picture of a phase of the physical aspects of the city in which we live. The study, covering the range and distribution of residential densities on a city and borough-wide basis, has found that there are, on the average, fifty-five dwelling units or 175 persons occupying every acre in the city.
An Aurora Borealis of unusual brilliance and intensity blacked out radio communications last night between the United States and the rest of the world.
A possibility that tonight's election of officers for the Teamsters Joint Council here may lead to a court fight was voiced yesterday by a candidate on the insurgent New Deal slate.
Irving Sherman, who figured in the 1951 Senate crime investigation as an alleged link between the underworld and former Mayor William O'Dwyer, was ordered deported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Atomic Energy Commission intends to ask additional money to accelerate research on how to use the thermonuclear reaction of the hydrogen bomb for peaceful purposes.

WOMEN will always be concerned about having shiny noses, but few of them seem to care about the case that holds the powder puff. A few years ago, a woman's compact reflected, to some degree, her own individual taste.

FOR a general view of the print field, the compendium of more than 100 modern etchings, lithographs and engravings at the FAR Gallery, 746 Madison Avenue, serves very well. It includes a rare and sharp impression of a Cezanne lithograph of bathers; a few Renoir lithographs, and several Daumiers, all of good quality.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A bipartisan bloc of Senators introduced today a civil rights bill that would give the Government broad new powers to encourage school desegregation and fight infringements of rights.
Shipments of slab zinc last month were the smallest in eighteen months -- and stocks at smelters swelled to the highest level since August of 1954.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10 -- The new United Arab Republic has aroused serious fears for Lebanon's future.
JOAN HAMMOND, the Australian soprano who appeared with the New York City Opera in 1949, returned to Town Hall last night to offer a song recital.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (AP) -- This country's hopes for amateur tennis focused today on the West and a retired business executive named Perry T. Jones, who promised:

There will be a seven-man field in the Baxter Mile at the New York Athletic Club's track and field meet at Madison Square Garden Saturday night. The field was completed when it was announced yesterday that Istvan Rozsavoelgyi, the Hungarian distance star, had obtained visa clearance and would arrive Thursday.
PEIPING, Feb. 10 (Reuters) -- Premier Chou En-lai began a new campaign today to give Communist China a voice in international conferences and a seat in the United Nations.

The City Hall conference yesterday in aftermath of the drastic suspension policy by the Board of Education against violent or insubordinate delinquents was official recognition that government's responsibility has not ended with the discharge of the juvenile offenders from their schools.

A Presidential emergency fact-finding board hit a snag over procedure as it opened hearings here yesterday in a labor dispute between Eastern Air Lines and the Flight Engineers International Association. The snag developed as the result of the board's dual mission to investigate both Eastern's dispute with the flight engineers and its -talled negotiations with the Air L,ne Pilots Association.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The Wagner Administration denounced today a Republican proposal to ease the requirements for setting up a Charter revision commission for New York City.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- A Republican State Senator from New York City today offered a plan for dealing with pupils suspended from the city's school system for acts of violence.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 10 -- An ultimatum demanding the formation of a new Indonesian Cabinet free of pro-Communist influence was issued here this evening.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Passenger car output has moved up slightly but it is still substantially behind the 1957 pace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UP) -The Republican National Committee was said tonight to be depending on Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. for mustering at "least 65 per cent of the G. O. P. votes" to pass the disputed natural gas bill.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (Reuters) -- Following, in official translation, are excerpts from Premier Chou En-lai's report to the National People's Congress, as distributed by the Hsinhua (New China) News Agency:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Bills were introduced in the Maryland General Assembly tonight to exempt advertising from state or local taxes.
Robert Cushman Murphy, naturalist and author, yesterday testified in Federal Court, Brooklyn, that nature had been thrown out of balance on his Long Island estate by aircraft spraying DDT.
Seven writers, two painters and an architect have been named members of the National Institute of Arts and Letters. Their election was announced yesterday by Malcolm Cowley, the institute president.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A spokesman for the Senate Special Subcommittee to Investigate Juvenile Delinquency said today that its chief cousel, James Sullivan, was in New York looking into school crime.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Hasty Scenes, a 5-year-old bay mare, scored a three-length victory over Brandy Fib in the $5,000 Carrollton Purse at Bowie race course today.

A 16-year-old witness reported yesterday that he had been threatened with death if he continued to testify against seven teen-agers charged with first-degree murder. A twenty-four-hour police guard was assigned to him and he continued his testimony.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- If there is one month more than another in which an incumbent President of the United States should be able to take bitter personalities with philosophic calm, it must be this one. For it is in February that the American people celebrate the anniversaries of the births of two Presidents of the past who were unusually depreciated by contemporaries.
" What will consumers do next?" asks the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. It holds that the answer to the question is the key to the business outlook.

A young mother dropped her two small children safely into the arms of a passer-by from a second-story window yesterday during a fire at 115 Hart Street, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. She then jumped from the window, and her fall was broken by the same man.

PARIS, Tuesday, Feb. 11 -- The French Government met last night to evolve a policy to counter mounting condemnation, at home and abroad, of a French bombing raid Saturday on a Tunisian border village.
MONTREAL, Feb. 10 -- Cyrus Eaton, Cleveland industrialist, said here today that the arms race was driving the world to "bankruptcy and suicide."

The Protestant Council of the City of New York last night elected the Rev. Dr. Gardner Calvin Taylor as its president. He is the first Baptist, the first Negro and the youngest man to hold the office.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Industrials declined extensively on the stock exchange today in the face of only moderate selling.

THE New Century Players' program of contemporary chamber music last night in Carnegie Recital Hall began with a serious and quite beautiful "Concerto for Ten Instruments" by Norman Cazden and ended with an elaborate prank by Henry Brant.
A tiny artificial muscle to move the fingers of paralyzed polio patients has been designed by the physicist who "pulled the trigger" for the first atomic bomb blast thirteen years ago in New Mexico.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild announced today that reporters from York, Pa., and Daytona Beach, Fla., would share the 1957 Heywood Broun Memorial Award.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Morgan Moore Moulder is a big raw-boned lawyer from the land of "show me" and the Missouri mule. This has helped him through one of the most sizzling initiations ever undergone by an aspirant for national prominence.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Congressional hearings on President Eisenhower's request for $3,900,000,000 in foreign aid funds will open Friday with closed testimony on secret reports.
ON the theory that a woman must keep up her appearance at all times, here is a round-up of some new and pretty robes and sleepwear in the city's stores.
Mickey Crawford of Saginaw, Mich., outpointed Tony (Tex) Gonzalez of East Orange, N. J., in a brisk ten-rounder at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
Major banks, the city's schools, most of the municipal departments and nearly half of New York's business offices will be closed tomorrow in observance of Lincoln's Birthday.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 10 (AP) -- It appeared unlikely today that the Delta Queen, last of the overnight passenger boats on American rivers, would wind up as a floating college classroom.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -- A Florida legislative committee was told today that the Communist party had "achieved a degree of success" in penetrating the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People not paralleled in any non-Communist organization of comparable size.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 3 -- The African nationalist movement is weak and confused in South Africa today. But it is slowly gaining in strength and purpose.

WEST ISLIP, L. I., Feb. 10 -- A forty-lane bowling alley and restaurant building in operation less than five months was destroyed by fire this afternoon. The loss was estimated at between $750,000 and $1,000,000.

Howard Fast, who renounced communism, is dramatizing his widely known novel, "The Unvanquished," in which George Washington is the motivating force. Mr. Fast has signed a contract with Joseph M. Hyman, sponsor of "Fair Game," to deliver the final version of the "comedy-drama" in June for a fall production.

You have recently given much space to reporting efforts to have Ellis Island made available for use as a hospital for drug addicts. May I call your attention to some hospitals that have been vacated by the City of New York that are available and more accessible than Ellis Island?

ESSENTIALLY Carlo Goldoni's "The Servant of Two Masters," which was done last night at the Davenport Theatre on East Twenty-seventh Street, is a gusty old farce that should pique the curiosity of the theatre historians.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 6 -- The adolescent State of Israel will soon begin celebrating its tenth birthday.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 -- The Indian Government intensified today its warnings to the West against stationing nuclear weapons on the subcontinent.

Trans-World Airlines deserves great credit for pursuing what its acting president, Warren Lee Pierson, calls "a gradual system of racial integration" in its employment policies and particularly for the promise made last week by the company's counsel that within ninety days a Negro hostess will be hired.
DALLAS, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A group of construction employers called today on building and construction trade unions to "support the principle of giving a full day's work for a full day's pay."

Cardinal Spellman yesterday called the United States "the Good Samaritan in the history of the world" because its gifts, made officially and through private agencies, were offered "with no thought of receiving."

A hard-to-find break in a water main gave 800 boys an unexpected day off yesterday at La Salle Academy, 44-50 East Second Street. Water began pouring into the basement of the Roman Catholic high school about 8 A. M., causing the boilers to be shut down.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Congress today voted an emergency appropriation of $43,400,000 to replenish nearly exhausted unemployment compensation funds for veterans and Federal employes.
Fifty-three boys and girls from seventeen junior high school sudents councils heard a 19-year-old defendant admit in court yesterday that he could not read his junior high school diploma.

Benjamin Britten's opera, "The Turn of the Screw," will have its first United States performance on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, March 19 and 20. It will be given by the opera department of the New York College of Music, Siegfried Landau conducting.
MIAMI, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito, the champion jockey of 1952, returned to the saddle today and put on a sensational ride for 21.216 Hialeah Park fans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Mongi Slim, Tunisian Ambassador, told Secretary of State Dulles today that his Government had decided to appeal to the United Nations Security Council against the French bombing in Tunisia Saturday.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Governor Harriman vetoed tonight a Republican bill to reconstitute the Rockefeller Commission and give it new powers for recomminding revisions of the State Constitution.

LINDENWOLD, N. J., Feb. 10 (AP) -- A fire destroyed the St. Lawrence Catholic Church last night and the police said a 15-year-old boy had admitted starting it accidentally. Five firemen were injured in falls while battling the wind-whipped blaze.

The Continental Can Company achieved record sales last year, but earnings were 5 per cent less than those for 1956, according to the preliminary annual statement issued yesterday by General Lucius D. Clay, chairman.

The nation's door-to-door salesmen are planning on a big year, even though many of their customers will have less money to spend. This report was made yesterday by Edward L. Sard, executive director of the National Association of House-to-House Installment Companies.

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool, burlap and hides rose; sugar, rubber, lead and zinc declined, and price movements for cocoa, coffee and copper were mixed.
New York City is planning to borrow $44,500,000 on serial bonds to finance the construction of schools and the payment of claims against the city.
The ninety-second annual charity ball to be given by the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique, 349 West Forty-eighth Street, will be held on April 12 in the Grand Ballroom of the Statler.

Events today: Regina Sarfaty, mezzo-soprano, Town Hall, 3; Cleveland Orchestra, Erica Morini, violinist, George Szell, conductor, Carnegie Hall, and Philomusic Society of New York, Carnegie Recital Hall, both at 8:30.
" My young man" signed his 1958 contract for the New York Yankees yesterday. That young man is Tony Kubek, the 22-year-old who played five positions for the American League champions last season.

A syndicate headed by The First Boston Corporation and Dean Witter Co. will place on the market today $1,000,000 shares of $25 par value preferred stock of Southern California Edison Company. The shares bear a dividend of 4.78 per cent and are priced at $25.55 a share to yield 4.68 per cent.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 10 (UP) -Herb Score of the Cleveland Indians started workouts today, confident he'll be back burning 'em over the plate when the 1958 American League season gets under way.
Eighty-six per cent of teenagers in Nassau County drink alcoholic beverages on occasion, Dr. Mathew N. Chappell of the Hofstra College psychological division said yesterday.
LAST night's "Voice of Firestone" over Channel 7 was a soothing experience for a viewer seeking to escape from conventional programs.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 10 -- Gangs of weary men worked along the water line network in the downtown area tonight in a frustrating search for an elusive rush of water.

A kangaroo named Sheba and a giraffe named Ermintrude would make most little boys want to join the circus to which the animals belong. But in "The Little Boy Who Wanted to Leave the Circus," the Junior League Puppeteers are giving a new twist to the old story.

Record snows and numbing temperatures left eighteen persons dead yesterday in New York State as the season's worst cold wave continued to grip most of the country from the Rocky Mountains to the Atlantic Ocean.

OUR books today are "Don Quixote's Profession,"* a study of Miguel Cervantes by Mark Van Doren, and "Prejudices: A Selection," an anthology of H. L. Mencken's essays chosen, and with an introduction, by James T. Farrell.
Increasing interest is being shown in employe pension plans that attempt to offset the decreasing purchasing power of the dollar, a Chicago banker said here yesterday.

A book dealer "poking around" in a country antique shop recently made a purchase that treasure-seekers dream of. He paid $5 for an item that turned out to be worth $1,000 or more. The lucky find, tacked on a wall, was a broadside proclaiming in great black type: "The Union is Dissolved!"
BONN, Germany, Feb. 10--East Germany decided today to decentralize its heavy industry in the manner recently carried out in the Soviet Union.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 -- The captain does the fishing. The captain and the boat and the motors, ably assisted by the gentlemanly mate, the outriggers and the fighting chair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A panel of five economists was unanimous today in the opinion that the nation would not return to a state of prosperity by November unless the Government took further anti-recession action.
The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., announced plans yesterday for the construction of a $28,000,000 oil refinery in Venezuela.
TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- The Democratic majority in the State Assembly defeated today a Republican proposal to continue the Legislature's investigation of garbage disposal contracts in North Jersey.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Skiing conditions today as reported to the State Commerce Department:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Despite strained relations between their two nations, protocol brought the ambassadors of France and Tunisia to a White House state dinner for thirty- eight diplomats tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson announced today the appointment of a "nuclear brain trust" for the Senate-House Subcommittee on Military Applications of Atomic Energy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -The House Committee on Un-American Activities said today its hearings last year had established that the Communist party had been able to infiltrate deeper into vital United States industries.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The legislative watchdog committee ran into a new mystery today as it continued its inquiry on organized crime in Utica.

The terms "Academy" and "Institute" over the centuries, especially in France where they have had such cultural prominence, have become identified with conservative trends in art and literature. Under that famous dome which looms above the Left Bank end of Paris' lovely, spidery little foot bridge, the Pont des Arts, one rarely expected to find a ferment of modernity.
The city announced plans yesterday to keep a close eye on troublemakers suspended from the schools while setting up hearings to decide what is to be done with them.

The provocative intelligence gleaned from a recent survey for the American Express Company that Americans lose more than $100,000,000 in cash each year makes us wonder if carelessness has become a national characteristic.

Leading sales finance companies cut the yields yesterday on commercial paper they sell directly to investors by another 1/4 percentage point. The reduction brought the rates down to 2 to 2 3/8 per cent.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Airman Donald G. Farrell began making space history today feeling "bright and chipper."

HONG KONG, Feb. 10 -- Roman Catholic Bishop Dominic Tang, Apostolic Administrator of the Canton Archdiocese, has been placed under formal arrest by the Chinese Communist authorities. His secretary, the Rev. Ngan Tak-kan, was also arrested.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 (AP) -- An arrangement under which William Steinberg will become conductor and music director of two of the world's foremost symphony orchestras was announced here today.

Bob Boozer and his Kansas State teammates, advancing at the expense of their Big Eight Conference rivals from the University of Kansas, took first place yesterday in the United Press major college basketball ratings.
It seems to me that one of the great needs in our schools is to provide adequate supervision, so that children may be given a chance to learn at their own pace and at their own level of ability.

GARY, Ind., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Joseph Lafleur, who described himself as a Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover agent, told a house subcommittee today that the Communist party had sixty "dedicated members" in the Lake County section that concentrated on northwestern Indiana's big steel mills.
Gov. Orville Freeman of Minnesota charged last night that Vice President Richard M. Nixon had deliberately fostered "a new kind of isolationism" in the Midwest as a "political tool."
Mayor Wagner has given his department heads a week to ten days to cut their 1958-59 budget requests below the totals they have submitted.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 10 -- "Anyway," said a woman, huddling with her cup of steaming coffee, "it's still better here than in New York."

Claude G. Bowers, who died Jan. 23, served this country as Ambassador to Chile from 1939 to 1953. He held the post under four American Presidents and during the regimes of four Chilean Presidents during that period.
The Bay Park House garden apartments at 1193 to 1215 East Broadway, Hewlett, L. I., have been sold by Irving Klein and Edward Ingram to an investor represented by S. J. Ungar, attorney.

Using a Sicilian defense, Oscar Panno of Argentina triumphed in thirty-three moves over Joaquin Gutierrez of Costa Rica yesterday in the chess championship of the Americas at Bogota, according to a report from Colombian news sources.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Dr. Bernard Schwartz has been asked by the Fund for the Republic to make a study of one of the Federal agencies he had been investigating as counsel for a House subcommittee.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- The Tunisian Government informed the United Nations today that French troops in Tunisia had been forbidden to take positions outside their usual camps.
Business and consumers were urged yesterday to continue spending at the "normal rate" to prevent the recession from deepening.

When the breed competition that began the eighty-second Westminster Kennel Club dog show ended in Madison Square Garden last night, one of last year's finalists had a victory stowed away and two others had fallen by the way.

Today's new film is "The Gift of Love," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic drama starring Lauren Bacall and Robert Stack, at the Paramount. It was produced by Charles Brackett and directed by Jean Negulesco.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 -- Four men set sail in a small boat from San Pedro today for Eniwetok, where they hope their presence may discourage the Government from setting off nuclear explosions.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Many Continentals have doubts about Britain's proposal for a European free trade area as a corrective of the discriminatory aspects of the common market embracing France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 10 -- Millions of gallons of water ran loose today under downtown Jersey City, where 100,000 persons live and work. Water-supply crews hunted anxiously for a leak in the system from late Sunday throughout the day.

CAIRO, Feb. l0 -- The Egyptian National Assembly met today for what probably will be its last session before union Republic. It approved a detailed agreement signed in Moscow last month for use of $175,000,000 in credits extended to Egypt by the Soviet Union last November.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 9 -- Oil from the Sahara is moving northward so slowly that one Algiers newspaper complains that it reaches the Mediterranean port of Philippeville in "an eyedropper."
The first performance of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of "Madama Butterfly" on Feb. 19 will be sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild as a benefit for the opera's production fund.

Sponsors of the magazine Iberica made public yesterday their protest to President Eisenhower against further economic aid to Spain. The signers included Norman Thomas, chairman of the Post-War World Council, and Victor Reuther, administrative assistant to the president of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations.
HAVANA, Feb. 10 -- The struggle between Government authorities and exponents of President Fulgencio Batista is taking an increasing number of lives.

The annual bridge, tea party and fashion show of the Supply Chapter of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will take place tomorrow afternoon in the parish house at 2 East Ninetieth Street.

Steel production edged off a shade more last week, although not quite as much as the industry had expected. The nation's steel-making furnaces poured 1,457,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- The Chicago police censors have placed a partial ban on the film version of Eugene O'Neill's drama, "Desire Under the Elms," by restricting theatre showings to persons over 21.

Mrs. Benjamin R. Shute, benefit committee chairman, has announced that the March 11 performance of "Who Was That Lady I Saw You With?" by Norman Krasna, has been chosen as a benefit for Grosvenor Neighborhood House, Inc.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was unchanged to 26 points up yesterday, with new crop months strongest. The advance equaled $1.30 a bale.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The House subcommittee investigating the regulatory agencies discharged Dr. Bernard Schwartz, its chief counsel, tonight.
Johnny Bach, Fordham's basketball coach, suggested yesterday that three officials be employed instead of the standard two-man officiating team "for more proper handling of the game."

Former President Truman, in a statement to the North American Newspaper Alliance published in this newspaper yesterday, expresses the opinion that the present slow-down of the American economy reflects a "lapse of confidence by our people in what we have been doing and where we are going."

NEWPORT, R. I., Feb. 10 -- Beaulie, the nine-acre estate with a forty-four-room brick mansion where the late Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt ruled summer society for a quarter century before her death in 1953 was purchased today by Banjamin Coates of Haverford, Pa., and New York for $60,000.
THIS spring, men will gaze at those famous American legs through rose-colored stockings. Or green, or charcoal or apricot ones.
LOURDES, France, Feb. 11 -One hundred years ago today a little French peasant girl returned from the grotto called Massabielle, radiant with wonder.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Secretary of State Dulles said today that it was not essential to have a foreign ministers' meeting prior to a conference of heads of government.
A selling job among college men was urged yesterday to promote selling as a career.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Russia is among the few places Bob Hope has yet to visit for entertainment purposes. The comedian said today he was going to try to fill this gap.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -The national Republican hierarchy from President Eisenhower down repudiated today an effort by Texas Republicans to tie party fund-raising directly to passage of the natural gas bill.

The bombing and strafing by French planes on Saturday of the Tunisian village of Sakiet-SidiYoussef has hit public opinion everywhere in the world with a stunning impact. Whatever one feels or believes, it must be admitted that this is a major development in contemporary affairs.

RON DELANY is gregarious by nature, a friendly fellow who delights in good company. Maybe that's his trouble. He was pitter-pattering along in the Wanamaker Mile at Madison Square Garden last Saturday at peace with the world and his companions. But then the Olympic champion from Ireland suddenly was off by himself in front.

Although Stella Holt is blind, she refuses to permit such a handicap to block her theatrical activities. In conjunction with the Riverside Neighborhood Assembly, which represents a group of West Side community organizations, Miss Holt will put on "The Long Gallery."

The Temporary State Commission on the Constitutional Convention, with Nelson A. Rockefeller as chairman, may not be the ideal agency in some respects for a new assignment to advise the Legislature on revision of the Constitution. But Governor Harriman, instead of vetoing the Republican bill to extend the commission's life, might better have yielded to this approach in the interest of encouraging and cooperating with the constitutional reform to which he is sincerely devoted.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Five Russian scientists came to the United States today for twenty-three-day stay. They plan to visit pharmaceutical and medical research laboratories in Philadelphia, New York, Boston and Baltimore.

ISIDORE LATEINER, the Cuban violinist who made his debut here in 1956, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in a joint program with the pianist Joseph Wolman. The event was sponsored by the Philomusic Society of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States would like to see in Indonesia "a government which is constitutional and which reflects the real interest and desires of the people."
Richard (Pancho) Gonzales tonight faces the most formidable challenger to confront him in New York since he became recognized as the world's foremost tennis player.

A plot 225 by 100 feet on the east side of University Avenue, between 181st and 183d Streets, the Bronx, has been purchased by Isadore Rosen Sons, builder for improvement with a six-story apartment house.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Big-deal fishing in this area overwhelms and holds in poorboy obscurity another kind of sport that in many ways is far more important -- the light-tackle fishing in Lake Worth.
PADANG, Indonesia, Wednesday, Feb. 12 -- The rebel colonels here said this morning that they were prepared for possible military moves by Jakarta in the wake of the rejection of their ultimatum.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 4 -Japan formally agreed today to extend a $50,000,000 loan to India over a three-year period for repayment in ten years. The credit will be used to purchase Japanese hardware for India's hard-pressed five-year development plan.
TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- The New Jersey Blue Cross asked the State Department of Banking and Insurance today to approve an over-all increase of 28.9 per cent in its hospitalization insurance rates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill authorizing tax collectors to "crack down" on employers who fail to turn over to the Government tax money withheld from employes.

The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada sold a record $917,737,287 of new life insurance in 1957, George W. Bourke, president, told yesterday's annual meeting at Montreal. This was the largest amount ever sold in one year by any Canadian life company and $63,000,000 more than the company's previous high, set in 1956.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Hess, Inc., Perth Amboy, N. J., today reluctantly agreed to have a statement designed to establish its position as a crude oil importer considered as an application for an import allocation under the Government's voluntary program to curb crude imports.
The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California borrowed $18,000,000 yesterday on an issue of waterworks bonds due serially from 1959 to 1970 and secured by general taxation.

ROCHDALE, England, Feb. 11 -- Britain's most critical by election campaign since 1951 ended tonight with the Labor party confident it would win the House of Commons seat from the Conservatives tomorrow.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11 -King Saud is the most impor tant of the three monarchs, involved in the Iraqi-JordanianSaudi Arabian triangle but he also is the one who appears the least willing to declare his hand.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Actors Equity Association and the American Guild of Musical Artist have endorsed a joint statement vigorously protesting the United States' "limited participation" in the Brussels World's Fair of 1958.

Coffee futures were sharply lower in early trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Several months fell about 1 1/2 cents a pound. The market later recovered to close near Monday's levels.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Final prices were 18 points off to 37 points up, with the strength most pronounced in the far months. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Petroleum Association has estimated that there are billions of barrels of oil and trillions of cubic feet of natural gas still capable of being produced from the rich sedimentary basin covering western Canada.
Tentative plans for the publication of a magazine devoted to the arts and culture of the United States were announced yesterday by the editors of American Heritage, a magazine of history.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The deputy police chief of Utica resigned under pressure today. Two state agencies continued to press their parallel investigations of graft and corruption in the upstate industrial city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -The new chairman of the House Investigation of Federal regulatory agencies is an easy - going, earnest - appearing Democrat who brings to his job the political know-how of seventeen years on Capitol Hill.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 11 (Reuters) -- The West Indies cricket team today scored the first victory in its test series against Pakistan, winning the second match by 120 runs. The first match was drawn.
Edward R. Murrow's next "See It Now" presentation will combine a travelogue and the examination of a serious question: Should Alaska and Hawaii be granted statehood?
A man being booked on a minor charge yesterday in the Flushing, Queens, police station chose a poor time to make a break for freedom.

WOOD-RIDGE, N. J., Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Curtiss-Wright Corporation confirmed today the resignation of two vice presidents and a vice president of its Wright Aeronautical Corporation for what were termed personal reasons.
EVEN when faced with the temptation of bridal gowns, Tailored Woman manages to stay pat on its policy of unfussy fashions.
Barnard College has opened a campaign to raise $2,000,000 for a new dormitory and a student center. Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of the college, announced the drive yesterday.

VADUZ, Liechtenstein, Feb. 11 (UP) -- "The Little Four" will go ahead and hold a meeting of their own regardless of what the Big Four do, it was disclosed today. Theirs will be a summit meeting, too -- on top of a mountain.
The aurora borealis continued to disrupt radio communications yesterday. Although not visible in the New York area, the aurora was so brilliant over Europe that it aroused fears of conflagrations.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 11--Pressure on French forces to evacuate Tunisia increased today.

BURNINGLY amorous letters written between 1742 and 1750 by the French philosopher Voltaire to Marie Louise Mignot Denis, widowed daughter of his sister Catherine Mignot, will go on public display on Friday, in the Morgan Library at 33 East Thirty-sixth Street.

The five leaders in the chess championship of the Americas in Bogota all triumphed in the fifteenth round, leaving their respective standings unchanged, according to a report received yesterday through Colombian news sources.

Members of the New York Women's Council of the Save the Children Federation met recently in the home of Mrs. C. Herbert Rauch, chairman, of 30 mulate plans for their eighth annual benefit card party. It will take place at the Pierre on April 18.
A woman died yesterday as a result of a hold-up in her apartment. The two robbers' loot was $5.

AN audience of more than 2,600 was on hand last night at Carnegie Hail to give the Cleveland Orchestra a second welcome when it played the second of the three concerts it is giving here this winter as part of its seasonlong celebration of its fortieth anniversary.
UPTON, L. I., Feb. 11 -- A nuclear physicist said today that a "deep-seated desire" to find answers that are not in books transcends all other qualifications for becoming a scientist.

The Great Northern Railway last month lost $411,124 hauling freight and passengers, but nonrailroad income enabled it to report a net income of $759,333. This compared with earnings of $2,357,122 in January, 1957. On a share basis, the profit was 12 cents, down from 39 cents a year earlier.
Patrons have been announced for the Feb. 27 benefit performance of Sir Laurence Olivier in "The Entertainer" at the Royale Theatre. Proceeds will aid the Turtle Bay Music School.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 11 -The French bombing attack on a Tunisian village may force Morocco to revise her policy on France, according to sources close to the Moroccan Government. The Government has been under pressure from the Moroccan public and from Arab states to change its policy of cooperation with France.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 11 -French and West German defense officials laid plans today for coordinating the air defense systems of their countries.
The New York Philharmonic will scrap its old formal Thursday night concert next season in favor of an informal Thursday preview.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- A Republican bill to raise the maximum weekly unemployment insurance benefits from $36 to $45 was jammed through the Legislature today despite threats of a veto by Governor Harriman.
Regina Sarfaty, mezzo-soprano, winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award, made her debut in a strong recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
New York University, which is making determined efforts to tone up its sports program, struck on a formula last Saturday that evoked a highly enthusiastic reaction.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) -- A Redstone ballistic missile was test-fired here tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb 11 -- A high rate of drug addiction among physicians was reported here today.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The retreat in the stock market became more pronounced today and spread to virtually all sections except South African gold minings stocks. Fresh losses pushed the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary stocks down 1.1 points to 161.3, making a fall of 3.1 points in two days.

PARIS, Wednesday, Feb. 12 -- Premier Felix Gaillard successfully defended before the National Assembly early today the French bombing of the Tunisian border village of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef on Saturday.
Parke, Davis Co. last year turned in the highest sales and earnings in its ninety-one-year history, Harry J. Loynd, president of the pharmaceutical concern, reported yesterday.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Feb 11 -The Mergenthaler Linotype Corporation of Brooklyn indicated today that it would move part of its facilities to a twenty-fouracre site at Plainview.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -Net profits of banks in the Federal Reserve System increased $142 million in 1957, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A gas heater in a work trailer exploded yesterday on heavily traveled Main Street in Flushing, Queens, in the morning rush hour. A workman in the trailer was burned, two passers-by were cut by glass, about 100 windows in stores and dwellings were broken, and traffic was tied up for two hours.
Cairo, Feb. 11 -- Egypt and Britain apparently are still far from agreement on a formula for the evaluation and return of assets seized during the Suez invasion fifteen months ago.
Former Federal Judge Lawrence E. Walsh has been named a special commissioner to wind up litigation stemming from the collision of the liners Andrea Doria and Stockholm.
The Clark Equipment Company, a leading maker of materials handling equipment, plans to expand into trailer manufacturing, through the proposed acquisition of Brown Trailers, Inc.

The nine-story office and loft building at 416 Broadway, at Canal Street, has been sold by the Blosmar Realty Corporation to a client of the Tricap Realty Corporation, broker, represented by Jack J. Coopersmith, president. The buyer insured title with the City Title Insurance Company.

Your editorial of Feb. 8 "The Schools' Dilemma" is well reasoned and sound. The Board of Education's new policy of suspending troublesome students is, indeed, aptly described by you as a little plan to solve a big problem.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Following is the text of a White House statement today on Post Office modernization:
NEWARK, Feb. 11 -- The Presbytery of Newark has elected the Rev. C. Lincoln McGee of Montclair as its moderator. He is the first Negro to hold the top administrative post.

Douglas Grewer, a past president of the New York Region of the Porsche Club of America, has taken over the herculean task of running the Eastern Conference of Sports Car Clubs, an informal organization made up of more than sixty groups on the Eastern seaboard.
Stocks yesterday had their widest decline since Dec. 17. The market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange fell almost $1,800,000,000.

THE alchemy that transforms bits of torn and cut papers into works of art remains a mysterious performance in which only a few artists have knowledgeably participated. One of the few artists to wrest magic from the collage medium, Esteban Vicente, shows his recent work at the Rose Fried Gallery, 40 East Sixty-eighth Street.

JUPITER, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) -Joanne Goodwin of Haverhill, Mass., and James McHale of Philadelphia headed the qualifiers in the national mixed foursomes golf tournament today but had to play twenty holes to gain the honor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The United States satellite Explorer was reported today to be "working beautifully" as a scientific researcher in space.
The Pierre Hotel, one of the city's most luxurious hotels, will be converted into a tenantowned cooperative under a plan announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- A special adviser to the United States Commerce Department said here today that he thought Soviet authorities soon would approve United States Government participation in an American trade fair scheduled to be held in Moscow this summer.
Committee heads have been chosen and initial plans have been made for the eleventh annual Salute to Summer Cocktail Party and Tea Dance of the Society of Memorial Cancer Center.

THERE are very few juvenile delinquents among the thousands of youngsters reared in Israel's collective villages, or kibbutzim. On the other hand, the percentage of delinquents among Israeli youngsters reared with their families approximates Western world figures.
DUBLIN, Feb. 11 -- Sean O'Casey, "for very cogent reasons," has withdrawn his new play "The Drums of Father Ned" from the Dublin Theatre Festival, which begins May 11.

In recent years many top Government officials, including the Controller General, the Secretary of the Treasury and the Postmaster General have urged that -- in fairness to the American taxpayer -- postal savings should be abolished.
John J. O'Rourke, an ally of James R. Hoffa, was re-elected last night by an overwhelming majority to head the Teamsters Joint Council here for the next five years.

A laboratory with the purpose of finding a way to cut the noise produced by electrical equipment was opened by the McGraw-Edison Company yesterday in Canonsburg, Pa. The day marked the 11th anniversary of the birth of Thomas A. Edison, the inventor.
The American Express Company last year achieved the highest earnings in its history and expects foreign and domestic travel to increase this year about 10 per cent above the 1957 levels.
Steel production last month was nearly 39 per cent below that of January last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 11 -- The water crisis that plagued Jersey City since Sunday night ended at noon today after a break in a thirty-six-inch auxiliary main was discovered under the Hackensack River.
PEIPING, Feb. 11 -- Premier Chou En-lai gave up his job as Foreign Minister today to a long-time friend.

MIAMI, Feb. 11 -- When A. J. Ostriker's colt Nisht Amool was ridden back to the winner's enclosure after today's feature race at Hialeah, the customers cut loose with the warmest round of applause of the Florida racing season.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 11 -- The Indonesian Government rejected tonight an ultimatum demanding its resignation and ordered the dishonorable discharge of four colonels who have been leading a dissident group.
New York was thoroughly explored yesterday by a group of young men interested in discovering what goes on behind the building facades.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Feb. 4 -On this high East African plateau, 8,000 feet above the Red Sea, a strange new forest has grown up. It is a forest of slender steel towers, scores of them, lending an incongruously modern touch to the wild landscape around Asmara.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa yesterday became the first major city official to diverge from Mayor Wagner's views on the purchase of city automobiles. It was disclosed yesterday that on Friday the Board of Estimate is scheduled to refer to Budget Director Abraham D. Beame a proposal of the Purchase Department to buy a 1958 Cadillac limousine for Mr. Gerosa's use.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The British Government announced tonight the terms of a new bond issue of 300 million ($840,000,000) tailored for American investors.
Competition must not be permitted to undermine the stability of the nation's financial system, the president of the American Bankers Association warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -The House of Representatives is expected to follow the Senate's lead in setting up a special legislative committee on outer space.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Cliff Hagan, with seven points in the last five minutes, led the St. Louis Hawks to a 107-105 victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight. Cincinnati beat Minneapolis, 106 -- 103, in the first game of the National Basketball Association doubleheader before 9,228 fans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Secretary of State Dulles remained publicly noncommittal today on the dispute between France and Tunisia. Meanwhile, United States diplomats worked to help still the crisis in the relations between the two countries.

The cold wave continued through its fourth day here yesterday with subfreezing temperatures, but throughout much of the blizzard-buffeted East residents were able to dig themselves free of deep snows. No marked relief from the bitter cold is in sight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- The Zenith Radio Corporation filed suit in Federal District Court here today charging the Admiral Corporation with patent infringement on two television features.

WHEN American buyers saw the new French fashions last month, they did more than applaud; they threw money.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Rejecting a last-minute plea from Mayor Wagner, the Assembly approved a Republican bill today to facilitate the selection of a City Charter revision commission.

THE soup kettle that filled grandmother's kitchen with a wonderfully appetizing aroma, is, regrettably, as out of date as the wood-burning stove on which it simmered. But the delightful custom of a hearty, hot soup on a cold winter day is as pertinent as ever.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, gave the House Banking Committee a list of Federal Reserve Bank expenses today. They included a $6,000 organ and a $6,145 roof garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -The Army announced today a major advance in developing a mobile anti-missile missile for the use of field mines. The Army gave few details, other than identifying its project as Plato.
Airline flight engineers won a procedural victory over the pilots' union yesterday.
The economic recession cost the Transit Authority $815,849 in passenger revenues last month, it said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic clergyman, who supervises feeding of 135,000 destitute Koreans a day, made a plea for the world's hungry today.
A murder witness denied vigorously under cross-examination yesterday that he was a member of a teen-age gang that was an enemy of two gangs to which the murder defendants belonged.

New table settings now being shown by Tiffany abound with ideas for spring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Two psychiatrists who had complained that drug companies had been overzealous in selling new tranquilizer drugs to physicians praised the companies today for toning down their promotion techniques.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- British officials who have been studying a Polish proposal for a zone in Central Europe free of nuclear weapons have tentatively concluded that Britain would not be willing to accept any variation of the plan.
CAIRO, Feb. 11 (Reuters) -An agreement on Yemen's federation with Egypt and Syria will be signed after Feb. 21, it was officially announced tonight.

Two sharply worded letters from President Roosevelt to Premier Stalin, written in 1945 but still classified as secret in the United States, have turned up in an official Soviet publication of World War II top-level correspondence.

Champion Puttencove Promise, a 3-year-old white standard poodle, became the dog of the year in Madison Square Garden last night by winning the highest bench show honor of the country. He was judged best in show of the eighty-second Westminster Kennel Club competition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Postmaster General will go before Congress tomorrow to present "a $2,000,000,000 program to modernize the obsolete physical plant of the Post Office Department."

CHRISTOPHER, Marlowe's "Edward II" -- the eleventh presentation in the matinee series under the sponsorship of ANTA's Greater New York Chapter -- received an intelligent airing yesterday at the Theatre de Lys.

City Council President Abe Stark yesterday urged that former school buildings be used as emergency educational and guidance centers for suspended students. He made the proposal in a letter to Mayor Wagner, Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, and Superintendent of Schools William Jansen.

Most of the early risers who studied comparative literature on television last semester received passing grades. About 10 per cent should have stayed in bed. The results of the course were announced yesterday by New York University.

Robert Moses dealt politely but firmly yesterday with an entire Indian tribe.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- A Coast Guard cutter plowed a "fast track" for midwinter shipping through the shore-to-shore ice of the Hudson River this morning.

A suspended high school freshman threw a 7-year-old girl to her death yesterday from the roof of a Bronx apartment house, the police said. The 15year-old youth, Francis Medaille, walked into a Bronx police station and confessed the slaying.
