The proxy fight for control of the Cinerama Productions Corporation ended early yesterday afternoon after a stormy threehour annual stockholders meeting. Late in the day the management reported victory, though the final count of proxies was not expected before Friday.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- For years Continentals have said that Britain's ties with the Commonwealth were a mere pretext for her relatively aloof attitude toward Europe. They argued that those ties need not prevent her joining the European economic communities, or even the political fed eration to which they were designed to lead.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A Congressional study committee said today that Government farm programs emphasizing production controls would apparently be needed for at least ten years more.

AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 11 (AP) -- King Hussein of Jordan and King Faisal II of Iraq conferred today amid indications that they would announce shortly the federation of their countries to meet the challenge of the new Egyptian-Syrian union.
Meyer Lansky, a gambler, was taken into custody last night and questioned about the murder of Albert Anastasia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- An 1860 letter from Abraham Lincoln telling his wife about his Cooper Union address was among four Lincoln items given today to the Library of Congress.

Communist China has apparently launched a campaign for a larger role in world affairs, based on what Premier Chou characterizes as the "superiority" of the forces of "socialism" over those of "imperialism." That, at any rate, seems to be one purpose of two steps taken by the Peiping regime.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -What would happen, asked the worried Congressman, if matter should collide with anti-matter?
Recent threats of state and municipal taxes on advertising have receded suddenly in the face of strong opposition from business groups.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 4 -- White supremacy will remain the basic policy of South Africa in the near future, no matter who wins the national election on April 16.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -Trading in grain futures was at a low ebb today and except for the soybean and two other contracts, prices on the Board of Trade hardly changed from Monday's closes.

Students of agriculture are perhaps the nation's youngest capitalists. Last year, commercial banks in New York made about $150,000 in loans to farm boys for some particular project -- the purchase of cattle or poultry, for instance -- or to get them started in the business of farming. The loans ranged from $50 to more than $10,000.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- A hitch developed today in Republican plans to name Edward M. M. Warburg, banker and philantropist, to one of three vacancies on the State Board of Regents.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 11 -The merged labor federation decided today to play its cards close to the vest in bargaining with Congress and the White House on anti-racket union curbs.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- George Raft is coming back into films after a three-year absence.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- James F. Adams of Baltimore was named lacrosse coach at the United States Military Academy today. Pie succeeds Morris Touchstone, who held the position from 1929 until his death last fall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Dr. Bernard Schwartz, discharged as chief counsel of an investigating House subcommittee, disclosed tonight he had turned over to Senator Wayne Morse a large part of his "working files."
Gil McDougald signed his Yankee contract yesterday for an estimated $35,000, an increase of from $5,000 to $7,000. He is the twenty-third signer.

There are so many facets to the towering figure of Abraham Lincoln that first one and then another catches the light. Some are likely to be overlooked, for a time, and reminders are helpful. It is right, therefore, on his birthday, to think of some of the things that we might, momentarily, have chanced to forget.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- The United States Junior Chamber of Commerce said today that it would no longer cosponsor the annual "Voice of Democracy" contest because it had "become an admitted lobbying device for the National Association of Broadcasters."
TORONTO, Feb. 11 -- Canada's chartered banks will cut the prime interest rate on loans from 5 1/2 to 5 1/4 per cent next Monday.

Harry Fromkes, theatre owner, lawyer and real estate specialist, was killed yesterday in a fall from his twelfth-floor apartment at 320 Central Park, West, at Ninety-second Street. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The General Services Administration today outlined the New York City area in which a site will be selected for the largest Federal office building ever planned outside the Washington area.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- It is almost as cruel and bloody a process to relinquish as to make an, empire. This old truism of history was learned successively by Rome, Madrid, Vienna and Constantinople. Now again London and Paris are acquainting themselves with its sad, bitter verity.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Unemployment climbed by twice the normal seasonal amount in January, largely because of layoffs in manufacturing, the Commerce and Labor Departments reported today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- George Raft is coming back into films after a three-year absence.
Allen C. Duncan, Valfred J. Gardner and Arthur Hall have been appointed trust officers of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The conservative old guard in the Senate is fading. Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia is the last of an impressive list of influential conservatives of both parties who have either announced their retirement, died, or been defeated at the polls in the last three years.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- France took the initiative today to inform her North Atlantic Treaty Organization partners of the circumstances of Saturday's bombing by French planes of the Tunisian village of Sakiet-SidiYoussef.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Air Force officials expressed optimism today over man's ability to withstand the rigors of space travel as Donald G. Farrell completed three days of his week-long simulated trip to the moon.

While the number of jobless normally shows an increase in January -- the first month following the yearend holidays -- not more than half of this year's rise of 1,100,000 can be explained in terms of seasonal influences. The joint report of the Commerce and Labor Departments on the situation as of mid-January showed total unemployment at 4,494,000, or 5.8 per cent of the labor force.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Britain's exports declined last month and her imports increased.
Casey Stengel's "Pet," the Yankee manager's own designation for Don Larsen, his world series perfect game pitcher, has signed his 1958 contract.
In the cotton futures market yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange the old March option fell 3 points. Other months advanced 3 to 27 points. A point is equal to 5c a bale.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Hugh Gaitskell, Opposition leader, said today that the Government was seeking to strengthen the House of Lords to use it "as a Tory machine to delay and obstruct socialist legislation."

NAHA, Okinawa, Feb. 12 -Naha's newly elected Mayor has announced plans for the formation of a political party this month. He says the new group, the Okinawa Socialist party, will not function fully until after Okinawa's general election March 16.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell last night predicted a substantial increase in employment by midsummer.
Governor Harriman met yesterday with Mayor Wagner on the city's school crisis and announced that state officials would study whether additional state aid was required.
Ralph Edwards has found there is no pot of gold at the "End of the Rainbow." The television show he packages under that title will terminate Saturday after a run of six performances.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- John Fagen today won the New York State junior ski jumping championship. Fagen, a 5-foot 11-inch Lake Placid High School sophomore, executed 43 and 42-foot leaps before 10,000 fans, to head a field of forty-two.

The Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy has taken blocks of choice seats for the Feb. 26 and 28 performances of Sir Laurence Olivier in "The Entertainer" at the Royale.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 12 -- Indonesia reacted today to Secretary of State Dulles' comments on developments here with the warning that outside powers should not meddle in her internal affairs.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 12 -- Tunisia demanded today the evacuation of all French forces as the price of restoring French-Tunisian friendship. The Government underscored its demand with a display of increased hostility.
Albert M. Kahn, former head of Spear Co., announced yesterday he had reacquired control of the company. Details of the transaction were not disclosed.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Britain has begun a new move toward international control of Antarctica.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Senator William F. Knowland today made a quick trip back to his home state from Washington to spur his campaign for Governor.
HAVANA, Feb. 12 -- The Government is pouring reinforcements of troops into Oriente Province as rebel attacks and sabotage increase daily.

NEWARK, Feb. 12 -- The state's control commission for legalized games of chance reported today that a record total of 5,228,110 players had taken part in 22,887 bingo games last year. Receipts totaled $19,025,938.
The Abbott Kimball Company, Inc., will merge with Grant Advertising, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

The next certain public appearance of Champion Puttencove Promise, the white standard poodle that won Westminster's best-in-show title at Madison Square Garden late Tuesday night, will be in the Eastern Dog Club event in Boston Feb. 22 and 23.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 12 -- Congress elected Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes President of Guatemala today for a full sixyear term.

The International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday that it had thrown its support behind three Congressional measures designed to promote waterfront safety and to liberalize medical and legal procedures in connection with injuries.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- To meet one of the objections raised by organized labor, the Republican transit labor bill was amended further today.

The parents of Francis Mich el Medaille, the 15-year-old boy who was arrested on a charge of hurling a 7-year-old girl to her death from a building roof, were interviewed yesterday by Hal Boyle, a columnist for The Associated Press.

Gasoline stocks continued to rise last week, while supplies of light fuel oil declined. Production of crude oil showed a slight increase above that for the preceding week, but imports, crude oil runs to refineries and production of gasoline declined.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
Wall Street yesterday had little more than a cool, incurious glance for President Eisenhower's prediction that the economic curve would Bend upward in March. Stocks continued to fall.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- The Netherlands lost more shipping than any other country (3,977 tons) during the second quarter of last year, according to statistics published today by Lloyds shipping service.

Richard Rutter gave in his Jan. 30 article "U. S. Well Armed to Battle Slump" an excellent survey of the actual and potential stabilizers of our economy. But his is a rather one-sided story, as he did not mention two important destabilizers which may considerably diminish the effectiveness of the stabilizers in our Government's economic arsenal.
This year -- awake or asleep -- there is no escape from the chemise silhouette: lingerie designers have adapted its languid profile for everything from slips to nightgowns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The Robert P. Patterson Memorial Award was presented today to 2d Lieut. James J. Barber of Owatonna, Minn., who is assigned to the Eeighty-second Airborne Division at Fort Bragg, N. C.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 12 -- The Pathet Lao leader in Laos, Prince Souphanouvong, was quoted here today as having denied a recent United Press report that he had abandoned leanings to communism.

Francis S. Levien and Harry E. Gould, directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, who liquidated their common shareholdings in the company last Nov. 29, have re-purchased the securities.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Britain has consulted the United States and France about the possible effect of the union of Egypt and Syria on the three countries' 1950 agreement to preserve national boundaries in the Middle East.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Feb. 12 (UP) -- An Air Force C-124 Globemaster left Antarctica hurriedly today when McMurdo Sound's ice runway started to crack. It arrived at Christchurch with one of its four engines dead and another on fire.
NEWARK, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A record number of school budgets have been rejected in New Jersey and will have to be resubmitted to voters.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Colombia, world's second largest coffee producer, suspended today all international sales of coffee until Monday because of the death two days ago of Manuel Mejia, the country's coffee "czar."
Governor Harriman called yesterday upon critics of his fiscal policies "to look at the budget before you howl."

ROME, Feb. 12 -- A new Government-licensed lottery has warmed up Italian politics overnight. It is also worrying the world of sports because it may cut into the financing of the 1960 Olympic Games, which are to be held in Rome.

Operation of two Florida ilmenite mines will be taken over by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. next Tuesday, the company announced yesterday. Ilmenite is a black, sandy ore used to make the whitest pigment known -- titanium dioxide, which has widespread applications in the paint, paper, plastics and other industries.
A new cancer program has been started here to help both man and his best friend by treating dogs like humans.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox had one of the most expensive days in the club's history today. They signed Nellie Fox, their second baseman, for a record payment; Billy Pierce, a left-handed pitcher, for a near-record sum, and Bob Keegan, a right-handed pitcher, for a substantial pay rise.

The chances that a new EastWest summit meeting will be held this summer have improved considerably as a result of Secretary Dulles' statement that the United States does not insist on a prior conference of the foreign ministers as "essential."
MIAMI, Feb. 12 -- Bill Hartack, back on the job after a two-day time-out, had another triple at the Hialeah horse park today, but the list-topping jockey didn't win the big one.

As a long-time reader and admirer of The New York Times, both as a Government official and more recently as a private citizen, I must express a growing concern regarding your editorial policy toward President Nasser and the Arabs.

The French Government has now said what it feels and thinks officially about the bombing of the Tunisian border village of SakietSidi-Youssef on Saturday. Premier Galliard was unyielding and uncompromising in his support of the military commanders who ordered this terrible reprisal against Tunisian support for the Algerian rebels.
Suburban housewives, husbands and teen-age youngsters were attentive playgoers last night at the Saddle Rock School in Great Neck, L. I.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -Mayor Richardson Dilworth today attacked District Attorney Victor H. Blanc for having banned the Brigitte Bardot film "And God Created Woman" here.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Joey Giardello, a middleweight contender, flicked a fast left hand tonight to outpoint Frank Szuzina of Germany and win a unanimous decision in a national-televised ten-round bout. It was Giardello's fifteenth straight bout without a loss.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 12 (UP) -- William M. Holaday, the Defense Department's missile director, said tonight that the "over-all status" of the United States and Soviet Union missile programs was now about even.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Willy Brandt, West Berlin's Socialist governing Mayor, left here for New York today after a four-day visit during which he was greeted by official Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -United States exports to Poland increased more than eight-fold last year. Last summer's $95,000,000 loan to that country and the relaxation of export controls were a major factor.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 -- There are some fairly astonishing figures here on what a few determined men and women can do to promote the conservation of game fish.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12 -Public Works Director August W. Heckman said today that the broken water main under the Hackensack River that drained 18,000,000 gallons had in no way affected the city's supply or caused any danger of contamination.

Films as real as animal life itself and as imaginative as a small boy's daydream will be included in the fare to be offered by The Children's Cinema, a new film society for youngsters 4 to 8 years old.

One of the keenest of the intracity rivalries will be resumed tonight when St. John's University faces Manhattan College in the headline event of the collegiate basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 (AP) -Boggs Buhl, 89-year-old Pittsburgh store, announced today it was going out of business.

Discovery of an apparent conflict of law that might nullify restrictions recently imposed on woolens imports stirred interest among traders yesterday. There were doubts, however, as to how effectively it could be exploited.
PORT - AU -PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 7 -- Haiti has promulgated a new Constitution since the inauguration of President Francois Duvalier But many of its aspirations still appear far from fulfillment.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- A bipartisan deal has been negotiated for the addition of seven State Supreme Court justices in the Tenth Judicial District, composed of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The district now has thirteen justices.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today appointed two new members to the United States Naval Academy Board of Visitors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Shirley Temple will play her first dramatic role on television in "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow." She will portray Katrina in the adaptation of the Washington Irving classic, to be presented live and in color March 5 on the National Broadcasting Company network as part of the "Shirley Temple Storybook" program.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Solid Son, a fast-improving son of the California stallion Solidarity, won the $28,900 San Luis Rey Handicap today at Santa Anita Park. He ran the mile and one-half on the Camino Real grass course in 2:30 3/5 and collected $17,350 for Carl Roles.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Feb. 12 -- Little theatre presentations in Suffolk County, as elsewhere, have a wide following. "Standing room only" is the rule.
ALBANY, Feb., 12 -- The Republicancontrolled Legislature today named a second Democrat to the thirteen-member board of regents. He was Edward M. M. Warburg, a New York banker and philanthropist.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- Pravda today hailed the recent fall of Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez, Venezuelan dictator, as a blow at the United States.

CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Petroleum Association says it favors a national policy on natural gas export as an important step in assisting further exploration of potentially rich deposits throughout western Canada.
NEWARK, Feb. 12 -- "All right, everybody. Let's take places for a run through of Scene 1, Act II."

" THE UNCHAINED GODDESS," seen last night over Channel 4, was another installment in the interesting science series presented by the Bell Telephone System. The program was an examination of the causes and effects of weather and, in its limited approach, was consistently informative.
Ski Sketch: When Frank Scofield, the head of the ski school at the Chantecler in Ste. Adele, Quebec, was an 8-year-old, he decided he wanted skis. He asked his father to get him a pair for Christmas.

Stella Unger is at work on a musical comedy with an outer space theme. It is called "Twinkle, Twinkle," says Miss Ungar, who co-produced and wrote the book and lyrics for "Seventh Heaven" several seasons back.

The nineteenth annual WNYC Festival of American Music was inaugurated with a concert yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The festival, by the time it is completed on Feb. 22, will have offered more than 100 special programs and seventy premieres of works by American composers.

IGOR STRAVINSKY'S "Agon," joined with George Ballanchine's choreography, was the surprise success of the New York City Ballet's season. In its first New York concert performance at Carnegie Hall last night, played by the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch, the score was required to stand and move on its own feet.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 12 -Despite the diminishing number of traveling shows and the rising costs of trips to New York plays, residents of Westchester County are being exposed to an increasing amount of live drama.

GLORIA DAVY, young American soprano, made a well-received debut last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The role she sang was Aida. This is the part in which she made her operatic debut a year ago in Nice, France, and which she sang last summer at the Lewisohn Stadium.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 12 -- The president of Princeton University said tonight there had been "unfortunate allegations of religious discrimination" by some students who said they had been denied membership in eating clubs they considered suitable.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 12 -Coffee circles here believe no unusual nervousness will occur in the coffee market as the result of the death of Senor Mejia.
TRAVELERS to Europe this spring may not go emptyhanded, but they certainly will go light.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- The Screen Directors Guild is asking that its members be paid 25 per cent of their original salary on theatrical movies made after Aug. 1, 1948, that are sold for free television exhibition.

The five-story apartment house at 1263 Jerome Avenue, assessed at $20,000, has been sold by Burton G. Kebart and Frances Cahn to an investor. The Taylor Company was the broker. The structure, on a plot 25 by 100 feet, contains ten apartments and two stores.
The annual bridge party and tea for the benefit of the joint scholarship fund of Marymount College and Marymount School in New York will be held March 1 at the college, 221 East Seventyfirst Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Senator Harry Flood Byrd, a right-wing Democrat from Virginia, announced today that he would not ask for re-election at the expiration of his term in January. He is 70 years old.
American travel will veer toward South America in the future, according to a survey on travel trends issued yesterday by American Express.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 12 -- A Federal court order directing that seven Negro pupils be admitted to white schools in Arlington County, near Washington, was upheld today by the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals.
Thomas B. Adams, 38 years old has been named president of the Campbell-Ewald Company, Inc. He had been a vice president and assistant to the president, Henry G. Little.
THE Bach Aria Group presented the third concert of its current subscription series at Town Hall last night, under the direction of Frank Brieff.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 7 -- Israel is beginning her second decade of statehood with a new uncertainty about how many immigrants she can expect in the near future.

What appears to have been overlooked in the struggle against youth delinquency are stronger, more effective citizenship-education programs in the schools -- surely a fundamental requirement in any effort to improve the situation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield told the Senate today that President Eisenhower's $2,000,000,000 postal modernization plan would give the economy "a timely stimulus."

The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has formed a thirteen - member Advisory Council for the Dance as the nucleus of the governing body that will select or create an autonomous dance institution to represent that art in the Center.
Paramount Pictures yesterday moved to allay the apprehensions of exhibitor groups both here and abroad by opposing the sale of motion pictures produced after 1948 for free showing on television.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 12 -The Cornell goalie, John Detwiler, warded off fifty-one Princeton shots, but seven others got through as Princeton defeated the Ithacans, 7 -- 0, tonight in an Ivy League hockey game on Baker Rink.

Aid to the state governments by the Federal Government increased threefold from 1946 to 1956, according to an analysis of the Census Bureau. The data were released today by the National Industrial Conference Board.
CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 12 -Representative Charles A. Wolverton, announced in Washington today that he would not seek re-election from the First Congressional District in New Jersey this year.

THESE menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The United States has devised a plan for a shopping center for military spare parts to help the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
TORONTO, Feb. 12 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 2, tonight, and opened a 27-point first-place lead over the idle New York Rangers in the National Hockey League.
TOKYO, Feb. 12 -- Japanese scientists successfully fired today what was believed to be the world's first rocket with a plastic body from a beach near Akita, on Japan's northwestern coast.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Electric power has wrought a greater transformation along the coastal plains of northwest Mexico since 1950 than in the previous 300 years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The top price for slaughter steers at $34.25 today was the highest since Feb. 19, 1955 at the livestock market here. It was paid for five loads of 1,200 to 1,350 pound high prime grade.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- G. D. Searle Co., manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, said today it had aranged to buy Root Chemicals, Inc., of Puerto Rico, and Productos Esteroides, S. A., of Mexico, a Root subsidiary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Ambassador Williams S. B. Lacy predicted today that the first exchange of United States and Soviet political broadcasts would take place within the next two months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The State Department is debating the possibility that the Baghdad Pact will be dissolved as a consequence of the IraqiJordanian move toward a second Arab union.

How the Negro and white school children of the South have been affected by the Supreme Court decision on integration is described in a picture and textbook entitled "Tender Warriors." Written by Dorothy Sterling with Donald Cross, the book records events in Little Rock, Clinton, Clay and Louisville.

An offering of $3,500,000 of 4 3/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures of Red Owl Stores, Inc., is being made today by a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers, J. M. Dain Co., Inc., and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood.
MAN, W. Va., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Five men were believed crushed to death tonight under tons of the rock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The United States satellite's more powerful radio voice apparently has stopped after eleven days of transmitting scientific information.

Two men who should make able, conscientious members of the Board of Regents have been elected by the New York Legislature. They are Carl H. Pforzheimer Jr. and Edward M. M. Warburg. Another excellent member, T. Norman Hurd, has been re-elected
Eight hundred persons over 65 years old met yesterday in Brooklyn to demand an increase in Social Security benefits.

Trading was quiet yesterday on those New York commodity exchanges that were open for business. Only four items were traded. Futures of wool and cottonseed oil declined; potatoes rose, and price movements for soybean oil were mixed.

Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation plans to redeem all of its outstanding 4 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock of the 1951 series and its 4 1/2 per cent series A and 4 3/8 per cent series B subordinated debentures issued in 1952.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--President Eisenhower sought to assure the nation today that it was not facing a prolonged economic recession.
Below-freezing temperatures still gripped the city yesterday and red-cheeked youngsters could puff their breath into the breeze and see it.
MADRID, Feb. 12 -- The Spanish Government tonight denied charges that "more than 200" students and workers were arrested last month and mistreated by the police.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 12 -The Iraqi and Jordanian Governments announced tonight that talks on the union of their countries were going on in a cordial atmosphere and would continue.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A smiling and friendly Soviet Ambassador exchanged pleasantries with Vice President Richard M. Nixon for forty minutes this afternoon.

The thirty-family apartment house at 5413 Seventh Avenue, in the Borough Park area of Brooklyn, has been sold by James Storepakis to an investing client of Saul Siller and Judah Rosner, brokers in the transaction.
ROCHDALE, England, Feb. 12 -- The Conservative Government suffered a decisive defeat in a parliamentary by-election here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -Representative Oren Harris, angry over charges that a House subcommittee was ready to "whitewash" its study of Federal agencies, promised tonight "the most thorough investigation Capitol Hill has ever seen."
Richard (Pancho) Gonzales is still the undisputed world professional champion in the eyes of a record tennis gathering of 15,237 that saw him defeat Lewis Hoad at Madison Square Garden last night.

AN agreeable pace is set in a group show at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. Most of the examples are relatively small in scale, and many reflect whimsical moods or moments of lightness for otherwise more weightily serious artists.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Liberia's National Legislature gave speedy approval today to a law making racial discrimination a crime in this Negro republic. It is punishable by fines of up to $30,000 and jail terms in some cases.
Net income of the United States Rubber Company dropped 6.8 per cent in 1957 from that of the previous year, and sales were off 3.1 per cent, the concern reported yesterday.

The President's Committee for Traffic Safety has performed a valuable service in its pilot project that for the first time tends to throw bright light onto one of the most baffling aspects of highway safety -- the failure of drivers to listen to the experts.
The ideals of Abraham Lincoln were cited yesterday as a guide to the nation in confronting its problems of achieving brotherhood and world peace.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 -- An American college expedition will start digging for the riches of Croesus next summer.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill to facilitate the creation and extension of street lighting districts in Suffolk County.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 12 -- Gerald N. B. Watkins is a retired international banker. He is of distinguished appearance and speaks with the cultivated accents of his native England.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The University of Virginia today named Dick Voris, 36, as head football coach. Voris, an assistant to Earl Blaik at West Point since 1955, got a three-year contract.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 12 -- A Protestant educator objected today to proposals that tax funds earmarked for public education be used to set up separate church schools to avoid racial integration. Such proposals have been made in a number of Southern states.
The president of the American Bar Association proposed yesterday creation of new legal machinery to encourage private investment in underdeveloped countries.
The Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company said yesterday that stockholders would receive "in excess of $16.25" a share through the sale of its Hershey sugar properties and liquidation of the company.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 12 -Shock and dismay from Virginia officials and voters greeted Senator Byrd's announcement.
The West Penn Electric Company system had an 8 per cent gain in net income in 1957, according to a preliminary report yesterday.
Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks accused the Democratic party last night of deliberately gambling with peace and prosperity solely for greedy partisan advantage.
DETROIT, Feb. 12 -- The Ford Motor Company reported today that 1957 dollar sales were the highest in its history and that net income for the year as 19.5 per cent above the 1956 level.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Three Auburn business men who were caught in the Apalachin raid last November are suing the state and a state police sergeant for $1,500,000.

The flowers that bloom in the winter put on their customary brave show yesterday in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The day was raw and chill and snowflakes blew over them to make their blossoming even more dramatic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today conditional approval of most increases in freight rates and other charges proposed by the railroads on a selected list of commodities. The average is about 2 per cent.

Thousands celebrated Lincoln's Birthday yesterday by crowding into Gotham's department stores. Late in the afternoon, while the cash registers still rang merrily, some store executives were confident that sales were well ahead of those a year earlier.

WHAT'S happened to all those lugubrious articles about the modern novel's decline and fall? They seem to have gone into an ironically appropriate senescence of their own. Isn't that prose, if not poetic, justice? The state of the modern novel is blooming by comparison. "Infact, the novel remains the best of all ways to express the contemporary world in art.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 12 -- Only one seeded player saw action as the women's national squash racquets singles championship opened at the Greenwich Country Club today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 -- James R. Hoffa reported today that he had started to liquidate the extensive business interests that helped to get him in trouble with Senate investigators and the merged labor federation.

JUPITER, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -Nan Berry's putting enabled her and Billy Watts of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to upset Barbara McIntire and Dick Chapman, 3 and 2, in the first round of the national mixed foursomes golf tournament today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Tunisia asked today for Security Council action on the French bombing of SakietSidi-Youssef.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A New York physician testified today that Dr. Leona Baumgartner, New York City Health Commissioner, started an inquiry late in 1956 that caused drug companies to curb their claims for tranquilizers.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 12 (UP) -- A B-47 jet bomber jettisoned a "portion of a nuclear weapon" off Savannah Beach a week ago. The weapon was dropped after the bomber collided with a fighter plane at 35,000 feet.
IN case anyone doubts that Laurence Olivier is a versatile actor, consider the subject closed. He is versatile.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 12 -- A novel arbitration award provided a settlement today of a jurisdictional dispute between New York's two most powerful unions, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Virtually all sections of the stock market declined today. Only gold mining shares kept firm.

WESTERNERS take a negative attitude toward cooking because their recipes read from left to right. The Chinese, on the other hand, take a positive attitude because their recipes read from top to bottom, requiring the head to move up and down affirmatively.
The first of a series of five concerts by Musica Viva was presented last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The United States expressed hope today that a way could be found to reach "an amicable and just solution" of the dispute between France and Tunisia.
The Greater New York Safety Council has set up a new post -- director of community services -- to spur the city's lagging pedestrian safety campaign.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Governor Harriman urged the Legislature today to tighten rent controls so as to bar landlords from making exorbitant profits and to save tenants from excessive rent increases.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Jon Arnett of the Los Angeles Rams, who had the season's longest kick-off return with a 98-yard jaunt for a touchdown, won the 1957 kickoff return title in the National Football League, according to the official statistics announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- It was disclosed tonight that the Air Force was considering dropping the Army's intermediate range ballistic missile Jupiter.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Minnie Jean Brown, one of nine Negro students at Little Rock Central High School, was suspended today for two weeks. The superintendent; Virgil Blossom, recommended that she be expelled from the school for the rest of the year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The General Services Administration tonight awarded a $110,000 contract to design a new $15,200,000 Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn. The contract went to the New York architectural firms of Carson Lundin, 425 Park Avenue, and Lorimer Rich Associates, 35 West Fiftythird Street.
Upsets marked the completion of adjourned games yesterday in the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas in Bogota, according to a report received through Colombian sources.
Five meet records were set yesterday in the eighth annual Fordham Prep Catholic high schools relay carnival on the outdoor board track of Fordham University. Twenty schools participated.
Sometimes it is hard to say just what constitutes trivia. In relationship to outer space and the cold war, an event taking place the 18th of this month probably would be regarded as such.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A former Soviet agent testified today he never had met or seen M/Sgt. Roy Rhodes at the time the sergeant was being described in secret Moscow messages as a spy for the Soviet Union.
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Feb. 13 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was reported today to have decided to accept the resignation of Finance Minister T. T. Krishnamachari.

WILLY BRANDT, Governing Mayor of West Berlin, who is visiting New York today, sometimes describes himself as a kind of stand-in for a ghost. There is nothing about his craggy, muscular, 185-pound figure to suggest the sepulchral, but he says: "I am in office only be cause the men who should be leading this city are dead.
BIZERTE, Tunisia, Feb. 12--Nearly 10,000 French soldiers, sailors and airmen are isolated at this big French naval base by Tunisians who have blocked the roads to six military establishments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Feb. 5:

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Governor Harriman was reported today to have picked Julius S. Wikler of Mount Vernon to replace Leffert Holz of New York as State Superintendent of Insurance at $18,500 a year. Mr. Wikler is First Deputy Superintendent.
Meyer Lansky, who was questioned by the police Tuesday night about the murder of Albert Anastasia, has been called to tell his story to the state watchdog committee, too.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 12 -Ten German scientists who had worked in the Soviet Union since World War II returned to West Germany today with their families.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- General heavy selling set off by a Government report clipped grain futures prices fairly deeply all along the line on the Board of Trade today.

The incredible ham-handedness of the Texas oil and gas lobby has done again what all the good arguments against the Natural Gas Bill have not been able to do. Two years ago President Eisenhower felt it necessary at the last minute to veto an exemption measure (that had had his approval in principle) because of the industry's "arrogant" lobbying activities disclosed on the floor of the Senate a few days earlier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -The chairmen of the Senate and House Republican Campaign Committees said today that they would accept the $100,000 raised by a Houston, Tex., party dinner. The money had been spurned by the Republican National Committee.
Senate labor rackets investigators will begin an inquiry today into Tuesday's election of officers of the Teamsters Joint Council here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The discharge of Bernard Schwartz by the House subcommittee whose commission he held as counsel was inevitable after he became its prosecutor. In the course of his reactions to the obstacles he encountered in his effort to center the inquiry on the personal conduct of Federal Communications Commissioners, Schwartz managed to transgress every obligation which a Congressional committee counsel assumes.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Feb. 12 -- The Soviet Union and its satellite nations are paying a high price for "systematic neglect" of veterinary science, a Federal official said here today.
TRENTON, Feb. 13 -- The state today appealed a decision of its Public Utility Commission giving the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company rate increases on business and residential services.

The Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce of the House of Representatives has approved a resolution asking the Federal Communications Commission to change its mind about a decision to allow field experiments with pay television.

Contracts for the construction of four improved dry-cargo ships for the American Export Lines were awarded by the line and the Maritime Administration in Washington yesterday. The award marks the start of the steamship line's freighter replacement program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Representative Melvin Laird, Republican of Wisconsin, called tonight on Senator John J. Sparkman to explain what Mr. Laird termed the Senator's "mysterious connections with broadcasting."
HAVANA, Feb. 13 -- Sabotage by youthful rebels fighting the Government of President Fulgencio Batista occurred in various places in Cuba during the last twenty-four hours.
AFFABLE is the adjective most often used by his friends to describe Richard Alfred Mack.
CHRISTCHURCH, N. Z., Feb. 13 -- The United States will operate four scientific stations in Antarctica in 1959.

The master of the British tanker Tynefield, which was in a collision with the - Staten Island ferryboat Dongan Hills last Saturday, gave testimony yesterday that varied from that of the ferry's captain.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Willy Brandt, Governing Mayor of West Berlin, said today that West Germans should not "set knives and forks" for their East German cousins until the United States and the Soviet Union had settled "the big problems."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Feb. 6 you stated editorially that my Senate speech on Feb. 4 would "not be helpful" on the subject of the editorial "Dealing With the Soviets." I am sure you would expect me to reply.
Twenty thousand subway riders and commuters were late getting to work yesterday morning in a series of delays on the IND subway and the New Haven and New York Central Railroads.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa cautioned the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday to move very slowly in supporting the proposed $500,000,000 debt exemption to finance new schools.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- France today barred negotiation with Tunisia under threat to French troops and civilians there. She placed blame for the explosive situation there on Tunisian violation of agreements.
Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, exiled former President of Cuba, and eight other Cubans were indicted here yesterday for conspiring to set up a well-financed military expedition to attack Cuba.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- It isn't news any more in Hollywood when an actor becomes a director, but the reverse situation is more or less a novelty.
The General Tire and Rubber Company achieved record sales and the second largest earnings in its history in the fiscal year ended last Nov. 30.

Potato futures rose sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The April and May positions hit new highs for the life of the contracts during trading. Final prices were 5 to 12 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) up on 2,430 car lots.

A survey made public yesterday by Mayor Wagner disclosed that ninety-one elected city officials, heads of agencies and deputies have the exclusive personal use of city-owned automobiles with city-employed chauffeurs.

CLARION CONCERTS got off to a good start last night. The first of the three programs drew more than 1.125 persons to Town Hall. Enthusiasm ran high. Newell Jenkins led a well-rehearsed chamber orchestra in spirited performances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Doubts of the President's "executive energy" that were intensified by the mild stroke he suffered a while ago -- his third serious medical experience -- are inconsistent with an account of his activities in connection with the reassuring statement of the economic prospect that he issued yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad received permission today to cut its passenger service beginning Feb. 16 on fourteen runs between Philadelphia and New York, Washington and Pittsburgh.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 13 -- The French-Tunisian situation deteriorated rapidly today. There was a possibility that the Tunisians would completely cut off supplies to French military posts.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 13 -Britain's White Paper declaration of readiness to retaliate with strategic nuclear weapons is regarded here as consistent with the policy of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The legality of Fordham University's participation in the $205,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment was argued yesterday before the Appellate Division.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 14 -Hiroshima's City Council has drafted a strong protest to Harry S. Truman over his remarks on a United States television program defending the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August, 1945.

TOKYO, Feb. 13 -- Displaced Japanese settlers of the Bonin Islands, which are now serving as a United States naval base, plan to ask Washington for approximately $8,000,000 as compensation for the use of their lands.

Earnings before taxes of the Minute Maid Corporation, producer of citrus juices, for the quarter ended Feb. 1 were about $800,000, John M. Fox, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday. A year earlier earnings were $80,000.

MANILA, Friday, 14 (AP) -- An Indonesian rebel leader, Col. Ventje Sumual, announced today that the rebel movement would form a revolutionary government one minute after a rebel ultimatum to President Sukarno expires at noon Saturday.
ALONG with hot dogs, Indian art and the Yale Glee Club, this nation will export its finest in fashion to the Brussels World's Fair.
Elston Howard, who is rated as the Yankees' No. 2 catcher, behind Yogi Berra, yesterday became the club's twenty-fifth contract signer.
The Barnwell, S. C., plant of Amerotron Company, one of the nation's largest woolen mills, has achieved a high degree of production efficiency in less than two years.
A social worker for the City Youth Board and two teen-age boys were ordered yesterday to stand trial in Special Sessions Court on a charge of possessing narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -Sam Rayburn, Speaker of the House of Representatives, said today that Democratic leaders in Congress would soon start an economic review to "see where a tax cut, if there was one, would do the most good."
The fortieth anniversary of the Fordham University under-graduate newspaper, The Ram, was celebrated yesterday with a luncheon and the printing of the fattest edition in the paper's history.

BOTH Bernard Buffet and, to a lesser degree, Antoni Clave are sufficiently well known to New Yorkers not to need the inadequate showing of their work at the Hutton-Chambard Gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street.
SPIRALING costs continue to plague food consumers.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Governor Harriman joined today with ten other Democratic Governors in urging President Eisenhower to institute "a practical program" to halt "the growing national recession."

THE average sports fan probably was unaware of the existence of Dr. Harold Anson Bruce, but he was a familiar and respected figure in track and field circles. His coaching career included stints at Lafayette, Union and City College in this country and he directed the Austrian Olympic team in 1936. But his recent death inevitably recalled a fascinating tale that Dr. Bruce liked to tell.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 13 -- The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church f the United States is considering erecting a new headquarters building in midtown New York.

MARIA CALLAS, who has had her ups and downs in the title role of "Lucia di Lammermoor," was way up last night at the Metropolitan Opera. The soprano, singing the role for the first time this season, was in beautiful voice, and she achieved a vocal consistency that this listener has never heard from her.

Governor Harriman has recognized experience, ability and character in two reappointments to the Port of New York Authority. Howard S. Cullman, now honorary chairman, was first appointed by Governor Smith and has served as a Commissioner for more than thirty years.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 13 -James R. Hoffa had a friendly first meeting today with three monitors a Federal judge appointed last month for the scandal - scarred International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
The Chrysler Corporation made a striking comeback last year, with the highest dollar sales in its history and an increase of nearly $100,000,000 over 1956 in earnings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A special House subcommittee took sworn testimony today that Richard A. Mack, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, had accepted $2,650 from a "fixer" acting for a television company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, accused Republicans in Congress today of choosing $100,000 over "political integrity."

A proxy fight for control of Williams-McWilliams Industries, Inc., of 745 Fifth Avenue, was disclosed yesterday. Four directors will head a group opposing Sinclair Robinson, president, who acquired a controlling stock interest in the company in November, 1956.
A new union formed to organize pier hiring bosses in New York has received a "donation" of $3,000 from the West Coast labor chieftain Harry Bridges.

A 16-year-old high school girl was found murdered yesterday in the basement of her Washington Heights home. Her 15year-old brother, returning from school, found her burned, battered body covered by a mattress.
Fifteen men were arrested yesterday in a series of nineteen raids against betting establishments in four boroughs by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 10 -From Dan to Beersheba, Israel was covered this week with a rich green carpet of growing things.

The red ball was up yesterday for penthouse ice skaters. This innovation in winter sports for Manhattan apartment dwellers was created by Howard Barker, a 33-year-old scenic designer. A bachelor, he occupies a two-and-a-half-room penthouse atop the seventeen-story building at 60 East Ninety-sixth Street.

WEMBLEY, England, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The team that will represent the United States in the world amateur ice hockey championships suffered a costly defeat tonight when it bowed to the Wembley Lions in a rough game, 7 -- 6.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- J. Douglas Casey, a director of Fairbanks, Morse Co., said yesterday that Leopold D. Silberstein, president of PennTexas Corporation, had been trying to sell his Fairbanks, Morse holdings but had not found a way to get his investment back.

Little by little women are attaining their day in the sun in the pleasure boating world. Some of the distaff side think it has been a long, hard tussle. And it has. Too long has boating been a sport for men and kings and only on a subordinate level for the girls.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 (UP) -- Thoroughbreds from south of the Equator, normally six months younger than horses foaled in the Northern Hemisphere, will receive special weight allowances at Hollywood Park to compensate for the age difference, vice president and general manager James D. Stewart said today.
When a ski operator becomes jovial about the conditions in his area, any ski enthusiast knows the picture must be a bright one.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Congress should be urged to create a nonpartisan commission on social welfare policies to conduct a nation-wide survey of social trends, a welfare leader said today.
GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 13 -- A 3-year-old brown and black German shepherd dog is providing added security for the extensive property of the Great Neck School District.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Strategic nuclear bombardment would be the West's reply to Soviet attack by conventional forces, Britain declared today.

Whenever a onetime poor lad became a top executive, newspapers years ago always mentioned "rags to riches" and Horatio Alger, whose heroes generally got to the front office by saving the president's daughter from a runaway horse.

Consolidated net operating income of the Marine Midland Corporation, New York State bank-holding company, was $15,270,120, or $1.74 a share, last year, it was reported yesterday. This compared with $13,696,606, or $1.62 a share, in 1956.

PARENTS who feel that the movies their children attend have no more lasting effect on the youngsters' lives than the popcorn they eat while watching them get little support from Mrs. Robert Flaherty. The widow of the man whose name stands for greatness in the field of documentary films, Mrs. Flaherty takes a firm position against movie-going merely for the sake of going.
MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- Soviet leaders are disturbed by the tendency of some regional economic officials to stress local interests rather than the national welfare.
A blood specialist warned yesterday that DDT sprays might be encouraging cancer of the blood, Hodgkin's disease and other ailments.
A preview of an exhibition of thirty-five oil paintings by Sir Winston Churchill will take place at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on the evening of March 6.
ATHENS, Feb. 13 -- Sir Hugh Foot, Governor of Cyprus, called on Archbishop Makarios, exiled lay and spiritual leader of the Greek Cypriote community, today.

The largest goal in the thirty-nine-year history of New York Catholic Charities, $3,000,000, will be sought in the 1958 fund appeal, Cardinal Spellman said yesterday. The sum represents a 10 per cent increase over 1957.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 13 (UP) -- The rule that caused a furor in the 1957 Masters golf tournament -- reduction of the field to the low forty plus ties at the half-way mark -- will be in effect again this year. But one small change may leave fans happier.

Istvan Rozsavolgyi made his long-awaited arrival in New York yesterday. The Hungarian runner, whose off-again, onagain plans to race Ron Delany here had kept the transoceanic cables humming for nearly a month, proved to be an impressively determined athlete.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The repeal of the capital gains tax at this time would be of much benefit to the economy. Billions of dollars of stagnant equity capital would be released for reinvestment in the creation of new and the expansion of existing business or industry.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was heartening indeed to read your editorial "Social Security Needs" published on Jan. 13. So logical and practical was this statement of the facts and the action which reasonable men would conclude must follow that we took the privilege of reproducing it and sending it to every member of the Legislature, as well as our own state C. I. O. affiliates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -Following are excerpts from Dr. Bernard Schwartz's testimony today before the House of Representatives Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight:
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that "over - specialization in youth work by the police is an unrealistic approach to current crime problems."
Confronted with the prospect of increased violence on Cyprus, the British Government has launched a new initiative to resolve a dangerous dispute.

JACK BENNY, who is 64 years old today, observed his "fortieth birthday" last night on the "Shower of Stars" program over Channel 2. The man who made a career of always being 39 on radio and television deserved a much more fitting party than he received.

Member bank reserve positions tightened slightly in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. On average, net free reserves declined $31,000,000 to $190,000,000.
Events today: Wagner's "Die Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; New York Philharmonic, Rafael Kubelik conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The House of Commons approved tonight the admission of women to membership in the House of Lords. Women have never sat in the House of Lords before.

A new issue of $25,000,000 of Indiana Michigan Electric Company's 3 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1988 is being offered for public subscription at a price to yield about 3.8 per cent to maturity.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 12 -Preparations for the May 4 election of twenty-one members of the National Assembly are dications of any increase of Communist strength in Laos.
Sidney Sheldon's goal is to become a Broadway producer. He aims to do so next season with a musical, temporarily entitled "The Gypsy King," for which he wrote the plot.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Two new bills dealing with branch banks and bank holding companies were submitted to the Legislature today.
William Lombardy of New York, junior chess champion of the world, took second place yesterday in the chess championship of the Americas at Bogota, according to a report from Colombian news sources.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The three executive deans of the State University were designated today to perform the presidential duties of Dr. William S. Carlson until his successor is chosen.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 13 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower arrived here in mid-afternoon today with the temperature barely above freezing and in the wake of the first "measurable" snowfall since 1912.
AMMAN, Jordan, Friday, Feb. 14 -- Iraq and Jordan signed an agreement for the union of the two Arab kingdoms at 7:45 A. M. today.

A RECENT chapter in the history of the French priesthood is the background for the new play that was unveiled by the Blackfriars' Guild in its theatre last night. "The King's Standards," by Costa Du Rels, as translated from the French by Helen A. Gaubert, has for its background the story of the worker priests and the controversy they stirred over the proper functions and duties of the priesthood.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 13 -Every angler in Florida this year ought to take along with him every day one essential piece of equipment: a wise old head. There are days when the angler will catch nothing, and the wise old head can tell him why he didn't, and how to get out of the situation with honor.
Stocks put on a vascillating performance yesterday, ending up a little or off a little, depending on the measure used.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Harold J. Crawford, a Domestic Relations Court justice, was appointed to a City Court vacancy in Queens today by Governor Harriman. Justice Crawford is a Democrat and a former Assemblyman.
MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- Ambassador Llewellyn E. Thompson returned to Moscow tonight from two weeks of consultations in Washington.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A sudden, sharp rally in grain futures on the Board of Trade today caught some dealers by surprise while they were still lamenting Wednesday's bearish behavior.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Michigan Consolidated Gas Company filed suit in United States District Court here today in an attempt to collect $17,000,000 from the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 -- This is a winter of crazy, mixed-up weather in Miami and some crazy, mixed-up horse-racing results (in the opinion of the players of favorites) at the Hialeah track. Many sets of flossy mutuels have been flashed on the pay-off boards.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today plans for more simulated flights into outer space as its first test entered the home lap.
Latest indications are that the United States' artificial earth satellite, the Explorer, will have a life span of about four years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -Britain, by agreement with the United States, is concentrating on missile weapons more advanced than the intermediate-range ballistic missiles Thor and Jupiter.
ATHENS, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the British-Greek statement:

A published rumor yesterday may give George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, a difficult question when he addresses the New York Society of Security Analysts at their luncheon meeting today.
LUIGI (called Gigi) Molinari is director of restaurants at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He had somewhat the same job at the Plaza Hotel years ago. He is dark-haired and eager-eyed.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The stock market shook off the initial reaction today to the Government's heavy defeat in the Rochdale by-election. Industrials rallied to within a few pence below yesterday's closing prices and British Government securities resumed their advance but at a slower pace.
The 15-year-old war lord of a teen-age gang described in detail yesterday the events that led to the night of July 30, when Michael Farmer, 15, was killed in Highbridge Park.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Dave Marr carded an 8-under-par 63 in bitter cold today to take the first-round lead in the $15,000 Texas open tournament.

The crisis that was started by the French bombing of the Tunisian border village of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef last Saturday has now become dangerous. Without excusing what the French did, it must be stated that President Bourguiba and the Tunisian Government are the ones who are now inflaming the situation.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday development of a new plastic material and plans for a $9,000,000 plant to produce it.
The Board of Education plans to abandon on April 1 its new policy of first suspending troublemakers and then deciding what to do with them.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 13 -- Mrs. W. Pepper Constable of Princeton, N. J., the defending champion, led the way into the semi-finals of the women's nation squash racquets championships at t he Greenwich Country Club today. She defeated Mrs. Garth Kauffman of Greenwich, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 13, 15 -- 7, in the round of eight.
SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP) -- A daring rescuer inched 300 feet down the jagged, crumbling cliff where others had failed and found a 13-year-old boy dead on an icy ledge today.
BECAUSE she sets the example of a twenty-threeinch waistline, a flawless complexion and forty years at the top of her profession, Alexandra Danilova has no qualms about advising women on keeping fit.

PARIS, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Jorgen Ulrich of Denmark pulled the first big upset in the French indoor tennis championships today by defeating Budge Patty of Paris and Los Angeles in the quarter-finals, 15 -- 13, 6 -- 1, 8 -- 10, 7 -- 5. Patty was seeded second.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 13 -- The Mexican Government, which has been struggling the last week with a total telegraph strike, is now being faced with another embarrassing problem -the wholesale invasion of prize farmland in the State of Sinaloa by landless and jobless farm laborers.
New York University has appointed Dr. John Dale Russell, chancellor and executive secretary of the New Mexico Board of Educational Finance, to an administrative position.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies were 5.9 per cent higher in January than they were in the like 1957 month, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times. It was the tenth consecutive month to show an increase.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams declared today that a United States concern said it had paid $1,809,000 in bribes and kickbacks to Dominican Republic officials. He demanded that Congress prohibit income-tax deductions for such pay-offs.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals dealt three legal blows today to state and city officials trying to keep racial segregation in Louisiana schools, colleges and parks.
For eight weeks Edward T. Ragsdale and Edward C. Kennard rated as the most sought-after guests on Madison Avenue. But Marion Harper Jr. has emerged as the "host with the most."

General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries achieved gains in nearly all of its 1957 operations, according to the preliminary annual report released yesterday. However, the report emphasized that the rates of increase were not as large as they were a year ago, particularly in industrial sales and revenues.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- The National Broadcasting Company will initiate color program reproductions on the West Coast next Wednesday.
A Liberal party suggestion that New York State Democrats nominate Ralph J. Bunche for the United States Senate this year has received a cold Democratic response.

Berkshire Industrial Farm in Canaan, N. Y., will benefit from the April 9 performance of "Who Was That Lady I Saw You With?" The play, which Stars Peter Lind Hayes, Mary Healy and Ray Walston, will open at the Martin Beck on March 3.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13 -- India's Finance Minister became the major casualty today in a scandal that has dominated the political life of this country for weeks.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 16 points up to 6 points off yesterday. (One point equals 5 cents a bale.)

It is definite that 'Lucky Dollar," another game show in a budding trend, will make its debut on March 29 over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. It is based on the old parlor game, "Ghost."

A study of Anglo-American relations is presented by William Clark in "Less Than Kin," which Houghton Mifflin will issue Feb. 27. Mr. Clark says "the element of rivalry" has kept the relationship between the two countries "at all times interesting; at most times irritating to one country or the other; but in crisis a unifying force."
H. J. Barnum Jr. has been appointed a director of Salada-Shirriff-Horsey, packager of foods in Boston.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Tunisia submitted a formal request here today asking for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council to consider "an act of aggression" by France against Tunisia.
The Buick advertising contract was awarded yesterday to McCann-Erickson, Inc., a dark-horse in the feverish jockeying for the $24,000,000-a-year account.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 13 -- The Woman's Auxiliary of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church will hold its annual pre-Lenten dessert bridge on Monday in the parish house.
WARSAW, Feb. 13 -- The Polish Foreign Office is preparing a formal presentation of its ideas for a zone in central Europe from which nuclear weapons would be barred.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The president of a union in the merged labor movement accused the leadership today of "acting in the style of the worst labor-hating employer."

BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 13The National Association of Manufacturers elected David M. Reeves secretary today at the opening of the board's mid-winter meeting. Mr. Reeves, a resident of Old Greenwich, Conn., succeeds Thomas M. 'Brennan, who was recently appointed assistant general manager of the association.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Work stoppages in the state during 1957 were at a post-war low, the State Labor Department reported today.

Dazzling, marksmanship in the first half gave St. John's a 15-point edge over Manhattan at Madison Square Garden last night. On this comfortable cushion, the tournament-conscious Redmen rode comfortably to a 77-66 victory over their rivals of fifty years.

Soviet Government approval of a United States Government exhibition at a Moscow fair next August is expected to be granted by Monday, Norman Winston, special adviser to the international trade fair division of the Department of Commerce, said yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The Legislature received three proposals today designed to make navigable waters safer for motor boating.
CHATTANOOGA, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The City Relief Bureau passed out surplus food today to 176 families representing 925 persons.

THERE are times when the New York Philharmonic rides the waves of the future. With Rafael Kubelik making his first appearance as guest conductor of the orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, something new was added to baroque music -- an amplified harpsichord.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Lew Hoad turned on the power tonight and whipped Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, to increase his lead in their world championship professional tennis tour.
MARION McDOUGALL, soprano, who made her New York debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, proved a gifted singer who lacked the technique and artistic scope for the program she undertook.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 -- Thurman A. Whiteside, Miami lawyer, denied "categorically and absolutely" yesterday charges by Bernard Schwartz that Mr. Whiteside had used personal and financial pressure on Richard A. Mack to get a television license for National Airlines.

"Bill to Speed Street Lighting in Suffolk Gets Final Approval in State Assembly" said a headline in yesterday's Times. The same news story told how the Legislature had completed action on another bill that would give all Suffolk County towns the power now enjoyed by Babylon and Huntington to control sand and gravel pits, requiring contractors to remove dangers to children caused when the pits filled with water.
Do you want to find out in a hurry the top historicalevents of the year 30 or I683 or even 1492?
Miami, Fla., is planning to borrow $12,700,000 in the public bond market on March 5. The money will be raised by the sale of bonds secured by general taxation.

River View Terrace, a threestory garden apartment building on River Road, Edgewater, N. J., has been sold to a syndicate of investors represented by Sydney V. Stoldt of Ridgefield Park, N. J. The sale was made through the transfer of stock of River View Terrace Apartments, Inc. The property covers two acres and contains twenty-nine apartments. It was sold through the George J. Wolf Realty Company, broker.

Two Times Square landmarks are to disappear: the squat green police information booth, which men began to tear down yesterday, and the squat and friendly policeman in it. He has been put on terminal leave prior to retirement.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- Stylists of the Ford Motor Company disclosed today their concept of the atomic-powered car of the future.
A plot of land at 422-34 Warburton Avenue, opposite Trevor Park in Yonkers, has been sold by Armino A. Campagna, realty operator. It is 279 by 205 feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A proposal by the Universal Marion Corporation of Washington to acquire the Scullin Steel Company of St. Louis was approved today by their directors. It now will be submitted to shareholders.
TRENTON, Feb. 13 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority today named Grover C. Richman Jr., former State Attorney General, as its general counsel.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 13 -- Renie Cox, a Middlebury sophomore co-ed won the women's downhill race as the twentyseventh Middlebury ski carnival got under way today.
NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- The national Government tonight dissolved the City Council of Naples for "action contrary to the essential rules of correct and responsible administration."
The United States Lines is embarking on a world-wide expansion of public relations to tell the story of the American merchant marine and the company's role in international trade.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Jackie Pung of San Francisco today shot the most dazzling round of golf ever played by a woman here. She had an eight-under-par 66 to lead the first round of the women's annual St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 13 -The executive board of the 400,000-member Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America decided today to expand its organizing efforts in the South. It acted despite an anti-union tide in that area, stirred by the fight over racial segregation and other issues.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York announced yesterday that it had borrowed $20,000,000 from a group of banks here for emergency migration and to care for "thousands of refugees recently arrived in Israel."

A revival seems under way for New York State's nickname, Empire State. Last fall an effort was started to remove it as the tagline from the state's license plates in 1959 in favor of a phrase advertising next year's celebration marking the 350th anniversary of Henry Hudson's voyage up the Hudson and the discovery of Lake Champlain.
JUPITER, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP) -The 1957 winners and the 1958 medalists fell by the wayside today in the quarter-finals of the national mixed foursomes golf tournament.

A fairyland decor, twinkling lights and fabulously gowned women brought the spirit of Mardi Gras to the ballroom of the Sheraton-Astor last night. The occasion was the seventh annual Mardi Gras Ball of the Junior League of New York, a benefit for its welfare trust fund.

The age-old city of Sardis, where twenty-five centuries ago King Croesus of Lydia reigned, has long tempted the archaeologists. The site of Sardis, looking westward toward the Aegean Sea and the city that used to be called Smyrna, has layer upon layer of history underneath it.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 13 -- Supervision of training activities for Air Force Reserve and Air National Guard units in the fifteen northeastern states will be transferred from Mitchel Air Force Base to Robins Air Force Base, near Macon, Ga., on March 25.
The Ideal Toy Corporation is increasing its advertising budget this year to $750,000 from $600,000 in 1957, Melvin Helitzer, advertising director, announced yesterday.
New York's twelve-day strike of building-material truck drivers appeared on the verge of settlement yesterday.

W J SLOANE'S Valentine to budget watchers is a series of light and airy settings in a new shop opening today on the store's third floor. These settings, which are young in spirit, present myriad ideas on how to stretch the budget.
Obviously, one of the more direct routes to become a head football coach is to accept an assistant's job on Earl Blaik's Army staff.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 13 -- The United States appeared today to have become involved in a dispute between Indonesian factions on such issues as communism and President Sukarno's idea of "guided democracy."

Kurt Nielsen of Denmark and Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, head the field of thirty-two players drawn yesterday for the national indoor tennis championship. The tournament starts Wednesday evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory and ends Feb. 23.

The city entered its seventh straight day of below-freezing temperatures early this morning. At 2:30 A. M. the temperature dropped to 14 degrees and at the high yesterday the mercury recorded a chilly 24.7 degrees.
LONDON, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Antarctic team has reached the "Pole of Inaccessibility" -- a desolate area so far unexplored by man, Moscow radio declared today.

SOME literary traditions die hard. Although it has been critically unfashionable for years, the old-fashioned novel of narrative vigor and broadly portrayed, recognizably normal characters still continues to flourish. Readers, surfeited with death and damnation, ambiguous symbolism and Freudian disasters, turn with relief to the pleasures of conventional and unpretentious fiction.

Loans to business outstanding at the larger New York City banks declined $50,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yes terday. This compared with an increase of $90,000,000 in the corresponding week a year ago.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 13 -- Use of the Roman Catholic Legion of Decency's film ratings as a basis for this city's official film censorship system was attacked today in bills of complaint filed in Federal District Court.

Business leaders across the country expect an upturn in production and employment about June. This was reported here yesterday by Philip M. Talbott, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -Dr. Bernard Schwartz testified today that former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York had refused to turn over to House investigators his law firm's files on a case before the Civil Aeronautics Board.

PARIS, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Tim Brown, a medical student from Glendora, Calif., held a surprising 17.4-point lead over the defending champion, David Jenkins of Colorado Springs, today after the men's six compulsory figures in the world figure skating championships.
The nation was warned yesterday against accepting security and defense as the ultimate goals of education.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times-indicated in parentheses:
OMAHA, Feb. 13 -- The bestselling Revised Standard Version of the Bible has acquired four new publishers, and may get a fifth.

Benny Goodman, who toured the Far East in 1956 under the auspices of the State Department, will appear with his jazz orchestra at the Brussels World's Fair next May under the sponsorship of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The State Parole Board announced today the suspension for two months of Abe Hutter and Leon Miller, both Senior Parole Officers in the New York office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A Congressional subcommittee heard today the story of how a Greek engineer who invented the principle behind modern powerful atom - smashers had been dismissed as a "crank' by American scientists.

The latest Federal data on unemployment have aroused a political storm in Washington. In this Congressional election year it is understandable that the opposition party should scent the possibility of victory in November by confronting the voters with a black economic picture, responsibility for which will be put on the Eisenhower Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The State Department received with disappointment tonight the news that Tunisia had formally requested in writing a meeting of the United Nations Security Council to consider the French attack on Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef.
The first link of the Harlem River Drive was opened to traffic yesterday, with Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner among those helping to cut the ribbon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A compromise plan likely to settle the problem of Presidential succession when a President is incapacitated was put before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today.
ALL those who forgot St. Valentine's Day, take heart. The one you broke yesterday can be mended without delay.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A heavy demand for wheat futures appeared, in the final minutes of today s Board of Trade session here and prices rose sharply.
