PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 14 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight the Republican Administration "won't stand by and allow a recession to continue or unemployment to rise."

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 14.-Th Princeton Undergraduate Council, the official voice of the undergraduate body, presented today to the university administration a petition asking specific answers to seven questions about the university's stand on Princeton social life.
Have your readers so soon forgotten that the outstanding characteristic of the depression of the Nineteen Thirties was "poverty amid plenty" ?
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Reynolds Metals Company announced today a $3,000,000 improvement and expansion program for its foil rolling plant here.

Isaac Logart of Camaguey, Cuba, and Virgil Akins, a St. Louis welterweight, agreed yesterday to meet in an elimination match at Madison Square Garden. Their fight, scheduled for twelve rounds, will be held on March 21.
General Lucius D. Clay said yesterday that in the present military stalemate between the East and West national character could be the decisive factor.

Building materials, tobaccos and pharmaceuticals -- the strong stocks of recent depressed days -- continued to rise yesterday, but this time they had company. A heavy majority of the issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange made gains.
WARREN, Mich., Feb. 14 -Roy Cataldo, a General Motors engineer, drove a 1958 Chevrolet onto a concrete test track at the General Motors Technical Center today.
Striking sand, gravel and ready-mix concrete truck drivers voted unanimously yesterday to end their twelve-day walkout and go back to work Monday.
A request to Governor Harriman to veto legislation providing for revision of the City Charter was sent to Albany yesterday by Minority Leader Stanley M. Isaacs of the City Council.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 14 -Tunisians demonstrated today against the presence of French troops and what they regard as overbearing French aggression. But once again they obeyed the instructions of President Habib Bourguiba, and no Frenchman or French property was attacked.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- The union today of Iraq and Jordan again raised speculation here about the effect of the action upon the United Nations membership. The question was brought up a week ago in the merger of Syria and Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Industrial production declined in January for the fifth consecutive month, largely because of "broad curtailments in durable goods industries," the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Among the built-in stabilizers that go to work when the economy starts to sag are what the economists call transfer payments. In effect, they result from the transfer of income from one part of the population to another.
Shipments of refined copper to fabricators both here and abroad rose sharply last month -- to the surprise of many in the industry, who said their sales volume showed no corresponding increase.
Two motormen were injured slightly yesterday morning when an empty IND subway train ran into another empty train on the lay-up track at 200th Street.
A parade of witnesses, headed by Mayor Wagner, voiced unanimous opposition yesterday to railroad rate differentials. They said the differentials were harmful to the port, city and state of New York.

THE gifted child as a national resource in the struggle for scientific supremacy is finding himself the center of a spirited controversy. Parents who have been baffled about the best kind of schooling for the budding genius in their home can expect no clear-cut answers from educators.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Court of Military Appeals upset today the conviction of Marine Pfc. Frederick A. Renton. He had been sentenced to leave the service for having abused recruits at Parris Island.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Richard A. Mack of the Federal Communications Commission rejected today charges that he had accepted a pay-off for his vote in a Miami television case.
The weather was below freezing here yesterday for the seventh straight day. The Weather Bureau in Washington predicted that subnormal temperatures would prevail in the Northeast through mid-March.
Increased sales but a drop in earnings were reported for last year by the Diamond Alkali Company, Cleveland, producer of basic chemicals for industry and agriculture.

Prime Minister Rahman of Malaya has come back to his country after a short trip to Ceylon, free Vietnam and Thailand. While he was in Ceylon he made a suggestion upon which he has now elaborated. It is that the free countries of Southeast Asia might well promote some highlevel discussions of their common problems.

Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba, chose to become a prisoner in Miami yesterday because three men indicted with him for revolutionary activities against Cuba were unable to raise bail.
A SPECIALIST in weddings has joined the staff of The Bride's Shop at Rosette Pennington, 20 East Fifty-sixth Street.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- Prince Rainier tonight ran into a political storm over his role as Europe's only absolute monarch.
Five precious and somewhat fragile items were delivered safely, if casually, with yesterday's mail to the Grolier Club at 47 East Sixtieth Street.

A dapper hospital chef was charged last night with the murder of his widowed landlady's 16-year-old daughter. He told the police he had acted on an impulse when he saw the girl making herself up before a mirror.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 12 points down yesterday in light trading.

NEWARK, Feb. 14 -- Superior Court Judge Alexander P. Waugh today released John R. Cooney from the State Prison in Trenton, where the former president of the Firemen's Insurance Company of Newark was serving a one-to-two-year term for embezzlement.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A former Chinese Nationalist marine captain's contention that he will be killed if he is forced to return home drew a denial today from the Chinese Ambassador.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's new 1958 Cadillac limousine has already been ordered by the city, even though the Board of Estimate has not yet approved the purchase.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Airman Donald G. Farrell fought off five days of fatigue and loneliness today as he went into the final forty-eight hours of a simulated trip to the moon and back.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 14 -This has been and is a mixed-up fishing season in these parts, but it ought to assure fine fresh-water angling for several years to come. It is even likely that there will be first-class fishing a little later this year.

MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Jean Vuarnet of France posted the fastest time today in the giant slalom race at an international ski meet but was disqualified for reporting late at the starting point. The jury declared Bruno Alberti of Italy the winner.
Your recent editorial entitled "T. V. A. Keeps on Growing" indicates a misunderstanding of the facts with respect to its operations.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- Volume 40 of the Great Soviet Encyclopedia, containing an official biography of stalin, was made public today, almost two years after its scheduled publication.
A "Protestant revolution" fostered by laymen was urged yesterday by the president of Union Theological Seminary.

Directors of the Continental Motors Corporation yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration of 15 cents a share for payment April 18. In previous quarters shareholders received 10 cents a share.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest, Treasurer of the United States, tonight received the 1958 award of the Philadelphia Club of Advertising Women.
Manufacturers' contributions to special promotional events of department stores may violate the Robinson-Patman Act, according to a trade association executive.
The National Supply Company last year attained the highest sales and earnings in its history, despite a decline in its fourth-quarter business.

A high bid of $201,000 was submitted yesterday for Ellis Island as the Federal Government opened offers for the abandoned harbor property. If the bid is accepted, a New York builder plans to convert the twenty - seven - acre site into a $55,000,000 resort and cultural center.

NEWARK, Feb. 14 -- New Jersey's Commissioner of Conservation and Economic Development appealed today for teamwork between industry and government to preserve and extend the state's industrial and economic resources.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Dr. I. I. Rabi, Nobel Prize-winning physicist, has been appointed top United States member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's new Science Committee, the State Department announced today.
A shopping center that is, in a refined way, perhaps the most luxurious in the country opened recently in Palm Beach to coincide with the height of that resort's season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Gladys Swarthout, whose singing career was interrupted by heart ailment, received a Valentine Day's "Heart-of-theyear Award" from the American Heart Association.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- France filed a countercomplaint against Tunisia with the Security Council today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -The Administration admitted today that accidents involving nuclear weapons in transport might result in poisonous fallout in the form of dust.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 8 -If boredom is the problem, then perhaps the solution is to enroll in a spearfishing class under Bernie Butler, a swashbuckling young teacher who sometimes teaches lessons to sharks.
Deputy Police Commissioner Robert J. Mangum was officially reprimanded yesterday for "impulsive and improper" action in voiding an arrest in a traffic case, but he was cleared for return to duty.

While diplomatic soundings are under way to ascertain whether a new summit meeting is possible, the British Government has issued a clear warning that any Soviet attack on the West will be answered immediately with a strategic nuclear bombardment.
Formation of an export trade corporation under the name High Volatile Coal Export Association, Inc., was announced yesterday following a meeting of the new group at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A proxy fight for control of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad apparently has been averted. The terms are expected to be announced following a directors' meeting next Monday.

New faces will be prominent tonight in the nation's oldest track meet. The New York Athletic Club has corralled fresh talent to send against the regulars of the indoor circuit in its ninetieth anniversary games at Madison Square Garden.
Lufthansa, the West German airline, started Super-Star Constellation service yesterday. The first nonstop flight from Frankfurt to New York carried the Mayors of Frankfurt, Hamburg and Vienna.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to interfere with the Pennsylvania Railroad's plan to curtail and consolidate passenger train service between major Eastern cities.
Christians will begin this Wednesday -- Ash Wednesday -to mark the penitential season of Lent that precedes Easter Sunday, which falls this year on April 6.
Historians and other churchmen at the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church here are engrossed by the remarkable news that one man was offered two bishoprics on the same day.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- The new president of the rackets-encrusted International Union of Operating Engineers promised today he would clean up all abuses revealed by Senate investigators or by the ethical practices group of the merged labor federation.
Six fire fighters were killed last night in a fierce, smoky, five-alarm fire that demolished a paper and twine factory at 137 Wooster Street, in downtown Manhattan.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 14 -- Planning board members in near-by Franklin Township hereafter must swear to their honesty before voting on subdivision proposals.

The police chief of Utica, N. Y., told state investigators yesterday that he kept $10,000 in cash in a dresser drawer in his home but denied that it was payment for protecting gambling and prostitution in the upstate city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee served notice today in its first major action on President Eisenhower's new budget that Congress had lost its zeal for economy.
The Raytheon Manufacturing Company of Waltham, Mass., one of the largest electronics concerns in the country, was sold and leased back its research laboratory plant in Wayland, Mass.

Today's new film is "Festival in Moscow," a feature-length Soviet-made color documentary, at the Cameo Theatre. Made by the Central Documentary Film Studios of Moscow, the import depicts the activities last August at the World Youth Festival.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- Henry Cabot Lodge said today that India would find the United States an "earnest associate in the search for disarmament."
Iraq and Jordan, united yesterday as the Arab Federation, have long been linked culturally and historically. The federation erases a frontier in existence only thirty-six years.
Albert L. Hart has been appointed vice president of national sales, Cotan division, Interchemical Corporation.
William Howard Melish denied yesterday that he was guilty of contempt because he had continued to reside in the rectory of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights.

NEWARK, Feb. 14 -- The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark announced today an intensive campaign against indecent literature and motion pictures. The drive, starting next week, will be organized on a parish level.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Behind the brouhaha and bluster of its somewhat lame explanations on the Tunisian bombing, the French Government is deeply embarrassed by this totally unnecessary tragedy. France's real attitude is not to be detected in Premier Gaillard's explanatory speech.

The price of antimony metal was reduced 4 cents a pound yesterday by the nation's principal supplier, the National Lead Company. The change was the first in the price of antimony since Aug. 17, 1955, when it was raised 4 1/2 cents.

Gray Drug Stores, Inc., announced yesterday it had purchased the twelve stores operated by the King Drug Company of Cincinnati. The purchase price, including fixtures, leasehold and inventory, amounted to about $1,000,000.
BERLIN, Feb. 14 -- United States officials are hearing with increasing frequency from Germans that the United States is not adaptable enough about seeking ways to an East-West rapprochement.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The stock market ended the week much more firmly than it seemed likely a few days ago. Prices generally were steady with South African gold mining stocks moving strongly ahead on substantial investment demand.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -Navy officials said today that the three projected nuclearpowered Polaris missile submarines would be the largest submarines ever built. They are to be finished in 1960.
The river of electricity that girdles the earth at the equator in the upper fringes of the atmosphere appears to be many miles deep.
CAIRO, Feb. 14 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser sent to King Faisal today a message congratulating him on the federation of Iraq with the sister monarchy of Jordan.

THE current vogue for oriental furnishings has brought with it a demand for pewter accessories. The influx of fine pewter pieces rivals the golden age of the Dutch Pewterers Guild in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -The Insurance Company of North America companies have reported that premiums written in 1957 totaled $322,738,000, an increase of 12 per cent over the 1956 figure of $288,391,000.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 -- A bomb threat cleared a Harvard lecture hall tonight in the midst of a debate on racial integration.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- The French Government was under heavy fire in Parliament today for its failure to control its military forces responsible for the bombing of Sakiet-SidiYoussef in Tunisia. Foreign Minister Christian Pineau faced the brunt of the storm when he went before the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly to explain FrenchTunisian relations and the decision to file a counter-charge against Tunisian with the United Nations Security Council.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -The Nuclear Corporation of America, Inc., received a patent this week for a ship in which the cargo could be irradiated on its way to market.

The new capital market is again becoming congested. A heavy volume of corporate and local government securities is standing by, awaiting its turn at the market. More than a half-billion dollars worth of this is slated to come up for pricing and offering next week.
A man and wife who reportedly defrauded the city's Welfare Department of $10,000 in the last eleven months were arrested early yesterday on grand larceny charges.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The United States endorsed the union of Iraq and Jordan today in cautious words like those it employed when Egypt and Syria united two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -Representative Wright Patman says the Government owns the Federal Reserve System and "Congress can no longer ignore its obligation to place proper safeguards and audits on this Government agency."

MIAMI, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Manager Al Lopez of the Chicago White Sox, co-favorite with Alvin Dark of the St. Louis Cardinals in the National Baseball Players' golf tournament, defeated Don Bessent of the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3 and 2, in a first-round match today.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Feb. 14 -- Col. Fred G. Hook Jr. is charged with the supersonic defense of New York City. But at the same time he is fighting a running battle to hold in uniform his highly specialized personnel.
Nuri Eren's interesting discussion of partition and Cyprus in your Feb. 4 issue contains errors and omissions of fact which are fatal to his thesis.

One more step in closing the loop to form a peripheral highway around Manhattan has been taken with the completion by the city of the construction of the first stage of the long-projected Harlem River Drive. In itself the first stage provides for a direct vehicular connection with the Third Avenue Bridge, the Triborough Bridge and the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today the Republican bill scheduling the primary election for June 3 and state nominating conventions for June 16 and 17.

RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 14 -The North Carolina State Ports Authority today held up on the employment of D. Leon Williams of Savannah, Ga., as its executive director after learning that Mr. Williams and other officials had been under legislative fire for their operations of the state ports in Georgia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- The screen branch of the Writers Guild of America will attempt to force recognition of a new contract demand for royalty participation in films that may be shown on pay television. The membership voted last night to cancel the guild's contracts with the major studios," as soon as legally possible."
A conference aimed at improving lighting methods throughout the country will be held at the Coliseum from March 9 to 12.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -Secretary of State Dulles will cut short his mid-winter holiday and return to Washington Monday to direct United States efforts to settle the Tunisian crisis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Universal-International has decided to become active in the field of entertainment films for television. As the first step, the studio has completed production deals with the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- A seven-man delegation of the Soviet Communist party started a monthlong inspection of Italian communism today. The visit of the Soviet Communists coincides with the opening of the Italian Reds' campaign for the coming general elections.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and his closest Cabinet advisers have dismissed an early general election from their political considerations.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 14 -The formation today of the Arab Federation, joining the kingdoms of Iraq and Jordan, was described by key diplomats as a spectacular stride toward Arab unity.
The ferryboat Dongan Hills did not see the approaching tanker Tynefield until it was too late to avoid a collision, the British tanker's Hudson River pilot testified yesterday.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The French said tonight that up to 400 Algerian rebels from Tunisia cut their way through an electrified barbedwire barrier last night and entered Algeria. Some of them were brought to battle today, the French command reported.

The number of reported cases of syphilis in the United States rose in 1957 for the second consecutive year, three health agencies reported yesterday. The agencies were the American Social Hygiene Association, the Association of State and Territorial Health Officers and the American Venereal Disease Association.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 14 -- Military and political leaders of Central Sumatra continued today to manifest defiance of the Indonesian central Government in Jakarta.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Alexander J. Lechert Jr., 39 years old of 225 Adams Street, Brooklyn, was awarded $175,000 today for injuries suffered in a 1956 train accident.

There can no longer be any doubt that Bernard Schwartz, deposed counsel of the House subcommittee investigating Federal regulatory agencies, has started something that must be carried through to an uncompromising conclusion.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Feb. 14 -- Clouds of political tension are rolling over the warm, flat plains of Northern Rhodesia.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Feb. 14 -The scientist who directed the design of the hydrogen bomb said here today that settlement houses were better designed than the bomb to preserve freedom in the world.

A one-volume edition of the twenty-two volume "Dictionary of American Biography" is being prepared under the auspices of the American Council of Learned Societies and will be published by Scribners. A second supplement to the parent Dictionary, shortly to be published, will add 585 biographies of celebrated Americans and extend the work to include all important figures who died before the end of 1940.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 14 -- There was no question in Jakarta tonight that both sides had squared off in one of the gravest crises to face Indonesia.
For people living in houses built upon stilts the winter thus far probably has been routine, without major incident. For those at ground level it could have been no more than faintly tiresome.

PARIS, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The police tonight banned a meeting called by a group of leftist intellectuals, including Jean-Paul Sartre, to protest the French bombing of the Tunisian village of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef. The police said the meeting might lead to public disturbances.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles today named Lawrence T. (Buck) Shaw to coach the club out of the National Football League cellar.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -The level of average primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent to 118.8 per cent of its 1947-49 average during the week ended last Tuesday, Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

A match between Oscar Panno of Argentina and William Lombardy, United States, highlighted the pairings in the seventeenth round of the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas in Bogota yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The City, London's financial district, still shows its war scars. Great empty spaces contrast sharply with narrow, congested streets that seem overbuilt and, by day, overpopulated. These gaps are being filled by modern buildings and The City continues to be the principal banking center of the world.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 14 -Senator Jacob K. Javits tonight proposed a national strategy convention of the Republican party to devise an action program for reversing the recession.
Gale Kerwin defeated Stefan Redl in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The decision was by majority vote and was not well received by the crowd of about 3,000.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- The proclamation today of the Arab Federation of Iraq and Jordan contained the following twelve articles:
Mikhail A. Menshikov, the new Soviet Ambassador, will make his American television debut on March 16.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 14 -- President Eisenhower remained indoors at Milestone Plantation near here today as the temperature rose to 56 degrees on the Glen Arven Country Club Course near-by. At 8:30 A. M., however, the temperature outside the President's cottage had been 22 degrees.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Feb. 14 (UP) -- American scientists and pilots filled in a huge blank area on Antarctic maps today with the announcement of the discovery of a mountain range comparable in size to the Rockies.
The Fire Patrol, a private force of 180 men, fights water while city firemen cope with the blaze.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., has signed contracts for four new merchant ships at a total cost exceeding $43,000,000.
DETROIT, Feb. 14 -- The General Motors council of the United Automobile Workers proposed today that prepaid health insurance be financed from the company's excess profits.
The Acme Air Appliance Company, manufacturer of valves, gauges and screwmachine parts, has leased the new one-story building in the Metropolitan Industrial Center on Newman Street, Hackensack, N. J.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- The Claiborne Farm's Nadir made a last-place start and a first-place finish in his first 1958 race at the Hialeah track today. And it's probable that his owner, A. B. (Bull) Hancock Jr., heaved a sigh of relief when it was over.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14 -The Government has halted the decline of the cruzeiro by prohibiting Brazilian banks from speculating in dollars. The Bank of Brazil issued an order forbidding banks from selling or speculative borrowing of dollars from one another.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP) -Motor vehicle production in United States factories this week will total 104,419 cars and 18,814 trucks, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. This compared with 109,028 cars and 19,481 trucks built last week.

DES MOINES, Feb. 14 (AP) -The Des Moines Register said today in a copyright story by Clark Mohlenhoff of its Washington Bureau that Sherman Adams had intervened with the Civil Aeronautics Board in an airlines case in which Murray Chotiner was an attorney.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Gypsy Markoff, an accordionist, showed her crippled right shoulder before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today. She pleaded for compensation for injuries suffered in a plane crash at Lisbon, Portugal, in 1943.

The five-story building containing twenty air-conditioned apartments at 330 East Fiftyseventh Street in the Sutton Place area has been purchased by Leonard J. Winston, realty operator. The property, on a plot 37 by 100 feet, was sold by a client of Charles S. Phillips, attorney, for cash over mortgages of $195,000.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 14 -- Middlebury's team was leading by .36 of a point tonight in a bid for the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association championship at the Middlebury winter carnival.
A new chain letter scheme using United States Savings Bonds as the pay-off is making the rounds, the Post Office Department warned yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- At the age of 22, Faisal II of Iraq is the senior King in the Middle East. He succeeded to the throne almost nineteen years ago.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- Two persons died and at least twenty-two were made homeless early today by a fire that swept the upper floors of a five-story apartment house at 8 Beechwood Avenue, near the Pelham boundary.

Four essay contest winners from four continents arrived yesterday to take part in World Brotherhood Week beginning Monday.

The Priors Club, an affiliate of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, awarded a newly created scholarship yesterday to Marsha Feinbaum, a 16-year-old senior at the Bronx High School of Science.

AN unglamorous but very worthwhile item, a locking differential, is being offered as optional equipment on most of the 1958 automobiles. In effect, the device transfers power from the skidding wheel to the other wheel.

THE Berkshire Festival has engaged six young American pianists to appear as soloists with the Boston Symphony at Tanglewood this summer. THE installation of wood paneling in almost any room in the house is a popular form of home improvement. However, it is not complete until the desired finish is carefully applied. THE title of Anita Rowe Block's first volume of short stories is misleading. In spite of the "sophistication" implicit in her title, Mrs. Block's most effective stories are about teenagers. SCHEDULES for the major spring garden shows list a wide range of exhibits, arrangements and educational displays. The first of the local shows -- the Long Island Nurserymen's Association's twelfth annual Spring Garden Show -- will open its doors at 12 noon on Saturday.

AT the close of last Sunday's column I reverted to an old weakness of mine, and ventured a literary prediction. Now, probably, I shall be accused of hedging on it, but here goes. I expressed the belief that naturalism in the American novel is on its last legs, and that the writers who are aware of its decay are the ones who "will carry American literature on to new levels of achievement and power.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Princeton defeated Cornell, 66 -- 63, in an Ivy League basketball game tonight. The Tigers won from the foul line. They sank twenty of twenty-eight foul shots while the Big Red managed fifteen of twenty-three.

TRENTON, Feb. 15 -- Comprehensive plans to reduce the tax burden on residential property owners in New Jersey were presented today to Gov. Robert B. Meyner and the Legislature. After several years of rigid Government control, the cotton industry is faced with a critical supply situation unless legislation is enacted soon to increase the permissible acreage for this year's crop.
MIAMI, Feb. 15 -- A Calumet Farm 3-year-old colt, with William Hartack doing the horse-chauffeuring, won Hialeah's Everglades Stakes in 1956. Same story in 1957. Ditto today.

The Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., trade organization, will hold its fifty-fifth annual fair March 10 to 19 at the New Yorker and Sheraton-McAlpin hotels. The show will be about the same size as those of recent years.
DETROIT, Feb. 14 -- The automobile industry is suffering mid-winter jitters about lagging sales, labor troubles and mounting unemployment.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 -- Californians are bracing for another bitter campaign contest.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Feb. 15 -- Industrial workers of this city and neighboring Saco know what George M. Humphrey meant by a "hair curling" depression. They have been living with one for the last six years or so.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The White House has designated five Cabinet members to present to Congress the Administration's case for extension of an effective reciprocal trade program.

HARVARD -- Salaries Harvard University will increase all faculty salaries this summer. Full professors will receive a top of $20,000, associate professors $11,000, assistant professors $7,700 and instructors $5,500. There will be increased tuition charges at Harvard College, Radcliffe College and two graduate schools.

GENUINE primitive art, whose primary purpose was the satisfaction of spiritual or psychological needs, imposes a formidable task of appreciation on Western man. For, by and large, and more emphatically now than ever, we have reduced art to acts of self-expression which appeal to the eye, to our sense of poetry and to personal or fashionable taste.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Navy plans to build twenty new ships, convert seven others and make a start on items for an atomic - powered carrier in the fiscal year 1959, which begins July 1.
For a number of reasons our annual National Heart Month has particular international significance this year. Heart disease is now recognized as a world problem.

Oscar Panno of Argentina was still in the lead in the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas, in Bogota, after seventeen rounds, with two adjourned games still pending, according to a report received last night through Colombian news sources.

ONE year ago, on Jan. 22, 1957, French Canada's best - known character actor and producer -- Gratien Gelinas -- announced that he was about to try to realize a long-cherished dream: the creation of a theatre dedicated to encouraging the works of Canadians.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) The Administration is working on another billion-dollar program for lease-purchase construction of 150 to 170 Federal buildings.

From two different directions during the last few days the question of the future of the Antarctic has been raised. The United States has announced that it will continue, after the conclusion of the present International Geophysical Year, to operate four scientific stations in the area.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 15 -- Tenafly High captured the Lieut. Al Blozis Memorial Eastern States one-mile relay at the Jersey City Armory today. With a 3:37.3 clocking, Tenafly beat Boys High and St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Sharp increases in claims for unemployment compensation throughout the Middle West point up a worsening economic picture in the first six weeks of 1958.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 15 (UP) -- The Knollwood Stable's Movitave, a Maryland-bred filly, led nearly all the way today in registering a one-and-one-half-length victory in the $16,750 Miss Maryland Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Bowie.

The Niagara University basketball team staged a late rally to beat Fordham at the Rams' gym last night, 88 to 81. The issue was decided in overtime, the teams being tied at 80-all at the end of the regulation time.

THIS is the season for annual awards, which have grown from one in the not very remote past to three last year and five this year. The annual Capezio Dance Award, the first in the field, still gives only one award each year, and continues to make it a very practical one, consisting of money.

A key man in any Congressional investigation is the chief counsel of the investigating committee. His job is to direct the staff that gathers the evidence, and then to have witnesses put it in the record in hearings. Nominally he is chosen by the committee majority, but in practice he gets his job from the chairman.

LIKE so many concepts about plant growth, the theory regarding the cause of winter damage to broadleaved evergreens is now being seriously questioned. Heretofore wood screens and burlap shields were used to protect leaves from sun and wind. Four years ago it was demonstrated that a very thin layer of plastic -- applied as a spray -- protected plants as well as did older methods.

MARIO SOLDATI is a writer who is nothing if not unpredictable, "Dinner With the Commandatore," the first of his books to be published in the United States, was a trio of urbanely told stories slightly reminiscent of Somerset Maugham.
The punishment of youthful offenders was said yesterday to be effective usually on a short-range basis only, and when administered by an adult interested in the child's welfare.

THE Twenty-second Annual New York Press Photographers exhibition will be placed on display Wednesday at the Chrysler Automobile Salon, Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue, where it may be seen 9 A. M. to 6 P. M. to Feb. 28 (Feb. 22 and 23 excepted).

A Brooklyn man, who investigators said loaded his wife and seven children into the family Cadillac and drove to the Welfare Department to complain about a proposed reduction in his $40-a-week allotment, was arraigned yesterday in Weekend Court on a charge of fraud.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals was asked yesterday to set aside the conviction of Colonel Rudolf Ivanorich Abel for having conspired to spy for the Soviet Union.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -Mayor Richardson Dilworth, often mentioned as a possible Democratic candidate for Governor this fall, took himself out of the race today.

To keep down the clouds of dust that rise in confined areas when dirty floors are being swept, moistening with water is often resorted to. One way to apply just the right amount of water without puddling is to spray it on. Use a garden sprayer or a vacuum cleaner spraying attachment filled with water.

IN an age like this, dedicated, in writing at least, to the glorification of the submental and the study, in fiction, of idiot psychology, the hope of the serious novel, must lie, I imagine, in the past or the future. The contemporary standards of craftsmanship have destroyed, for me, the faith and the work of a lifetime.
HONG KONG, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- Hong Kong's appointed Legislative Council has adopted a new education law aimed at insuring that the schools in this colony are not used for propaganda purposes.

THE community project has been gaining favor among camera clubs across the country. A recent example was the preparation, by members of the Lens and Shutter Club of Omaha, of a photographic history of the Nebraska city.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- For the third year in a row Harvard's track forces proved too strong for Yale and Princeton as the Cantabs took the sixth annual indoor triangular meet at Coxe Cage on the Yale campus today.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- Walter Ulbricht, Communist party leader of East Germany, envisions a proposed federation of East and West Germany as a treaty arrangement between equal states. They would come together in a council on which the two would have equal membership.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 15 -- The Moroccan Foreign Ministry protested today against the movement of French troops in the region of Agadir, Morocco's southernmost port.

I have read with great interest and no little amusement the three separate articles under the common title "Vodka Drinkers of the World --". The writer of the third article, "Remorseless Liquid," is certainly in error when he states "originally made for the Russian Czars from potatoes, etc."
PERTH, Australia, Feb. 15 -- Herb Elliott, 19-year-old Perth runner, gave the home folks a thrill today. He defeated Mervyn Lincoln by a foot for his third consecutive mile timed under four minutes.

MIAMI, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Mickey Mantle's long drives got caught in forty-mile-and-hour winds today and the Yankee slugger lost to Manager Al Lopez of the Chicago White Sox, 4 and 3, in a quarter-final match of the baseball players' national golf championship.

AROUND-UP of orchestral disks released during the last few months reveals the expected concentration on the standard repertory. One disk that stands out is the performance that Otto Klemperer and the Philharmonia Orchestra (Angel) have given the Brahms First Symphony.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- Harold Stassen faced the opposition of the state Republican organization today in his bid for the gubernatorial nomination.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Johnny Monckton, a 19-year-old carpenter, broke two world back-stroke records tonight in the Australian swimming championships and swam the first leg for a relay team that smashed another world record.

They blast off without countdown.

The New York Knickerbockers kept their hopes alive for a play-off spot in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association last night. Ken Sears' two free throws with forty-two seconds remaining enabled the Knicks to down the Cincinnati Royals, 99 to 97, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- With all of its catering to luxury-loving visitors, Florida still possesses many primitive, out-of-the-way places that offer hideaways for quiet solitude. Many of these comparatively un-touristic spots lie along the coast of the Gulf of Mexico in the western part of the state, offering a striking contrast to the built-up areas with which most Florida tourists are familiar.

The number of deaths from influenza and pneumonia in 108 cities has been rising steadily for the past four weeks, it was reported last week by Surgeon-General Leroy E. Burney of the United States Public Health Service. The cause of the rise is a mystery, as there is no evidence of any widespread increase in Asian influenza cases throughout the United States.

A STRIKING figure among contemporary French composers and one too little played in this country is Olivier Messiaen. Salvatore Anthony Maglie will be 41 years old next April 26. An athlete of those years, especially a major league ball player, usually is regarded as having reached "a ripe, old age."

Hope that four men were still alive beneath the smoldering wreckage of a downtown paper and twine factory vanished last night as the one remaining wall threatened to collapse on rescuers. Seven hundred fifty firemen -- more than 500 of them volunteers -- had dug through the wreckage most of the day.

The big question facing retailers now is whether the chemise fashion can give a lift to sagging ready-to-wear sales. With Easter only seven weeks away, observers are wondering if large numbers of women can be influenced to replace their present wardrobes with the unfitted look and thereby inject new life into the industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The long-dormant Commission on Civil Rights hopes to find a staff director next week and get to work.

OERNSKOELDSVIK, Sweden, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Bengt Eriksson of Sweden continued his domination of a Swedish-United States Nordic ski meet by winning the fifteen-kilometer cross-country race today in 1 hour 1 minute 12 seconds.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- The favored Wolverhampton Wanderers today defeated Darlington, 6 -- 1, as Manchester United sat out the fifth round of competition for the Football Association Cup, the top trophy in British soccer.

United States trade in the Far East stands in no immediate jeopardy, in the opinion of Joseph F. Gillen of the American President Lines. He says this country is still the Orient's big supplier and best customer, and the general impression there is that we will continue to hold that dual role.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Army's basketball team gave plenty of anxious moments to a favored New York University quintet today before suffering a 91-to-88 defeat in an overtime contest.

Nonagricultural employment in Illinois in December was 77,900 below the 1956 level, the State Employment Service has reported. The total was 3,502, 000 on Dec. 15, compared with 3,579,900 on Dec. 15, 1956. There was a gain of 7,400 from Nov. 15 to Dec. 15, owing to the sharp seasonal increase in retail trade employment, which rose 23,600 to 554,200.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Murray Rose of Sydney, Australia, swam 440 yards faster than any other person in history when he was clocked in 4 minutes 21.5 seconds in the Yale pool tonight. On his way to the 440 distance Rose bettered all previous performances at 400 meters with a time of 4:20.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Unshaken by fierce attacks from Left and Right, the Liberal party decided today to nominate the largest possible number of candidates for Britain's next general election.

MIAMI, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Albie Pearson, a rookie outfielder with the Washington Senators, won the major league division of the Baseball Players' Golf Tournament today on the nineteenth hole. He defeated John Gray of the Philadelphia Phillies.

Today begins what is likely to be one of the most important and fiercest legislative battles of this Congressional session. The struggle will be joined at the hearings before the House Ways and Means Committee, which will consider President Eisenhower's request for a five-year renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

Rudolf Firkusny, who was the soloist in the world premiere of Bohuslav Martinu's Fourth Piano Concerto at the Metropolitan Museum in October, 1956, played the same work again yesterday afternoon with the New York Philharmonic under the baton of Rafael Kubelik.
The Sheikhdom of Kuwait will have 2,500,000 gallons of fresh water a day from the salt water of the Persian Gulf by the end of this month.

A group of high school students said yesterday that teen-agers were increasingly rebellious toward authority -- especially parental authority. And the tension behind the teen-agers' attitudes come from a lack of close understanding with their parents, they added.
WASHINGTON, N. J., Feb. 16 (AP) -- The militia was called out today to help get an expectant mother to a hospital.
Most New Yorkers stayed home yesterday, and for good reason.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- A British soldier was wounded early this morning in a raid on an army camp in southwest England by a band of men who said they were members of the Irish Republican Army.
A Roman Catholic priest from New Delhi, India, accused many Americans yesterday of "unwittingly" feeding the Communist propaganda machine in the wake of the two Soviet earth satellite launchings.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- Two profoundly important repercussions have emerged from the Sakiet bombing. The Algerian civil war has now been "internationalized" willy-nilly, despite French efforts to the contrary. And it has been plainly demonstrated that Paris cannot simultaneously seek to hold the friendship of Tunisia and Morocco while pursuing a policy of repression in the area between.
CAIRO, Feb. 16 -- Egyptians began to take a more critical look today at the Arab Federation of Jordan and Iraq.

Still undefeated after eighteen rounds of the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas in Bogota, Oscar Panno of Argentina was a point ahead of Miguel Najdorf of Argentina, with one round to play, according to a report received yesterday through Colombian news sources.

The hottest issue in this session of the Legislature is the question of selecting the best method to fight organized crime. It is hot only because the Republican leaders are irresponsibly seeking to make political hay out of very serious business.

The winter's heaviest snowstorm smashed into the Northeastern States yesterday, turning into a full-fledged blizzard after roaring past the New York metropolitan area. Heaping drifts and hardening ice foreshadowed widespread difficulties for commuters at the start of the work week today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 16 -- The army tonight ordered the arrest on treason charges of the Premier and five Ministers of the revolutionary Government proclaimed in Sumatra yesterday.

PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Alex Goguen of Pittsfield, Mass., today won the North American outdoor speed skating championship in a snowstorm. About 100 skaters participated in the two-day event.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 -- There was less gloom in the steel industry last week: The slight change in attitude was the result of a cessation in the decline of new orders. There also was a tendency for the level of new business to flatten out.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 16 -- A white toy poodle from Medina, Ohio, Ch. Silhou-Jette's Snow Sprite, could not have had a more appropriate name for today's Elm City Kennel Club dog show.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 16 -- Israelis clashed with forces of the two-day-old Arab Federation this afternoon on Mount Scopus, an Israeli demilitarized area surrounded by Jordanian territory northeast of Jerusalem.

SEOUL, Monday, Feb. 17 (AP) -- South Korean military men said today that the missing Korean National Airline plane had been tracked by radar to a point about ten miles from Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Montgomery Ward Co. put into the mail today its 1958 farm catalogue of 180 closely printed pages.

The week-end storm disrupted travel generally in the metropolitan area but motorists had the worst time, many being snowed under. Driving will still be hazardous today, but improvement is expected on the main routes.
A Klondike type of rescue brought to safety yesterday a 66-year-old woman marooned in Brooklyn's snow. New York's mechanized equipment had been foiled by drifts and ice.
ROME, Feb. 16 -- Adriano Olivetti, Europe's leading typewriter manufacturer and the founder of a new left-of-center party, opened his campaign today for Italy's forthcoming general elections.

Proceeds from the March 26 evening performance of "The Entertainer," starring Laurence Olivier, will go to Encampment for Citizenship, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, to be used for scholarships.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (UP) -- George Halas, the owner of the Chicago Bears, today said he would return as head coach of the National Football League club next season. He confined himself to front-office duties the last two years.
The Globe Theatre was renamed yesterday the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre to honor the acting team of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Dr. William F. MacCalmont, pastor of Westminster Presbyterian Church, Akron, Ohio, will become president of Westminster Choir College here, effective June 15. This was announced today by Dr. John Finley Williamson, founder and retiring president of the college.

A vacant building at 237 East Seventy-second Street has been sold by Margaret Nugent to Joseph L. Ennis Co., realty operators. The sale was the first involving the property since 1925 and was negotiated by Douglas Gibbons-Hollyday Ives, Inc., broker.

THE Canterbury Choral Society placed Handelians in its debt yesterday. It presented a carefully prepared and musically sensitive performance of a work Handel-lovers seldom get to hear, "Samson," the oratorio he began as soon as he completed "Messiah."

A HANDSOME woman who writes delicate novels leaves her Sutton Place apartment every Monday morning to work for her twin loves: policemen and children. She contends that they have one thing in common -- both are frequently misunderstood.

The editorial on "Privacy in Peacemaking" in The Times of Feb. 6 has a pertinent bearing on the delicate and difficult problem of balance between openings and secrecy in the conduct of international relations. Its reference to Woodrow Wilson in connection with comments on and by U. N. Secretary General Hammarskjold kindled a nostalgic memory for this letter writer, who was a research and reference clerk with the Wilson Peace Commission in Paris during 1919.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen called today for a summit conference moderated by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations and including Poland and Czechoslovakia among the conferees.

Private electric utilities said yesterday that they should be allowed to use advertising to meet any competitor, even when that competitor is the Federal Government. Moreover, they said, the cost of such advertising should be deductible as an ordinary business expense.

PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 16 -- The head of the new revolutionary Indonesian government held his first Cabinet meeting tonight. Dr. Sjafruddin Prawiranegara, designated as Premier of the rebel regime, called the session after receipt of news that Jakarta had ordered the arrest of six civilian members of the Cabinet here.

WILKES STATION, Antarctica, Feb. 4 -- The South Polar skua -- often called the vulture of the Antarctic -- has found a dedicated defender in Carl Eklund. "The skua is the miniature eagle of the Antarctic," insists Mr. Eklund, who has just completed a year as scientific leader at Wilkes Station. "All the nasty things people say about the skua are a lot of hogwash."
Andrew J. Seidler has resigned as executive director of the New York City Council on Port Development and Promotion to become director of the Youth Counsel Bureau of the District Attorney's office.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- A Republican housing program involving two state bond issues of $100,000,000 each was announced today by Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan. He is chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing.
Verdi's "Otello" will return to the Metropolitan Opera repertory Feb. 27 after an absence of two seasons.

The Columbia Gas System, Inc., subsidiaries sold more gas in 1957 than in any previous year, according to the annual report released over the weekend. Columbia Gas is a holding company. Gas sales totaled 646,402,000,000 cubic feet, a gain of 6.8 per cent over the previous high in 1956.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 16 -- Nassau County's mental health program will be expanded this year to provide additional treatment and diagnostic facilities for the county's 1,200,000 residents. Four outpatient centers are planned to augment the eleven treatment and diagnostic centers now in operation.

Increasing concern is being felt along the Main Streets of suburban New York because of competition from large, regional shopping centers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- Broad plans for reorganizing production operations and streamlining the film-distribution system of Universal-International were formulated by Milton R. Rackmil, president, in meetings here last week with Nate J. Blumberg, board chairman, and other company executives.

" WIDE WIDE WORLD" presented yesterday afternoon a generally absorbing study of persons in their middle years and those who sensibly planned for their retirement. While the ornate prose and careful rehearsal of the program tended to impair the spontaneity of the ninety minutes over Channel 4, it none the less was often informative and helpful and vicariously interesting.

The five-story apartment house for twenty families at 144 West Ninety-first Street was purchased by an investing client of Louis Schlesinger, attorney, Robert Sheldon, president of Ehrlich, Corso, Feldman Co., was the broker.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 16 -- The next ministerial meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has been scheduled to take place in May, West German Government sources said today.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Bill Johnston, a professional golfer from Provo, Utah, won the $15,000 Texas open today with a three-under-par 68 for a 72-hole total of 274.

Word has been received from Dublin that another play -- a dramatization of James Joyce's "Ulysses" -- has been dropped by the Dublin Theatre Festival, set to begin on May 11. The play, adapted by Alan McClelland, is called "Bloomsday."
What are the facts behind the Tunisian crisis which has shaken the Western world so badly during the past nine days? What are the chances for a peaceable way out of it?
Winter visited all its miseries on more than half the nation yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A five week's tour set-up to help save South American children from malnutrition got under way this week-end.

VERDI had his share of muddled librettos, but in "Rigoletto" he found a story that was straight and swift. Here at last, as the vigorous, earthy middle period of his creative career began to flower, he could unloose his power as a writer for the lyric theatre, and here, too, he could find fuller expression for his grasp of the human predicament.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Prices of grain futures made their shifts mostly in big leaps and under strong influences last week, but the net results were small except in wheat and rye.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 16 -- Airman Donald G. Farrell completed today a seven-day simulated trip to the moon. He reported that nothing seemed impossible or boring about space travel. His duties kept him too busy to get bored or scared, the 23-year-old volunteer said after he had crawled from an experimental space cabin at Randolph Air Force Base.

HELSINKI, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Russia finished one, two in the world speed skating championships today with Oleg Goncharenko, the 1953 winner, overhauling Vladimir Shilikovski in the last two events of the two-day competition for the title.
NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A United States Air Force transport plane vanished last night on a flight to Turkey, touching off a vast sea and air search in the Mediterranean.
The Very Rev. James A. Pike declared yesterday that the tide was turning against "an era of secularism" prevailing in the United States for fifty years.

HAIFA, Israel, Feb. 10 -- The wisp of a man who perches behind a huge desk in Haifa's cavernous Technion building is one of the few persons in Israel today with more concern about how to spend his money than about where it is coming from.

It is an annoying fact that choices once made don't always stay made. The contrary wish remains, nudging at the outer borders of decision. For example, one had decided long ago to live in the North -- yet the pull of the South (particularly at this time of year) reasserts itself occasionally with strength.
WESTON, Conn., Feb. 16 -- The Fairfield County Wheaton Club will open its Scholarship Fund Drive with a Prologue Party Feb. 28 at the Cobbs Mill inn here.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The three Christian brothers of Warroad, Minn. -- Billy, Gordon and Roger -- accounted for six goals today as the United States ice hockey eam whipped Switzerland, 13 -- 1.
The United States dropped from sixth to eighth place among twenty-six merchant shipbuilding nations last year, a report by the Shipbuilders Council of America discloses.

By producing a world record, a trio of new winners and a lot of rousing performances, the ninetieth anniversary carnival of the New York Athletic Club set the stage well for the championship phase of the indoor track season.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The precise and gentlemanly civil servants of Whitehall have bitten off more than they can chew. They have drafted a bill to reduce the status of the Cinque Ports.

It takes more than a snowstorm to discourage admirers of Yehudi Menuhin. When the violinist appeared at Hunter College on Saturday evening, the hall was filled. Mr. Menuhin's recital was the eighth event of the 1957-58 Hunter College subscription series.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- A delegate who has been in close touch with behind-the-scenes efforts here to resolve the French-Tunisian dispute quietly, said today the Tunisian move to take up the Algerian problem would "complicate'' the situation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 16 -- Finance Minister Jose Maria Alkmim an official statement today denied that the Brazilian Government had been thinking of trying to borrow $100,000,000 in the United States and securing the loan with surplus coffee stocks held by the Brazilian Coffee Institute.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 16 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, S. C., came from behind today to win the $7,500 St. Petersburg women's open by four strokes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Eisenhower's proposal a month ago for the complete transfer of vocational education to the states so far adds up as "easier said than done."

The University of Connecticut became the first conference team in the nation to qualify for a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament by clinching the Yankee Conference title Saturday. But the Huskies are the second team to make the championship tournament.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week. Net changes for the period ranged from a decline of four points on the March delivery to an advance of seventy-one points in the July position.

William H. Vanderbilt, former Governor of Rhode Island, announced yesterday the formation of the Committee on Campaign Contributions and Expenditures. Through its seventy-three members, the committee will seek new laws requiring prompt public disclosure by candidates of all campaign contributions and expenditures.

THREE long works by contemporary composers were performed for the first time in New York at Carnegie Hall last night. They were Miklas Rozsa's Second Concerto for Violin and Orchestra; Ashley Vernon's "Millefleurs," a divertimento for orchestra, and Joz h Wood's Third Symphony. Leon Barzin conducted.

Representative Emanuel Celler warned yesterday that a Congressional investigation of juvenile delinquency here might be used by segregationists as a "defense mechanism" for their opposition to school integration in Little Rock, Ark.
The Police Department yesterday announced the establishment of a Pedestrian Education Unit in an attempt to curb mounting traffic deaths on the city's streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations accused the Administration today of trying "to tranquilize the American people" about the current business recession. It proposed a broad Government program for stimulating the economy.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 16 -- President Eisenhower stayed close to the fireside again today on the advice of his physician, Maj. Gen. Howard McC. Snyder.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Feb. 17 -- A Korean National Airlines plane, carrying thirty-two persons and with an American pilot, swerved from its regular domestic flight yesterday and flew into Communist North Korea.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- In this semi-rural area where snow-drifted driveways spell disaster for car-dependent residents, neighbors northeast of town depend on a 16-year-old high school girl and her tractor.
Miss Georgie Sprague has retired as executive secretary of the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N. J. She hold the post for thirty-four years.

Two of the police line organizations have offered to "forego" cash for overtime worked during the recent subway strike in return for a forty-hour week. The city, however, has refused to pay for the overtime.

Continued scientific and medical progress was predicted last night for Israel in the next ten years, despite that nation's "limited resources." The prediction was made by Dr. Joseph Kaplan, chairman of the United States Committee for the International Geophysical Year.

The blizzard blanketing the East yesterday forced the postponement and cancellation of many sports events. Athletics had not been so hard hit since last fall, when the influenza epidemic played havoc with schedules.

MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Willy Forrer of Switzerland won the downhill race today and beat Tom Corcoran of Westfield, N. J., for first place in the Alpine combined competition of the international ski tournament. He covered the 3,200-meter course in 1:56.7.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- State Department officials drafted today a formal United States offer of good offices in the dispute between France and Tunisia.
One of the saddest events of recent years was the French attack from the air upon a Tunisian village, which shows that the civilized modern world can descend to the level of the primitive blood-feud.
A new Vanessa was seen in the opera of the same name Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Opera. She was Brenda Lewis, who had sung the role in Philadelphia but never in New York.

An original twenty-page manuscript by Albert Einstein containing one of his early attempts to find a Unified Field Theory has been given to Yeshiva University. The donor is Dr. Leo Perlman of Mount Vernon, N. Y., an associate of Sutro Bros. Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

Guy Gendron, the little Ranger whom few people seem to notice, was wildly applauded by 12,156 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. He scored the goal that broke a tie and enabled the Broadway Blues to post a 3-to-2 victory over the Boston Bruins in their National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Dr. Bernard Schwartz, chief-counsel-turned-chief-witness for the Legislative Oversight subcommittee, which is investigating Federal regulatory agencies, has had a disillusioning shock over what he has learned about practical politics in Washington.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 16 -- President Eisenhower saw "an encouraging sign for the economy" today in a report showing substantial increases in applications for insurance on all major categories of housing construction.
" THE SEVEN LIVELY ARTS," which had a rather indifferent career on television, came to the end of its run yesterday over Channel 2.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 -- The Air Force Missile Test Center, first installation of its size and scope in the nation's history, now dominates life along the east central Florida coast. It has generated a land boom and posed serious housing problems.

A CHILD was born every seven and one-half seconds in the United States last year. It was the seventh consecutive year of increased birth rates. It also was a year when an estimated 4,310,000 women faced the problem of what to wear during pregnancy.

LIKE the proverbial terrier who would fight a brick wall, Louis Carlotti's tractor plow bucked a shelf of hard-packed snow on Fifth Avenue yesterday. The seven-and-a - half - foot - long blade shuddered under the impact, the heavily chained, four-foot-high rear tires spun ineffectually in a frenzy of despair on the glistening ice, and Mr. Carlotti jounced in his high-mounted cab.

In the first of three articles projected here on the recent study, "Foreign Central Banking: The Instruments of Monetary Policy" by Peter G. Fousek, the author was paraphrased as summarizing his findings thus:
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers today announced the outright sale of Sandy Amoros, a left fielder, to their Montreal farm club in the International League.
Newark announced yesterday plans for the sale of bond issues totaling $15,000,000. The securities will be offered on March 11.

CRANS - SUR - SIERRA, Switzerland, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Betsy Snite of Norwich, Vt., won the women's slalom in the Mont Lachaux trophy ski meet today, finishing ten seconds ahead of Madeleine Chamot-Berthod of Switzerland,
Schools in the city will remain open today.

PETER A. DE MAEREL is one Manhattan bachelor whose dinner parties are memorable occasions. Perhaps the secret of success is the intelligent way in which Mr. De Maerel, who is director of the Belgian Tourist Bureau here and an official of the Brussels World's Fair, adapts menus of his native Belgium to New York City tastes and appetites.
A 16-year-old Brooklyn boy was accused yesterday of striking two other boys with a revolver and robbing one of them.

The steamship charter market has resumed its downward move after a halt of only one week. The loss last week of the slight strength gained earlier by the Pacific Coast segment of the market sent the freight rate index back on the toboggan.

A decision to terminate "The Gisele MacKenzie Show" March 29 has been agreed upon mutually by the singer, the National Broadcasting Company and the television program's two sponsors. It is expected to become official this week upon the signing of legal papers by the variout parties.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The Old Lady of Threadneedle Street, as the Bank of England is respectfully known, emerged from the recent bank rate hearing with her hoary head high and her skirts unsmirched.

" Twentieth Century" last night offered over Channel 2 a filmed reprise of the Senate televised crime investigation of 1951, the inquiry which brought Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, and many others into national prominence.
A Columbia College junior has found that enthusiasm alone will not enable him to spread the gospel of the United Nations. It will take a little money, too.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 16 -- A major shift in United States policy toward North Africa, involving clear-cut support for an early settlement to give Algeria independence by stages is reported to have been recommended by three top-ranking State Department officials.
HONUS WAGNER, one of the greatest of all ballplayers, had to win his fifth batting championship before he finally got his salary raised to the then monumental height of $10,000 per annum.

Consolidated sales of the Sperry Rand Corporation for the nine months ended Dec. 31 increased to a record total of $648,571,966, from $616,861,158 for the like 1956 period. Earnings, however, were down $7,524,497.
RYE, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- William Tully of New York Athletic Club won the Apawamis Club's sixteenth annual invitation singles squash racquet tournament today.
The annual observance of Brotherhood Week began yesterday in communities across the country. It is conducted each year under the sponsorship of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 16 -- President Habib Bourguiba has moved to bring the Algerian question before the United Nations Security Council as an extension of the Tunisian complaint on the bombing of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 16 -- President Eisenhower's detailed proposal to Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin for an East-West meeting will be made public here tomorrow.
NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Joe Shepard, 25-year-old Tampa, Fla., sports car driver, won the 96-mile Paul Whiteman Trophy race here today.
" I have received no assurances of additional General Motors Corporation advertising business," said Marion Harper Jr., president of McCann-Erickson, Inc.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Rookie Ian Cushenan scored his first-goal of the season and Ed Litzenberger got his twentieth and twenty-first tonight to help the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

There is no great optimism among business men, but most of those surveyed by Dun Bradstreet on what the second quarter holds expect their companies to equal, or exceed, the results of the corresponding 1957 period.

Norma Talmadge, Star of the silent screen, left an estate of $1,548,415, it was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court. Her executors petitioned for letters of administration in order to take over her assets in this state.
PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared today that the exploration of outer space could not be put under military control.
HAVANA, Feb. 17 -- Reports of heavy fighting between rebels and Government troops at Pinto del Agua in Oriente Province reached here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The United States rounded a major turning point in its North African policy today by formally extending its good offices to the Tunisian and French Governments to help "settle outstanding problems between them."
Betty Jane Watson, stand-by for Martha Raye in "Annie Get Your Gun," will assume the leading feminine role in the musical, which begins a two-week stand tomorrow night at the City Center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Dr. Bernard Schwartz testified today that two letters by Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, in a 1953 case involving a regulatory agency were evidence of "grossly improper'' activity.
WELLINGTON, N. Z., Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- Dr. Vivian Fuchs got his trans-Antarctic expedition back on the move today after a long stop for repairs to a Snocat tracked vehicle.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- Since time immemorial, man has battled the destruction of rivers running wild. Within the last decade, however, the scope of these efforts has expanded many fold with the aid of the Eeconomic Commission for Asia and the Far East, which mobilized the skills and the tools of the twentieth century.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- Snowdrifts that blocked garage doors kept most of Rockland County's commuters at home today.

The University of Dayton and St. Bonaventure yesterday became the first teams to accept invitations to compete in the twenty-first annual National Invitation basketball tournament, March 13 to 22, at Madison Square Garden. The N. I. T. is a twelve-team event.

The Alamo and the men who defended it to the last are the subjects of a book by Lon Tinkle, book editor of The Dallas News and a descendant of one of the fort's heroes. Called "13 Days to Glory," the narrative describes what happened inside the converted Franciscan mission during "its days of seige and terror." McGraw-Hill will publish the book March 3.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission was accused of "religious favoritism" today by Protestant and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- A constitutional amendment designed to simplify preparation of state personal income tax returns received strong Republican support today.
"Kraft Television Theatre," now produced by the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, is expected to be produced by Talent Associates, Ltd., an independent company, beginning April 2.

BRIGHTON, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Although technically at war with the United States, Florida's Seminole Indians sang songs of peace and brotherhood, yesterday when white friends presented them with nearly three tons of food, clothing and blankets.
The economic talks between the State Department and representatives of Poland caused a stir yesterday in the market for the defaulted dollar bonds of Russia's restive satellite.
YORAM KANIUK, who was born in Tel Aviv in 1929 and has been living in New York since 1951, is showing recent paintings at the Feigl Gallery, 601 Madison Avenue.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Slaughter steers brought a new top of $34.50 today, highest since Feb. 16, 1955, when the price was $35.
Jack Soble, convicted last October as a Soviet spy, was reported to have attempted suicide yesterday.
Mayor Wagner threw his support yesterday behind the Tweed Commission's revised plan for court reform in New York State.
The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company yesterday announced plans to issue 130,000 shares of new preferred stock ($100 par value) and 450,923 shares of common ($8.50 par value).

Bobby Shant'z, the New York Yankees little southpaw pitcher, signed his 1958 contract yesterday. Shantz, who had the major leagues' best earned-run average last year with 2.45, probably will receive in the neighborhood of $16,000 this season.
Plans have been completed for the Mi-Careme ball, which will take place Friday evening in the ballroom of the Ambassador.
A frigid temperature drop to 6 degrees numbed the city yesterday with Arctic cold, and even lower temperatures of 4 degrees were predicted for today.

With few exceptions Americans are not going to have a preference in the Canadian general elections of March 31, but all of us ought to be greatly interested. Lester Pearson's many American friends, who knew him when he was Secretary of State for External Affairs in the Liberal Government of Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent, may be rooting for the Liberals on his behalf.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield discouraged today what he called the "false hope of exorbitant pay increases" for postal workers. But he declined to say whether President Eisenhower would veto a 7 1/2 per cent rise.
An economist for the American Paper and Pulp Association said yesterday the paper industry might profit by lessons learned during its current slump.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 17 -- Suffolk County, bedded under ten to twenty-three inches of snow that had been swirled into drifts up to ten feet high stirred into action today with no major emergency or distress calls on its records.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 (UP) -- Nominations for the thirtieth annual Academy Awards were announced today by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. "Sayonara" leads the list with ten nominations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A yachtman from Balboa, Calif., reported tonight by ship-to-shore telephone that his yacht had been seized by twenty-one escaped Ecuadorian prisoners who held the crew captive for three days.
Gene (Ace) Armstrong, an undefeated middleweight from Elizabeth, N. J., outpointed Charley Joseph of New Orleans in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
DUBLIN, Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- More than 1,000 workers walked out at Dublin's deep-sea docks today over an interunion dispute, forcing the docks to close.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from President Eisenhower delivered today to Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Chairman of the Soviet Council of Ministers:
TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner submitted a record budget to the Legislature today and requested new taxes to balance it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Atomic Energy Commission will soon ground-test a large jet engine that will power the first atomic airplane.

TERESA WRIGHT was just a little girl back in the Nineteen Twenties. Once grown, she could vaguely remember what the adults of that era looked like and little about how they behaved. However, not until she prepared to portray one of them did she spend much time wondering how they might have felt or thought about marriage and parenthood.

ABILENE, Kan., Feb. 17 (AP) -- A nation-wide campaign to raise $3,000,000 to construct the Eisenhower Presidential Library in Abilene will be started here Feb. 27, the Governor's national committee for the library announced today.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- Achille Lauro, uncrowned "King of Naples," defied here today a Government investigation of his regime in Italy's third city. He proclaimed himself champion of the underprivileged South.
I would appreciate it if you would publish this reply to Dr. G. D. Dorman's letter published Feb. 1 concerning my research on fluoride poisoning.

Harry Stromberg, a gambler and racketeer, advanced $50,000 to alleged members of an international narcotics ring to pay for a shipment of heroin from France, a witness testified yesterday in Federal court.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower left the hunting lodge of Milestone Plantation for the first time today to motor in a heated limousine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Evidence is accumulating that Henry H. Fowler, who was director of the Office of Defense Mobilization under President Truman, has made the most helpful contribution thus far to the effort to provide for continuous effective government when a President has become incompetent to exercise his "powers and duties" and is either unwilling or unable to announce this.

A large sign along a highway or railroad line announcing that an industrial plant will be situated there sometime in the future represents the work of many experts with specialized talents -- and not only sign painters.
A VERY competent new chamber music group, the Tichman Trio, made its first New York appearance last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Sammy Davis Jr. has won his campaign to play Sportin' Life in the Samuel Goldwyn production of "Porgy and Bess."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 17 -- The Democratic Action party opened headquarters here today.
Production will be resumed today at the two Long Island plants of the Kollsman Instrument Corporation, which had been strike-bound since Jan. 22.

Although no word has been received from official sources here or abroad, Twentieth Century-Fox has announced that its production of William Faulkner's "The Long Hot Summer" has been selected as the American entry in the Cannes Film Festival to be held in that French resort city in May.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Twenty-three families were evacuated from two heatless apartment buildings tonight and moved into the gymnasium of the Stamford High School.
KHARTUM, The Sudan, Feb. 17 -- Egypt has laid claim to an area of northern Sudan, and Egyptian troops are on the way to the area, Mohammed Hahgoub, Sudanese Foreign Minister, said tonight.
Joseph P. Collins of Jamaica, Queens, won a $50,000 award yesterday in a negligence suit against the city before Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Revived suggestions that the price of gold might be increased prompted widespread demand for South African gold mining stocks on the stock exchange today. Gains, which spread almost throughout the list, were accentuated by a shortage of stock.
REHOVOT, Israel Feb. 17 -- Israel's dream of becoming a Middle Eastern center of scientific research was close to fulfillment this week as the nation approached its tenth anniversary.
