LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Britain's Conservative Government will plunge this week into an ordeal by Parliamentary fire on its foreign and defense policies.
ROME, Feb. 17 -- St. Clare of Assisi was proclaimed the patron saint of television everywhere in the world today by Pope Pius XII. She was a co-founder of the Order of Poor Ladies, or Poor Clares.

Gian-Carlo Menotti is composing a new opera, "Marie Golovin," which the N. B. C. Opera Company will produce as an American entry at the International Exposition in Brussels, Belgium, in August. Mr. Menotti also wrote the text for the opera.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A railroad official said today northern Atlantic port railroads were losing foreign traffic because of freight differentials.

Snow and cold affected New York's economic life yesterday -- but not too seriously. Rail and bus travel into the/ city, while hobbled by delays,1 was generally adequate. Most! of the out-of-towners who work! here reported to their jobs, but] many were late.

In the sharpest note he has sent thus far President Eisenhower bluntly accuses the Soviets of creating an "impasse" in the discussions about another summit meeting. He calls on them to stop sending him warmed-over propaganda speeches and get down to business to break the deadlock.

"THE SUNDIAL,"* by Shirley Jackson, is a novel about the end of the world. It is developed dramatically in dry, stinging dialogues that may remind you of the kind of talk you find among Ivy Compton-Burnett's English country-house fables based on classical themes. The supernatural overtones and undertones of Miss Jackson's book, however, are closer to Sutton Vane's play about a shipload of lost souls sailing toward oblivion, "Outward Bound."
Lent begins tomorrow, Ash Wednesday.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 17 -- Gunmen of the Irish Republican Army struck at Northern Ireland early today with three attacks on police stations.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today two bills that would have outlawed unauthorized "bugging," or electronic eavesdropping, of private conversations.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Final prices were 18 points off to 37 points up from Friday's close, with new crop months strongest. One point equals 5 cents a bale.

BOOKWORMS can turn to Brentano's for help. Treasured tomes can be preserved for their pleasure, or for that of another generation, by being fitted with a new binding. And Brentano's is one of the few book stores in the city that is prepared to undertake this lifesaving measure.
Good looking, well fitting shoes, a sign of good grooming, require proper care. Little time and effort are needed to make shoes look their best and last longer.
DETROIT, Feb. 17 -- The General Motors Corporation reported today a net income of $843,592,435 in 1957, down slightly from 1956 but still the third highest in the company's history.

The federation of Jordan and Iraq has led to renewed speculation as to whether some of the more than half a million Arab refugees now in Jordan cannot find new homes in under-populated Iraq. Some persons who are honestly interested in the fate of these refugees have argued that it is better to say as little as possible about this subject, in order to avoid annoyance to Cairo politicians or embarrassment to the Iraqi Government.
The bodies of two men buried in the charred rums of a downtown factory were recovered last night by firemen. Two others were still missing.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The Republican leader of the Assembly backed tonight the Board of Regents' plan for a $78,000,000-a-year increase in state aid to education.
Your article by Leonard Buder, with the accompanying pictures, is a constructive and objective endeavor in presenting to the public the school construction program.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 17 -- Word was received here today of the death of Albert A. Scharwachter, vice president of the Arizona Chemical Company. Mr. Scharwachter was killed and his wife Bertha slightly hurt by a wild automobile while they were sitting on the patio of a motel at Winter Park, Fla.
Schools, stores, factories and offices in many parts of New Jersey closed yesterday as the state began digging out of its worst snowstorm in two years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Whatever the railroads may think about it, the nation's transportation policy is sound, spokesmen for the trucking industry told Congress today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had remained virtually unchanged from a week ago.

Snow laid a cold blanket on the market yesterday. With many traders missing from their normal bases of operation, the New York Stock Exchange floundered through the narrowest and most inactive market since Nov. 11.

The active, current-crop potato positions soared the daily limit of 30 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. These positions, March, April and May, climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Jon Konrads, Australia's 15-year-old swimming sensation, and an Olympic star, Dawn Fraser, easily won their free-style heats tonight in the Australian swimming championships.
THE forty days of Lent, which starts tomorrow, demand that fish, eggs and cheese be served with style if they are to substitute for meat on fast days.
BINGO came to the home television screen yesterday and it could play hob with the afternoon routine of housewives and school children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The president of the New York Stock Exchange said tonight that the Soviet earth satellites had increased this country's needs for investment capital, while Government policies discouraged the man who might put up the money.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A bill aimed at knocking out one of the legal props under Federal secrecy was approved unanimously today by a House subcommittee on information.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Eisenhower Administration opened a battle against heavy odds today for continuation of an effective reciprocal - trade program.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, which this year is observing its sixtieth anniversary, achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history in 1957. The company said the showing also was a record for the rubber industry.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- France and Tunisia accepted today an offer by the United States and Britain to use their good offices toward settlement of the Paris-Tunis dispute over troubles arising on the Algerian border.
LITTLE ROCK, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Little Rock School Board expelled tonight Minnie Jean Brown from integrated Central High School for the remainder of this term.
A disciplinary trial for thirteen reputed top leaders of last December's subway strike was postponed yesterday to March 19 by former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 18 -- Communist North Korea rejected today a demand by the United Nations Command for the immediate return of a South Korean airliner that flew thirty-two persons to North Korea Sunday. Two American fliers, one an Air Force man, were on the plane.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- Tunisia asked today that the Security Council consider the French war in Algeria and its "overflow" into Tunisian territory.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Dr. Wernher von Braun said tonight that the Army had been given both authority and the money for five new "satellite or space projects."
A whiff of radioactive gas is being tried at St. Luke's Hospital here as an aid to diagnosis of heart ailments to be repaired by surgery.
BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- Charles Fred Stanley Bell, 41 years old, an actor, plunged to his death early today from the eighth floor of the Hotel Touraine.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- Reports that important unsettled differences exist within the East German Government are circulating in West Berlin. In Communist East Berlin the stories have brought scornful comments.

The Metropolitan Opera opened the seventeenth week of its season with its fourth presentation of the double bill of Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" and Strauss' "Salome." The operas gave new opportunities to two young singers, Emilia Cundari and Ezio Flagello.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 17 -- The Tunisian Government, although accepting "in principle" the offer of good offices, is awaiting a written note defining what they are to be.
MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 17 -- Nassau County residents began the arduous task today of digging out of an accumulation of eleven inches of snow and three-foot-high drifts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Following, in unofficial translation, are the texts of a note and memorandum by Adam Rupacki, Polish Foreign Minister, delivered to the United States Ambassador in Warsaw, as made public today by the Polish Embassy here:

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 17 -- Harry J. Ekelund, 40 years old, controller of the supplies division of the International Business Machines Corporation, was found dead early this morning in his car in the garage of his home at 16 Burling Avenue. The police said that the engine of the car was running and that the garage doors were closed.

The Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company plans to redeem by call on March 20 all outstanding 5 per cent convertible debentures due Feb. 1, 1972. There were $2,306,000 outstanding on Feb. 14. The call price is 104 5/8. The debentures are convertible into common stock until the close of business March 5 at a conversion price of $22.62 for the common.
The New York premiere of Douglas Moore's "The Ballad of Baby Doe" on April 3 will be the opening performance of the New York City Opera's spring season of American opera.
WARSAW, Feb. 17 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka says that Poland's "international policy is, and will be, in accordance with the policy of the whole Socialist camp."
The city announced yesterday that the Stock Construction Corporation of 70 East Forty-fifth Street had submitted the lowest bid for initial construction of the new Holland-America Line terminal.

A border between Egypt and the Sudan running along the Twenty-second Parallel was last fixed in 1936, when Britain and Egypt signed a treaty for condominum (joint dominion) over the Sudan. The agreement was abrogated in 1951 and the Sudan was proclaimed independent in 1956.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Representatives of organized summer baseball and a special National Collegiate Athletic Association committee met today to iron out details of the N. C. A. A.'s new program governing collegians playing on summer teams.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The nation's secondary school principals, bombarded with suggestions how to improve the teaching of science and mathematics, came up today with revolutoinary proposals. They included the following:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Following are excerpts from the testimony today of Dr. Bernard Schwartz before the House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight:

Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said here yesterday that cooperation between Western Europe and the United States must remain "the main basis for our further work" toward reuniting the 17,000,000 persons in Soviet-occupied East Germany with those of West Germany.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 17 -- Strong gusty winds made snow removal a repetitive chore in Westchester County today. Two shovelers collapsed and died of apparent heart attacks.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Prices of grain futures climbed again today on the Board of Trade, the third successive session in which some of them, particularly wheat, have run up good gains.
A member of a teen-age gang accused of slaying a crippled boy testified yesterday that he had been "pushed around" by the police after his arrest.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- William Gunlock of Chillicothe, Ohio, was named an assistant football coach at the United States Military Academy by Earl H. Blaik, Army's head coach, today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A recommendation that President Eisenhower seek to address a "peace appeal" directly to the people of the Soviet Union was made today to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
A new facade, containing a wide band of porcelain enamel panels faced with gold, has been completed on the Franklin Society Savings and Loan Association building at 217 Broadway.
THREE new models have been introduced by the Necchi-Elna Sewing Machine Corporation.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The Liberal party called tonight for steps to bolster the state's economy and to meet educational problems.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Doctors gave Airman Donald G. Farrell an intensive examination today seeking to determine what happens to a man traveling in space.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- A bill that would cost localities millions in real estate taxes and save railroads the same amount was approved in the Assembly tonight without opposition.

The Westchester Country Club of Rye, which came back to the tennis schedule last year with an international round-robin, followed by an elimination tournament, has applied for sanction to conduct these events again in 1958.
When Airman Donald G. Farrell completed his seven-day ordeal under the simulated conditions of space travel he became a genuine pioneer. He is, in one sense, the first "space traveler."

CRANS-SUR-SIERRE, Switzerland, Feb. 17 (UP) -- United States skiers made an excellent showing in the giant slalom events at the Mont Lachaux meet today by taking the first two places in the women's race and tying for second in the men's test.

Kansas City, Mo., borrowed $7,000,000 for public school construction yesterday. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds due from 1959 to 1978 to a syndicate headed by First National City Bank of New York at an interest cost of 2.659 per cent.
The thirty-second annual New York City Golden Gloves finals were staged at Madison Square Garden last night before 10,648 fans.

Undefeated in nineteen rounds of the tournament for the chess championship of the Americas in Bogota, Oscar Panno of Buenos Aires emerged as victor yesterday, according to a report received through Colombian news sources.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A Senate subcommittee heard conflicting views today on whether the east front of the Capitol should be extended. It then asked the commission that Congress created to study the question for "clarification" of its position.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad said today that any disengagement of Soviet and Atlantic alliance troops in Europe that weakened Western defenses without compensatory assurances would be unacceptable.
Sales and earnings of the J. C. Penney Company last year were the highest in the fifty-six-year history of the nation-wide department store chain.
Dean Acheson said yesterday that the United States should not negotiate with the Soviet Union on major issues at this time.

The president-elect of the American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers called yesterday for "more stress on quality in our new engineers and scien tists, and less on quantity."
Directors of Marchant Calculators, Inc., yesterday cut the quarterly common stock dividend to 15 cents a share, payable March 15, from 32 1/2 cents paid in previous quarters.

Electrical trouble, a rear-end collision and a stuck drawbridge added confusion late yesterday to New Haven Railroad travel, already beset by the storm. Homeward-bound commuters who had left Grand Central Terminal after 6 P. M. were more than three hours late in some cases in reaching their homes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Seneca Indians insisted today it would take a special act of Congress to empower the Government to take the Western New York reservation they have held by treaty since Washington's time.

A lot of enthusiastic voters hopped on the Cincinnati bandwagon after the Bearcats showed they could handle a couple of tough rivals. But the weight of numbers still favored Kansas State for top ranking yesterday in the weekly Associated Press poll of sports writers and broadcasters.
A Congressional bill that would, in effect, provide many airlines with additional funds to buy new planes is scheduled to come before the Senate for a final vote in the next few days.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 17 (AP) Parliament ratified unanimously today the agreement of King Faisal II of Iraq and King Hussein of Jordan to unite in a federal Arab state. The two houses of the Jordan Parliament will ratify the pact in Amman tomorrow.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 17 -- Fresh manifestations of support for the revolutionary Indonesian Government were reported here today.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Cameron Cobbold, Governor of the Bank of England, declared tonight that Britain's fight against inflation was only half won.
Paul G. Hoffman, former president of the Ford Foundation, warned last night against the continuing international armaments race.

Errant automobile drivers and careless pedestrians were cautioned and coaxed yesterday to mend their street manners. Separate meetings were held for each group, but the aim for both was a reduction in the number of traffic accidents and fatal injuries.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Bowie race track today called off tomorrow's card and the management said it would decide from day to day when to open the snowbound oval. Chances were that the horses would not run on Wednesday, either.
If ever an athlete merited comparison with Jack Armstrong, the legendary all-American boy, it is Eric Groon.

WARSAW, Feb. 17 -- Poland has suggested to the United States that the opening of discussion now on her proposal to bar nuclear weapons from Central Europe would contribute to a successful top-level meeting.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 (UP) -- Frank Gifford, a star halfback for the New York football Giants, today signed a contract for a film career that made his return to the gridiron uncertain.

MIAMI, Feb. 17 (AP) -- C. M. Kline's Adare II today won Hialeah's featured Cape Canaveral Purse at odds of better than 50 to 1. The long shot paid $103.70, $25.30 and $11.60 for $2 across the board to his supporters in the crowd of 20,250.

DR. SJAFRUDDIN PRAWIRANEGARA, Premier of the revolutionary Government proclaimed in Padang, Saturday, was a leader in the Indonesian struggle to win independence from the Dutch. But with that struggle won, he became increasingly a symbol of a less dramatic fight within the Sukarno regime for sound economic policy and strict control of Communists.
CONSTANTINE, Algeria, Feb. 17 -- Algerian authorities conceded today that they were encountering difficulty in enlisting officials for the new political organs created by the French reform law.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which thrives on superlatives, added another championship yesterday -- biggest corporate money earner.

The New York Knickerbockers can gain a virtual tie for third place with the Philadelphia Warriors in the Eastern Division race of the National Basketball Association if they defeat the Boston Celtics tonight at Madison Square Garden.
ALMA, Ga., Feb. 17 -- Wilfred Smith found out today that he had the makings of a good bird dog, and finding out was a pleasure in itself. It also was a fine thing to watch.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The following skiing conditions were reported to the State Commerce Department today:
WHEN the Chicago Bears stumbled at the start of the season, George Halas professed unconcern.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns, first chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under the Eisenhower Administration, has contributed greatly toward dispelling the smog that has enveloped the economic picture since it fell into the hands of the politicians. He did this in the course of a talk at the end of last week at Columbia University.
Scout leaders in Queens began their part last night in the National Safety Good Turn Project of the Boy Scouts of America.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Germain Green Glidden is keenly interested in squash and oils, but there isn't an ounce of vegetarian in him. He spends his working hours as an artist and his leisure hours on the squash racquets court.

The collapse of the Wooster Street loft building that took six lives during the fire on Friday night was a tragedy that should never have occurred. But it brought into spectacular play the superlative spirit and technique of the Fire Department in rescue work under cruel weather conditions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The real test of President Eisenhower's influence over his party opened on Capitol Hill today.

The Chinese New Year of 4656 starts today. According to the Chinese, this is the year of the dog. In the old China people took a long time to prepare for this grand occasion. Chinese markets and shops closed for the holidays for at least ten days, so provisions had to be stocked.

I particularly concur in the statement in your excellent editorial of Feb. 13 "Next Move in Tunisia" that one consequence of the French bombing of Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef in Tunisia is that the Algerian war has become an international issue.

DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Further cuts in passenger car output loom as distinct possibilities as the industry's retail inventories continue to mount. The latest count shows dealer stocks moved up to 781,446 units on Feb. 1, against 652,208 units on Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower called on the Soviet leaders today to stop propagandizing about a summit conference and get to the work of arranging one.
A syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., is offering for public subscription $25,000,000 of new preferred stock of Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.

The Coast Guard will reopen briefly today its hearing into the disappearance of the small tugboat Jim Steers. The vessel was lost near Throgs Neck, the Bronx, on Jan. 19. Her crew of three has been missing since then and efforts to locate the craft have proved fruitless.

The city's Sanitation Commissioner complained yesterday that hazardous driving conditions were being made even more hazardous by home owners and shopkeepers who shoveled snow and ice into freshly cleared streets.
The Senate's Special Subcommittee to Investigate Juvenile Delinquency has tentatively decided to hold public hearings here on Feb. 27 and 28.
Bitter cold and a mounting death toll followed yesterday in the path of the heaviest Eastern snowstorm of the winter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill in effect authorizing the Interstate Commerce Commission to divide between the Boston and Providence Railroad and the New York, New Haven and Hartford the revenue received by the latter for operating the Boston and Providence.

THE skimpier slip will compete with the wider, full-skirted petticoat this spring. Regardless of the destiny of the chemise, spring fashions will feature enough wide skirts to create a demand for a petticoat that will complement them.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has moved the advertising account of its television, radio and record-playing equipment from McCann-Erickson, Inc., to the Grey Advertising Agency, Inc.

The preliminary report of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. disclosed yesterday that 1957 earnings from operations increased above those for the year before, chiefly as a result of a larger physical volume of sales.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Most of Fairfield County lay under twelve to seventeen inches of snow today. Drifts were as high as fifteen feet. There were at least three deaths.
Coast Guard hearings on the collision Feb. 8 of the tanker Tynefield and the ferryboat Dongan Hills ended yesterday with the testimony of a docking pilot.
The nation's steel production declined last week for the fourth consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Events today: Wagner's "Tristan and Isolde," Metropolitan Opera House, 7:45; Philadelphia Orchestra, Paul Kletzki conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Ruth Lakeway, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
Connecticut raised $77,000,000 yesterday for the permanent financing of its new turnpike by the sale of serial bonds maturing over thirty-nine years at an interest cost of 3.2584 per cent.
TODAY'S menu is designed for a teen-age dinner party for ten.

Glamour can be short-lived for a metal just as it can for a woman. "Several years ago during the first flush of enthusiasm over its properties, titanium was dubbed the 'Cinderella Metal'," the new president of the American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers told the group's annual meeting yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 18 -- The Indonesian Communist party, in a militant statement of policy, urged today that "firm actions" be taken without delay to combat the challenge of the anti-Communist rebel Government proclaimed in central Sumatra three days ago.
DUBLIN, Ireland, Feb. 18 -- The Dublin Tostal Council announced tonight that the International Theatre Festival, due to begin May 11, would be postponed.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A proposal that crude oil production allowables in Oklahoma be reduced by 50,000 barrels a day immediately was made to the industry at an open meeting of the Oklahoma Independent Petroleum Association today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Eisenhower Administration and the Republican Congressional leadership rejected today all present talk of tax cuts or other emergency measures to stimulate the national economy.
Twenty-nine cars equipped with two-way mobile radios but without a single policeman sped on special missions yesterday.

PAUL KLETZKI is not a man in a hurry. In his New York debut as guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night he proved that he was an interpreter in the broad, German tradition.

A committee of members of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Henry C. Brunie, has reserved a section of boxes and arena seats at the Seventh Regiment Armory for the semifinal and final matches, Saturday and Sunday, of the national indoor amateur tennis championship tournament. Kurt Nielsen of Denmark is the defending champion.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck charged today that a group of politically influential employers in New York City was using labor union leaders to obtain a veto of the Republican unemployment insurance bill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The United States all but closed the door again today to Poland's proposal for a zone in Central Europe free of nuclear weapons.

Minnie Jean Brown, 16-yearold Negro student who has been expelled from the Little Rock Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., yesterday accepted a $1,050 scholarship to the New Lincoln School here.
An epidemic of sticky doors, jammed brakes and frozen switches -- all caused by the cold -- slowed subway transportation yesterday for thousands of New Yorkers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- About half the grain futures contracts finished on the plus side today after battering against profit-taking throughout most of the Board of Trade session.
A 24-year-old man arrested yesterday has confessed the $12,440 robbery of a Bronx bank, the police said. A 12-year-old girl was used as a hostage in the hold-up on Feb. 6.

The coastal storm that has blanketed the Middle Atlantic and Northeastern states with snow, and sent the mercury plummeting down, has added many millions of weather sufferers to those in the South who have been hard hit for weeks by the cold. Explanations are in order.
In the quietest market since Nov. 11, stocks yesterday had a trifling loss in the morning, a brief rally in the afternoon and a negligible gain on the day.
Twenty-four men from a sinking Italian freighter were presumed lost early today in the storm-swept Atlantic off the North Carolina coast.

A dispute between Customs authorities and Mr. and Mrs. George P. Goulandris has been "resolved" by a payment of $12,500, Customs officials announced yesterday. Mr. Goulandris is treasurer of the Orion Shipping Trading Company, Inc., of 80 Broad Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Secretary of Defense urged Congress today to maintain the Reciprocal Trade Act as a weapon to combat the Soviet Union's "economic, psychological and political" war against the free world.

Your editorial of Feb. 9 "Vietnam's Worries" published after the article by Greg MacGregor, which appeared in The Times of Feb. 7, seems to make an indiscreet and unsubstantiated inference in suggesting that "Cambodia's position has been somewhat equivocal in the past and that one ministerial declaration may not change basic policy."
The twenty football teams in the Public Schools Athletic League will use the new National Collegiate 2-point conversion rule during the 1958 season.
HERE comes a letter from a man who is trying intelligently and without fatuous optimism to do something about the diminishing hunting and fishing in the vicinity of New York City.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Florida began telling Northerners today how warm it is in Miami Beach.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Selling increased in the stock markets today and prices were lowered in virtually all sections.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Department of Labor assured its farm labor advisory committee today that it had given instructions to its field offices to tighten up this year on the admission of Mexican farm labor.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
TAKE nine parts of Robert Chambers and one of August Strindberg and you would have something approximating "Obbligato," which opened at the Theatre Marquee last evening.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Jon Konrads, a 15-year-old immigrant wonder of Australian swimming, turned in an almost incredible performance tonight as six world records were set in the Australian championships.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- The Security Council today postponed debate on the French-Tunisian issue to allow time for conciliation between France and Tunisia by the United States and Britain.

The school problem, much in the news today, is discussed by John Keats in his new book "Schools Without Scholars." Mr. Keats presents a parent's view of public education. He says two opposing educational philosophies are trying to answer the question: "Just what do we want our schools to accomplish?" The book will be published March 20 by Houghton Mifflin. Mr. Keats is the author of "The Crack in the Picture Window."
A large public response to electronic Bingo, which made its debut here Monday, has forced television station WABD to change the procedure for playing the game.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 18 -- Disappearance of 133 ballot boxes has prevented the election tribunal from certifying the victory of Mario Echandi in the presidential elections of Feb. 2.

ATLANTA, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Attorney General of New Hampshire told the Georgia Legislature today that the use of troops in Little Rock, Ark., was "probably the greatest insult to a sovereign state since the Constitution was adopted."
RUTH LAKEWAY, soprano, made her appearance in a song program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 18 -- President Eisenhower has designated Gordon Maclean Tiffany, a close personal friend of his assistant, Sherman Adams, to be staff director of the Civil Rights Commission.

The Pennsylvania Railroad and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad yesterday announced sharply curtailed service because of operating difficulties as other railroads serving New York struggled through a wave of delays and breakdowns.

While millions of farmers are being driven from the land by the politics of our Government, our leaders are mute to or acquiescent in this exodus. While farmers and their simple demands for a decent living are vilified on all sides by unions, industry and the petty politician, no one stands tall, strong and vocal to defend the thing that made America great -- rural America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A sometime poet with a sonnet for sale turned up today in the Congressional net spread under the Federal Communications Commission. He is Herbert Sharfman, 48year-old F. C. C. hearing examiner whose ruling in Miami's controversial Channel 10 television case was overridden by his superiors.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev has warned that if Britain establishes missile bases directed against the Soviet Union similar bases will have to be established by the Russians. He did not say where.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- One accepted definition of the word paradox is: "An assertion or sentiment seemingly contradictory, or opposed to common sense, but that yet may be true in fact." In this sense contemporary France is an extraordinary land of paradox. Consider:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Religious divisiveness was singled out here today by a New York psychologist as a form of segregation that Communists "make capital of" and secularists find "repelling."

Today's new film is "Cowboy," a Western drama in color, with Glenn Ford, Jack Lemmon, Anna Kashfi and Brian Donlevy, at the Capitol. Julian Blaustein produced and Delmer Daves directed, from a screen play by Edmund H. North based on Frank Harris' "My Reminiscences as a Cowboy." Dick York, Victor Manuel Mendoza and Richard Jaeckel are among the supporting players.

Political storms, like natural ones, sometimes seem to come out of a clear sky. Every map drawn since 1902 has shown the boundary between Egypt and the Sudan to run mostly along the twenty-second parallel, but with a small enclave north of Wadi Halfa on the Nile and a large one along the Red Sea in favor of the Sudan.
CAIRO, Feb. 18 -- A dispute over a few hundred square miles of border territory that Egypt has always claimed but Sudan has administered has flared into open recriminations between the two countries.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 18 (AP) -Jim Hegan, a member of the Cleveland Indians for seventeen years, was dealt to the Detroit Tigers today in a straight four-player swap.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 17 -- One day last week forty bearded Israelis, wearing sidecurls and dressed like medieval Russian noblemen, were taken into Jerusalem's police station.

Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned yesterday that a military challenge by the Soviet Union would become "very real" in fifteen or twenty years unless the United States remained strong.

The Commercial Credit Company had a consolidated net income of $26,896,969 in 1957, the highest in its forty-six-year history, according to the annual report. The net was equal to $5.33 a share and compared with $26,478,671, or $5.26 a share, the year before.

Columbia ended its longest losing streak in fifty-eight years of basketball last night. The Lions, on their home court, vanquished Rutgers, 70 to 66. Prior to the game, Columbia had lost nine in a row. Its previous victory was registered against Cornell at Ithaca on Jan. 6.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The Government announced today that contributions to the National Health Service by those using it and by employers would be increased in July.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Brown, playing without its ace scorer, Joe Tebo, upset Yale, 74 -- 67, tonight in an Ivy League basketball game. Gerry Alaimo, co-captain, led the Bruins with 17 points.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 18 -- The policy of the South African Government is to market produce grown by Africans in the same manner as that grown by whites, a state Information Service spokesman declared today. Nevertheless, the spokesman conceded, it was possible that deviations from the policy could occur.
NICE, France, Feb. 18 -- Sir Winston Churchill, 83 years old, was reported tired and sick tonight at the Riviera villa where he is vacationing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Army asserted today that its new tactical ballistic missile, the Sergeant, would have a guidance system "invulnerable to any known means of enemy countermeasure."
Wanted: three agencies for automotive advertisers with billings totaling $32,000,000 a year.

Judith Anderson is thinking of appearing in Speed Lamkin's new play, "Comes the Day," previously labeled "The Angel Tree." If she takes the assignment, she will be required to portray a woman of strength and humor, who possesses an additional asset -- the ability to dance the Charleston.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Governor Harriman today ordered all new state cars, including those used by the state police, to be equipped with front seat safety belts.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 18 -- Pro-Egyptian forces have launched a new offensive against the Baghdad Pact on the basis of the federation of Iraq and Jordan.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Tweed commission's latest plan for reorganizing the state's court system got a thorough review today by judges, lawyers and interested laymen.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- The Matson Navigation Company announced today "a major expansion in foreign operations."

Jack Soble, 54-year-old convicted spy, swallowed one pound and nine ounces of nuts and bolts shortly before he was brought here from the Lewisburg, Pa., Federal penitentiary. Paul M. Williams, United States Attorney, said surgeons removed the hardware yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe of "My Fair Lady" renown will write the screen adaptation of their musical comedy, "The Day Before Spring," for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The United States will call a meeting here of the sixteen United Nations involved in the Korean war to consider Communist China's announced intention to withdraw its troops from Korea and its proposal for the withdrawal of all foreign troops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Senate investigators said tonight that Robert A. McDonald, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense, was "absent from his Government position approximately two-thirds of the time" during an eight-months period.
Mayor Gijsbert van Hall of Amsterdam expressed the hope yesterday that next week's $15,000,000 financing by Amsterdam will encourage more European flotations here.

Attention of this discursive corner has been attracted to an exhibition recently opened at the Museum of the City of New York, continuing to June and happily named by May Davenport Seymour, curator of the museum's theatrical collection, "Perennial Pygmalion, From a Myth to a Musical."
In one of the keenest National Basketball Association games seen at Madison Square Garden in many a season, the Boston Celtics outlasted the New York Knickerbockers for a 113-111 victory last night.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 18 -- Exhaustive Soviet ice studies -- including a novel sound-wave attempt to determine the age of glacial accumulations -- were outlined today at the opening session of an international Antarctic symposium.
The 15-year-old "war lord" of the Egyptian Dragons testified yesterday that when the gang wanted more members than those who had asked to join, "we went out and looked for them."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. E. C. Itschner, chief of the Army Corps of Engineers, said today that the Soviet Union had embarked on a "remarkable" water resource development program.

VIENNA, Feb. 18 -- The governments of Hungary and Czechoslovakia have taken new restrictive measures to defend communism against the inroads of private enterprise in the form of "small craftsmen." Poland began to take similar measures last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Air Force expects to launch a 3,000-pound test satellite in October. It will be a forerunner of reconnaissance satellites that would be able to scan the earth from space.

Two Italian hermit monks took their first look at the United States yesterday and found it just the place to establish a hermitage. "We arrived only last night on the Con stitution in New York," said Dom Augustine Modotti of Camaldoli, "but already we are impressed by the eremitical tendencies we see here.

COS COB, Conn., Feb. 18 -- The first reception in the partially restored Bush-Holley House will be held on Sunday afternoon by the Historical Society of Greenwich and the Greenwich Unit of the Stamford Junior League.

Kurt Nielsen of Denmark, the winner of the French indoor title tournament in Paris a few days ago, will begin play tonight in defense of the United States indoor tennis championship. The tournament starts at 6 o'clock this evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth street.
The immediate elimination of rail-rate differentials that place the Port of New York at a disadvantage was urged in a concurrent resolution introduced in the Senate and Assembly in Albany yesterday.
Mayor Wagner accepted as a compliment yesterday a diplomatic slip of the tongue placing his birth in 1919 instead of 1910.

IT was simple to spot weekend storm effects at street level. The town's dogs developed snow-hysteria. They buried their noses in the deepest drifts. They ran in crazy circles, kicking up a kind of snow spume. Puerto Rican boys who had never seen a town buried in snowy silence stared in awe, then reacted pretty much as the pups did. Buried cars threw long and melancholy shadows in deserted streets at night.
BONJOUR, Virginie de Paris. Thousands of American women who wear sizes five to thirteen cannot go wrong in welcoming this Parisian's designs to Bergdorf Goodman.

The American Jewish Congress yesterday expressed opposition to proposals in the state legislature to authorize school officials to display a "nondenominational" version of the Ten Commandments in public schools.
MINNEAPOLIS, Wednesday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Albert Quie, a Republican dairy farmer, won a seat in Congress from Minnesota's stanch Republican First District.
A technique for comparing the efficiency of operations to improve the blood supply to the heart was described here yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- An omnibus bill to settle the state's seven-year-old branch banking and holding company controversy won the qualified support of the State Banking Department today. The measure, introduced by Senator Samuel L. Greenberg, Democrat of Brooklyn, and Assemblyman Benjamin H. Demo, Republican of Lowville, would widen the New York City branch banking district to include Long Island and Rockland and Westchester Counties.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Feb. 19 -- Communist Chinese forces who fought in the Korean war against the United Nations will withdraw completely from North Korea this year, the Hsinhua (New China) news agency reported today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 20 points ($1 a bale) up yesterday, with old March leading the advance.
A study to find what proportion of the 7,600 aged persons in 121 private nursing homes in the city can be made self-sufficient will be started in the spring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- A special radio television signal to alert the public of approaching hurricanes, floods and tornadoes will be serving most areas of the nation by late summer, the Weather Bureau announced today.

Merck Co., Inc., and subsidiaries, manufacturing chemists, last year had the highest sales and earnings in the company's history, John T. Connor, president, reported yesterday in a preliminary statement.
PARIS, Feb. 18 -- France proposed tonight the formation of a French-Tunisian commission under neutral chairmanship to control the trouble-breeding Tunisian frontier with Algeria.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Ski conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

The retirement of Philip D. Reed as chairman of the General Electric Company on April 23 was announced yesterday. Mr. Reed will end all active service with the company next year at the age of sixty. Retirement is mandatory at General Electric at age 65.
A well-adjusted white male rat named Barnabel taught a few things yesterday to psychology students at Barnard College.

Potato futures continued strong yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. For the second consecutive day the March, April and May positions rose the 30-point (hundredths of a cent a pound) daily limit during trading.

BETTY SMITH'S third novel is published today. It is called "Maggie-Now"* and it comes to us ten years after her second, "Tomorrow Will Be Better," and sixteen years after her first, "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- Gracie Allen has decided to retire from theatrical life. The comedienne's husband and stage partner, George Burns, confirmed today she had made the decision to end her career and said:

Government research on "exotic" fuels is being concentrated on high-energy compounds that theoretically could increase the range of jet aircraft 40 to 70 per cent and double the propulsion energy of rockets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the 1957 net income of Class I railroads at $732,000,000, off $149,000,000 or about 17 per cent below the $881,000,000 cleared in 1956.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Feb. 18 -- Two helicopters of the Army Aviation Section here flew rescue missions today to evacuate seventeen persons marooned by snow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers opposed today the creation by Congress of a commission to rule on the inability of a President to hold his job.

Senator Hubert Humphrey in his four-hour foreign policy speech before the Senate on Feb. 4 suggested a number of forms of "positive approach" to be made by our Government toward the solution of world problems. Among them was the prompt negotiation of an agreement with the Soviet Union to suspend nuclear testing, independent of all other issues.
HARTFORD, Feb. 18 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff submitted to Republican legislative leaders today a series of proposals to ease the unemployment situation in the state.

There will be fifty-eight men here this morning who will not mind New York's unusually frigid weather. They are the officers and crew of the United States Naval Ship Towle, the first vessel to return from Operation Deepfreeze III, the third and largest Navy Antarctic supply operation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- The House passed today an Interior Department money bill trimmed only three-tenths of 1 per cent below President Eisenhower's request.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- A Republican bill to provide an alternate method for revision of the New York City charter was reported to the floor today by the Assembly Committee on the Affairs of New York City.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Mitchell bill to give the State Labor Relations Board power to determine collective bargaining units among New York City Transit Authority employes was approved in the Senate today. The vote was 31 to 23.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Feb. 18 -- More than 1,000 automobiles of all types have sped over the beach sands here in the last week in search of records.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The United States is preparing to ease its negotiating position on travel restrictions against Soviet citizens. It would be done in a way that could improve chances for opening more territory here and in Russia.
PARIS, Feb. 18 -- New details of the Rapacki plan elicited today a restatement of the French position that security and political problems in Central Europe were inseparable.

TEBESSA, Algeria, Feb. 18 -- The so-called Morice Line leaks like a sieve. The French estimate it stops barely 20 per cent of the arms traffic regularly flowing from Tunisia in increasing volume to the Algerian rebels.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Reorganization of the Royal Navy for "greater mobility and immediate readiness" will involve abolition of the Nore Command and closing of the famous dockyards at Sheerness and Portland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A House of Representatives Appropriations subcommittee has voted to give the Administration about half of the $2,054,000 it wants to improve the United States' showing at the forthcoming Brussels world's fair.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 -- The seventh race usually is the Hialeah feature, but today the fifth was the main event. The reason: Maine Chance Farm's Jewel's Reward the champion 2-year-old of 1957, made his 1958 debut in it.

IZMIR, Turkey, Feb. 17 -- The American Tobacco Company has purchased 5,250,000 kilograms (11,550,000 pounds) of American grade manipulated tobacco from the Turkish Government. This will bring $7,968,750 to this credit-starved country.

There's a surprise in store for Istvan Rozsavolgyi. The Hungarian miler, who has stressed his "aloneness" as an unaccompanied, uninitiated runner competing against rivals familiar with each other and with board track racing strategy, will have a close acquaintance at his side Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Spokesmen for the nation's truckers asked Congress today to spurn appeals of the railroads for authority to enter freely into other forms of transportation, specifically trucking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- An official of the Boston and Maine Railroad today protested that carriers serving Portland, Me., and Middle Atlantic ports have lower rates to Midwestern territory than those serving Boston and New York, despite greater mileages.

THE Greenwich Village Antiques Show -- the show for young couples beginning their "collecting" and for the visitor with an acute eye for "sleepers" -- will open tomorrow at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street. It will run through Saturday from noon to 10 P. M. daily.

The B. F. Goodrich Company lifted sales 1.4 per cent last year to $734,650,802 from the 1956 volume of $724,168,401. But earnings fell $4,395,726, according to the report of John L. Collyer, chairman, and J. W. Keener, president.

A new contract covering 23,000 employes and providing wage increases and other benefits worth 38.5 cents an hour was negotiated yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company and the Utility Workers Union of America.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- By a vote of 101 to 38 the Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill revising the Brooklyn approach to the proposed Narrows Bridge between Bay Ridge and Staten Island.

Lewis Conger, the 123-year old New York specialty and housewares retailer, is "definitely staying in business" despite its present financial difficulties, a spokesman for the company declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- The world index of industrial production stood at 116 (on a 1953 basis of 100) in the third quarter of last year, a record for any third quarter, the United Nations monthly Bulletin of Statistics has reported.

The capital city of Washington belongs to all the people of this country; and it is a matter of concern to all the people when efforts are made -- as they continually are being made -- to rob it of its fragile and unique beauty.
THE trouble with dogs is women who will not let them lead a dog's life.
"FOR one horrible moment," said Dan Ferris, "I thought he was about to pull a Joe Loomis on me and disappear."
Bitter 4-degree cold shattered the season's day-old record for low temperatures here yesterday. The city edged close to its record for a sustained cold wave.

American paper manufacturers were urged yesterday to look to foreign markets for increased sales. Speakers at a meeting of the export committee of the American Paper and Pulp Association said that countries in the European Common Market and in the Western Hemisphere were particularly good prospects.
The New York Rangers will attempt to solidify their hold on second place in the National Hockey League race when they skate against the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A Greek captain, officers and crew replaced German seamen aboard the supertanker World Glory yesterday. It was the first step in a new fleet-wide policy of Hellenization formulated by Stavros S. Niarchos, Greek shipping magnate.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The three highest officers of the International Brotherhood of Carpenters were indicted today. They were charged with conspiracy to bribe a state official in the Indiana land profiteering scandals.

Three basketball teams were named yesterday to compete in post-season tournaments. Notre Dame and Pittsburgh were selected for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and Niagara was picked for the National Invitation tournament.

Gordon Y. Billard, a limited partner in J. R. Williston Co., New York brokerage house, and William S. Bartman, a Los Angeles attorney, announced yesterday that they have filed suit against Western Air Lines in Delaware to compel the management to call a stockholders' meeting.
A third body was uncovered yesterday in the smoldering ruins of a downtown factory. Firemen continued to search for the fourth victim.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- A bill that would broaden the power of the courts to review decisions by administrative officers and agencies was approved by the Assembly today.
Living began to get back to normal in the New York suburbs yesterday despite a night of temperatures near zero that followed the week-end snow.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 18 -- Indian policemen arrested today a stock market speculator whose activities have involved Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Government in a still-boiling controversy.
ROME, Feb. 18 -- Many Catholics in Rome have fallen into a state of "spiritual inertness" and are interested only in material pleasures, Pope Pius XII said today.

Having concluded their appeal to Washington, the railroad presidents hastened to Albany to put before Governor Harriman and legislative leaders their case for help to survive against increased costs, high taxation, duplicated governmental regulation, subsidized competition and passenger losses.
GIL McDOUGALD is just as good at running surveys as he is at running bases.

At times during the Security Council meeting yesterday it seemed as though the controversy between France and Tunisia were going to be threshed out then and there. The Tunisian representative, Ambassador Mongi Slim, seemed skeptical of a happy outcome.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The American Council on Education urged Congress today to approve a Federal college construction program and to create a Federal agency to deal with graduate schools.
TUNIS, Feb. 18 -- Settlement of the Algerian war must await pressure by the United States and other Western powers to change the French position, President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia said today.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury has indicted four Miami area bankers, including a former "man of the year," on charges of misapplying more than $7,000,000.
The Board of Education is planning to open four new schools for suspended pupils within a week or ten days.
JERRY LEWIS, during a one-hour performance on Channel 4 last night, demonstrated that he is virtually indefatigable. The same cannot be said for some of his viewers:
The City Council moved yesterday to seek additional school construction and help in the fight against juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A Miami lawyer testified today his firm had tried to approach a member of the Federal Communications Commission on a pending case through a "friend" of the commissioner. A former partner of the lawyer, now a judge, said he had suggested the move.
LONDON, Feb. 18 ( Reuters) -- Wally Brockwell, a warehouseman, today won a tax-free, cash prize of 206,028 ($576,878) -- a record prize for Britain's soccer pools.

Members of the frozen food industry were urged last night by Sigurd Anderson, Federal Trade Commissioner, to report to his agency any "bad competitive practices" of which they had proof. He assured those making such complaints of complete "confidentiality."
TOKYO, Feb. 18 (UP) -- The Japanese Antarctic Expedition reported today that it would try to rescue by plane the fifteen sledge dogs it had left behind on Showa Base on Ongul Island.

QUITO, Ecuador, Feb, 18 (AP) -- A revolt in a Galapagos Islands penal colony has collapsed after covering the escape of twenty-one convicts aboard a commandeered United States yacht, the Government said tonight.

A proposal to extend Beekman Place across East Forty-ninth Street by building a bridge has evoked more than sighs in that fashionable neighborhood. Many residents, in fact, are up in arms. They feel that the two-block-long north-south street with its view of the United Nations and the East River is already too well traveled.
A group of 233 underwriters led by Morgan Stanley Co. is offering today $150,000,000 of 4 per cen debentures of General Motors Acceptance Corporation, due in 1979, at 98.50 to yield 4.1 per cent.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 18 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff kept a five-month-old date here today with two parochial-school pupils.

The fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 1136 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Ninety-fifth Street, has been purchased by I. Jerome Riker Co. and associated interests. It contains forty-three apartments and was sold for cash by Herman and Theodore Basch in a deal negotiated by Williams Weinstein, brokers. The plot is 105 by 102 feet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Congress was told today it must give able military men a chance to move ahead faster or risk having the services heavily weighted with the ambitionless.
HAVANA, Feb. 18 -- Premier Andres Rivero Aguero has become Presidential candidate for the four-party government coalition in the elections of June 1.
The Air Force revealed yesterday that an air-flow speed of 32,400 miles an hour had been attained for about one-tenth of a second in a new wind tunnel.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 18 -- The rebel government here made plans today to end the isolation imposed on central Sumatra by Jakarta's severance of communications to this area.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd told the House of Commons today that he was convinced a solution of the Cyprus problem acceptable to both Greek and Turkish Cypriotes was possible.
WARSAW, Feb. 18 -- The Polish Government has granted two major requests made by the Roman Catholic Church in negotiations that were resumed recently after a lapse of several months.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 18 -- President Eisenhower will send a special message to Congress tomorrow asking for $3,900,000,000 for military and economic foreign aid during the fiscal year of 1959.

Sub - freezing temperatures and stinging winds continued their numbing course across the eastern third of the country yesterday as the death toll in winter's worst cold wave rose to 182 since Saturday.

NAHA, Okinawa, Feb. 18 -- Kansai Miyara, a Left-Wing Socialist, has organized a new political party in Okinawa. It is called the Socialist Democratic party, and, according to Mr. Miyara, it will maintain a common front with the Okinawa People's party, which now is called the Minren.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Representative Sam Rayburn said today that he and Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. had conferred on the disputed natural gas bill without determining what to do about it.

After consultation with Soviet Russia and other "socialist" countries, the Communist regime in Poland has now submitted a formal outline of the so-called Rapacki plan for a denuclearized zone in Central Europe. This is accompanied by a request for immediate negotiations as a contribution to a successful summit meeting.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Republican legislative leaders agreed at policy conference today to sponsor legislation fixing Aug. 12 as the date for this year's primary elections.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 18 -- Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, will not reopen the eating club controversy that has upset the campus, it was disclosed today.

The appointments of four executives -- three vice presidents and a general manager of operations for steel -in the production department of the United States Steel Corporation, were announced yesterday by Harvey B. Jordan, executive vice president for production.
The study of the history of science was proposed last night by Dr. I. Bernard Cohen as a means of making science "a subject of humane dimensions."

Three of the five upper floors of the six-story Gall Lembke Building at 7 East Forty-eighth Street have been taken on ten-year leases. Joseph B. Rosenblatt and Rennold Wacht; realty investors, recently converted the upper part of the structure from manufacturing and loft occupancy to air-conditioned offices.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Government announced today that the mock attack on the United States to be staged as part of Operation Alert 1958 had been scheduled for May 6-7.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A bipartisan bill to add twenty-five justices to the State Supreme Court was submitted to the Legislature today. It is identical with a measure vetoed by Governor Harriman in 1956.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- "The Untouchables," a personal recollection by the late Eliot Ness of lawlessness during the Prohibition era, is to be filmed by Seven Arts Productions. Mr. Ness, who was a Treasury Department agent, wrote the book in collaboration with Oscar Farley.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The stock market was more buoyant today. The recovery was ascribed to a more optimistic view of Egypt's dispute with the Sudan and the revived hope that the bank rate might be lowered before long.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Doubts about the possibility of establishing a European free-trade zone were expressed here today at the opening of a three-day conference of employers and trade unionists from sixteen countries.

Nearly twenty-five years ago a young and enterprising curator of the Metropolitan Museum of Art started in pursuit of a coveted acquisition for the Cloisters. Just a few days ago his efforts were finally rewarded with the arrival here of the treasure -- a stone apse of a Spanish twelfth century church.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 19 -- This city has appointed a 29-year-old clergyman to help keep its delinquent youth out of further trouble.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Milton Berle's role in "Kraft Theatre" this evening actually was a tryout for a new hourlong anthology series to be titled "Off-Beat." Tonight's play, "Material Witness," was the pilot production for the planned series, which would be seen on the National Broadcasting Company television network.

ROME, Feb. 19 -- Negotiations aimed at a financial settlement in connection with the nationalization by Egypt of the Universal Suez Canal Company in July, 1956, got under way in Rome today with good prospects of success.

FISH, the oldest symbol of Christianity, has long been an unrestricted food during the times of fasting established by the church. It is axiomatic, therefore, that more fish is consumed during the forty days of Lent than any other time of the year.

ROME, Feb. 19 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt will make a state visit to Italy next summer. An announcement by Government sources here tonight said it was "auspicious" that the long delayed event could take place in the near future because this indicated a gradual easing of the situation in the eastern Mediterranean.
The New York Philharmonic's spring tour of Latin America has been extended from four to eight weeks to satisfy the demand for appearances by the orchestra.

ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 19 -- Premier Kwame Nkrumah opened today an extraordinary session of the Commission for Technical Cooperation in Africa South of the Sahara. This body will launch a foundation for mutual assistance in Africa, which is intended to serve as a clearance house for technical cooperation among the participating countries.
The railroads serving New York City struggled back toward normal yesterday, but misfortune continued to dog the Pennsylvania.
A suspicious explosion yesterday morning shattered the plate glass window of a lower East Side bakery that was recently involved in a labor dispute.

MIAMI Feb. 19 -- Fred W. Hooper, who bought a Kentucky Derby winner the first time he bought a thoroughbred, made a jubilant phone call to Atlanta a few minutes after the running of the $21,650 Florida Breeders' Stakes at the Hialeah house park today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- The Soviet people are preparing, and are being prepared, to elect the 1,364 Deputies to their two-house national legislature, the Supreme Soviet.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that Arthur Godfrey would star on separate radio and television programs on weekday mornings beginning March 31. A portion of the entertainer's radio program, which began on the network in 1945, has been televised simultaneously since 1952.
Alabama sold yesterday six issues of bonds totaling $21,000,000 to finance the construction of educational buildings and hospitals and the improvement of inland waterways.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Prison sentences of eighteen months and fines of $2,500 each were imposed in Federal Court today on seven persons convicted of conspiring to falsify non-Communist affidavits filed with the National Labor Relations Board.
Two more crewmen of the lost Italian freighter Bonitos were rescued yesterday, bringing the total of survivors to five.
SOMERVILLE, Mass., Feb. 19 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today it would close its assembly plant here on March 14. The plant was opened thirty-one years ago.

THESE menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The American Concert Choir and Orchestra, conducted by Margaret Hillis, presented an interesting program as usual last night in Town Hall. The pieces played were Purcell's "Ode on St. Cecilia's Day," Stravinsky's "Renard" and two works by the late Erich Itor Kahn -- Three Madrigals and the world premiere of "Vocalise."
Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight boxing champion, is going to be under official pressure soon to defend his title.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today envisaged modest success at a summit conference as leading to further meetings between the leaders of East and West.

TEANECK, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey called on the United States tonight to sponsor in the United Nations a study aimed at putting space travel and communication under international rule.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Feb. 19 -- A pessimistic bulletin on Roy Campanella's condition was issued today by the Community Hospital here.
The city's spell of frigid weather has caused the death of seven deer at the Bronx zoo, directly or indirectly.

Regional Subcommittee II of the Voluntary Home Mortgage Credit Program has announced the election of R. Manning Brown Jr. as chairman. He has been a member of the group since 1956 and is a vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company.
The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations yesterday gave its Murray-Green Award for 1957 to Dr. Jonas E. Salk for his vaccine against poliomyelitis.

A plot of land with a front-age of 420 feet on Wetherole Street, at Sixty-sixth Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, has been purchased by New York builders for improvement with an apartment building of 185 suites.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 -- Wall Street turned a somewhat chilly shoulder today to Los Angeles' plans for revitalizing its transit facilities.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Bad weather forced the Golden Rule, a thirty-foot ketch, to turn back today from its voyage to protest nuclear tests, the Coast Guard said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Representative John Bell Williams, Democrat of Mississippi, accused Northern newspapers, news magazines and the big radio and TV networks today of biased reporting of racial conflicts.

The surviving remnants of free enterprise in Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary are causing trouble for the Communist rulers of those countries. Some of the "crimes" charged against these small entrepreneurs make peculiar reading. In Czechoslovakia, for example, free enterprise establishments are said to be paying excessively high wages so that they draw workers away from state-owned plants.
Harlem objectors to a proposed public housing development were invited by the city yesterday to find a private developer who would build on the site.
The guidelines for a new Latin American order based on mutual defense against dictatorship have been set out in a manifesto signed by representative intellectuals from eight countries.

The Navy's ship Towle had almost as much trouble yesterday with New York ice as she had with the Antarctic variety. The 15,000-ton, ice-strengthened cargo vessel is the first of ten supply ships to return here.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Air Line Pilots Association reinstated its strike call against Western Air Lines today after the management rejected a Government proposal to settle the dispute.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A bill making a year's residence a condition for receiving home relief was rejected decisively in the state Senate today.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The disappearance of Paul Joe Payne, 19-year-old hold-up man, baffled State Penitentiary authorities for nineteen years. How did he escape ?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The State Department named Deputy Under Secretary Robert Murphy today to try to help settle the dispute between France and Tunisia.
What does The Times advocate for the Middle East? That question, which has long puzzled me, has been exploded into type by Harold B. Minor's important letter in your issue of Feb. 13.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The defending champion, Mrs. Barbara Romack Porter of Sacramento, Calif., breezed through her opening match in the South Atlantic women's amateur golf tournament today. She defeated Dale Fleming of Tulsa, Okla., 5 and 4.

In a strong and effective message asking Congress to approve a $4 billion mutual security program for the coming fiscal year President Eisenhower has challenged the loud but irresponsible opposition in both parties to accept his proposals in substance or frankly face up to the consequences.
The State Public Service Commission yesterday approved the elimination of fifteen hazardous grade crossings on the Long Island Rail Road in Queens and Nassau Counties.

FOR several years the National Academy of Design, in its annual exhibitions, has been widening the basis of the shows, including more work by non-members and putting on displays with an increasingly contemporary look.
AIN ROMANA, Algeria, Feb. 13 -- The French Army's ammunition in Algeria includes new houses, schools, improved agricultural techniques and expanded public health services.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- In the absence of picketing, a work boycott by the musicians is not expected to affect production at the studios.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Manchester United, Britain's greatest soccer team, which was virtually shattered in an air crash in Munich two weeks ago, returned to the playing field tonight.

On Feb. 13 you published a front-page article from Albany relating that "a bipartisan deal has been negotiated for the addition of seven State Supreme Court justices in the Tenth Judicial District, composed of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
DETROIT, Feb. 19 -- The United Automobile Workers has decided to ask the Chrysler Corporation to re-establish a forty-hour week for its workers and to lay off those it cannot employ full time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn raised the possibility today that the House of Representatives might refuse to authorize continuation of the reciprocal trade program.

Cocoa futures rose sharply to new life-of-contract highs during trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange Trading was influenced by indications that crops would be small and supplies tight this year.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 19 -- The governing junta is preparing a decree that will name a special commission to draft a national electoral statute for Venezuela, President Wolfgang Larrazabal said tonight.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 18 -- Israel's kibbutzim, some of the oldest and most successful communal settlements in modern history, are today facing new problems.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 19 -- In an effort to protect its water supply for twenty years, Bergen County will object tomorrow to a proposal by the North Jersey District Water Supply Commission. The agency wants to double the amount of water it draws from the Ramapo River.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Growers voted overwhelmingly yesterday to extend Federal marketing quotas on the 1958, 1959 and 1960 crops of fire-cured tobacco of types 21, 22 and 23, and dark air-cured tobacco.
Recruiters in seventeen cities are hiring scores of unemployed engineers with experience in missiles and related fields.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals outlawed today segregation on city buses and street cars in New Orleans.
The number of city pupils suspended in the recent crackdown on delinquency in the schools has risen above 700, it was reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The State Council of Retail Merchants appealed to Governor Harriman today to sign the Republican unemployment insurance bill now before him.

Charles A. Rheinstrom, considered in trade circles an authority on transportation advertising, is leaving the J. Walter Thompson Company to return to the airline business. A vice president and director at the agency, he has been named executive vice president for sales at American Airlines, effective April 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The American economy is becoming not only the major political issue of 1958 but the main foreign policy issue as well.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Trading in grain futures of the Board of Trade was at a low ebb today and prices scarcely strayed from their previous closes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The House Government Operations Committee charged today that cigarette manufacturers had "deceived" the public through their advertising of filter-tip cigarettes.

An early romp developed into a torrid struggle for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. The Broadway Blues had an edge of three goals to none well past the half-way mark of the third period.

SINCE there is no business like show business, "Annie Get Your Gun" opened at the City Center on schedule last evening. Martha Raye, who had expected to be the star performer, was tucked away in the hospital, no doubt biting her nails from frustration.
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Feb. 19 -- Police departments in towns near the Suffolk County Air Force Base were alerted tonight to look for a possibly live warhead on a Falcon air-to-air missile.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The Legislature received a Republican proposal today to provide $200,000,000 in borrowing power to New York City for school construction over a ten-year period.
In banking, Canal Street, Manhattan, divides the city from the country.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- France decided today to establish a No Man's Land about 200 miles long and averaging fifteen miles in depth on the Algerian side of the Tunisian frontier to check rebel infiltrations.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Amid predictions of a 25-cent fare, the Assembly approved today the transit labor bill for New York City.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Ralph (Tiger) Jones, a middleweight, turned the tables on the former welterweight champion Kid Gavilan, tonight. With a persistent hooking attack, Jones gained a split decision in the first fight ever televised from a hotel.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The French Government received a scarcely veiled warning from its financial experts today that the country's continued economic and social progress depended to a large extent on an end of the Algerian war.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Brown scored three goals in a 2-minute 20-second stretch of the first period and then went on to score two in the second and one in the third to crush Yale, 7 -- 0, in hockey tonight.
IN the spring, a housewife reluctantly turns to clearing out closets. But how does she unburden herself of the white elephants she finds ?
The New England Ski Councll issued at 5:30 P. M. yesterday the following reports, along with the Weather BureaU. forecast:
The threat was raised yesterday that several lawyers might withdraw as counsel to several teen-agers on trial in General Sessions Court for first-degree murder.
The State Department yesterday called on public relations agencies to give active support to cultural-goodwill exchanges with the Soviet Union.

Sam Giammalva of Houston narrowly escaped defeat last night at the hands of an unranked 20-year-old Australian newcomer as the national indoor tennis championships started at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
IF anything can lure the teenager out of her blue jeans, it is the new "Young Junior" shop at Russeks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -Lewis L. Strauss stirred a Congressional hornets' nest today with an atomic plant proposal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Council of Chief State School Officers urged today outright Federal sharing in the costs of supporting the nation's schools.
Joseph Foier has been promoted to vice president and sales manager of American Molding Powder and Chemical Corporation, Brooklyn.

In a joint communique with North Korean Premier Kim, Premier Chou of Communist China announces that the Chinese "volunteer" armies which invaded Korea in 1950 and still number around 350,000 men will be withdrawn by the end of this year, and that -- how fortunate! -- the "volunteers" have fully concurred in this move.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y. Feb. 19 -- Mrs. Donald V. Buttenheim, president of the Mount Kisco Junior League, has appointed Mrs. Hughes Dallas of Chappaqua general chairman of the Washington Birthday Pan-American Circus benefit performances.

PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 19 -- Dr. Sjafruddin Prawiranegara issued a sharp reminder here this evening that his revolutionary regime expected an answer "within a few days" from President Sukarro to its demands for government changes in Jakarta.
Sales last year of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., were the highest in its fifty-sixth-year history. Earnings, however, declined to $12,655,839 from $14,835,389 in 1956.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 19 -- Spanish planes were reported today to have bombed the northern part of Ifni enclave, which fell into the hands of Moroccan rebels last December.

WIESBADEN Germany, Feb. 19 -- The heavy hand of justice descended today upon Valentin Korn, former wine maker. The Rhineland grape industry, represented by rows of stern-faced men seated in the state court of Hesse here, nodded in grave approval.

A proxy fight for control of the Penn-Texas Corporation has been started. The target is Leopold D. Silberstein, president and chairman. The attackers are a dissident group of stockholders and directors.

A strong indication that Nikolai M. Shvernik, former Soviet trade union leader, is being groomed to take a high Government post, possibly the Pre miership now held by Marshal Bulganin, has been given by the Soviet press.
There has been quite enough of this winter. With freezing temperatures and snow sufficient to cover three centuries there is no need for further of the same. This winter may end now.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that any sharp reduction in the Mutual Security program would ultimately mean a "beleaguered America" all but alone in a Communist world.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced yesterday that it would omit payment of interest due May 1 on its general mortgage series "A," 4 1/2 per cent convertible bonds maturing in 2022.

Directors of the Crucible Steel Company of America cut the quarterly dividend yesterday to 10 cents from 40 cents. At the same time the steel producer, which is considered of medium size, reported net income for 1957 of $6,543,594, compared with $12,767,625 in 1956.

" The Kingdom of Jordan," a new book by Raphael Patai, is planned for March 31 publication by Princeton University Press.
