Described as "the first full-length study of Jordan in the English language," the book gives detailed information about the country's government, finances, industry, agriculture, labor, communications, religion and culture. Dr. Patai is director of research at the Theodor Herzl Institute.

Several years ago Henry Bruere wrote, at the conclusion of an obituary tribute to a former city official: "A grateful city that certainly in the long run appreciates good services rendered will, I hope, find some appropriate and enduring way to record its gratitude to an honorable, efficient and devoted public servant."
HAVANA, Feb. 19 -- Dissatisfaction within the four-party Government coalition resulted today in a major change in its slate of candidates.
A middle-aged man with a bottle of whisky in his hand turned out last night to be a lot tougher than a young man with a pistol.
A $23,000,000 contract for the reconstruction of port facilities in Kuwait, the oil-rich sheikhdom on the Persian Gulf, has been awarded to two American concerns.

Robert A. McDonald, former Deputy Assistant Defense Secretary, replied yesterday to a charge that he had spent more time away from his job than on it. He called it part of "an extensive program of defamation."
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 19 -- Half of the Antarctic coast was pictured today as a semi-circular chain of glacier-covered islands.
Hunter College will award degrees to 391 students tonight at its 112th commencement in the college's Assembly Hall, 695 Park Avenue. The ceremonies will begin at 8 P. M. with an academic procession.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- Donations of private funds for the purchase of Byram Lake and some surrounding property have been offered to this village, it was learned today.

The Public Service Commission held a hearing yesterday on a proposal by the Long Island Rail Road to cut service on the Rockaway Beach Branch spur in Queens. The service is used by 500 residents of the communities of Rego Park, Parkside, Brooklyn Manor, Woodhaven and Ozone Park.

LAWRENCEVILLE, H. J., Feb. 19 -- Gene Shahan, a senior from Jackson, Mich., paced Princeton with his long-distance running today to its ninth straight victory in the twentieth annual Polar Bear meet. Princeton had 57 points to 47 1/2 for Pennsylvania and 32 1/2 for Columbia in the three-team meet at the Lawrenceville School.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Dr. Bernard Schwartz, who was discharged last week as chief counsel of the special House subcommittee investigating the Federal regulatory agencies, is returning to academic life -- part time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Christianity was warned here today to combat corruption on the local level or to acknowledge defeat in its battle for the souls of city dwellers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Ralph J. Cordiner urged Congress today to put his committee's military pay plan into effect immediately -- without delays and changes recommended by the Department of Defense -- to obtain "strong impact."

Medical treatment for heart failure is capable now of giving normal life expectancy to patients who would have died some twenty years ago. This development was reported yesterday at Monteflore Hospital by researchers supported in by the New York Heart Association.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Six men were killed and forty injured today when a furnace exploded in a plant engaged in secret Government work.

Plans for a twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 210 to 218 East Fifty-eighth Street, east of Third Avenue, were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property to the 210 East Fifty-eighth Street Corporation.

Ski Sketch: Seven years ago Ajax Marsten, a stationery and office equipment merchant in Pittsfield. Mass., searched for ski equipment for his two daughters, Marquita and Pamela. He encountered difficulty. The reason? Marquita was only 4 and Pamela 2.
MILTON BERLE made his dramatic debut last night in a play entitled "Material Witness," presented on the "Kraft Television Theatre" over Channel 4.

THE President of the United States has chosen a new member for his Cabinet. The Senate has not yet acted on the nomination. It seems unlikely that the man, Ansel Gibbs, really wants, or will receive, approval. For all the tumult about it makes him feel like a player in a fantastic morality, "the Shadow King, meeting and holding court with the faculties of his lapsed humanity."

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- South Korea is reported to have instructed Ambassador You Chan Yang in Washington to appeal to the United Nations for help in effecting the return of kidnapped persons aboard a Korean National Airways plane forced to land Sunday in Communist North Korea.

Yeshiva College received yesterday a trophy for contributing proportionately the greatest number of pints of blood to the Red Cross in competition with fourteen other colleges last year. Approximately 200 of the college's 400 students gave blood.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, today held out the hope that an effective defense against missiles was in the making.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- The record of Arthur Frank Katzentine, who testified today on his losing bid for a controversial Miami TV channel, would make him eligible for inclusion in a Who's Who Among Crime Busters.

Today's new film is "The Brothers Karamazov." a MetroGoldwyn-Mayer adaptation of the novel by Fyodor Dostoevski, at the Radio City Music Hall. Heading the cast of the color film are Yul Brynner, Maria Schell, Claire Bloom, Lee J. Cobb, Richard Basehart, Albert Salmi and William Shatner.
Cotton futures declined 4 to 15 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The drop equaled 20 to 75 cents a bale.
St. Patrick's Cathedral reported that it had the largest one-day's attendance in its history yesterday as Ash Wednesday opened Lent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- House investigators heard testimony today that "pressures" to win a valuable Miami television channel had not been one sided.
Stock prices rose during most of yesterday's session but followed the tobaccos down in the final minutes to close slightly, lower on the day.
TOKYO, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Chou En-lai challenged the United States and its allies tonight to match Communist China and withdraw their troops from Korea.

The metal beryllium is widely considered one of the most promising structural materials for advanced aircraft and rockets. But how can the supply be increased until demand is big enough to warrant the considerable expenditure involved? And how can demand be stimulated, unless potential users are confident of an adequate supply?
A Brooklyn judge denounced the "incompetence" of the Kings County District Attorney's staff yesterday in the trial of five men charged with second-degree manslaughter.

VICTOR BORGE, whose sources of income are honorable, varied and substantial, is in the happy position of not being required to work often on television in order to survive. His show over Channel 2 last night was his first TV assignment in more than a year.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Snow reports received today by the State Department of Commerce: Birch Hill -- 4 to 8 inches powder snow, 8 to 15 inches base; skiing excellent.

" The Eisenhower Administration," wrote our correspondent John D. Morris from Washington a few days ago, "opened a battle against heavy odds today for continuation of an effective reciprocal trade program."
" When times are good, it is axiomatic common sense to prepare for less prosperous times." -- L. Judson Morhouse, State Republican chairman.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- The Soviet Union gave its full, and not unexpected, support tonight to the Polish Government's plan for establishing a zone in Central Europe that would be free of nuclear and rocket weapons.

THE Metropolitan Opera's new "Madama Butterfly" is exquisite in taste and sensibility. The encrustations of tradition at its worst have been wiped away and have been replaced by a fresh view painted by the delicate brush of Japanese imagination.
Opponents of the proposed $205,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment carried their fight into Federal court yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 19 -- President Sukarno will meet with former Vice President Hatta tomorrow.
Senator Wayne Morse accused the Eisenhower Administration last night of trying to solve the recession with "bankers' boon-doggles."
The short interest as of Feb. 14 on the New York Stock Exchange was 3,921,260 shares, the highest aggregate since mid-February, 1932, the exchange reported yesterday.
ROQUEBRUNE - CAP - MARTIN, France, Feb. 19 -- Sir Winston Churchill, Britain's 83-year-old elder statesman, has pneumonia and pleurisy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Attorney General Rogers' firm exclusion, at a Senate subcommittee hearing yesterday, of anything save a constitutional amendment to provide for continuous, orderly government during a period when a President is disabled and cannot, or will not, so declare, has ended any chance of doing this by a veto-proof Congressional statute.

The 20-cent increase in the quarterly dividend of the P. Lorillard Company and the extra dividend of 25 cents voted by the American Sugar Refining Company were the only bright spots in a list of dividend actions announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The United States has no intention now of withdrawing its forces from South Korea, the State Department said today.

A theatre party at the April 7 performance of "Say, Darling" is being arranged by members of the Women's Association of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. The new play, with David Wayne and Vivian Blaine in the leading roles, will open at the ANTA Theatre on April 3.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board reduced today the reserve requirements of member banks in its most substantial counter-recession move so far in the current business slump.
The international executive board of the American Federation of Musicians last night issued strike orders to its Local 47, which serves the major film producing studios in Hollywood.
The American Rayon Institute has budgeted $1,750,000 this year to promote the use of rayon in tire cord and textiles.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Former President Harry S. Truman disclosed tonight that he would soon make a speaking tour in which his theme would be "The Brotherhood of Man and the Fatherhood of God."

BONN, Germany, Feb. 19 -- West Germany rejected the Rapacki plan today on the ground that it implied the continued partition of Germany and the permanent military superiority of the Soviet Union over the Western Allies.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 19 (AP) -- President Eisenhower went for another automobile ride today while the weather stayed cold. He again passed up hunting and golf.
Jerome Robbins has established a foundation to assist young choreographers in bringing their work to the attention of the public.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union announced yesterday that it would put $20,000,000 into a low-income and middle-income housing project south and west of Pennsylvania Station.
KHARTOUM, The Sudan, Feb. 19 -- The Government announced tonight it had rejected an Egyptian proposal that both the Egyptian plebiscite and Sudanese election be postponed.
The possibility of using electronic devices to locate firemen buried in collapsed buildings was noted yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
Errol Flynn, star of "The Master of Thornfield," has decided to bow out of the forthcoming dramatization of Charlotte Bronte's novel "Jane Eyre" after Saturday night's performance in Cincinnati.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee voted today to let the Government sell an additional $2,000,000,000 worth of farm surpluses overseas for foreign currency.
Prices of paper products will tend to be steady to higher despite the industry's excess capacity, David L. Luke said yesterday.
Imports of petroleum and oil products rebounded to a record high last week from a twelve-month low the week before. Gasoline inventories also set a new high.
The sun smiled upon the city yesterday, snow began melting in the streets and the temperature surged all the way up to 30.9 degrees at 4:10 P. M. It was the warmest day here since Feb. 8.

WASHINGTON Feb. 19 -- Robert Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, warned today against the widespread notion that there was something inevitable or imminent about a heads-of-government meeting with the Soviet Union.
The City Planning Commission recommended yesterday that the Board of Estimate disapprove a proposal to extend Beekman Place across East Forty-ninth Street by building a bridge.
MANAMA, Bahrain, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A new British freighter carrying explosives for Iran's oil fields blew up tonight while the crew was fighting a fire in the hold.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Japan protested formally today the United States nuclear tests scheduled in the Pacific this spring.

ROME, Feb. 19 -- The wreckage of a United States Air Force C-47 transport plane missing since last Saturday night was found on the northern slope of Mount Vesuvius today. Rescue parties reported that the sixteen American servicemen aboard were all killed in the crash.

The Republican choice of June 3 for the primary election this year and Governor Harriman's veto seem to have been equally and almost unashamedly political in motivation. Both parties looked upon the date primarily from the point of view of what's in it for me.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals solidified their hold on second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association by breaking away in the final period for a 116-110 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in the second game of a double-header tonight.

I am convinced that the Board of Education can do more than any other agency to cure juvenile hoodlumism -- and it need not cost a dime. All they have to do is abolish whatever course of instruction in each grade they consider least important and substitute a course in common good manners.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Governor Harriman announced today the appointment of two new park commissioners and the reappointment of four others.
More than $38,000,000 in new securities are being offered to the investing public today by underwriters.

The Canadian Government reportedly is concluding leasing negotiations for space in Canada House. The twenty-seven-story office building is nearing completion on the southwest corner of Fifth-Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

BRIAN BROWN of Alexandria, Va., formally laid claim yesterday to a fortieth part of the long-distance fish-championship of the world. It seems that the International Game Fish Association will certify the title, if the association hears about it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Feb. 12:

TUNIS, Feb. 19 -- President Habib Bourguiba summoned the United States Ambassador, G. Lewis Jones, and the British Ambassador, Charles Angus Malcolm, today to complain strongly about the "defiant attitude" of France over Tunisia's repeated requests for the closing of four French consulates.

Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society, who gave concert versions of Mozart's "The Abduction from the Seraglio" in 1950 and 1951 at Town Hall, last night revived it at Carnegie Hall. That the larger hall was needed was attested by the audience of more than 2,500.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- Povl Bang-Jensen, a suspended senior political officer, was formally accused today of misconduct during the United Nations investigation of the Hungarian uprising in the fall of 1956.

Nino Valdes of Cuba and Alex Miteff of Argentina will clash in a scheduled ten-round heavyweight fight at Madison Square Garden tonight. This will be the first bout between heavyweights at the Garden in fifteen months.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -- Dr. Edward Teller, an advocate of continued nuclear weapons testing, and Dr. Linus C. Pauling, who backs an international agreement to end testing, debated the issue for an hour today.
WELLINGTON, N. Z., Feb. 20 -- The discovery of mummified seals on mountaintops near McMurdo Sound was reported today by an American scientist.
PARIS, Feb. 20 -- France's Roman Catholics and anti-clericals, who have lived in troubled coexistence since the Revolution of 1789, have found a new subject of controversy -- a postage stamp.
PARIS, Feb. 20 -- Two important meetings of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be held this spring to discuss the Western alliance's military and political policies.

Whatever combination of contra-cyclical devices may be employed for purposes of heading off an incipient recession or containing one that may already have started, the first stage normally consists of action by the monetary authorities to ease credit conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, said today that more than $16,500,000,000 worth of strategic materials, machine tools, farm products and other items now were in the nation's stockpile.
Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney is looking into contract-letting and bidding for electrical work in several city departments.
ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Governor Harriman announced today the selection of Richards Wesley Hannah of Brooklyn as the state's first bingo supervisor.

THERE are men in town who have walked, as far as they know, where no man ever walked before. They are freshly home from that spot, the Cerro Neblina, or the Mountain in the Clouds. They discovered it in 1954 and have just come back from it after a second journey.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Administration is giving serious consideration to a plan for exchange visits by high-ranking United States and Soviet officials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 533,237 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Profits of the Reynolds Metals Company declined last year, despite record sales, the aluminum producer and fabricator reported yesterday.

A move to establish a method for ratifying a work contract that had been tentatively reached on Tuesday between the Consolidated Edison Company and union leaders was rejected last night by angry rank-and-file members.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Nathan Leopold, a partner with Richard Loeb in one of the nation's most shocking murders, today was granted parole from the Illinois state prison. He has served nearly thirty-three and one-half years for the 1924 "thrill" slaying of Bobby Franks, a 14-year-old schoolboy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Senate Committee on Postoffice and Civil Service approved today increases in postal rates totaling about $750,000,000 a year. This went further than the $700,000,000 President Eisenhower had requested in an effort to meet the rising postal deficits.

Vicente Grisolia, young Dominican pianist, possesses a powerful pair of hands with which he knows how to produce the large masses of sound of which every pianist dreams. Against this, he seems rarely able to produce a soft, singing tone; and quite often his right hand attacks the keyboard a fraction of a second after the left, giving the effect of an appogiatura where the composer intended none.
The Texas Railroad Commission yesterday cut allowable oil production in that state next month to the equivalent of nine days' production, the lowest since the state began to regulate oil production.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- A better feeling developed in the stock market today. Although there was no expansion in turnover, prices moved ahead in most of the principal groups.

The Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange has voted to suspend trading in the common stocks of Allied-Albany Paper Corporation and United Dye Chemical Corporation. The suspension is effective March 3.
CAIRO, Feb. 20 -- Egypt went ahead today with plans to include border areas the Sudan holds in tomorrow's plebiscite.

C. P. SNOW'S "The Conscience of the Rich"* is the seventh novel in his distinguished and ambitious fictional study of men, morals and politics in contemporary England. This continuous work consists of a succession of novels told in the first person by Lewis Eliot, a brilliant lawyer and civil servant with an analytical mind and a rare gift for objective detachment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A Federal Reserve Board examiner recommended today against the establishment of a bank holding company linking the second largest bank in New York City and the largest in Westchester County.

Joseph Fuchs and his sister, Lillian Fuchs, were the soloists with the New York Philharmonic last night at Carnegie Hall. They played Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante for Violin and Viola in E flat (K. 364), a work with which they have been closely identified through phonograph records.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 20 (AP) -- United State District Judge Kenneth Grubb ruled today that union strike benefits were taxable.
A first birthday will be observed quietly today at the youngest museum in New York, the Museum of Primitive Art, 15 West Fifty-fourth Street.
TO the maintenance - minded homemaker, the most important trend in carpeting this year will be the increased use of man-made fibers.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Little Rock school board today asked the Federal courts for the second time to suspend the six-months-old racial integration at Central High School.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the State University's Medical College at Syracuse was entitled to the benefits of a $660,000 bequest left to the college when it was a part of Syracuse University.

A $3,000,000 damage suit against the United Fruit Company and a subsidiary resulted in a deadlocked jury in Federal Court yesterday. Nine men and three women on the jury were dismissed after deliberations that began Tuesday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, testified today that an end to the draft was still a long way off.

Funeral services will be held today for the four men crushed to death last Friday when a downtown factory collapsed during a five-alarm fire. They were members of the private Fire Patrol, an insurance group that protects the contents of burning buildings from water damage.
Forty United States students and twenty from the Soviet Union are to participate next summer in the first exchange of student groups between the countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Polish Embassy tonight gave Americans a lesson in the proper way to take pride in their own artists. It disclaimed any intention to make propaganda, but it could not have succeeded better if it had tried.
LODI, N. J., Feb. 20 -- Three Bergen County towns protested today against the final proposed alignment of the Bergen-Passaic Expressway through their limits.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -- By ones, twos and threes the Los Angeles Dodger batterymen arrived in camp today by plane, train and auto, prepared for what promised to be a chilly opening workout tomorrow afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved by voice vote today a temporary $5,000,000,000 increase in the $275,000,000,000 ceiling on the national debt.
ROQUEBRUNE-CAP-MARTIN, France, Feb. 20 -- Sir Winston Churchill appeared today to be holding his own against an attack of pneumonia and pleurisy that confined him to bed here three days ago.
The Army was criticized yesterday for its "arbitrary attitude" in assigning Cheatham Annex, Williamsburg, Va., as its new chief distribution point for perishable food from New York.

WARSAW, Feb. 20 -- Eight persons, including a priest, have been arrested on charges of trying to prevent the burial of a Communist Mayor in consecrated ground. A second priest is under investigation by the Warsaw Province prosecutor's office.

THE new collection of home decorations in Ohrbach's expanding fourth-floor boutique provides a trip around the world without the necessity of a passport. These tempting treasures, be they old or new, or from Florence or Hong Kong, all are in keeping with the current "return to elegance."
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 20 -- An Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile exploded in a flash of flame today shortly after an apparently successful take-off.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 20 -- The Government asked the United Nations today for an immediate meeting of the Security Council to stop "Egyptian aggression."
The Flintkote Company and its subsidiaries last year achieved the highest sales in company history, with the total $116,249,878. Last year the volume was $113,655,116.
SOMERVILLE, Mass., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Civic and governmental officials today sought a new industry for the automobile assembly plant, which the Ford Motor Company plans to close March 14.

New York may be hard-pressed this year to maintain its record pace for drawing tourists and conventions -- more than visit any other place in the world -- according to a cautiously optimistic report made yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The Coliseum Commission today approved a two-year contract enabling the Los Angeles Dodgers to play their 1958 and 1959 home games in the 101,000-seat stadium.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (UP) -Robert Tyre Jones Jr., 55 years old, was named winner today of the William D. Richardson Trophy for outstanding contributions to golf by the Golf Writers Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A witness said today that he had heard Richard A. Mack of the Federal Communications Commission deny ever having pledged his vote to any contender for a television license in Miami, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland said today that testimony taken by Senate investigators indicated that visiting delegations from "subverted churches" behind the Iron Curtain were sent here to further the aims of communism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The world's airlines have been advised that the jet age may create fumes as well as noise at airports.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union broke off negotiations yesterday with five dress employer groups and prepared for a strike March 1 by 60,000 workers.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- A sharp clash between Governor Harriman, a Democrat, and Joseph F. Carlino, Republican leader of the Assembly, enlivened a public hearing to day on proposed changes in the Unemployment Insurance Law.

Republican and Democratic National Committees put aside their differences yesterday to set out together in pursuit of $80,000,000 in campaign contributions that is said to be available for the asking.

Two chemists in the City Medical Examiner's office presented scientific findings yesterday that they said cast new doubt on theories that heart disease might be linked to cholesterol in the blood or to fats in the diet.

College basketball's proposed thirty-second rule will get another complete game trial tonight. Fairleigh Dickinson University has arranged to enforce the half-minute time limit on shooting in its Tri-State Collegiate Basketball League game with Brooklyn College.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The House of Representatives Appropriations Committee approved today the Administration's requests for $2,837,882,907 in additional funds to operate the Government the rest of this fiscal year, which ends June 30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea, has yielded to United States pressure and has agreed to reduce the size of his country's armed forces, according to official sources here.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 -- Minister of Interior Santiago Rey tonight announced that Meyer Lansky, a gambling figure in the United States, will not be readmitted into Cuba. The Minister said that the situation of Lansky in the United States is such as to make him undesirable.
Kurt Nielsen of Denmark and Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, underwent exacting tests last night in gaining the quarter-final round of the national indoor tennis championships.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 20 -- The Indonesian Navy's biggest warship, the Gadja Mada, maneuvered for four hours off Padang today.

NATHAN LEOPOLD, granted freedom yesterday, has said he has undergone a complete physical and psychological change in his thirty-three years in prison. When he went to prison for the "thrill" killing of 14-year-old Bobby Franks, Leopold was a slender, black-haired, good-looking youth of 19.
Higher salaries for all teachers, but no special bonuses based on the subject taught, were urged yesterday by the Board of Education's committee on teacher recruitment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Canada's request to have its oil exempted from voluntary restrictions imposed on oil imports into three West Coast states has been formally turned down by the United States, it was disclosed today.

The Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America held their annual meeting yesterday in an unusual setting -- aboard the Navy's 27,000-ton aircraft carrier Tarawa. The ship docked at Pier 84 on the Hudson River to play host to the Scouts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Roger (The Terrible) Touhy today was granted one of the two paroles he will need to leave the Illinois state prison in August, 1959.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard, the most prolific scorer in National Hockey League history, tallied two goals tonight as he returned from a forty-two game lay-off to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-0 league victory over the Boston Brains.

Mongi Slim, Tunisian Ambassador to the United Nations, said yesterday that the United States should take the same stand against France in the Tunisian dispute that it maintained during the Suez crisic in 1956.
For the first time in thirty years, graduates at Hunter College yesterday received diplomas immediately.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20 (UP) -- Mickey Mantle, the American League's most valuable player for the last two years, failed again today to reach a 1958 salary agreement with the New York Yankees.

A book about the great canals built in this country between 1817 and 1850 will be published Feb. 27 by Putnam. Written by Madeline Sadler Waggoner, it is called "The Long Haul West" and tells about the transportation problem that confronted the pioneers on their trek.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The State Department's view of the Egyptian - Sudanese boundary dispute is that it involves an intricate legal question on which both countries can make substantial arguments.
DOES the weatherman tell Gimbels? Definitely not. Ignoring the elements outside, balmy spring coats and suits in misses' and junior sizes are sprouting all over this store's third floor.
THE recent zero and sub-zero temperatures have been playing havoc with meat prices. Many cuts, already at record high levels, have increased even more.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The nation's inter-city truckers completed three days of testimony here this morning before a Senate investigating committee studying the condition of the railroads by showing a wide split within their ranks.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20 -- The battle for votes in Argentina's general elections Sunday will end officially tomorrow. There are indications that supporters of the ousted dictator Juan D. Peron may be holding the balance of power.

Pleasure boatmen beginning this week will be flexing flabby muscles unused since last fall to pump out their ships. It is too early, of course, for the spring fitting-out and the necessary pumping that is demanded at that time, when hulls with dried, open seams are lowered into the water and must be guarded for a few hours or a few days until the seams swell.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Washington area of the Methodist Church said today that he feared "stumbling capitalism" as much as "creeping socialism."

Today's new film is "Sing Boy Sing," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical with Tommy Sands, Lili Gentle and Edmond O'Brien, at the Mayfair Theatre. Henry Ephron produced and directed the Cinema Scope film, from a screenplay by Claude Binyon.
HALIFAX, N. S., Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Royal Canadian Air Force said today a United States Navy plane carrying twenty-three crew members was missing in the North Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Liberal foreign trade advocates got some ammunition from an unexpected source today in their fight against proposed restrictions on the President's tariff-making powers.

It comes a little late in his term of office, but Dr. William Jansen's plan to hold a weekly press conference to discuss problems of the New York City school system should prove a public service. The Superintendent of Schools has usually had a good "press," or at least a sympathetic one.
Governor Harriman declared an emergency in the state yesterday as a result of heavy snows. He appealed for more Federal helicopters and snow-removal equipment to aid beleaguered upstate areas.
The General Electric Company had record sales and earnings last year, Ralph J. Cordiner, president, announced yesterday.

It is reported that more than 13,000 books were published in this broad land last year, more by 5 per cent than in 1956. No one need run out of reading matter in the midst of this liberal provision and the choice should be wide enough to suit the most fastidious taste, but obviously no one can read more than a small fraction of this annual feast in print.
Wayne P. Brobeck has been elected vice president of government contracts and nuclear activities for Ionics, Incorporated, Oambridge, Mass.
The National Broadcasting Company will initiate another group of educational television programs for noncommercial stations.
HARTFORD, Feb. 20 -- The number of unemployed in Connecticut has nearly tripled in the last year.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20 -- The Yale University Art Gallery has acquired works of art by Pablo Picasso, Sir Jacob Epstein and David Smith.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Gov. Foster Furcolo of Massachusetts was taken to Garfield Hospital this morning for observation and treatment of "an upper respiratory infection."
The Pennsylvania Railroad remained crippled yesterday, but the line promised that its drastically curtailed service would be restored by next Monday.
PARIS, Feb. 20 -- Proposals to counter the British-sponsored free trade zone for Western Europe were drawn up here today by Cabinet Ministers meeting under Premier Felix Gaillard.

The only American ocean-going vessel built from the keel up for general cargo and the roll-on, roll-off handling of military vehicles arrived here yesterday. She can carry one-sixth the mobile equipment of an armored division.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill designed to help small subsidized airlines obtain new planes and other equipment.

In your issue of Feb. 12 you report the publication in Moscow of "two sharply worded letters from President Roosevelt to Premier Stalin, written in 1945 but still classified as secret in the United States."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -- Hollywood musicians at major studios today obeyed a work-stoppage order from the American Federation of Musicians.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- The Security Council will meet at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon to hear charges by the Sudan that Egypt was threatening her northern frontier.
Six West German clothing manufacturers studying American production methods and styles visited the plant of D'Andrea Brothers, Inc., here yesterday,
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee voted on party lines today to set up an advisory commission on Presidential inability.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- William F. Knowland, Senate Republican leader, denied today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon went to California last week to halt backbiting among state Republicans.
A 14-year-old juvenile delinquent testified yesterday that the Egyptian Kings gang had not only senior and junior divisions but also one for boys 12 years old. It was known as the Egyptian King Tots.

AT first glance the National League's Green Book looks as handsome as it always does. Perhaps the latest volume of press information is a mite more pretentious than is its wont, because the insignia of the Baseball Writers Association is on the cover in a salute to the press-box tenants and their golden anniversary as an organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold expressed today the belief that the good offices of the United States and Britain might lead to at least a partial solution of the issues between France and Tunisia.

A political science class from Hiram College in Ohio has been meeting this week at the United Nations. In keeping with the college's belief in concentrated study and field trips, the students are examining the actual workings of the international organization.

"POINT OF NO RETURN," a television adaptation of Paul Osborn's play derived from the John P. Marquand novel, was a thoroughly plodding drama last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2. Only in the waning moments did it rise to any compelling distinction.
One of the busiest week-ends in years loomed for skiers, innkeepers and area operators yesterday as metropolitan New York's snow enthusiasts prepared to invade the north country.

The special Kings County grand jury investigating violence in the public schools bitterly criticized Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday for having the "temerity to insinuate that we were acting illegally."

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Selling pressure sat fairly heavy on grain futures trading today and most prices on the Board of Trade drifted lower, but wheat finally cracked through to the plus side shortly before the finish.

A plot of land 200 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Crosby Avenue and Roberts Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Leo Silver, builder and realty operator. It will be improved with a one-story building to be occupied as a supermarket by a national chain-store organization.
SEATTLE, Feb. 20 -- Dave Beck Sr., wealthy and once-powerful labor leader, was told today he must go to prison for up to fifteen years for stealing $1,900 from the International Teamsters Union.

It's a cold winter in Detroit. Ward's Automotive Reports, trade publication, indicates that consumers are staying out of showrooms in droves. By the end of the month, it says, "the new car stockpile will be pushing toward the 900,000 unit level * * * the highest point ever reached."
The paper industry has begun to work its way out of problems caused by excess capacity, but it may take two or three years to bring demand into line with capacity, David L. Luke said yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 20 -- Two Princeton University professors and the editor of the campus newspaper urged today that the university act on reported religious discrimination in membership elections to student social clubs.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 20 (UP) -- General Manager Howard S. Pierce called off tomorrow's program at Bowie but ground crews late today cleared most of the running strip at the snowbound track in hopes that racing could be resumed Saturday.
The state obtained a court order yesterday permanently barring the Nassau Management Company from dealing in real estate shares or other securities in this state.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Ilse Konrads, a 13year-old Latvian refugee, smashed two world records tonight while winning the women's 880-yard free-style in 10 minutes 16.2 seconds in the Australian swimming championships.

The city's right to condemn thirteen blocks in the Lincoln Square area and resell sites to private and institutional developers, including Fordham University, was upheld unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the 1957 calf crop was 41,007,000 head, a decline of 2 per cent from 1956.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
TRENTON, Feb. 20 -- The State Legislature will convene in extraordinary closed session March 3 to discuss New Jersey's fiscal situation with state officials.

Federal Judge John M. Cashin refused yesterday to dismiss a wiretap conspiracy indictment against James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. He also declined to postpone trial for six months or transfer it to Michigan.

There is much discussion in and out of Cuba of the Presidential and Congressional elections that are supposed to be held on June 1. Considering the state of ferment in Cuba, the rebellion that covers the whole eastern third of the island, the incessant bombings, hangings, arrests and sabotage, and the protests of groups of all kinds against the elections and the Government, it is hard to see how valid elections can be held.
Two bullish news items came to nothing in yesterday's stock market. Prices opened an eyelash higher and declined thenceforward with some persistence.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Most of the picturesque characters who make stock automobile racing such a thrilling sport are in town today. They are here for the big three national championship events of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing that brings down the curtain on the annual speed carnival here.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 -- The Soviet Government called tonight for "a conference of the nations concerned" to discuss the Korean problem.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Feb. 20 -- A search for the mising warhead of a Falcon air-to-air guided missile was caled off tonight until tomorrow. The warhead has been missing since yesterday morning when the F-102 jet plane on which it was mounted exploded in an alert hangar at the Suffolk County Air Force Base here.
Delaware borrowed $21,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of schools, highways and other public improvements.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 20 -- President Eisenhower told eleven Democratic Governors today that there was no danger of a "deep and protracted economic decline" unless the people's "tough-minded confidence" was impaired.

A comparative study of maternity cases in this city has shown that women who received maternity care under the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York had a lower infant morality rate than private patients generally in this city.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 20 -- President Sukarno and former Vice President Hatta conferred for two hours today.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 20 -- Syria was living out her last day as an independent state today. Tomorrow by plebiscite she will become a province of the United Arab Republic formed by her union with Egypt.

Cocoa futures dipped yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, in what was termed a technical reaction to recent strength. Prices declined 10 to 31 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 763 lots. The volume was the fifth largest of the year.

IN ALGERIA, Near the Tunisian Frontier, Feb. 20 -- French artillery fired sixteen rounds into pitch blackness early today at a signal from a series of peaks and valleys that dissolved on the normally horizontal green line of an American-made radarscope.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 -- Mikhail G. Pervukhin, Soviet foreign aid chief, has been appointed Ambassador to East Germany.
Airman Donald G. Farrell of the Bronx, who lived in a sealed chamber to test the effect of space flight on humans, arrived here early this morning for two weeks of public appearances.

Contracts were signed yesterday by Tony Richardson to stage the musical transformation of the Somerset Maugham novel, "Of Human Bondage." Mr. Richardson is the young British director of two current Broadway plays, "The Entertainer" and "Look Back in Anger."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that a St. Louis diemaker had been legally expelled from his union on the ground that he had advocated, encouraged and supported communism.
With warmer weather, easier footing has been forecast for marchers in parades honoring George Washington's birthday tomorrow.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Eddie Arcaro scored the 4,000th victory of his long riding career today.
Two hundred farm animals checked into the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at 3:30 A. M. yesterday and spent the day in the Astor Gallery there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The House Appropriations Committee refused today to grant an additional $2,054,000 for expenses of the United States exhibit at the Brussels World's Fair. It acted afer a subcommittee had heard testimony that the Soviet Union's building would be far less expensive than was first supposed.

The Pacific Uranium Mines Company announced yesterday the completion of a $32,100,000 financing program to construct the Kermac Nuclear Fuels Corporation uranium mill and mines in the Anbrosia Lake area of New Mexico.
George Champion, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, criticized yesterday the Federal Reserve Board's 1/2 percentage point reduction in member bank reserve requirements.
Brown Bolte will become president of Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles, Inc. He is now an executive vice president and chairman of the plans board at Benton Bowles, Inc.
A couple of court-wise, competition-hardened teams from the Midwest gave two New York fives a basketball lesson at Madison Square Garden last night.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union is producing an estimated total of 17,000,000 ounces of gold a year -- almost 60 per cent of the output of the rest of the world, it was reported today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -- The National Broadcasting Company began regular color tape telecasts on the West Coast last night with the "Kraft Theatre" production of "Material Witness."

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The British Government's determination to approach summit talks with the Soviet Union only through consultation with members of the Atlantic alliance was endorsed in the House of Commons tonight by a majority of 66.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 20 -- A proposal by Westchester County to buy the John Jay mansion in Bedford as a memorial to the nation's first Chief Justice was blocked temporarily by a Democratic Supervisor today. He pleaded for economy in the current economic recession.
OPENING one's home and heart to a child who eventually, will be returned to his own parents requires, at the very least, a certain hardiness of spirit.

Directors of the Underwood Corporation, business machines manufacturer, voted yesterday to omit the first-quarter dividend on the common stock. Shareholders had received 10 cents in previous quarters.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The Ministry of Defense and the Army announced today details of their plans for cutting expenses and streamlining the military forces in the next year.
Harry Lanza, 48-year-old brother of Joseph (Socks) Lanza, the convicted extortionist, was sentenced yesterday to ten years in jail for contempt of the Legislature.
MIAMI, Feb. 20 -- A lot of the fun went out of Saturday's $100,000 added Widener Handicap when Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons said this afternoon that Bold Ruler wouldn't be a starter.

ATLANTA, Feb. 20 (AP) -- David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, urged today that a Federal Bureau of Economic Intelligence be created to clarify "the legal rules of the game in business."
ROME, Feb. 20 -- The announcement that Gamal Abdel Nasser, President of Egypt, would visit Rome caused a mixed reaction in Italy today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 20 (AP) -- A fourth accused Ku Klux Klausman was convicted today of taking part in the mutilation of a Negro handyman. He was sentenced to twenty years in prison.

Loans to business by the seventeen larger New York City banks rose $152,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase compared with one of $67,000,000 in the corresponding week a year ago.
HAVANA, Feb. 20 -- Property damage and loss of life mounted in Cuba today as youthful revolutionists continued their sabotage and terrorist activities throughout all the provinces.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- In some respects the mounting appeal to Harry F. Byrd to reconsider his decision to leave the Senate is unique in recent times.
The resignations of two members and an aide of the strife-torn New York City Housing Authority were announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
NORTHFIELD, Vt., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Middlebury's ski team held a substantial lead over five rivals in Norwich University's winter carnival tonight following victories in the slalom and cross-country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Two Florida friends of Richard A. Mack testified today that they had talked futilely with him to influence his vote on the award of television Channel 10 in Miami.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 21 (Reuters) -- Hungarian Communist leaders have started a move to bring back exiled supporters of Matyas Rakosi, former party chief of Hungary.
MOSCOW, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said in a speech made public today that the Soviet Union "stands firmly" on its desires for "peaceful coexistence."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Democratic National Committee unanimously adopted today a resolution attacking President Eisenhower for his "Hoover-like approach" to "the depression now gripping the country."

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, sees some good in a Polish plan for a zone in central Europe from which nuclear weapons would be barred but not enough to make it acceptable to the West.
J. Kenneth McCabe, acting District Attorney of Kings County, yesterday defended an assistant who stalked out of a courtroom Thursday after a clash with a judge.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 21 -- As Casey Stengel, embarking on his tenth season as manager of the Yankees, marshaled his Bombers tonight on the eve of another spring training campaign, there was a break in the club's solid holdout front.
Morning rush-hour service on the IRT subway was disrupted widely yesterday when the Clark Street tunnel under the East River was blocked off by a stalled train.

The continued pressure of new investment supply in the bond market is bringing about some heaviness in the values of long-term obligations, despite the continuance of general economic conditions favoring fixed-income investments.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 21 -- The publisher of the Juedische Allgemeine Wochenzeitung of Duesseldorf, organ of the Jewish community in West Germany, warned today of the growing danger of a revival of anti-Semitism in Germany.
Barry MacKay was the victim of one of the most stunning reversals in years in the national indoor tennis championships last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- An Army court-martial convicted M/Sgt. Roy A. Rhodes today of having conspired to spy for the Soviet Union and sentenced him to five years' imprisonment at hard labor.

The St. Joseph Lead Company, the nation's largest lead producer and a major miner and smelter of zinc, plans to curtail output of both metals sharply. A spokesman dis closed yesterday that it expected to adjust operations at its lead mines in southeastern Missouri so as to reduce production some 6,000 tons over a one-to-three-month period beginning in March.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today the Republican unemployment insurance bill, providing for a 25 per cent increase in maximum weekly benefits and an upward revision of payroll taxes.
ELEANORA GARNETT, the designer, could fly from here to Rome in one of her own balloon-topped dresses.

In your Feb. 18 editorial on "Jordan's Refugees" you advocate resettlement of "hundreds of thousands" of these refugees in Iraq -- a solution which is impossible on both practical and ethical grounds.

TUNIS, Feb. 21 -- Developments at Remada, 300 miles south of here in the Tunisian Sahara, continued to disturb the Tunisian scene today. The Government charged tonight that French forces had encircled the village and had established a roadblock manned by 400 soldiers with armored vehicles on the main road north to the village.

Waco, Tex., has borrowed $5,250,000 on two issues of bonds. The city sold $3,650,000 of general obligations, due from 1960 to 1983 and callable after fifteen years, to Mercantile Trust Company of St. Louis and associates at an interest cost of 3.2205 per cent.
A Teletype system to transmit airline tickets to business offices will be put into effect by American Airlines on April 1.

Hallmark Estate, Inc., bought the fifteen - story apartment building for forty-seven families at 47 Plaza Street, corner of Union Street, Brooklyn, for investment. The property is 157 by 135 feet and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $350,000.
Funeral services were held yesterday for four men killed last Friday in the collapse of a burning downtown factory building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, announced today that support prices for 1958 crops of such livestock feed grains as oats, barley, sorghum grain and rye would be maintained close to last year's levels.
ATLANTA, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Much juvenile crime is an illness and should be treated as such, a New Jersey judge said today.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 21 -- The Moroccan Government expelled the Spanish Vice Consul at Agadir today as tension increased over the latest Spanish military drive to regain control of the Ifni enclave.
Twelve persons, including an undisclosed number who were employed by the City Housing Authority, have been subpoenaed to appear next Thursday before the House Committee on un-American Activities.

MIAMI, Feb. 21 -- Hialeah Race Course will run its big handicap on the morrow. It's the $130.000 Widener, at a mile and a quarter, and the winner's paycheck for the two-minute chore will be $92,800 if all ten of today's entrants stay in the line-up.
Fresh and canned fish for the city's restaurants and households are in short supply, John Von Glahn of the Fishery Council said yesterday. He said he expected the situation to improve by next Monday.
The United States gets $3 in measurable benefits for every dollar spent in improving the inland waterway system.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Feb. 21 -- The ceremony of installing R. A. Butler, Home Secretary and Lord Privy Seal, as Rector of Glasgow University today turned into chaos.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Two prominent atomic manufacturers said today the Administration program for development of atomic power was not adequate to maintain world leadership in nuclear technology.
State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday he believed that George Washington, if he were alive today, would be a supporter of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the United Nations.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan expressed tonight a continuing interest by Britain in a heads-of-government meeting.
At next November's election every polling place in the solidly Republican up-state counties will have a trained Democratic watcher for the first time.
SEAFORD, L. I., Feb. 21 -- The mysterious force that has caused strange happenings at the home of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Herrmann has won a temporary victory.
Many dinner parties were given last night in connection with the Mi-Careme Ball at the Ambassador.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Banjo Matthews, an apple-cheeked, bespectacled young man from Asheville, N. C., won the annual championship race for sportsman and modified stock cars before a crowd of 10,000 today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers and Supervisor Burton W. Chace as president of the Coliseum Commission today officially signed the contract permitting the baseball club to use Memorial Coliseum as its home stadium during 1958 and 1959.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today a bill providing for the reorganization of the probation services in Suffolk County. His objection was based on a provision that would have allowed county judges to appoint a director of probation without respect to Civil Service standards.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 21 -- President Eisenhower took advantage of the best weather of his Southern holiday today to bag some quail during a morning in the fields.
BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- Top functionaries of the Communist-dominated labor Federation of East Germany are meeting in East Berlin to consider ways of raising the productivity of industrial workers.

The state charged yesterday that hundreds of housewives in the metropolitan area recently had bought merchandise sold under false pretenses by salesmen posing as representatives of New York newspapers.

THE perfect cup of coffee, much sought after to awaken one in the morning and stimulate lagging spirits in mid-afternoon, was discussed here recently. It was suggested that, for a satisfactory brew, the water should be at the boiling point when it first comes into contact with the coffee grains.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Johnny Antonelli considered the key to whatever success the Giants hope to have in their first pennant race in San Francisco, agreed to terms today -- for an estimated $25,000 per year.

Soltzer-Lampert, realty operators, bought and immediately resold the seven-story apartment house for twenty-six families at 929 West End Avenue, near 106th Street. Menken-Schwebel Associates, brokers, negotiated the deal.
ROQUEBRUNE-CAP-MARTIN, France, Feb. 21 -- Sir Winston Churchill appeared today to be recovering well from the pneumonia and pleurisy that struck him four days ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Average wholesale prides in primary markets increased 0.3 per cent to 119.1 per cent of the 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Despite a ban by Cuba, Meyer Lansky said yesterday he hoped to return to his gambling interests there.
The financial district was somewhat surprised that the Treasury did not accept the invitation of the present strong market for short-term securities.

COLE PORTER and S. J. Perelman should send out for the genie. Their attempts last night to make a musical out of "Aladdin," the imperishable "Arabian Nights" story of the boy with the magic lamp, ran headlong into sustained disaster.

SURACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Representative John E. Moss struck out today at what he termed "off-the-record censorship" of missile firings at Cape Canaveral, Fla. Mr. Moss is chairman of the House Government Information subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Air Force has sharply criticized Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, for giving the Army the responsibility to develop a weapon against enemy ballistic missiles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Radio Corporation of America was indicted today on charges of multipule violations of the antitrust laws.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Tariff protectionists, despite an apparent setback, pressed with new vigor today a drive to curb the President's tariff-making powers.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 21 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, here to open Puerto Rico's Red Cross campaign, called today for "a broadening vision" by Americans to meet the challenges and responsibilities the United States faced in "uniting the free world."

A 16-year-old boy was stabbed in the back in the Bronx last night, after a brawl in a candy store, in which about ten youths took part. The wounded boy was taken to Fordham Hospital, where his condition was described as fair.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 21 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones, Republican of Bergen County, will ask the Senate on March 3 to resume the investigation of municipal garbage contracts.

The current House inquiry into the F. C. C. has now developed the totally unsurprising fact that pressures on Washington officials came from both sides in the bitter contest over allocation of a lucrative Miami television channel.

Ever since you started it I have wanted to tell you how interesting I have found reading the personal vignette you have seen fit to print about the leading figure in the news of the day. The press of daily chores kept me from the typewriter, however.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Jack George scored 26 points tonight in leading the Philadelphia Warriors to a 117-111 victory over New York in an overtime game before 3,814 fans. The victory put the Warriors three and one-half games ahead of the Knicks in their race for third place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 21 -- The Syrian people trooped to the polls in peace and order today to vote the country out of existence and into the United Arab Republic.
The Pennsylvania Railroad said its service was in "pretty good shape" yesterday after five days of breakdowns in locomotives and schedules.
Directors of the Detroit Steel Corporation yesterday cut the common dividend to 12 1/2 cents a share, payable March 20, from 25 cents paid in previous quarters.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- France said today that she was preparing to concentrate most of her forces now in Tunisia in the region of the Bizerte naval base once Tunisia renounced her harassing tactics.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 21 -- President Sukarno branded the rebels' activities unlawful today. He charged unnamed foreign powers with seeking to exploit the crisis within the framework of the "cold war."
WASHINGTON Feb. 21 -- The Pullman Company proposes to increase its charges for "seatnig accommodations" in sleeping cars on Eastern railroads effective April 1.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Joseph W. Appleman resigned today as superintendent of Missouri's intermediate reformatory. He acted after investigators reported they had found disgraceful conditions and poor administration there.
TOKYO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Communist North Korea said today that the crew and passengers of a captured airliner would be released if President Syngman Rhee of South Korea would negotiate.
The Federal Government last night rejected Governor Harriman's appeal for aid in fighting the snowstorm that hit the state last week-end.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Two persons were killed and two were wounded by Algerians here last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Alleghany Corporation asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to issue $15,000,000 in promissory notes to help refinance a bank loan of $17,000,000.
"The Awakening," an Italian-made drama with English titles starring Anna Magnani, will have its American premiere at the Little Carnegie Theatre next Friday.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) -- William Norvell, 56-year-old golfer from Chattanooga, today upset George Toms of Durham, N. C., the defender and medalist in the tournament of golf club champions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- New claims for unemployment insurance benefits last week continued a downward trend, the Labor Department's Bureau of Employment Security reported today.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 21 -- Indonesian military forces made their first attack today against rebellious Central Sumatra.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Grain traders maintained a steady but moderate demand for wheat futures on the Board of Trade today and carried all contracts through with gains, despite profit-taking and hedging along the way.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 21 (UP) -- A judge cracked down on six Ku Klux Klansmen with fines and felony charges today after a police undercover agent planted among them told of a plot to dynamite a Negro school.
Trading volume in potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange this week was the highest ever recorded.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 21 -- Diplomatic representatives of the North Atlantic treaty countries boycotted the ceremonious arrival in Bucharest this afternoon of Janos Kadar, Hungary's Communist party chief.

The first of a group of three polished songs by Darius Milhaud, French composer, proved to be so beautiful that it drew a gasp of delight and astonishment from the audience at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The murmurs of appreciation lasted nearly as long as the song -- that is to say, roughly one minute.

Returning from a forty-day tour abroad, President Sukarno of Indonesia has assumed again the powers of his office under the shadow of a latent civil war between his own Government in Jakarta and the anti-Communist rebel regime set up in Sumatra.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Were Hamlet to wander along the Seine these days he might regard the turbulent sky above the National Assembly and inquire of Polonius: "Do you see yonder cloud that's almost in shape of a camel?" And this is a cloud no longer the size of a man's hand, no little cloud.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- A program of decentralization, diversification and rigid control of costs for Armour Co. was outlined today by William Wood Prince, president, at the annual stockholders meeting in the company's general offices here.
A major shake-up has taken place in the national leadership of the Communist party in this country.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Louisiana slashed its oil production allowable for March today to 755,715 barrels a day, 48,140 barrels below this month's level of 803,855.
A three-way opportunity for new manufacturing plants is being offered in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Robert P. Post, the city's Industrial Commissioner, reported this week.

OSLO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The crack Whitby, Ont., team, which will represent Canada in next week's world amateur ice hockey championships here, trounced the United States, 9 -- 2, today in a wild game marked by a free-for-all and the arrest of one spectator.
MOUNT VERNON, Va., Feb. 21 -- The home of George Washington, on this eve of his birthday, is beset by the mystery of the missing sketch, "Destruction of Bastille."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The largest vessel ever to visit this area, the Navy tanker Mission Buenaventura, is inching her way up the Potomac River against the worst ice conditions within recent memory. The ship is bringing some 50,000 barrels of urgently needed fuel oil.
ATLANTA, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Edgar N. Eisenhower said today that he believed his brother, President Eisenhower, had received some poor legal advice when he ordered Federal troops to Little Rock.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 21 -- Mayor Charles S. Witkowski ended unity talks today with Hudson County Democrats, charging that the political retirement of John V. Kenny was a "gigantic hoax."
Airman Donald G. Farrell said yesterday that the next experiment in space medicine would be a two-man simulated flight to the moon.
NEW YORK STATE'S first supervisor of bingo is a Brooklyn lawyer, a civic figure, a Boy Scout leader, an ardent golfer and a man who has played very little bingo.

Alex Miteff of Argentina gained a decision over Nino Valdes, a Cuban heavyweight, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The fight, one of the bloodiest seen at the Garden in years, was decided by a majority vote.

James S. Rockefeller, president of the First National City Bank of New York, said yesterday the bank would oppose a hearing examiner's second recommendation that the Federal Reserve Board reject its application to form a new holding company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers today approved a proposed merger of two glass companies at Pittsburgh, Pa., and Kingsport, Tenn., for the asserted purpose of setting up new competition in the flat glass manufacturing field.

President Eisenhower took a useful initiative in his recent letter to Soviet Premier Bulganin when he raised the question of reciprocal visits to each country by influential figures in both. Obviously it is not the expectation that a visit of, say, Mr. Khrushchev to this country or of, say, Vice President Nixon to the Soviet Union would change the political orientation of either.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter denied yesterday a petition by the 935 Park Avenue Realties, Inc., to void amendments to the rent and eviction regulations of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission dealing with cooperative apartments.

For most practical purposes, Wall Street might well have taken a holiday yesterday instead of today. Many traders were absent in a premature celebration of Washington's Birthday. Activity was just about the dullest of the year.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 21 -- Forty Egyptians were removed from a barge in the Nile River last night while they were trying to land in a disputed area on the Sudanese-Egyptian border.

The New York State Assembly, without debate and without dissenting vote, has refused to permit a reduction in the local real estate tax relief that veterans have enjoyed in New York State for nearly sixty years, or longer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The manager of a Miami supermarket has applied the cornfield scarecrow principle indoors to deter shoplifting. The observation tower for which he received a patent this week may or may not contain a watchman, but a pilferer assumes it does.

GOTHENBURG, Sweden, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Ingemar Johansson, Sweden's undefeated European heavyweight champion, blasted Joe Erskine's dream of a shot at the world title tonight by pounding the British Empire champion so relentlessly he quit in his corner after the thirteenth round.
WARSAW, Feb. 21 -- Poland and Yugoslavia signed today an economic cooperation agreement that pointedly underlined the special political sympathies between their governments.
A juvenile delinquent testified yesterday how he and two defendants on trial for murder had bragged about how they assaulted 15-year-old Michael Farmer last July 30 in High Bridge Park.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Government today moved to reopen the employe bargaining rights situation at the Sears, Roebuck Co. retail store at Boston.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Attorneys for Arthur Miller, playwright, contended today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities had used his romance with Marilyn Monroe to seek publicity for itself.
Leonard Bernstein has agreed to compose two songs for Christopher Fry's "The Firstborn," in which Katharine Cornell and Anthony Quayle will be starred.

Under ordinary circumstances one birthday in every twelve months has been found sufficient by most people. It is true that before the age of 12 or 15 there may be times when an extra birthday would be a welcome asset, but later on the charm of having even one birthday a year fades.

The Radio Corporation of America asserted yesterday that it had "licensed all comers under all patents" to promote competition. The statement was in response to the company's indictment on charges of antitrust violations.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 19 -- In the hope of establishing a new relationship with the Arabs living on her borders and with her own Arab citizens, Israel has opened an all-Arabic broadcasting service.

Four Puerto Ricans -- the industrialist Ferre brothers -- have given the University of Miami $200,000 for a new graduate school building. Luis Ferre explains they have business in Miami and want to show that Puerto Ricans aren't just one-way folk -- they will aid the mainland whenever they can.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Harold A. Keats, executive director of a fund-raising group under investigation by the House Veterans Affairs Committee, denounced today what he said were lies circulated about his group.
Two brothers were arrested yesterday on charges of assaulting an assistant principal who cried to break up a fight near his school.

Rabbi Solomon J. Sharfman, president of the Rabbinical Council of America, criticized Mayor Wagner yesterday for what the clergyman said was the Mayor's failure "to keep the unequivocal pledge" to aid Jewish merchants to conduct business on Sunday.

A BRIGHT brush war between California and Connecticut blazes in Stephen Birmingham's "Young Mr. Keefe."* The unpardonable heresy of disdaining glorious San Francisco is uttered from time to time. And the contumely, mind you, is stated by fugitives who have escaped bondage in the ancestral mansions of Connecticut's most affluent hillbilly set.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Navy's John Griffiths staged a major upset today as the national singles squash racquets championship began.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Development of the Lower Mekong River Basin in Southeast Asia should await further investigation and the collection of indispensable technical information, the Technical Assistance Administration of the United Nations has been told.
MANILA, Feb. 21 -- The Philippines' avowed policy of neutrality toward the Indonesian crisis is under strain. But President Carlos P. Garcia and the Foreign Office are adhering to it firmly.
DETROIT, Feb. 21 -- The Ford Motor Company said today that 14,000 workers at its Rouge plant in Dearborn would be laid off all next week.

A Government scientist testified yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn that examinations had shown employes of DDT manufacturing plants suffered no ill effects after having absorbed large amounts of the chemical.
PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Feb. 7 -- A mass resettlement program aimed at improving living conditions for approximately 100,000 farmers in Vietnam passed the half-way mark this month. It began last May.
THERE is something pathetic about a musical show that is hopeless. Specifically, about "Portofino," which opened at the Adelphi last evening.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Government declined to intervene today in a strike scheduled to begin tomorrow by pilots on Western Air Lines.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A political dispute is delaying an inquiry by the Senate rackets committee into the United Automobile Workers and the four-year-old Kohler Company strike.
Old March cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined yesterday 2 points (10 cents a bale), but other months advanced 9 to 27 points.

HALIFAX, N. S., Feb. 21 (AP) -- The search for a missing United States Navy plane with twenty-two men aboard was intensified today after lights were reported sighted in the Atlantic near where the plane disappeared.

CAIRO, Feb. 21 -- First returns from the plebiscite held today in Egypt and Syria showed nearly unanimous approval for the union of the two countries into the United Arab Republic. The first Egyptian place to report, Malawi Province in the south, said not a negative ballot had been found in the 10,979 cast there.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- A Westchester Republican proposed today that the Legislature authorize strict controls over ballroom dancing studios for adults.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- The Security Council temporarily shelved today discussion of the border issue between Egypt and the Sudan after both nations had promised to negotiate the issue directly.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Racquets and court tennis champions survived the opening day of the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis and racquets tournaments at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club today.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 -- The nation's largest bank went to the aid today of Los Angeles' faltering $40,000,000 transit bond issue.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Mexico yesterday signed a $28,600,000 loan contract with the United States Export-Import Bank for the purchase of railroad equipment for the National Railways of Mexico.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Secretary of State Dulles bade Godspeed today to Howard P. Jones, new United States Ambassador to Indonesia, with the warning that he was taking on a "tough" job.

Insurance premiums and annuity payments to the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States topped $1,000,000,000 for the first time in the company's ninety-eight-year history, James F. Oates Jr., president, has reported.
Net income of the United States Gypsum Company in 1957 declined to $38,756,752 from $40,613,651 in 1956, the building materials producer has reported.

Events today: Verdi's "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Bizet's "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York Philharmonic, Claudette Sorel, pianist, Franco Autori conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont., Feb. 21 (Canadian Press) -- The St. Mary's River will open for navigation three weeks later than usual this year, mainly because of the business slowdown, Commander E. J. Bodenlos of the United States Coast Guard station at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., said today.
BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- Mold that grows on bread has yielded an extract that can hunt and destroy blood clots anywhere in the human body within minutes, the Massachusetts Heart Association said today.

GENEVA, Feb. 21 (Reuters) -- A meeting called by the International Civil Aviation Organization today stressed the need for controlling civil and military operations at high altitudes because of the "shortage" of space.
The Christian churches entered the penetential season of Lent this week with special tasks and services.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Robert Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, took off for London, Paris and Tunis today with the assignment of persuading France and Tunisia to compose their dispute.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 -- A search of much more immediate importance than the one for playing talent got under way early today, the opening of "winter" practice for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- More than a week of debate on constitutional reform ended tonight with the Deputies no closer to agreement on ways of enhancing Government stability.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 21 -- The Indonesian central Government served notice on domestic and foreign correspondents today that it felt "entitled to restrict the dissemination of news" concerning rebel leaders in Central Sumatra.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- State and county officials and roadbuilders opposed today any "slowdown" of the $37,000,000,000 national program of highway construction.
The winter track and field campaign will reach its peak tonight in the seventieth annual American indoor championships off the Amateur Athletic Union.
ROME, Feb. 21 -- Negotiations for settlement of claims arising from the nationalization of the Suez Canal by Egypt were suspended here today. They may be resumed later in Cairo.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- The Government closed down today the strike-ridden Opera and Opera-Comique and discharged a considerable part of their personnel.

Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company have announced the election of Walter W. Kremer as vice president-traffic. He succeeds Paul H. Draver, who was elected to the new post of vice president-industrial development.
DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today motor vehicle output would drop this week to the lowest level so far this year.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 22 -- President Eisenhower will return to Washington tomorrow on a circuitous 3,600-mile route by way of Phoenix, Ariz.

THIS mild little book of childhood reminiscences centers around the English governess to a Russian family -- the indomitable Miss Williams. While his first novel undeniably reflects its author's folksy good nature, Mr. Reiner's initial venture into a new medium is something less than an undiluted success.

THE recommended order in which to read these books -- and both are emphatically recommended -- is to start with "Five Down and Glory." Bennington College in Vermont has decided to do something about the perennial problem of rising costs and the gap between costs and tuition. The decision is to reduce the gap by increasing the tuition and at the same time help the student to meet the increase.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 22 -- Syria's union with Egypt was consecrated today by a virtually unanimous Syrian vote.
