IN a few weeks, the winner of the United States Chess Championship, the United States Open Chess Tournament, the United States Junior Championship and several other assorted baubles will go to the hospital and have his adenoids out, thus missing a few days at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn, where he is a sophomore.

RED BLUFF, Calif., Feb. 22 (UP) -- Three Army helicopters of a formation of seven flew into the side of a low ridge fifteen miles north of here today during a rainstorm. Six crewmen were reported killed.

The St. John's University basketball team subdued the Fordham quintet at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory last night. With Alan Seiden setting the scoring pace with 30 points, the Redmen tacked up an 82-to-74 triumph.

MOST of the major garden displays for the forty-first International Flower Show are designed to help amateur gardeners with landscaping and cultural problems. The show will be staged from March 9 to 15 at the New York Coliseum.
THERE was a time in the recent past when a well-puffed souffle was the hallmark of a good cook, an achievement that served to separate the skilled chefs from the amateurs at the range.
The American business executive is said to be the travelingest man in the world.

HAVING youthfully transcended the hurdle of retirement at three score years and ten, Albert Guerard, has brought together here from the periodicals in which they first appeared, some fifteen essays, urbane, witty, pithy and often profound under the guise of casualness.
New York University, in conjunction with the University of Madrid, has created a Junior Year in Spain program for students in all United States colleges and universities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges served notice today he would fight to end what he called the "travesty'' of economic aid to Communist Poland.
Chinatown celebrated the start of the Year of the Dog yesterday.

The Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, has announced that competition will open May 1 and close Nov. 1 for 165 scholarships in thirteen countries. The scholarships will be for 1959-60. A similar competition for this year closed in January.

Within a month two new, rival political entitles have appeared in the Middle East -- the United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria and the Arab Federation of Iraq and Jordan. SPRING - HUNGRY New Yorkers can attend the first major spring show of the season -- the twelfth annual Long Island Garden Show -- which opened at noon yesterday at the Island Garden Arena, West Hempstead, L. I.

THE broadcasters have not covered themselves with glory in their all-out assault on pay-as-you-see television. In the last few weeks their screams of apprehension have done more to make the public aware of toll TV than even the system's promoters have managed to accomplish. By their frantic determination to make certain that subscription TV is stillborn the broadcasters may have given new impetus to the idea of a box office in the home.

And while the rest of the world had moved into the long-playing age, you had to content yourself with scratchy 78 r. p. m. disks.

Dowling.

Retail business has been betrayed by the weather. At a time when the elements could do much to help the economy out of the doldrums, nature has become extremely unfriendly. Cold, snow, and freakish storms have combined to keep shoppers away from stores. Result: dollar volume so far in February is more than 5 per cent below the 1957 level in department stores and most probably is similarly lower in other segments of retail trade.
Here is one business that can look forward confidently to a pick-up in the spring. Nurseries are not too concerned about a recession.

ROME, Feb. 23 -- Commemoration of the Iealian resistance movement in World War II against fascism and nazism was marred here today by Neo-Fascist demonstrations. The ceremonies marked the tenth anniversary of Italy's republican Constitution, which went into effect Jan. 1, 1948.
Benjamin Fine, education editor of The New York Times, has been named dean of Yeshiva University's Graduate School of Education, Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of the university, announced yesterday.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Skaters from Massachusetts today captured the top titles of the North American Invitation indoor speed skating championship.

The home of Mrs. Anthony B. Akers at 920 Fifth Avenue will be the scene Wednesday afternoon of an enlistment tea, sponsored by the Women's Special Events Committee for Just One Break, Inc. At the tea the committee will further plans for its May Festival dinner dance to be held May 12 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
As every suburban gardener is aware, there is no garden quite so fine as the one that is grown in February. The big thing is, of course, that it is quite imaginary.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- Ch. Puttencove Promise, the dog celebrity of the year through winning best in show at Westminster, added to his stature tonight with another major victory in his first time out since the Madison Square Garden event.
"WHAT'S wrong with boxing?" asked the man with the pencil. Julius Helfand, about to begin his second three-year term as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, thought about it.
New York State's mental hospital program needs wider research facilities, according to a report released yesterday by the National Committee Against Mental Illness, Inc.

When the United States exports at the rate of $21.8 billion a year and imports at the rate of $13 billion a year, as it did in 1957, the slack has to be taken up somehow. We have tried to do this by giving away money, by lending on easy terms and by investing at market rates.

Boston College, despite its "small college" listing, yesterday was named to play in the National Collegiate championship basketball tournament. The Eagles, coached by Don Martin and the holders of a 15-2 record, join Connecticut, Oklahoma State, Notre Dame, Pittsburgh, Manhattan, Temple and Idaho State in the N. C. A. A. competition.
Four films will arrive in firstrun theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- United States officials are studying the desirability of offering a counter-proposal to the Polish plan for establishing a central European zone free of nuclear weapons. The Government has made clear its disapproval of the plan, proposed by Adam Rapacki, Polish Foreign Minister.

GREENPORT, L. I., Feb. 23 -- Commercial fishing boats, tied up at their piers for the last five days because of ice, sailed again tonight from here, Montauk and other harbors on Long Island. Warmer weather for the last three days has opened channels through frozen bays to the ocean.

Governor Harriman's public hearing on the Republican unemployment insurance bill, which he has vetoed, has dramatized the tragic farce of making a political football out of an urgently needed social security measure. The battle of hyperbole between the Governor and Assembly Majority Leader Carlino had nothing to do with the main issue raised by the bill: a lift in the ceiling on unemployment benefits.
ORLEANS, France, Feb. 23 -- About 250 persons received a strong dose of anti-Government propaganda here last night and reacted strongly to it.

Ticket holders to "Winesburg, Ohio," who are entitled to refunds for performances after the closing on Feb. 15 at the National Theatre, are being paid through voluntary contributions by members of the League of New York Theatres.
IN addition to heaven's protection, the working girl, when pregnant, can count increasingly on the support of both her employer and obstetrician in continuing on the job.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation soon may produce color television sets in quantity and promote them aggressively. For more than a year the Radio Corporation of America has been virtually alone in its efforts to put color television across.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 23 -- A proposal has been made to use New York State income tax moneys from New Jersey residents to support a Metropolitan Rapid Transit District.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 23 -President and Mrs. Eisenhower arrived here this afternoon after a seven-hour flight from Moultrie, Ga. They were greeted by 25,000 cheering Arizonans in sunny weather that prompted the President to remark, "It's a lovely day."

James F. Oates Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, has also been elected chairman. This was made known through an announcement, prepared for release today, of the retirement of Ray D. Murphy as chairman.

Is Khrushchev becoming another Stalin? That question is a natural one for anyone who has seen the picture of Mr. Khrushchev in his lieutenant general's uniform addressing the Moscow celebration of the Soviet Army's fortieth anniversary last Saturday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 23 -- South Sumatra's military commander told the Indonesian Air Force today that the dispute between the Government and rebellious Central Sumatra should be settled through negotiations, according to a radio report monitored here.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said tonight that Selwyn Lloyd was "a very good Foreign Secretary" and that he had done his work "very well."
CHALLENGES facing education were explored yesterday in a rewarding one-hour telecast over Channel 2.
FLORENCE, Italy, Feb. 23 -A Roman Catholic Bishop and one of his parish priests are to sit on the "bench of the accused" in a criminal court of this city tomorrow.

Three Brooklyn legislators who have been fighting the proposed Narrows Bridge from Brooklyn to Staten Island plan to introduce a resolution at Albany tonight, calling on Governor Harriman to suspend all work on the project until a substitute proposal can be studied.

JORDAN was in the news again two weeks ago when the precariously balanced little Arab kingdom joined with Iraq in a suddenly arranged federation. And it is likely that Jordan will provide front-page copy for some time to come -- for as long as Middle East politics remains the witches' cauldron of intrigue, conspiracy, riot, assassination and Communist subversion that it is.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 23 -- Many civilians have been evacuated from Padang in the wake of attacks by Indonesian Air Force planes on this seat of the rebel government.
Automation can be a great blessing "if it is used intelligently and with social and moral responsibility," Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, said yesterday.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Roger M. Blough, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, declared here today that the present political and tax philosophy discouraged savings and investment and was "the dangerous barrier to the formation of the capital that this nation must have for its survival."

"Going Dutch" may acquire a new meaning if a Brooklyn business man keeps on with the successful enterprise he has developed in a little more than two years. To George L. Seedman the expression already has prime new associations. Besides good business, it suggests the fun of cycling -- and on Dutch bicycles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The General Accounting Office recommended to Congress recently that banks be required to pay interest on Treasury funds deposited with them, and that the Treasury in turn pay the banks for services they now perform free. The Treasury's reaction was strong and negative.
CAIRO, Feb. 23 -- Several countries sent their ambassadors to the Foreign Ministry today to present new credentials to the United Arab Republic. But the United States was not among them.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Discipline, drabness and dedication are the three "D's" dominating the memories of my recent travels in the new China.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday called on the United States Supreme Court to reverse a ruling of the California Supreme Court in which tax exemption was denied to two churches that refused to sign a non-Communist loyalty oath.
Six years after his last full season of competition, Richard Savitt won the national indoor tennis championship yesterday.
A steering committee was appointed yesterday to survey and plan for a three-state system of parks and recreation facilities in this area.

A top official of the International Longshoremen's Association denied yesterday a report that his union had set up a joint Washington legislative committee with Harry Bridges' International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

The trustees of the S. H. Kress Foundation have refused comment on charges made Feb. 14 that certain of them were starting a proxy fight for control of S. H. Kress Co., the variety store chain. Rush H. Kress, chairman of the company and president of the foundation made the accusation.
The theatre's current season -- one of the most active in years -- began to level off somewhat over the week-end. Ten shows ended their runs on and off Broadway last night and on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Commerce Department reported today that the annual rate of the nation's output declined by $7,400,000,000 -- a little more than 1.5 per cent -in the final quarter of 1957. The largest part of that was a sharp reversal in the trend of inventories, from up to down.
The disastrous attack of French warplanes on a Tunisian village gives us a frightening preview of how a local military officer, acting on his own, might push the button to start a world war.

HENRY GHEON'S simple evocation of "The Marvelous History of Saint Bernard" was given an effective and reverential performance yesterday in the chapel of the Broadway Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.
Combating temptation is the business both of the clergy and of the laity, the Very Rev. James J. McLarney said yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Considering that The Hill School has been represented by a swimming team only since Briggs S. Cunningham, class of '26, presented a pool to the Blue and Gray in 1951, the Hillites have been doing remarkably well.

DETROIT, Feb. 23 (UP) -Dickie Moore scored his thirtyfirst goal of the season with a minute 58 seconds left to play tonight and enabled the Montreal Canadiens to gain a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- American Broadcasting Company personnel will move into the network's new technical building here next Saturday as the first phase of the new studio construction is completed.

A history of the Sudan by a Sudanese authority is planned for May publication by Robert Speller. Entitled "The Independent Sudan," the volume presents historical background on the newly independent nation, which is now under pressure from Nasser's United Arab Republic.

Sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company in 1957 were the highest in the company's history, according to the annual report issued today by Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman, and Albert K. Chapman, president.

DEER PARK, L. I., Feb. 23 -- The Fairchild Engine Division's new vest-pocket J83 turbojet engine has been selected by Canadair, Ltd., to power proto-types of its basic jet trainer, it was announced here today.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh last night urged easier access to narcotics for addicts and legalized gambling.

PETER USTINOV, the theatre's gifted man of many trades, appeared yesterday afternoon in his own drama, "Moment of Truth," which was produced in London in 1952. There was both technical skill and compassion in his portrayal of a senile marshal but his play on the immorality of war and the emptiness of fame and importance was too diffuse to be tragically gripping.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Republican majority leaders in the Legislature are expected to reach decisions this week to prune $12,000,000 to $20,000,000 from Governor Harriman's proposed record budget of $1,800,800,000.

New York City had a good year in 1957 as host to conventions and tourists. While the city has long been its own drawing card, its growth as a place to meet and spend a vacation or a week-end is not entirely an accident. The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau is dedicated to bringing such business here.
TUNIS, Feb. 23 -- Algerian nationalist insurgents appear to be moving into Tunisia in sizable numbers, according to well-informed Tunisian circles.
Dr. Juscelino Kubitschek, President of Brazil, in a message yesterday criticized nations that have established barriers against refugees "in want of shelter and protection."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -President Eisenhower is learning to his surprise and sorrow that his personal conduct is much more subject to criticism during an economic recession than it was a couple of years ago during the boom.
The Italian soprano Marcella Pobbe will make her Metropolitan Opera debut Saturday evening, March 8, as Mimi in Puccini's "La Boheme."

Columbia University scientists drifting on an Arctic ice pack have taken photographs of tracks on the ocean floor 7,000 feet below the surface and about 400 miles from the North Pole. The scientists and their colleagues at the Lamont Geological Observatory in Palisades, N. Y., are puzzled by the tracks, which are 1/4 to 1/2 inch wide and 2 to 2 1/2 inches long.

HAVING exhibited his prowess as an interpreter of concertos, Leonid Kogan, the Russian violinist, went on to establish his quality in recital at Carnegie Hall last night. He left no doubt of the exceptional subtlety and refinement of his art. If the men in the Kremlin will forgive the expression, Mr. Kogan played like an aristocrat.
A STROLL in the downtown gallery district offers varied rewards. At the Brata Gallery, 89 East Tenth Street, three young men pool talents in a group show.

SINCE various degrees of cold weather are expected for the next few weeks, women might do well to remember that a shivering rednosed female is not the most attractive sight. Following are some methods of insulation.

The current Congressional investigation of the Federal Communications Commission raises some broad and very important questions which do not appear to be receiving due public consideration.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 23 -- The board of trustees of Princeton University has approved plans for an $8,000,000 engineering quadrangle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- House investigators have turned up a case in which Government conservation payments on land formerly held by a New Mexico farmer jumped from $5,000 to $48,919 a year after he had sold it to twelve persons.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- Premier Abdullah Khalil said tonight that a Sudanese advance post had sighted a company of Egyptian troops today in a "distant part" of the border area claimed by both countries.

Claudette Sorel was the soloist on the Saturday evening program of the New York Philharmonic. The young American pianist, heard in MacDowell's D minor Concerto, was appearing with the orchestra for the first time in an evening series, though in previous years she had played at the youth concerts.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Snobirds are a unique golfing species unclassified by ornithologists. Each year in Westchester County they appear before the first robin or any other sign of spring. Two of them were in evidence at the Siwanoy Country Club today when the Snobirds' golden anniversary tournament was completed.
Argentines voted yesterday in a general election considered free of official intimidation, corruption and fraud for the first time in thirty years.

KOHLER, Wis., Feb. 23 -Herbert Vollrath Kohler, the president, chairman and major stockholder of the family -owned Kohler Company has become the symbol of embattled, old-fashioned rugged individualism to much of the business world.
A fast-acting policeman rescued a hysterical woman and a semiconscious man from a burning tenement on the lower East Side yesterday, then collapsed on the street.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 -- Steel sales last week were no lower than in the week before with most concerns. In a few instances the volume of new business was up slightly. There is some slight evidence that seasonal influences will be operating in the steel market by the end of March, or early in April.

Cotton future prices moved irregularly last week; closing mostly higher. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended down 4 to up 74 points. New crop months recorded life-of-contract highs.
The installation of an integrated traffic control and safety system will begin this morning on Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Henri Salaun of Boston successfully defended his national squash racquets singles championship today by defeating G. Diehl Mateer Jr. of Philadelphia.

It is not very well balanced. Earnest and dedicated as the other members of the group are, they often seemed to be providing only an accompaniment for Mr. Bress. Advice on transit labor problems was offered to Governor Harriman by two groups yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 23 -- This city's harbor and electric power officials have been watching New York's financial district with more than usual interest this last week, and the reason is clear: they are looking for money.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 23 -- Art Devlin, the 36-year-old Lake Placid motel owner, proved again today that he has lost little of his prowess as a flight engineer in the ski jumping sport.

A congregation composed chiefly of Christians of Scottish descent took home sprigs of heather yesterday after a special service in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church at South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.
The police yesterday searched every house on two Brooklyn blocks for a 29-year-old brideto-be who disappeared Saturday morning only hours before she was to be married.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Jill Klein of Bedford Hills, Karen McIntosh of Bedford Village and two Connecticut girls -- Carla Leet of Old Greenwich and Penny Marty of South Norwalk -- won major riding honors at the Sunnyfield Farm horse show today.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Geoffrey Atkins of New York, a former world and United States racquets champion, defeated Clarence C. Pell Jr., also of New York and the national titleholder, in the final of the Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournament today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club.

Ron Delany and Istvan Rozsavolgyi, whose second fascinating mile duel stole the show at the Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships, will vie again for the spotlight at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Unfortunately, they won't be competing directly against each other.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- Hecht-Hill-Lancaster has reactivated plans to film "The Devil's Disciple," George Bernard Shaw's comedy of the American Revolution. The project is to be undertaken in association with Kirk Douglas' independent company, Bryna Productions.

Valleys almost entirely free of snow and ice have been discovered within 300 miles of the South Pole. It is hoped that they will provide clues to Antarctica's past and to its potential for the future.

Spotting their rivals a twogoal lead in the first period, the New York Rangers just about walked over the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. With Andy Bathgate playing one of his better games, the Broadway Blues subdued the Canadian outfit, 4 to 2.
BECAUSE eyeglass frames are bigger and bolder than ever these days, the estimated 35,000,000 American women who wear glasses often have trouble in selecting the frames that suit them best.

The "Du Pont Show of the Month" series has been renewed for the 1958-59 season. A total of nine ninety-minute productions, one less than the current season, will be televised over the Columbia Broadcasting System network beginning in September.

Erwin D. Swann has joined the L. H. Hartman Company, Inc., as executive vice president and general manager. He has also entered into an agreement that will enable him to purchase an interest in the agency.
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 24 -- Dr. Sjafruddin Prawiranegara said today that the revolutionary Government he heads would control all of Sumatra within a month.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Court of Appeals was asked today to stay further progress on the Lincoln Square urban renewal project pending the determination of a pending appeal from a lower court decision. It reserved decision.

PARIS never looked younger than it did at the recent spring fashion collections. Yves St. Laurent, Christian Dior's successor, stole the show. For months before, this frail, 22-year-old designer had captured the imagination of the public and the press.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The sports aspects of professional football, baseball, basketball and ice hockey would be exempt from antitrust laws under legislation proposed today by Representative Byron G. Rogers, Democrat of Colorado.
The New York Life Insurance Company increased its net assets by $185,363,977 in 1957 to a new high of $6,424,807,259, according to the annual report released yesterday.

In an agreement signed on Washington's Birthday the United States and Britain linked their destinies even more closely in the common defense of the free world. This agreement provides for British bases for American intermediate-range missiles with nuclear warheads.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- The Soviet proposal for reunifying Germany by confederating the West and East German states is gaining acceptance among West German politicians.

One of the ablest and most likable city officials, Abraham D. Beame, New York's Budget Director, received the tribute of a luncheon in his honor yesterday. If man bites dog makes news because it is the opposite of the usual, so this tribute was somewhat unusual because of its source.
TORONTO, Feb. 24 (Canadian Press) -- A proposed fourfor-one split in common stock of Page-Hersey Tubes, Ltd. was announced today by the company's solicitors.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Republican leaders decided at a policy conference today to trim nearly $25,000,000 from Governor Harriman's proposed $1,800,800,000 budget. The savings will be used to increase state aid to education.

DETROIT, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Louis Armstrong had the crowd in the Masonic Auditorium rocking, but the local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, some disk jockeys and music critics were playing the blues.

THURMAN ANDREW WHITESIDE is a 48-year-old Miami lawyer with a reputation for shrewdness. He also has a reputation as a man who knows the right person at the right time and knows him well enough to ask a favor.
HAVANA, Tuesday, Feb. 25 -- Cuba's premier automobile race ended in tragedy yesterday fifteen minutes after its start.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 24 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America raised its sales of insurance during 1957 by 36 per cent to a record total of $11,296,000,000, Carrol M. Shanks, president, reported here today.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Equitable Securities Corporation is offering for public subscription today $29,000,000 of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of Pennsylvania Electric Company due in 1988.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Treasury bill rate took another steep dive this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,860,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was 1.202 per cent, compared with 1.731 per cent last week.
GENEVA, Feb. 24 (Reuters) -- The eighty-nation "Law of the Sea" conference opened today in landlocked Switzerland. Prince Wan, Foreign Minister of Thailand, was unanimously elected chairman.

The National Foreign Trade Council threw strong support yesterday to renewal of the reciprocal trade program which is facing heavy opposition in Congress. The council, onetime major advocate of the tariff-cutting program, had not taken an active stand on it in recent years.
The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday net income of $220,000,000 for 1957, a decline of nearly 12 per cent from the $249,503,667 cleared in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Eisenhower struck back at his critics today as "men of little faith and of little spirit."

Minnijean Brown attended school here for the first time yesterday since her expulsion a week ago from Central High School in Little Rock, Ark. She expressed the hope that her life during the coming months would be calm.

FISHING tackle manufacturers are still in a furious race to out-gimmick one another in the production of new spinning reels, and especially closed-face spinning reels. If anything, the pace has been stepped up.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 -- Arturo Frondizi seemed tonight to have made a clean sweep in both the Electoral College and popular votes in yesterday's elections.
A Government toxicologist testified yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, that two prison experiments had shown that inmates who were subjected to large doses of DDT suffered no adverse effects.
An estimate that one-tenth of "upper-class American Women" become pregnant before marriage was made public yesterday in the latest Kinsey report.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Administration is considering an attempt to break the disarmament deadlock through meetings of the United Nations Security Council and an eventual East-West heads-of-government meeting.

Directors of the Lawyers Title Insurance Corporation, Richmond, Va., have declared an extra dividend of 2 1/2 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly of 12 1/2 cents on the common stock. Both are payable March 20 to holders of record March. 6.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24 -- Most baseball players' children are miniature vagabonds.

Over-all production of goods and services in the United States -- Gross National Product -- in the fourth quarter of 1957 was at an annual rate of $432.6 billion, according to the Department of Commerce. This was a decline from the third quarter rate ($440 billion) of $7.4 billion, or a little more than 1.5 per cent.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- United State ballistic missiles capable of attacking Moscow, Leningrad and Odessa are to be deployed by the Royal Air Force in bases in eastern and northern England.
FLORENCE, Italy Feb. 24 -- The Bishop of Prato and one of his parish priests went on trial here today on charges of criminal defamation of character.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 24 -- A record $29,023,733 Hudson County budget appeared certain of adoption by the Board of Freeholders despite protests by a score of speakers at a noisy five-hour public hearing today.

Thomas (Teddy) Gleason, general organizer of the International Longshoremen's Association, proposed yesterday a ten-point program of close cooperation with Harry Bridges' International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.
DES MOINES, Feb. 24 (AP) -Approval by United States District Judge Henry Graven of a trustee's plan for liquidation of the bankrupt Automatic Washer Company of Newton, Iowa, was filed today.

A statement by a line organization official that the Fire Department was confronted with an unusually large number of retirements was characterized by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday as "ill advised" and "reckless."
The Government securities market had time over the weekend to ponder the implications of the Treasury's decision to borrow $1,250,000,000 on nineyear bonds rather than shortterm securities.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- William Arthur Bostwick, 55-year-old vice president of the First Westchester National Bank, was found dead of a gunshot wound this morning at his desk in the bank's Bronxville branch.

In 1956, when the Russians proposed a phased disengagement in Europe, Secretary Dulles considered it inadvisable to enter into negotiations because he thought that the Russians were in serious trouble and that their weakness should be allowed to develop further.
SAN FRANCISCO, always a volatile agent in American painting, has been the scene of several breathtaking shifts in esthetic viewpoint.
HOUSTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver today shot a 5-under-par 67 to win the $30,000 Houston invitation golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 281.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Feb. 24 -- North Korea called today for the withdrawal of the United Nations forces from South Korea as the first step toward unification of Korea.
DETROIT, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Each of the big three auto companies planned short work weeks at some facilities this week and Ford and Chrysler had some facilities closed for the week.

Paul Muni is to appear in the musical version of "Grand Hotel." The star, who this year is celebrating his fiftieth anniversary as a performer, will depict Kringelein, a role previously portrayed by Sam Jaffe on the stage and Lionel Barrymore on the screen.
The Chrysler Corporation has awarded a major portion of its advertising account to two agencies, the Leo Burnett Company, Inc., and Young Rubicam, Inc.
Two women who have been waging a war against gobbledygook at Columbia University achieved success yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 24 -- Mrs. Golda Meir, Israeli Foreign Minister, expressed regret here today that the new United Arab Republic and Arab Federation seemed to be maintaining their hostility toward Israel.
Events today: Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15, and Monteverdi's "The Coronation of Poppea," American Opera Company, Town Hall, 8:45.
BUDAPEST, Feb. 24 (Reuters) -- A rock 'n' roll on ice done by the Canadian world skating champions, Robert Paul and Barbara Wagner, stole the show before 8,000 Hungarians tonight.
Cotton futures advanced 3 to 16 points (15 to 80 cents a bale) yesterday in moderate business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Schenley Industries, Inc., is entering the atomic energy field. Schenley, a large producer o falcoholic beverages, ethical and proprietary pharmaceuticals, toiletries, dyes, cooperage and farm feeds has acquired a substantial stock interest in Radiation Applications, Inc., 342 Madison Avenue.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 24 -- There is no possibility of compromise with defiant Central Sumatra, according to the Chief of Staff of the Indonesian Army. The military forces and the central Government have agreed that the rebels must be punished, he said.
A crowd of 18,150 paid $54,169.37 to watch the ten-bout card of wrestling exhibitions at Madison Square Garden last night.

The election of Frank Altschul as a director of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and chairman of its finance committee was announced yesterday by John D. Rockefeller 3d, president of the center.
Five thousand dressmakers in the metropolitan area went on strike yesterday in what may be the forerunner of a general stoppage this week-end in New York's biggest industry.
A former New York City Councilman was accused yesterday in Kings County Court of taking $6,500 to get a prospective student into a New York State medical school.
A framework for major changes in traditional advertising-industry practices was presented yesterday with the publication of the long-awaited Frey Report.

BABAESKI, Turkey, Feb. 24 -- The Shell Oil Company started drilling today about six miles from this town in Turkish Thrace. The venture follows two years of surveys and represents a $2,000,000 investment.
The New York City Housing Authority will receive bids March 4 on $9,499,000 of short-term notes to finance the development of low-rent projects subsidized by the State Government.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which has been responsible for improving the entire landscape of a large section on the lower East Side, has now undertaken to do the same thing on a much larger scale in the Chelsea district.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The American diet is seriously in need of overhauling. Although we are the best fed and the most overfed nation on earth, our dietary lacks are appalling. There are vitamin deficiencies at every income level and 20 per cent of the population is overweight.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 24 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith called on this nation's European allies tonight to pool their resources and join in economic aid and technical assistance to undeveloped nations of Asia and Africa.
ATLANTA, Feb. 24 -- For the first time, President Eisenhower has nominated as a Federal judge a man found unqualified by the American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Senate Rackets committee was still bogged down tonight in a squabble over the order of witnesses for hearings on the United Auto Workers-Kohler Company strike.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Racial violence, two newspaper men said today, is an increasing problem in large cities of the North and is not peculiar to the South.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Thurman A. Whiteside testified today that he and Richard A. Mack shared an interest in a company that insured the Miami television station to which the Federal Communications Commission awarded Channel 10. Mr. Mack voted for the award as a member of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Secretary of Defense virtually ruled out today proposals for a single chief of staff for the services. Neil H. McElroy, the Secretary, said: "I don't believe that that point of view is having predominant attention."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Eisenhower and her party were vacationing at the Maine Chance resort near here as "guests of Mrs. Arden," Mrs. Maydelle Bankston, business manager at the desert retreat for women, said today.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- Robert Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State of the United States, began his mission of good offices here today in an atmosphere of skepticism about his chances of healing France's breach with Tunisia.
Mayor Wagner told a group of city employe representatives yesterday that the outlook for salary increases for city workers in the 1958-59 budget was not bright.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 24 -- Protests by Western Socialists over the trial and sentences imposed on two Yugoslavs have aroused indignation here.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -Deternination to fulfill what they believe to be China's destiny as a leading world power, if not the leading power, is the motive.that drives political chiefs and department officials-charged with modernizing that nation of 650,000,000 people.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A shortage of a liquid propellant has delayed another Vanguard satellite test vehicle launching attempt. Minor electrical difficulties also have contributed to the delay.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Former Govs. Thomas E. Dewey, Herbert H. Lehman and Charles Poletti were among fifty persons invited by Governor Harriman today to serve on a committee for celebrating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Civil Service Commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -- The holders of pay-television franchises in Los Angeles today asked the city to take them back. The ordinance authorizing the franchises has been put on a future ballot by a referendum movement backed by the South California Theatre Owners Association.
A Transit Authority employe won a $222,500 verdict yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court. He had sued the city for false arrest, assault and malicious prosecution.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 16 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian Premier, denied in an interview today that the Pathet Lao organization was or ever had been Communist.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- Fritz Selbmann, one of the leading economic officials of East Germany, is under a steady fire of public criticism. The development appears to foreshadow a sharp reduction in his prestige if not outright dismissal from the regime.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Directors of American Potash and Chemical Corporation and Lindsay Chemical Company have agreed to merge, the two companies said today.

Perhaps it was the balmy weather or simply that they had become bored with such stimulating wintertime activities as curling, dry-fly tying and marshmallow toasting. Whatever it was, sportsmen yesterday turned their thoughts to summertime and the prospect of going octopus wrestling.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The Hsinhua (New China) news agency said today the Chinese Roman Catholic Bishop of Canton and a priest had been arrested for alleged espionage activities. The report said the espionage began early in the Korean war and included accepting money from United States "imperialist agents."
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 24 -- Premier Adnan Menderes has told Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin that peaceful intentions should be confirmed by deeds rather than words.

Evidence was presented yesterday by the prosecution to support its contention that premeditation was involved in the slaying of 15-year-old Michael Farmer. Young Farmer, a polio victim, was killed on July 30 in Highbridge Park.
ROME, Feb. 24 -- The Vatican protested to the Italian Government today against press criticism of Pope Pius XII.
Net income of the Douglas Aircraft Company in the year ended Nov. 30 declined to $30,665,000 from $33,202,000 the year before, despite a rise in sales to $1,091,366,000 from $1,073,515,000.
Youthful scientists, scholars, artists and technicians at a Manhattan public school put their new knowledge of the physical world on exhibition yesterday.

The American Communist party is again firmly under the control of those who believe subservience to the Soviet Union is the first obligation of every Communist, observers close to the party reported yesterday.
Jutta Wolf, an actress, was found dead yesterday in her apartment on lower Fifth Avenue. The police listed the cause of death as an apparent overdose of sleeping tablets, pending an autopsy.

The Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, which has given guidance to young women for nearly half a century, will gain as a result of a bridge and canasta party. The event, sponsored by the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre on April 7.
The surplus materials industry, which deals in items ranging from needles to deactivated atomic power plants, isn't worried about the recession.

One of man's most useful tools throughout the generations now comes in for some honors. This is Pencil Week, when we pay tribute to man's primary writing instrument. Use of the pencil dates back to ancient days, when man used disks and sticks of silver and soft lead to make markings on his papyrus, yet it seems to have learned the magical formula that allows it to defy the laws of obsolescence.
Sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company rose to a new high last year, but earnings declined from the 1956 level, according to the annual report issued today.
Opponents of water fluoridation presented to Mayor Wagner yesterday a document challenging the American Medical Association's position favoring fluoridation.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 24 -- Suffolk County's ten-man Board of Supervisors again divided 6 to 4 here today in favoring a proposed charter form of government for the county.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Members of the new Civil Rights Commission told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that they did not feel they would have authority to investigate any such incident as the school integration dispute at Little Rock.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The National Steel Corporation today cut its dividend rate from $1 to 75 cents a share.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, who has been called "the watchdog of public funds," was accused yesterday of barking up the wrong tree in his criticism of the city's school construction program.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. Feb. 24 -- The Michigan Congress of Industrial Organizations and a substantial delegation from the American Federation of Labor joined forces today to establish a united organization to be known as the Michigan State A. F. of L.-C. I. O.

The steel industry used only a little more than half of its rated production capacity last week as output was trimmed for the fifth consecutive week. The steel-makers, operating their facilities at an average of 50.9 per cent of capacity, poured 1,373,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

If Jimmy McDermott, the volatile coach of Iona College's basketball team, did not directly charge a "freezeout" of his New Rochelle Gaels from the forthcoming two major post-season tournaments, he dropped strong hints to that effect yesterday. Among the points he made and the questions McDermott asked, one in particular, carried weight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Western diplomats gave Mr. Murphy less than an even chance today of success in his effort to exercise United States good offices in the dispute between France and Tunisia.
The city counted its weather blessings on both hands yesterday. There was great satisfaction, too, in the suburbs and in upstate New York.

Arturo Frondizi, the Intransigent Radical candidate, won an overwhelming victory in the Argentine Presidential elections on Sunday. This was a free choice of the people of Argentina in a democratic election, the first in thirty years. Senor Frondizi is to be congratulated and wished every possible success for himself and his troubled country.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The importance of the Los Angeles Dodgers to this community of 8,500 is usually measured by how much business the club gives to local merchants directly and what attraction the team offers tourists.
Tulips, daffodils, jonquils and other flowers will greet strollers this spring along Fifth and Park Avenues and in a number of midtown parks and squares, according to plans discussed yesterday.
Representative Ad2m Clayton Powell Jr. warned Tammany Hall and Governor lr2vriman yesterday agnint opposing hm for re-election tb year.

Renewed suggestions to Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner that they act to establish a narcotics hospital on Ellis Island have been made by Senators Irving M. Ives and Jacob K. Javits and Representative Victor L. Anfuso.

In the existing vacancy on the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals President Eisenhower has a fine opportunity to make a judicial appointment that will carry out his frequently expressed ideal of naming highly qualified individuals to major Federal posts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- "They will squeal like stuck pigs" was Speaker Rayburn's prophecy of the effect on the Republicans of former President Truman's Saturday night speech. And the Republicans duly obliged, making noises of protest that really sounded somewhat like echoes from the barnyard after the frost has firmly set in.
The First Army has asked boys in the metropolitan area please to stop playing with matches, especially when used as fuel for rockets.
ATLANTA, Feb. 24 -- The American Bar Association approved in principle today the idea of assuring that nine judges sit in every case decided by the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. of Missouri proposed today that Congress enact a passport law under which citizens could visit such countries as Communist China at their own risk.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -Pentagon proposals for reducing the strength of the Army National Guard were presented in detail to Congress today and they set loose a flash flood of protests.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The United States is not suffering a serious shortage of scientists, a Chicago educator said today, but it is running low on science teachers.
A two-day blood donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will begin today at the United States Military Academy, West Point, N. Y.
Until City Hall telephoned him yesterday, a clergyman was under the impression that his offer to give his own small automobile to the city for Mayor Wagner's use had been accepted.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -Contrary to a popular impression first created by a Russian scientist, sea ice is not necessarily weaker than fresh-water ice.

A family physician expressed the belief yesterday that a 29-year-old woman who disappeared in Brooklyn five hours before her wedding on Saturday did so because she was "apprehensive" about the marriage.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption for January averaged 31,992 bales for each working day.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

Architectural details have been announced for the fifteen-story office building at 141 Livingston Street, at the corner of Smith Street, in Brooklyn. It will be owned by the Brooktown Building Corporation of White Plains and leased to the American Fore Insurance Group.

Six scientists will participate in a television symposium on "The Role of the Scientist in America's Future." It will be presented by the Columbia Broadcasting System on March 16 (5 to 6 P. M.) was the second program in the network's series titled "The Great Challenge."
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 24 -- Westchester County will consider next Monday a complete reappraisal of the engineering and financing aspects of reconstructing its parkway system.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Two very attractive American works were high points of a rewarding concert by the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Union employes of seven major Jewish Welfare Centers voted last night to accept a work contract that had been proposed by a special panel. The contract calls for wage increases for both professional and nonprofessional workers.

Bipartisan unity on the issue of mutual security is scheduled to be demonstrated impressively in Washington today. Leaders from many walks of national life and from many parts of the country will gather in the capital to affirm their support of the concept of mutual security.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 24 (UP) -- The military junta that took power after the overthrow of dictator Marcos Perez Jimenez began its second month in office today with a reorganized Cabinet.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- It's a young man's game, this business of baseball. At least it's nothing you can expect to play in your later years, like golf or pinochle.
DETROIT, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Worker absenteeism resulting from severe weather along with some labor troubles and lower production schedules are holding down motor vehicle output.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower would be host tomorrow at a breakfast for Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, President-elect of Guatemala.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 24 -- A "stretchout" program in construction of the multi-billion dollar national interstate highway system was denounced by several Western governors today.

Edward Oscar Heinrich, pioneer American criminologist, is the subject of a biography by Eugene B. Block, which will be published next Monday by Coward-McCann. "The Wizard of Berkeley" tells how Heinrich worked for many years in his California laboratory, shunning publicity and known only to the police and other experts in the field, yet playing a vital part in solving many famous crimes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Word that the Government will support the 1958 soybean crop at the same figure as for 1957 sparked a good demand for the September and November deliveries on the Board of Trade today.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The two living former Presidents will receive honorary degrees from the University of the State of New York.

The weather-induced shortage of fresh and frozen fish for the city's restaurants and households last week has been overcome, according to August Strauss, president of the Fulton Market Fish Mongers Association.

New York City is in a housing crisis and Mayor Wagner should fill vacancies on the Housing Authority, Ira S. Robbins said yesterday. He is executive vice president of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The president of the Amateur Athletic Union said today the national organization had been assured of the money necessary to promote reciprocal meets between American and Russian track teams.

Herman Shumlin, who directed the original 1939 production of Lillian Hellman's play "The Little Foxes," will stage the new production of Marc Blitzstein's "Regina" for the spring season of American opera at the City Center.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 24 -- First Lieut. Peter Colin Nast, a pilot attached to the Forty-second (Rainbow) Division of the New York National Guard, was killed today in an airplane crash near here. A Naval Reserve officer who was with him was injured.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 24 -- Premier Abdullah Khalil charged today that Egypt was interfering in the Sudanese election campaign "in cooperation with the Communists."
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- A Republican resolution was filed in the Legislature tonight to assure the continuance of the Rockefeller commission as a joint legislative committee.
The steady decline in the size of the active high-seas merchant fleet of the United States continued through January, the Maritime Administration reported yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Only youth African gold mining shares withstood the general decline in the stock market today.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 19 -- Fierce controversy is raging in New Zealand about whether one of the most popular summer sports for girls is a sport at all or a sign of hidden fascism.
Wool prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange in sympathy with lower London quotations and weakness at the Australian auctions.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Ringling Brothers Circus announced today it was closing winter quarters here by April 1 and selling surplus animals and equipment.
Harry Lanza was granted a certificate of reasonable doubt yesterday in his fight to upset a conviction for contempt of the Legislature.
The French Hospital of New York will benefit from a gala dinner dance to be held in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on March 10.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is negotiating a new four-picture contract with Virginia and Andrew Stone Productions, an independent husband - and - wife company. The Stones collaborate on screenplays and share producer responsibilities, including the editing.
Kansas State led the United Press major college basketball ratings yesterday for the third straight week. Notre Dame appeared among the top ten teams for the first time this season.
Gloomy industrial news yesterday proved a more potent stock market factor than Presidential optimism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Senate tonight passed and sent to President Eisenhower the bill he had asked raising the Federal debt ceiling by $5,000,000,000.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Reports circulated here today that about twenty-five persons had been arrested on charges of subversive activity. But an official source said "only eight have been jailed."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 24 (UP) -- The United States was pitted against Venezuela in the first round of the 1958 American Zone Davis Cup competition today in the draw conducted by the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 24 -- The recent mergers of Arab nations are a potential threat to Israel but not an active danger now, an Israeli official said today.

I thoroughly agree with much of the editorial in The New York Times of Feb. 21. I am among the first to admit that our method of giving out information has long been inadequate. In the very first budget that I recommended to the Board of Education I included an item for a bureau of public information. However, this item was stricken out in the budget adopted by the Board of Estimate.
GENEVA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A six-member American ski team will compete in Poland and Czechoslovakia next month, Haines Gaffner said today.
HAVANA, Tuesday, Feb. 25 (AP) -Cuban rebels freed Juan Manuel Fangio early today.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- There was only one break in the seeding as the women's national doubles platform tennis championship moved to the semi-final stage at Fox Meadow Tennis Club today.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A sixty-three-year-old mystery, the theft of the original British Football Association tournament cup, was solved yesterday when Harry Burge, 80, confessed he helped steal it.

MIAMI, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Pucker Up, the 1957 champion among the fillies and mares, made a disappointing winter debut as she lost a half-length decision to Happy Princess in the $7,500 Kissimmee Purse today at Hialeah.

Paramount Pictures announced yesterday that it had completed the sale of its library of pre-1948 movies to EMKA, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Music Corporation of America. The subsidiary was called the Management Corporation of America when the then pending $50,000,000 deal was announced two weeks ago.

The turning point in Tom Laris' track career occurred early last month when his coach summoned the slim George Washington High School senior to his office and bluntly told him he lacked the speed to become a top miler.
A good volume of orders was booked at the National Sanitary Supply Association's exhibit in the New York Coliseum, which opened last Saturday. The exhibit closes today.

FROM the time the first set of tennis was brought into the United States, less than a year after the game's invention in 1873 under the curious name of Sphairistike by Maj. Walter Clopton Wingfield of Wales, the sport has been under the guidance and control of the East.

PARENTS should discard any notion that discipline is a harsh word, Dr. Othilda Krug, University of Cincinnati psychiatrist, declared recently. Actually, she added, discipline is education or training in its widest sense.
Jimmy Archer of the Bronx scored a technical knockout over Danny Russo, Brooklyn boxer, in the main bout, scheduled for ten rounds, at the St. Nicholas arena last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -Following is the text of the United States-British memorandum on missile bases:
The semi-annual Leather Show sponsored by the Tanners Council of America will be held today and tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Ninety-seven tanners will have exhibits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- John Foster Dulles testified today that it would be "totally disastrous" for Congress to amend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act as proposed by a strong coalition of tariff protectionists.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The most criticized diplomat in the Western world, John Foster Dulles, will be 70 years old tomorrow, and he's still smiling.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, introduced today a resolution aimed at a possible change in the system of foreign aid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Department of Defense disclosed, in response to questions, that all of the United Statesmade missiles to be sent to Britain in the agreement made public today would be Air Force Thors.

The International Shoe Company announced yesterday that it would sign a consent decree to satisfy a Federal Trade Commission complaint. The commission charged last July that International Shoe and its subsidiary, the Shoenterprise Corporation, were guilty of unfair trade practices in requiring retailers to shun competing brands.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 24 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic arrived today in a surprise visit to Syria, a new province of his state. Egypt is the other province of the Republic. The popular welcome here was so enthusiastic that it took the President an hour and a half to travel less than a quarter of a mile at one point.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Small price declines continued today in virtually every section of the stock market.

"The Big Record," which stars Patti Page, will be reduced to a half-hour and televised on Wednesdays from 8:30 to 9 P. M. beginning March 26. Since last fall the musical program has been presented from 8 to 9 over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 25 -The American Bar Association went on record today in opposition to a pending Senate bill to restrict the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
Despite a 50 per cent reduction in financial support, United States science exhibits at the forthcoming Brussels World's Fair will be "of the first magnitude."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 25 -- An inspired Harvard hockey team overcame a two-goal deficit in the last four minutes tonight to tie Dartmouth, 4 to 4.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- A proposal that attendance at summit talks should vary with the subject on the agenda for each session is being discussed in British diplomatic circles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A secret report on arms aid says that France diverted substantial quantities of United States material to North Africa where the French are trying to subdue rebellious Algerians.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 25 Leaders of foreign and economic policy of six governments pushed ahead today with the organization of an integrated "Little Europe."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- A pre-production purchase of screen rights to "The Pleasure of His Company," a play by Samuel Taylor and Cornelia Otis Skinner, has been made by George Seaton and William Perlberg, independent producers, in association with Paramount. The sale price was said to be more than $350,000.

FLORENCE, Italy, Feb. 25 -A court trying the case of the Bishop of Prato heard counsel for the plaintiffs argue today that atheists were not liable to penalties of church law and that ecclesiastical authorities did not have immunties under Italian law.

There were so many boos resounding throughout Madison Square Garden last night one might have suspected that Walter O'Malley was somewhere in the house. However, the hoots were directed against the home team, the New York Knickerbockers, who rarely have looked more futile than they did while succumbing to the Philadelphia Warriors, 132 -- 110.
Johns-Manville scientists revealed yesterday the development of a new type of aviation insulation. They said it would greatly improve the range and accuracy of guided missiles.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25 -- Organized supporters of Juan D. Peron, exiled dictator, presented their bill today for having helped elect Arturo Frondizi as President of Argentina.
Ice-gazers at the Rockefeller Plaza rink, some of them deeply mystified, saw a demonstration of curling by a group of visitors from Toronto yesterday at noon.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union has started to withdraw some of its troops that poured into Hungary to crush the anti-Communist revolt in October, 1956, the Communist party newspaper reported here today.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (UP) -Willie Pastrano of New Orleans, warned by the referee for landing a low punch, went on to score a ten-round decision over Brian London of England tonight at Harringay Arena before a capacity crowd of 10,000.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- L. L. Colbert, Chrysler Corporation president, and Walter P. Reuther, United Automobile Workers president will meet Monday to try to settle a dispute that has plagued the corporation since Jan. 27.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -After hearing the farm soil bank program denounced as "unsound," "outlandish" and a joke, the House today voted an additional $250,000,000 for it.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 25 (UP) -- State officials said today that a quirk in Illinois law would bar Nathan Leopold from a life of service in a Puerto Rico mission hospital.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- The Jennie Clarkson Home in Valhalla will benefit from the annual dessert bridge party, which will be held on March 7 at the Scarsdale Women's Club.

Top officials of the S. H. Kress Company yesterday struck another blow in their attack against the trustees of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation. The foundation did not answer because, it said, its hands are tied by Securities and Exchange Commission proxy rules.
The American Cancer Society announced yesterday its first new research grants for 1958 amounting to $968,105. This brought its total dollar support of current research to more than $12,165,000.

A nineteen-story and penthouse building containing 135 apartments will be erected at 1280-88 Third Avenue, southwest corner of Seventy-fourth Street. The site has been purchased by the Cohen Bros. Realty Construction Corporation, builders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The State Department confirmed tonight that some of the planes used by the French to bomb Sakiet - Sidi - Youssef had been supplied under the United States military aid program.
Robert K. Christenberry, Republican candidate for Mayor last fall, is expected to make formal peace with Republican county leaders here today.

Notre Dame has been a significant sports name in New York for a couple of generations. For years, the Notre Dame-Army football game was a bright spot on the local calendar. Madison Square Garden's program of intercollegiate basketball double-headers started with a contest between Notre Dame and New York University.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -The United States and allied governments are studying ways to break the disarmament impasse, the State Department said today.

SOME impulsive townsfolk seem to thing that spring has put her foot inside the door, but she hasn't. Tree buds may look a little fatter to the optimistic eye. A mild thaw has started grimy snowpiles runneling and a greatcoat weighs heavily. Since Monday there have been all these signs.
New issues of public utility securities totaling $60,000,000 will be placed on the market today for public subscription by investment banking syndicates, as follows:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, President-elect of Guatemala, conferred with President Eisenhower and was honored by the Organization of American States today.

WHEN new hats burgeon in the shops, surely spring cannot be far behind. Those delving about for a new bonnet will find Gimbels overflowing with three favorite silhouettes. These are the cloche, the breton and the turban.
ROBERT EDMOND JONES (1887-1954) was one of the most gifted American theatre designers of the twentieth century. A memorial exhibition of his work opens today at the Whitney Museum.
State Commerce Commissioner Edward T. Dickinson has scheduled an emergency conference here today in an effort to save a Long Island aircraft plant threatened with liquidation.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Feb. 25 -- The proposed move of the Mergenthaler Linotype Corporation of Brooklyn to a twentyfour-acre site at Plainview received impetus today at a public hearing before the Town Board.
Fewer oranges and less orange concentrate are certainties for the present season, Homer Hooks, general manager of the Florida Citrus Commission, said here yesterday.

A Nigerian statuette reported to have been stolen from Paul Manship, the sculptor, brought trouble yesterday to two junk dealers. The statuette, valued at $6,000, had been sold by one dealer to the other for $2, the police said.

A series called "Ten Great Films," numbering outstanding screen achievements from 1915 through 1952, will be presented by the Abbey Film Society of Fordham College, starting next month. Gordon Hendricks will introduce "Birth of A Nation," which begins the series at 7:45 P. M., March 6, in the college's Freeman Hall.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 -- One hears strange tales in a baseball spring training camp. As an old chronicler once put it, "It's there you really get the inside of the inside story."
Plans for bringing up to date the state's standards for children's institutions were announced here yesterday by the state's Department of Social Welfare.
Leopold D. Silberstein has stepped down as head of PennTexas Corporation. The action came yesterday as a climax to a protracted internal struggle and averted a showdown proxy battle.

THE television broadcasters, who in the evening hours command the lion's share of the home audience, last night did not afford live coverage of President Eisenhower's address bringing to a close the Conference on Foreign Aspects of United States National Security.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -The 1,200 guests who attended the bipartisan conference here today to promote the foreign aid program will probably never know who picked up the check for the long program.

IN 1826 when the fat and foolish George IV was King of England a sophisticated, cultivated and charming German prince arrived in London in search of an heiress. His name was Hermann Ludwig Heinrich, Prince of Puckler-Muskau. He had recently divorced his wife, Lucie, Countess of Pappenheim, whom he loved devotedly, so that he could restore his family fortune by marrying English money.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- An adviser to the Democratic minornity in the Assembly was disclosed today to be the highestpaid man on the legislative payroll.
TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- Thorn Lord, a member of the Port of New York Authority, emerged today as the principal contender for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New Jersey.

New York City raised $44,500,000 in the bond market yesterday through the sale of bonds maturing serially over fifteen years at an interest cost of 2.848 per cent. Of the proceeds from the sale, $40,500,000 will go for the acquisition of school building sites and the construction of buildings and $4,000,000 will finance payment of judgments and claims against the city.
GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- Britain's Attorney General took time off today from an international conference on the law of the sea to plead the case for a venerable English dish -- fish and chips.

This year's Award of Merit Medal of the American Academy of Arts and Letters will go to Jean de Marco, the sculptor. The award, with a prize of $1,000, will be presented in May at the annual ceremonial of the academy and the affiliated National Institute of Arts and Letters.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- I believe that a trial agreement for two years between the United States and the Soviet Union on a first-step limitation of armaments and the suspension of nuclear explosions under a rigid reciprocal system of inspection can be negotiated within the next six to nine months.
BRANFORD, Conn., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Paulette Goddard, actress, and Erich Maria Remarque, novelist, were married today in a quiet civil ceremony.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 -- Japan defended the free world's military alliances and chided the Soviet Union on the Kremlin's policies toward Eastern Europe and Germany in a note to the Soviet Government yesterday. She also depreciated the Soviet boycott of the United Nations disarmament efforts.

PHOENIX Ariz., Feb. 25 -The evolution of the rookie baseball player has reached a state of such refinement that hotel bellhops frequently are mistaking rookies for gentlemen, scholars or possibly advertising men with liberal expense accounts.
BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- Inflation is catching up with the 10-cent baggage locker.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 25 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser asserted today that "imperialists" were responsible for the Egyptian dispute with the Sudan over territory on the Red Sea.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, said today that American industry would win the race with Russia to develop atomic energy as a lowcost source of peacetime power.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Historic Sites recommended today that the state accept from Westchester County the John Jay homestead at Katonah and maintain it as a historic shrine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -The new Soviet Ambassador, Mikhail A. Menshikov, said today that he considered official protocol less important than improvement of relations between the Soviet Union and The United States.
William T. Bigler, formerly general manager of the Kenmore Hotel, Boston, has been named general manager of the Sheraton-Ritz Carlton Hotel in Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -The White House acquiesced tonight in a decision by the television and radio networks and newsreels to broadcast "morning newspaper" news at 6 P M., Eastern standard time. This is one hour earlier than the time under previous understandings.

ELK POINT, S. D., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Axel J. Beck disputed today an assertion by an American Bar Association spokesman that he was not qualified for the Federal judgeship for which he has been nominated.
CORNWALL, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- The Metropolitan Council of Planning Agencies began a preliminary study here today of the need for a three-state system of parks for recreational purposes.

Sharp price movements and heavy volume were registered yesterday by several commodities on the New York exchanges. Several potato positions rose the daily limit in spirited trading. Copper futures fell almost to the lows for the life of the contracts in heavy volume, and cottonseed oil dropped in an active market.
The days are getting longer, truly. They began doing so a few days before Christmas, although everyone was too occupied at the time to notice. Now they are beginning to amount to something.
The State Commissioner of Social Welfare said yesterday that no child accepted as a public charge should be denied care because of limitations of voluntary child-care agencies.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- The recent struggle within the East German regime involved an attempt to range Premier Otto Grotewohl against Walter Ulbricht, First Secretary of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party.

The six-foot, one-inch "prime minister" of the Egyptian Dragons testified yesterday that the assault that led to the death of Michael Farmer was "quick and spontaneous and no one gave orders to attack."
PADANG, Indonesia, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The rebel Government said today that it had moved to secret mountain headquarters to avoid attack.
George Meany decided yesterday to make a final effort next Wednesday to bring about a voluntary labor merger in this state.

The Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice has opened an inquiry into the Music Corporation of America and the William Morris Agency, the two largest organizations representing entertainment talent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -The Treasury announced today that its new cash offering would be a 3 per cent bond dated Feb. 28 and maturing on Aug. 15, 1966.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Legislature headed tonight toward another record for proposing changes in the law.
A Brooklyn judge charged yesterday that a grand jury had withdrawn an indictment based on the death of six children in the Williamsburg cavein at the request of the District Attorney's office.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 25 -- A group of Western Governors sounded the states rights battle cry today. They freely crossed party political lines to do it.
BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- How can a lightweight who has lost fortythree fights expect to defeat an opponent who is unbeaten in twenty-five starts?
"LUCIA DI LAMMERMOOR" was staged at the Metropolitan Opera last night, with Eugenio Fernandi singing Edgardo for the first time with the company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The research chief of the Air Force asked Congress today to hurry a program to send a rocket to the moon -- lest the Russians do it first.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- Work begins this week to re-erect part of the prehistoric stone monument called Stonehenge, near Salisbury, in western England.
A referee's report in the State Supreme Court yesterday recommended that the Guaranty Trust Company be authorized to sell all or any part of the securities of the Universal Oil Products Company.
About 500 members of ten Jewish religious organizations picketed City Hall yesterday in a futile effort to spur legislation to help Jewish merchants conduct business on Sunday.
DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- Truck drivers affiliated with James R. Hoffa's home local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters will be wearing distinctive windbreakers soon.

Taking a hand in the debate now under way in most countries regarding the issues that might be discussed at another summit meeting, General Norstad, Supreme Commander of NATO forces in Europe, has warned the West of the military realities present in the situation.
New York as a port has no champion in Congress, a leading marine industrialist charged yesterday.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 25 -Ceylon and the Soviet Union signed an agreement today under which Moscow will provide Ceylon with technical cooperation in such projects as irrigation, hydroelectric power development and expansion of agriculture.

The Commercial Credit Company was involved in some noteworthy ups and downs yesterday. On the New York Stock Exchange the company's stock traded at a new 1957-58 high of 55 1/8 and closed at 55, up 1 7/8 points.

I have read with great interest and approval President Eisenhower's reply to Soviet Premier Bulganin's last letter. No fair-minded person, whether Russian or American, could doubt that President Eisenhower is sincere in his efforts to establish better relationships with Russia, if its leaders will approach urgent world problems in a way to indicate that they really mean what they say.
The New York Central Railroad, which last December reported a net profit after chalking up a loss in November, plunged back into the "red" last month.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (UP) -Britons took their minds off missiles for a moment today to gasp at a new challenge to the art of brewing a cup of tea.
Your paper has been so consistently fair regarding our case that we feel you will welcome correction of some misunderstanding in your recent editorial entitled "Teamster 'Settlement.'"

TUNIS, Feb. 25 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia told a United States conciliator today that the fundamental problem to be resolved by United States-British good offices was the Algerian guerrilla war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Consumer prices rose sharply to another record in January despite the business recession, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Following are the texts of addresses on foreign aid given in Washington yesterday by President Eisenhower and former President Harry S. Truman, as transcribed by The New York Times:
Albany, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the State Commerce Department today:

HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Juan Manuel Fangio, the Argentine automobile racing champion, said today that those who kidnapped him Sunday were young men who treated him with consideration and even friendliness. The driver was released shortly after midnight.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- Discovering the human beings who exist behind a national caricature is as rewarding as it is refreshing. One finds people who have the same basic aspirations and problems as one's neighbors.
Stores all ever the country today may sell General Electric Company radios, irons, toasters and other small home appliances at any prices they please.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Feb. 25 -- The Soviet Union was alternately praised and criticized here today by Walter M. Kotschnig, leader of the United States delegation to a United Nations economic meeting.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Harriman asked the Legislature today to cut the reserve requirements of nonprofit hospital insurance companies to delay a rate increase.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Following is the text of a statement today by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, concerning suspended students in the New York City school system:

A plan to help the city school system combat juvenile delinquency was disclosed yesterday by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner. The plan contained both immediate and long-range measures to meet the "serious situation."
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 25 -- Michigan's newly unit ed labor organization seems destined to become a strong and broad-based political arm of the Democratic party in this state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Treasury Department said for the first time today that it would back a move to stop American business men from listing bribes to foreign government officials as tax-deductible expenses.
The Steamship Office Workers Union yesterday advanced on two fronts in its drive to organize white collar workers in ship line offices here.
