MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Eugene Meyer, whose home here overlooks Byram Lake, has offered to buy it as a $256,000 gift to this village. Mayor Betty Potter identified the prospective donor tonight. She said that the lake, long part of the New York City water system, would be restricted in perpetuity to use for water supply, conservation of natural beauty and park purposes.

The boyhood and hazardous youth of a royal African tribesman is told in "I Was a Savage,'' which Harcourt, Brace will publish March 12. The author, Prince Modupe, tells of growing up in a native village in French West Africa, of his puberty rites, his test of manhood and of the ritual and witchcraft of his people.
HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Fidel Castro, rebel leader, has sent to President Fulgencio Batista a proposal to end Cuba's worsening civil war.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 25 -- A germ-killing gas that can be used to sterilize hospitals has been discovered by Army Chemical Corps scientists.
SETAUKET, L. I., Feb. 25 -- The evening grosbeak, an "irregular" visitor to Long Island, and the tufted titmouse -- an extremely rare resident here -- were reliably reported in this area today.

HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- The English-language Cuban daily newspaper, The Havana Post, said today in an editorial, "One thing demonstrated by yesterdays' Gran Premio auto race is that the streets of this city are not suitable or adequate for a race of this character.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 -- Japan's Socialist party announced the absorption of the newly formed Okinawa Socialist party today. Both organizations are opposed to continued administration of the island of Okinawa by the United States and have urged that the strategic air base be restored to Japan's jurisdiction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, was urged today by striking Hollywood musicians to permit picketing of film studios and to ask the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes not to cross picket lines.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PARIS, Feb. 25 -- The French political Right and Left clashed today in the National Assembly over the Algerian war. At one point the sitting had to be suspended to restore order.
Webb Knapp reportedly is negotiating for the sale and leaseback of the Astor Hotel, a property that the realty concern has agreed to buy from the Sheraton interests.

Despite mergers and growth of branches, competition in banking remains highly effective in New York State, according to the results of a two-year study published yesterday by the State Banking Department.
Red Cross bloodmobiles will be sent today to the Chase Manhattan Bank, 57 William Street, and the New York Telephone Company, 18 Boerum Street, Brooklyn.

A leading custom smelter trimmed the price of copper 3/8-cent a pound yesterday to 23 1/8 cents -- the lowest smelter price since early October, 1950. Other smelters matched the new price, while the major producers continued to quote 25 cents a pound, their price since about mid-January.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Some of the production work behind this year's Channel 9 television spectacular, "The Philadelphia Phillies in New York," has grown to unwieldly proportions. In the future, the number of young and hopeful actors may be cut.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Casey Stengel whittled down his Yankee school prospects today. When he got through handing out diplomas and accolades only three were tapped to remain for more intensive and advanced studies.

OWEGO, N. Y., Feb. 25 (UP) -The Tioga County grand jury returned its first indictment today in the investigation of the Apalachin, N. Y., gangland convention. It charged Anthony P. Riela, a Newark, N. J., motel operator, with contempt for refusing to answer 17 questions.

Rarely can there have been a more foolish decision than that made by the Board of Education in suspending young delinquents from school in the absence of any alternative provision for them. This decision will merely have the effect of transferring delinquency from the schools into the community.

The Leo Burnett Company, Inc., named Monday to handle the corporate advertising of the Chrysler Corporation, had held talks with the auto maker's executives before the account was resigned by McCann-Erickson, Inc.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Pulling away smoothly in the last half, the New York University basketball squad downed Rutgers tonight, 88 -- 73.

Net income of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation in 1957, its fiftieth year of operation, rose to a record high of $39,092,388, or $4.27 a common share. The installment financing concern cleared $37,753,863, or $4.12 a share, in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -George Meany assailed "the maneuverings" of some members of the Senate Rackets committee today for delaying the appearance of Walter P. Reuter.

AN opera that was written over 300 years ago, and that in many respects is as modern as anything being written today, moved a soldout audience last night in Town Hall. It was Claudio Monteverdi's "The Coronation of Poppea," and it was presented by The American Opera Society as its last performance of the season.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 25 -- The Sudanese Government announced today that an Egyptian patrol had withdrawn from the disputed frontier area near the Red Sea where it had entrenched itself during the last week.

William E. Jenner of Indiana, who is doing a service to the nation by retiring from the Senate this year, is author of a bill, to limit the appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in certain areas where the court has been courageously defending some of our basic American liberties.

Clark Equipment Company linked its independent dealers yesterday with the home office at Buchanan, Mich., with a 13,000-mile leased wire line. Officials of the company, which makes materials handling machinery, said this was the largest private wire network in existence.
MIAMI, Feb. 25 (UP) -Budge Patty of Los Angeles defeated Jerry Moore of Miami, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, today in the second round of the seventh annual Miami tennis championships.

Twelve proposed low-cost state and Federally aided housing projects encountered some opposition yesterday at public hearings before the City Planning Commission. The total cost of the twelve projects would be about $80,000,000.
ERIC ALLEN JOHNSTON is the personality boy of United States capitalism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today delayed action for a second time on the nomination of W. Wilson White to be head of the Justice Department's new Civil Rights Division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -The Federal Court of Appeals ordered further proceedings today on whether the railroads had violated antitrust laws by acting in concert to give the Government reduced fares for transportation of military personnel.

MIAMI, Feb. 25 -- Morris B. Frank, a horse-owner from Glenville, Ill., and Arnold N. Winick, a horse-trainer from Chicago, went after three straight races at Hialeah today. They wound up with two firsts and a second.
DURING the last eighteen years as a New York couturier who has made fashion history, Mainbocher's comments about his own brand of chic have, in a sense, explained his brilliant success.
The Kips Bay Boys Club will benefit from its annual dinner-dance to be held at the Plaza on April 17.
Liz Renay, a 31-year-old actress, was questioned yesterday for more than two hours in connection with the murder of Albert Anastasia.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- A glimpse of a blue bird and a flock of Canada geese and the discovery of a fine stand of skunk cabbage were greeted with pleasure today by one of New York's most unusual car pools.
Although steels and golds put up a stanch defense, the stock market retreated yesterday for the fifth successive session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, introduced today bills that would give the teachers Federal tax benefits and provide loans to secondary schools for science laboratories.
A new high in contributions to higher education in 1956-57, was reported yesterday in a survey by the John Price Jones Company fund-raising organization.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Diefendorf Commission on Highway Financing agreed today to a report recommending a 25 per cent increase in motor fuel taxes.

Diplomats and international lawyers from eighty-seven nations are meeting in Geneva in an attempt to reach international accord on problems arising in the law of the sea. The conference, held under United Nations sponsorship, will try to draft one or more treaties to settle conflicting maritime legal principles presently advanced by different countries.
MacManus, John Adams, Inc., has announced the formation of an international department, which will have a network of affiliated agencies in thirty-five countries.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 25 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia reversed himself today and announced he would seek re-election.

The development of a chemical that is both a powerful rat poison and an anticoagulant was hailed here last night. It has been used by President Eisenhower since shortly after his heart attack in Denver on Sept. 24, 1955.
Consternation will strike "fair trading" business men today when they learn that their most powerful ally has deserted to the free pricing camp.

The physical and mental vigor that John Foster Dulles exhibits daily in his grueling post is so impressive that it probably came as a surprise to many Americans to learn that he was 70 yesterday. A much younger man might well be crushed by the burden of responsibility and the fatigue of frequent travel which are our Secretary of State's normal load, yet he seems to thrive with the passage of time.

The United States Information Agency has asked for $105,000,000 for the fiscal year beginning July 1. For radio facilities in the Middle East where the Russians and Egyptians outvoice us, $5,000,000 additional is requested. The matter is now before the House Appropriations subcommittee, Congressman John Rooney (Brooklyn Democrat), chairman.

The advent of the jet airliner here will present New York's tourist industry with a serious challenge before the year is out, Walter H. Johnson Jr., vice president of American Airlines, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -The House Post Office and Civil Service Committee voted pay rises of nearly $1,000,000,000 a year to 1,500,000 Government workers.

Irwin Shaw, who generally writes about the serious aspect of life, will switch to comedy in his next stage venture. He is to adapt the Parisian hit, "Patate," for Gilbert Miller. Despite contrary views, the Paris atmosphere as well as the action will not be tampered with.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -A one - man picket line marched in front of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations building today. He was protesting recent discharges of federation employes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The boyhood ambition of John Foster Dulles was to be a locomotive engineer.
Prices of cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 3 to 31 points (15 cents to $1.55 a bale) yesterday. The pressure was most pronounced in new crop months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -The Department of Commerce said today that there were indications that the flow of dollars from the United States to other countries would not decline at this time despite the recession.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower and former President Harry S. Truman appealed to Congress today to carry forward a strong foreign aid program as the price of national security.

SOME surprising information about the New York State hunter and his game was furnished by a sampling survey conducted by the State Conservation Department. He likes pheasants best, but kills more of almost every other small game; hunts mostly close to home, often buys a license and doesn't hunt at all, and is, by and large, pretty successful when he does hunt.

IF John Osborne, on the strength of "Look Back in Anger," is to be regarded as Broadway's current "angry young man," then surely Henrik Ibsen, on the basis of last night's revival of "An Enemy of the People," is entitled to the sobriquet of Off Broadway's "angry old man."

Net income of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation last year rose to a record high of $46,037,136, compared with $45,705,188 in 1956, according to the annual report issued today by Charles G. Stradella, president.

A new "Tournament of Fashion" has been announced by Bergdorf Goodman. Students of the Fashion Institute of Technology, the Parsons School of Design, Pratt Institute and the Rhode Island School of Design are invited to participate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A potentially significant split has developed within the Atomic Energy Commission over a proposal by two Pennsylvania companies to build a large atomic power plant with Government assistance.
There were inconclusive engagements yesterday on two farflung fronts in the battle over the Lincoln Square redevelopment.

The election in Argentina, the revolution in Venezuela that followed other revolutions against dictatorships in Colombia and Argentina, the popular pressure that forced the Peruvian dictator to hold fair elections, the Cuban struggle -these and other events of recent years are signposts in the long, hard, uphill journey toward democracy in Latin America.
A tax cut would do more than a program of public works to revive the national economy should the expected upturn by July 1 not materialize, the nation's Budget Director said last night.

JOSEPH MEIERHANS, at the Artists Gallery, 851 Lexington Avenue, is a painter whose fancy runs to such ideas as the festive air of a city and the multiple facets of nature. He paints with relish, laying on bright reds, blues and yellows in small, but profuse areas.
The Transit Authority asserted yesterday that its declining passenger revenues in the subways were caused by the economic recession.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- In the absence of any consequential influences, grain futures drifted quietly on the Board of Trade today.
Former President Harry S. Truman rose yesterday to the defense of President Eisenhower.

HAVANA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Cuban police threw a heavy guard around the world lightweight boxing champion, Joe Brown of New Orleans, today. They want to insure that Fidel Castro's rebels will not succeed in any attempt to break up his ten-round bout tomorrow night with Orlando Echevarria of Cuba.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 25 -- Trying to judge any contemporary society by its authors is risky. It would be exaggerated to view American life through the eyes of Kerouac and Faulkner or to measure modern England only by Kingsley Amis and John Osborne.

BONN, West Germany, Feb. 25 -- General Lauris Norstad, Supreme Allied Commander for Europe, said tonight that atomic weapons for the German army were "absolutely indispensable" for the successful defense of the West.
THE Case of the Disappearing Waistline is now being presented at Bloomingdale's Green Room.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Plans to offer two new anthology series, dealing with women and aviation, respectively, to sponsors for nighttime scheduling next fall were announced today by Alan W. Livingston, vice president in charge of programs for the National Broadcasting Company's Pacific division.
Heavy retail shoe volume and light supplies at all levels, despite record production last year, resulted in larger attendance and sizable buying orders yesterday at the opening of the Leather Show.

The Senate has finally confirmed the action of the House in authorizing a temporary rise of $5 billion in the ceiling on the Federal debt. The limit is now $275 billion -- a ceiling that the Administration is now approaching. The new upper limit of $280 billion will remain in effect through June 30, 1959.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 25 -- President-elect Mario Echandi declared today that he would abolish the country's armed forces when he takes office next May.

John Adams High checked Benjamin Franklin, 55 to 45, and Franklin K. Lane High eliminated Port Richmond, 59 to 44, in preliminary round games of the city Public Schools Athletic League basketball play-offs at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
The police yesterday traced several false and unpromising leads in the disappearance of Irene Arzedi, 29-year-old Brooklyn bride-to-be.

The Rev. Bob Richards, the Olympic pole vaulting champion, yesterday added his prestige to a national program for youth fitness sponsored jointly by the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce and the new Wheaties Sports Federation organized by General Mills.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation announced yesterday a quarterly dividend of 12 1/2 cents on its common stock, payable March 31. This compares with 17 1/2 cents paid in December, and with 25 cents paid quarterly prior to that time.

AS every good cook knows, it is not necessary to be extravagant to prepare a dinner that satisfies the appetite and titillates the taste. The following Lenten meal for six, including wine and matelote (a simplified version of the French fish dish, bouillabaisse) costs about $6.95. The sum is based on present retail prices.

AS every good cook knows, it is not necessary to be extravagant to prepare a dinner that satisfies the appetite and titillates the taste. The following Lenten meal for six, including wine and matelote (a simplified version of the French fish dish, bouillabaisse) costs about $6.95. The sum is based on present retail prices.

SIX people enter into every marriage. Two of them are real and the rest are imaginary. The resulting confusion and disillusionment account largely for the high divorce rate in the first five years of married life.

Four men and two women died of methyl alcohol poisoning yesterday after attending a Sunday night party in the Puerto Rican section of East Harlem. Dr. Milton Helpern, the medical examiner, said that all the deaths were caused by drinking of methyl, or wood, alcohol.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Soviet biologists report that they have transplanted a dog's head onto a puppy's body and kept the resulting animal alive for six days after the operation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A Republican member of the House of Representatives subcommittee investigating pressures on the Federal Communications Commission demanded today that Richard A. Mack resign immediately, or that President Eisenhower remove him.
A combination of industrial layoffs and the winter's worst snowstorm sent the city's jobless total up last week after a five-week dip.

After flattening out in December, the consumer price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics resumed its rise, momentarily at least, in January. The index, which is based on the three - year period 1947-49 as 100, rose last month from 121.6 to 122.3, which is to say by seven-tenths of a point, or six-tenths of 1 per cent.
The New York Society for Crippled Children and Adults will benefit from an Easter Bonnet Tea and Fashion Show to be held in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on March 11.

Andy Bathgate never looked better than he did last night as he paced the Rangers to a 4-to-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. The smooth-skating right wing thrilled the crowd of 10,638 with his skillful moves and he was repeatedly cheered for his excellent performance.
SEAFORD, L. I., Feb. 26 -- A psychologist from Duke University will investigate the strange happenings at the home of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Herrmann here.
Cold weather resulted in a record decline in the nation's stock of light heating oil in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Gaso

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Feb. 19:
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The Stock Market improved today despite the renewed weakness of sterling, decreased industrial activity in the United Kingdom, and the depressing business news from America.

A recent article in The Times on United States participation in the Brussels Fair stated that "a cross-section of the arts of the United States is being assembled for exhibition at the Brussels World's Fair in April."

Last summer's disclosures of intolerable living conditions of New York's migratory workers have stimulated a crop of bills which have now appeared at Albany. They are designed to carry out measures of improvement backed both by the government and private agencies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- The Mirisch Company has added a new story purchase to its growing library of properties for United Artists release and announced the signing of writers to prepare scripts for two other pictures.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 -- Two dozen 2-year-olds, who were lined up across the track from fence to fence at the start, raced in the $24,275 Hialeah Juvenile Stakes today. It was a race that broke up the card game in the jockey room; there weren't enough little men left behind to form a quorum.

It is unfortunate that the provocative speech made by the Assembly majority leader at the hearing on the unemployment insurance bill, bringing on an understandably angry retort by the Governor, should have beclouded the presentation made in support of a veto.
HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- Four or five youthful rebels raided the annex of the National Bank of Cuba today and burned a quantity of canceled checks and other documents.
The policemen whose job it is to witness patrol - car speedometer tests may be pounding beats soon if a Queens magistrate's ruling is upheld.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 26 -Forty-two members of the San Francisco Giants, weighing collectively 7,972 pounds, held their third drill of the spring season today, did calisthenics, took batting practice and created such exciting news that sports writers wound up interviewing sports writers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The State Department is officially closing its eyes for the time being to the French use against Tunisia of planes given by the United States.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- A new Republican unemployment insurance bill was announced today. It won a cautious welcome from Governor Harriman.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- An early meeting between President Eisenhower and the group of men ruling the Soviet Union is highly desirable in the interest of peace.
IN French and American cuisine, dishes containing poultry bear regal name. Locally, one speaks of something "a la king"; in France, foods made with chicken are labeled "a la reine."
Roy Campanella is cheerful and hopes he will play ball again, a friend said yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 26 (Reuters) -- Many industrial enterprise in Czechoslovakia will be merged to form "trusts" and workers will get a greater say in their management beginning April 1, it was announced today.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The Conservative Government's reliance on a nuclear deterrent as the principal means of avoiding a third world war emerged unshaken tonight from a barrage of Labor criticism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Food and Drug Administration warned today that a new cosmetic product called Ten-Day Press-On Nail Polish was causing disfiguring and sometimes painful injuries to users. But the manufacturer denied the product was harmful in any way.

Several large New York City banks, led by the First National City Bank of New York, joined yesterday in a movement toward lower interest rates on foreign time deposits. They reduced rates generally 1/2 percentage point.
In the current controversy over the moving and rebuilding of the east front of the Capitol in Washington certain facts having direct bearing on the matter are being consistently overlooked.
The National Maritime Union, the American Merchant Marine Institute and six major shipping lines were named yesterday in a Federal court damage suit brought by fourteen merchant seamen.
The Beane of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will disappear from that company's name after tomorrow and will move on April 1 to J. R. Williston Co., also a member of the New York Stock Exchange.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb 26 -Fordham rolled up a scoring mark for the season as it beat the Army five, 92 to 76, en route to the National Invitation Tournament today.
The New York County grand jury that has been investigating the "bugging" of the offices of the Motormen's Benevolent Association reported yesterday that it had found no evidence of crime.
The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday cleared the first public offering of bonds of a European city to be marketed in the United States since 1929.

As might have been expected, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, has made a temperate, well-balanced, constructive contribution of guidance to New York City in meeting its problem of juvenile delinquency in the school system.

Four hundred plant fossils, including about thirty previously undiscovered species, were taken from a parked automobile in Brooklyn last night. They are about 40,000,000 years old. Some of them may be irreplaceable.

HOMEMAKERS are not as fickle as furnishings manufacturers. While man-made fibers are the glamour queens of this season's new collections of rugs and decorative fabrics, homemakers are still faithful to the old natural fiber stand-bys -- cotton and wool.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
Replying to a Soviet note circulated last December among all members of the United Nations Japan has taken a welcome stand at the side of the Western powers.

The March, April and May potato positions tumbled the daily limit of 30 points (hundredth of a cent a pound) yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Final prices were 21 to 30 points lower on 2,473 car lots.

A sale of rare postage stamps appeared yesterday to be heading toward a record for an auction sale. Last year a sale of jewelry, paintings, antique furniture and other objects of art from the estate of Mrs. John E. Rovensky brought $2,438,980 -- the highest total for a single sale.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- East-West trade in 1957 reached a post-war peak, according to estimates in a report released today by the International Cooperation Administration.
HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- A rebel leader capable of throwing into battle only 400 riflemen boasts that within a few months he will oust the Batista dictatorship and occupy all Cuba.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have told France that any step to make the French naval base at Bizerte, Tunisia, a North Atlantic Treaty Organization base would be regarded as an unfriendly act.

The announcement that Colgate has begun distribution of the first dentifrice to be packaged in an aerosol container is the latest in a flurry of toothpaste innovations, including dental cream in squeeze bottles and toothpaste that emerges from its tube in the form of colored stripes.

TO help their respective alma maters in the hectic scramble for team honors, Ron Delany of Villanova and Tom Murphy of Manhattan will run two events each in Saturday's Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America (that unwieldy name!) track and field championships.
TRENTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -Frank Brunell, a University of Indiana freshman, tonight lowered the American marks in the 100 and 110-yard butterfly swim.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Traditionally it has been the role of youth to rebel against old ways.
MIAMI, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Bill Parks of Los Angeles scored three victories today to advance to the semi-finals of the seventh annual Miami invitation tennis tournament.
The discovery of a hereditary defect that apparently causes the disastrous anemias that may follow the ingestion of some drugs and chemicals was reported here yesterday.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Tornadoes swept Mississippi tonight, killing at least ten persons and injuring more than fifty.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Senate hearings into the United Auto Workers strike against the Kohler Company got off to a delayed start today on Republican terms.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Eisenhower made the following major points at his news conference today:
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 26 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion warned the Arab Federation of Iraq and Jordan today that Israel would be free to act if the Iraqi Army approached the Jordan River.
PARIS, Feb. 26 -- After three and a half months in office, the Cabinet of Premier Felix Gaillard appears to be on its way out.
Albert (Jack) Johnson, the world open court tennis champion, reached the semi-final round of the national open tournament yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- If you are a county chairman, it is better to elect a Governor than to control the Legislature.
WARSAW, Feb. 26 -- A resolution adopted unanimously last night by Parliament formally declared the years 1960 to 1966 as a period for celebrating the millennium of the Polish state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Government has ordered the building and construction trades unions to drop illegal closed-shop hiring arrangements by June 1 or face stiff penalties.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 26 -- The Indonesian Army announced tonight that forces loyal to Jakarta had seized control of the town of Gorontalo, in dissident north Celebes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Senator Jacob J. Javits called today for a study of the country's economy from the viewpoint of the consumer.
An eight-man advertising group has met with officials of the Internal Revenue Service and made "some progress" on revising a proposal to disallow institutional advertising as a business expense.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- State Department officials said today that they knew nothing of any discussions here on Rumania's reported application for export licenses.
TRENTON, Feb. 26 -- Dwight R. G. Palmer warned today that New Jersey must spend $2,750,000,000 to expand and modernize its highways in the next seventeen years.
The Borden Company achieved record earnings and sales last year, Harold W. Comfort, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Eisenhower said today that he had a "clear understanding" with Vice President Richard M. Nixon on what to do if the President should become unable to perform his duties.
Columbia University has asked the rector of Moscow University to visit this country in the spring as part of a cultural exchange program.

Walston Co., stock brokers with a home office in San Francisco, leased the ground floor and two upper floors in the former Seamen's Savings Bank Building at 72 Wall Street. The lessee will move its headquarters here from the West Coast and will have a customers' board room on the ground floor, an unusual arrangement for a Wall Street brokerage house.
New York City revenue will rise by about $1,000,000 this year as a result of an amendment to the sales tax regulations.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The French announced today that the Algerian rebels had started a major new offensive.
SILVERWARE manufacturers are elated over the anticipated rise in marriages this year.
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Feb. 26 -- The warhead of a Falcon missile was found tonight within sixty feet of the spot where the body of the missile was discovered a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- When the Truman Administration was looking around for a Secretary of Defense the name of Representative Carl Vinson was mentioned as a possibility. Mr. Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, heard about this and put it to sleep with this comment: "Shucks, I'd rather run the Pentagon from up here."

The mutual security program has no more to do with partisan politics than has the national defense. In fact, they are two facets of the identical problem. The point was well demonstrated in Washington when the topmost leaders of both political parties, beginning with President Eisenhower and former President Truman, outdid each other in enthusiastic support of this policy at an all-day conference called to emphasize America's stake in military and economic assistance abroad.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy disclosed yesterday that there had been a sharp increase in robberies in the city this year.

One of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's largest stockholders disclosed inadvertently yesterday that it had declined to expand its holdings under the latest offering of convertible debentures.

YOU can't keep a good octogenarian down. Bruno Walter was stricken with a heart ailment shortly after conducting the New York Philharmonic on March 8, 1957, and canceled all engagements until further notice. But he was back on the podium conducting the Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall last night, and the old touch was still there.
KHARTUM, the Sudan, Feb. 26 -- About 1,500,000 male Sudanese will vote tomorrow in the first general elections since the Sudan gained her independence two years ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Eisenhower turned a deaf ear today to Congressional farm bloc demands that "Benson must go."

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 13 to 31 points (65 cents to $1.55 a bale) yesterday. The market displayed strength during the afternoon with advances carrying the October and new crop July deliveries into new highs for the life of the contracts.

Summer housing can be rented again this year in the Hammels and Seaside areas of the Rockaways. But the Mayor's Committee on slum clearance says it will be the last season for properties that are to be taken over for housing projects.
Mary Barbara Williamson, a contralto from Cleveland who studied at the Eastman School of Music, sang a debut recital at Town Hall last night. She gave a generally satisfactory account of herself.
After five successive sessions of decline the stock market staged what was termed a solid technical rally yesterday that affected every major group in the list.

" DARK OF THE MOON," revived last night at the Carnegie Hall Playhouse, is a provocative mixture of fantasy and earthiness. In this oddly piquant production, the color of folklore and the pathos of human yearning are effectively combined.

The difficulties of squeezing a few million more dollars out of the House of Representatives for the American exhibit at the Brussels Fair should make every American ashamed. This is an international exhibition, which will really have the eyes of the world upon it, but the Soviet Union is going to spend something like five times as much on their exhibit as we are on ours.
Sales of the Radio Corporation of America rose to a new high last year, but earnings showed a slight decline, according to the report issued today by David Sarnoff, chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- The Reading Railroad reported today that its net income in January was 54 per cent below the 1957 levels. The earnings last month totaled $300,968, compared with $655,229. On a common share basis, earnings were 5 cents and 30 cents, respectively.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Shirley Temple will expand her theatrical activities by appearing as the guest of Dinah Shore on the "Chevy Show," May 4 on the National Broadcasting Company network.

HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- Cuba's magnificent new Sports Palace opened tonight on an exciting note. Joe Brown of New Orleans, the world lightweight champion, flattened Baby Echevarria, the champion of Cuba, in the first round.

Max Rudolf conducted Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier" last night for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House. He was an outstanding element in the production, which in its five previous showings was led by Karl Boehm.
Drinking was called a "serious threat" to the stability of families and communities yesterday by the governing board of the nation's largest federation of churches.
DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- The United Automobile Workers asked the General Motors Corporation today to lay off some employes instead of "constantly reducing the work week for all."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A program to supplement Venezuela's medical facilities and techniques for rehabilitating the crippled and handicapped will be sponsored by the Sinclair Venezuelan Oil Company.
Report to the curious who wondered about that cumbersome machine being installed yesterday in a Rockefeller Center show window:
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Directors of Diamond T Motor Car Company voted today to sell the business to the White Motor Company of Cleveland. Both companies make trucks.

The annual spring dance sponsored by the Junior Auxiliary of the New York Infirmary will be held March 21 at the Stork Club. Proceeds will go toward the auxiliary's pledge for a nursery in the new hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) -Temple University rolled to its twentieth straight victory tonight, overwhelming Lafayette, 77--54. , I Guy Rodgers of Tple led I the scorers with 21 points. The Owls led, 4020, at half-te. In the second ge of the double-head, St. Joseph's defeated LaSaUe, 8277.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today a bill to simplify the procedure for creating or extending street lighting districts in Suffolk County.
Management, labor and government agreed yesterday to pool their efforts to save the jobs of 672 persons employed at the Liberty Aircraft Products Corporation plant in Farmingdale, L. I.
BOON, Germany, Feb. 26 -- Prof. Werner Heisenberg, a Nobel Prize winner, said yesterday that he had worked out a mathematical formula from which the structure of the cosmos might be explained.

The trailership Bienville began loading at Port Newark yesterday for the start of new service by the Waterman Steamship Corporation of Puerto Rico from North Atlantic to Puerto Rican ports. She is scheduled to call at Wilmington, Del., today before proceeding to San Juan and Ponce.

Einstein devoted the last thirty-nine years of his life to the search for a unified field theory that, in one set of equations, would establish uniform physical laws to explain the universe from galaxies to atomic nuclei.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner struck back today at critics of his bill to strip the Supreme Court of authority to review lower court decisions in certain types of subversive cases.

TOKYO, Feb. 23 -- Two American productions have been named winners this year in an international motion picture competition sponsored by the Japanese Government. The prizes in this contest are extra allotments of jealously guarded foreign exchange, which the winning exhibitors may use to bring in more foreign films.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Eisenhower said today that "it will take some time to stop the recession." He made plain that the best he expected in March was some seasonal improvement in "job opportunities," not an actual upturn in general business.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Representative John E. Fogarty, Democrat of Rhode Island, today succeeded in earmarking $1,000,000 of this country's Brussels World Fair funds for a health exhibit.
These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook.

Two more books about the Civil War ]ave been announced for publication. Louisiana State University Press will issue March 10 "Doctors IrrGray: The Confederate MediCal Service," by H. H. Cunningham. It tells about the men behind the Confederate Armies who, with little or no training and experience in military medicine or surgery, facedmore than 3,000,000 cases of disease and wounds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Eisenhower's memory was apparently in error today in regard to Congressional support of foreign aid bills in 1957.
General Sessions Court was threatened yesterday with an invasion by the Egyptian Dragons unless seven teen-aged members of the gang being tried for murder were freed.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 -Pacifists opposing nuclear weapons mapped new plans today to sail into the area of the forthcoming United States atomic tests in the South Pacific.
Justus Heymans has been elected a senior vice president, overseas division, of Philip Morris, Inc. He was vice president of special projects and new development.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 -- It rained again today in sunny Florida, so Ed Roebuck, a Dodger pitcher, gave his opinions instead of his arm a workout.
THERE are those who do not agree that New York State has too many deer and that more deer ought to be harvested every year on an equal-sex basis. And these persons ought to be heard.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Artificial insemination was sharply criticized in the House of Lords today.

FLORENCE, Italy, Feb. 26 -- The public prosecutor asked today for the acquittal of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Prato and one of his parish priests, on trial here for criminal defamation of character.

THE most rewarding -- and the rarest -- of foreign observers is the one who sees in a country both the forest and the trees. He loses, of course, the heady pleasure of indiscriminate damnation or, if that happens to be his bent, unbridled praise. He does not single out one hobby horse to ride to death in his gallop through another nation's landscapes.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 (UP) -- A proposed cutback of New York Central Railroad passenger service, including reduction of the Empire State Express to local status, was protested today by cities along the railroad's main line in New York State.
Waterfront workers won most of the annual awards presented yesterday by the Life Saving Benevolent Association for rescues of persons in danger of drowning.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Most of Western Europe was snow-blocked tonight. But in Rome and Vienna people shed their overcoats in freak, spring-like weather.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The United States Army promised today "appropriate action" in the case of a Korean boy who was crated and carried off in a helicopter after he was caught stealing at a military base.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Slaughter steers brought as much as $36.50, the highest since that price was paid on Feb. 2, 1955, and equal to the highest since January, 1953.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 26 -- Taxpayers in the Purchase section of near-by Harrison filed suit in Supreme Court here today to halt the operation of the $11,000,000 Westchester County Airport.
Superintendent of Schools William Jansen disclosed yesterday that 726 pupils had been suspended in the crackdown on youthful troublemakers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that the Administration's $3,942,000,000 foreign aid request was a "rock-bottom" figure that could not be cut without seriously jeopardizing this country and the free world alliance.

A strike of 86,800 dress workers in seven Northeast states was authorized last night by 3,500 union shop chairmen. A walkout would be the first in twenty-five years in the billion-dollar-a-year industry.

While it is still too early to evaluate fully the results of sending roving crews of young patrolmen to critical intersections where pedestrian deaths have been highest, the plan is having one immediate and beneficial effect. Jaywalkers are beginning to heed the message that is the theme of the city's yearlong drive to cut pedestrian fatalities: "Cross on the green, not in between."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Administration is talking bluntly to head off a brush with Moscow over visits by high Soviet political figures.

Ski Sketch: Ron MacKenzie, postmaster at Lake Placid, N. Y., has been running on hickories ever since he was a teen-ager in World War I days. Now 55, he has a ready explanation why skiing fascinates so many.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Two thoroughbreds fell and one of them had to be destroyed today at the Bowie race course. The track has been in bad shape since a sixteen-inch snowfall Feb. 15.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The story about catching birds by putting salt on their tails may be a myth, but there are an increasing number of people who are catching trout by tickling their bellies with their fingers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Senate approved tonight, by a vote of 49 to 42, President Eisenhower's call for a 5-cent stamp on out-of-town letter mail. The present rate, in effect since 1932, is 3 cents an ounce for both local and nonlocal letters.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 26 -- St. Benedict's won the final event, an eight-lap relay, to capture the New Jersey independent schools' sixth annual state track championship today at Lawrenceville School's Lavino Field House.
Accomplish's success was a reminder of a 1949 tale of the turf. Accomplish's dam is the Clark broodmare Plunder.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 (AP) -The Forest City Publishing Company announced tonight the sale of radio station WHK to the Du Mont Broadcasting Corporation of New York. The transaction is subject to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission.
A price war in small appliances broke out yesterday, largely without the knowledge of the public. Store executives and their professional shoppers were the principal combatants.

Sales of the American Optical Company this year are expected to increase about 10 per cent above the record volume of $78,000,000 estimated for 1957, Victor D. Kniss, vice president and general manager of the Ophthalmic division, said yesterday.
A union of 272,00 telephone workers called on Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell yesterday to appoint a fact-finding board to pass in advance on the union's demands for higher pay.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 26 -- Western Governors called on the Eisenhower Administration today to push already authorized reclamation projects in the West as an antidote to rising unemployment.

The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway's earnings fell to $1,978,422 in January from $4,680,325 in the like month last year, as the road's freight carloadings lagged more than 9 per cent behind the 1957 level.

A retired admiral, two business executives and a California corporation were indicted yesterday by a grand jury in Federal court, Brooklyn, on charges of defrauding the Government of nearly $500,000 in a five-year period.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Without discussion or dissent, the Senate approved today a Republican bill to permit New York City to set up a Charter Revision Commission without a referendum.

Robert Briscoe, former Lord Mayor of Dublin, arrived here by air yesterday to promote Ireland to American tourists and investors. During a two-month tour of the United States and Canada, Mr. Briscoe, who is Jewish, also will help to sell Israeli bonds.

HAVANA, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Formal charges of manslaughter were filed today against the driver of a racing car that plunged out of control into a crowd of spectators during Monday's Gran Premio automobile race, killing seven persons and seriously injuring forty others.

The University of Utah last night became the seventh basketball team to accept a berth in the National Invitation Tournament starting March 13 at Madison Square Garden. The Utes won the event in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- George V. Allen, director of the United States Information Agency, said today that the Soviet Union's satellites had "dimmed temporarily the bright picture of the United States" as the world's technical leader.

A DESIRE for cleanliness is a woman's major reason for wanting a new house. This means not only new equipment and rooms, but also air conditioning and new, tight windows to help prevent the seepage of dust into the home.
OTTAWA, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian newsprint production, now almost half the total world output, may more than double to 12,500,000 tons by 1980.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Administration will ask Congress next month for an additional military appropriation of more than $1,300,000,000. Neil H. McElroy, Secretary...
Tennessee raised $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance highway construction by the sale of serial bonds at an interest cost of 2.687 per cent.

" Twinkling of an Eye," described as a modern morality play, by Hamilton Wright and the late Guy Andros, has been acquired for Broadway presentation next fall by Emmett Rogers. It calls for a company of fifteen speaking players and six non-speaking parts.

The twenty-seventh anniversary of Hunter College's Bronx division was celebrated at a Founders Day Convocation on the college's uptown campus yesterday.

A supervising inspector for the Department of Buildings was arrested yesterday on an indictment charging perjury and criminal contempt. The indictment had been handed up Monday by a grand jury investigating reports of graft and corruption in the department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The "conviction" expressed here under date of Feb. 19 that the President had taken steps to assure that the Vice President would take over his "powers and duties" if or when the President lay in a state of physical and/or mental disability to exercise them was confirmed by the President at his news conference today.
The year 1957 was "the best from an over-all view of any year in our history," Frederic W. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Army today appointed Lieut. Gen. Donald P. Booth as High Commissioner of the Ryukyus and commanding general of United States Forces on Okinawa.
LIVINGSTON, N. J., Feb. 26 -- A revolt aginst county tax procedures has developed in West Essex municipalities.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Poundage, without intending a pun, usually is a weighty matter for a ballplayer. Some are concerned with taking it off; others worry about putting it on.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26 -- Two refinery towns fifty miles south of Buenos Aires were placed under military rule tonight to prevent disturbances by striking Government oil workers.

In considering how high to raise hemlines this spring, experiment first on the extreme eighteen inches from the floor. Use double-edged tape to temporarily take up a straight skirt. Try it on in front of a full-length mirror to get the full effect.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Corn had the strange role of leader among grain futures gains on the Board of Trade today.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, Izler Solomon, Richard Tucker and Nathan Milstein will be among guest artists performing this spring and summer with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra in celebration of Israel's tenth anniversary.

PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 26 (AP) -- The proposal by a newspaper publisher to help combat the recession with a "Believe in America" campaign has drawn favorable comment from both of New Jersey's Senators and the Governors of four states.

In its first change of ownership in twenty years, the apartment house for twenty-two families at 2860 Creston Avenue, corner of Minerva Place, near the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been sold by Mrs. A. Campsen. It is assessed at $60,000 and was bought by an investing client of Norman Siegel.

An old suitor for the hand of the International Longshoremen's Association -- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters -- is scheduled to be a guest of honor today at a Miami meeting of the pier union's executive board.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 25 -- Premier Chivu Stoica said today that Rumania was ready to buy for cash more than $100,000,000 worth of industrial equipment from the United States but that difficulties over export licenses might compel her to place the orders in Western Europe.
BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- Walter Ulbricht, East German Communist leader, checkmated a move to oust him when he recently directed the disciplining of three high party officials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A bipartisan plan for reorganizing the Defense Department while preserving its basic structure was advanced today by leaders of the House Armed Services Committee.

Twentieth Century-Fox' "The Young Lions," co-starring Marlon Brando, Montgomery Clift and Dean Martin, has been scheduled to open at the Paramount Theatre early in April. Edward Dmytryk directed and the late Al Lichtman produced the adaptation of the novel by Irwin Shaw, which was filmed in Europe.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26 -- The fever of nationalism aroused by the union of Egypt and Syria has begun to cause serious fears for the independent future of Lebanon.

Musica Viva, which presented concert version of Purcell's "The Fairy Queen" last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, claimed it is a first New York performance.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt endorsed yesterday an $850,000 church and community house project for Puerto Ricans at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street. To be known as La Hermosa (the Beautiful), it will take the place of a store-front church of the same name at 66 East 110th Street.
LEMONT, Ill., Feb. 26 -- Plans for a major effort to tame plutonium for peaceful uses were announced today at the Argonne National Laboratory.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- A new state commission to protect consumers against unfair advertising and business practices would be created under legislation that has been introduced with a partial Republican blessing.

A junior committee headed by Miss Sheila Cobb has been chosen to work for the success of a theatre party for the benefit of Camp Green Acres, a family camp project of the New York City Mission Society.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A spokesman for the publicly supported colleges and universities of the United States opposed today any Federal scholarship program.
Garry Moore announced yesterday that he would retire from daytime television on May 23. His program began nearly eight years ago on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
ROQUEBRUNE-CAP-MARTIN, France, Feb. 26 (Reuters) -- Sir Winston Churchill, apparently recovered from his illness, plans to go through with his visit to President Eisenhower in April.

Directors of the American Snuff Company, Memphis, Tenn., declared yesterday the usual quarterly dividend of 70 cents and an extra 20 cents on common stock payable on April 1 to stockholders of record of next Thursday.

An understanding of atherosclerosis or hardening of the arteries -- an underlying cause of heart attacks and strokes -- may be gained during the next ten years, according to ten leading heart specialists.

John Gates, who resigned last month as a member of the Communist party and as editor of The Daily Worker, has received permission to speak at the six municipal colleges.

DR. ARTURO FRONDIZI, leader of the left-wing Intransigent Radicals won the Argentine Presidency this week largely with the help of voters who once supported his bitterest enemy, Juan D. Peron, the ousted dictator.

TRENTON, Feb. 27 -- Either Thorn Lord or Harrison A. Williams Jr. will be the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, party leaders said tonight. The disclosure followed a lengthy conference with Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Casey Stengel and his Yankees officially got off the mark today in quest of another American League pennant as infielders and outfielders joined the batterymen in the Bombers' first regular workout of the year.

The Thiokol Chemical Corporation of Trenton has agreed to purchase the principal assets of the Hunter-Bristol Corporation, of Bristol, Pa. Terms were not disclosed. The acquisition is subject to approval of Hunter-Bristol stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A Senate Antitrust subcommittee called on the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission today to investigate steel pricing for possible antitrust violations.

A shipping man who less than three years ago became the youngest captain in the American merchant marine was honored here yesterday for outstanding service to community and industry. He is Capt. Robert J. Wall of Farrell Lines.
Federal Communications Commissioner Richard A. Mack should resign.
The sixtieth anniversary dinner dance of the North Carolina Society of New York will be held tonight in the St. Regis Roof.

GENEVA, Feb. 27 -- The United States reaffirmed today its belief that national claims of sovereignty over a belt of sea extending more than three miles off coastlines were "not recognized by international law."
Even though Max Shulman sold his best-selling novel, "Rally Round the Flag, Boys!," to Twentieth Century-Fox, he held on to the stage rights.

STRATFORD, Conn., Feb. 27 -- Mrs. Franklyn Bulkley of Fairfield, president of the Junior League of Bridgeport, has announced that the league will sponsor a program, "April Rhapsody," featuring Roger Williams, pianist, and the French singing group Chanteurs de Paris on April 12 at the American Shakespeare Theatre here.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 -- Publicists at the National and American Broadcasting Companies here rejected today recently negotiated contract proposals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver announced today he was withdrawing his objection to the nomination of Axel J. Beck to be United States District Judge in South Dakota.
A $150 instrument to help physicians measure enzyme levels in blood samples in their offices was described here yesterday.

THE new Seven Arts Center, 120 Madison Avenue, is getting off to a start with a public showing in its art gallery, in a six-story building designed by Stanford White. Originally projected as the first "club" for women in New York, the center now houses two proscenium theatres, a theatre-in-the-round and the Ballet Russe dance school, as well as modern and Indian dance classes and a number of other activities connected with the various arts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Soviet Union has indicated a willingness to discuss at a heads-of-government meeting at least some of the topics proposed by President Eisenhower.
