PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27 -- At 9:30 A. M. today, a half-hour before practice, most of the San Francisco Giants were gathered in the dressing room exchanging bon roots, drinking coffee and walking around with no more clothing than is necessary to make the team with the Folies Bergere.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, twice delayed in their bid to become the new National Hockey League champions, tonight clinched their tenth title with a 4-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The steel industry will have to raise its prices to maintain financial health, if costs continue to rise, Joseph L. Block, president of the Inland Steel Company, told stockholders today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Government has abandoned attempts to open an exhibition in Moscow's Gorki Park this year.

Today's new screen offering is a double-bill program including "The Last Paradise" and "Satchmo the Great," at the Victoria Theatre. The former is an Aidart Pictures release, photographed in CinemaScope and color on islands in the South Pacific with a cast predominantly of native islanders.
Loans to business outstanding at the seventeen larger New York City banks increased $42,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

CHESTER LaROCHE and James Van Alen are dedicated men with similar missions. Famous athletes in their younger days, each is heading a drive to raise funds for the building of a hall of fame for the sports in which he excelled.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The way apparently was opened today for 32,000 Hungarian refugees to become permanent residents of the United States
Two world champions met yesterday in the semi-finals of the American open court tennis championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 -- The co-features at Hialeah Race Course today were the seventh and eighth races, a pair of six-furlong sprints for $5,000 purses. The contestants doubtlessly are held in high regard by their owners, but the races didn't provide much to write home about.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27 -- President-elect Arturo Frondizi has begun a detailed study of Argentina's problems. At the same time he is busy on reconciliation with groups that did not support him in last Sunday's elections.
DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- The number of jobless in Michigan has reached a total of 350,000, or 12 per cent of the labor force, The Michigan Employment Security Commission reported today.
Newell Jenkins, who conducted the second of three Clarion Concerts last night in Town Hall, is a man with a sense of style.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Corn futures were in fairly good demand again today on the Board of Trade and they added around a cent or more a bushel to all contracts while soybeans declined sharply under general selling.
PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Some of the most violent fighting thus far in the Algerian war has caused severe rebel losses but also considerable concern in Paris.
Following is the text of an address last night by former President Herbert Hoover before the New York Chamber of Commerce at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Glens Falls Insurance Companies showed gains in premium writing and investment income last year but recorded a loss from underwriting operations, G. D. Mead, president, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 18 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Eleven challengers were named today to race against Round Table, the solid favorite, in the $135,000 guaranteed Santa Anita Handicap Saturday.

The Sudan is holding its first full-fledged elections since becoming independent a little over two years ago. The voting began yesterday and the results will not be known until March 10. Communications are slow and the southern half of this vast country is primitive.

NYACK, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- Bipartisan village government has been approved by the Nyack and Spring Valley local political committees. The decision ignored the request of both Democratic and Republican county and state leaders to nominate a complete slate for village elections on March 18.

PAINTINGS and drawings by Clara Klinghoffer are being shown at the Juster Gallery, 154 East Seventy-ninth Street. The artist had established a reputation in England before coming to this country in 1939 and her draftsmanship had won enthusiastic comment from Jacob Epstein.

The thirty-nine-day-old mystery of the missing tugboat in Long Island Sound appeared to have been solved yesterday. The police reported that the thirty-seven-foot, Diesel-powered boat Jim Steers had been found in seventy feet of water 500 feet northeast of Stepping Stone Light.
A block of four Newfoundland airmail stamps was sold at auction yesterday for $17,000, a record price for the block. Only one other four-stamp block of the same issue is known to exist.
Robert A. Barnet, chairman of the American Irving Savings Bank, Manhattan, is retiring Saturday, but will continue as a trustee and honorary chairman.
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 26 -- The trial of former Capt. Henrique Galvao, accused of defaming high government officials, began behind closed doors yesterday.

The American Committee for Israel's Tenth Anniversary Celebration announced its plans yesterday amid expressions of support and congratulation from Governor Harriman, Mayor Wagner and two former Senators.
The 400 plant fossils stolen from a geology professor's car outside Brooklyn College on Wednesday night were safely back in his hands yesterday.
A store, to be occupied by Bonwit Teller, will be erected in the fifty-acre shopping center owned by the Prudential Insurance Company of America in Millburn, N. J.
The Zenith Radio Corporation's stockholders at a special meeting yesterday in Chicago approved a proposal to double the number of its outstanding shares on March 31.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Eisenhower was under bipartisan pressure from Congress today to make public the terms of his "clear understanding" with Vice President Richard M. Nixon on the Presidential disability question.
The Arthur Kill channel was blocked yesterday by a coal barge that sank after a collision with an oil tanker.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- If President Eisenhower asked Richard A. Mack to resign from the Federal Communications Commission and Mr. Mack refused, could the President dismiss him ?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Defense Department has given the Army permission to launch a third Explorer satellite.
The Union Pacific Railroad continued last month to make more on its oil and investment interests than on operating trains over its 9,700 miles of track.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles has asked four private citizens to advise him on disarmament policy.
The Television Bureau of Advertising reported yesterday that estimated ad expenditures in the medium last year were $1.315.000.000, compared with, $1,209,900,000 in 1956.
ONE night a little more than thirty years ago, Broadway was in an unusual hubbub. Searchlights with more than 2,000,000 candlepower held the new $10,000,000 Roxy Theatre in pallid brilliance.
THE chemise is bigger than ever -- in more ways than one.
The number of deaths believed to be attributable to wood alcohol poisoning in the city rose to thirteen yesterday.
Plans have been completed for the card party that will be held next Thursday in the Plaza for the benefit of the scholarship fund for the Texas Club of New York.
The Norfolk and Western Railroad, one carrier that appears to be immune to manage the ills that the railroad industry has been heir to lately, will have a new man at the throttle after March 31.
The first structure in the city to combine offices and apartments is soon to be built in Queens.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 -- Hollywood's old pros hold a comfortable numerical lead this year in the Academy Award races for best actor and actress.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 6.8 per cent below the like week of last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 6.7 per cent, compared with the same week last year, and orders down 16.2 per cent.

With the passing of Julia Steinway we have lost one of the most beloved personalities in the musical life of New York. She and her husband, Frederick, created the great tradition of the House of Steinway, which made their home the focal point for musicians in New York.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is studying the problems involved in an East-West heads-of-government conference. This was announced today by a spokesman for the organization's permanent council.
State Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan was chosen yesterday to head the New York County Republican Advisory Committee.
ATHENS, Feb. 27 -- Two members of the Greek Cabinet resigned today. Their action followed Premier Constantine Karamanlis' announcement that he had drafted a new electoral law.

Harold E. Stassen, who has just resigned as the President's adviser on disarmament, has advanced a new proposal for ending nuclear bomb tests. He proposes, in two articles published in this newspaper, that the United States and Soviet Russia agree between them at a summit meeting at United Nations headquarters in New York to suspend such tests unconditionally for a trial period of two years, subject to United Nations supervision.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Opposition appeared to be rising today in the House of Representatives to the 5-cent stamp for out-of-town letters voted yesterday by the Senate.
A new work and a first New York performance figured in last night's performance of the New York Philharmonic.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 27 (UP) -- The Iranian Government announced tonight that it had uncovered and foiled a plot to overthrow the Government.

IN the matter of television's coverage of addresses by the President of the United States additional facts have come to the fore. They cast a disquieting light on the exercise of journalistic independence by the networks.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 -- The United Community Funds and Councils of America today elected John A. Greene, board chairman of the Ohio Bell Telephone Company, president.

ONLY an opera company of the first rank can rise to the challenge of Verdi's "Otello" as the Metropolitan did last night. And only a cultivated public, which respects great art, knows how to appreciate this masterpiece as last night's gathering did.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A former sheriff of Sheboygan County, Wis., testified before Senate rackets investigators today that the Kohler Company strike had led to his being "bounced" from the Republican party.

A young delinquent who participated in the killing of 15-year-old Michael Farmer testified yesterday that the victim had been a member of the Jesters gang. He said young Farmer had told him this two weeks before the slaying July 30 in High Bridge Park.

WARSAW, Feb. 27 -- Poland's ruling Communist party has decided to dismiss superfluous industrial workers. The number may go up to 200,000, principally from the iron and steel and machinery industries.

Directors of the Aerojet-General Corporation have proposed a ten-for-one split of the company's common stock, Dan A. Kimball, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts at its luncheon yesterday at Schwartz' Restaurant, 54 Broad Street.
The Oldric Royce collection of custom-made clothes for spring is now ready and waiting at the designer's salon at 16 East Fifty-second Street.
Walter Slezak has the unusual assignment of starring in two successive plays on "The United States Steel Hour." One will be a light comedy and the other a historical drama.
An inquiry into possible links between city employes and the Communist party was started here yesterday by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The former Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Scotland, recently acquired by the Hamburg-Atlantik Line, has been renamed the Hanseatic. This was announced here yesterday by Home Lines, representatives for the new line in this country and Canada.

President Nasser of what we used to call Egypt, but for a week now head of the United Arab Republic, has been visiting in Damascus. His reception was extraordinarily cordial. The Syrians did not seem to feel that they had lost anything when their own former President, Shukri al-Kuwatly, stepped down to make room for the new leader.
Leading coffee roasters and supermarket chains announced yesterday a reduction in coffee prices. The new price level is the lowest it has been in five years.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- A speech by Christopher Soames helped the Conservative Government win two parliamentary victories for its defense policy tonight.
For ninety minutes yesterday morning, guests at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were restricted to three elevators. The forty-two story, 2,100-room hotel normally operates sixteen elevators.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Some encouraging company reports, yesterday's rally on Wall Street, and the rise in the pound sterling combined today to help the stock market extend its recovery. However, a few shares, notably industrials and oils, closed below their best.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Roy Cullenbine, a Detroit Tigers' scout, won low-gross honors in the St. Petersburg baseball players' golf tournament today with a 38, 36 -- 74.
It could have been a movie. It was the annual meeting of Loew's Inc., held yesterday at Loew's State, a motion-picture theatre on Broadway.
The premiere of the motion picture "Theodore Roosevelt -- American" was shown yesterday at the birthplace of the nation's twenty-sixth President, 28 East Twentieth Street.

A campaign luncheon for their committee members will be given in the Edwardian Room of the Plaza today by Mrs. June Blossom and Mrs. Cleveland F. Bacon. They are chairman and vice chairman of the Neighbors March for Nephrosis Women's Committee of the Nephrosis Foundation of New York March has been proclaimed Nephrosis Month by Mayor Wagner.
Governor Harriman warned yesterday that unless the current economic recession was checked, a "sharp increase" in discrimination and group tensions at home would follow.
Herbert Hoover predicted last night that if world peace prevailed the current recession would not become a 1929 type of depression.
The Board of Estimate has decided to use plans for a thirty-six-foot roadway as the basis for official public discussions on how to carry automobile traffic through Washington Square.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Three men were found guilty tonight in a trial involving charges of police corruption in Brighton, a British seaside resort. Two other defendants, including Brighton's police chief, were declared not guilty.

One is quite amused these days, I think, to hear diatribes on American education from perfectly virtuous Government sources. The whole procedure is so obviously a political attempt to "pass the buck" for the Government's own failure in the missile and rocket field.
James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, announced yesterday a re-alignment of responsibilities of his executive staff.
RUMBAI, Indonesia, Feb. 26 -- The revolt against the Indonesian Government has put a squeeze on the operations of the big Caltex Pacific oilfields in this part of Central Sumatra.
TRENTON, Feb. 27 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called on the Legislature today to approve without delay the tax increases he has requested.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 27 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser said here tonight that "we shall fight against imperialist stooges" in Iraq and Jordan.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Representatives of the food industry urged at a public hearing today that state legislation to regulate chemical additives in food be deferred until Congress has acted on the problem.

Seven tugboat captains in New York Harbor were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of evading a total of $18,797 in income taxes. The evasion occurred between 1951 and 1954, the indictment charged.

Potato futures fell as much as 20 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) in early trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices were depressed by overnight selling orders, following Wednesday's limit declines.

George Eichhorn, the engineer on Diesel 2008, which pulls the Long Island's 7:04 A. M. out of Sayville, L. I., retired yesterday. And because it was a memorable occasion, a blind woman and her dog rode in the cab with him.
TUNIS, Feb. 27 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia protested vigorously today against the French Government's decision to set up a No Man's Land of scorched earth on the Algerian frontier.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it had leased a second blockfront on Park Avenue to Uris Brothers, builders.

A mineral investigation laboratory, said to be uncommon in mining, has been put into operation by the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation at its experimental research station in Mulberry, Fla.

The New York Allergy Society last night honored a man whose own trouble with horses impelled him to found a lasting medical specialty. His trouble was not betting on horses: it was simply being near them.
Two policemen were arrested early today and accused of striking a woman and pointing a pistol at her son. Both were charged with felonious assault.
BOLTON, England, Feb 27 (AP) -- An airliner crashed today into a blizzard-whipped mountain, killing thirty-five men.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower created today an emergency board to investigate a wage dispute between seven major airlines and about 25,000 mechanics.
Thousands of drenched but determined shoppers jammed city stores yesterday to snap up bargains in radios and small home appliances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Air Force received approval today for a new project to produce an advanced type of ballistic missile whose range can be varied from 500 to 5,500 miles. The project is called Minute Man. It envisages underground installations, harboring solid-fuel ballistic missiles, several miles apart to make them less vulnerable to attacks.
Union employes of the Consolidated Edison Company last night ratified terms of a new contract that had been challenged last week by some of the rank and file.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Richard A. Mack fought today for his job on the Federal Communications Commission.

A syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. is offering for public subscription today an issue of $12,000,000 of first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds of the California Electric Power Company. The bonds are priced at 101.656, to yield 4.4 per cent to maturity in 1988.

NEWARK, Feb. 27 -- A civil suit seeking an injunction against low-flying plane operations over populated areas in the vicinity of Newark Airport was dismissed today on all counts. Federal Judge William F. Smith ruled that any court-ordered modification of operation rules would be an "unwarranted interference" with the regulatory power of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 -- The Communist party approved tonight Nikita S. Khrushchev's revolutionary plan to abolish machine-tractor stations. These have served and supervised the nation's collective farmers for nearly thirty years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted today to give President Eisenhower nearly all the funds he sought to run the Treasury and Post Office Departments in the fiscal year starting July 1.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that the Administration would "take whatever action is necessary" to halt any recession. But he warned that "acting too fast and too extensively can only lead to a renewal of inflation."

Executive Ignorance of Health? It would be interesting to know how many business men who attended the American Management Association's annual marketing conference here the other day on their return home promptly visited their physicians for physical examinations.
LITTLE shavers often balk at a haircut. But each week, Best Co. trims the locks of at least 600 wriggly customers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

FUERSTENWALDE, Germany, Feb. 27 -- One mechanized regiment of Soviet troops left this little garrison town thirty miles east of Berlin today. Speakers at a farewell ceremony said this began a planned reduction of the Soviet Army.
Meyer Lansky, who is said to control gambling in Cuba and other places, was acquitted of a vagrancy charge yesterday in Manhattan Arrest Court.
A majority of the companies that haul building material to construction sites reached an agreement here last night with striking truck drivers.
THE news for food shoppers is dismal again this week.

A floor and one-half in the new office building at 405 Park Avenue, at Fifty-fourth Street, have been leased by the Kennedy-Van Saun Manufacturing and Engineering Corporation of Danville, Pa. The lessee is one of the world's largest manufacturers of cement-making, lime-crushing and mining machinery and will use the space for its New York headquarters.
Day Care Week, which will be proclaimed by Mayor Wagner from March 3 to 9, will be opened with a breakfast reception for city and state officials at the Roosevelt Hotel on Monday.
The Board of Education's plans to open a temporary school on Monday in Greenwich Village for suspended pupils ran into strong opposition yesterday from residents of the area.

The election of J. V. Naish as president of the Convair division of the General Dynamics Corporation, succeeding Gen. Joseph T. McNarney (U. S. A., ret.) was announced yesterday by Frank Pace Jr., president of the parent concern, following a meeting of the directors in San Diego, Calif.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The number 7 may be lucky, but in the case of the Los Angeles Dodgers it is a puzzling one, leading to trade talk that is being vehemently denied.

A twelve-story and penthouse apartment building is planned at 311-19 East Sixty-ninth Street where a plot 121 by 100 feet has been purchased by a client of Mitchell Seigel, attorney. The property was sold by Hugh K. McGovern, who bought it three years ago.
Maurice Frere, former Governor of the National Bank of Belgium and of the International Monetary Fund, has been elected to the board of the Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., Toronto, Ont.

The season's second meeting between the Manhattan College and New York University quintets was a duplicate of their first -- no contest. The National Collegiate tourney-bound Jaspers outdrove and outshot the Violet Vikings and romped to a 95-77 victory before 4,018 fans at Madison Square Garden last night.
THANKS to the electronic range the high school boys who received a public chiding for taking cooking classes rather than science courses may yet have their day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A diminished backlog of unexpended funds is one reason the Administration is concerned about Congress' cutting its $3,942,100,000 foreign aid request.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Legislature's fiscal committees reported out Republican bills today that would require affirmation by a majority of eligible voters in a locality as a condition for legalizing bingo.
YOU can expect an outburst of fruit fever this spring. For example, take Ohrbach's, which has turned to orchards and berry patches for all the colors in its new spring accessories.
LAKEHURST, N. J., Feb. 27 -- An obsolete Navy blimp, turned runaway on a gusty, rainy night, gave aircraft pilots along the East Coast five troubled hours early today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Instead of praising President Eisenhower for taking the first constructive step in American history to provide for continuous, legal and orderly Executive government in event of the physical and/or mental disability of a President who cannot or will not announce this, Democrats in Congress today were concentrating on criticism.
An amusing twin bill was staged yesterday at City Hall, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa got the money for his new Cadillac and the Board of Estimate got a lecture for voting it.
WASHINGTON, Feb, 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's new Ambassador would like to see top Russian leaders visit the United States and American leaders go to Russia.
The P. Lorillard Company had the highest unit volume, dollar sales and profits in its history last year, Lewis Gruber, president, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Ships flying flags of convenience were described here today as the "modern freebooters" of the world's sea routes.
Mayor Wagner called on union and employer negotiators yesterday to "expend every effort" to ward off a strike of 86,800 dressmakers in seven Eastern States.

In a highly irregular session that saw small gains peppered throughout the list, stocks returned yesterday to their briefly interrupted downward trend. For the sixth time in seven sessions they closed lower.

The President's message to Congress a few days ago made out a very strong case for a large foreign aid program. It pointed to the military and economic needs of our allies and of the uncommitted countries. It stressed the dangers of our neglecting those needs in an attempt to save expenses now -- only to face far more expensive consequences later on.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Revised figures today placed the state pay of the chief adviser of Assembly Democrats slightly above the salaries of Chief Justice Earl Warren and Chief Judge Albert Conway of the Court of Appeals.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Persons convicted of a single crime would have their police records sealed under the provisions of a bill that has been introduced in the Legislature again by Senator Harry Gittleson, Brooklyn Democrat.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 -- Mutuel-window ticket-cashiers at the Hialeah race track have been on the alert since last Tuesday to make an extra-careful study of every ticket. Counterfeiters have been at work at the horse park -- with a near-perfect prodduct.

An announcement by the Massachusetts Heart Association of the discovery and development of a new anti-coagulant drug, derived from bread mold, may well be a medical milestone in our times. Work has been going on for ten years. Animal subjects have been widely used.
The General Telephone Corporation increased total revenues and net income in 1957, Donald C. Power, president, reported yesterday.

With new crop months setting the pace, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were strong yesterday. All contracts from October forward set new highs for the life of the contracts. Final prices were 13 to 45 points above the preceding close.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 27 -- A serpentine queue of men, their dark shiny faces set off by gleaming white turbans and flowing white robes, passed slowly into a brown mud police building. When they came out again the fingers of their left hands had been painted with indelible ink to show that they had voted in the Sudan's first general elections since it became independent.
Directors of the Anaconda Company, the third largest American copper producer, yesterday reduced the quarterly common dividend to 50 cents a share, payable March 31, from 75 cents paid in December.

"ANGRY HARVEST,"* a first and in all probability last novel by Hermann Field and Stanislaw Mierzenski, is a massive, powerful and morally earnest book that commands respectful admiration. That this should be so is altogether extraordinary because the mere fact that "Angry Harvest" was written at all is remarkable enough.
ABILENE, Karl., Feb. 27 (AP) -- A nation-wide campaign was started today to raise $3,300,000 to build an Eisenhower Presidential Library in Abilene.
The annual Three Choir Festival of Congregation Emanu-El will be presented at Temple Emanu-El on Friday and Saturday, March 14 and 15. It will be under the direction of Lazare Saminsky.
An expert in welfare budgets said here last night that the Eisenhower Administration was not spending enough for health and security.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Bowie race track, handicapped by the elements for the past ten days, today called off tomorrow's racing program to give its grounds crew time to fix some of the ruts in its weather-beaten racing strip.

The action of the pound sterling here early yesterday reflected a rumor and the law of supply and demand. Lionel D. Perera of Lionel Perera, Manfra Brookes, foreign exchange dealers, first became aware something was afoot when he began to receive more than the usual number of inquiries and orders to buy pounds.

There's plenty of youthful bounce in the eighty-two-year-old Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America. The I. C. 4-A will unveil one of its finest groups of sophomore athletes in its thirty-seventh indoor track and field championships tomorrow.

Events today: Bizet's "Carmen," special student performance, Metropolitan Opera House, 1 o'clock; Puccini's "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale, duo-pianists, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, declared today that he was not interested in forming an often-rumored new Federation of Transport Workers Unions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Air Force relieved its commander in the Philippines today on the ground that he had undermined morale by over-lavishly redecorating four sets of living quarters on Luzon.

Safer boating is every skipper's aim these days. Among the thousands of newcomers to recreational pleasure boating preaching the doctrine of safety are important increments of Young America known as the Boy Scouts.

Carlos Ortiz, an undefeated lightweight from the Bronx, and Tommy Tibbs of Boston will meet in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The scheduled ten-round contest will mark the first appearance for each contestant in a Garden main event.

San Antonio, Tex., received bids yesterday on an issue of $5,000,000 of general obligations maturing serially from 1959 to 1978. The best bid was an interest cost of 3.1121 per .cent, submitted by a syndicate headed by First National City Bank of New York.
Sales and earnings of the American Tobacco Company rose to new highs in 1957, Paul M. Hahn, president, announced in a report issued to stockholders today.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- In a small office off Parliament Square there hangs a map of the world dotted with blue, red and green flags. Each one represents a chapter in Britain's effort to stop counterfeiting of her gold coin -- the sovereign.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 492,389 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
ALL lovers of figures who read these words in the United States or abroad are saluted by the archers of the Eastern seaboard, who are hereby about to turn themselves loose statistically.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Congressional Joint Economic Committee, with only one dissent, said today that the recession had not reached the point where a tax cut was necessary.
Bank clearings for twenty-six leading cities in the week ended last Wednesday were $20,884,161,000, an increase of 7 per cent above those of the like 1957 week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 27 -- The Town Commission today announced it would not fluoridate the municipal water supply. It said the decision was made despite the "inescapable conclusion that fluoridation would be beneficial."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- Tunisia lodged two new complaints with the Security Council today, charging France with violating an agreement to refrain from violence pending efforts to settle their dispute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Following are excerpts from the testimony by Richard A. Mack, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, before the Special House Sub-committee on Legislative Oversight:
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP} -- Corn futures, with their two-day advances of about 3 cents a bushel, ran into resistance today on the Board of Trade and all deliveries except March closed with small losses.

Earnings of the Union Oil Company of California rose last year to a new high of $38,235,535, or $4.95 a common share, Reese H. Taylor, chairman, reported yesterday. Net income in 1956 was $34,240,878, or $4.44 a share.

The Congressional Joint Economic Committee, with only Senator Paul Douglas of Illinois dissenting, has decided that the business recession has not reached the point where a tax cut is necessary. Senator Douglas, on the other hand, believes that "the time to act has arrived."

The Northern Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday operating revenues of $128,615,204 last year, against $111,279,605 in 1956. Net income of $15,213,786, equal to $3.74 a share, compared with $14,538,308, or $3.56 a share, in 1956. The 1957 earnings included 28 cents a share of revenues collected under bond since last Aug. 27.

Your editorial of Feb. 24 "Politics and Jobless Pay" reiterates the suggestion made several times previously in your columns that there is need for an objective appraisal of New York's social insurance laws and states that the Consumers League program "goes far to fill that bill."
President Eisenhower yesterday commended the Little Red Schoolhause for its work in "searching out new paths for the training of free citizens."
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The Air Force fired today the first Thor missile fitted with the critically important re-entry nose cone.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Princeton upset Dartmouth, 53 -- 46, tonight with a tenacious defense, but the Indians clung to their one-game lead in the Ivy League basketball race as second-place Penn lost to Harvard.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- No. 39 never will be worn by a Dodger player again unless Roy Campanella, who has worn 39 on his shirt for years, returns to the Los Angeles line-up.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Government reversed its position today in a long-standing case on the question of protection for American industry against imports.
Albert (Jack) Johnson, world open court tennis champion, retained his American open title yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
Gimbels managers, with shirt sleeves rolled up, acted as sales clerks and stock boys yesterday to serve customers clamoring for cut-price small home appliances.
Today will be Red Cross Sabbath in many of the synagogues of New York. Tomorrow churches in the metropolitan area will observe Red Cross Sunday.

The newness of today's fashions makes last season's tightly fitted dresses look dowdy. To be "1958," a dress has to flow from shoulder to hem, and suggest, rather than define, the shape of the wearer.
MIAMI Feb. 28 -- The executive council of the International Longshoremen's Association has taken new steps to increase its control over the union's locals and districts, once virtually. autonomous.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Following is the text of the statement read by Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, and chairman of the Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight, and remarks by Richard A. Mack, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, during latter's testimony:

A tea dance to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the founding of The Finch News, the student publication of Finch College, will be held next Saturday in the Gold Room of the Savoy-Plaza. Proceeds will go to the general scholarship fund of the college.

In another column on this page we publish a letter from Royal W. France which, like a similar letter published on this page on Jan. 21, denies that the Soviets agreed at the Geneva summit meeting to a reunification of Germany by means of free elections and later repudiated this agreement.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- A leading Soviet scientist said today that United States, British and Soviet physicists seeking to harness thermonuclear energy for peaceful uses would never be fully honest with one another until atomic and hydrogen weapons were banned.

Madison Square Garden will resound to the excitement of The Old College Try today. The Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America takes over the arena for its thirty-seventh annual indoor track and field championships. There'll be day and night sessions, starting at noon and 8 P. M.
President Ngo Dinh Diem of Vietnam announced yesterday approval by his government of twelve industrial projects for the economic development of his country.
The crew of the ocean-going tug Joseph H. Moran II has a new name for the skipper. He is now called "Shanghai" Jenkins.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 28 -- The movement of shipping in Colombo port was considerably hampered today as a result of a strike by 750 workers of the port's operational staff.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Five players from Minnesota, Johnny Mayasich, Paul Johnson and the three Christian brothers, led the United States to a 12-4 victory over Poland tonight on the opening day of the world amateur hockey championship.
MARIA MENEGHINI CALLAS is a convincing, stirring Tosca. In her first appearance this season at the Metropolitan in the title role of Puccini's opera, she sang and acted with style and intensity.
DOVER, Del., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Stockholders in Servel, Inc., have rejected a proposal that the company pay off more than $700,000 of back dividends to preferred stockholders.
A future generation of housewives is sharpening its domestic claws.

PRESTONSBURG, Ky., Feb. 28 -- A school bus carrying forty-one children plunged today over a fifty-foot cliff into the Big Sandy River. The state police said that twenty-seven children and the bus driver had drowned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A patent was awarded this week for appartus with which a cook can fry twenty-four eggs in three and a quarter minutes. The inventor makes good use of the equipment; he is food service manager at the Virginia State Penitentiary in Richmond.

Two films will open at first-run theatres today, "The Awakening," an Italian-made drama starring Anna Magnani, is at the Little Carnegie. The Riz zoli-Pallavacini Production was directed by Mario Camerini. Eleonora Rossi Drago and Antonio Cifariello are among the featured players in the Kingsley International release.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- American President Lines, Ltd., and the Federal Maritime Board today signed a $29,132,000 contract for the construction of two Searacer merchant ships by the Bethlehem Pacific Coast Steel Corporation of San Francisco.

IT was Peter Fleming, if memory serves, who, on entering Japan in the tense years before World War II, was asked to state why he was there and replied with the single word "espionage." This, the legend goes, flabbergasted the war lords' minions. But they let him in, nevertheless. If you think that's a pretty tall story, wait till you read his new book, "My Aunt's Rhinoceros."*
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 28 -- A tense situation has developed between the two new Arab alliances -- the United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria and the Arab Federation of Iraq and Jordan.

Events today: Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera House, 1:30; Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" and Strauss' "Salome," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30; New York Philharmonic, Jacques Abram, pianist, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Caryl Chessman lost today another appeal in his ten-year fight to avoid death in the gas chamber.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Governor Harriman signed a bill today extending the effective day of the Youth Court Act until April 1, 1959.
Market financing was assured yesterday for fulfillment of the first step in the plans of Los Angeles, Calif., to take over and expand the privately owned transit systems that serve the city.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Governor Harriman today directed Arthur L. Reuter, acting Commissioner of Investigation, to expand his inquiry into official corruption in Ulster County to eight other Hudson Valley counties. All are Republican strongholds.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Almost thirty years ago Joseph A. McGinnies, a veteran of the legislative wars, volunteered some advice to a young and ambitious Republican lawyer from Brooklyn.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 -- One of the most important cold war propaganda centers is Tashkent, capital of the Soviet Republic of Uzbekistan and largest city in all Central Asia. From that sprawling, jerry-built metropolis within sight of the great Tien Shan range of mountains that divides the U. S. S. R. from China, a powerful radio disseminates Communist propaganda in most of the languages of the Orient.

Drury Gallagher, a 19-year-old Fordham sophomore, broke two meet records in winning three events at the twelfth Metropolitan Collegiate Swimming Association qualifying heats in New York University's pool last night.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The British Labor party warned its 630 constituency parties today to have nothing to do with the Victory for Socialism group, which has rebelled against the party's leadership and policy.

In December, 1928, Jean Cocteau enter a clinic in St. Cloud, France, to be cured of opium addiction. His observations and reflections during a four-month confinement are set down in words and drawings in "Opium." Among the subjects Cocteau discusses are the clinical details of his cure, his literary opinions, film making and meetings with Proust and Nijinsky.

The city will make a new attempt Monday to upset a 1956 ruling by the State Education Commissioner that public school teachers cannot be compelled to identify other teachers who are or were Communist party members.

ROME, Feb. 28 -- Legal experts from East and West, meeting for the first time since World War II, have discussed ways of harmonizing their law practices in matters of foreign trade and nationalizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -Harold E. Stassen said today he was convinced that a two-year trial halt on nuclear weapons tests, with inspection safeguards, could be negotiated with the Soviet Union within six months.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 16 to 25 points yesterday. The drop equaled 90 cents to $1.25 a bale.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -The Defense Department announced today plans for the Air Force to develop long-range ballistic missiles that would be powered with new solid fuels.

FONDUTA, a cross between a Swiss fondue and Welsh rarebit, is a cheese dish peculiar to the north Italian province of Piedmont. A reader who remembers savoring the dish at a restaurant in Turin would like to know how it is made.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 -- A blistering indictment of industrial managers and local political bosses who feathered their nests at the expense of the workers was issued today by Yugoslav League of Communists.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -Like most men, the United States postman is being bossed more and more by women.
AT the end of "Children of Darkness," which was acted last evening at Circle in the Square, one character is generous to another.
Sidney Hodes, a friend of Johnny Dio, convicted labor racketeer, was arrested yesterday on a charge of coercion on the complaint of a reporter for El Diario, a Spanish newspaper.
A stolen automobile, carrying two men who were fleeing the police, injured five women last night when it mounted a sidewalk and crashed through a waiting line at a Brooklyn bus stop.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb, 28 -- The head of the United Jewish Appeal declared here today that Israel lacked the funds to carry out settlement programs for immigrants.
STOWE, Vt., Feb. 28 -- One hundred thirty-seven boys and thirty-four girls aged 14 through 17 competed in the United States Eastern amateur giant slalom championship on Spruce Peak today.
The police in Queens broke up two armed groups of juveniles last night -- one on a tip that a gang battle was planned. Thirty boys were arrested.
Volume sagged in the stock market yesterday and prices, though higher, were noticeably so only in specialties.
Offerings of public utility bonds and stocks in the capital market here in February were above the 1957 level. But tax-exempt bond flotations accounted for most of the new issues marketed.

ADEN, Feb. 20 -- A British official of this Crown Colony at the tip of the Arabian Peninsula pointed out the window of his creaking, nineteenth-century office, across the busy harbor of Aden. Beyond stretched seventy miles of lifeless desert to an escarpment of purple mountains that marks the beginning of the ancient, still-feudal kingdom of Yemen.
HAVANA, Saturday, March 1 -- Cuba's Roman Catholic hierarchy called last night for a "national union government" to halt bloodshed in the rebellion-torn island and restore "normal political life."

Flooding disrupted local train service on the BMT subway for more than eleven hours yesterday between Pacific Street and Twenty-fifth Street stations, Brooklyn. There was four feet of water near the DeKalb Avenue station.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 28 -- The Board of Freeholders voted 7 to 2 today to adopt a record 1958 budget of $29,023,733. This is $1,890,530 higher than last year's. Its passage stirred wide complaints from municipal officials throughout Hudson County.
FRANCONIA, N. H., Feb. 28 -- You can't ski if you can't see.
The May 19 performance of "Say, Darling," at the ANTA Theatre will benefit the Brotherhood Scholarship Fund of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.
The Canadian Pacific Railway had a net income of $578,356 during January in contrast to a $3,383,759 deficit in the 1957 month.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Critics of President Eisenhower's handling of a shotgun in a recent photograph prompted the President to tell a story that was retold last night by George M. Humphrey, former Secretary of the Treasury.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that John A. Roosevelt cannot use the word Republican in the name of his political club without the consent of Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader of New York County.

BATON ROUGE, Feb. 28 (AP) -- John Barnum and Ken Venturi shot three-under-par 69's today to climb into a three-way tie with Arnold Palmer for the 36-hole lead in the $15,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

Heavy rains, high winds and continued thaws caused minor flood conditions in many sections of New Jersey, Connecticut and Long Island Thursday night and yesterday. Some concern was expressed about communities in the Naugatuck Valley in western Connecticut, which was hard hit by floods in 1955.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board took under advisement today a two-year-old case designed to expand local airline service to a seven-state region in the Midwest.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A Senate investigator told today of preparations for a violent strike made by the Kohler Company in 1952, about the time the plant union joined the United Auto Workers.
Information accusing the Nassau Management Company of defrauding the city on tenant relocation contracts was sent to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
Stocks declined last month in the slowest trading since September.
The deaths of three more East Harlem residents yesterday brought the toll of those known or believed to have died from the drinking of wood alcohol to sixteen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The wholesale price index of average primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent to 119.2 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 (UP) -Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
Myron Cohen, who took advantage of a confusion of names to walk out of the Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn on non-existent bail last July, was recaptured last night in Manhattan's Garment District.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 28 -- Premier Djuanda's Cabinet won a vote of confidence in Parliament tonight. The vote was on the Government's antiDutch campaign, which is aimed at getting Netherland New Guinea from The Netherlands.
THE Girl Scouts of this country have made a discovery: Boy Scouts.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 28 -Prof. Werner Heisenberg, a renowned nuclear physicist, believes he may have discovered a new constant in nature -- the "shortest length."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -The Senate approved tonight a bill increasing postal rates by more than $700,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -The chairman of the House investigating subcommittee told Richard A. Mack today that the "best possible service" he could render would be to resign from the Federal Communications Commission.
The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy of Stratford, Conn., will expand its activities next summer to include an educational project for college and nonprofessional theatre craftsmen.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Nearly four years ago perhaps the most extensive forest survey in history got under way in Brazil with the cooperation of the United Nations technicalassistance program. Its aim is to assess the productive potential of the Amazon jungle, the "green hell" of modern fiction writers.
The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham was named "Salesman of the Year" last night by the Sales Executives Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations asked Congress today to reject a bill to remove the Supreme Court's authority to pass on anti-Communist laws.

Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan yesterday ordered Lowell M. Birrell, financier, to pay a $3,256,639 judgment to the Dynamics Corporation of America "for the frauds committed upon the corporation by Birrell."
LONDON, Feb. 28 (UP) -Europe fought floods today in the wake of a series of blizzards.
A special grand jury in Queens has recommended legislation that would make it a crime for a company to place checked-off union dues in its general corporate account.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The nation's wheat surplus is expected to rise about 103,000,000 bushels next year, canceling an anticipated decline this year, the Department of Agriculture said today.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The stock market ended the week on a cheerful note with British Government funds continuing to lead the way.
DETROIT, Feb. 28 (AP) -Motor vehicle output in United States factories this week will total 93,025 cars and 18,415 trucks, Ward's automotive reports said today.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- Japanese newspaper correspondents moving more or less freely in Communist China were reported today to be threatened with reprisals for what Peiping regards as a "hostile attitude" by the Japanese Government and press.
The chairman of a local school board, in whose district a school for suspended pupils will be opened on Monday, threatened legal action yesterday against the city Board of Education.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Two of Britain's major opera companies, the Sadler's Wells and the Carl Rosa, plan to merge to overcome financial difficulties.

Two more leading gasoline suppliers -- the Esso Standard Oil Company and Socony Mobil Oil Company -- will raise wholesale prices today in several Eastern states. The move follows similar action early this week by the Gulf Oil Corporation.

The twelve-story building containing seventy-two apartments at 645 West End Avenue, southwest corner of West Ninety-second Street, has been sold by the 645 Realty Corporation to 645 Associates, Inc., for investment. The property, 136 by 100 feet, is assessed at $565,000.

The new capital market is heavily congested.
The New York Naval Militia, the naval equivalent of the state's National Guard, has begun to make plans for its own demise in case its funds are not restored to the budget.

The appointment of John S. Andrews as general manager of Ford-Werke A. G., Ford Motor Company subsidiary in Cologne, Germany, was announced in Dearborn, Mich., yesterday, following a meeting of the Ford-Werke directors.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- France's long agony in North Africa, brought to a new crisis by the Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef bombing and its aftermath, is poisoning the relations of Frenchmen among themselves and with the rest of the world.
Israel's United Nations delegation building at 15 East Seventieth Street was damaged yesterday morning by a fire that tied up traffic in the area for about two hours.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- For a change there may be a degree of permanency to the Yankee infield this year -- at least around second base. But a lot depends on how matters progress in left field.

Latin America is worried about imports of coffee by the United States from Africa. Yesterday, in Washington, Ernani Do Amaral Peixoto, the Brazilian Ambassador, spelled out the problem. The curtain on the final act of another corporate drama -the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad proxy dispute -- was lifted a little yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Unemployment among workers covered by the unemployment compensation system rose to a record in mid-February, the Labor Department reported today. WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Eisenhower has cut the Gordian knot at which Congress has been plucking listlessly for 169 years. His "clear understanding" with Vice President Nixon, whereby the latter temporarily will exercise the "powers and duties" of the Presidency if or when the President becomes incompetent to function, provides for such an emergency in this Administration.

Margaret Harshaw sang the role of Isolde for the first time this season in a rather routine performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The price of potatoes, one of the staples of the American diet, has been climbing. Quotations in the New York wholesale market are the highest at this time of the year since 1952. Retail prices have advanced correspondingly.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Senator William F. Knowland asked President Eisenhower today to consider returning to home markets some of the foreign buying the Government was doing under the Mutual Security Program.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- Democrats pressed at party rallies tonight charges that President Eisenhower was showing "weak" and "inadequate" leadership amid mounting national problems.
