However, in his summation on how to cope with the situation, Mr. Bacon does not mention the fact that we rely on preventive meaures in the treatment of other diseases.

I READ with great interest Donald Davidson's review of the "Letters of Ellen Glasgow." I am completely at a loss, however, to understand Mr. Davidson's query "What, then, sustained her?" (meaning Miss Glasgow, of course) and his speculation following the question.

AFTER a lapse of almost four years, Boston and Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, again are to be linked by overnight steamship service. The same ship that once made the run, the Yarmouth, is scheduled to resume the trips on June 30, from Boston, and through the season until the last trip from Yarmouth on Sept. 14.
The same cup of bitter tea. That about sums up the present recession as compared with the two previous ones since World War II -- in 1948-49 and 1953-54.

THIS comes as a sort of rebuttal to the letter signed "An American Conductor." Without meaning to be a traitor to my own, how many of our American conductors are really well-trained enough to assume a major podium ? How many are really steeped in the cultural background necessary to make a well-rounded, mature, introspective conductor?
BONN, Germany, March 1 -West Germany's longest street tunnel, a 900-yard passage under the city of Stuttgart, is scheduled to be opened this month.

BRUSSELS, March 1 -- Officials responsible for the United States exhibition at the 1958 world's fair opening here next month were surprised to learn that they might be ordered to spend $1,000,000 for a "health for peace" exhibit.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 1 -- Round Table raced to victory by some two lengths in the $135,000 Santa Anita Handicap and set a track record for the mile-and-a-quarter distance.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 1 -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club frostbite skippers defeated the Huntington (L. I.) Yacht Club winter sailors, 272 to 199, in an inter-club series in Dyer Dhow dinghies today.
PARIS, March 1 -- France registered satisfaction today over Soviet acceptance of a foreign ministers' meeting to plan the agenda and invitation list for a subsequent meeting of heads of government.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 1 -- A University of California scientist has devised a radically new method, still in the drawing board stage, for distillation of sea water on a large scale. Two state legislative committees were told this week that it held promise of economic feasibility.

The World Brotherhood has announced an expansion of its international program and the appointment of a full-time administrative president to meet "the present critical world situation demanding increased attention to fundamental human values."
A 17-year-old Washington Heights youth was arrested last night and charged with sending a threatening letter that demanded the release of seven teen-agers on trial for the murder of Michael Farmer.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1 -- "Terrible for me" was the way Duke Snider described the Los Angeles Coliseum ball park. But the Dodgers' center fielder feels he will have plenty of opportunity to play in the "terrible'' park now that his left knee has been repaired by surgery.

ASPEN, Colo. -- After three years of toil and vigilance, a group of citizens of this Elk Mountain community have achieved what in America could be regarded as a miracle. They have virtually eliminated advertising signs from the ninety miles of highway serving Aspen and have set up rules which govern the character of 90 per cent of the signs in the town itself.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The staggering problem under which the less-developed nations ceaselessly labor is how to achieve a modest but steady growth of their productive base so as to bring about a gradual improvement in living standards.

THE editor of this magazine charges that I am, by avocation, a letter writer and therefore must have something to contribute on this subject. A letter in the sense in which he uses the word is apparently not a stereotyped business communication, an engagement book, a diary, a Baedeker or a timetable, however nostalgic, dramatic and significant their implications may be to the author or to any other private eye.

Landlords, shopkeepers, other businessmen and residents occupying space required for a proposed union housing project in the Chelsea section of the West Side yesterday opened headquarters in a store at 230 Ninth Avenue to campaign against the plan.
The winds of change blew hot and cold over the Pentagon last week as the White House and Congress drew blueprints for the nation's military organization.

President Eisenhower has emerged cheerfully from an overnight stay in Walter Reed Hospital in Washington, minus a cracked tooth but plus a good medical report from his attending physicians. He seems to be doing very well for a man who had a heart attack in September, 1955, an intestinal operation in June, 1956, and a mild stroke in November, 1957. The doctors say so -- and they ought to know.
CHICAGO, March 1 -- Less co-education in American high schools was viewed as desirable today by David Reisman, Professor of Sociology at the University of Chicago.

THREE months, 7,500 miles and sixty choruses visited may not qualify the visitor as an expert on British choral music, but it does present a cross-section varied enough to make it possible to speak with some authority on what is happening today in a country long famous for its choral singing.

The International Ice Patrol, the Coast Guard's annual chore of guarding trans-Atlantic shipping lanes against the dangers of floaing ice, will get under way March 15. On that date the patrol's headquarters at Argentia, Nfld., will become operational for 1958.
BERLIN March 1 -- The front pages of all the newspapers in East Germany were covered today with pictures and articles marking the second anniversary of the founding of the National People's Army.

THE traditional concept of the artist, that of a painter or sculptor working alone in his studio for a private clientele, excludes too much to apply to American art today. For, as two unusual current exhibitions demonstrate, esthetic imagination and talent of a high order explore esthetic fields far beyond the making of works of art for drawing rooms.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Thurman A. Whiteside was subpoenaed today to take before a Federal grand jury all records of his dealings with Richard A. Mack, Federal Communications Commissioner.

TOKYO -- Japan has gone into high gear on a five-year program to attract more visitors by expanding hotel accommodations and other travel facilities. Last year 130,000 tourists left a welcome $65,000,000 worth of foreign exchange in the coffers of this import-hungry country.
Some $345,000,000 of the 1957 funds of Military Sea Transportation Service were spent with the maritime industry. The agency said this showed that it was one of private shipping's best customers.

Foster Parents Plan, which has already done so much for children in Greece, Italy, South Korea, France and Belgium, has initiated a new and interesting project. Its current "plan" is the raising of a modest sum to provide 100,000 pairs of "quoc," or wooden shoes, for the children of Vietnam.

The Soviet Union has obviously made a major concession to the West in its agreement, made public yesterday, to participate in a foreign ministers' meeting to discuss who should attend a summit conference and what the agenda of such a conference should be.

WARSAW, March 1 -- A slashing Right - wing attack on Wladyslaw Gomulka's leadership of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party developed unexpectedly today in a meeting of the party's Central Committee.
BONN, Germany, March 1 -West Germany's energetic Defense Minister, Franz Josef Strauss, will leave here tomorrow night for a nine-day visit to the United States.

" A YOUNG woman in prodigiously difficult circumstances" -such was Harriet Martineau's brief description of Queen Victoria soon after she had ascended the throne. And the same description, allowing for differences of age, might be applied to almost all twenty of the royal letter-writers here presented by Miss Margaret Sanders.
Flood conditions that developed in parts of the metropolitan area Thursday and Friday appeared to be subsiding yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- The Chicago Tribune reported tonight that the White House has demanded the resignation of Richard A. Mack from the Federal Communications Commission.
PARIS, March 1 -- The French Government is getting into an increasingly tight financial and political squeeze because of the Algerian war.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 25 -- Farmers in the Midwest corn-hog belt are considering a scheme some think may be the means of gaining the collective bargaining power and stable incomes they have sought so long. The idea is to produce hogs for meat packers under contract, rather than offer the hogs on the open market.

MANY readers will find this a disturbing first novel, for it is strong meat, not a warmed-over broth. Mr. Feibleman is an ardent new talent, telling in fine, sensuous prose the story of an in-between Alice in a wonderland of whites and blacks.
Gifts to New York's Neediest Cases have reached a total of $449,371.11 in the fund's forty-sixth annual appeal.

SPOLETO, Italy -- An ambitious new all-round art event to be held next June in Spoleto provides an excellent excuse to visit this offbeat hilltown in charming Umbria. The Festival of Two Worlds has been conceived by Gian-Carlo Menotti, the composer, as a medium to bring young American artists and an international audience together.
ALGIERS, Feb. 22 -- Mme. Jacques Massu is demonstrating in the field of social welfare the kind of leadership her husband, a paratroop general, has shown on the field of battle.

Charles L. Nielsen, vice president and treasurer of American Export Lines, resigned last week. He had been with the company since 1950, and had been its top financial official since November, 1955. He also resigned as a director.

THE adult sentimentalist, regarding today's picture books, might well wonder what ever became of the hearts-and-flowers school of prettiness of his fond recollection. To be sure there are still some of these around, like THE ENCHANTED EGG (Rand McNally, $1, ages 3 to 6), an anonymous story with pastel illustrations by Elizabeth Webbe featuring flower-capped birds, a flower-decked Easter egg and an elf, all in old-fashioned candy-box style.

SELECTIVITY is the primary consideration in all purposeful photography. It is appropriate, therefore, that the heaviest emphasis in a photographer's training and experience is placed on developing an instinctive ability to pick the significant detail, incident and aspect out of miscellany.
Four of the five new owners of the tenements, apartment buildings, shops and other real estate on the site for the Lincoln Square Redevelopment project took over their property yesterday.

HANOVER, N. H., March 1 -- The National Collegiate skiing championships, delayed one day because of hurricane-force winds, limped through the first session today. It was a day unlike most days -- skiwise. Through no fault of their own, officials found themselves with varied problems that ranged from a breakdown of mechanical equipment on the slalom course to protests.
A Government plan to ease problems of workers displaced by mechanization has been put before the Puerto Rican Legislature.

ONE of the laws there ought to be is a ban on any dancer's attempt to be funny in public without a license. And such a license should not be issued carelessly for no field of art demands a more special gift, a more mature mind, a greater skill. Comedy, indeed, is a very serious business, which no tyro should be allowed to touch.
Negotiations to head off a general strike by 105,000 dress workers in seven Eastern states collapsed yesterday.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., March 1 -- After a fourteen-year nap, the Democratic party here has splashed cold water on its face and will challenge the Republicans to a fight for control of the village administration on March 18.

LOOK at it objectively. Isn't the tale of "Madame Butterfly" almost a prototype of the tear-jerker? The story concocted by John Luther Long and dramatized by David Belasco was deliberately lachrymose more than fifty years ago, and time has not turned it into a tragic masterpiece.

FOUR months after George F. Kennan delivered his six lectures on -- Russia, the Atom and the West over the British Broadcasting Corporation network, they are published under the same title -- and are still being debated in many parts of the world. The interesting thing about them is their durability.

A check last week of how the three Twelve-Meter yachts that are being built as America's Cup defense candidates were coming along developed that the one for the Henry Sears syndicate was farthest along and that for the Hovey family in Boston was least advanced.

I DISAGREE with the Van Wyck Brooks' "aphorism," quoted in the book review from Mr. Brooks' new book "From a Writer's Notebook," that "one has to be interested in England to enjoy Anthony Trollope, but to enjoy Balzac all one needs is to be interested in life."

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Tourist travel to Middle East countries has returned virtually to normal after serious setbacks through the crises of the past two years. The present prospects are for peace and quiet in the area. Tourist departments, hotelkeepers and travel agencies are working hard to make the travelers' visits worth-while.
How far can a tax-exempt foundation go to protect its investments?
A warning of attempts to "cripple" the Supreme Court and to "erect spite walls" around it was sounded yesterday at the annual conference of the New York Civil Liberties Union.
Mrs. William C. H. M. Georgi de Mallerais, chairman of the twenty-seventh annual Loyola luncheon and bridge party, has announced the formation of a junior committee.
WARSAW, Feb. 23 -- Prof. Adam Schaff is a no-nonsense sort of man about how to make things work in communism.

" THERE is no other island quite like it off the coast of America. It is not only that the island seen from the air or from the sea gives the appearance of being legendary -- something you can hardly believe because it is so perfectly poised there, and so brilliantly shaped -- but once you step ashore, you seem to have entered another age, richer than our own."
The beleaguered railroads will have an important ally in the airline industry when the Senate inquiry into the "precarious" condition of the railroads resumes on Thursday.

THE experts, whose job it is this time of year to hold a wetted finger up into the. wind to determine which way the tourists will be going three months hence, are sending back strange reports to the decoding center. Their predictions keep repeating the adjective "normal" as the guide to the coming spring and summer foreign travel season.

THIS magic and enchanted first novel by a 67-year-old Dutch author, is difficult to define. The story ("De Tienduizend Dingen" was its Dutch title) is set in one of the green, volcanic islands of the Moluccas. Unquestionably Maria Dermout has drawn it from her rich memories -- which are still vivid as a coral garden in clear bay water.
MADRID, March 1 -- Spanish armed forces have successfully concluded a three-week campaign to drive Moroccan rebel bands out of the Spanish Sahara, the Government announced tonight.
Two men were arrested on homicide charges yesterday in the deaths of two Bronx men believed to have been victims of wood alcohol poisoning.

When France was Gaul and Tunisia Africa they got on very well. They were important parts of the whole of the Roman Empire and with Spain formed the western half of the known world, which was regarded as a counterbalance to the Hellenized eastern half.

Archbishop Molloy of Queens captured the City Catholic High Schools basketball championship yesterday with a 70-57 victory over All Hallows of the Bronx. The game was played in the Power Memorial Gymnasium, Manhattan.

MANHASSET, L. I., March 1 -- Mrs. .... Gilbert Cgu. rtney of IFlower Hfil, Manhasset, is I general chairman of the comlmittee in charge of the sev[enth annual Spring Fair of the North Shore Hospital.' The event will be held June 6-8 on the polo grounds of Greentree, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney.
MIAMI BEACH, March 1 -- The executive vice chairman of the United Jewish Appeal outlined here tonight a ten-point program for aid this year to Jewish men, women and children throughout the world.

FOREIGN-LANGUAGE records available for children proceed on several theories. There are records that take the place of the teacher -- the guiding voice says the phrase in the foreign language and leaves a time space for the listener to repeat.

BEERSHEBA, Israel -- This year, for the first time in her brief history, Israel is able to show tourists the Negev, the harshly beautiful desert that comprises the southern half of this tiny country. A new 143-mile asphalt highway through this local version of the Badlands was opened in January. Israel, celebrating its tenth anniversary as a state this year, counts the road as one of her proudest accomplishments.

HAVANA, March 1 -- An appeal by the Roman Catholic hierarchy for the formation of a "government of national union" caught the regime of President Fulgencio Batista by surprise today and caused considerable chagrin in Government circles.
JERSEY CITY, March 1 -- The use of magnetic tape recorders in modern language instruction began this week at St. Peter's College.
A British magistrate arrived last week on the Queen Elizabeth and pledged to prove that the English are not so "starchy" and conservative as Americans think.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -When Harry S. Truman laid heavy stress on the recession in his blast at the Administration a week ago, he was signaling the obvious: that the state of the domestic economy has suddenly become the number one campaign asset for the Democrats in the forthcoming Congressional campaign.
New York University won its third consecutive Metropolitan Collegiate Swimming Association championship last night at the John Quigley Memorial pool. The winner's point total was 83.

The fading New York Knickerbockers, paying the penalty for "standing around" through most of the contest, were beaten, 103 -- 101, by the Detroit Pistons last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

IT was in answer to the pleas of French bishops in the Middle West who were in dire need of teachers that Mother Philippine Duchesne came to the United States. Of an aristocratic family in pre-Revolutionary France, she brought as assets an excellent education, exquisite manners, a fine brain and deep faith.
HARTFORD, March 1 -- The Connecticut Legislature will meet in special session next Tuesday to consider the unemployment situation and proposals to increase state financial aid to the jobless.
THE installation of wall coverings which simulate the textured effect of natural brick is a home improvement gaining favor with home owners and apartment dwellers.

FOR THIS WEEK: Lawn seed to improve old turf can be sown; it is best to do this when the soil is still laced with frost. . . . Check stored canna roots and start divisions in damp peat moss. . . . Tree and shrub pruning is a pleasant chore on a mild day. A pair of hand pruning shears is fine for trimming shrubs.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System is in line for an award -- the salvage award of the week. Faced with a sinking television show titled "The Big Record," which carried a mutinous crew of advertisers, the network skillfully sliced the program in half and retained one advertiser to be the full-time sponsor.
Managers of the Wolverine tube-making plant in Detroit struggled with a hard decision. Their thirty-year-old plant was obsolete. Its processes could not compete with those of newer mills.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 1 -- A controversy has arisen over this city's refusal to appropriate $5,000 to underwrite a joint convention by two veterans' organizations.
CHICAGO, March 1 -- Following is the text of statement issued today by Samuel Cardinal Stritch, Archbishop of Chicago.

BELGRADE -- Year by year Yugoslavia's corrugated coastline on the sunny Adriatic attracts more refugees from the misty regions of Northern Europe. Germans, Scandinavians, Netherlanders and Britons by the thousands, in search of clear skies, warm soft bathing and budget prices make up the bulk of the southward traffic.
NEW HAVEN, March 1 -- Two geologists, working independently more than 2,000 miles apart, have found that the presence of hydrogensulfide gas is a clue to concentrations of uranium ore.

The American drive for a reduction of armaments ought to take new impetus from the appointment of James J. Wadsworth o direct it and the selection by Secretary of State Dulles of four eminent private citizens to advise on the subject. The private citizens include two former generals, Alfred M. Gruenther and Walter Bedell Smith; former Secretary of Defense Robert M. Lovett and former High Commissioner for Germany John J. McCloy.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 1 -- Discussions between the British-American oil combine and the Ceylonese Government for setting up an oil refinery in Ceylon are nearing conclusion.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 1 -- Army swept its swimming, gymnastic and rifle competition with Navy today.

BOWIE, Md., March 1 (AP) -- Flying Chief, a 6-year-old that never before had won a stakes race, took the lead at the start of the $22,750 Southern Maryland Handicap and held it throughout to win by three lengths today. Mr. Turf finished second, a head in front of Honey's Tiger.
MIAMI, March 1 (AP) -- Karol Fageros of Miami won the Miami women's singles tennis championship today with a 6-2, 7-5 victory over Mrs. Barbara Davidson of Milwaukee.

THREE years ago, photographer David Douglas Duncan dropped in upon Pablo Picasso, at his villa outside Cannes. It was to be only a courtesy call, but, a little like the man who came to dinner, he remained off and on for better than three months.

A FEW pieces by Liszt are firmly ensconced in the active repertory, but it is amazing how little of his music actually is heard today. Liszt wrote prolifically in many fields, and the sum of his works, what with transcriptions and original compositions, is fairly staggering.

IN the graph of passenger shipbuilding, from back a few years up into the future, there is a leveling-off in the year 1958. Where last year, seven new vessels sailed out on the North Atlantic run, the world's most traveled sea lane, there are none scheduled this year. For the future, the graph rises again, since new ships are building, for the Atlantic and service on other oceans.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Soviet Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov proposed today that the United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation as a step toward "peace on our planet."
An error in the Latin date written 191 years ago on the Master of Arts diploma granted to John Jay, first Chief Justice of the United States, has come to light.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 1 -- The fear of an economic depression in the West has brought thousands of industrial concerns to the spring session of the Leipzig Fair, which opens tomorrow.
The great task of our time is to make the American public science-conscious, Dr. Russell Meyers, a brain surgeon, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A summit meeting seemed a much more real prospect today after the Soviet Union's sudden acceptance of a preparatory foreign ministers' meeting. But the Soviet move did not entirely break through the procedural impasse that has grown up on the road to the summit.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 1 (UP) -- Betty Cuthbert, the Australian sprinter who won three gold medals at the 1956 Olympic Games, equaled the women's world record of 10.4 seconds for 100 yards while winning the event today at the New South Wales track and field championships.

FOR the information of collectors who "write up" their stamps before placing them in the albums, the United Nations Postal Administration's Director, Reidar Tvedt, issued last week a concise review of how the world organization's seal came into existence.

IN addition to the starry chickweed flowers and golden crocus, there are some early-blooming rhododendrons that will lead off spring's parade of bloom. A. few warm days now -- if the weatherman cooperates -- and the shrubs will show color in the garden.

Ron (the Racer) Delany for the second year in a row engineered an inspired double last night to lead Villanova to victory in the thirty-seventh annual indoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Air Force expects to have the Thor, its intermediate-range ballistic missile, pronounced combat-ready by June and perhaps earlier.

IT is more economical to travel by car in Europe than by public transportation and, unless travelers from this country expect to be overseas for six months or more, it is less expensive to rent or buy a car in Europe than to ship their own vehicles across the Atlantic.

A benefit concert will be given on March 16 to mark the first anniversary of Parents Without Partners. Karl Ulrich Schnabel, pianist, will donate his services to the concert, which will take place at the New York Center for Better Living, 227 West Forty-sixth Street.

Columbia's basketball team suffered its twelfth straight Ivy League defeat last night when Yale outscored the Lions, 91 -- 88, on the University Hall court. Already in the league cellar, Columbia now seems about to drop all the way through.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands -- As a result of some happy circumstances over which they have practically no control, the boosters of travel and tourism in the Netherlands expect the 1958 season to be a stand-out success.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 1 -- No sooner had President Gamal Abdel Nasser become uncontested President of the curious new Arab union of Egypt and Syria than he began to strike out in all directions against those in the Arab and African world who spurned his leadership.
The State Workmen's Compensation Board awarded an average of $7,942 in 1956 to workers in this state whose skulls were fractured in on-the-job accidents.
ATHENS, March 1 -- The Government headed by Constantine Karamanlis, in office just more than two years, suddenly found itself tonight in a crisis.

Mayor Wagner will appoint Dr. Peter Marshall Murray to the Board of Hospitals, City Hall sources said yesterday. Dr. Murray will be the first negro member of the board, the policy-making body of the Department of Hospitals.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- Harvard clinched the Ivy League hockey title by beating Yale, 6 -- 2, before 3,800 fans tonight.

The most widely known name on the art calendar here this week is Sir Winston Churchill. A selection of his paintings over a period of thirty years will be shown at the Metropolitan Museum beginning on Friday.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- Possible House defeat of a Senate-approved bill increasing the cost of mailing an out-of-town letter to 5 cents was predicted today.

While Wall Street's board rooms keep an uneasy watch over the zigzag of stock prices, its ivory towers are astir over a striking change that has been taking place in a less known cardiogram of the economy -- "the Treasury yield curve."

A first reading of "Johnny Appleseed,'' a play in verse by Stanley Young, will take place tomorrow at 8 P. M. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West Fifty-third Street. The reading is the last in a "Poets and Playwrights" series at the center.
Pepper, the king of spices, is expected to remain in plentiful supply, despite the upheaval in Indonesia, but prices may go up.
A statement was issued through the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday opposing any change in state laws prohibiting many kinds of business on Sundays.

PEIPING, March 1 (Reuters) -- Chou Hsing, one of Communist China's seven Vice Ministers of Security, has been relieved of his post, the Communist party newspaper Jen Min Jih Pao (Peiping People's Daily) reported today.

THE travel horizon, still expanding, covers practically all lands this year. Journeys are more diversified than ever, combining as they do train, ship and air transport, with travel by bus, jeep and even helicopter beyond rail lines.

BRYCE CANYON, Utah -- Successive snowstorms, sweeping across the tip-tilted, roadless Kaiparowits Plateau, this winter dumped near-record layers of powder atop the spires and minarets of Bryce Canyon National Park.

THE onrush of stereo means, among other things, that the audio hobbyist has a new set of terms to absorb into his working vocabulary. And if the thought of learning more audio technicalities brings a weariness to your spirit, you haven't truly chosen this way of life.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sunday, March 2 -- More than 300 passengers were believed to have lost their lives when a ferryboat overturned and sank yesterday in an inlet of the Sea of Marmara.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 1 -- The University of Notre Dame began today a $66,600,000 ten- year development program. It is the biggest fund drive in the history of the 116-year-old Roman Catholic institution.

HUNDREDS of thousands of noble words extolling the sanctity of the right to vote in America shook the rafters of House and Senate during the long civil rights debate last summer. Yet one searches in vain, in all that debate, for a single critical word directed to the continued denial of voting rights to the 831,000 citizens in the nation's capital itself -- a population greater than that of any one of twelve sovereign states.

TIME - CONSCIOUS, weight - conscious Americans -- and one description or the other seems to apply to nearly all of us today -- have pulled the platter right out from under the traditional morning meal. The diminishing American breakfast has, in many households, vanished altogether, and nutritionists are becoming increasingly concerned.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 1 -- A study undertaken by the conductor of the Knoxville Symphony Orchestra demonstrates that children who enjoy good music have a more active imagination, greater qualities of leadership and generally better scholastic averages than other students.

TOURISTS returning from Italy frequently describe their culinary tours in terms of incomparable pastas bathed in succulent sauces perfumed with native mushrooms, and consumed in the company of robust domestic wines. There is more to the Italian cuisine, however, than macaroni.

FOR many gardeners the yellow blooms of forsythia open the spring-flowering shrub season. While no one disputes the value of this popular member of the olive family, its exclusive use as a starter for the spring shrub parade actually may deprive the garden of as such as two months of early bloom.
WITH the busy spring and summer season just over the horizon, the year 1958 appears to hold in store for international commercial aviation more than an ordinary amount of change and challenge.
THE complete text of the acceptance speech made by Albert Camus when he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature last December, has just been published by Alfred A. Knopf in the form of a brochure.

MANILA, March 1 (AP) -- Manila's two leading newspapers rallied today to the defense of Maj. Gen. John B. Ackerman, who was ousted from his Air Force command in the Philippines for spending too much on his living quarters.

VALENTINE'S DAY, 1959, is a long way off but the State of Oregon is already busy planning a celebration that will start next Feb. 14 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of Oregon's admission to statehood.

THE Federal Communications Commission, as had been generally expected, crumbled last Wednesday afternoon in the face of Congressional opposition and pigionholed indefinitely the idea of pay-as-you-see television. For all practical purposes toll video over the airwaves may be considered virtually dead.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Soviet Union has proposed that a foreign ministers' meeting be held in April to arrange a summit conference.
BUENOS AIRES, March 1 -- A strong possibility has emerged here in these post-election days that Argentina may soon invite foreign companies to help her explore her petroleum.

Syracuse University will hold a summer session workshop on July 7-11 on "Merit Salary Schedules," Dean Virgil Rogers has announced. The workshop is designed for intensive and critical examination of a current problem in public-school administration with which many communities are now confronted.

RARELY does one hear such silence in a crowded gallery as there is now at the Marlborough in Bond Street. The works on exhibition are by Juan Gris, and their mood is imposed irresistibly and absolutely.
Unheralded among the literary events of our time is the fact that Mushky Jackson is writing his memoirs.
LONDON, Sunday, March 2 -- Dr. Fuchs will be knighted, it was announced from Ten Downing Street today.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 1 -- There's nothing like a sports victory over a Navy team to rouse the enthusiasm of the Army Cadet Corps. While a capacity crowd of 5,000 yelled approval. Army's basketball team beat the midshipmen, 78 to 68, at the Field House court today.

TWO years ago, after a survey of the domain of 2,270 priests, 8,766 nuns, 529 institutions and nearly 2,000,000 souls of which Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch is spiritual shepherd and temporal guide, a prominent Roman Catholic said: "If I were doing his job for the money, I wouldn't take $10,000 a week."

As a composer with a background similar to that of Peggy Glanville-Hicks, being versed in twentieth-century techniques of East and West, I agree with the ideas in her article. However, I feel it is necessary to clarify the importance of dissonance in Eastern music.
TOKYO, March 1 -- Relations between Japan and South Korea seemed to have touched their lowest point today since the former Japanese colony became independent after World War II.
Drew Middleton, in his article "Churchill as War Leader: A Reappraisal" (Feb. 16), has raised a question that urgently needs to be examined.
PARIS -- Two widely differing and separated attractions are expected to make 1958 one of France's most successful tourist years in history.

HAVANA, March 1 -- President Fulgencio Batista is determined to hold general elections June 1. He maintains this view despite a spreading rebellion in Oriente Province and a conviction widely held throughout Cuba that the election would be fraudulent and farcical.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 1 -- Official spokesmen for the Republican and -- Democratic parties debated state aid to education in a public forum at Hofstra College here today.

HELSINKI, Finland -- The Midnight Sun and the strange atmosphere of Lapland, the northern part of Finland, are the oldest but at the same time the newest attractions for foreign tourists during the coming tourist season.

MADRID -- Spain's famous fighting bulls seem to be retreating slowly before this country's lovely beaches as the number-one tourist lure. Once bullfights, tire cathedrals and museums brought the visitors here in droves; now it is the seashore, the sun and cobalt-blue skies they want.
ABOARD THE U. S. S. ARNEB, Feb. 7 -- For the third successive year a three-ton mass of lead and paraffin is capturing cosmic rays on an around-the-world cruise.

Deakin, friend of Churchill and leader of the first parachute mission to Tito, has gathered about him a small group of international students seeking to unravel some of the secrets of our time.

ACCORDING to reasonable, if perhaps not totally provable. calculations, "Peyton Place" now has become this century's second best selling fiction book. To date, some 5,750,000 copies have been printed in the year and a half of its life -- soft cover and hard. Just behind it is "Gone With the Wind," at something better than 5,000,000 copies, and ahead lies that winner-take-all, "God's Little Acre." Close to 7,000,000 for that one.

LOURDES, France -- This year is the centenary year for this celebrated shrine, and during the year as many as 10,000,000 persons from every corner of the globe are expected to visit Lourdes. "This is the pulsating heart of Arabism," cried Nasser as the crowds cheered wildly. "[We have realized] a great event in Arab history -- the event for which our fathers and forefathers struggled -- an event which demonstrates Arab strength and dignity."

THE Roxy Theatre, which closes its doors tonight after thirty-one years of operation as the nation's second largest first-run showcase, will re-open in about six weeks as a much smaller house. OAKLAND, Calif., March 1 (AP) -Alice Gentle, a former opera star, died yesterday after an eight-year fight against an undiagnosable anemia. She was 69 years old.

THE 13-year-old Sarah who tells, in her own bewildered and bewildering way, this story of a week in the south of France, complains of being "treated as a child at one moment and then, the next moment, expected to know and understand a whole heap of things which should not concern children."

The National Heart Institute of the United States Public Health Service is carrying on a pioneer community-wide study at Framingham, Mass., to gain information on the causes of heart disease. The study was begun in 1948 and will continue for another decade.

ATLANTA, March 1 -- A Southern interracial organization warned today that expulsion of a Negro student from Little Rock's Central High School had "dangerous implications for basic control of public education in the region."
Pope Pius XII to be 82. (He was 2 elevated to the Papacy on this' day in 1939.)

BUENOS AIRES, March 1 -- The remark most often heard in Buenos Aires this week is that Arturo Frondizi, the man who last Sunday was elected Argentina's first civilian President in fifteen years, is "very intelligent."
ALBANY, March 1 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today a bill that would have altered the route of the Brooklyn approach to the proposed Narrows Bridge. He had vetoed the same measure last year.
Sixty-three years ago a curious mind got the better of a 7-year-old boy on Long Island.
Carrol M. Shanks is a happy man.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Feb. 22 -- On any Saturday evening, just about sundown, one can hear the loud blare of music -- popular American, Italian and native Eritrean songs -- pouring from scores of loudspeakers hung on the lamp posts, trees and buildings of the main streets of Asmara.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- New firearms regulations, stripped of several proposed requirements that stirred widespread protests last year, went into effect today.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 1 (Reuters) -- Garfield Sobers, a 21-year-old West Indian cricket player, set a world record in scoring for a test innings today.
Shoppers crowded into department stores, discount houses and the big appliance chains yesterday on the fourth day of leap-frogging price cuts on small home appliances.
Setting the pace most of the way, St. John's University's basketball team checked City College's well-drilled outfit, 69 to 55, in City's Wingate Gymnasium last night.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 1 -- The National Trust for Historic Preservation in Washington has entered the controversy over the fate of the Harral-Wheeler Mansion here.
PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -A copy of the Ferrara Bible, which ranks with the Gutenberg Bible as a rarity, was placed on display today by its new owner, the Free Library of Philadelphia.
The April 15 performance of 'q3ack to Methuselah" will benefit the Educational Institute for Learning and Research.

DUBLIN -- For those wise travelers who wish to avoid the frantic peak months of July and August, when both transportation and accommodations on this side of the Atlantic are heavily burdened, May and June are particularly good times to visit the Republic of Ireland.

VICKSBURG, Miss. -- It is showboat time down here where the Yazzo meets the Mississippi. Of special interest to tourists this year is that aboard the S. S. Sprague the tenth anniversary of the current revival of the old-time riverboat divertissement will be celebrated.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Eisenhower's physicians said today that he was completely recovered from the mild stroke he suffered in November. The President said he was feeling "fine."

So long as the Kremlin believes that its base of power, the U. S. S. R., would suffer severely in a war, it seems right to reckon that the proprietors of the Soviet empire will continue to find it in their interest to avoid a head-on military collision.

MORE and more people seem to be taking trips to Africa these days, and many of them wonder beforehand what to carry with them. To these, it may come as a surprise to find that, in some parts of the continent at least, evening gowns for the women and black or white-tie equivalent for the men are as essential as anti-malaria pills, even more so.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 1 -- Dr. Mohammed Hatta went on record again today as being opposed to Communist participation in the Indonesian Government.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Dr. Edward Teller said tonight that world disarmament was "a lost cause" at present because there was no foolproof inspection system and the Russians could "cheat" if they wanted to.

The United States Trotting Association disclosed yesterday that it had been notified by the Department of Justice that an antitrust suit charging monopolistic practices would be filed against it this week. Counsel for the association said it had been told the suit would be filed Wednesday in Columbus, Ohio, home office of the association.
The steamship charter market held steady last week, at previously reached low levels, as United States-flag vessels achieved slight rate gains and foreign ships fell off similarly.
Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, said yesterday that the United States should take immediate steps to avert a possible war in the Middle East.
Racial discrimination in the United States was described yesterday by a Roman Catholic editor as a "disease of the soul" and an "affliction of the human heart."

HAVANA, March 2 -- The Revolutionary Directorate, one of the groups of youths engaged in rebel activity, expressed satisfaction today with the appeal by the Roman Catholic hierarchy for the establishing of a national union government in Cuba.
BATON ROUGE; La., March 2 (AP) -- Ken Venturi, a 26-yearold San Francisco pro, shot his fourth -under-par 69 today to gain a 4-stroke victory with 276 in the $15,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

Two prominent young American composers shared the program of the Composers Showcase Saturday night at the Nonagon, Second Avenue at Sixth Street. They were Irving Fine of the faculty of Brandeis University and Gunther Schuller, French horn player of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., March 2 -- On Wednesday night ninetysix girls will get new hats here and they will not be disappointed that all are alike. The hats, signifying that the wearers have become junior staff aides among the Nightingales at Valley Hospital, will be presented at a capping ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

Saturday, March 1, the world's largest brokerage firm officially dropped "Beane" as the last name in its title and added "Smith." Result: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith. However, since Saturday is a regular holiday for all brokerage activities, the change was made quietly.

The Sheraton Hotel in Philadelphia announced yesterday it will open a studio in the hotel soon that will beam convention meetings, entertainment, news and even commercials on a closed circuit to all television sets in the building.

VIENNA, March 2 -- Austria's need for capital to meet the demands of European integration came to focus last week when Dr. Josef Joham, general manager of the Creditanstalt-Bankverein and president of the Austrian Bankers Association, surveyed the problem in an address.
BOSTON, March 2 -- Two threatening telephone calls led the police today to assign a guard detail to Archbishop Richard J. Cushing.
SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, March 2 (Reuters) -- Dr. Vivian E. Fuchs and his party celebrated today their 2,100-mile crossing of the Antarctic continent with a caviar-and-champaign party.
GUATEMALA, March 2 -Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes was sworn in today for a sixyear term as President. The inauguration took place in Congress.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, March 3 (AP) -- The North Korean Communists went back today on their promise to return the two United States pilots and two West Germans aboard a South Korean airliner, hijacked and held in the North.

Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., Professor of History at Harvard, has received the Francis Parkman Prize for 1957 from the Society of American Historians. The award was made for his book "The Crisis of the Old Order, 1919-1933."

Dimitri Mitropoulos, at the New York Philharmonic concert on Saturday evening, conducted the world premiere of Yeorgo Sicilianos' Symphony No. 1. Mr. Sicilianos is a Greek composer, born in 1924, who has studied in this country and abroad. He now lives in his native country.

Hobart Nichols' letter, which you published on Feb. 7, sounded a note which bears frequent repetition. The current death-trial drama of seven youths charged with murder of a teen-ager is an arraignment of the community and its elders.

The 200 young Americans who will serve as guides in the United States pavilion at the Brussels Fair are to be given a ship and shore orientation while en route to their tasks. They will leave this month.
MOSCOW, March 2 -- Statistics to warm the heart of any temperance advocate were given out by the Government today to support a demand that Russians volunteer for membership in a Good-Living Society.

SINCE World War II, American homeowners have' taken a deep plunge into outdoor living. First, patios were annexed as alternate living rooms and furnished with all the trappings associated with indoor comfort. Next, terraces were treated to barbecues and other cooking aids and, finally, backyards were explored for their swimming pool possibilities.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended March 1:
LONDON, March 2 -- Last week was an erratic one for the stock markets and for the pound sterling.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Administration is facing growing pressure from a recession statistic that has received little public notice -- the growing number of persons who have exhausted their unemployment benefits.
BANGALORE, India, March 2 -- India's only aircraft plant has been closed by an employer fighting a string of labor troubles.
The Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said yesterday that integration had become a question of the United States' survival as a great world power.
A PUBLIC health expert who has been busy keeping track of how American families spend their leisure time is off on a recreational bender.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 2 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser and Yemen's Crown Prince announced today that Yemen would federate with the United Arab Republic.
The spectacle of a great artist performing at the very top of his form was afforded by Jussi Bjoerling at his Carnegie Hall recital last night.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -Congressional advocates of liberal tariff policies are seeking ways to "sweeten" the Administration's reciprocal trade bill. They hope to make it less distasteful to a majority of the House of Representatives.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Paramount Pictures has decided to go all the way with television by becoming active in the production of filmed shows for the home screen. Last month the company became the last in Hollywood to sell its pre-1948 theatrical film library for television exhibition.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 2 -- For years the virtuosity of Marshal Tito's diplomatic tightrope act dazzled an international audience. From a Russian angle he was the only Communist statesman who didn't kowtow to the Kremlin. From a Western angle he was the only Communist statesman virtually regarded as an ally.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Pentagon officials expect March to be a crucial month in their intensified effort to maintain this country's reputation as the greatest military power.

ST. LOUIS, March 2 (AP) -- Representative Morgan M. Moulder, Democrat of Missouri, a member of the Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight, said today he wanted Thomas E. Dewey and Mr. Adams to appear before the committee.

SAALFELDEN, Austria, March 2 (AP) -- The first world biathlon championships today were a Swedish-Russian affair with the American skiing marksmen ending near the bottom of an eight-nation, 28-contestant field.
A plan for the mental, physical and economic rehabilitation of chronic drinkers has been proposed by Edward J. McGoldrick Jr., founder and director of Bridge House.
Net income of the American Home Products Corporation last year rose to a record high of $38,617,510 from $31,250,355 in 1956. Gross sales advanced to $372,354,746 from $317,258,976 a year earlier.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- If Los Angeles wants to make the Dodgers feel at home, someone ought to check on the restaurants, the number of legitimate shows and the chances of forming a Cimoli fan club.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Lawyers concerned with the Federal Communications Commission hope that Congressional attention will shift soon from corruption to what they regard as a graver problem -- the standards used to award television channels.
Six new films are slated to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
ALBANY, March 2 -- Democrats proposed today a $20,000-a-year ceiling on the pay of legislative employes. The recommendation came as an answer to public criticism of legislative payroll practices.

SAN SIMEON, Calif., March 2 -- A lanky young man who has been plodding about a Santa Lucia Mountain ridge in sports clothes changed them this week for a uniform. The switch symbolized the ending of a major chapter in one of the world's most extraordinary stories: the saga of William Randolph Hearst.
Domestic cotton prices continued to move up last week, though they weakened sharply in two trading sessions.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- "If hollering was all that was needed to clinch a job with the Yankees," said the tall blond fellow with a rueful smile, "well, you can bet all your dough I'd holler my head off. But I don't know.

FOR the last few months all seems to have been quiet on the Cyprus front. While politics erupt in the near-by Middle East an uneasy silence reigns in the ancient island whose troubles have virtually broken the fragile pact between Greece and Turkey and have nearly destroyed the long-standing affection between Greece and Britain.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- The development of electrical gear for use in the fisheries industries is on the upsurge. Indications are that increased emphasis upon the commercial importance of seafood and fish by-products will accelerate the trend.
The Port of New York Authority has urged Congress to appropriate $6,000,000 for a vital waterway-deepening project in New York Harbor.

The Bulgarian National Front of the United States and Canada protested yesterday against Western support for the Tito regime in Yugoslavia and the Gomulka regime in Poland. It warned that the two Governments had not changed their internal Communist policies opposing freedom.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 2 -- The onrushing suburbs will put the final claim to another victim here Wednesday. An auction at 10:30 A. M. will dispose of the remaining equipment and machinery of Harmony Farms at Lake Avenue and Lower Cross Road in the town's "back country" section.
"SEE IT NOW" turned its attention yesterday to the question of statehood for Alaska and Hawaii. The onehour program over Channel 2 studied the subject in revealing detail.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -Corn futures prices, long under pressure from a variety of bearish influences, suddenly hit a turning point on the Board of Trade last week and surprised many dealers with a stubborn show of strength.

ROME, March 2 -- Pope Pius XII marked his eighty-second birthday today, saddened by what Vatican officials described as a sudden flare-up of anti-clericalism in Italy. The Pontiff, who was said to be in good health, showed himself in a window of his private study on the third floor of the Apostolic Palace for a few minutes at noon.

In 1957, holdings of gold and dollars by foreign countries showed a net decline for the first time since 1951. With the single exception of the lastnamed year, the rebuilding of the world's monetary reserves had been one of uninterrupted progress from 1949 through 1956.
Motorists, golfers, sight-seers and strollers flocked outdoors yesterday to enjoy a March that had arrived like a lamb.
Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila" will be restored to the Metropolitan Opera repertory on March 13 after a year's absence. The title roles will be suhg by Mario Del Monaco and Rise Stevens.
Popovers are very easy to make. The secret of success is in the baking.

OSLO, Norway, March 2 (AP) -- Canada and Russia continued to pour in the goals today as they easily wrapped up their second straight victories in the world ice hockey championship. Canada blanked Norway, 12 -- 0, and Russia shut out Finland, 10 -- 0.

MIAMI, March 2 -- Conn McCreary was standing near the door of the jockey room at Hialeah yesterday when a messenger rushed in breathlessly. This was shortly after the dramatic Flamingo Stakes had been run, with Manuel Ycaza on Jewel's Reward and Willie Hartack on Tim Tam coming down the homestretch like a chariot team.

Irene Arzedi, the 29-year-old Brooklyn seamstress who disappeared on the day she was to have been married, turned up yesterday afternoon at the Port Authority Bus Terminal at Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street.
SINGAPORE, March 2 -- The Indonesian Government at Jakarta has imposed a blockade of considerable effectiveness on the Central Sumatran base of the new revolutionary government.

THE status of the American woman gained ground during 1956-57. According to Mrs. Alice K. Leopold, assistant to the Secretary of Labor and director of the Labor Departments Women's Bureau, distaff achievements soared in this two-year period.

Two editions of the eighteenth-century Chinese classic, "Hung Lou Meng," will be published by two concerns March 21. Twayne Publishers have titled their version "Dream of the Red Chamber"; Pantheon Books call theirs "The Dream of the Red Chamber."

It is expected that one, two or all three remaining spots in the National Invitation basketball tournament will be filled within the next forty-eight hours. It also is expected that if Iona College's coach, Jimmy McDermott, does not hear from the selection committee by 1 P. M. today he will unleash a blast considerably stronger than the one he fired a week ago.

As Moscow undoubtedly expected and hoped, the latest Soviet note with regard to preparations for a possible summit conference has been well received in much of the Western world. Though this note has not yet been made public, what is known of its contents appears to suggest that it departs somewhat from the rather rigid attitude shown in Premier Bulganin's last letter to President Eisenhower and in Mr. Khrushchev's Minsk pronouncement on foreign policy.
MIAMI BEACH, March 2 -The United Jewish Appeal opened its 1958 campaign here tonight with initial contributions of $18,400,000.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2 -With few exceptions, the Giants will miss New York -- its Broadway shows, its jabbering cab drivers and its diverse sports luncheons with their imported vintages, thick steaks and abundant ham (human and otherwise).

PITTSBURGH, March 2 -Steel business in February was below the January level because it was a shorter month. However, on a daily basis, February's production was about the same as January's depressed average.

The State of Iowa has scheduled for sale on March 27 an issue of $24,700,000 of bonds to finance payment of bonus compensation to veterans of the Korean War. The bonds will come due serially from 1958 to 1976.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- Both the Army and the Navy plan to launch satellites this week.

OUT of Seoul in Korea the other day news agencies sent a story of native outcry over cruel mistreatment by G. I.'s of Kim Chung Nyon, a boy taken up for filching little items from a noncoms' mess. The incident stirred ill feelings against Americans.
PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., March 2 -- A school problem that seemed to have been solved last March has come back to plague this northern Westchester community in a more acute form.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 2 -- This city has begun to fashion a twenty-two acre park that is scheduled to provide a dramatic setting for vast redeveloping of its most blighted area. The park will be on a narrow strip between the Raritan River and the new Memorial Parkway.
The School Settlement Association at 120 Jackson Street, Brooklyn, will benefit from a luncheon and fashion show to be held in the grand ballroom of the Plaza on April 8.

A long-range program is under way to construct twelve new community centers throughout Greater New York under the auspices of the Associated Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association of Greater New York, 1391 Lexington Avenue, New York 28.
ATHENS, March 2 -- Constantine Karamanlis resigned as Premier of Greece today. He advised King Paul to dissolve the Chamber of Deputies and declare a general election.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 2 -- Richard Hebard and James Carlisle of the host Fox Meadow Tennis Club, regained the men's national doubles platform tennis championship today. Rallying after dropping the first two sets, the 1955 title holders defeated two clubmates, George Harrison and William Pardoe, 4 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, in the final, which had to be finished under lights.
WARSAW, March 2 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka has received the formal approval of the Communist Central Committee for his policy of seeking as much independence as possible from the Soviet Union.

In thinking about the future demands of education there is, curiously enough, a tendency to pass over lightly the sticky question of where the teachers are to come from, while dealing more adequately with the supply of physical plant. The New York State Education Department, in a program made public this morning, deals with the problem of staffing our colleges.
A SLENDER young woman dressed for tropical temperatures was not bothered by the city's recent wave of Arctic weather.
PRESTONSBURG, Ky., March 2 (AP) -- A school bus containing the bodies of the driver and fourteen youngsters was found today in the flooded Big Sandy River.
The recession is creating mounting uneasiness among United States officials concerned with the economic race between the United States and the Soviet Union.
A panel of five high school students yesterday discussed ways to combat Communist propaganda.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 2 -- John B. Royce's Sing Hi's Sun Tu from Brookline, Mass., became best of breed winner today in the eighty-first specialty of the Pekingese Club of America. There were fifty-six dogs for sixty-one entries, all Americanbreds, in the Hotel Roger Smith.

MANILA, Monday, March 3 -- Indonesian rebel headquarters at Menado, in North Celebes, reports that the airfield there was bombed yesterday by two B-25's of Jakarta's Air Force. The bombers were said to be based at Halmahera, 200 miles to the east.
President Eisenhower, in proclaiming March as Red Cross Month, pointed out that a two-year cycle of natural disasters had exhausted Red Cross disaster funds and cut into other reserves.
TUNIS, March 2 -- Robert Murphy, United States Deputy Under Secretary of State, flew to Paris today for his second round of talks on the French-Tunisian crisis.
An English churchman, the Very Rev. C. P. Hankey, Dean of Ely, was guest preacher yesterday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.
AMSTERDAM, March 2 -The recession in the United States so far has barely touched the Netherlands.
More than 1,000 persons joined a celebration here yesterday for the ninetieth birthday of Dr. W. E. B. DuBois, Negro sociologist and author.

LAHTI, Finland, March 2 (UP) -- The world Nordic ski championships opened with two major upsets today when one Finnish entry won the thirty-kilometer race and another took the lead at the halfway mark of the Nordic combined event.
BERLIN, March 2 -- East German educators are divided on practical methods of running a Socialist state and even on the theoretical tenets of Communism.

Back yards on Mondays, these days -- in suburbs and country -- look pretty much like back yards on Friday or any other day. It was not always so. Mondays were wash days, and back yards so proclaimed it. One notes, on Monday excursions from the city, no long, long lines of snow-white laundry hanging in back yards as they once did.
A band of American Indians is heading for Puerto Rico to learn how a once-depressed people lifted itself by its bootstraps.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Navy is accelerating Arctic research in the belief that the ice-capped polar region is a potential battle area for nuclear-missile fleets.

It will be two weeks tomorrow since France and Tunisia agreed in the U. N. Security Council to accept the "good offices" of the United States and Britain in the affair of the Sakiet-Sidi-Youssef bombing. The French have expressed regret at the loss of innocent lives and may have taken steps to see that the incident is not repeated.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27 -American interests have taken the lead in the international race to develop rich landlocked iron ore reserves in Minas Gerais State.

Although they did not win the game, the Detroit Red Wings gained the glory in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The visitors rallied from a three-goal deficit to earn a 4to-4 tie.

An apartment house is planned at 339-45 East Fiftyfourth Street, between First and Second Avenues. A plot measuring 82 by 100 feet has been purchased by the builders, who were represented by Meadow, Morton Meadow, attorneys.

CHICAGO, March 2 (UP) -The Toronto Maple Leafs rallied from a three-goal deficit tonight to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 -- 5, and keep alive their hopes for a National Hockey League play-off berth.
BUENOS AIRES, March 2 -A young Roman Catholic priest is reported to have defied the Paraguayan dictatorship with a public appeal for the restoration of freedom in his country.
BROADWAY tradition was cracked last night, but probably not irreparably, when leaders of the legitimate theatre declared peace on a critic.

AS much as $150 can be spent for four pounds of chocolates at Blum's, a new candy store at 700 Fifth Avenue. It is the item's packaging -- an exquisite Limoges porcelain box -that increases the price. The chocolates themselves, perhaps among the finest made in this country, are $1.95 a pound and up.

The former chaplain to Roman Catholic students at Princeton University renewed his attack yesterday on the academic "liberal intelligentsia," terming them a worse danger than the "sputniks of Khrushchev."
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- En garde, John Foster Dulles!
THE Virtuosi di Roma played instrumental Italian music of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries with sparkle and finesse at their Town Hall concert on Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield has denounced both Senate and House bills to raise postal workers' pay as "completely unjustified."

The Rev. Charles Howard Graf, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's in the Village, 218 West Eleventh Street, accused the Board of Education yesterday of acting "like an authorized dictatorship."
CAIRO, March 2 (AP) -- The newspaper Al Shaab announced details of the agreement today. The Nasser Government often uses Al Shaab to release official information.

Four young American singers gave a joint recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall under the auspices of Aristo Artists. They were Jane Craner, contralto, from Syracuse, N. Y.; Rhys Ritter, bass-baritone from West Virginia; Janice Seward, soprano from Kansas, and Paul Huddleston, tenor from Kansas.
Here are some ways to break the ice in making a winter wardrobe feel up to spring:
ONE of the wealthiest ships ever to dock on Seventh Avenue was "The Good Ship Lollipop." Now, twenty-four years between trips, it is tying up again to unload a new cargo of Shirley Temple dresses.
"SALOME" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night, with the tenor William Lewis making his debut in the role of Narraboth.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that unemployment here was "not as acute" as elsewhere in the state and nation. But he warned that mounting welfare costs could push the city budget above $2,000,000,000.
A leading Soviet scientist has suggested that it may be possible to remove the ice from the Arctic Ocean, opening it to world shipping.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 (AP) -- Ralph B. Dewey, vice president in charge of the Washington office of the Pacific American Steamship Association, will become president of the association on April 1.

Americans want to do the right thing in foreign affairs. But too often we live within the boundaries of what we personally feel and see, hence we are unrealistic in the extreme toward nations and peoples unlike ourselves.
