The Litton Industries exchange offer to stockholders of the Aircraft Radio Corporation has been terminated, both companies announced jointly today.

Mathew and Milton Prince of Brooklyn have purchased the six-story apartment building at 1161 Stratford Avenue, the Bronx, from Joseph Teichman in a deal negotiated by Alfred Kohn Co., broker. Assessed at $210,000, the property is 168 by 100 feet and was bought for cash over mortgages amounting to $155,000.
Jim Ethridge and Carl Badger of the Field Club of Greenwich won the annual Arthur H. Lockett invitation squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday at the University Club.
HANOVER, N. H., March 2 -- Dartmouth, which has been enjoying considerable success in athletics since last fall, chalked up another important triumph today.

JAMES C. HAGERTY, White House press secretary, has set forth his views on the subject of live television coverage of addresses by President Eisenhower. In the course of a telephone conversation with this department over the week-end, he advanced these main points:
TOKYO, March 2 -- Japan's economic recession is beginning to make big black headlines as conditions continue to deteriorate in many fields.
The parting of Swift Co., meat packer, and the J. Walter Thompson Company after sixty-five years has ended one of the longest client-agency relationships.
Governor Harriman has done just the right thing in asking the State Legislature to authorize a thorough study of the operations of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield organizations.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 2 -- Arthur Knapp Jr., the season defender, strengthened his lead for a ninth Larchmont Yacht Club winter sailing championship in twelve years by winning today's frostbite regatta. Leading in the first two of four races staged in light air, Knapp's Agony added a third and fourth place to gain 155 of a possible 160 points. Knapp's mate was Bobby Walden.

A study for the first thorough overhauling of the city's zoning law is going into its final stage. The city's adoption of the zoning law set an example for the rest of the nation, but that was forty-two years ago.
Dennis Perren, baritone, made a pleasing impression in a debut performance at yesterday afternoon's Twilight Concert in Carnegie Recital Hall.
A program to eliminate some of drabness from hospital life for elderly patients and to reduce the cost of caring for them is being undertaken by the Department of Hospitals.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- There is a man at the missile base here whose blue-gray eyes harmonize with the dark blue of his Air Force tie and the paler blue walls of his office. The office has all sorts of pictures, models and ashtrays based on rockets and missiles.

WHEN Stravinsky's "The Rite of Spring" had its premiere in Paris in 1913, it was probably the last thing that any one dreamed possible that one day the composer would be honored with a program of his works in a Protestant Episcopal Church on New York's Fifth Avenue.

A floor in 16 East Fortieth Street, near Fifth Avenue, has been leased by the International Silver Company, manufacturer of International Sterling, 1847 Rogers Bros. Silverplate and other brands. The lease was negotiated by Collins, Tuttle Co., broker, through Williams Co., agent for the building.
Top officials in the Eisenhower Administration have adopted a rule against risky special Congressional elections.
A state Republican leader said yesterday that key public officials probably devoted more time to politics than their jobs.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The White House is on the verge of announcing the forced resignation of Richard A. Mack as a member of the Federal Communications Commission.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Feb 28 -- A tougher attitude by British Columbia in negotiating on socalled downstream benefits in the United States from developments on the Columbia River is indicated in the latest Government statement on this subject.
A 17-year-old boy was held yesterday in $2,500 bail as the writer of letters intimidating a witness and threatening the court where seven gang members are being tried for murder.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Eisenhower will try to find out from the Soviet Ambassador tomorrow the meaning of Moscow's sudden willingness to hold a foreign ministers' meeting to prepare a conference of heads of government.
In another shining hour, Ron Delany led Villanova University's successful defense of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America team title last Saturday night.
Nearly forty public and private agencies are experimenting with a unified approach to what they consider the breeding ground of most juvenile delinquency -- the "multi-problem family."

ANKARA, Turkey, March 2 -- Naval units and volunteer civilian crews recovered twenty-one more victims today of Turkey's worst marine disaster in sixty-eight years. This brought the total of known dead to 220.

The National Better Business Bureau reported yesterday that it had received 75,000 requests for information and aid last year. Allan E. Backman, executive vice president, in releasing the report for 1957, said this was a record.
Mayor Wagner sought yesterday to head off a strike of 105,000 dressmakers in seven Eastern states.
An experimental blood test for the detection of active tuberculosis has been reported by scientists at Northwestern University Medical School.

The police said yesterday they were confident that distribution of lethal wood alcohol had been stopped in East Harlem and the Bronx. But the origin of the illegal drink has not yet been established, they said.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The Court of Appeals has ruled that a convicted criminal is not entitled to have counsel assigned to him for an appeal as a right.
HOW does the world learn about the United States? A partial answer for Americans was provided in a program, "Foreign Press Review," which started on Channel 4 on Saturday afternoon.
STOWE, Vt., March 2 -- Norton Weboer of Farmington, Me., and Sunny Snite of the Hanover, N. H., today became Eastern junior Alpine combined champions.

Arthur A. Bailey has been named vice president in charge of the Los Angeles office of Foote, Cone Belding. He succeeds Roy Campbell, executive vice president, who is retiring but will continue, as a consultant.

Nylon curtains stretched twelve feet above the entire expanse of the Berkshire School's natural rink in Sheffield, Mass., are receiving much of the credit for the Green and Gray's first Tri-State League hockey championship.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Dr. Henry A. Kissinger, associate director of the Center for International Affairs at Harvard University, urged here tonight action for more flexible attitudes on the part of those dominant in conducting the affairs of the United States Government, including its foreign policy.
The number of physicians in the United States is falling behind the growing population.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -The United States Government will begin exploratory diplomatic discussions with the West Germans this week on their possible role in a concerted Western program of aid to under-developed countries.
The sudden ousting Thursday of the president of the Mutual Broadcasting System by the chairman of the board may represent the fastest shake-up in network history.
Jose Quintero, Theodore Mann and Leigh Connell are producers who seem to have no trouble shifting their focus from Broadway to off Broadway and back again.
The death of four more men raised to twenty-three the city's toll of those known or believed to have died from wood alcohol poisoning during the last six days.
Senator Jacob K. Javits. said yesterday that President Eisenhower should make a "vigorous" and "immediate" demand for increased Federal spending to end the economic slump.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court dismissed today a suit by twenty-three former Hollywood actors and writers who contended they had been unconstitutionally blacklisted from the movie industry.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Eisenhower praised B'nai B'rith today for its activities in human rights.
ALBANY, March 3 -- The Assembly approved and sent to Governor Harriman tonight a bill designed to simplify procedures for City Charter revision.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- The little man who wasn't there ten years ago has become one of Asia's most promising economic assets. He is the small businessman.
St. Joseph's House of Hospitality, a refuge for the poor and unfortunate, is in trouble again.

The commanders of the first two ballistic missile squadrons being organized by the United States were in New York yesterday to show models of the Thor and Jupiter, weapons they will soon help to deploy in Europe.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- A change in the duties for some members of the Los Angeles Dodgers' front office staff will be made in the near future. Walter O'Malley, who has been the club president for seven years, will hand over more of his work to E. J. (Buzzie) Bavasi.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 3 -- Ezra Taft Benson warned the Republican party today that it would lose the farm vote if it turned its back on the Administration's farm program.
THE woman who cannot decide whether to buy a chemise this spring is now faced with a more provocative problem. She may not be able to buy any new dress -- with or without a waistline.

With the six-man selection committee voting by telephone, Bradley (18-5) of Peoria, Ill., and St. Francis (17-4) of Loretto, Pa., yesterday were named to two of the three vacant basketball berths in the National Invitation Tournament.

RICHMOND, Va., March 3 -- The American Automobile Association has supported legislation to give a 1 per cent bonus to states regulating outdoor advertising along the 41,000-mile interstate highway system.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3 -- The big man was deeply tanned and looked healthy, but up close you could see the lines in his face, the gray hair around his cap and how, when he moved around in the outfield, he was no Nijinsky.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court held unconstitutional today a California statute forbidding rail and other carriers to reduce rates on military shipments, except by permission of the state Public Utilities Commission.

By a seasonal coincidence this week's exhibition schedule includes work by several of the most sturdy representatives of what methodical historians now refer to as "younger generation" painters. In the United States the younger generation, in the visual arts at any rate, reaches its categorical limit at the ge of 35. Both of the painters referred to in this column make it.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 3 (AP) -- The Texas Republican Executive Committee gave H. J. (Jack) Porter, national committeeman, a unanimous vote of confidence today and decided to keep a $100,000 political fund he raised. The Republican National Committee had rejected the money.
CHICAGO, March 3 -- College-level courses in high school were urged today for gifted children.

The New York City Housing Authority explained yesterday why it was pressing for the eviction of the families of three youths who were arrested after the killing of 15-year-old Michael Farmer last summer. The families live in a low-cost project in Harlem.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 3 -- President Sukarno and former Vice President Mohammed Hatta held a ninety-minute talk today. It generated optimism among some political moderates here about the possibility of reuniting the two ideologically estranged Indonesian leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Despite surface diplomatic courtesies, the Administration is profoundly disappointed by the latest Soviet proposals for a heads - of - government conference.
WARSAW, March 3 -- Only six members out of seventy-five stood against Wladyslaw Gomulka to the end of the voting that wound up a turbulent meeting of the Polish Communist Central Committee Saturday.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today the new six-man Civil Rights Commission. Southern committee members voted against the three Northern commissioners.
Net income of the Coca-Cola Company and its consolidated subsidiaries last year rose 2.5 per cent to $29,919,776, from $29,196,584 in 1956.
Auto production continues to lag well behind the 1957 pace.

Graham-Paige Corporation stockholders were advised yesterday that they might receive later this year their first dividend in thirty-two years. John J. Begren, chairman, and Irving Mitchell Felt, made the announcement in the annual report.
The National Maritime Union won a tactical victory yesterday when a Federal judge reversed as "clearly erroneous" his own recent decision in the Robin Line labor certification case.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court today held illegal the Army policy of giving draftees less than honorable discharges because of subversive activities before their induction.

TRENTON, March 3 -- The Assembly approved today a 1-cent a-gallon increase in the tax on gasoline. The present state rate is 4 cents. The measure, which now goes to the Senate, was adopted by a vote of 40 to 8.
Deputy Commissioner Robert J. Mangum, head of the Police Department Juvenile Aid Bureau, who is recovering from injuries received in an auto accident Oct. 12, returned to duty yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 3 -- Embattled leaders of the Pennsylvania Democratic organization agreed unanimously today on Gov. George M. Leader for United States Senator and Mayor David L. Lawrence of Pittsburgh for Governor.
An investigation to determine whether negligence was involved in the death of a 30- year-old tuberculosis patient is being conducted by officials of Van Etten Hospital in the Bronx.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 3 -- Approximately 4,000,000 Colombians will be eligible to vote in the nation's March 16 general election, it was estimated today after the close of registration.

ROME, March 3 -- The Vatican newspaper said today that automatic excommunication had been incurred by a man and wife who caused the Roman Catholic Bishop of Prato to be tried and sentenced for criminal defamation of character.
The Steamship Office Workers Union scored its third consecutive success yesterday in its drive to organize the white collar personnel of ship lines here.

PREVAILING weather conditions last night made the Brahms "Regenlied" Sonata in G an appropriate opening number for the joint recital at Town Hall by John Corigliano, violinist, and Heida Hermanns, pianist.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Most grain futures contracts finished with gains on the Board of Trade today. Only soybeans had plus signs for all contracts.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- Two seniors of Newton (Mass.) High School placed first and second tonight in a nation-wide science competition in which 25,035 high school seniors participated.

When Vincent J. Squillante left the Federal Detention Headquarters at 427 West Street a month ago to serve a one-year sentence at the United States Penitentiary in Lewisberg, Pa., he interrupted a friendship that had grown almost poetic.
Today's new film is "The Confessions of Felix Krull," a German import with English titles based on the novel by Thomas Mann, at the Guild Theatre. The drama stars Henry Bookholt and Lisa Pulver.
" Leave It to Beaver," a filmed domestic comedy currently televised on Friday evenings, appears to be the leading contender to replace the first half-hour of "The Big Record" beginning March 26.
LOS ANGELES, March 3 -- The Los Angeles Metropolitan Transit Authority bought the city's two major transit lines today -- and along with them $2,600,000 worth of new buses.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Herbert H. Lehman said today President Eisenhower "is long overdue in applying moral force" to bring about compliance in the South with the Supreme Court's decision outlawing school segregation.

Making an earth satellite is a blue-sky business. There are no precedents, no guidances, no reference books, no formulas, nothing to use as a starting point. The nose cone on the Jupiter-C, four-stage vehicle that put the Explorer into orbit on Jan. 31, is made of stainless steel.
The Board of Education opened two special schools yesterday for pupils suspended in the crackdown on juvenile delinquency.
ALBANY, March 3 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

Like all Ivy League football coaches who need not concern themselves with the grueling task of spring practice, Buff Donelli of Columbia has much time on his hands these days. So he's been spending most of it looking for high school players, talking to their coaches and extolling the virtues of a Columbia education.

There's a gold rush on among American investors. The flurry does not involve buying the yellow metal, which cannot legally be owned by Americans except in tiny amounts, but buying shares in gold-producing companies.
The sharpest decline in more than a year was registered during January in the volume of contracts for future construction in the United States.

The chief of the nation's 1,250,000 unionized steel workers gave it as his "judgment" last night that President Eisenhower's Council of Economic Advisers would resign because of inability to convey views on the current recession to him.

The edge of the price war in small appliances was off yesterday in New York stores. Crowds were as big as ever in department stores. But there was no frantic grabbing for bargains in General Electric, Sunbeam and Toastmaster toasters, irons and similar products.

The new Lunt-Fontanne Theatre has a flexible premiere date for its first attraction, "The Visit." In case the house, which is undergoing extensive remodeling, isn't in shape to greet the Lunts on April 14, the gala occasion will be deferred to May 1.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- The twenty-nine-ration Asian-African bloc has been summoned to meet Wednesday behind closed doors to discuss the critical situation in North Africa.

ST. PETERSBURGH, Fla., March 3 -- Four years ago when Elston Howard, a powerfully framed outfield prospect, came up from the Kansas City farm club for his first tryout with the Yankees, Casey Stengel made one of his startling announcements.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- Four Governors protested to Congress today that the Army's plan to cut its National Guard strength by 10 per cent would dangerously weaken defenses.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today fixed Oct. 13 for a second round of arguments in the dispute between the Federal Government and five Gulf states over the ownership of the submerged land in the Gulf of Mexico.
The number of New York workers out of jobs so long that they have exhausted their unemployment insurance pay is running more than 50 per cent ahead of last year.
Young victims of last autumn's flood disaster in Valencia, Spain, will benefit from a concert to be held at Town Hall on April 15.

The Constiution is "for the despicable as well as for the admirable,'' the United States Court of Appeals said yesterday in unanimously reversing contempt of court convictions against two men involved in the acid blinding of Victor Riesel.

The average reader following the news stories dealing with the attitude of Congress toward the retention of Ezra Taft Benson as Secretary of Agriculture might be forgiven if he concluded that the only Republican standing behind this dedicated and courageous friend of the farmer was the man who appointed him, President Eisenhower.

The Committee of One Million Against the Admission of Communist China to the United Nations called on the United States yesterday for immediate action to obtain an answer from Peiping on the fate of 450 missing Americans captured in the Korean war.

NEWARK, March 3 -- A fare increase estimated to yield close to $10,000,000 a year was sought today by the Public Service Coordinated Transport. Half the 5,000 local buses in New Jersey are run by the company, which carried 24,910,540 passengers in January.

IF we do not ordinarily think of the harpsichord as an instrument of modern music that is not the fault of Sylvia Marlowe. In the last of three delightful evenings of harpsichord music last night in Carnegie Recital Hall Miss Marlowe played three fine twentieth - century chamber works in which the harpsichord has a central part.

The late Wendell Willkie, circumnavigating the globe a century or so ago -- or was it only sixteen years ago? -- came back with a conception of what he called "One World." His thinking rose out of a wartime sense of urgency, yet it also had more hope in it than he might derive from such a journey today.

The American Export Lines yesterday confirmed a report that it was withdrawing from service one of its four combination passenger ship-freighters, known as the "Four Aces." The reason given was the decline in ocean cargoes between the United States and the Mediterranean.

A special grand jury was sworn in yesterday to investigate ambulance chasing in Kings County. Much of the testimony taken at an Appellate Division inquiry is expected to be submitted to the new panel.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The White House announced today details of an agreement between President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon on what is to be done if the President becomes disabled.

MIAMI, March 3 -- John W. Galbreath owns the Pittsburgh Pirates and he also owns Darby Dan Farm. The Pirates are going nowhere in a baseball way -- unless it be to California to play the Giants and Dodgers. But Darby Dan is going far in horse racing, perhaps even to the creation of one of the great breeding dynasties on the American turf.
The New York City Housing Authority announced plans yesterday for the sale of two issues of short-term notes totaling $33,520,000.
NOT for the first time, the actors are more entertaining than the script.
The trustees of Columbia University announced yesterday that Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Dean of the Faculty of Medicine and College of Physicians and Surgeons since 1931, would retire on June 30.

A quarter-century of labor peace in the billion-dollar-a-year dress industry is scheduled to end at 10 A. M. tomorrow. Orders for a strike of 105,000 dressmakers in New York and six other Eastern states were issued last night by the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
ALBANY, March 3 -- The Senate unanimously approved the Suffolk County Charter Bill today. It provides for a county executive type of government similar to those in Nassau and Westchester Counties.

ONE more award won't hurt the world irretrievably, or make the award industry any sillier than it is. But this is going to be a sensible award; that is, it will be named for the recipient, or awardee, and the donor will keep the trophy.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 3 -- British business men exhibiting at the Leipzig Fair reported today that the British Federation of Industries was negotiating an informal trade agreement with East Germany.
LONDON, March 3 -- After a warm debate the House of Commons rejected today a Labor party motion censuring the Government for lifting some rent controls and relaxing others.

LAHTI, Finland, March 3 (UP) -- Paavo Korhonen, a 30-year-old electrician, scored today for Finland in the world Nordic ski championships, winning the Nordic combined event, a test of jumping and cross - country ability.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- Judge Arthur P. Bretherick recommended today that unwed mothers of three or more children be jailed.
DETROIT, March 3 -- The Chrysler Corporation agreed today to schedule forty hours of work for as many employes as possible and to lay off most of the others.

HAVANA, March 3 -- Eight rebels were killed in an encounter with Government troops at Belic, near Niquero on the south coast of Oriente Province, according to a communique isused today by army headquarters at Camp Columbia.
BONN, March 3 -- Prosperous, inflation-shy West Germans put up more than $100,000,000 to acquire as private property about one hundred tons of gold last year.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today told the United States Court of Appeals here to take another look at a chemist's efforts to prevent the Atomic Energy Commission from publishing details of his method for making heavy water.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Sam Goody, New York's largest phonograph retailer, lost a legal battle today on claims arising from his sale of pirated records.
The seven teen-age members of the Egyptian Dragons gang accused of killing Michael Farmer were put in separate cells yesterday in Manhattan City Prison (the Tombs).
Members of the nation's two largest unions of marine engineers appeared yesterday to have voted heavily in favor of opening formal negotiations to merge their organizations.
GUATEMALA, March 3 -- Col Guillermo Flores Avendano, who was Provisional President until Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes took over yesterday, became Minister of Defense in the new Government today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today a demand by six states that Chicago be required to return to Lake Michigan water taken for domestic use and now discharged into the Illinois Waterway.
PARIS, March 3 -- A Foreign Ministry official said tonight that the latest note to the French Government was a "step -- perhaps only a small one" -- toward an East-West headsof-government meeting.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- The United States wants both the United Nations Disarmament Commission and the Security Council to discuss the disarmament deadlock as a preliminary to the proposed meeting of heads of government.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Administration has rejected an Air Force proposal to speed the development of the first atomic-powered plane.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court held 8 to 1 today that Federal court rules of practice had the effect of law in perjury charges growing out of them.

SEAFORD, L. I., March 3 -- The Case of the Herrmann House is a month old today. Last night, after four days of quiescence, it kicked up again. The case remains a Whodunit without a crime, a criminal or a solution.
GENEVA, March 3 -- Saudi Arabia reminded delegates of eighty-three nations at a United Nations conference on the law of the sea today that the laws they were codifying applied only in time of peace.

BERLIN, March 3 -- The Communist party, which controls the organization and financing of higher education in East Germany, has yet to win the minds of most teachers and students, a party congress has disclosed.

Sugar Hart, speedy Philadelphia welterweight, defeated Duke Harris of Detroit in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The victory was by majority vote, and it had a mixed reception by the crowd of 1,401.
Legislation will be introduced in Congress this week to set up a program of Federal aid to match state funds given to day care centers for children of working mothers.
ALBANY, March 3 -- The Public Service Commission reported today that present Long Island Rail Road fares were "not unreasonable" and added a warning they might be raised again soon.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -The Supreme Court left standing today a decision that bars foreign lawyers from practicing foreign law in New York unless they become members of the New York Bar. The rule had been attacked as unconstitutional discrimination against aliens.
MOGADISHU, Somaliland, Feb. 10 -- "We are heading for what I believe you Americans call a showdown in our own ranks before we reach independence."

MIAMI, March 3 (AP) -- Pardala, a 3-to-1 shot, today won the $39,550 Black Helen Handicap at Hialeah. Under a hustling ride by Dave Erb, Pardala came from fifth place in the long straightaway to beat the favored Amoret by a neck.
Prices of cotton futures moved 9 points up to 19 points off yesterday.
Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, arrived here by plane yesterday from Paris, where she recently won the world women's figure skating championship for the third straight time.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 3 (UP) -- President Hernan Siles Suazo announced today his desire to resign from office as a solution to Bolivia's latest political crisis.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to increase the lending authority of the Export-Import Bank by $2,000,000,000. But final Senate approval was held up by a belated motion to reconsider.

Most coffee positions soared the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The spot month has no limit and advanced more than 2 cents. The strength followed reports that Colombia had raised minimum export prices.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court rejected today a Government motion to move the so-called Memphis natural gas case forward on its calendar and set an early date for argument.
TRENTON, March 3 -- Former Representative Harrison A. Williams Jr. was designated by Gov. Robert B. Meyner tonight as the Democratic organization candidate for United States Senator.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 3 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia has withdrawn her minister in Tirana, the Albanian capital, in protest against mishandling of Yugoslav diplomats by Albaian authorities, a usually well-informed source said here tonight.
THE first runway that French fashions hit when they make their American debut is not red-carpeted. It is a cement strip at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- The National Broadcasting Company is in the process of closing a deal to purchase 138 of the half-hour filmed shows "People Are Funny," made by John Guedel and Art Linkletter. The purchase price reportedly is more than $1,000,000.

Plans have been made known for a 100-unit Howard Johnson motel on a six-acre tract on the northeast corner of the interchange of U. S. Route 1, New Jersey Route 18 and the New Jersey Turnpike, in New Brunswick, N. J.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The exclusive exemption of labor unions from the antitrust laws has given them unique power to compel steady rises in labor costs of production. Though statisticians disagree on the degree to which these rises have inflated prices and depressed consumption, the preponderant conclusion is that some degree exists.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers today announced antitrust action against the United States Trotting Association, charging the association had obtained a "stranglehold" over harness racing in this country.
A question of double jeopardy for a defendant in a murder case will be raised on Thursday in General Sessions Court.

THE FAIR - HAIRED BOY," which was last night's vehicle on "Studio One in Hollywood" over Channel 2, was concerned with the struggle for power in the motion-picture business. It took a long time to cover the familiar ground.
A $176,500 claim was presented yesterday for the loss of three unpublished manuscripts 250 feet under the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.

A recent article by Edward Teller and Albert Latter in Life Magazine gives the impression that an agreement to stop nuclear testing is impractical because violations would be undetectable. An editorial by Eugene Rabinowitch in the January Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists says that monitored cessation of nuclear tests is technically feasible but would be useless as a first step in disarmament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said today that "it is very much in the interest of the United States" to continue to provide economic assistance for Asian countries.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- The Soviet Union released tonight the text of its message to France accepting a foreign ministers' conference as a prelude to a meeting of chiefs of government of East and West. Moscow suggested that the foreign ministers meet in Geneva in April in preparationfor a summit meeting in June.
Consumers have not been the only beneficiaries of the present price war in small appliances. Newspapers and radio advertising also is receiving a considerable impetus.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senate Democratic leaders have given top priority to a $3,000,000,000 housing bill in their program of anti-recession legislation.

PARIS, March 3 -- Robert Murphy, United States Deputy Under Secretary of State, still is doing more listening than talking in his effort to settle the bitter dispute between France and Tunisia.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator John L. McClellan accused the Kohler Company today of "low" and "rotten" tactics after disclosure that it had ordered pictures taken of Senate investigators seen talking to a United Auto Workers attorney.

OSLO, Norway, March 3 (UP) -- The crippled United States team scored a 6-1 victory over Norway tonight in the world aamteur ice hockey tournament after the favored Canadians routed Finland, 24 -- 0. Czechoslovakia defeated Poland, 7 -- 1, in today's other game.
The New York Central Railroad has laid off more than 300 employes, it was announced last night. It is prepared to "furlough" at least 550 more this month.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Governor Harriman and Republican legislative leaders became embroiled tonight in a dispute over legislative payroll practices.

With corporate reports in the flood stage, the First National City Bank of New York has ladled up some preliminary figures for its monthly letter, just published. Reports for 2,474 companies show net income of $15.4 billion for 1957, an increase of 1 per cent.

Starting today, in sixty-two cities in the United States and Canada, 200,000 persons will attend what may be the most gargantuan sales get-together in history. Thanks to the modern miracle of closed-circuit television they will not have to move a step from the cities in which they live.

Hundreds of tenants in the Lincoln Square area queued up yesterday in unfamiliar offices to pay rent to new landlords. Thousands of others waited for the new owners' agents to knock on their doors, as the old landlords had done early each month.

WHITE PLAINS, March 3 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors today blocked for at least sixty days any move by the County Parkway Authority to collect tolls on the Cross County Parkway and to straighten the four-lane roadway into a modern six-lane divided highway.
Oils and rubbers led an advance in the stock market yesterday that embraced almost every important group. Motors and aircrafts were relative laggards.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Clifford Odets is preparing a Biblical drama of clashing armies and personal jealousies for production by the Jerry Wald Company at Twentieth Century-Fox.
ALBANY, March 3 -- The Senate approved tonight a bill to require a referendum prior to any fluoridation of the New York City water system. The vote was 42 to 13.

Development and Resources Corporation said yesterday that work would start this month on an access road to the site of the Dez dam project in southwestern Iran. The corporation also announced completion of all contract arrangements on proposed preliminary work authorized by the Iranian Government Plan Organization.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Richard A. Mack submitted his resignation from the Federal Communications Commission, late today. President Eisenhower promptly accepted it and called the Commissioner's action "wise."
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Dr. Edward Teller urged Congress today to create a National Institute of Applied Science to spur education in that field.

REVOLUTIONARY HEADQUARTERS, Central Sumatra, March 3 (AP) -- Rebel Premier Sjafruddin Prawiranegara said today his regime would ask the United States for arms if the Jakarta Government sought weapons from the Soviet Union for an invasion of rebel-held territory.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 26 -- When President Petru Groza died here last month, he was buried with due pomp and ceremony, according to Communist custom -- and the rites of the Eastern Orthodox Church.
CINCINNATI, March 3 (AP) -James G. Cross will have opposition in his bid for re-election as president of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union.

LONDON, March 3 -- Prices improved modestly in almost every major section of the stock market today. However, the volume of trading remained small. With the exception of British Government securities and oil shares, price rises were ascribed to the drying up of selling rather than an increase in demand.

Sales of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area last month were, on the average, only 1 per cent below sales in February, 1957. The decline, based on a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times, was considered slight in view of the unusually bad weather in the month.
Blood will be given to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today at the Fordham University Downtown Division, 302 Broadway.
ALGIERS, March 3 -- United States consular officials were notified by the French today that a B-17 plane that landed at Bone last Tuesday was free to leave, but that its cargo of arms would be held.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A sharply divided Supreme Court struck down today some long-established barriers to state taxation of United States property.
Directors of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company declared a 3 per cent stock dividend on the concern's common stock yesterday. The dividend is payable on June 6 to holders of record of May 1.

VIENNA, Austria, March 3 (AP) -- Dr. Karl Fellinger, head of a clinic in Vienna's School of Medicine, and two assistants say they have discovered the virus that causes serum hepatitos, better known as infectious jaundice.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Government need not prove the "likely source" of a person's income when it prosecuted him for tax evasion under the "net-worth" method.
In the face of a heavy new supply of corporate public utility bonds awaiting marketing, prices of new offerings of this kind beat a visible retreat yesterday.
Two of the city's major hotels, the Astor on Times Square and the Ambassador, on Park Avenue, changed hands yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court order that Prince Edward County in Virginia make a "prompt and reasonable start" toward ending school segregation. The case is generally regarded as a crucial test of Southern resistance to the Supreme Court's 1954 decision holding public school segregation unconstitutional.
A study of 145 serious heart wounds treated at Harlem Hospital during the last twenty-five years suggests that extensive surgery is the best treatment.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- The Senate approved by voice vote today a bill that would extend the school milk program for two more years.

There are few developments more significant or interesting in the contemporary history of Latin America than the way the Roman Catholic Church has been moving in against the military dictatorships. So far as Cuba in concerned, it certainly is true that the action of the Catholic hierarchy in calling for a "national union government" on Friday ranks as one of the most important events in the island's recent history.

It is ironic that our New York State legislative leaders should announce their denial of small salary increases to the low paid state employes simultaneously with the reaching of a new peak in the consumer price index. Instead of raising the too little appropriation of $7,780,000 recommended By Governor Harriman, the Republican legislative majority has eliminated it entirely.

PURIM, which will be celebrated by members of the Jewish faith this Thursday, is a holiday for having a good time. It commemorates the occasion in ancient Persia more than 2,400 years ago, when Queen Esther intervened with her husband to deliver the Jews from extermination at the order of the king's minister, Haman.

The ceiling at the right had a big gaping hole, the draperies were filthy beyond description and literally falling apart.

It comes as no great surprise to anyone inside or outside the Soviet Union that Nikita S. Khrushchev's latest revolutionary reform in Soviet agriculture has now been approved by the Communist party Central Committee only a few weeks after Mr. Khrushchev first voiced his proposal publicly.

IN the late summer of 1953 Harrison Arlington (Pete) Williams Jr., a 33-year-old lawyer from Plainfield, N. J., was the last-minute Democratic nominee for the House of Representatives in a district that had never sent a Democrat to Congress.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 3 (Reuters) -- Gen. Nuri as-Said, Iraqi elder statesman and a major figure in Middle Eastern affairs since World War I, became Premier today in a move to strengthen the fledgling Iraqi-Jordanian federation.
Sales and earnings of the National Lead Company in 1957 were lower than in 1956 but still were the second highest in the company's history, Joseph A. Martino, president, reported yesterday.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 3 (UP) -- Cleveland's General Manager, Frank Lane indicated today that Chico Carrasquel, the Indians' shortstop, faced the possibility of a financial penalty for reporting late.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- American Broadcasting Company executives told the Federal Communications Commission today the television audience stood to lose some programs of high quality if the Commission adopted staff proposals for drastic changes in network business policies.
GENEVA, March 4 -- The Soviet Union said today that the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea should outlaw tests of Muclear weapons on the high seas.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Ambassador Ali Amini of Iran said today that he had been recalled because of a speech he made a month ago advocating a Middle Eastern oil pool.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Dr. Eugene Byrd, a Miami, (Fla.) psychologist, today told Senators a story of mass beatings with a heavy leather strap at an institution for delinquent boys.

ALGIERS, March 4 -- Gen. Raoul Salan, French commander in Algeria, reported today that the French Army killed 8,000 rebels during the first two months of 1958. In the same period 500 French troops were killed, he said.
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company had record sales and earnings in 1957, according to the annual report issued for publication today.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 4 -East Germany is a land of startling contrasts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Before directing "Green Mansions" for Metro, Mel Ferrer will resume acting to play a co-starring role with Inger Stevens and Harry Belafonte in "End of the World." The picture is being independently co-produced for the studio by Mr. Belafonte and Sol C. Siegel.
CHICAGO, March 4 -- A surgeon urged smokers today to get chest X-rays every six months to detect any signs of lung cancer.

HARTFORD, March 4 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff opened a special session of the Connecticut Legislature to deal with the unemployment situation today. He called for "humaneness, calm thinking and forthright action."

Unconvinced by all the evidence from competent scientific, medical and dental authority, the New York State Senate has passed a bill to require a referendum prior to fluoridation of the New York City water supply.

"Dick and the Duchess" has been granted a reprieve. The comedy-adventure series starring Patrick O'Neal and Hazel Court, which had been scheduled to end March 22, will continue in a new time period-Fridays from 7:30 to 8 P. M.

MANY people in television often tend to think of programing in the superficial terms of formats. Whether a presentation is live or on film, whether it runs thirty or sixty minutes or whether it is produced in New York or Hollywood supposedly affords some magic guide to its quality or mediocrity.
IN the dual role of observed and observer, Blanche Thebom usually rates and makes good criticism. The mezzo-soprano's recent trip to Russia was no exception.
Last-ditch efforts to head off a strike of 105,000 dressmakers in New York and six near-by states collapsed last night.

Five years ago today the Soviet Government officially announced the death of Joseph Vissarionovich Djugashvili -- better known to history as Stalin. For almost thirty years he had ruled unchallenged over the Soviet Union, and by the time of his death he had become the most powerful single individual in the world.

Two new issues of senior public utility securities, $40,000,000 of mortgage bonds of Ohio Edison Company and $25,000,000 of preferred stock of Public Service Electric and Gas Company, are being offered for public subscription today.
Mount Sinai Hospital's refurbished pediatric surgical and orthopedic ward was dedicated yesterday. This completed the four-year modernization program of the Pediatric Pavilion.
George Jones, 11 years old, told the police yesterday that he had pushed two younger playmates into the Hudson River, one last summer and the other last Sunday.

Reversing itself for the third time within a week, the Communist regime of North Korea, whose forces pirated a passenger plane over South Korea, again announces its willingness to release the kidnapped passengers and crew, including the two American pilots.
By a vote of 21 to 1, the City Council requested the State Legislature yesterday to approve Mayor Wagner's plan for a nine-member commission to revise this city's Charter.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower approved today a plan for compensating financial payments to military personnel living in substandard Government quarters in this country or overseas.
SINCE there's nothing quite as tonic as having an Anouilh comedy open on Broadway every few months, we must consider ourselves lucky that "The Waltz of the Toreadors" has come back.

A CONCENTRATED, astringent atmosphere encloses the schematic figures in Lester Johnson's new paintings at the Zabriskie Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street. This atmosphere is so opaque, so intensely worked, that the few human profiles, potted plants and outlines of tables and room interiors take on a supernatural aura.
A railroad with only ninety-six miles of track may not be a New York Central, but is that any reason for its not being modern?

A police helicopter hunted down a stolen car fleeing at speeds up to 100 miles an hour in a twisting, six-mile chase through Queens yesterday. Three of the five teen-agers in the car were arrested after the driver lost control and crashed into a tree. The other two youths escaped on foot.
ALBANY, March 4 (AP) -- A bill that would add five days to the 1958 thoroughbred horse racing season won unanimous approval in the Assembly today, and was expected to gain Senate approval soon.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The volume of consumer installment credit outstanding declined in January, but by a smaller ratio than is customary for the month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The director of the International Cooperation Administration denied today that American foreign aid funds had been used for frivolous purposes.

Two floors in the office building rising at 200 East Forty-second Street have been leased by the New York Compensation Insurance Rating Board from Joseph Durst, builder and owner. The board consists of 144 insurance carriers authorized to issue workmen's compensation insurance in this state.
MIAMI, March 4 (AP) -- Tartan Stable's Chilean-bred Meeting took the lead soon after the start and raced home five lengths in front of twelve others in the $99,000 Hialeah Turf Handicap today.
Most cotton futures declined yesterday. Final prices were unchanged in the October contract to 11 points (55 cents a bale) lower in the expiring March. Trading was moderate.
OSLO, March 4 (AP) -- The defending champion, Sweden, crushed American hopes in the world ice hockey tournament tonight by sending the injuryhit United States team to an 8-3 defeat.
PARIS, March 4 -- The French Cabinet resolved a dangerous conflict among its members today by giving absolute priority in the 1958 military budget to the Algerian war.
The Eastern College Athletic Conference received a call at its Newark headquarters the other day.
PARIS, March 4 -- Holders of founders shares in the Universal Suez Canal Company approved today a reorganization of the company's capital structure.
LONDON, March 4 -- The gold and dollar reserves, held by Great Britain as central banker for the sterling area scored another substantial gain last month.

Once again, and by the impressive vote of 131 to 9, the New York State Assembly has approved legislation to compensate the innocent victims of hit-run, illegally used and uninsured out-of-state automobiles. This is the logical complement to compulsory automobile liability insurance, now in its second year of effectiveness in New York.

Fred H. Hill has contracted to sell the four tenement buildings on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 347-53 East Eighty-first Street. the property, near First Avenue, is assessed at $80,000. It is being sold to Herbert Jacobson, president of the Caram Construction Corporation.
DETROIT, March 4 (UP) -Don McKenney's twelve-foot goal, with less than two minutes left, tonight enabled the Boston Bruins to score a 2-1 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -The Secretary General of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization declared today that the eight-nation alliance was beginning to function as an effective barrier to Communist expansion.
Governor Harriman says he is in favor of banning advertising billboards from the National System of Defense and Interstate Highways, a joint Federal-states project now under construction.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Wednesday, March 5 -- Private capital should be attracted to Asia through a collective effort by interested countries in channels provided by United Nations economic organizations, Prime Minister Abdul Rahman told delegates to the opening session of a conference of the Economic Commission for Aid to Asia and the Far East this morning.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The United States and its fifteen allies who fought in the Korean war agreed tentatively today to reject Communist China's recent proposal to withdraw all foreign troops from North and South Korea.
ALBANY, March 4 -- The Assembly moved today to protect the state's motorists and pedestrians against the few uninsured drivers still using New York highways.
PARIS, March 4 -- The North Atlantic Council looked the latest Soviet gift horse in the teeth tonight and found the teeth false.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Despite solid opposition from public and private relief agencies, the Senate approved by 30-24 today a bill setting a one-year residence requirement for receiving any form of public relief.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- Bobby Shantz, the Yankees' vest-pocket southpaw, is a busy little man these days. Somewhere along the line he has mislaid something and he's determined to recover it. It's his slow ball, or let-up pitch.
Directors of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation declared a 25-cent quarterly dividend yesterday, payable on March 28 to holders of record March 14. In previous quarters a 40-cent dividend was paid.
Choice items from the shelves of the Irvington House Thrift Shop will be sold at a booth at the fourteenth annual National Antiques Show in Madison Square Garden from March 10 through March 16.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee agreed informally today to hold a hearing on Alaska statehood legislation "sometime after March 15."

RABAT, Morocco, March 4 -- The Moroccan Defense Ministry announced today that it had sent reinforcements to the Moroccan Royal Army posts of Goulimine and Bou Ikakarn, a few miles west of the Ifni enclave.
The Council Child Development Center will benefit from the April 10 performance of "Who Was That Lady I Saw You With ?" at the Martin Beck.
The work of medical missionaries in Africa is the subject of three books, two of them novels, that will be issued this season.

SEAFORD, L. I., March 4 -- A flying flashbulb became the latest object to break the peace in the James M. Herrmann household here today. In the space of an hour, there were four other unexplained incidents.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Secretary of the Air Force reaffirmed today the verdict of guilty brought against Brig. Gen. William (Billy) Mitchell in a court-martial nearly thirty-three years ago.
ALBANY, March 4 -- A bill to prevent the Liberal party from designating "dummy" candidates for public office received final approval today in the Senate.
GOOD seasonings used deftly can definitely contribute to good nutrition. So says Dr. Norman Jolliffe, director of the Bureau of Nutrition of the city's Department of Health.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 4 (UP) -- The Little Rock School Board said tonight it had expelled a 16-year-old pro-segregationist white girl from Central High School because the girl and her mother had attacked a faculty member.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The average 1958 salary for college and university faculty members is $6,120, according to a study issued today by the Federal Office of Education.

KASSERINE, Tunisia, March 3 -- The war in Algeria has spilled over into Tunisia again, this time in the form of human wreckage. Seventeen hundred refugees have crossed the border in the last week in the wake of what is called a "ratissage" by French troops in the region of Bekkaria.

ALBANY, March 4 -- A bill designed to weaken the hold of the Transport Workers Union on the New York City subway system was vetoed today by Governor Harriman. The measure would have permitted the State Labor Relations Board to designate craft unions representing segments of transit employes as collective bargaining units for their members.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles rejected today a "pre-summit" foreign ministers' meeting on the terms proposed by the Soviet Union.
In resigning from a post to which he should not have been appointed, Federal Communications Commissioner Richard A. Mack has taken the only acceptable step he could have taken.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands (AP) -- The Netherlands Government said today that it had protested what it contended was an armed Indonesian attack on a Dutch navy vessel Feb. 20.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., March 4 -- Additional gifts of land to the Mianus River Gorge Conservation project in the Towns of North Castle and Pound Ridge and adjacent Connecticut have increased the preserve to 161.4 acres.
New York University's basketball team defeated City College, an old metropolitan rival, 61 to 53, last night at the Fordham Gym.

Seattle, Wash., borrowed $20,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance expansion of the city's electric light and power facilities. The money was raised by the sale of revenue bonds due serially from 1959 to 1987 at an interest cost of 3.628 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- When John Foster Dulles says "no" to the Soviet Union in 3,000 well-chosen words and is immediately supported by the overwhelming majority of the diplomatic corps, the Congress and the press, it is a fair conclusion that something important has happened in world diplo macy.
MANHASSET, L. I., March 4 -- A long-simmering controversy over a proposed North Hempstead Town incinerator came to a boil today at a six-hour public hearing here.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Army announced today that it had found a way to quadruple the power of existing radar devices and perhaps double their detection range.

GOING steady, the teen-ager's version of Social Security, sometimes defeats its own purpose. This point was made by six Hunter High School girls at a recent meeting of the school's Parent-Teachers Association. The girls are presidents or past presidents of their grades.
Why must we follow the worst examples in history?
BUENOS AIRES, March 4 -- President-elect Arturo Frondizi said tonight he would welcome Government and private cooperation from the United States for Argentina's economic development.
A 15-year-old boy told the police that as he bent over on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive to light a cigarette he was shot last night. He was treated at New York Hospital and released.

Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther expressed the hope here yesterday that Americans would develop emotional stamina and the sophistication in world affairs needed to cope with "the uneasy, dangerous days ahead."
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would crack down on malingerers.
JERSEY CITY, March 4 -- The elaborate furnishings planned for the new quarters of the Hudson County Board of Freeholders were jettisoned today.

A $2,000,000 contract for the design, engineering and construction supervision of a corn processing plant has been awarded by the Corn Products Refining Company through the Bedford Construction Company, its subsidiary, to Walter Kidde Constructors, Inc., engineering and building concern of this city and Houston.
In the annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday, top officials of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation forecast that the steel industry was nearing the bottom of its recession.
LAHTI, Finland, March 4 (AP) -- Finland turned the world Nordic ski championships into a rout today.

Foreign representatives of the Young Women's Christian Association working for democracy in Asia, the Middle East, South America and Africa are facing increasing Communist competition, Mrs. Maurice T. Moore said yesterday. She is chairman of the foreign association division.

For many months the Administration has been urging upon Congress the importance of closing a gap in the Constitution which leaves uncertain the procedure to be followed in case any President of the United States should become unable to perform the duties of his office.

HALEDON, N. J., March 4 -- Because of the gratitude of a Chicago industrialist to the surgeon who had operated on his wife, a small enterprise here is making life possible for persons who otherwise might die.

LONDON, March 4 -- The Soviet Union's insistence that a foreign ministers' meeting in April should be followed by a heads-of-government meeting in June is regarded here as the principal reason for the United States rejection of the latest Soviet proposals.

Three new films open today. "I Accuse" and "The Safecracker" are bracketed on a double bill at various neighborhood theatres. Jose Ferrer stars in the former and also directed Sam Zimbalist's production for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer which includes Anton Walbrook and Viveca Lindfors among the players.

Two prominent criminal lawyers, both usually soft-spoken, appeared close to blows yesterday in General Sessions Court. The lawyers are defending two of seven teen-age members of the Egyptian Dragons gang who are on trial in the killing of Michael Farmer, 15 years old, in High Bridge Park on July 30.

THE little old lady in the little red hat died on Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She had told the nuns when she was brought in a week ago Monday that she was 94 years old. She said she was Mrs. Ida Robinson.
IF the Paris look catches on in New York, full-grown women will be getting into the movies for half price.
"THE chemise," said Sophie Gimbel, the designer, "is everywhere -- and it's dreadful." There is no mistaking this woman's scorn for the sack invasion. Sophie still stands for shape.

ALBANY, March 4 -- A bill to make certain that bingo winnings and door prizes are subject to the state income tax received the approval of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee today. It is expected to come up for a floor vote Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The House subcommittee investigating alleged misconduct in the Federal Communications Commission planned today to press its inquiry, even though Richard A. Mack, a Commissioner, has resigned under fire.

Forest Hills High of Queens defeated Curtis of Staten Island, 59 to 47, DeWitt Clinton High checked Abraham Lincoln of Brooklyn, 65 to 54, and Morris High beat Wingate, 48 to 46 in overtime as the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs continued yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP) -- The itinerary of the Philadelphia Orchestra's eight-week tour of Europe this spring and summer shows that twenty-two of its forty-two concert engagements are in the Soviet Union and Soviet bloc countries.
After sixteen court sessions, the suit to restrain the Government from spraying Nassau and Suffolk County property with DDT from airplanes ended yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn.
Superintendent of Schools William Jansen yesterday replied to critics of the special school for suspended pupils that was opened Monday in Greenwich Village.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Government announced new regulations for the fast tax write-off program today, to fit the tighter law written by Congress last summer.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- The President of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad is uncertain about the future of American rail lines.

TRENTON, March 4 -- The New Jersey Highway Department moved today to speed final Federal approval of the $388,500,000 freeway that is to run from the Holland Tunnel to Phillipsburg. Dwight R. G. Palmer, State Highway Commissioner, set March 19 for a public hearing on the alignment of a seventeen-mile stretch of the new artery through Somerset and part of Union County.
ROME, March 4 -- The Italian Government was much relieved today when lawyers for the Bishop of Prato appealed his conviction for criminal defamation.
MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- Johnny Ruane has been winning races during the Hialeah meeting by as much as eight and nine lengths. Never has he eased up, though. Never has he looked back. He doesn't dare.

Guy Sparrow and Richie Guerin led the New York Knickerbockers to a 104-99 decision over the champion Boston Celtics before 12,632 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. However, the Philadelphia Warriors, who lead the Knicks by three games in the Eastern Division, downed the Cincinnati Royals, 97 -- 91, in the opener of the National Basketball Association double-header.

The lost and found column appearing daily in this newspaper -- usually on the next to last page -- is, among other things, a reminder of the perishability of jewelry. The majority of losses reported there deals with watches, rings, bracelets, brooches, and the like.
The services of the Police Athletic League will have to be curtailed unless it gets more financial support from the public, Police Commissioner Stephe P. Kennedy warned yesterday.
Money has tightened after several weeks of easing.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today a credit of $24,200,000 to the Government of Israel. The money will be used for expansion of Israeli water supply, irrigation and other facilities for agricultural development with equipment from the United States.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology will move its cosmic ray study center to New Mexico in June. The site will be Volcano Ranch, about fifteen miles west of Albuquerque.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced yesterday more than twenty shifts in its operating staff.

ROME, March 4 (Reuters) -- Leaders of the Government and the ruling Christian Democratic party, which is Roman Catholic, showed acute embarrassment today at being caught between their duties as Catholics and their duties to protect the Italian judicial system.
An enlargement of the site for the Lincoln Square cultural center is being considered by the city's Committee on Slum Clearance.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved in full today the Administration's request for additional funds to operate the United States exhibit at the Brussels Fair.
LONDON, March 4 (Reuters) -- Great Britain has obtained a twelve-month extension from the United States Export-Import Bank on drawing a remaining $250,000,000 in credit, it was announced here today.
ALBANY, March 4 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
The type of hospital insurance coverage held by a person has been called a factor in whether he seeks admission to a hospital or not.
CHICAGO, March 4 -- The Pabst Brewing Company, caught in the throes of a proxy fight, today reported a loss last year of 12.7 per cent in sales and a net loss of $2,871,200.
Two co-chairmen and a secretary were elected yesterday at the first meeting of the joint steering committee of the Regional Park, Recreation and Open Space Project.
RICHMOND, Va., March 4 -- New York State officials were accused today of provoking a "climate of hysteria under which restrictive measures are being enacted in the guise of traffic safety."

"The Entertainer" will have an extended run through the efforts of Laurence Olivier, who portrays the title role. Instead of terminating the sold-out eight-week stand on April 5, David Merrick's production of the John Osborne drama will continue until May 10 at the Royale.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Agreement on $225,000,000 in United States credits to India was announced today by the Export-Import Bank and the Development Loan Fund.

PARIS, March 4 -- Henri Foulon, 19 years old, of La Ferte-Chevresis, in northern France, was recently called to the colors, as all young Frenchmen are sooner or later. But Henri Foulon will not serve.
A LITTLE browsing in the summary of game law violations for the month of December reveals what appear to be several trends, none of them encouraging.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- President Eisenhower exchanged gifts with 4-H Club members today and told them his grandson David might go into 4-H Club work.

JERSEY CITY, March 4 -- A touch of harmony entered the state-wide Democratic political picture tonight when City Commissioner James F. Murray Jr. withdraw from the primary race for United States Senator to run for the House seat from the Fourteenth Congressional District.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Wednesday, March 5 -- Two men were being questioned here early this morning by the local police and New York detectives on the deaths from wood alcohol poisoning in New York.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- "War and Peace," the motion picture based on Tolstoy's novel, will probably be the first major film with Hollywood talent and financing shown to the Soviet people since World War II.

MOGADISHU, Somalia, Feb. 10 -- The dispute between Somalia and Ethiopia over their frontier is posing a problem for the Western powers, who are seeking to maintain a firm friendship between both peoples.
ALBANY, March 4 -- In a bipartisan attempt to quiet public criticism, legislative leaders today ordered a special committee to clean up the Legislature's payrolls as promptly as possible.
MIAMI, March 4 -- Despite mounting evidence that the Cuban dictatorship of President Fulgencio Batista is on its last legs, foes of President Batista living in exile here remain bitterly disunited.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Government took a major step today to accelerate construction of the first nuclear-powered ocean tanker.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Following is the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:
ALEXANDRIA, United Arab Republic, March 4 -- Egypt has decided to accept in effect a devaluation of Egyptian pounds in international exchange.

The proposal of Senator A. S. Mike Monroney for the establishment of a new international lending institution to make long-term loans on less rigid terms than the World Bank, as set forth in The New York Times of Feb. 23, is a valuable contribution to the current discussion of foreign aid.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Emotionalism erupted today in the Senate's investigation of the Kohler Company strike. Frequent clashes occurred among Republicans, Democrats and union witnesses.
CINCINNATI, March 4 (AP) -- James G. Cross, whose dismissal had been sought by the merged labor federation, was re-elected president of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union today.

HAVANA, March 4 -- President Fulgencio Batista reiterated today that he would hold the elections scheduled here June 1. His statement was made in response to an appeal by the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy in Cuba for restoration of peace and the formation of a government of national union.
A 5-year-old redhead, Loretta King of the Bronx, cut a birthday cake yesterday morning for the Greater New York Fund.

The recession will have no effect on the new stores program this year of the Kroger Company, chain grocers, it was said yesterday by Joseph B. Hall, president. He addressed a luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts, Inc.
The recession is forcing companies throughout the nation to look to their sales techniques. Training programs and aggressive selling are being stressed.

Last year and the year before, through the help of your paper, we were successful in obtaining some very fine volunteers. They are still with us at the Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital and Home on Welfare Island.
The United States Maritime Administration repossessed the 437-foot freighter Carib Queen yesterday at a Federal marshal's sale in Jacksonville, Fla.

AFTER World War I, in which he served in the Army Tank Corps, George Theodore Baker worked for an auto finance company in Chicago. Often he had to repossess cars from gangsters who by the very nature of their calling were averse to giving things up.
BRUSSELS, March 1 -- The United States may set a record for candor at an international propaganda contest when the 1958 World's Fair opens here next month.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- West Germany's Defense Minister said tonight that his country would accept a United States offer of Matador pilotless bombers for its new armed services.
City officials and the public "have become hysterical" in the current juvenile delinquency situation, the Rev. C. Kilmer Myers said last night.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Compromises on unemployment insurance and nomination dates for the fall campaign were offered to Republican legislative leaders by Governor Harriman today.

A model of a proposed group of fountains to surround the base of the Columbus Monument was unveiled yesterday. Douglas Leigh, a sign company executive, who has undertaken to contribute and raise the necessary funds at no cost to the city, called it "a touch of the fountains of Rome."

Eighty-nine notices that delivery would be made on expiring contracts for potatoes were issued yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Most of them circulated for some time. This heavy schedule of offerings induced general selling, weakening futures early in the day.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 4 (AP) -- Premier David Ben-Gurion told Parliament today that he hoped the French would be convinced that an arms-carrying B-17 plane that landed in Algeria was en route from Israel to South America.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 4 -- It is perhaps perplexing that Marshal Tito, who invented the heresy of National Communism; doesn't admit National Communism exists. At least that's what he says.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- Congress paid tribute today to the memory of both President Roosevelts -- Theodore and Franklin D.
Helen Hunter, soprano, offered a song program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in which she disclosed a voice of potentially good quality, as yet not fully realized.
May I congratulate you on your editorial of Feb. 24 in which you stress the need for immediate action on unemployment insurance benefits?
Dimitri Mitropoulos will make his final appearances of the season with the New York Philharmonic on March 13, 14 and 16, conducting the first New York performance of the Mahler Tenth Symphony.

Mikhail Botvinnik, the former champion, made an auspicious start yesterday in the return match for the world title with Vassily Smyslov, his successor, when he adjourned their first game after 41 moves with an advantage of two clear pawns, according to a report received here through Soviet news sources.
In tests with animals, tranquilizing drugs have been used to prevent death from shock after severe injuries.
Brooklyn fans won't see the Dodgers at Ebbets Field any more, but they will be able to see baseball and numerous other sports activities at the old ball park this year and in 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Senate Banking Committee, acting with rare speed, gave tentative approval today to key features of a Democratic housing bill designed to combat the recession.
Steels, oils and building materials led a moderate rise yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Authority to call a strike against producers of filmed television commercials was sought today by the board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild. Strike ballots were mailed to the membership to be returned by March 18.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Some enlargement of the Second Banking District appears likely to receive legislative approval this year as a result of conferences here today.
LONDON, March 4 -- Stock market prices rallied further in almost all principal sections today. The recovery was particularly strong in industrials.

A settlement outside of court was announced yesterday in the 1950 libel suit by former Representative W. Kingsland Macy against The New York World-Telegram Corporation. Both sides called the settlement satisfactory, but the terms were not disclosed.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Governor Harriman today gave the Chief of Police of Kingston until March 15 to resign or face removal proceedings.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 4 -- The San Francisco Giants today held "picture day," an annual spring training rite that enables news cameramen and color photographers to swarm over the diamond filming athletes up, down, sideways and jumping through hoops.

W. J. Kishler has been elected president of St. Mary's Woolen Manufacturing Company, a subsidiary of Fieldcrest Mills, Inc. Mr. Kishler, who will continue as treasurer of St. Mary's, succeeds Philip H. Herzing, who has resigned.

THE basis of modern Western civilization is twofold: scientific and industrial. This is as true of Russia as of the United States. But one aspect of American civilization seems to be peculiarly our own, the importance of advertising in our economy and in our culture. In other nations sellers advertise their wares; but nowhere else do advertisements support so lavishly so many other activities, newspapers, magazines, television, radio and the advertising business itself.
CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- The strongest and most constant demand in several days hit all the grain futures pits today. At the close of trading on the Board of Trade there was not a loser in the list.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A House Armed Services subcommittee rejected unanimously today a Defense Department plan to reduce Army National Guard and Army Reserve forces by 10 per cent.

WINTER PARK, Fla., March 4 -- A field of more than 100 cars seems assured for the Great Florida Triangle Rally to be run on March 14, 15 and 16. This will be the first of thirteen or more national rallies on the Sports Car Club of America calendar for 1958.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A bipartisan effort was begun today to authorize a Vice President to take over as acting President whenever a President was unable to carry out his duties.
ROME, March 4 -- The establishment of closer ties between Britain and "Little Europe" will be sought in a seven-nation meeting opening here tomorrow.

The Glen Alden Corporation plans to acquire the business and assets of List Industries Corporation. The announcement was made jointly yesterday by Francis O. Case, president of Glen Alden, and Albert A. List, president of List Industries. Stockholders of both companies will be asked to approve the proposal.
The one-day Jewish festival of Purim will be celebrated beginning at sundown tonight.

SEOUL, Korea, March 4 -- The United Nations Command announced today that the North Koreans had agreed to return at a meeting in Panmunjom Thursday "the persons who wished to return" among those on the South Korean airliner that flew into North Korea last month.

Though New York, as the host team, was ineligible for the team championship, the fighters from the metropolitan area supplied most of the thunder at the Eastern Golden Gloves championships in Madison Square Garden last night.
A leading art periodical, Art News, is appearing today with an editorial that calls the art section of the American Pavilion at the Brussels World's Fair "a public comic scandal."
Britain's latest medium jet transport, the Comet IV, has been granted permission to make demonstration flights at New York International Airport, it was announced yesterday.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 5 -- Duke Snider, Johnny Podres and Don Zimmer of the Los Angeles Dodgers were injured in an automobile accident early today when their car left the road.
Six new housing projects to provide 2,355 low-rent apartments at a cost of $39,668,000 were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

The Italian haute couture arrived here yesterday by proxy and brought with it a touch of spring. Fourteen representatives of Italy's foremost designers for men and women are here to launch the Italian Festival of Fashions, a series of style shows conducted by the Italian Government on behalf of its fashion industry.

ALTHOUGH he feels "very much" pro-union, the president and executive director of United Popular Dress Manufacturers, Inc., never was a member of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union when he was an employe. . . .
BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, March 5 (AP) -- Budge Patty and Gardnar Mulloy today gained the quarter-finals of the Barranquilla city tennis championships.

"THE Legend of Sleepy Hollow" was brought to television last night as a live play with film on "Shirley Temple's Storybook" hour over Channel 4. The saga of Ichabod Crane and his encounter with the Headless Horseman was rather uneven.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 5 -- Princeton triumphed over Pennsylvania, 59 -- 55, tonight in an Ivy League basketball game at Dillon Gym.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The House Government Operations Committee brushed aside opposition by all Government departments today and approved a bill designed to loosen the flow of information to the public.
Net earnings of the CurtissWright Corporation in 1957 were lower than in 1956, but were the second highest in the company's history.
