"WHY does modern furniture cost so much?" a consumer asked a critic yesterday. "Because not enough of you buy it," he retorted.
A dissident group of preferred stockholders of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has settled for less than control.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., March 5 -- Copper cakes as long as twenty-five feet and weighing as much as nine tons are being produced by a new "continuous casting" installation at the American Smelting and Refining Company's refinery here.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Two teachers from the Bronx were among the five top winners in the 1958 Science Teachers Achievement Recognition competition, it was announced today.
The source of the wood alcohol that is believed to have killed twenty-seven persons in New York in the last nine days has been found, the police said yesterday.
JUPITER, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Four of the consistently low scorers in the fifty-first annual South Florida amateur golf championships won semi-final berths today.

MANILA, Thursday, March 6 (AP) -- The Manila Times reported today that three small warships of the Indonesian Government yesterday shelled a port area fifty miles south of the rebelheld city of Menando, North Celebes.

The Harsco Corporation reported yesterday that sales and earnings rose to new highs in 1957 for the fifth consecutive year. The company, formerly the Harrisburg Steel Corporation, produces steel products for industry and reclaims steel from open hearth waste products.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today that the Federal Government must continue to pay $3,500 a day to keep Federal troops in Little Rock, Ark., "to make certain that the Federal courts cannot be defied successfully."

NO ONE needs to tell the next fellow that Nancy Walker in "Wonderful Town" is bound to spell good news for our town. By general consent she is one of the champion buffoons of our time, a lovable clown whose shrug of a shoulder, whose arching of an eyebrow are inevitable harbingers of laughter.

MONTREAL, March 5 (AP) -Eight to twelve workmen were missing and believed killed tonight in the collapse of a coffer dam at a bridge construction site in the Rivieres des Prairies, on the north of Montreal Island.
John Gates, former editor of The Daily Worker who was barred from speaking at City College a year ago, addressed a student group there yesterday.

As it has done so many times in the last three or four years, the Supreme Court has again handed down a major decision on the side of civil liberties and in defense of the individual against the overwhelming power of the state. This tribunal has become the single most effective protector of the rights of the citizen under the Constitution.

SHE travels easiest who travels the way Ann Cox does. Yesterday, between pithy comments on her new spring collection, this designer cheerfully and effortlessly packed an overgrown golf bag with all the clothes she will take to Hawaii and Alaska on a week's flying trip.

United States tramp shipping activity, already hit hard by the cut rates of foreign-flag tramps, is now confronting severe competition from United States tankers, J. C. Anderson said yesterday. Mr. Anderson is executive secretary of the American Tramp Shipowners Association, Inc.
BAGHDAD, Iraq., March 5 -The new Iraqi Cabinet faces the job of making federation with Jordan a working reality.

Nearly every freight shipper will agree that, with 1,700,000-odd freight cars, the nation's railroads are under-euipped. Last week, however, great numbers of those cars, each one of which cost $8,000 or more new, were not working.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- West Germany's Defense Minister outlined today conditions under which the Polish plan for a central European zone free of nuclear weapons might be considered.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Senate rackets committee inquiry into the four-year-old Kohler Company strike erupted into clashes today. At one point the chairman threatened to eject a union lawyer.
LAKE GROVE, L. I., March 6 -- Federal agents and the police raided a farmhouse on Moriches Road here today. They seized a 1,000-gallon-a-day alcohol still and arrested one man.

Three thousand women descended on the Midtown Department Store at Union Square yesterday morning for a sale that offered such apparently irresistible items as 17-cent sweaters, 11-cent handbags, 7-cent pajamas and 2-cent belts.
On Feb. 11, according to an analysis of signals from the satellite Explorer I, there was a marked increase in the intensity of cosmic rays outside the earth's atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Representative Brooks Hays, who tried to mediate the school integration incident in Little Rock, Ark., urged Congress today to make a nation-wide study of the impact of the Supreme Court's decision barring school segregation.
KODIAK, Alaska, March 6 (AP) -- A private plane vanished over the Gulf of Alaska yesterday with six aboard.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- With the weather having been just about the worst in fifty years, according to Al Lang, it wasn't until today that Casey Stengel got around to seeing his full squad engage in its first intramural session.
OSLO, Norway, March 6 (AP) -- Canada became a favorite for the world amateur ice hockey championship today after crushing the defending titleholder, Sweden, 10 -- 2, in a wild, fist-swinging contest.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Navy announced plans today for expanded explorations of the Arctic basin this summer. Three submarines, two of them nuclear-powered, were designated to operate around and under the North Polar ice cap.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Grace DeMoss of St. Augustine, the medalist, was toppled from the women's Florida East Coast amateur golf tournament, leaving the battle for the title to the Curtis Cup player, Mrs. Barbara Romack Porter, and three young champions of their home states.
Donald V. Lowe, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, will begin an intensive trade development tour of the port's leading overseas market on March 17.

PARIS, March 6 -- The United States and British conciliators have suggested simultaneous action by France and Tunisia to break the deadlock on the status of French troops barricaded in Tunisia, French sources said today.

The recent disclosures respecting the presence on the state payroll of political district leaders and of the spouses and relatives of legislators call for a thorough investigation. This should cover the need for the services such individuals are supposed to perform, whether or not they are competent and effective in their respective positions and the relation between what they do and what they are paid for it.

MANILA, Friday, March 7 -- Top military men from the eight nations of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization were winding up today a three-day meeting in advance of the foreign ministers' conference of the organization beginning Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The House of Representatives passed a hotly fought budget reform bill today that sponsors said would save taxpayers billions. Opponents said it eventually would increase Government spending.
TRENTON, March 6 -- Officials of the New Jersey Blue Cross and hospital administrators insisted today that Blue Cross rates must be increased if that organization was to remain solvent.
"BON CHAPEAU" is the name of Bonwit Teller's new collection of spring millinery, and the group is aptly titled.

Robert P. Koenig, president of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation, announced yesterday that production of copper, lead and zinc at its La Croya, Peru, smelting and refining plant was being further reduced "to bring supply more in line with present and prospective short-term future demand.

Four string players well known to record collectors but previously unknown in the flesh to New Yorkers gave a concert last night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
ELKHART, Ind., March 6 -- Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, today dedicated and officially opened the Robert R. Young railroad freight yard here.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined $147,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Of the total, $126,000,000 of the decline was accounted for by reduced sales finance company borrowings.
The congestion of new corporate bonds in the public market was cleared further yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Charles (Babe) Pearson and Stanley W. Pearson of Philadelphia," the defending title-holders, headed the strongest starting field in years as the amateur racquets championship of the United States began yesterday.

HOWARD GREER, famous Hollywood designer, showed his spring collection yesterday at Jay Thorpe. Repeatedly, he made his point of view, as well as a woman's figure perfectly clear, in a series of dresses based on a svelte, strapless sheath filled in with a chest full of marquisette.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, March 7 -- President Sukarno and Dr. Mohammed Hatta were to resume their talks today as reports circulated that Indonesia might be planning an infantry offensive against defiant Central Sumatra.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Sam Rayburn killed today a move to invite three Democratic Senators to testify before a House subcommittee studying the award of a Miami television license.

THE Metropolitan Museum will open to the public today an exhibition of paintings by Sir Winston Churchill. Most of the forty are on loan from the British statesman or members of his family; a few have been lent by private collectors to whom he has presented examples of his work.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6 (UP) -- Willie Mays and Willie Kirkland today were removed from the Giants' traveling list to Tucson for San Francisco's exhibition series opener against the Cleveland Indians on Saturday.

Thoughts of the Old Foxhole When new military weapons are announced -- as they seem to be so frequently these days -- the war veteran is apt to take a purely personal view of them, as well as the view normally taken by the interested citizen.
CAIRO, March 6 (Reuters) -- The eight joint Egyptian-Syrian ministries are:

A group of vice presidents for the city's 'Salute to Spring' was announced yesterday. The project is intended to beautify New York for its residents, attract tourists and spur trade. It will open April 17.

Mississippi borrowed $20,000,000 in the public bond market yesterday to finance public school construction. The bonds were sold at public sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by the First National City Bank of New York at an interest cost of 2.6806 per cent. A syndicate headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank, Blyth Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers bid a cost of 2.697 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Does no one in the Government appreciate the finer things of life?

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- T. S. Peterson, president of the Standard Oil Company of California, told Congress today that putting restrictions on the reciprocal trade program would do "irreparable damage" to national defense.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold indicated today that the dispute between France and Tunisia might be thrown back into the United Nations. In such a case, he said, the "obligations" of his office might cause him to step in.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter to Representative Melvin Price, Democrat of Illinois, on nuclear-powered aircraft:
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, March 6 -- A Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister proposed today a reappraisal of foreign aid.
The prosecution rested its case yesterday in the trial of seven teen-age gang members accused of killing Michael Farmer, a 15-year-old polio victim, last July 30 in High Bridge Park.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated new Ambassadors to the Sudan, Costa Rica, Uruguay and Honduras.
SPAIN'S leading designer, Pedro Rodriguez, has tied the chemise in the middle to make women more shapely.

ROME, March 6 -- France, West Germany and Italy promised today that they would coordinate their armament programs with those of their Western allies and with the Atlantic alliance. The three nations recently formed a pool for standardizing conventional weapons.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 6 (UP) -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin signed a bill today outlawing special advertising taxes levied by subdivisions in Maryland -- a move designed to kill the Baltimore tax on advertising.

Orders for National Cash Register Corporation's electronic computers and other relatively new products in 1957 exceeded those for cash registers, Stanley C. Allyn, chairman, said yesterday. In the annual report, he said 1957 was the first year that this had happened.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Eisenhower has personally decided against the hurried building of an atomic plane for prestige purposes.

Republican "economy" performed on Governor Harriman's budget commits an injustice to New York City in respect to the four municipal colleges. The fact that the money "saved" by this economy is to be transferred to the worthy cause of increased aid to elementary and secondary education does not condone the continuation of an inequity.
Eight persons were injured yesterday when an IND subway train rolled backward into another train south of the Canal Street station. All of the injured were discharged after treatment at a hospital.

BOSTON, March 6 (UP) -- Jerry Toppazzini's second goal of the game earned a 4-4 tie for Boston against the last-place Chicago Black Hawks tonight. The Bruins went into a tie for third place in the National Hockey League with the idle Detroit Red Wings.

It was with a great deal of satisfaction that I read a news item in The New York Times of March 3 reporting the experiment being undertaken by nearly forty public and private agencies in New York City to trace multi-problem families through their delinquent children. In this way it is hoped to help solve the terrible conditions under which they are trying to exist.

It was said of the old Austrian Empire that if it had not existed it would have had to be invented. Now a number of statesmen are in process of "inventing" a North African Union of Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia, which seems equally necessary.
Community opera will be the theme of the fourth annual conference to be sponsored by the National Council of the Metropolitan Opera. The conference will be at the Biltmore Hotel on March 21 and 22.

It soon may become fashionable to own a "limited edition" range or refrigerator. These items are part of a new line of "custom trend" appliances by Hotpoint that appear, on original inspection, to be of radical concept.

EL ADASIYA, Jordan, March 6 -- A line of stone markers shows where a diversion pipe will carry water of the Yarmuk River through a tunnel in the cliffs to irrigate 30,000 acres of the Jordan River valley.
PANAMA, March 6 -- President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr. said today that Point Four week in Panama would start Sunday.

MERCURY, Nev., March 6 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today lifted momentarily the veil of secrecy surrounding its newest installation. It is an $11,000,000 base for the development of nuclear rockets and aircraft propulsion.

Instead of calling it a boat, users of the Kayot creation say it is the "family playground afloat." It has more versatility than most ships of the sea: No cramped quarters on this design, no being miserly with the square inches of elbow room.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Federal Reserve Board approved today a reduction in the discount rate from 2 3/4 o 2 1/4 per cent at the Federal Reserve Banks of New York, Philadelphia and Chicago.

SEOUL, Korea, March 6 -- North Korean anti-aircraft artillery shot down a United States jet fighter plane on a training mission near the demilitarized zone-today. The pilot was seen drifting by parachute into Communist territory.
A military guard of honor fired a three-gun salute yesterday over the grave of Herman Buckow, 87 years old, at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.

BUENOS AIRES, March 5 -- The Provisional Government of Argentina has stepped up its public insistence that investments of private foreign capital are essential if the nation's oil and electric power resources are to be developed adequately.
Major United States shipyards will not face serious economic troubles for at least three more years, according to J. B. Woodward Jr.

LONDON, March 6 -- Additional charges of corruption against Brighton's suspended police chief, Charles Ridge, were dropped today. He was acquitted last week in a jury trial at which two of his subordinates were given five-year prison sentences.
EDMONTON, Alberta, March 6 -- The Social Credit movement, which has governed this oil-rich province of Canada without a break since 1935, awaits the March 31 general election with confidence.

"Teacher's Pet," a Paramount comedy starring Clark Gable and Doris Day, will open Wednesday, March 19, at the Capitol Theatre. William Perlberg produced and George Seaton directed from a screenplay by Fay and Michael Kanin.

Francis E. I-Ieil has Been elected see-! retary and treasurer of the Maryland Shipbuilding Drydock Company, Baltimore. E. Maxwell Sauerwein succeeds Mr. Hell as assistant secretary and assistant treasurer of Maryland.

Prices of near potato futures opened down yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange but turned strong early in the day. Forty-one notices were issued and they were well received. As soon as the notices were stopped, heavy short covering and trade buying pushed prices up as much as the 30-point (hundredths of a cent a pound) daily limit in the April and May positions.

Member bank reserves eased considerably in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Much of the additional reserves became available because of a 1/2 percentage point reduction in reserve requirements which became effective during the week.
Earnings of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, the world's largest producer of sulphur, fell sharply last year.

WARSAW, March 6 (AP) -- The Polish United Workers (Communist) party announced today the ouster of Stefan Matuszewski from the chairmanship of the commission that supervises party machinery. He is considered a Stalinist.
An outstanding new Fricka in Wagner's "Die Walkuere" and an acceptable new Siegmund sang their roles for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.
WOMEN who have rebelled all their lives against wearing hats may surrender this spring.

There was much ado about very little at Columbus Circle yesterday. Photographers assembled at 10 A. M. to take publicity pictures of two pretty girls changing the street sign on a lamp-post outside the Coliseum from "Columbus Circle" to "Flower Show Circle."
The New York University Bellevue Medical Center has received a $500,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation for a ten-year study of radiation hazards.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Produce Exchange moved 4 points off to 6 points up yesterday, with the new crop months displaying underlying firmness. Buying was believed to be based primarily on legislative developments.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- Dag Hammarskjold said today that it would be "perfectly feasible" and "perfectly appropriate" to hold the proposed heads-of-government meeting at United Nations headquarters.

The rapid increase of population which is taking place in the United States is upsetting traditional thinking in medical education, as it has in almost every area of our national life. The American Medical Association has long maintained that we have all the doctors we need to meet the "demand" for their services -- about one physician to every 750 people.
AN expert in home illumination expressed the hope recently that dealers and consumers would soon begin to see the light.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- "The Snow Birch," a new novel by John Mantley, has been acquired by Twentieth Century-Fox in a pre-publication purchase. The book is to be brought out next month by E. P. Dutton Co.

At the present time we are told by the Republicans that the economy is strong and healthy. The rising unemployment and sagging production in many industries are only a passing occurrence. Our main worry is inflation -- witness the recent rise in the cost-of-living index.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce eased its export limitations on nickel and nickel-containing scrap materials today because of enlarged supplies in this country.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 (AP) -- The Santa Fe, Western Pacific, Union Pacific and Southern Pacific Railroads are increasing the speed of their freight trains between the Midwest and the San Francisco Bay area.
Leonard W. Hall told a group of Young Republicans yesterday that it was "about time for Republicans to take their chins off the floor."

LONDON, March 6 -- The stock market responded today to the rally on Wall Street and better business news from the United States. Most share groups, particularly industrials, scored modest gains although there was little or no expansion in turnover.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- Thomas E. Dewey, former Governor of New York, charged here today that the distilling industry was losing millions of dollars as a result of the so-called "force-out" provisions of the Internal Revenue Code.
RECENT warm weather probably has saved hundreds of deer from starvation, but an emergency feeding program ordered a few days ago by Conservation Commissioner Sharon J. Mauhs is being continued.

The blockfront on the east side of the Grand Concourse from 171st to 172d Stret, the Bronx, has been sold by 1460 Associates to investing clients of Leepson Rubman, attorneys. The property consists of three five-story apartment buildings housing 174 families. It was sold in a deal negotiated by the Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company, broker. The plot is 370 by 100 feet.
The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is considering a proposal that its cultural project include facilities for educational television.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Loading of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 553,645 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Twenty-five big, box-like excavation trucks were driven slowly past the offices of a teamster union local yesterday morning in an unusual picketing demonstration.

Mikhail Botvinnik was in a highly favorable position last night when the second game in his title match with Vassily Smyslov, the world champion, was adjourned after forty moves with the challenger one pawn ahead, according to a news report from Moscow. He was expected to chalk up his second victory upon resumption of play today.

The Connecticut Light and Power Company reported yesterday new highs for electric and gas sales and net income in 1957. But common share earnings declined slightly from the 1956 level. Sherman R. Knapp, president, traced the decline to a rise in the number of shares outstanding and to the drought last summer, which reduced output from hydro stations to about 63 per cent of normal.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 6 -- An edict prohibiting "public manifestations" until after the March 16 Congressional elections was issued last night by Colombia's military junta Government.
MONTREAL, March 6 -- Twenty-one thousand students boycotted classes today at five universities in the Province of Quebec.

The policy committee of the Liberal party said last night that it would pursue the possibility of endorsing Ralph J. Bunche, Under Secretary of the United Nations, as a candidate for the Senate although Dr. Bunche said yesterday he would not run for elective office.
Three different teams of enforcement officers gave the American liner Independence an unusual searching yesterday and took nine seamen into custody.
Unemployment by conservative standards is exceeding the five-million mark. Whether seasonal or other unusual circumstances make it better or worse, five million persons are looking for employment.
The seventy-fifth anniversary of the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge will be celebrated by the Brooklyn Museum. A Diamond Jubilee Ball will be held at the museum on April 26.

Teacher took an apple to his pupils here yesterday. In fact, a dozen or more members of the faculty at the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration of City College, 17 Lexington Avenue, took veal goulash with noodles, hamburgers and frankfurters and anything else several hundred students ordered from the cafeteria menu.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Legislation to halt the plan to rebuild the east front of the Capitol was endorsed today by the Senate Public Works Committee.
TRENTON, March 6 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner has received a major setback in his efforts to avoid an open primary and unite the Democratic party behind a single candidate for United States Senator.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Grain futures prices sagged all along the line near the close of the Board of Trade today. At the finish only soybeans were ahead.

A new two-story building containing thirty-one rooms has been added to the Van Cortlandt Motel at Broadway and West 256th Street, opposite Van Cortlandt Park in the Riverdale area of the Bronx. The motel, one of the first of its kind within the city limits, now has fifty-one units and can accommodate 200 guests. The first section was opened about three years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- William F. Knowland, the Senate Republican leader said today that the Presidential disability problem must be solved because the country "cannot afford a hiatus" of leadership.

Giuseppe Torelli was the outstanding composer of last night's Clarion Concert at Town Hall. This was only fitting, for he was allotted the major part of the program and Newell Jenkins, the conductor, made that allotment to honor the tercentenary of his birth in 1658.
PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- For the second time within a month, Philadelphia police today stopped the showing of the French motion picture "And God Created Woman" at two small mid-city theatres.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 6 -- Masked gunmen slipped through downtown Tel Aviv today and painted savages roamed the streets of Jerusalem.
LONDON, March 6 -- The Labor party and the Trades Union Congress demanded today a ban on patrol flights by British-based planes carrying hydrogen bombs.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- Joe Pignatano was an easy out on a force at second base in the third inning of today's Los Angeles Dodgers' intra-squad game. He was out by twenty feet despite the fact that Charley Neal, the second baseman, had dropped the ball and couldn't recover in time to get a double play.

DURHAM, N. C., March 6 (UP) -- A Duke University parapsychologist said today he was convinced the mysterious happenings in the James E. Herrmann home at Seaford, L. I., were not a hoax perpetrated by a member of the family.
Plans to build a low-rent state-aided housing project to accommodate 775 families in the Chelsea area appeared yesterday to have been blocked.

HAVANA, March 6 -- The Government of President Fulgencio Batista indicated tonight that it would accept the "observation of representatives of international organizations," over the general elections scheduled for June 1, if the Opposition so requested.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- The verdict that Explorer II had plunged into the ocean was reached this afternoon on the basis of information funneled through the Army's computation Center at Cape Canaveral, a few miles north of here.

Arthur Miller's next play, untitled at present, may introduce the playwright's wife, Marilyn Monroe, to the Broadway stage in October or November. Verification, however, could not be obtained yesterday from the dramatist, who won the Pulitzer Prize and the Critics Circle award for "Death of a Salesman."
CAIRO, March 6 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser completed today the formation of a Cabinet for the new United Arab Republic with Egyptians holding the key posts of Defense and Foreign Affairs.
LONDON, March 6 -- A Labor party effort to gain political asylum in Britain for a refugee from Spain failed tonight in the House of Commons.

LIMA, Peru, March 6 -- A communique signed by the Ministers of Government, War, Navy and the Air Force made public last night, reported the failure of an attempt to overthrow the Government of President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche Feb. 21.
The Bethlehem Steel Company is seeking orders for submarines in order to gain work for its Staten Island shipyard.

Reports that Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr. would give up his seat in Congress this fall have precipitated a rush of candidates for the Republican nomination. None, however, at this point is openly challenging the incumbent.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., March 6 (AP) -- A plant that manufactures parts for missiles was seized and closed by the Government today in an effort to collect an income tax claim against its owner.

The downtrend in the economy is likely to be longer and deeper than the recessions of 1948-49 and 1953-54, Roy L. Reierson, vice president and chief economist of the Bankers Trust Company, predicted yesterday.

"The greatest earth on earth" was inflated in thirty-six minutes yesterday in a hangar at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. It is a globe fifty-two feet in diameter that holds 180,000 cubic feet of air.

DIMITRI MITROPOULOS giveth, and Dimitri Mitropoulos taketh away. He conducted Richard Strauss' searing tragedy; "Elektra," with passion and intensity at Carnegie Hall last night, but he weakened his achievement by sanctioning an intermission in this one-act opera and eliminating a crucial scene.
CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., March 6 -- Plans to use part of an estate here as a country club for disabled veterans have met a legal setback that may end a simmering controversy.

AT supper hour tomorrow a line of giants will lumber into the Liederkranz Club at 6 East Eighty-seventh Street. Through the evening the hall will ring to lusty song, to sonorous toasts, then to Scandinavian dance music.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses:
THE purse-conscious consumer will be put to the test at the food counters again this week-end. Particularly costly is meat, the commodity that takes the biggest bite out of the family food budget.
A city Youth Board worker charged with possessing heroin won an acquittal yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions.
ALBANY, March 6 -- The Republicans beat down Democratic amendments today and rammed through their modified version of Governor Harriman's record budget in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today the nomination of Dr. Paul D. Foote, retired oil industry executive, as Assistant Secretary of Defense for research and engineering.
A Supreme Court justice yesterday denounced owners of most large taxicab fleets for assertedly operating a "legalized racket" to "defraud the public" in accident claims.
ALBANY, March 6 -- A new test to measure the physical fitness of school children in grades four through twelve was announced today by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education.
Every year when spring approaches the nation engages in a debate on foreign aid.

Century Composition Service, Inc., linotype composition house, has purchased the seven-story commercial building at 124 West Eighteenth Street. The property is assessed at $50,000. It was sold by the C S Holding Corporation through Louis Schrag, Inc., and Morris Schindelheim, brokers.

Command of the 27,000-ton Italian liner Augustus has been given to Capt. Corrado Pinotti, long-time master of Italian-flag trans-Atlantic vessels. Ezio Bonfanti, general manager of the Italian Line in this country and Canada, said yesterday that Captain Pinotti would be on the bridge when the ship arrives here Wednesday.

ALBANY, March 6 -- A group of college presidents received assurance today that Governor Harriman and Republican legislative leaders would support the program of graduate fellowships recommended by the Board of Regents.

Sam Rayburn has been a member of the House of Representatives for forty-five years and as Speaker is one of the most respected and powerful men in the United States Government. But he doesn't own the Capitol.
ROME, March 6 -- Charges that priests were meddling in Italian politics led to a fight in the Chamber of Deputies tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26 -- In the temple near the fort, the doctor sat cross-legged on a wooden bench and shook his head sadly at the rooster. Shiv Nath, a short, lean 45-year-old Brahman, was gloomy because he could not treat the rooster, a rather miserable-looking old fowl.

Sixty-two-year-old Howard (Jake) Cann last night wrote finis to a basketball coaching career that covered thirty-five years at New York University. For a long time it appeared that Cann might bow out the way he made his debut back in 1923 -- with a victory.

TUNIS, March 6 -- Tahar Ben Ammar, who was the first Premier of independent Tunisia, was being held by the Tunisian police tonight in connection with the discovery of a cache of jewels of the former beylical (royal) family of Tunisia.

Edward C. Gray, executive vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, celebrated two anniversaries yesterday. One was his fortieth year with the exchange and the other was the first birthday of the exchange's new exhibit hall.
A Brooklyn Supreme Court jury yesterday awarded two workmen $500,000 for injuries they received on a Queens College construction project last May 6.

The varsity spiked-shoe set, which has produced much high excitement this winter, will have its last 1958 round-up on Madison Square Garden's banked boards in the New York Chapter Knights of Columbus games tomorrow.

COUNT Sarmi, Elizabeth Arden's custom clothes designer, continues to make some of the prettiest evening gowns in town, not to mention the most. His current spring collection, shown this week, contained about forty of them. They were both short and long.

LAHTI, Finland, March 6 (UP) -- A rally by the anchor man, Per-Erik Larsson, gave Sweden an upset victory in the men's forty-kilometer (24.84-mile) race today in the world Nordic ski championships but second place enabled Russia to increase its over-all team lead.
Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., which lost the $4,500,000-a-year Lincoln account in 1955 after handling it for seven years, won it back yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- No matter how hard television viewers in Los Angeles peer at their screen, they are not going to see or be affected by advertisements flashed by subliminal-projection techniques.
The City Council voted 14 to 7 yesterday to request the Legislature to pave the way for permitting Jewish merchants here to do business on Sunday.
BUFFALO, March 6 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad said today the 300 workers in the Buffalo division would be laid off next week.
Ike Chestnut of New York, a contender for the world featherweight championship, will meet Harold Gomes of Providence in a scheduled ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.
MOSCOW, March 6 -- Izvestia, the Soviet Government's leading newspaper, charged today that Secretary of State Dulles was trying to impede agreement between the Communist and non-Communist worlds.
A long-range program to prevent juvenile delinquency was urged yesterday by Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Formation of a national Roman Catholic organization aimed at bringing Christian principles to bear on American social problems was announced here today. It is made up of priests and laymen active in various social fields.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Army announced today that its second Explorer satellite had failed to go into an earth-circling orbit.

Pierre Mendes-France, the controversial French statesman, is the subject of a book by Alexander Werth which Abelard-Schuman win issue April 15. "Lost Statesman: The Strange History of Pierre Mendes-France" tells about the man of "catastrophe and salvation," who ended the war in Indochina and the upheaval in Tunisia, officiated at "the burial of the E. D. C." and, with Sir Anthony Eden, brought Germany into NATO.
A restudy of sentences imposed on 1,500 multiple offenders in New York County resulted yesterday in the technical freeing of two men in General Sessions Court.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov of the Soviet Union talked for forty-five minutes today of "sincerity," "trust," "friendship," "confidence," "cooperation" and "peace" between the Soviet and the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, a Republican from New Yark, today told Congress that a bill to straighten out the anti-trust status of baseball and other professional team sports could -- as now written -- eventually ruin them.

ALBANY, March 6 -- A bill to license baby sitters was defeated overwhelmingly in the Assembly today. It had so little support that the sponsor withdrew the proposal before the results of the vote were announced.
The junior board of the George Junior Republic will sponsor the annual Junior Republic Ball on May 2 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Short covering and a poorly kept secret combined yesterday to add about $2,500,000,000 to the market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange portfolios.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The United States formally rejected today Soviet proposals for preparing a summit conference.
Bob Hope has reached agreement with the Soviet Union. And he didn't call them; they called him.

I am always deeply moved when, at times of hysteria and alarm over the behavior of our young people, pressure is brought to bear on fining and holding parents responsible for the behavior of their children.

Health authorities were advised yesterday to consider placement in foster homes for children in families chronically disrupted by alcoholism and its attendant psychiatric disorders. It was said that this might save the children from possible alcoholism later.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Congress moved decisively today toward an early clash with President Eisenhower over farm policies.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 6 (AP) -- Lilly Endowment announced today a $144,500 grant to Atlanta University, Georgia, for the remedial teaching of reading to freshmen.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- A United States aviation official said today that the Soviet Union's civil airline, Aeroflot, had been gaining over the United States while "the attention of the world has been focused on sputnik."

TUNIS, March 6 -- President Habib Bourguiba said today the French-Algerian struggle was forging closer unity of all North Africa. It will finally create the dreamed-of North African federation, he added.

WHEN the lights are turned on "The Long Gallery," a drama by Ramsey Yelvington that opened last night at the RNA Theatre of the Greystone Hotel on Broadway and Ninety-first Street, there are an imposing, weather-beaten frame home, a huge porch, trees and a fenced-in backyard that contains an unseen baying dog.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 6 (UP) -- Bryan Field, the general manager of Delaware Park, today said that each of the fourteen stakes to be run during the Delaware Park meeting would close ten days before the event.
Associate Superintendent Joseph O. Loretan, in charge of the city's junior high schools, declared yesterday that the present budget did not fulfill school needs.
Sir Winston Churchill's first one-man art show had its gala invitational opening last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art with a tribute from the White House.
Dr. Bernard Schwartz suggested yesterday a Federal law requiring all persons dealing with Federal regulatory agencies to register as lobbyists.

Alemaya means "New Place" in Amharic, the principal language of Ethiopia. What is new in Alemaya, as Osgood Caruthers writes to this paper, is an "agricultural college and farm, built and operated with United States assistance." The new town and the new college are on a lake 200 miles east of Addis Ababa, where the Ethiopians, living in primitive conditions, have been growing corn, sorghum and wheat and raising cattle and black-faced sheep.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The nation's major airlines said today that Congress could not solve the financial plight of the railroads by taking steps that would hurt other carriers.
Social welfare experts urged yesterday that delinquent children be given "intensive" care after their discharge from institutions until their readjustment to community life was satisfactory.

SOME individually persuasive performances, led by Paul Muni as a tired, old-fashioned attorney, imparted interest last night to a rambling and disorganized play entitled "Last Clear Chance," by A. S. Hotchner.' The drama was seen on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2.

"What's this?" asks an American hockey fan when he reads that Sid Smith is playing for the Canadian team in the world amateur championship tournament in Oslo, Norway. "Sid Smith! Can that be the guy who used to play left wing for the pro Toronto Maple Leafs?"

The Boys Club of New York, which for more than eighty years has helped needy boys from crowded areas of the city, will be the beneficiary of a spring dance. The fete will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on May 1.

After nearly two and a half years of stable government and economic improvement, Greece, a bulwark of democracy in eastern Europe and an anchor of the North Atlantic alliance, has again been plunged into a political crisis. This has led to the overthrow of the strongly pro-Western Cabinet of Premier Karamanlis and the appointment of a caretaker regime charged with dissolving Parliament and holding new elections.

SEVENTY years ago on a sugar plantation in Java a girl child was born to an old colonial family. For hundreds of years her ancestors had lived in the Dutch East Indies, and for most of her own life she, too, was to live there. But since the end of World War II Maria Dermout has lived in the Netherlands.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6 -- According to the celebrated philosopher, former pitcher and deacon of the double negative, Jerome (Dizzy) Dean, baseball at the moment may be suffering from a shortage of buoyance, bonehead plays and even dimwitted ballplayers.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower accepted today the retirement from active service of Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Second Circuit Court of Appeals. In a warm letter, the President wished him many happy years.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 6 -- Joe McKenney, the propaganda minister of the Boston Red Sox, saw the four old gaffers standing together, and got an idea. He assembled a half-dozen top infield candidates on the current Bosox, and posed them for a picture with the quartet of ancients. Twenty years ago the same foursome comprised the infield of the Fenway Millionaires.
ALBANY, March 6 -- Defeat of a bill permitting the posting of the Ten Commandments in public schools was urged today by the State Council of Churches, a Protestant group.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Following are an unofficial translation of the Soviet aide-memoire delivered to Lewellyn E. Thompson Jr., United States Ambassador to Moscow, last Friday and the text of the United States reply, made public today:
ALBANY, March 6 -- Republicans introduced a bill today to bar the use of part-time laboring jobs in the State Public Works Department for political patronage.
Mayor Wagner is expected to call union and industry leaders to City Hall this afternoon in an all-out effort to end the strike of 105,000 dressmakers in New York and six near-by states.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Democrats in Congress, pressing the anti-recession campaign, goaded the Administration today for more action on public works and took action on their own emergency housing program.

Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger in the match with Vassily Smyslov for the chess championship of the world, gained his second consecutive victory yesterday when Smyslov resigned without resuming play in their game adjourned from the night before, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.
The dispatches of your correspondent Paul P. Kennedy from the Caribbean are distinguished by their penetrating and impartial exposition of the problems of that area.
Spring has taken a one-week lease on the Coliseum, effective tomorrow at 2 P. M. Then the doors will open to the forty-first edition of the New York International Flower Show.
The first note of optimism on Roy Campanella's condition was sounded yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- Freddy Hutchinson, the strong, silent skipper of the St. Louis Cardinals, may not be a match for Casey Stengel as a conversationalist, but when it comes to thinking up something novel, Hutch is conceding nothing to the Yankee manager.
GENEVA, March 7 (Reuters) -- Poland today joined India in asking for an end of nuclear explosions over the high seas.

PORT CANAVERAL, Fla., March 7 -- It is unlikely that this little man-made port ever will rival Newport News, but, for a piece of geography that, less than a decade ago, was a barren chunk of sand, it is doing quite handsomely.

LONDON, March 7 -- Industrials continued to move ahead on a wide front in the stock market today. They were mainly helped by the strength of Wall Street and the expectation that the cut in the Federal Reserve discount rate would keep the American markets buoyant
LONDON, March 7 (UP) -Sir George Bolton, one of Britain's leading bankers and an international financier, said today the world economic boom was over.
Runaway children may be running toward delinquency -- at the least, they are revealing serious maladjustment, a group of psychological researchers said here yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7 -- The United Arab Republic, formed by the union of Egypt and Syria, today made its first official appearance in the United Nations.
Old dolls and young dolls will be going on the road again soon for the American Museum of Natural History after a spell of retirement.

TWO RIVERS, Wis., March 7 (AP) -- A runaway switch engine pulling nine freight cars thundered through two port cities and plunged into Lake Michigan today. Authorities still had not learned tonight whether anyone was at the controls.

Formation of a stockholders committee to seek control of the Metal and Thermit Corporation at the annual meeting on April 10 was announced yesterday by Alexander Rogers, a director. Metal and Thermit makes industrial chemicals, welding materials and metal-plating supplies and reclaims metallic tin and steel from scrap.
WITHEE, Wis., March 7 (UP) -- A telephone call to the White House has resulted in free medical care for an infant who needs a heart operation.
CHICAGO, March 7 (API) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, March 7 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
BONN, Germany, March 7 -The Communist rulers of East Germany have placed the imprint of Eastern Europe on the populace, which numbers 17,000,000.
MADRID, March 7 -- A shift this week of United States military commanders in Spain marks a milestone in the $350,000,000 airbase building program in the country.
DELAND, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Otto the hippopotamus escaped from the circus today but a nap in the sun and a bag of bread proved his undoing.
The 87-year-old former gunboat Ranger, now the Emery Rice, left the United States Merchant Marine Academy yesterday on her last voyage. Her destination was a Baltimore scrap yard.
PARIS, March 7 -- The French railway system was disrupted today by a strike of locomotive engineers.

SAKS FIFTH AVENUE is egging Easter on with an imperial looking new lighter. It is, as is to be expected, egg shaped and ringed with lacy bronze around the center, where it opens on the excellent Evans lighter itself.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 8 -- Two United States Marine planes collided in the air near Okinawa last night and crashed into the sea. One plane, a transport, was carrying twenty-five persons, the other, a fighter type, had only the pilot aboard.

Four winners of the national singles racquets title will go on the court today in one of the semi-final matches in the amateur doubles championship of the United States at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Sales and earnings of the International Harvester Company in the three months ended Jan. 31, the first quarter of its fiscal year, were lower than in the corresponding period of 1957. Sales declined 13.6 per cent and profits 20.6 per cent.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., March 7 -A missing Brooklyn boy was found dead in an unoccupied summer bungalow here today. He had died of carbon monoxide poison. A friend, who had also been reported missing Wednesday, was taken to Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, where he was reported in fair condition.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 7 -- This city's new $1,500,000 First Presbyterian Church -- constructed in the shape of a gigantic abstract fish -- will be dedicated on Sunday.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., March 7 -- Huntington Township officials met with civic and church leaders here today to begin a clean-up campaign on the town's slum conditions.

Prices of cotton futures at New York moved 2 points lower to 8 points higher yesterday in a listless session, with fluctuations relatively narrow. Some evening-up before the week-end presumably reflected nervousness over possible legislative developments.
COCA BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- The test firing of a Vanguard satellite vehicle, scheduled for early this morning, was postponed shortly before noon today.
ST. PAUL, Minn., March 7 -- An underground explosion is rumbling across the Farm Belt. It is setting off a chain reaction in farm production.
Shares emerged from a scrambling session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday practically unchanged.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- The Post Office Department announced today that it would issue a new stamp honoring Paul Revere and his famous ride. Dr. Sam Prescott, as usual, was left out.
Three officials of the New York State Communist party have resigned their posts in protest against the pro-Soviet party line adopted last month.

Two seven-story apartment houses at 92 to 102 Hamilton Place, near City College, have been sold by Street and Avenue Properties, Inc., represented by Robert J. Eliasberg. They contains fifty-three suites and occupy the blockfront on the west side of Hamilton Place between West 141st and 142d Street.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Dr. Edgar S. Gordon of the University of Wisconsin Medical School said today that it was "doubtful" that hardening of the arteries was necessarily linked to aging. He addressed the clinical conference of the Chicago Medical Society.

TO a 70-year-old grandmother with time on her hands, a paint brush can possess secret charms. One began wielding hers nine months ago, not on canvas, but on the walls and furnishings of her Greenwich Village walkup apartment at 121 West Third Street.
The French American Wives will hold their thirteenth annual Bal des Berceaux at the SheratonEast (formerly the Ambassador) on March 28. The event will aid needy children in France.

A pastoral letter from Cardinal Spellman urging sacrificial giving to the annual Catholic Bishops' Relief Fund will be read tomorrow at all masses in the 400 churches of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

Dr. Carl Ebert, general manager and first stage director of the West Berlin Municipal Opera, will come to New York next season to stage the first Metropolitan Opera production of Verdi's "Macbeth." He will use setting designed by Caspar Neher.

The Red Cross Motor Service needs no jet propulsion to make it go, no atomic power to project it into space. Its motive power is provided by the men and women volunteers who give generous and devoted service, day in, day out, rain or shine.
ST. ANTON, Austria, March 7 (AP) -- America's Betsy Snite, with an assist from a couple of Austrian friends, placed third in the downhill race of the international Kandahar ski competition today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants' manager, Bill Rigney, today named a team including five rookies to face the Cleveland Indians in tomorrow's opening spring exhibition game at Tucson.

For some folks spring comes on a robin's wings. For others the season's herald is one of those perennial pictures of the "first" snowdrop or crocus, or perhaps the sight of wind-whipped King Alfred daffodils on a peddler's cart. But for 150,000 or so New York City residents and visitors the coming of spring is inextricably linked to the International Flower Show.
A shorter post-surgery convalescence and a quicker return to work were suggested as appropriate and safe in studies presented here yesterday.

The European Common Market presents a new concept of merchandising for United States importers, Richard Weinberg, vice president of the Walborg Handbag Import Corporation declared last week. The common market is a customs union formed by Italy, West Germany, Belgium, France, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, for stepping up trade.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 -- Harvard College used the telephone today to tell alumni in six other cities simultaneously about progress in an $82,500,000 program to strengthen the college.

The Marine Towing and Transportation Employers' Association has re-elected its two top officials for one-year terms. James P. McAllister, president of McAllister Brothers, Inc., remains as chairman. Robert B. Mitchell Jr., vice president of the Oil Transfer Corporation, continues as vice chairman.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, said today that Representative Robert W. Kean "is the best qualified and strongest candidate" to succeed him.
Sheer curtain fabrics have made sizable progress in matching the current architectural vogue for the wide, wide window.
Dentistry as a career for young women as well as young men was urged yesterday by a speaker at the third Workshop for a Career in Dentistry.
HAVANA, March 7 -- Opposition political parties expressed cautious optimism today toward the apparently conciliatory attitude of President Fulgencio Batista and his Government.
ROME, March 7 -- The Sacred College of Cardinals, often called the "senate" of the church, assured the Pope today that it shared the "grave bitterness" that afflicts his "august heart."

A contract for the purchase of the apartment house for fifty-four families at 2758 Cruger Avenue, the Bronx, has been signed by the Federal Funding Corporation, Harry Siegel, president. Renard Realty, the seller, owned the property for twenty-four years.
WESTON, Conn., March 7 -- A 43-year-old educator who voluntarily demoted himself from superintendent to principal is resigning in disillusion.
Two new participants in a proxy fight for control of the Bullard Company have filed preliminary statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- The American Medical Association announced plans today to publish a sixteen-page tabloid newspaper.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent to 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 level in the week ended Tuesday, the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
A large, powered needle that combines features of the riveting machine, the machine gun and the portrait artist's brush has built a $2,000,000 rug and carpeting business for Edward Fields.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 7 -Since it was raining, baseball was scratched, and the Santa Rita Hotel lobby was crowded with Mexican merchants, a few dozen cowboys and the Cleveland Indians, a friendly (but bored) tribe of restless lobbyloungers.

RALEIGH, N. C. March 7 (AP) -- Maryland shook off the jitters after losing a 15-point lead, and defeated Duke, 71-65, in overtime tonight to gain the final of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.

President Eisenhower in his last press eonference rightly pointed out that he ran far ahead of his own party's Congressional candidates in 1956. And he added that he thought it would be better if they would support the national ticket.
ALGIERS, March 7 -- France faces a long, tough and expensive struggle in Algeria. There is no short or easy road to victory.

IT is estimated that about 675,000 Americans will pack their bags and take off for Europe this spring and summer. Many of these voyagers will have had some traveling experience. A bit of advice for the novices, however, will help save time, temper and money.
Commodity futures prices were generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions before the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

TWO new magazines dedicated to the investigation of firearms and shooting have appeared on newsstands, and between them they illustrate just how wide and intense is the interest in hunting and in weapons as fine or rare mechanisms.

At the turn of the century public elementary schools assumed one main responsibility, the teaching of the three R's -- reading, writing and arithmetic. Beginning with a primer, graded readers were used basic texts to achieve the first objective.
ALBANY, March 7 -- A legislative showdown on the question of permitting Jewish merchants in New York City to operate businesses on Sunday was assured today.

Dr. Willard Cole Rappleye was a young man of 39 when he became Dean of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. In the twenty-seven eventful years that have followed he has more than fulfilled the great expectations by his fellows of a highly successful career as the guiding spirit of one of our great medical centers of learning.

LONDON, March 7 -- Hugh Gaitskell warned the Labor party tonight that the rebellion in the party over nuclear disarmament jeopardized Labor's prospects of "substantial" victory at the next general election.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 7 (UP) -- Herb Score of the Cleveland Indians sprained his right ankle in an indoor workout at the Y. M. C. A. today, and probably will not be able to pitch against the San Francisco Giants here tomorrow as scheduled.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The United States and the Soviet Union were as far apart as ever today on the concept of a summit meeting and how to prepare for it. Nevertheless, the Administration was proceeding on the assumption that the meeting would take place.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -The Senate subcommittee on Constitutional Rights began hearings today on bills to reverse a Supreme Court decision that has disturbed the Washington police and prosecutors.

ONE of the most popular shellfish dishes in restaurants here is broiled shrimp redolent with garlic. It is found most often in those establishments with an Italian kitchen, although it has been adopted, too, by many seafood restaurants.

The impact of Jewish thought on America and the repercussions of that impact on Jewish character is told by Sol Liptzin in "Generation of Decision." He reviews the attitude of such American non-Jewish writers as Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Mark Twain, Lincoln Steffers, Thomas Wolfe and Eugene O'Neill and he discusses the reaction of American writers of Jewish origin toward "their cultural duality."

DALLAS, March 7 (AP) -- A small town banking leader from Texas called on independent bankers throughout the United States today to what he termed a "fight for survival" of the independent banking system.
Private secondary schools were urged yesterday to take advantage of their special opportunity to make good use of the rebellious nature of their students.

The Amalgamated Lithographers of America are continuing to make labor-management history in working with their employers to further the use of labor-saving methods and machines on the theory that these create more jobs than they save -through lower unit costs and consequent business expansion.

THERE definitely is no recession in the quality of production being presented this season by the Equity Community Theatre. Last night at the DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx this industrious organization tackled "Oklahoma!" with commendable consequences.

The top stars of the indoor track and field circuit will have their final 1958 rendezvous at Madison Square Garden tonight in the thirty-ninth annual games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Manufacturing and trade inventories, on a seasonally adjusted basis, decreased $650 million in January, the Department of Commerce reported today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 7 -- Revolutions, like other human institutions, grow old. Yugoslavia's has lost much of the zeal which marked its earlier years. And with this change has crept in what the Communist Administration sees as a series of "petit bourgeois, nationalist and chauvinist excesses."
COPENHAGEN, March 7 -Financial and government circles expect the bank rate to be lowered by a half per cent very soon. Since June 23, 1954, the rate has been 5.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today that some of its researchers had uncovered evidence "that could point the way toward development of a vaccine for treatment of some types of cancer."

SYDNEY, Australia, March 7 (UP) -- Justice McLelland of the Equity Court today said that pianist Liberace acted like a "petulant child" in refusing to play to a Sydney audience on Wednesday because a court order banned use of music from "My Fair Lady."

PRINCETON, N. J., March 7 -- William Faulkner said today that parents and educators were endangering American education with false values. Both the North and the South, he said, are not facing up to important realities.

One hundred forty-one parcels of real estate in five boroughs brought a total of $993,315 at an auction conducted last week by Henry G. Walte-made, Inc., auctioneer, for the City of New York. The upset prices on the properties amounted to $733,125.

The Fordham University Glee Club gave its annual concert in Town Hall last night under the direction of James B. Welch. They were joined by alumni formerly of the Glee Club in singing "The Fordham Marching Song" by Breslin, "Alma Mater" by Joslyn and "The Ram" by Coveney-Joslyn.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 7 -- Rutgers University set the pace m the opening day's action of the thirty-fourth annual Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championships today.

IN its third and final visit of the season the Cleveland Orchestra brought to Carnegie Hall last night a new piano concerto by an American composer and a home-town pianist to play it. The composition was by Peter Mennin and the soloist was Eunice Podis.

Your editorial of March 5 is quite right that the man in the street is not qualified to judge the effectiveness of fluoridating the city's water supply. May I suggest, however, that he is competent to judge whether or not he wants medicine forced down his throat.

Richfield Oil Corporation plans to offer $50,000,000 of convertible debentures to the company's shareholders for subscription during a period tentatively designated as March 25 to April 14. Shareholders are to be offered rights to subscribe to the debentures at the rate of $100 of debentures for each eight shares of stock held.
A small, 68-year-old jeweler shot and killed a tall young hold-up man in a hand-to-hand struggle yesterday morning.

LAHTI, Finland, March 7 (UP) -- Radia Eroshina, Alevtina Kolchina and Lyubov Kozyreva gave Russia its second title at the world Nordic ski championships today. They led all the way in defeating Finland's defending champions in the women's fifteen-kilometer crosscountry relay.
Three anthropologists received medals and prizes of $1,000 each last night at a dinner of the Wenner-Gren Foundation for Anthropological Research at the Plaza Hotel.
THE National Antiques Show, which opens at Madison Square Garden on Monday, will reflect, in its vast conglomeration, the tastes of a fair crosssection of the country.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The United Automobile Workers made another offer today to submit its four-year-old strike against the Kohler Company to binding arbitration. The company refused.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission was urged today to approve promptly a $170 million construction project that would bring additional natural gas to millions of California and Arizona residents.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., March 7 -- The 252-gross-ton Diesel tugboat Irving T. Bush was launched here today at the Jakobson Shipyard. Prominent New York harbor personalities witnessed the event.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -Prof. Luis W. Alvarez, a physicist, received a patent this week for a stroboscopic golf training device. President Eisenhower is reported to have used one at the White House.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Army announced today it was reducing its paratroop units and increasing the number of its infantrymen in West Germany.

The recent daily installments of revelation on legislative jobholders in Albany clearly point to the need for a housecleaning. At first the tendency was to assume that this free-loading with minor politicians, with relatives of members of the Legislature, and other similar practices was just the "normal" routine of life in a state capital that "everybody" had known about for years.
CHICAGO, March 7 -- Between March 6 and March 16 many an American husband will find avocados on the table, whether he likes them or not.

DUBLIN, March 7 -- Irish whisky distillers think Americans should drink more of their product. They are asking the Government to finance their proposed advertising campaign in the United States by giving a rebate on the duty collected on whisky.

RANDOLPH CHURCHILL shows promise as a television performer. After his initial disaster on "The $64,000 Question," where he survived only a single inquiry, he returned Thursday evening to "Night Beat" and managed to stir up a reasonably engaging fracas.

Mark Marvin, a 50-year-old stage and film producer, was found dead in his apartment at 280 Riverside Drive last night. The police said a suicide note had been found beside the body, but the cause of death was listed as unknown, pending an autopsy.

Firing wordy broadsides faster than they can be answered, the Soviets continue to step up their campaign for a spectacular summit mass meeting under conditions which, in the words of Secretary Dulles, would perpetrate a "fraud or a hoax" on the world.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Feb. 14 -This picturesque mountain town, half way between the Red Sea coast of French Somaliland and Addis Ababa, is probably the kat capital of the world.
FLORAL PARK, L. I., March 7 -- Madison Avenue techniques are being used by a Nassau County school district to lure new teachers to the area.

OSLO, Norway, March 7 (UP) -- The crippled United States team suffered another injury and lost all hope of finishing first or second in the world amateur ice hockey tournament when it bowed to Russia tonight, 4 -- 1.
IN THIS week's bounty of one-man and group shows we find, at the Bodley Gallery, 223 East Sixtieth Street, some water-colors of faraway places by the sculptor, Elizabeth Model.
VALLEJO, Calif., March 7 -An ungainly looking, whale-like submarine with two missile hangars joined the Navy today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 7 -- A high Indonesian official indicated tonight that Jakarta was prepared to launch infantry action against the Central Sumatran rebels.
Chester Bowles, former Governor of Connecticut and President Truman's Ambassador to India, formally entered the Connecticut race yesterday for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.
The influx of foreign films here continues unabated.

Your cogent editorial of March 3 on the shortage of teachers is particularly timely during the current widespread agonizing reappraisal of our educations crisis. The Times is to be commended for its part in alerting the public in recent months to the most dangerous aspects of the situation, especially in the fields of the sciences and languages.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 7 -Friction between the United Arab Republic and the Arab Federation has emerged as a major threat to the peace of the Middle East and thus possibly to world peace.

SEOUL, March 7 (UP) -Communist agents who hijacked a South Korean airliner sprayed the pilots' compartment with bullets, drugged some of the passengers and acted so quickly there was no time to radio for help, the plane's pilots said today.

The whole country is alerted to the need to prepare more able young people to become teachers, scientists and engineers. The municipal colleges of New York City are ready to do their part in this city and state in making higher education available to increasing numbers of students.

Shoppers are not the only beneficiaries of the price war in small appliances, according to Eliott V. Walter, president of Macy's New York. He reported yesterday that sales of all items in the store had increased considerably.
Two members of Congress called yesterday for an inquiry into reports that the reduction in the Federal Reserve discount rate announced Thursday had been leaked to privileged persons.
RABAT, Morocco, March 7 -The Moroccan Government has banned all railway transport of foreign troops and materiel without prior Moroccan authorization.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- About one out of every six bombers of the Strategic Air Command was grounded during the last two years because of a shortage of trained crews and maintenance men, a Pentagon official disclosed today.
TRENTON, March 7 -- Dr. Daniel Bergsma, New Jersey's Commissioner of Health, warned today against complacency toward poliomyelitis.
MOSCOW, March 7 -- The Soviet Union has dropped its proposal that a firm date for a summit meeting be fixed as a prerequisite for a foreign ministers' conference to prepare a top-level gathering.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Federal grand jury investigation of the Federal Communications Commission will go beyond allegations relating to the business affairs of Richard A. Mack.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Harriman and the legislative leaders of both parties asked the Public Service Commission today for a report on the financial status and prospects of the railroads having lines in the state.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Clarence Mitchell, head of the Washington branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, today accused Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat of Arkansas, of "trying to turn back the clock of integration."
Harold Gomes of Providence gained the decision over Ike Chestnut of Harlem in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
Construction of a skyscraper office building in the block bounded by Park and Lexington Avenues and Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets may soon be resumed.

Cheryl Crawford and Joel Schenker have signed James Lee to write the stage version of his television play, "The Life of Samuel Johnson," which drew good notices from the critics when it was done last December as a presentation on "Omnibus."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- Abe Schneider, who began his business career as an office boy with Columbia Pictures, was elected president of the company today to succeed Harry Cohn, who died Feb. 27.
KINGSTON, N. Y., March 7 (AP) -- Police Chief Ray Van Buren submitted his resignation today, effective May 31.
Leonard Sillman, Broadway producer, will get his own television show on WABD (Channel 5) starting March 20.
A taxicab driver who turned over to the police a $100 bill he had received from a passenger under the impression it was $1 won possession of the money yesterday in Municipal Court.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., March 7 -- Four old friends will take the 5:30 A. M. train to New York tomorrow to serve again as judges for the International Flower Show.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- A fund-raising organization whose stated objective is to find jobs for disabled veterans has offered to disband under Congressional fire, it was disclosed today.

A NOVEL development in the resort field is under way at Asbury Park, N. J., where the Monterey-by-the-Sea, one of the community's two largest hotels, is being converted for use as a year-around residential hotel, designed especially for the elderly, retired and pensioned.

A FOREST fire, a blizzard, the birth of a baby and the ever-present threat of poverty are encompassed with rare, but realistic, calm in this story of a year and more in the lives of a Canadian Rocky Mountain family.

THE Argus C3 miniature camera, durable favorite among low-priced models for almost two decades with more than 2,000,000 users in fifty-five countries, last week became even simpler to operate. Now known as the Match-Matic C3, the new model employs a straight numbering sequence based on the popular Exposure Value system to take the place of traditional lens and shutter settings.

LISBON -- Hotel owners in Portugal claim that the number of "repeaters" is higher than ever. The last two years set records here in the number of tourists, but even without the inducements of special, added attractions, Portugal's ideal weather, low prices and comfortable accommodations started drawing crowds in mid-February.

The striking garment workers have brought dress manufacturing and shipping to a standstill, but the apparel stores were well supplied when the walk-out began. Resident buyers estimated that enough Easter merchandise had been delivered to most retailers to provide full selections for a week or two.

THIS is the time of year when most hunters and fishermen, being frozen in or otherwise immobilized, become a captive audience, and press agents really work them over. Sometimes the press agents tell them things about themselves, and quite often they are true.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 8 (UP) -- Four Big Ten records were broken and another tied today as Illinois won four of fourteen individual events to capture the Conference indoor track title with 47 1/2 points.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told a group of child psychology specialists yesterday that she thought children needed more discipline.

SOMETHING new has come to Washington -- a Soviet Ambassador who, in the words of one American diplomat, is "affable and outgoing." The phrase, an extraordinary one to use in describing a Russian envoy, is almost an understatement when applied to Mikhail Alekseyevich Menshikov, who arrived here on Feb. 6 to take up his duties as Soviet envoy.

As the Senate roads subcommittee delves into the progress, or lack of it, of the new Federal highway program, it is becoming disturbingly clear that there is wide difference of opinion as to what is happening to the Grand Plan.

MANILA, Sunday, March 9 (UP) -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of Britain arrived here today, more than twelve hours ahead of schedule. His plane was met by hastily assembled dignitaries but there was no time to arrange for an honor guard.

In 1956 the Congress of the United States recognized the urgent need for public library development when it adopted the Library Services Act. This law called for the expenditure of $7,500,000 a year for five years to enable the states and territories to set up and develop public library programs in the rural and sparsely populated areas of their states with funds supplied on a matching basis.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Senators from cotton states face a hard fight Monday on a proposal to increase acreage to relieve a shortage in high-grade cotton, Senator Allen J. Ellender conceded tonight.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 8 -- Army's swimming team smashed four pool records and took first place in every event in defeating Lehigh University, 64 1/2 to 21 1/2, today in the Myrl Jacobs Memorial Pool before a crowd of 700.
IOWA CITY, March 8 (AP) -Michigan's well-balanced swimming team regained the Big Ten championship tonight after a ten-year wait.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 -Silky Sullivan today won the $130,500 Santa Anita Derby by more than three lengths before a record crowd of 63,000 racegoers.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 8 (UP) -- Patty Berg went from first to second to first place again in the $5,000 women's Jacksonville open golf tournament today.

MAJOR exhibits of representative work by two pioneers in photography are announced by galleries in Washington and Rochester. The first American display of photographs by Dr. Erich Salomon (1886-1944), reputedly "the world's first candid camera man," opened last week at the George Eastman House, Rochester.
American University won the National Collegiate Eastern regional small-college basketball play-offs by defeating Wagner, 72 -- 65, at Grymes Hill, S. I., last night.
ATHENS, March 3 -- Frank C. Grismer is about to make an end of his two and a half years here. He is chief for Greece of the United States Operations Mission, which administers foreign economic aid.

DALLAS, March 8 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that the current recession made an extension of the reciprocal trade program more important than ever.

A ten-year study of 100 young heart disease victims indicates that job stress is more closely linked to heart, afflictions than other factors.

SLOWLY, but surely, George Tabori's "Brouhaha" is on its way to beholding the lights of a proscenium. That from Robert L. Joseph who, last season, with the Producers Theatre, presented the revival of "Major Barbara" and before that gave us the exciting "Tiger at the Gates."

HONG KONG, March 8 -The Government of Communist China has begun to loosen its highly centralized control over the country's financial operations. The provinces are being allowed to have more funds of their own, along with increased authority over expenditures.

Edgar Hoover bases this informal study of American Communists and American communism is that the Communist party within the United States is a clear and present danger to us today. AN old hand at depicting Rocky Mountain trappers of the Eighteen Thirties, Bill Gulick has packed this novel with just about everything that ever happened in the dear old Green River rendezvous days. His hero, Clint Davidson (shy, proud and tough), works for Captain Bonneville who plots to eliminate the Hudson's Bay Company and to prepare Oregon for American occupation.

" THE NUN'S STORY," currently being filmed, in color, in the Belgian Congo (see photo below) indicates that while our wide, wide world is growing smaller and smaller, some of the problems that plagued Stanley and Livingston still exist.

ED SULLIVAN has solved the problem for persons who have neither the time, money nor get-upand-go inclination to attend the Brussels World's Fair. Next month Mr. Sullivan, weighted down with three and a half tons of camera and other television equipment, will take off in a chartered plane to visit the fair and bring it back -not live, but by recording -- to his video fans.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- This past winter, while other parts of the country have been buried under snowdrifts, battered by tornadoes or flooded by torrential rains, Tucson has been going happily on its way, with temperatures in the 60's and 70's during the day, falling to the 40's and sometimes the 30's at night.

SHORT HILLS, N. J., March 8 -- Work by more than 100 of the country's leading artists and sculptors will be included in the contemporary art show sponsored by the Parent Activities Committee of the Far Brook School here.

The nation's largest antiaircraft missile -- the Air Force's Bomarc -- was put on exhibit at Rockefeller Center Plaza yesterday. It will be on view there today.

Results of tests on animals suggesting that tranquilizing drugs may be used to prevent death from shock after severe injuries were described last week at the New York sectional meeting of the American College of Surgeons. " The Thirteen Clocks," an opera by Mary Johnson based on a James Thurber story of the same title, had its world premiere at Hunter College yesterday afternoon, with Thomas Scherman conducting the Little Orchestra Society. The program was last but one in the Society's 1957-58 Young People's Concerts.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- About 6.4 per cent of the 938,026 immigrants who entered the United States during the fiscal years of 1953 through 1956 were professional, technical and kindred workers, the National Science Foundation disclosed today.
